Title: White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer's Statements on Flynn's Russia Contacts Proven False

Article:

Sean Spicer, the press secretary for President Donald Trump, held his first briefing in the Brady Room on the first official workday of Trump's presidency. Less than 24 hours after Trump's swearing-in, Spicer was sent to attack the media for its depiction of the inaugural crowd size, a critique that was later dubbed "alternative facts" by Kellyanne Conway. By Monday, Spicer had settled into a more defensive stance, addressing questions about Trump's national security adviser, Mike Flynn, and his contacts with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

Spicer initially stated that Flynn had made only one call to Kislyak, which dealt with four subjects: a plane crash, Christmas, a conference about ISIS, and setting up a call between Trump and Vladimir Putin. However, this assertion was later proven false. The Washington Post reported that Flynn had allegedly discussed U.S.-imposed sanctions on Russia with Kislyak, and had misled the White House about the nature of their conversation. Flynn resigned on February 13.

Less than three weeks later, the second part of Spicer's assertion was also disproven. The White House confirmed that Flynn had met with Kislyak alongside Jared Kushner, the president's senior adviser and son-in-law, in December. The meeting was first reported by The New York Times and confirmed by The Hive. A White House official explained that Spicer was not aware of the meeting with Kushner, Flynn, and Kislyak because Kushner had met with dozens of foreign officials throughout the transition.

This has become a common line of defense in the White House, as aides struggle to explain when various members of Trump's inner circle met with Kislyak, what they discussed, and why. While Flynn resigned as a result of his lack of transparency about his meeting with Kislyak, it remains unclear why he was so unforthcoming, or why those within the Trump administration who were aware of Flynn's misdirection chose to conceal that information from others, including Vice President Mike Pence. It is also unclear who knew that Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who recused himself from any investigations pertaining to Russia and the Trump campaign, had met with Kislyak during election season.

Title: Army to Decide Fate of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, Who Completed Active Duty Commitment

The Army is faced with a decision regarding the fate of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who has completed his active duty commitment. According to legal expert Charles Gittins, Bergdahl can either receive an honorable discharge or face a court-martial. The Army would need to pursue criminal charges to seek an other-than-honorable discharge.

Bergdahl's case has been under investigation since he walked off his base in Afghanistan in June 2009 and became an enemy captive until his release in May. The investigation, led by Maj. Gen. Kenneth Dahl, has concluded, and the report has been submitted to the Army Secretary John McHugh. A source familiar with the probe stated that Bergdahl has denied desertion and provided an explanation for his actions.

Bergdahl is currently assigned to the company headquarters at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, where he was interviewed by Gen. Dahl and his attorney, Eugene Fidell. Fidell described Bergdahl as having answered every question put to him and expressed admiration for Gen. Dahl.

The investigation's findings have significant implications beyond Bergdahl's fate. A court-martial finding of desertion could bolster the argument that President Obama endangered troops in Afghanistan for the benefit of a deserter. The president announced Bergdahl's release with great fanfare, bringing his parents to the White House for a joint appearance. National Security Adviser Susan Rice described Bergdahl as having served the United States with honor and distinction.

However, Bergdahl's former comrades have criticized him for abandoning his post, leading to a search that put lives at risk. A medic from his platoon, Joshua Cornelison, stated that Bergdahl's actions put everyone in danger. The investigation found that Bergdahl was abused while a captive for nearly five years, but he tried to escape and withstood the abuse.

The Pentagon has denied allegations of a ransom payment for Bergdahl's release, and the Defense Department inspector general has been asked to investigate. The Army will decide Bergdahl's fate, and the investigation's report may be made public at a later time.

Title: Congresswoman Tlaib's Facial Recognition Comments Spark Controversy

Article:

Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) recently visited the "Real-Time Crime" center in Detroit, which uses facial recognition technology to monitor the city. During the tour, Tlaib expressed concerns about the technology's accuracy, citing studies and peer-reviewed research. Specifically, she noted that the city's crime analysts are predominantly white, and that this could lead to biases in the system.

Tlaib stated that analysts should be African Americans, as they are more likely to understand the nuances of facial recognition technology and its limitations. She also referenced studies that show facial recognition algorithms are more likely to misidentify black faces, with the U.S. government's own tests revealing a 5-10 times higher error rate for black faces compared to white faces.

The Detroit Police Chief, James Craig, condemned Tlaib's remarks, calling them "insulting" and "a slap in the face" to the crime center's diverse group of analysts. Many critics and conservatives also criticized Tlaib's comments, labeling them as "reverse racism."

However, the article notes that numerous studies have shown that facial recognition technology is flawed and prone to biases, with researchers at MIT noting that the technology learns from human programmers, who are predominantly white and male. The article also references studies that demonstrate the "cross-race effect," where people are more likely to misidentify faces from a different racial group.

While Tlaib has repeatedly cited scientific studies to support her concerns, critics have not provided evidence to support their claims. The article concludes by noting that the scientific consensus on facial recognition technology's limitations is clear, but some individuals may choose to ignore or dismiss this evidence.

Title: Trump Faces Legal Challenges Over Emergency Declaration to Fund Border Wall

President Donald Trump has faced legal challenges to his decision to declare a national emergency to secure funding for a border wall along the US-Mexico border. The move, which bypasses Congress, has been met with opposition from Democrats and some Republicans, who argue it is a "gross abuse of power."

California and New York have announced plans to take legal action to challenge the emergency declaration, with New York's Democratic Attorney General Letitia James stating the state will "fight back with every legal tool at our disposal." The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has also announced plans to file a lawsuit to curb what it calls "this blatantly illegal executive action."

The declaration would allow Trump to access billions of dollars to fund the wall, which was a key campaign promise. However, the move has been met with skepticism, with some Republicans expressing concerns about the constitutionality of the move.

The National Emergencies Act, which allows the president to declare an emergency and access special powers, has been used by previous presidents to address foreign policy crises, not domestic issues like border security. The act also contains a clause that allows Congress to terminate the emergency status if both houses vote for it and the president does not veto it.

The move has also raised concerns about the potential impact on military projects, with some projects potentially being cancelled to fund the wall. A congressional aide told ABC News that projects that could be affected include constructions at Guantanamo Bay, a military school in Japan, and special forces facilities in North Carolina.

Trump officials have defended the move, with Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney stating that the president is "confronting the national security crisis on our southern border." However, the move has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some Republicans expressing concerns about the constitutionality of the move and the potential impact on military projects.

The controversy surrounding the emergency declaration is likely to continue, with the courts and Congress set to play a key role in determining the fate of the plan.

Title: Pakistan's Journalists Struggle with COVID-19 Infections Amid Eased Lockdown

Pakistan's media industry is grappling with a growing number of COVID-19 infections among journalists, with at least 54 cases reported across the country, according to data from the Freedom Network rights group. The surge in cases has raised concerns about the effectiveness of guidelines and protocols implemented by news organizations to protect their staff.

The data shows that journalists, technical staff, and media assistants are particularly vulnerable to infection due to their close proximity to each other in newsrooms and bureaus. The situation is exacerbated by the recent easing of lockdown measures, which has led to an increase in public gatherings and interactions.

Several journalists have shared their experiences of contracting the virus, including Salman Ashraf, a reporter for Geo News in Quetta, who described feeling unwell and dizzy after working in the office. Ashraf was one of seven people to test positive for the virus in his organization's Quetta bureau.

The data highlights a pattern of clusters of coronavirus cases in newsrooms and bureaus across the country, where journalists, technical staff, and media assistants often work in close proximity to each other. The situation is concerning, as Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan's government has insisted that a full lockdown is not economically sustainable for the country.

Journalists have expressed concerns about the lack of enforcement of guidelines and protocols, with some reporting that they are not being taken seriously. A journalist in Quetta, who wished to remain anonymous, said that guidelines were in place but were not being followed by many journalists.

The International Monetary Fund has estimated that Pakistan's economy will contract by 1.5 percent due to the coronavirus-related lockdowns, close to the worst such figures since the country gained independence in 1947. The government has insisted that industries must follow government-mandated standard operating procedures to keep workers safe, or face being closed down again.

The situation highlights the challenges faced by journalists in Pakistan, where competition in the news media landscape is cut-throat, with over 30 24-hour television news channels competing with each other for ratings, in addition to dozens of national and regional newspapers.

Title: Retired Gen. John Allen to Lead International Coalition Against ISIS

Retired four-star Marine General John Allen, who previously commanded American forces in Afghanistan, has been appointed to coordinate the international coalition against ISIS, announced Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday. Allen's new role marks a return to a challenging mission, as he has experience in coordinating military efforts in the region.

Allen's military career spans many years, including being one of the top commanders in western Iraq during the "Sunni Awakening" program, which aimed to turn Sunni tribes against al-Qaeda in Iraq. The militant organization, now swallowing parts of Syria and Iraq, is the successor to the original al-Qaeda group.

Before his command in Afghanistan, Allen was the deputy commander at U.S. Central Command, overseeing all military operations in the Middle East. He is a decorated veteran of the armed forces, having received several awards, including the Defense Distinguished Service Medal and the Defense Superior Service Medal.

Allen was briefly caught up in the 2012 scandal involving former CIA Director David Petraeus' infidelity, but the Defense Department cleared him of any wrongdoing. He retired from the Marines in 2013.

In his previous role, Allen developed a security plan for Israel and the West Bank during Israeli-Palestinian negotiations, which ultimately collapsed. He graduated with honors from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1976 and holds master's degrees from Georgetown University, the Defense Intelligence College, and the National War College.

Title: Defense Department Orders Most Furloughed Civilian Employees Back to Work Amid Ongoing Government Shutdown

The second week of the government shutdown has begun, with no signs of a resolution in sight. Despite the impasse, the Department of Defense has announced that most of its furloughed civilian employees will return to work on Monday. This decision affects approximately 400,000 workers, according to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel. The move is a result of the "Pay Our Military Act," legislation passed by Congress and signed by President Obama last week.

The law does not permit a blanket recall of all civilians, but it can be used to bring back workers who support service personnel. Hagel emphasized that the law does not provide a solution to the broader shutdown, stating, "There were no signs of serious negotiations over the weekend, and the longer the standoff drags on, the more likely the fight will bump up against the October 17 deadline to raise the debt ceiling, setting the stage for a giant battle over fiscal policy in the coming weeks."

Meanwhile, lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have continued to engage in partisan rhetoric, with more than a dozen lawmakers appearing on Sunday news shows to argue about which side is being unreasonable. The Washington Post has provided a guide to the "losers and not-quite losers" in the shutdown, noting that Republican governors with White House ambitions are faring better than their congressional counterparts. The article suggests that the shutdown and subsequent name-calling have provided evidence that all of Washington is broken and that a problem-solver from outside the Beltway is the only answer.

Title: Obama's Shift on Keystone XL Pipeline Jobs: A Change in Tone

The article reports on President Obama's recent comments about the Keystone XL oil pipeline project, which have sparked controversy and criticism from Republican lawmakers. In a speech in Chattanooga, Tennessee, Obama expressed skepticism about the project's job creation potential, stating that it would create only about 50 permanent jobs and calling it "not a jobs plan." This stance is a significant departure from his previous enthusiasm for construction jobs during his first term, when he emphasized the importance of infrastructure projects to stimulate economic growth.

During his first term, Obama highlighted the value of construction jobs, citing the need for infrastructure projects to create jobs and stimulate economic growth. He even held an event at the Key Bridge in Georgetown to call on Congress to approve more temporary stimulus spending on infrastructure projects to help unemployed construction workers. However, his recent comments suggest a shift in his stance on the Keystone XL pipeline project, which he now views as a limited job creator.

Obama's top aides have defended his comments, stating that the president is not disparaging the value of construction jobs but rather emphasizing the need for a comprehensive jobs strategy. They argue that the Keystone XL pipeline project is not a comprehensive solution to the nation's employment issues and that the president is calling on Republicans to present a more comprehensive jobs plan.

Republican lawmakers, on the other hand, have criticized Obama's comments, accusing him of trying to kill the pipeline project and dismissing the thousands of jobs it would create. They argue that the project would generate thousands of construction jobs and support additional jobs in related industries.

The State Department has estimated that the pipeline project would create 5,000 to 6,000 construction jobs per year, while TransCanada Corp., the company building the pipeline, has said it would generate about 13,000 jobs over two years. The State Department also estimates that the project could support another 42,000 jobs per year for two years across the U.S. in related industries.

Overall, Obama's comments on the Keystone XL pipeline project have sparked a heated debate about the project's job creation potential and the president's stance on infrastructure projects.

Title: Trump Endorses House Speaker Paul Ryan, Ending Days of Hesitation

Article:

In a move that sent shockwaves through the Republican Party, presidential nominee Donald Trump announced his endorsement of House Speaker Paul D. Ryan on Friday. Trump's decision to back the party's most powerful elected leader came after days of hesitation, during which he had refused to publicly support Ryan in his primary race against anti-establishment candidate Paul Nehlen.

At a campaign rally in Ryan's home state of Wisconsin, Trump praised the speaker as a "good man" and emphasized their shared goal of making America great again. The endorsement sent a clear message that Trump is willing to work with the Republican Party establishment, which had opposed his candidacy. However, it also sparked outrage among some conservative voters who view Ryan as a "RINO" (Republican in Name Only) and had been hoping Trump would support a more anti-establishment candidate.

Trump had previously withheld his endorsement in Ryan's primary race, saying he was "not there yet" in backing the speaker. Ryan had also resisted endorsing Trump, echoing his earlier comments. At the rally, Trump cited Ronald Reagan's philosophy that an 80% ally is not a 20% enemy, stating that while they may disagree on some issues, they mostly agree and will work together to achieve their goals.

In addition to endorsing Ryan, Trump also announced support for Senate Republican incumbents John McCain and Kelly Ayotte, who have been hesitant to back him. The endorsements were met with shock and disappointment from some of Trump's die-hard supporters, who felt betrayed by his decision to back the party establishment.

Trump's decision to endorse Ryan has sparked controversy among some conservative voters who had been hoping for a more anti-establishment candidate. Paul Nehlen, Trump's primary opponent, understood the decision, stating that Trump's refusal to endorse Ryan earlier sent a clear signal to Wisconsin voters that Ryan is not his preferred candidate. Nehlen also emphasized that Ryan's globalist agenda opposes the will of the Republican electorate, who want safe communities, immigration control, and leaders who put the needs of the American people first.

The Remington Research Group poll released on Friday showed Ryan leading Nehlen 80% to 14% in the Janesville district.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Rule to Limit Food Stamp Benefits, Sparking Controversy

The Trump administration has unveiled a proposal to eliminate a loophole in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which could affect up to 3.1 million recipients. The rule aims to eliminate benefits for families solely because they are enrolled in food assistance programs run by their states. USDA officials claim this change will save billions in taxpayer funds and "fix a loophole" that allows households to receive assistance when they don't need it.

Under the proposed rule, recipients who lose their benefits could reapply and qualify if they meet federal standards for assistance. USDA officials argue that the change will make the program more efficient and fair, while critics argue it will make it harder for families to work their way out of poverty.

The proposal has been met with strong opposition from anti-poverty advocates, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who called it an "act of staggering callousness." Other critics, such as Joel Berg, CEO of Hunger Free America, argue that the rule will make working Americans hungrier and harder for families to escape poverty.

Conservatives have long considered the food stamp program an example of government waste that needs to be made more efficient. The administration has also proposed tightening work requirements for SNAP recipients, restricting states from exempting work-eligible adults from receiving food stamps if they're not seeking employment.

The proposal is now awaiting review and potential approval from Congress.

**House Republicans Disrupt Impeachment Inquiry, Prevent Pentagon Official from Testifying**

Washington (D.C.) - In a dramatic confrontation, Republican lawmakers, encouraged by President Donald Trump to be more aggressive in fighting the impeachment inquiry, stormed a hearing room and prevented a Pentagon official from testifying on Wednesday. The move is part of an escalating probe that threatens Trump's presidency as he seeks re-election next year.

The impeachment inquiry focuses on Trump's request for Ukraine to investigate a domestic rival, Democrat Joe Biden, for his personal political benefit. The inquiry is led by the Democratic-led House and has been criticized by Republicans as unfair.

Laura Cooper, the U.S. defense official who oversees Ukraine and Russia matters, was due to testify behind closed doors when Republicans stormed the hearing room, yelling and preventing her from testifying. Capitol police were called in to clear the room and restore order.

The Republicans' actions are seen as an attempt to intimidate witnesses and disrupt the investigation. Democratic Representative Ted Lieu said, "They're freaked out. They're trying to stop this investigation. They don't want to hear from witness Cooper today. They know more facts are going to be delivered which are absolutely damning to the president of the United States."

The impeachment inquiry could lead to the House passing formal charges known as articles of impeachment, prompting a trial in the Republican-controlled Senate on whether to remove Trump from office.

Title: US Senator Bernie Sanders Calls for Unprecedented Measures to Combat COVID-19 Pandemic

Article: US Senator Bernie Sanders, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, has emphasized the need for the country to take unprecedented measures to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. In a recent commentary, Sanders highlighted the importance of prioritizing the guidance of doctors, scientists, and researchers in responding to the crisis.

According to Sanders, the country must increase the availability of coronavirus test kits, accelerate the processing of tests, build out more intensive care units, and obtain additional ventilators. He also emphasized the need for improved communication and collaboration with other countries to learn more about the novel coronavirus.

Sanders also touched on the long-term implications of the pandemic, stating that it is essential to remember how the country arrived at this moment of crisis and take steps to ensure better preparedness for future emergencies. He emphasized the need for a comprehensive healthcare system that guarantees healthcare to all Americans as a human right, not a privilege.

The senator also highlighted the importance of paid family and medical leave, stating that thousands of workers may be ill and should be staying home but continue to go to work to earn wages. He emphasized that people should not be going to work when they are sick, as it is unfair to them and those they interact with.

Sanders also criticized the country's trade policies, stating that outsourcing millions of jobs and factories overseas has gutted the economy and left the country dependent on other countries for essential goods. He emphasized the need for fair trade policies that bring production and manufacturing back to the United States.

The senator concluded that the days ahead will be difficult and challenging, but it is essential to put in place policies that transform the country for the better.

Title: Virginia Governor's Election: Democrat Ralph Northam Wins, Defeating Republican Ed Gillespie

The election for Virginia governor took place on Tuesday, with Democrat Ralph Northam emerging victorious over Republican Ed Gillespie. The outcome was seen as a significant setback for President Donald Trump, who had endorsed Gillespie but did not campaign with him. Trump had taken a break from his Asia trip to send tweets and record messages supporting Gillespie, but after the outcome, he distanced himself from the Republican candidate.

Northam, the state's lieutenant governor, overcame a barrage of attack ads by Gillespie that targeted him on divisive issues such as immigration, gang crime, and Confederate statues. Despite this, Northam's campaign focused on issues like education, healthcare, and the economy, which resonated with voters in the Democratic-leaning northern Virginia suburbs.

The election results showed Northam winning with a decisive margin, receiving 53% of the vote compared to Gillespie's 45%. Exit polls revealed that one-third of voters went to the polls to oppose Trump, while only 17% supported him. The strong turnout in the Democratic-leaning suburbs helped propel Northam to victory.

The outcome of the election sent a message to the country, with Northam stating that Virginia has told the nation to end divisiveness, condemn hatred and bigotry, and reject the politics that have torn the country apart. The election also saw Democrats sweep the other top statewide races, winning the offices of lieutenant governor and attorney general, and gaining seats in the Virginia House of Delegates.

In a surprise upset, Democrat Danica Roem became the first transgender person to win a state legislative race, defeating a long-time Republican incumbent. The election results provided a much-needed boost for national Democrats, who had been struggling to turn grassroots resistance to Trump into election victories.

The election also saw Democratic victories in local races across the country, with Mayor Bill de Blasio in New York and Marty Walsh in Boston easily winning re-election.

Title: Trump Administration Re-Imposes Sanctions on Iran, Carves Out Exemptions for Eight Countries

The Trump administration has re-imposed sanctions on Iran, effective Monday, covering the country's shipping, financial, and energy sectors. The sanctions are the second batch to be re-imposed since President Trump withdrew from the 2015 nuclear deal in May. The deal, negotiated by former President Obama, lifted sanctions on Iran in exchange for curbs on its nuclear program.

The new sanctions will hit Iranians hard, with the Iranian currency losing half its value since April. The government has taken measures to ensure basic services like trash collection are working normally and kept gas prices low at about 90 cents a gallon. However, prices in general have skyrocketed, with many Iranians worried about the new sanctions.

The sanctions will also affect countries that do not stop importing Iranian oil and foreign firms that do business with blacklisted Iranian entities, including its central bank, private financial institutions, and state-run port and shipping firms. The sanctions will not apply to eight countries that have been granted temporary waivers, including the United States' allies Turkey, Italy, India, Japan, and South Korea.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the sanctions are aimed at "fundamentally altering the behavior of the Islamic Republic of Iran." He has issued a list of 12 demands that Iran must meet to get the sanctions lifted, including an end to its support for terrorism and military engagement in Syria, as well as a halt to nuclear and ballistic missile development.

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the country is the "victorious party" after nearly 40 years of confrontation with the United States. He said the U.S. has failed to dominate Iran in the way it did before the 1979 Islamic Revolution that ousted a pro-Western monarchy.

Title: The Weinstein Company Requests Removal of Interviews from "Fed Up" Documentary, Claiming Deceptive Editing

The Weinstein Company, the distributor of the 2014 documentary "Fed Up," has requested that two interviews be removed from YouTube, citing allegations of deceptive editing. The interviews in question feature Dr. David Allison and Lisa Gable, who are critical of the documentary's production methods.

According to YouTube documentation, the takedown request was made by the Weinstein Company and classified as "manually detected." However, the Free Beacon, which originally published the interviews, has filed a counter-notification with YouTube, arguing that the videos are protected by fair use grounds as they are part of a news report.

The videos themselves show Dr. Allison struggling to answer a question and then pausing before the film cuts to another interview, with the answer to the question never being shown. Dr. Allison claims that he did provide an answer and that Katie Couric assured him he could pause to rework his answers if needed. He described the experience as "antithetical to human decency and civility" and "antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue."

The second video features an interview with Lisa Gable, a former spokesperson for the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation. Industry sources claim that the audio of the interview was manipulated to embarrass Gable. An audio clip shows an off-camera interviewer saying she didn't believe Gable was answering her questions, but sources say this did not occur at the moment it was portrayed in the film. "That response from the producer didn't actually follow that particular exchange and was edited to make it look like that was how their conversation actually went," a source said.

The Weinstein Company has not responded to a request for comment.

Title: Trump Administration Revokes Policy Requiring Disclosure of Civilian Drone Strike Casualties

The Trump administration has revoked a policy requiring the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) to publish the number of civilians killed in drone strikes outside of war zones. The policy was introduced by former President Barack Obama in 2016, in response to pressure to increase transparency.

The Obama-era executive order required the CIA to release annual summaries of US drone strikes and assess the number of civilians killed as a result. However, the Trump administration deemed the requirement "superfluous" and distracting, stating that it does not improve government transparency but rather takes away from intelligence professionals' primary mission.

The CIA has carried out drone strikes in countries such as Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Somalia since the 9/11 terror attack. According to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism, a UK-based think tank, there have been 2,243 drone strikes in the first two years of the Trump presidency, compared to 1,878 during Obama's eight years in office.

Human rights activists have criticized the drone program under both administrations, citing concerns over secrecy and civilian casualties. While Obama's administration released data on civilians killed in strikes outside of war zones, Trump's administration has made some operations more secretive.

Lawmakers and rights groups have criticized Trump's decision, saying it could allow the CIA to conduct drone strikes without accountability. Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat who chairs Congress's intelligence committee, called the requirement issued by Obama "an important measure of transparency" and said there is "no justification" for canceling it.

The Trump administration's decision does not affect reporting requirements on civilian deaths set by Congress for the military.

Title: Nike's 30th Anniversary "Just Do It" Campaign Features Colin Kaepernick

Nike has launched its 30th anniversary "Just Do It" campaign, featuring Colin Kaepernick, the unemployed quarterback who has been at the center of controversy due to his kneeling protest against police brutality. The campaign kicked off with a close-up of Kaepernick's face and the words "Believe in something. Even if it means sacrificing everything."

The reaction was swift, with Nike's stock falling 3% and other athletic shoe companies experiencing similar dips. The #NikeBoycott hashtag trended on Twitter, with reports of Nike gear-burning and protests emerging. The NFL season is set to kick off on Thursday night, and Nike and the NFL are partners, with the league signing a billion-dollar extension of their deal through 2028.

Kaepernick's grievance against the NFL for colluding to deny him employment received a significant boost when an arbitrator denied the NFL's request for dismissal. A portion of the money Nike pays the league for sponsorship could wind up in Kaepernick's pocket.

Nike plans to sell Kaepernick-branded shoes and sportswear, as well as back up the initial "Believe" ad with billboards, TV commercials, and online ads. A billboard of the first Kaepernick ad went up near Niketown at Union Square on Tuesday.

The NFL has released a statement, saying it believes in dialogue, understanding, and unity, and embracing the role and responsibility of everyone involved with the game to promote meaningful, positive change in their communities. The social justice issues raised by Kaepernick and other professional athletes deserve attention and action.

The controversy surrounding Kaepernick's cause has sparked a heated debate, with 54% of Americans feeling the NFL protests are "inappropriate" and 43% believing they are "appropriate." The NFL is caught in a difficult position, as it risks alienating half its fans and players if it follows the lead of President Trump, Cowboys owner Jerry Jones, and a majority of Americans.

Title: Comedian Kicked Off Stage at Columbia University Event for Homophobic and Racist Jokes

Comedian Nimesh Patel was removed from the stage at Columbia University's "cultureSHOCK: Reclaim" event after 30 minutes into his set, allegedly due to jokes deemed homophobic and racist. The event, hosted by the Asian American Alliance (AAA), aimed to provide a platform for Asian-American artistic expression and challenge harmful stereotypes.

According to the Columbia Daily Spectator, Patel's performance included commentary on his experience living in a diverse area of New York City, including a joke about a gay black man in his neighborhood, which AAA officials deemed inappropriate. Patel quipped that being gay cannot be a choice, stating that "no one looks in the mirror and thinks, 'This black thing is too easy; let me just add another thing to it.'" Members of AAA interrupted the performance, denouncing his material about racial identities and sexual orientation, and gave him a few moments for closing remarks. Patel claimed that his jokes were not offensive and were simply exposing the audience to ideas found in the real world. His microphone was cut off, and he exited the stage.

The AAA defended its decision to remove Patel, stating that his remarks ran counter to the inclusive spirit and integrity of the event. The group acknowledged that discomfort and safety can coexist, but deemed the discomfort caused by Patel's jokes unproductive in the space. AAA apologized for inviting Patel in the first place.

Audience members were reportedly divided over the decision to remove Patel. The 32-year-old comedian, who was the first Indian-American writer for Saturday Night Live, has not commented on the event.

Title: Trump Trails Democrats in Hypothetical 2020 Election Polls, but Experts Caution Against Reading Too Much into Results

Article:

Recent polls have shown President Donald Trump trailing most Democratic candidates in hypothetical 2020 general election matchups, both nationally and in individual states, including Texas. While this may be a cause for celebration among Democrats, experts warn against reading too much into the results, citing the unpredictability of elections and the importance of name recognition.

The polls, conducted by Latino Decisions, North Star Opinion Research, and the University of Houston, found Trump lagging behind Democratic candidates such as Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Kamala Harris in Texas. Similarly, a Washington Post and ABC News poll found Trump struggling to reach 45% against any of his potential Democratic opponents nationally.

While some may interpret these results as a sign of Trump's weakness, experts caution that too much can happen between now and the election, and that name recognition plays a significant role in these polls. For example, Biden and Sanders have higher name recognition among Democratic voters, which may contribute to their stronger showings.

The real story, according to experts, is Trump's low approval ratings and his inability to win over voters who dislike him. Trump's approval ratings have consistently been low throughout his first two years in office, and his recent uptick has been short-lived. This is particularly concerning given the strong economy, which is typically a key driver of presidential approval.

Trump's reliance on voters who dislike both him and his opponents may not be enough to secure his re-election, as he did in 2016. Instead, he needs to win over voters who are undecided or leaning towards his opponents. With his low approval ratings and poor showing in hypothetical head-to-head matchups, Trump's path to victory appears increasingly narrow.

In conclusion, while the recent polls may be a cause for concern for Trump, they also highlight the unpredictability of elections and the importance of name recognition. As the election approaches, Trump will need to find a way to win over voters and improve his approval ratings if he hopes to secure a second term.

Title: Congressman Urges FBI to Focus on Muslim Community in Boston Bombing Investigation

Article:

A leading Republican congressman, Rep. Peter T. King, has called on the FBI to focus on the Muslim community in its investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings. During an interview on "Fox News Sunday," King stated that "ninety-nine percent of Muslims are outstanding Americans, but the fact is, that's where the threat is coming from." He emphasized that the terrorists' strategy has changed since the 9/11 attacks, with individuals like the suspected Boston bombers, Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, being used to carry out attacks.

King criticized the FBI for failing to catch the two men before they carried out the bombings, which killed three and wounded over 160 people. The FBI had previously interviewed Tamerlan Tsarnaev, but found no links to terrorism.

The Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center released a statement expressing anger and disappointment over the fact that the suspects had been known to the community, including local schools, a boxing club, and a mosque. The statement noted that despite being aware of the suspects, no one was able to predict their actions.

It is worth noting that the FBI has not publicly confirmed any specific information about the suspects' motivations or connections to the Muslim community. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are still working to determine the exact motives behind the bombings.

Title: GlaxoSmithKline Starts Mass Production of Ebola Vaccine Despite Limited Human Testing

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing Ebola epidemic in West Africa, pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has announced it will begin mass production of a vaccine that has only just begun being tested in humans. This decision comes after the World Health Organization (WHO) deemed it ethical to try unproven and experimental treatments on people in this public health emergency.

The process of getting a drug or vaccine to market typically involves three phases of clinical trials in humans. Before testing in humans, researchers must provide promising data from animal studies to the FDA and receive approval to start recruiting patients. This "pre-clinical" phase can take several years, and for every 5,000 compounds discovered, only about five are allowed to be tried in humans.

If a drug or vaccine makes it to the first phase of human testing, researchers must find hundreds and thousands of volunteers to participate in clinical trials. The first phase involves testing for safety in a small group of healthy people to ensure the drug is not making anyone sick or worse. The second phase involves testing the treatment's effectiveness in a larger group of participants, comparing it to the best-available therapies or a placebo. The third phase involves an even larger group and careful analysis of safety data.

The entire drug development process typically takes 12 years and costs between $100 million and $1 billion. Only one in five therapies make it to the final phase, and it usually takes the FDA a couple of years to consider the data and bring the drug to market, if it chooses.

GSK is already manufacturing an Ebola vaccine with promising animal studies behind it, but it has not been fully tested in humans. The company has stockpiled 10,000 doses, but it is still in the early stages of development. When asked about the timeline, company representatives explained that the normal pathway for bringing a vaccine to market takes 10 years, and they are already three years into the process. However, they were unclear on what would happen after a successful phase one trial and how much longer it would take to scale-up manufacturing and get the vaccine approved for use in people.

While there is a chance that the usual process might be condensed or phases of clinical testing skipped due to the urgency of the situation, developing safe and effective therapies takes time, and unfortunately, most end in failure. The Ebola vaccine is currently in phase one, and if the data look promising, regulators will need to find ways to expedite the process to prevent another Ebola epidemic.

Title: Trump's Forceful yet Compassionate Speech at Brett Kavanaugh's Swearing-in and the State of American Politics

The recent swearing-in of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court was marked by a forceful yet compassionate speech from President Trump. The president opened with an apology to Kavanaugh and his family for the "terrible pain and suffering" they endured during the confirmation process, emphasizing the importance of the "presumption of innocence." Trump also tenderly addressed Kavanaugh's young daughters, praising their father as a "great man, a man of decency, character, kindness, and courage."

The event was a significant moment in American politics, with the president aiming to restore dignity to the judiciary at a time when the court has been mired in controversy. The ceremony was attended by eight other Supreme Court justices, as well as Republican Senators Mitch McConnell, Charles Grassley, Lindsey Graham, and Susan Collins.

The speech was a departure from Trump's usual tone, with the president acknowledging the pain and suffering inflicted on Kavanaugh and his family. However, the event was also seen as a "spike-the-football" moment for the president, with Trump aiming to capitalize on the political momentum.

The article also touches on the broader implications of the Kavanaugh confirmation process, with the author noting that the "ideas that the court is just another political branch and that the presumption of innocence no longer applies if you are on the other team represent a seismic shift in how we look at each other and the nation as a whole." The author warns that if these ideas stick, the consequences could be severe.

The article also critiques a recent statement made by Hillary Clinton, who declared that "you can't be civil with a political party that wants to destroy what you stand for, what you care about." The author argues that Clinton's statement is "reckless" and "stoking trouble," and that it is an admission that the ends justify the means.

The article concludes by highlighting a recent decision by the City of New York to allow individuals to choose their gender on their birth certificate, with the author expressing concerns about the potential impact on society and the priorities of the mayor and City Council.

Title: Project Veritas Releases Undercover Footage Alleging Rose City Antifa Promotes Violence and Combat Techniques

Article:

Project Veritas, an investigative journalist group led by James O'Keefe, has released undercover footage claiming to show the secretive Rose City Antifa (RCA) group in Portland, Oregon, promoting violence and teaching combat techniques. The footage was released on Thursday morning and appears to show an unnamed individual infiltrating RCA meetings, capturing conversations and activities.

In the footage, a man identified as Nicholas Cifuni advises RCA members to hide their weapons from the police, stating, "Don't be that fucking guy with the goddamn spike brass knuckles getting photos taken of you." He also discusses the importance of secrecy, saying, "Police are going to be like, 'Perfect, we can prosecute these fuckers, look how violent they are,' and not that we aren't, but we need to fucking hide that shit."

The infiltrator, wearing a hoodie, ski mask, and sunglasses to protect his identity, describes the process of becoming a member of Antifa, stating he was a "prospect" for the group. He notes that RCA enforced strict security measures, such as placing phones in a neighboring bathroom with a fan to muffle sounds during meetings to prevent surveillance.

The footage also shows the group's alleged founder, Caroline Victorin, who previously lived in Sweden with her Swedish husband. Records indicate the couple moved to the United States in 2017, following a 2015 GoFundMe fundraiser to procure funds for Caroline's husband's green card.

Sweden has a significant Antifa scene, with a Swedish Defence Research Institute (FOI) report detailing the extent of the movement and linking it to the Swedish "anti-hate" group, the Expo Foundation, and the UK anti-hate group Hope not Hate. Both groups have received funding from Hungarian-American left-wing billionaire George Soros through his Open Society Foundation.

Rose City Antifa has gained notoriety as one of the most violent Antifa cells in the United States, with journalist Andy Ngo being brutally beaten by the group during a protest last year, resulting in a brain bleed. President Donald Trump announced plans to designate Antifa as a terrorist organization in May 2020.

In November 2019, Gage Halupowski pleaded guilty to second-degree assault with an expandable baton and was sentenced to six years in prison, after attacking Adam Kelly, who suffered a concussion and required 25 staples to his head.

As the ongoing riots in Minneapolis and other cities have been linked to Antifa militants, RCA has been active in Portland, allegedly involved in a May 30 attack on a man carrying an American flag during an anti-police brutality protest, with the attackers shouting, "Black lives matter, faggot," as they beat him.

Title: Gunman Attacks Capital Gazette Office, Killing Five and Injuring Two

The Capital Gazette newspaper in Maryland published its Friday edition despite a gunman killing five people and injuring two others at its office on Thursday. The shooter, identified as Jarrod Ramos, was arrested and charged with five counts of first-degree murder. Ramos had previously sued the newspaper group in 2012 for defamation.

According to reports, the gunman fired through a glass door into the newsroom with a shotgun, shooting at staff members. Journalists inside the building posted on social media as the attack unfolded, with one intern, Anthony Messenger, tweeting that the attacker opened fire. Staff members hid under their desks, with crime reporter Phil Davis describing the scene as "like a war zone."

The suspect was found hiding under a desk when police arrived, with no exchange of fire reported. The police safely evacuated 170 people from the building, which housed 30 other businesses. An item believed to be an explosive device was found and destroyed, later revealed to be a smoke bomb.

The Committee to Protect Journalists tweeted that before the Maryland shooting, seven journalists had been killed in the US in relation to their work since 1992. The Gazette had previously written an article in 2011 about a woman who said Jarrod Ramos was stalking her, and he had failed in his attempts to sue the paper for defamation the following year.

Ramos is scheduled for a bail hearing on Friday morning in Annapolis. Federal agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, were involved in the response to the attack. Maryland Governor Larry Hogan and President Donald Trump offered condolences to the victims and their families. The New York City Police Department deployed counterterrorism teams to media organizations in and around New York City as a precaution.

Title: President Trump Delivers Unifying Speech to Congress, Emphasizes American Unity and Leadership

President Donald Trump delivered his first joint address to Congress on Tuesday, setting out to unify a divided nation and inspire the future. The speech focused on themes of American unity, leadership, and the importance of education and healthcare. Trump emphasized the need for the country to come together, stating, "We are one people with one destiny. We all bleed the same blood. We all salute the same great American flag, and we are all made by the same God."

The president highlighted several key issues, including the need to address hate and evil in all its forms, the importance of education, and the need to get tough on illegal immigration. He also recognized the sacrifices of fallen service members, including Senior Chief William "Ryan" Owens, who was killed in a covert raid against al-Qaeda in Yemen.

Trump's speech was met with widespread praise from congressional Republicans, who saw it as a bold and unifying message. Many Democrats, however, were more critical, citing a lack of specifics and details on key issues like healthcare and the budget.

The speech was part of a broader effort by Trump to appeal to evangelicals and Rust Belt voters who helped put him in the White House. The president's speech was delivered from the House of Representatives chamber, where he was joined by lawmakers from both parties.

In his speech, Trump called for Congress to "dream big" and "dare to make bold moves" for the nation. He also emphasized the importance of education, stating that it is the "civil rights issue of our day." The president suggested that allowing school choice will help revitalize urban regions and improve outcomes for minority youth.

The speech was followed by a Democratic response from former Kentucky Governor Steve Beshear, who criticized the president's policies and called for action on healthcare and other issues. Beshear warned that Democrats will do everything in their power to prevent the repeal of the Affordable Care Act and protect healthcare for all Americans.

Overall, Trump's speech was seen as a bold and unifying message, with many lawmakers praising his tone and language. However, Democrats were more critical, citing a lack of specifics and details on key issues.

Title: Republican Congressmen's Late-Night Swim in Sea of Galilee Sparks Controversy

A recent report by Politico has sparked controversy after it was revealed that a group of Republican congressmen, including freshman and leaders, went on a late-night swim in the Sea of Galilee during a trip to Israel last year. The report stated that Kansas Rep. Kevin Yoder was among those who went skinny-dipping, while others were clothed or partially clothed. The incident allegedly occurred after a dinner, and some participants may have been under the influence of alcohol.

According to the report, the congressmen who participated in the swim were Reps. Steve Southerland, Tom Reed, Jeff Denham, and Michael Grimm. Arizona Rep. Ben Quayle was also named as a participant, but his office and wife vehemently denied his involvement.

Quayle's spokesman, Jay Heiler, told Fox News that the congressman was not present at the beach that night and did not engage in any inappropriate behavior. Heiler also accused Quayle's GOP primary opponent, Rep. Dave Schweikert, of trying to push the story to discredit Quayle.

Schweikert, however, released a statement claiming that Quayle's behavior was "completely inappropriate" and called into question his fitness to serve in Congress. Quayle's wife, Tiffany, also denied their family's involvement in the incident, stating that they were present at the dinner but did not participate in the swim.

Kansas Rep. Kevin Yoder apologized for his actions, expressing remorse for causing embarrassment to his constituents and those who believed in him. The incident was rebuked by House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, the most senior Republican on the trip and the most senior Jewish lawmaker in Congress, last year.

Title: FBI Investigation into Florida School Shooting Raises Questions about Missed Signs

The recent massacre at a Florida high school has sparked concerns about whether the FBI missed signs that could have prevented the tragedy. A Mississippi bail bondsman and YouTube video blogger reported a comment on one of his videos that read, "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." The commenter's username was "Nikolas Cruz," the same name as the 19-year-old man accused of killing 17 people at his former high school. Although the FBI interviewed the man who reported the comment and searched public records databases, they were unable to conclusively link the account to the shooter.

The FBI's assessment of the tip was part of their standard procedure, which involves reviewing and investigating tips that may indicate potential threats. The agency receives tens of thousands of tips every year, and more than 10,000 assessments are opened. However, not all tips lead to a viable threat, and the FBI must balance national security concerns with civil liberties protections.

FBI guidelines restrict the steps agents can take during the assessment phase, limiting their ability to conduct intrusive techniques like wiretaps or internet monitoring without higher levels of approval and a solid basis to suspect a crime. The agency must weigh the potential threat against the potential harm to the individual's privacy and civil liberties.

The FBI's handling of the tip has raised questions about whether they should have done more to investigate the comment. However, experts argue that a vague, uncorroborated threat alone may not be enough to proceed to the next level of investigation. Many assessments are closed within days or weeks when the FBI concludes there is no criminal or national security threat.

The incident highlights the challenges the FBI faces in balancing national security concerns with civil liberties protections. The agency must navigate a complex web of information and prioritize its resources to ensure that true threats are identified and addressed while also respecting individual privacy and civil liberties.

Title: Putin's Just-in-Time Rescue Spares Obama Defeat, but at What Cost?

Article:

The recent Syrian crisis unfolded just as Congress was returning from its summer break, with the Class of '17 settling into college life. The young students, many on luxurious campuses with state-of-the-art facilities, are learning about the world and its complexities. However, the question remains: what do they learn? Will they absorb the important lessons of history and literature, or will they be trained to analyze and criticize arguments?

The article suggests that the liberal arts have been watered down, and few will be trained to think critically. The author notes that even a young graduate of an elite school was puzzled by the idea of a "deus ex machina," a term coined by Aristotle to describe the sudden, unexplained intervention of a god in a play. The author argues that presidents, like playwrights, should not rely on such interventions but instead find a better way out of a difficult situation.

In this case, Russian President Vladimir Putin played the role of the "deus ex machina" by intervening in the Syrian crisis, rescuing President Barack Obama from a difficult decision. The author notes that Putin's actions have given him control over the Middle East, delaying help for the rebels who had hoped for a better future. The debate on Syria is effectively over, decided by who best exploited and manipulated Secretary of State John Kerry's gaffe.

The article concludes that Putin's actions have given him a significant advantage, and the world knows who won this round. The author suggests that the president and his friends are working hard to make Obama the improbable hero, but Washington and the West cannot afford another victory like this one.

**Secret Service Director Julia Pierson Resigns Amid Security Breach Concerns**

Secret Service Director Julia Pierson resigned on Wednesday, following a security breach at the White House and other high-profile incidents that raised concerns about the safety of the president and his family. The resignation comes after a series of embarrassing disclosures about lapses in presidential security involving the Secret Service.

According to a written statement from Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson, Pierson offered her resignation, which was accepted. The White House confirmed the decision, with Press Secretary Josh Earnest stating that President Obama concluded that new leadership was required.

The resignation follows a recent incident on September 19, where an intruder jumped over the White House fence and entered the building, making it to the East Room before being apprehended. This incident was one of several embarrassing disclosures about lapses in presidential security involving the Secret Service.

Pierson's departure marks a sharp turnaround from a day earlier, when the White House voiced support for her leadership. However, she faced bipartisan calls to step down, with Representative Elijah Cummings stating that she is "not the person to lead that agency." Representative Jason Chaffetz welcomed the decision to step down and urged the president to fill the post with "new leadership from outside the Secret Service for a fresh start."

The resignation also comes after new and alarming details emerged about the September 19 intrusion, including the revelation that a security contractor armed with a gun who had previously been arrested for assault rode on an elevator with Obama and his security detail at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, violating Secret Service protocol. The president only learned about the incident on Tuesday.

A panel of independent experts will review the September 19 incident, with a report due by December 15. The panel will also advise on whether a broader review of the Secret Service is necessary. An internal review will be completed by November 1.

Pierson's resignation has been met with a mix of reactions, with some lawmakers calling for a fresh start and others expressing concerns about the impact on the agency's effectiveness.

Title: Turkey Continues Military Operation in Northern Syria Despite US Sanctions and Criticism

The Turkish government has announced its intention to press ahead with its military operation in northern Syria, despite the imposition of US sanctions and growing calls for it to cease its actions. The decision has sparked widespread criticism from both sides, with many questioning the US withdrawal of troops and Turkey's military incursion.

Critics argue that the US withdrawal has led to a power vacuum, allowing Turkey to take advantage of the situation and potentially perpetuate human rights abuses. They also point out that the US has not taken sufficient measures to mitigate the humanitarian crisis unfolding in the region.

Others have expressed concern that the US decision to impose sanctions on Turkey will not be effective in stopping the military operation, as it may take a significant amount of time for the sanctions to have an impact. They also argue that the US has a history of abandoning its allies, and that this decision will have long-term consequences for regional stability.

The US withdrawal from Syria has been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle, with some arguing that it was a mistake to abandon the region and others believing that it was a necessary step to reduce US involvement in the conflict.

The situation in northern Syria remains fluid, with the US scrambling to safely evacuate its troops and the Kurds signing on to cooperate with the Syrian government. The humanitarian crisis unfolding in the region is likely to continue, with the potential for long-term consequences for regional stability.

Title: Rand Paul Visits College Campuses to Advance Libertarian Agenda, Faces Challenges in Wooing Young Voters

Rand Paul, a Kentucky Republican and potential 2024 presidential contender, has been visiting college campuses to advance his libertarian agenda and build support among young voters. However, he faces a challenge in balancing his libertarian views with the more conservative stance of the Republican Party.

During an appearance at the College of Charleston, Paul was asked about his stance on the morning-after pill, also known as Plan B. He clarified that he is not opposed to birth control, but emphasized that Plan B is a form of birth control. This exchange highlighted the challenge Paul faces in appealing to young voters while staying within the Republican Party's boundaries.

Paul has enjoyed success on the campus circuit, with visits to universities from Harvard to Howard garnering positive headlines and support from Republicans seeking to modernize the party. He has railed against government surveillance and drug laws, which resonate with young people.

However, Paul's views on certain issues, such as same-sex marriage and drug legalization, put him at odds with many young voters. While he favors traditional marriage, he believes states should determine their own marriage laws. On drug legalization, he is not supportive, but believes drug laws should be left up to states.

Paul's comments on same-sex marriage were notable, as he acknowledged that society is changing and that people's opinions on the issue are evolving. However, he emphasized his traditional views and believes the government should not be heavily involved in marriage laws.

As Paul continues to navigate the complexities of appealing to young voters while staying within the Republican Party, he will need to balance his libertarian views with the party's more conservative stance on certain issues.

Title: Political Events Dominate the Week in Politics

The past week in politics has been marked by significant events, with the country grappling with issues of police shootings and violence. Two black men were killed by police officers in separate incidents, followed by an ambush of 12 white police officers in Dallas, resulting in five deaths. This has led to concerns about the country's divisions and the need for a unifying leader.

In the presidential campaign, both Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump have had to address these issues. Trump strongly defended the police, while Clinton urged national guidelines for the use of force by law enforcement. Both candidates canceled their campaign rallies on Friday, with Clinton postponing one with Vice President Joe Biden.

The email controversy surrounding Clinton's private server has not gone away, with FBI Director James Comey finding her guilty of setting up an unauthorized server and being "extremely reckless" in handling classified material. Trump, on the other hand, has not dwelled on the issue, instead focusing on his own campaign's use of a Star of David in a tweet.

Clinton has been criticized for her stance on issues such as free college and a government option in healthcare, which are seen as leaning towards the democratic socialist fringe of the Democratic Party. Sanders' supporters are expected to endorse Clinton this week, but it remains to be seen if this will mark the end of further challenges to the Democratic Party's rules.

The Republican Party's rules and platform committees will meet this week in Cleveland, with potential fights over the platform and rules. Trump is expected to announce his running mate this week, with options including Newt Gingrich, Gen. Michael Flynn, and Indiana Gov. Mike Pence.

Overall, the past week has been marked by significant events and challenges for both presidential candidates. As the country continues to grapple with issues of police shootings and violence, the candidates will need to demonstrate their ability to bring the country together and provide leadership.

Title: White House Proposes $1.6 Trillion in Tax Increases, Republicans Reject Offer

The White House has presented a budget framework to Republicans, which includes $1.6 trillion in tax increases and a promise of future spending trims to address the "fiscal cliff." The proposal was met with immediate rejection from GOP leaders, who demanded more specific spending cuts.

The White House's offer includes billions of dollars in stimulus spending, a call to curtail Congress's control over the federal debt limit, a rise in the estate tax, and an increase in taxes on dividends. In exchange, President Obama has pledged to find up to $400 billion in entitlement spending cuts and undertake an overhaul of the tax code.

House Speaker John Boehner, Ohio Republican, stated that the proposal is not a serious attempt to address the nation's debt and deficit, and that Republicans are willing to raise revenue through ending tax breaks and closing loopholes. However, he did not provide specific examples of which tax breaks he would end or spending cuts he would propose.

The White House has signaled some flexibility, with Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner privately telling key players that they would be willing to accept a tax rate higher than the 39.6% rate proposed by President Obama. However, they have emphasized that rates will have to rise somewhat.

The "fiscal cliff" refers to the expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts on January 1, followed by $110 billion in automatic spending cuts. If the cliff is not addressed, it could plunge the country into a short, sharp recession. The challenge for President Obama and Congress is to try to spread the pain while doing the least harm to the economy.

The negotiations are ongoing, with both sides trying to find a compromise. The White House has signaled some flexibility, but Republicans are still demanding more specific spending cuts and entitlement reforms. The outcome of these talks will have significant implications for the nation's economy and debt.

Title: President Obama Considers New Executive Actions to Advance Priorities

President Barack Obama is considering a series of executive actions to address various issues, including cybersecurity, housing, and energy efficiency. According to The Washington Post, the president is looking to create new standards for private companies to protect their computer systems from hackers, as well as policies to help homeowners refinance mortgages, provide protections for government contractors who identify as homosexual, and impose stricter regulations on coal-fired power plants.

The White House has emphasized that these executive actions are not intended to bypass Congress, but rather to move forward on the president's top priorities. However, Republican lawmakers have expressed concerns that the president is overstepping his constitutional powers. A recent federal appeals court ruling found that Obama exceeded his constitutional powers by appointing new members to the National Labor Relations Board while the Senate was on break.

One of the more significant executive actions being considered would give homeowners a better chance to refinance at today's low interest rates. The president has already taken steps to make refinancing easier for those with loans backed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and this new plan could extend those opportunities to those with privately backed mortgages.

The president's decision to take executive action is reportedly due to his conclusion that Republicans are unlikely to pass many of his major agenda items. The exact scope and details of the proposed executive actions are still unclear, but the White House has emphasized that the president is committed to using his executive powers to advance his priorities.

Title: The 2016 Presidential Contenders: A Reality Check

The 2016 presidential election is still a year away, but the Republican Party's "deep bench" of potential candidates is already showing signs of wear and tear. Former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell, once a rising star in the Republican Party, is now fighting public corruption charges and facing the possibility of prison time. Meanwhile, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie is dealing with multiple scandals, including the George Washington Bridge retribution scandal and allegations that his lieutenant governor threatened to withhold Hurricane Sandy aid from Hoboken, New Jersey, if its mayor blocked a Christie donor's development deal.

The "deep bench" metaphor, coined by Mitt Romney's V.P. vetter Beth Myers, has been proven to be nothing more than a myth. Sen. Marco Rubio, once considered a top contender, has imploded spectacularly after making a play for the center with immigration reform and then tacking right. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, who was ranked seventh on the National Journal's 2012 "deep bench" list, has become the most unpopular Republican governor in the country.

Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who came out of nowhere in 2012, has also seen his star fade due to his self-promoting and nasty brand of politics. Sen. Rand Paul, who was ranked sixth on the National Journal's list, has proven to be a lightweight with a plagiarism problem and a national security and foreign policy skepticism that is politically suicidal with the GOP establishment.

Rep. Paul Ryan, who was ranked fifth on the National Journal's list, has failed to make a significant impact as a presidential contender. While he has been praised for his wonk credentials, his only contribution to the 2012 ticket was to hurt Mitt Romney. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who was also on the National Journal's list, has been embroiled in an investigation into campaign finance violations and has been named one of the nation's "worst governors" by the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

Jeb Bush, who was ranked fourth on the National Journal's list, is the only remaining contender from the original "deep bench" list. However, his ties to Lehman Brothers, which went bankrupt in 2008, have raised concerns about his ability to navigate the complexities of the financial world. His wife, Columba, is also said to be against his running for president.

In conclusion, the 2016 presidential election is shaping up to be a crowded and competitive field, but the Republican Party's "deep bench" is looking more like a shallow pool.

Title: Michelle Williams Wins Golden Globe, Uses Platform to Emphasize Importance of Reproductive Freedom

Michelle Williams, an American actress, won her second Golden Globe award for her role in the miniseries Fosse/Verdon. During her acceptance speech, she used the platform to highlight the significance of reproductive freedom. Williams expressed gratitude for the acknowledgment of her choices as an actress and as a person, and emphasized the importance of living in a society where choice exists.

The actress's comments come as the Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in June Medical Services v. Gee, a case centered on Louisiana's law requiring abortion providers to have admitting privileges at an area hospital. This law is seen as a tactic to restrict abortion access, with advocates arguing that it is unnecessary and potentially harmful. The Court's decision is expected to have significant implications for reproductive rights, with some predicting that it could lead to the dismantling of Roe v. Wade.

Williams, an active participant in the Time's Up movement, emphasized the importance of women's right to choose and the freedom to make decisions about their own bodies. She encouraged women of all ages to exercise their right to vote, stating that it is essential to prioritize their own interests.

The audience applauded Williams' speech, with Tiffany Haddish, who presented the award, enthusiastically showing her support for reproductive rights.

Title: Global Risks to Watch in 2020: A Year of Unpredictability

The world is bracing for a potentially tumultuous 2020, with several global risks and uncertainties on the horizon. As the world grapples with the consequences of a fragile world order, several developments are likely to shape the year's trajectory.

One of the most pressing concerns is the 2020 elections in the United States. A Trump reelection could lead to further withdrawal from the multilateral world order, while a Democratic victory could bring about left-populist economic policies, potentially fueling uncertainty and turmoil in markets.

Brexit is another certainty, with the United Kingdom set to leave the European Union by January 31. However, the terms of the departure and the potential impact on the global economy remain uncertain. The Scottish Nationalist Party may pursue another independence referendum, while Irish nationalist MPs may consider their future, potentially leading to the breakup of the United Kingdom.

North Korea's defiance is another major concern, as it continues to develop strategic weapons and threatens to take a "new path" if the United States fails to make concessions. This could lead to a new cycle of "fire and fury" rhetoric, threatening confrontation and conflict.

The World Trade Organization (WTO) is also facing an uncertain future, with its arbitration mechanism potentially becoming defunct. This could lead to a shift towards bilateral and multilateral preferential trade arrangements, potentially fragmenting the global economy.

The decoupling of the world's two largest economies, the United States and China, is another major risk. This could lead to a bifurcated world, with the two economies operating independently, potentially disrupting global innovation and supply chains.

A "gray swan" event, such as a simultaneous slowdown in the three economic centers and the U.S.-China decoupling, could catapult the global economy into another deep economic crisis. China's internal contradictions, including massive public, household, and corporate debt, aging demographics, and sagging growth, make it vulnerable to a financial crisis.

Other risks include overlapping conflicts in the greater Middle East, such as Syria, Libya, Yemen, and Iran, which could escalate into proxy or real U.S. conflict with Iran.

As the world navigates these risks, it is essential to remain vigilant and prepared for the unpredictable nature of 2020.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder to Represent US at Paris Rally Against Terrorism

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder will represent the United States at a rally against terrorism in Paris, France, on Sunday afternoon, according to news reports. The rally is a response to the recent deadly attacks on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper and a kosher supermarket, which killed 12 and 4 people, respectively. The demonstration is expected to feature several European heads of state and high-level delegations from other countries.

Holder's involvement in the rally has raised some controversy, as he has been criticized for his stance on terrorism and extremism. In 2010, he refused to blame radical Islam in addressing the motives of terrorists who had launched attacks against the United States, stating, "I don't want to say anything negative about a religion." This approach has been criticized by some as being too cautious and not acknowledging the root causes of terrorism.

Holder has also been accused of creating an atmosphere of mistrust in the debate over the deaths of unarmed black suspects at the hands of police, which some blame for attacks on police, including the assassination of two New York Police Department officers. Former New York Governor George Pataki has tweeted that Holder's "divisive anti-cop rhetoric" contributed to the deaths of the police officers.

In addition, Holder has sought to try terrorists in federal courts rather than military tribunals, and has shown leniency to terrorists in the past. During the administration of Bill Clinton, he reportedly pushed the Department of Justice to drop its objection to the commutations of sentences for members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group.

Despite the controversy surrounding Holder's involvement, he will also participate in meetings with international counterparts about stopping terror attacks and will be the featured guest on five major Sunday morning news programs, except for Fox News Sunday.

President Barack Obama has no public events scheduled and is preparing to continue a nationwide tour this week to preview his upcoming State of the Union address. It is possible that Obama may attend the rally, but no official announcement has been made.

Title: The Pandemic Response: A Call for Accountability and Realism

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about unprecedented challenges, and it is essential to approach the response with a balanced and realistic perspective. Unfortunately, the left's stance on the nation's response to the pandemic has been marred by inconsistencies and moral posturing.

Many Democratic leaders, left-wing media outlets, and self-proclaimed "never-Trumpers" have focused more on criticizing President Donald Trump than on finding solutions to the crisis. They have accused Trump of being too slow to act, while also claiming he is overreacting. This contradictory stance is a hallmark of the left's approach to the pandemic.

In contrast, President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence, along with their medical team, have been providing daily briefings to inform the public about the virus and the government's efforts to slow its spread. The media, however, has often used these briefings to humiliate Trump rather than focus on the facts.

The left's criticism of Trump has been relentless, with many accusing him of prioritizing his re-election over the well-being of Americans. However, this narrative is not supported by the facts. Trump has been deferring to medical experts and working to reopen the economy while also taking steps to prevent new flare-ups.

The article also highlights the double standard applied to Democratic leaders, who are often exempt from scrutiny despite their own inconsistencies and flawed policies. For example, Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's statement that "no one is expendable" and that "no life is worth losing to add one more point to the Dow" is a cheap shot at Trump and those who want to reopen the economy.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for accountability and realism in the pandemic response. While there are no easy solutions, it is essential to work together to reopen the economy while also taking steps to prevent new outbreaks.
