The study's findings are based on a comprehensive review of the scientific literature and challenge the dominant narrative on sexual orientation and gender identity. The authors argue that human sexuality is shaped by a complex interplay of social, cultural, and biological factors, and that the idea that sexual orientation and gender identity are fixed and immutable at birth is not supported by scientific evidence.

The study's findings have implications for public policy and cultural norms, as they suggest that the LGBT community faces significant health and mental health challenges that require a nuanced and evidence-based approach. The study's authors argue that a realistic and messier understanding of human sexuality is needed to address these challenges and promote the well-being of all individuals.

Title: Illinois Becomes 11th State to Legalize Recreational Marijuana Use

Illinois has become the 11th state in the United States to legalize marijuana for recreational use after Governor J.B. Pritzker signed a bill into law. The legislation allows residents to purchase and possess up to one ounce of cannabis at a time, while non-residents can possess up to 15 grams. The law also establishes a comprehensive statewide cannabis marketplace, designed by legislators, and provides for the expungement of criminal records for nearly 800,000 people with past convictions for possessing 30 grams of marijuana or less.

The law, which fulfills one of Pritzker's campaign promises, also allows adults 21 and older to purchase cannabis at approved dispensaries, which are expected to begin selling on January 1, 2020. Until then, possession remains a crime. The law is expected to generate an estimated $800 million to $1 billion in annual tax revenue, with dispensary licensing generating around $58 million in the first year.

The legislation also addresses the disproportionate impact of the war on drugs on minority communities, with a focus on providing criminal-record scrubbing for past low-level offenders and giving preference to would-be marijuana vendors in areas of high poverty and records of large numbers of convictions. A portion of the tax proceeds will be reinvested in impoverished communities.

Police organizations have expressed concerns about enforcing driving under the influence laws and the need for further development of technology for testing marijuana impairment. They were successful in killing an earlier provision that would have allowed individuals to grow up to five marijuana plants at home for personal use.

Illinois joins 10 other states and the District of Columbia in legalizing recreational marijuana use, with Vermont and Michigan being the latest states to do so. Other initiatives have failed in New York and New Jersey, while Pennsylvania's lieutenant governor conducted a statewide listening tour on the issue last winter, but it did not gain traction.

Title: Nobel Prize Winner Peter Handke's Controversial Views on Bosnia War Spark Outrage

The recent awarding of the Nobel Prize in Literature to Austrian writer Peter Handke has sparked widespread criticism due to his controversial views on the Bosnian War. Handke has been accused of denying the genocide committed by Serbs against Muslims in Bosnia and has been linked to the Serbian strongman Slobodan Miloševic, who died in prison awaiting trial for genocide and war crimes.

Handke's most famous political offense was attending Miloševic's funeral in 2006, where he delivered a eulogy. He has also written essays and articles that have been criticized for their biased and misleading portrayal of the conflict. In his book "A Journey to the Rivers: Justice for Serbia," Handke claimed that the media unfairly portrays the Serbs as evil and that the West is responsible for the conflict.

However, critics argue that Handke's views are based on a lack of understanding of the complex politics of the region and that he has failed to acknowledge the atrocities committed by Serb forces during the war. Handke has also been accused of downplaying the existence of concentration camps in Bosnia and of denying the genocide committed by Serbs against Muslims.

The controversy surrounding Handke's views has sparked outrage among many, with some calling for the Nobel Prize to be revoked. The Nobel Committee has faced criticism for its decision to award the prize to Handke, with some arguing that it sends a message that denying genocide is acceptable.

In conclusion, the controversy surrounding Peter Handke's views on the Bosnian War highlights the importance of accurate and unbiased reporting of historical events. It is crucial that we recognize the atrocities committed during the war and that we do not perpetuate misinformation or deny the truth.

Title: Clinton Campaign Email Reveals Concerns Over Trump's Celebrity Politics and the Need for a Compliant Citizenry

A recently released email from the Hillary Clinton campaign, part of the Wikileaks data dump, has shed light on the campaign's concerns about Donald Trump's celebrity politics and the need to maintain a compliant citizenry. The email was sent by Bill Ivey, a former Clinton administration official, to campaign chairman John Podesta on March 13, 2016.

In the email, Ivey expressed worry that Trump's "celebrity politics" persona cannot be matched by Hillary Clinton, who is "not an entertainer, and not a celebrity in the Trump, Kardashian mold." He noted that Trump's ability to dominate TV and news cycles makes it difficult for Clinton to compete.

Ivey also lamented that simply focusing on policy would not be enough to combat Trump's appeal, stating that the left has "conspired" to produce an "unaware and compliant citizenry." He acknowledged that this approach has been effective in the past, but noted that it is no longer working as well due to the public's growing awareness and skepticism.

The email has sparked controversy, with some interpreting it as evidence of the Clinton campaign's elitist and arrogant mindset, viewing Americans as sheep that need to be herded in the right direction.

Title: Rep. Tom Cole Expresses Skepticism Over Minimum Wage Increase, Accuses White House of Politicizing Issue

Article:

Representative Tom Cole, an Oklahoma Republican, has expressed skepticism over the idea of increasing the federal minimum wage, stating that he would consider it if it were attached to job-creating measures. However, he accused the White House of using the issue as a "political weapon" and claimed that President Barack Obama has not presented a comprehensive plan to attract Republican support.

In an interview on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Cole said that while he recognizes the case for raising the minimum wage, he believes there are also valid arguments against it. He pointed to the Congressional Budget Office's estimate that raising the federal minimum wage to $10.10 an hour would reduce total employment by about 500,000 workers, even as it would boost wages for low-income workers.

The Congressional Budget Office report also noted that the uncertainty surrounding the impact of a minimum wage increase is substantial, with the potential loss of jobs ranging from "very slight" to as much as 1 million.

Cole's comments come after a proposal to raise the federal minimum wage from $7.25 an hour to $10.10 an hour fell victim to a filibuster in the U.S. Senate earlier this week. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, has expressed willingness to compromise on the issue, but not on the $10.10 figure.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney responded to Cole's comments, saying that offering a different number would not be effective in gaining Republican support. "We don't hear back from Republican leaders, 'Well, I can't do 10.10, I could do 9.50.' That's not what they tell you, and it's not what they tell us," Carney said. "They say they're opposed to raising the minimum wage. 'That's the wrong approach. It's not good for America. It's not good for the economy. It's not right for those families.'"

Title: The Unlikely Duos: Bernie Sanders and Michael Bloomberg's Paths to the Democratic Primary

The 2020 Democratic primary has seen an unexpected pairing: Senator Bernie Sanders and Michael Bloomberg, two candidates with vastly different backgrounds and ideologies, are vying for the party's nomination. Both men have been beneficiaries of the hollowed-out political parties, which have failed to perform the gatekeeper function of the nomination process.

Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, has a history of being on the right side of the civil rights movement and has been a consistent advocate for what he calls democratic socialism. He has been an enemy of the economic elites, particularly the "billionaire class." His supporters admire his unwavering commitment to social justice and his willingness to challenge the status quo.

Michael Bloomberg, on the other hand, is a billionaire businessman and former New York City mayor. He has been a poster boy for a kind of arrogant progressive, post-partisan technocratic government that prizes data over feelings. His supporters appreciate his ability to bring people together and his commitment to using data-driven approaches to solve problems.

Both men have their own unique strengths and weaknesses. Sanders has been a consistent advocate for social justice and has a strong grassroots following, while Bloomberg has a reputation for being a skilled administrator and a champion of data-driven decision-making. However, their approaches to governance are fundamentally different, with Sanders advocating for a more participatory and inclusive process, while Bloomberg has been criticized for his top-down approach.

The stakes of their contest are high, as the winner will likely define the Democratic Party's direction for years to come. If Sanders wins, the party may become more populist and focused on social justice, while if Bloomberg wins, the party may become more bureaucratic and focused on data-driven decision-making. Ultimately, the choice between these two candidates is a zero-sum game, and the outcome will have significant implications for the party's future.

Title: Greenland's Residents Unfazed by Speculation of US Purchase

The recent report about the possibility of the United States purchasing Greenland has sparked a mix of humor and concern among social media users. However, politicians and residents of the island nation are taking the situation seriously, emphasizing that Greenland is not a commodity to be traded.

Greenland, a country with a population of 56,000, has a long history of shared governance with Denmark, dating back to the Viking era. If the relationship were to change, it would not be up to Denmark or an American president's "impulse," according to Henrik O. Breitenbauch, an expert on Greenland and the head of the Center for Military Studies at Copenhagen University.

The speculation is that US President Donald Trump, a former real estate developer, is interested in Greenland due to its unique characteristics, such as its fresh air, direct access to the sea, and abundance of seafood and minerals. The island's proximity to international sea routes also makes it an attractive location for trade and commerce.

However, Greenland's residents are skeptical about the idea of becoming a US territory, citing concerns about losing their autonomy and cultural identity. "You don't just trade people and countries," said Aaja Chemnitz Larsen, a Greenlandic member of the Danish Parliament.

While some social media users have joked about trading Greenland for Hawaii, the idea is not taken lightly by those living on the island. "Greenland could choose to become Puerto Rico with snow, but I doubt there's much interest in that," said Breitenbauch, referring to the unincorporated US territory.

Title: Ryan Defends Journalists, Says Leaks Compromise National Security, Not the Journalist

Article:

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) defended journalists on Friday, stating that while intelligence leaks compromise national security, it is the problem of the leaker, not the journalist. Ryan made this comment at an event in Muskego, Wis., on Friday afternoon.

Ryan's statement comes just hours after Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a government-wide crackdown on leakers. Sessions warned that the media could be part of this crackdown and that the Justice Department could ask for sources behind leaks. The investigation will include a review of the Justice Department's policies on subpoenas for media outlets that publish sensitive information.

"We respect the important role that the press plays and will give them respect, but it is not unlimited," Sessions said. "We must balance their role with protecting our national security and the lives of those who serve in our intelligence community, the armed forces, and all law-abiding Americans."

Ryan's comments were met with criticism from the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Mark Warner (D-Va.), who called for Congress to probe the leak of transcripts of President Trump's phone calls with the leaders of Mexico and Australia, a leak both political parties have condemned.

Title: CDC Employees Collect $25 Million in Bonuses Amid Flat Funding

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has paid out $25 million in bonuses to its employees since 2007, despite flat funding and a supposed lack of resources to combat the Ebola outbreak. According to data compiled by American Transparency's OpenTheBooks.com, the agency's headcount increased by 23% during that time, adding manpower and contributing to higher payrolls.

The CDC's deputy director of policy and communication, Donald Shriber, received the highest bonus in the six-year period, with $62,895 in 2011, netting $242,595 in take-home pay. Other high-ranking officials, including Kathleen Dunlap, deputy budget director, received significant bonuses as well.

The CDC's handling of the Ebola outbreak has been criticized, with some arguing that the agency's response was slow and inadequate. However, the agency's budget has remained relatively flat since President Obama took office, with funding set at $5.39 billion in the latest budget request.

Despite the flat funding, the CDC still managed to hand out bonuses and add 1,888 positions from 2007 to 2013, data show. Employees at the CDC earn more than the federal average, with an average salary of $95,015 last year.

Title: RAND Study Examines DoD Policy Changes for Transgender Service Members

The United States Department of Defense (DoD) has been considering potential changes to its policy regarding transgender personnel serving openly in the military. A recent RAND study, sponsored by the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, aimed to identify the health care needs of transgender individuals, assess the costs of covering transition-related treatments, and examine the potential readiness implications of a policy change.

The study, conducted within the Forces and Resources Policy Center of the RAND National Defense Research Institute, found that if transgender service members are allowed to serve openly, certain DoD policies would need to be changed. The report identified the health care needs of transgender individuals and service members, including access to gender-affirming care and the range of transition-related treatments.

The study also estimated the costs associated with providing these treatments, which could range from $2.5 million to $8.5 million annually, depending on the scope of care provided. Additionally, the report examined the potential readiness implications of a policy change, including the potential impact on deployment and the need for additional training for medical personnel.

The study also reviewed the experiences of foreign militaries that permit transgender personnel to serve openly, highlighting best practices and lessons learned. The report concluded that allowing transgender service members to serve openly would not have a significant impact on military readiness or effectiveness.

The RAND study's findings and recommendations are intended to inform policy decisions and provide a data-driven understanding of the issues surrounding transgender service members. The report is part of the RAND research report series, which presents research findings and objective analysis to address the challenges facing the public and private sectors.

Title: Former State Department Official Explains Why Obama Administration Refused to Use Term "Radical Islamic Extremism"

A former State Department official has shed light on the reasons behind the Obama administration's reluctance to use the term "radical Islamic extremism" to describe the terrorist group Islamic State (ISIS). Richard Stengal, the former under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, wrote in a New York Times op-ed that the decision was based on practical considerations, not a lack of courage or political correctness.

According to Stengal, the Obama administration's strategy was to work with Islamic allies, such as Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia, to combat terrorism. These countries believed that the term "radical Islamic extremism" unfairly stigmatized the entire Islamic faith, and they did not consider ISIS to be Islamic. Stengal noted that ISIS's brutal violence against Muslims proved that it was not representative of the vast majority of Muslims.

Stengal argued that the Trump administration's decision to change the name of the "Countering Violent Extremism" program to "Countering Islamic Extremism" or "Countering Radical Islamic Extremism" may not be the most effective approach. He believes that the previous administration's strategy, which focused on working with Muslim-majority countries to counter terrorism, is still the best way to defeat ISIS. Stengal noted that ISIS is on the ropes in Iraq and Syria, and that the previous administration's approach has been successful.

However, Stengal expressed concerns about the new direction the administration is taking, stating that it is not up to the US to define what is and is not Islamic. He believes that only mainstream Muslims and independent clerics in Muslim countries can create a narrative that refutes ISIS's ideology and offers a more positive alternative. Stengal warned that using terms like "radical Islamic extremism" may inadvertently help ISIS's recruiting efforts.

Title: President Trump Warns Puerto Rico's Infrastructure is a "Mess" and Federal Aid Can't Last Forever

Article:

President Donald Trump issued a series of tweets on Thursday warning that Puerto Rico's infrastructure was a "mess" before Hurricane Maria and that federal officials cannot stay on the island "forever." The comments come just one week after Trump visited the U.S. territory, which is still recovering from the devastating effects of the hurricane.

Trump's tweets stated that Puerto Rico's electric and infrastructure were a disaster before the hurricanes, and that the island's financial crisis is largely of its own making. He also mentioned that Congress needs to decide how much to spend on aid and that the federal government cannot keep sending aid to Puerto Rico indefinitely.

The president's comments have been met with criticism from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, who tweeted, "Why do you continue to treat Puerto Ricans differently than other Americans when it comes to natural disasters?"

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), there were over 10,000 federal officials on the ground in Puerto Rico earlier this month. House Speaker Paul Ryan is set to visit the island on Friday, along with a bipartisan group, to meet with local officials and emergency personnel.

The House is expected to vote this week on an emergency spending package that includes billions of dollars in relief for Puerto Rico, Texas, and Florida, which were affected by hurricanes Maria, Harvey, and Irma this hurricane season. The president has asked Congress for a $4.9 billion loan to help Puerto Rico pay its bills from the storm.

Title: Rick Santorum Weighs Pros and Cons of Another Presidential Run

Rick Santorum, a former Pennsylvania senator and 2012 presidential candidate, is considering another bid for the White House, but is not ruling out a 2016 candidacy. In an interview with the Associated Press, Santorum expressed concerns about the Republican Party's ability to win elections unless candidates develop policies that benefit working Americans. He also criticized the party's libertarian streak, saying it distorts the definition of freedom and politicians wrongly look to President Ronald Reagan's policies to address today's challenges.

Santorum, who ran an upstart campaign in 2012, is currently enjoying a second career as a movie studio executive and is focused on his family, particularly his 5-year-old daughter Bella, who has a genetic disorder. He is also working on a book, "Blue Collar Conservatives: Recommitting to an America That Works," which outlines his policy ideas on energy, education, the economy, and healthcare.

In the book, Santorum argues that Republicans should focus on helping working-class voters and not just business leaders and "job creators." He believes that anxiety among those voters remains high and that Republicans have not effectively addressed their concerns. Santorum also criticizes Republicans who demonize social welfare programs, saying that they care less about the person at the bottom of the economic ladder than Democrats do.

Santorum's comments about the Republican Party's struggles and his own potential candidacy have raised questions about his viability in a crowded 2016 primary field. He is not rushing to commit to a decision, saying he may wait at least a year to decide.

Title: Iran Nuclear Talks Progress, But Tough Issues Remain

The Iran nuclear talks are ongoing, with top U.S. officials stating that the negotiations are progressing, but tough issues still remain. The Obama administration is seeking to reassure key constituencies in the U.S. while maintaining an increasingly fractious coalition of countries joining the negotiations. The U.S. is also ratcheting up pressure on Iran, with Secretary of State John Kerry stating that the U.S. is prepared to walk away from the negotiating table if a deal is not reached.

Kerry's statements are seen as a gambit to influence Iranian expectations and decision-making, as well as to reassure skeptical members of Congress that the U.S. is taking a hard line. The administration is also trying to manage expectations, with President Barack Obama stating that the chances of a deal are below 50-50.

The negotiations have been extended, with the U.S. and its partners, including Russia, China, Germany, France, and the UK, working to resolve outstanding issues. The coalition is showing signs of strain, with Russia adopting a stance on relaxing sanctions more in line with Iran's demands. The U.S. is pushing back against Iran's demand to lift the arms embargo, with Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey stating that the U.S. will not relieve pressure on Iran relative to ballistic missile capabilities and arms trafficking.

The negotiations are expected to continue, with the U.S. and its partners seeking to find a way to broker a lasting deal aimed at keeping Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

Title: Parkland Shooting Survivor David Hogg Calls for Younger Leadership in Democratic Party

Article:

Parkland shooting survivor and gun-control activist David Hogg has expressed his desire for younger leaders to take the reins in the Democratic Party. In an interview with New York Magazine, Hogg stated that older Democrats need to "move the f--- off the plate" for young people to be successful. He believes that the reason Republicans are successful is because they are empowering young people, whereas older Democrats are not willing to step aside and let them take control.

Hogg, who is 18 years old, noted that U.S. House Speaker Paul D. Ryan was 45 years old when he took up the leadership role. He is working on a seven-year plan, which includes spending the next several months meeting more activists and canvassing in advance of the midterm elections. After that, he plans to attend college in the fall of 2019, read a "sh---load of books," and then take some time off in 2020 to work on a presidential campaign. He also expressed his desire to run for Congress in the future.

Hogg is not thrilled with the current state of the Democratic Party, citing examples such as Senator Bernie Sanders being "terrible on guns" and former President Barack Obama increasing drone warfare and killing civilians. However, he does see potential in Democratic Socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who he believes will eventually culminate in a successful run for the White House.

It is worth noting that Hogg has already received approaches from certain candidates who want him to work on their presidential campaign. He has not yet decided which candidate he will support, but he is open to exploring his options.

**Hurricane Florence: East Coast Residents Urged to Flee as Storm Approaches**

The US East Coast is bracing for the impact of Hurricane Florence, which is expected to make landfall on Thursday evening. The storm has been downgraded to a category three, with maximum sustained winds of 120mph (195km/h), but officials warn it is still "extremely dangerous."

Up to 1.7 million people have been ordered to evacuate across South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. Four South Carolina motorways have been diverted one-way to speed the exodus. Georgia has declared a state of emergency, following the Carolinas, Virginia, Maryland, and Washington D.C.

The National Weather Service forecaster warned, "This will likely be the storm of a lifetime for portions of the Carolina coast. And that's saying a lot given the impacts we've seen from Hurricanes Diana, Hugo, Fran, Bonnie, Floyd, and Matthew." Jeff Byard, of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, described the storm as "a Mike Tyson punch to the Carolina coast."

North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper warned that "disaster is at the doorstep" and "tens of thousands" of buildings may be flooded. Waves 83ft (25m) tall were recorded at sea on Wednesday morning.

While many coastal residents have complied with mandatory evacuation orders, others are boarding up their homes and vowing to ride out the storm. Florence could wreak more than $170bn (£130bn) of havoc and damage nearly 759,000 homes and businesses, according to analytics firm CoreLogic.

The storm's slow movement and expected storm surges of up to 13ft pose a significant threat to the region. The National Weather Service predicts "catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding" in parts of the Carolinas and Appalachians.

The National Hurricane Center Director Ken Graham warned that waterways up to 40 miles inland may flood, and half of fatalities during hurricanes are caused by storm surges, while another quarter are due to inland rains and flooding.

The relationship between climate change and hurricanes is complex, with warmer seas powering hurricanes and a hotter atmosphere holding more water, potentially leading to more severe storms. However, the data is still being studied and analyzed.

Residents are urged to take the storm seriously and heed evacuation orders. As Florida Mayor Bob Buckhorn said ahead of Hurricane Irma in 2017, "Everybody has a plan until they get punched in the face. Well, we're about to get punched in the face."

Title: Clinton and Abrams Highlight Court Vacancy as Crucial Issue in Presidential Election

The recent death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has brought the presidential election into sharp focus, with Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Stacey Abrams emphasizing the importance of the court vacancy in the campaign. According to Abrams, a Democratic state representative from Georgia and House minority leader, the moment has arrived for action, and the election on November 8 is the time for voters to make their voices heard.

For Clinton, who is relying heavily on non-white voters to secure her nomination against Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, the court issue could be a crucial motivator. Should she defeat Sanders, she will need to rally Obama's loyalists to the polls. Clinton has been quick to capitalize on the anger and frustration among black Americans over Senate Republicans' opposition to President Obama's nomination of a replacement for Scalia.

In a speech to a predominantly black audience in Harlem, Clinton criticized Republicans for their stance, saying, "Now the Republicans say they'll reject anyone President Obama nominates no matter how qualified, some are even saying he doesn't have the right to nominate anyone! As if somehow he's not the real president." She also accused Republicans of perpetuating a pattern of mistreatment and hatred towards Obama, citing their opposition to his policies and actions.

The suggestion that racism is playing a role in the Republican opposition to Obama's nomination has sparked anger among some Republicans, who point out that Senator Mitch McConnell's formative political experience was working for a Republican senator who supported civil rights, and that he has an Asian-American wife.

Title: Appeals Court Deals Blow to Affordable Care Act, But Another Panel Issues Contrasting Ruling

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has ruled that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) regulation governing subsidies in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is invalid, dealing a significant blow to the healthcare law. However, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has issued a decision that contradicts this ruling.

The D.C. Circuit's decision, handed down on Tuesday, struck down subsidies in the 36 states that did not set up their own insurance exchanges. The Department of Justice has announced its intention to ask the full 11-judge panel to review the decision. In the meantime, the administration has emphasized that people receiving premium tax credits should be aware that nothing has changed, and tax credits remain available.

The ruling has the potential to affect nearly 5 million Americans who signed up for Obamacare through federal exchanges. Losing the subsidies could mean that millions of U.S. residents could become uninsured, as health plans sold through the exchange might be unaffordable without the assistance.

The courts were deciding whether Congress intended to provide subsidies for Americans who bought insurance through exchanges set up by states and the federal government on behalf of states. The D.C. Circuit's majority opinion, joined by Senior Circuit Judge Raymond Randolph, concluded that an Exchange established by the federal government cannot be considered an "Exchange established by the State." Only further legislation could accomplish the expansion the government seeks.

One of the three judges dissented, arguing that the majority failed to find ambiguity in the language, where there was clearly ambiguity. The Fourth Circuit, on the other hand, ruled unanimously that the ambiguity in the statute's language means the subsidies can be given to both those who signed up using state exchanges and those who used federal exchanges.

It is possible that this dispute will ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court.

Title: Trump's Handling of Pandemic and Presidential Authority Raises Concerns

The United States is facing two critical emergencies: the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and the presidency of Donald Trump. While Trump's administration has been criticized for its handling of the pandemic response, Trump's actions and statements have sparked concerns about his understanding of presidential authority and his willingness to prioritize his own interests over the well-being of the nation.

Trump's recent news briefing featured a campaign-style video defending his management of the pandemic, with glowing quotes from governors. However, reports have shown that Trump was slow to take action on the virus, diverting early discussions to talk of vaping and accusing advisers of being alarmist. Trump's overwhelming need to brag and burnish his reputation is unseemly at the best of times, and his prioritization of it during a national crisis is particularly concerning.

Moreover, Trump's suggestion that he might order state governors to ease shelter-at-home rules and begin to re-open their economies has raised concerns among experts, who fear that lifting the lockdowns too quickly could lead to a new wave of coronavirus illnesses and deaths. Trump's assertion that he has "total authority" to command states to re-open is also unconstitutional, as the Constitution clearly divides federal authority between the three branches of government and delegates power to the states.

Trump's performance has also highlighted the Republican Party's hypocrisy on issues of federalism and limited government. While former President Obama's assertions of authority would have been met with swift criticism from conservatives, Trump's similar claims are met with silence and assent. Trump's refusal to issue a national stay-at-home order and his tendency to scapegoat governors under the guise of federalism have also raised concerns about his willingness to use his authority to address the crisis.

In the absence of federal leadership, governors are devising their own workarounds, with some states forming pacts to plan how to re-open their economies. The federal government under President Trump appears to be broken, unwilling or unable to perform the tasks expected of it during a national emergency. Trump wants all the power, all the credit, and none of the responsibility, which threatens American democracy and public health.

Title: Armed Demonstrations in Public Places Raise Concerns Over Safety and Freedom

The recent trend of armed individuals openly carrying firearms in public places has sparked concerns over safety and freedom among many Americans. In the wake of the new Georgia law allowing concealed carry, some individuals have taken to displaying their weapons in public, often in areas where children and families gather. This has led to incidents where parents have felt endangered and have had to leave public spaces, such as a little league baseball game, due to the perceived threat posed by the armed individuals.

Open carry advocates argue that they are exercising their constitutional right to bear arms, but critics argue that this is not only unnecessary but also dangerous. The recent demonstrations at Starbucks and Jack in the Box, where armed individuals showed up to make a political statement, have caused concern among employees and customers. While no incidents have occurred, the presence of armed individuals has caused fear and discomfort among those present.

Some proponents of open carry believe that their actions are necessary to protect the public, citing the need for citizens to be able to defend themselves in the absence of police presence. However, critics argue that this is a form of vigilantism, where individuals take the law into their own hands and disregard the authority of the democratic system of government.

The debate surrounding open carry has raised questions about the balance between individual freedom and public safety. While some argue that the right to bear arms is a fundamental freedom, others believe that this freedom is being exercised at the expense of others' safety and well-being. As the trend of armed demonstrations continues, it is clear that this issue will remain a contentious topic in American society.

Title: Romney's Overseas Trip Marred by Gaffes and Controversy

Mitt Romney's recent overseas trip aimed to showcase his foreign policy expertise, but the journey was marked by distractions and controversy. Despite the campaign's claims of a "great success," the trip was plagued by gaffes and criticisms.

Romney's trip began in Britain, where he questioned whether London was ready to host the Summer Olympic Games. British Prime Minister David Cameron responded with a subtle dig at Romney's own experience hosting the Olympics in Salt Lake City. The London tabloids dubbed Romney "Mitt the Twit."

In Israel, Romney delivered a strong defense of Israel's right to exist and warned Iranian leaders against weaponizing their nuclear program. However, his comments on Jerusalem as the undisputed capital of Israel outraged Palestinian leaders and fueled already raw feelings in the region.

The trip was also marked by tensions between the campaign and the press. Romney's traveling press secretary, Rick Gorka, was involved in a heated exchange with reporters, shouting "Kiss my ass" and "Shove it" at journalists. Gorka later apologized to two reporters.

Despite the controversy, Romney's campaign remains confident about the trip's success. Stuart Stevens, a senior adviser, said the trip aimed to show off Romney's personality and foreign policy expertise, and that the reviews from supporters have been "very positive."

Conservative bloggers have defended the trip, saying it has been unfairly judged in the media. Greta Van Susteren, an anchor on the Fox News Channel, wrote that the press has been "unrelentingly negative" in its coverage.

When Romney returns to the United States, he will be greeted by a slew of new ads and a new mobile app, "Mitt's VP," about his vice presidential selection process.

Title: Trump Calls for Tougher Travel Ban After London Attack, Urges Proactive Approach to Combat Terrorism

Article:

President Donald Trump took to Twitter early Friday to express his condolences and outrage over the recent attack in London, which sent at least 22 people to hospitals. The President described the perpetrator as a "loser terrorist" and called for a "larger, tougher" travel ban to combat terrorism.

In a series of tweets, Trump emphasized the need for a more proactive approach to fighting terrorism, stating that the internet is a primary recruitment tool for terrorists and must be cut off. He also urged the public to stop being "politically correct" and focus on the security of their people.

The President's tweets come after a fire at a London subway station was declared a "terrorist incident" by the Metropolitan Police, caused by the detonation of an improvised explosive device. Trump later spoke with British Prime Minister Theresa May to convey his sympathies and prayers for those injured.

The White House stated that Trump pledged to continue close collaboration with the United Kingdom to stop attacks targeting innocent civilians and combat extremism. Trump also made the case for his travel ban, which is currently being fought out in the courts.

In his tweets, Trump also compared his administration's progress against ISIS to that of the previous administration, stating that his administration has made more progress in nine months than the Obama Administration made in eight years. He urged the public to be "proactive and nasty" in the fight against terrorism.

British Prime Minister May expressed her condolences to those injured in the attack and praised the bravery of emergency responders. However, former chief of staff to May, Nick Timothy, criticized Trump's tweets as "unhelpful" and stated that the President does not know the facts.

Title: New Jersey Becomes 14th State to Allow Illegal Immigrants to Obtain Driver's Licenses

New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy signed a bill on Thursday, making the Garden State the 14th in the country to allow illegal immigrants to obtain driver's licenses, along with the District of Columbia. The legislation, which was approved by the Democratic majorities in both the state Assembly and Senate, aims to improve road safety and provide a pathway to legal residency for undocumented immigrants.

The bill allows illegal immigrants over the age of 16 to obtain driver's licenses and learner's permits. Applicants can use foreign documents such as passports or their old driver's license from their home country to complete the process. A Social Security number is not required, according to The Associated Press.

The law establishes two types of licenses. One type conforms to federal REAL ID requirements and requires proof of legal residency. The second type requires only six points of identification and does not require proof of U.S. citizenship. This measure is similar to the "Green Light Law" signed by New York Governor Andrew Cuomo earlier this year, which also allows illegal immigrants to obtain a license without providing a Social Security number or proof of American citizenship.

Governor Murphy stated that expanding access to driver's licenses is "critical for the safety of New Jerseyans and a step toward building a stronger and fairer New Jersey for all." Assembly Speaker Craig Coughlin, a Democrat, also expressed support for the legislation, saying it brings the state "one step closer to ensuring all motor vehicles and drivers are insured, thereby creating safer roadways for all New Jersey residents."

Title: The Value of Publishing Controversial Opinions: A Matter of Principle

The recent publication of an Op-Ed by Senator Tom Cotton in The New York Times has sparked intense debate among critics and readers. The paper's editors deemed the piece did not meet their editorial standards, leading some to question whether the publication was a result of the paper's willingness to stand by the article or a desire to avoid controversy. Others argue that the piece should not have been published without critical evaluation by the news department, as it presents arguments that go beyond the moral pale.

However, the value of Senator Cotton's Op-Ed lies not in its moral righteousness but in its representation of a significant current of public opinion. By publishing the piece, The New York Times is providing readers with the opportunity to engage with and consider opposing viewpoints, rather than simply being told what to think. To suggest that readers should seek out alternative sources, such as Senator Cotton's Twitter feed, is to undermine the newspaper's responsibility as a trusted source of information.

A more serious concern is the potential risks posed by the publication of the piece, particularly for black Americans and members of the Times' staff. However, it is not the duty of the newspaper to shield readers from uncomfortable truths or potential risks. Rather, it is the responsibility of the paper to provide accurate and comprehensive information, even if it is unpleasant or challenging to consider.

Ultimately, the publication of Senator Cotton's Op-Ed serves as a reminder of the importance of having access to a wide range of perspectives and ideas, even if they are uncomfortable or unpopular. By providing a platform for diverse viewpoints, The New York Times is fulfilling its role as a newspaper of record and a champion of free speech.

**Russian Rouble Slumps to Lowest Level Since 2016 Amid US Sanctions**

The Russian rouble has fallen to its lowest level since November 2016, following the announcement of new US sanctions against Russia. The dollar-rouble rate reached 66.7 on the Moscow stock exchange, a significant drop from Tuesday's rate of 63.4.

The sanctions were imposed in response to the poisoning of ex-Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in the UK in March. The pair were exposed to the Russian nerve agent Novichok, although they have since recovered.

The share values of major Russian firms, including Aeroflot, Rusal, and Sberbank, also fell several percentage points in Moscow. The euro gained against the rouble, with the rate reaching 76.8.

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova stated that Moscow would prepare a response to the "unfriendly act" by the US, but did not elaborate. She also accused the US of trying to "demonize" Russia.

The UK investigation concluded that Russia was responsible for the Novichok attack, and the UK and its Western allies expelled many Russian diplomats in response. Russia retaliated with its own expulsions.

The new sanctions, which will take effect on or around August 22, cover exports of sensitive electronic components and other technologies that can have military applications. There will also be some further restrictions on Russian access to US financial services.

The US State Department stated that "more draconian" sanctions will follow within 90 days if Russia fails to provide reliable assurances that it will no longer use chemical weapons and will allow on-site inspections by the United Nations. The threatened measures include a far-reaching trade embargo on Russia, excluding food, and a ban on Aeroflot flights to the US.

This is the third time the US has determined a country has used chemical or biological weapons against its own nationals, following previous instances in Syria and North Korea.

Title: Prisons and Jails Become Hotspots for COVID-19 as Inmates and Staff Suffer

The COVID-19 pandemic has spread rapidly through the United States, affecting not only the general population but also the country's correctional facilities. The Federal Correctional Complex in Oakdale, Louisiana, has seen a significant outbreak, with seven inmates dying and over 100 infected, including staff members. The virus has also affected Cook County Jail in Illinois, with four inmates and 215 staff members testing positive.

Prisons and jails are particularly vulnerable to the spread of the virus due to the close living quarters and lack of social distancing. Inmates and staff are often in close contact, making it easy for the virus to spread. The situation is dire, with many inmates and staff members at risk of contracting the virus.

The article highlights the need for increased testing, social distancing, and protective measures in correctional facilities. It also emphasizes the importance of releasing non-violent offenders, the elderly, and vulnerable individuals to reduce the risk of transmission. The article also notes that many prisons and jails are not testing inmates and staff regularly, making it difficult to track the spread of the virus.

The article also mentions the concerns of corrections officers, who are at risk of contracting the virus and spreading it to their families and communities. The article concludes by emphasizing the need for the government to take immediate action to protect the lives of inmates and staff in correctional facilities.

Overall, the article provides a factual and informative overview of the spread of COVID-19 in correctional facilities and the need for increased measures to protect the lives of those affected.

Title: Democratic Lawmaker John Conyers Admits to Settling Sexual Harassment Complaint

Article:

Democratic Representative John Conyers, from Michigan, has acknowledged settling a complaint with an ex-staffer who alleged sexual harassment. The staffer claimed she was fired after rebuffing Conyers' advances. Initially, Conyers denied any knowledge of the allegations, but his office later confirmed the complaint was real.

According to BuzzFeed News, the allegations against Conyers include claims of requesting sexual favors, rubbing staff members' hands and legs, and making inappropriate comments. The woman who filed the complaint, who remains anonymous due to fears of retribution, claimed she was dismissed because she did not succumb to Conyers' advances. She received a roughly $27,000 settlement in 2015.

Conyers' office stated that the settlement was a "reasonable severance payment" and that the allegations are not true. Conyers himself has denied the allegations, saying that the mere making of an allegation does not make it true. He has also expressed his support for equality in the workplace and his commitment to fully cooperating with any investigation.

The allegations against Conyers are the latest in a series of high-profile sexual harassment claims rocking Capitol Hill. House Speaker Paul Ryan has called the report "extremely troubling" and has directed the Committee on House Administration to conduct a full review of policies and procedures related to workplace harassment and discrimination.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi has also commented on the matter, stating that she was not aware of the reported settlement involving Conyers and that the current process includes the signing of non-disclosure agreements by the parties involved. She also pointed to new legislation aimed at providing transparency on these agreements and making critical reforms.

The Michigan Democratic Party has called for a full investigation by the House Ethics Committee into the allegations against Conyers, and the Chairman of the Michigan Democratic Party has expressed disappointment and concern over the allegations.

Title: US Senator John McCain Diagnosed with Brain Cancer, Undergoing Treatment

Article:

Veteran US Republican Senator John McCain has been diagnosed with brain cancer and is currently undergoing treatment, according to his office. The 80-year-old politician underwent surgery to remove a blood clot from above his left eye last week, which revealed a primary brain tumor known as glioblastoma. His doctors are considering a combination of chemotherapy and radiation as treatment options.

McCain, a Vietnam veteran and six-term senator, is recovering at home and is said to be in "good spirits." He has thanked those who have wished him well and expressed his gratitude for the outpouring of support.

The senator's diagnosis has prompted an outpouring of support from both Republicans and Democrats, with many expressing their well-wishes for his recovery. McCain's family has also reacted with "shock" to the news, with his daughter Meghan stating that her father is "meeting this challenge as he has every other" and will not surrender to cancer.

President Donald Trump, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and former President Barack Obama have all issued statements wishing McCain a speedy recovery. Trump described McCain as "always a fighter," while McConnell called him a "hero to our country." Obama tweeted that McCain is "an American hero and one of the bravest fighters I've ever known."

McCain's diagnosis comes as a shock to many, given his history of overcoming adversity. As a prisoner of war in Vietnam, he was repeatedly beaten and tortured, and was never again able to raise his arms above his head. Despite this, he went on to become a respected senator and presidential candidate, known for his independent-mindedness and willingness to challenge the status quo.

Title: Army Warns of Devastating Impact of Budget Cuts on Readiness and Modernization

The United States Army is sounding the alarm about the potential consequences of automatic budget cuts, known as sequestration, on its ability to execute its defense strategic guidance. In an internal memo, Major General Laura Richardson, chief of Army legislative affairs, warned that unless relief is provided, the Army will be unable to fully execute its requirements and will be on a path to a "hollow Army."

The memo, obtained by The ███, highlights the devastating impact of sequestration on the Army's readiness, manpower, and modernization programs. The Army's active-duty force peaked at 570,000 during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, but is slated to shrink to around 450,000. Sequestration threatens to further reduce the force to 420,000.

Army Chief of Staff General Raymond T. Odierno has been vocal about the potential consequences of sequestration, warning that it will come close to breaking the Army. He has stated that the 450,000 level is the absolute lowest the active force can go and still carry out its strategic responsibilities.

Recent deployments have shown a busy U.S. Army, with forces sent to Europe to deter Russian aggression, deployed to Baghdad to advise the Iraqi Security Forces, and inserted into West Africa to help combat the Ebola virus. The Army has also maintained ground units in Afghanistan.

In an interview, General Odierno told the Army Times that more budget cuts will take the Army to a "breaking point." He stated that he would have to further reduce purchases of weapons systems needed to modernize a war-weary force. "As I look at that, it's end strength, it's modernization, it's readiness," he said. "I can't go any faster on end strength, so that means you have to take further reductions in readiness and modernization."

Title: Gun Violence Prevention Groups Launch Voting Rights Campaign to Highlight Link Between Democracy and Gun Violence

Gun-violence prevention organizations March For Our Lives, Brady, and Team Enough have launched a joint campaign, "Voting Access Saves Lives," to emphasize the connection between gun violence prevention and democracy. The campaign focuses on four categories: voting by mail and absentee voting, voter registration, early voting, and restoration of voting rights. The groups are releasing tool kits aimed at addressing voter access in 10 states they believe can enact change: Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Texas, and Wisconsin.

The report, "Accessing Democracy: A Gun Violence Issue," highlights the importance of voting rights, particularly for communities disproportionately affected by gun violence. The report notes that these communities have been historically marginalized and excluded from the democratic process, depriving them of the avenues necessary for citizens to have agency in their own future.

The tool kits provide information voters may want ahead of Election Day, including polling location and voter registration information, vote-by-mail and absentee voting laws, and early voting options. The kits also include "action plans" for each state, outlining steps citizens can take to advocate for voting rights. For example, the Arizona kit instructs voters to contact Governor Doug Ducey and Secretary of State Katie Hobbs, as well as mayors and city council members, to request actions such as mailing ballots to eligible voters and providing personal protective equipment to poll workers.

The campaign aims to ensure that all citizens can participate in the electoral process and have a say in the policies that affect their lives. The groups believe that a flawed electoral system and voter suppression are major obstacles to achieving this goal. The Voting Access Saves Lives coalition is committed to ensuring that communities are able to vote for elected officials who represent their beliefs in free and fair elections.

The campaign is not limited to voting rights; it also addresses the broader issue of gun violence prevention. The groups believe that ensuring voting rights is a crucial step towards achieving their goal of reducing gun violence. By highlighting the connection between democracy and gun violence, the campaign aims to empower citizens to take action and advocate for change.

The campaign's localized approach is designed to engage citizens in the states where they can make a difference. The groups are distributing the report and tool kits to hundreds of chapters and networks of gun-violence prevention organizations. The campaign's leaders believe that by taking a localized approach, they can mobilize citizens to advocate for voting rights and gun violence prevention in their own communities.

Title: NHTSA's Vehicle Safety Ratings: A Look at the Evolution and Effectiveness

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has been providing consumers with information on the crash protection and rollover safety of new vehicles since 1978. The agency awards up to five stars to vehicles based on various safety measures, with a high rating serving as a powerful government seal of approval for automakers. An analysis by The Times of individual ratings since 2001, obtained from Edmunds.com, shows that almost every model has attained high marks.

From 2001 to 2010, 87% of all safety ratings awarded through the program were four or five stars. However, in 2011, the agency introduced new standards to make it tougher to score high and added an overall safety rating. The program raised the safety bar by implementing more stringent crash tests, making it harder for vehicles to achieve the top ratings of five stars.

Despite this, the ratings have continued to edge higher. For models from 2011 to the present, 92% of overall safety ratings were four or five-star ratings, according to the analysis. The percentage of four and five-star overall ratings increased each year, from 83% for 2011 models to 96% for 2015 models.

While the NHTSA's ratings program has been successful in promoting safer vehicles, some critics argue that it has become too lenient. Jack Gillis, a former NHTSA official and independent rating publisher, believes that the government could stimulate competition among automakers by presenting the information on a more relative basis.

Title: President Obama Discusses NSA Surveillance Programs, Acknowledges Concerns and Need for Improved Safeguards

President Barack Obama addressed concerns about National Security Agency (NSA) surveillance programs during a CNN interview on Friday, acknowledging that while the programs are necessary, they can be easily abused if not properly monitored. Obama expressed understanding of the public's skepticism, stating that the American people need to be confident that their emails and phone calls are not being monitored without their knowledge.

The president noted that the NSA's surveillance programs have raised concerns about the balance between national security and individual privacy. He emphasized the need for improved safeguards to ensure that the programs are not misused, citing the potential for technology to outpace laws and protections in place.

The NSA's programs were first revealed by former federal contractor Edward Snowden, who has been charged with espionage and other offenses. While Obama expressed confidence that the NSA is not currently abusing its surveillance powers, he acknowledged that the public's trust must be earned through transparency and accountability.

The president's comments come as the NSA's activities have been under scrutiny following recent disclosures that the agency monitored as many as 56,000 emails and electronic communications of Americans over a three-year period, despite having no connection to terrorism. Obama emphasized the need for continued improvement of safeguards and oversight to address public concerns and maintain trust in the government's ability to balance national security and individual privacy.

Title: Obama Defends Bergdahl Deal, Says Administration Consulted Congress "For Some Time"

Article:

President Barack Obama defended his administration's efforts to rescue Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl from captivity, stating that bringing an American soldier home is a "pretty sacred rule" in the United States. Obama emphasized that the focus should be on recovering Bergdahl, rather than debating the circumstances surrounding his capture.

The President acknowledged that there are questions surrounding Bergdahl's conduct, but emphasized that officials are focused on helping him recover from the stresses of his captivity. He also noted that the Army's leaders will investigate any allegations of misconduct if they occur.

The White House did not notify lawmakers about the prisoner swap with the Taliban until after the fact, with the formal notification coming on Monday. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Mich.) pushed back on the administration's assertion that they had consulted with Congress "for some time," stating that they had not heard any details on the prisoner exchange since 2011.

Obama argued that his administration did what was right and appropriate in bringing Bergdahl home, and that the decision was made to seize an opportunity to rescue an American soldier. He also addressed concerns about the release of five Taliban members in exchange for Bergdahl, stating that their release was conditioned on the Qataris keeping eyes on them and creating a structure to monitor their activities.

The President emphasized that the United States has a "pretty sacred rule" of not leaving its soldiers behind, and that the focus should be on recovering Bergdahl rather than debating the circumstances surrounding his capture.

Title: NSA Director Rogers Expresses Skepticism Over Proposed US-Russia Cyber Unit

The National Security Agency (NSA) Director Mike Rogers has expressed doubts about the feasibility of a proposed US-Russia cyber unit, a concept that has been met with skepticism by several senior US lawmakers and has seen President Donald Trump seemingly back away from the idea. The proposal was initially discussed during the Group of 20 summit in Hamburg, where Trump met with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The idea of a joint cyber security working group was put forth by a Russian presidential envoy, but US intelligence agencies have assessed that Russia meddled in the 2016 US presidential election by hacking Democrats' emails and distributing online propaganda to aid Trump's campaign. Moscow has denied any interference, and Trump has said that his campaign did not collude with Russia.

Rogers, speaking at the Aspen Security Forum, stated that he is not a policy expert and believes that now may not be the best time to establish such a unit. He noted that any progress would require changes in Russia's behavior. Trump had earlier expressed interest in the idea, but later appeared to backtrack, saying on Twitter that the fact that he and Putin discussed the concept does not mean it will happen.

The proposal has sparked widespread concern and confusion, reflecting the Trump administration's struggles to articulate a clear approach to international cyber security issues amid inconsistent statements by the president and ongoing personnel changes.

Title: US Military Sees Opportunity to Take Out Islamic State Fighters in Kobani

The intense fighting in the Syrian border town of Kobani has created an opportunity for the US military to target large numbers of Islamic State (IS) fighters, according to military and White House officials. Despite concerns that the town could still fall to the IS, Army Gen. Lloyd Austin, head of US Central Command, believes there is an upside for the US and its allies.

The IS is amassing fighters and resources in Kobani, creating a "target-rich environment" for American and coalition air strikes, said White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest. The US military is taking advantage of this opportunity to strike clusters of fighters and depots of material and supplies critical to the IS's success.

While the US military is touting the opportunity to take out a large number of targets in Kobani, officials are cautioning against expecting quick progress in the overall campaign against the IS. The campaign to destroy the IS will take time, and there will be occasional setbacks along the way, said Austin.

The US military is also working to enlist the support of Sunni tribal leaders in Anbar province to turn the tide in that important region, where the IS has made recent gains. The Pentagon is preparing to set up a more formally organized command structure, known as a joint task force, to lead and coordinate the campaign from a forward headquarters, possibly in Kuwait.

As of Thursday, the US had launched nearly 300 airstrikes in Iraq and nearly 200 in Syria, and allies had tallied fewer than 100. The US and partner-nation air forces had dropped nearly 1,400 munitions as of Wednesday.

**Russian Airliner Crashes Minutes After Takeoff, Killing All 71 On Board**

A Russian airliner, an Antonov An-148 regional jet, crashed minutes after takeoff from Moscow's Domodedovo Airport on Sunday, resulting in the deaths of all 65 passengers and six crew members on board. The plane was operated by Saratov Airlines and was headed to Orsk, approximately 1,000 miles southeast of Moscow.

According to the Moscow Inter-Regional Transport Prosecutor's Office, all people on board the plane died in the crash. The plane's black box was found at the crash site, and authorities have cordoned off the area.

The crew did not report any malfunctions before the crash, and the cause of the incident remains unknown. Weather conditions and pilot error are among the possible reasons being investigated. The Russian Investigative Committee has launched an investigation into the crash, and all possible causes are being examined.

The passengers on board the airliner were believed to be residents of the Orenburg region, which is the destination of the flight. Russian President Vladimir Putin has postponed a planned trip to Sochi and offered his condolences to the families of those killed. A special commission has been set up to investigate the crash, and relevant agencies are conducting search operations.

Fragments of the jet were found in the Ramenskoye area, about 25 miles from the airport, with no on-ground casualties reported. The flight took off from Moscow's Domodedovo Airport and spent about 5 minutes in the air before a signal was lost about 12 miles southeast of the airport.

The Russian Emergencies Ministry said the recovery process would involve up to 300 people, and the crash scene was only accessible on foot due to weather conditions. The Antonov An-148 jet had been in service since 2010, with a two-year break due to a shortage of parts.

Title: Former FEMA Director James Lee Witt Considers Running in Arkansas, Boosting Democratic Recruiting Efforts

The ongoing fiscal crises in Washington have given a much-needed boost to Democratic candidate recruitment efforts, with several high-profile Democrats reconsidering their decisions not to run in key congressional races. The shutdown and debt ceiling standoff have made it difficult for Republicans to maintain their strong approval ratings, and many Democratic candidates are now jumping at the opportunity to challenge them.

In Nebraska, Omaha city councilman Pete Festersen has announced his bid to unseat eight-term incumbent GOP Rep. Lee Terry, citing the government shutdown as a major reason for his decision. Festersen had previously declined to run against Terry, but the shutdown's impact on the district's residents has changed his mind.

Similarly, attorney Bill Hughes Jr. from New Jersey is likely to run against longtime GOP Rep. Frank LoBiondo, after months of hesitation. Indiana Democrat Joe Bock, a University of Notre Dame official, has also reconsidered his decision not to run, citing the shutdown's impact on the district.

Other notable Democratic recruits include James Lee Witt, the former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency under former President Bill Clinton, who is considering running for the seat being vacated by Republican Rep. Tom Cotton in Arkansas. Alex Sink, the former chief financial officer of Florida, is also considering running for a seat in the St. Petersburg area.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has been actively courting these candidates, providing them with polling data and other support to help them win their respective races. While it's unclear how lasting the damage will be to the GOP brand, the shutdown and debt ceiling standoff have given Democrats a much-needed boost in their recruiting efforts.

The DCCC has been trying to woo candidates who can compete in conservative districts, and the shutdown has made those sales pitches more compelling. Vice President Joe Biden has even made personal calls to some of these candidates, including Festersen and Witt, in an effort to get them to run.

While it's still unclear whether these new recruits will be able to make a significant impact in the 2014 elections, the shutdown and debt ceiling standoff have given Democrats a much-needed shot in the arm.

Title: Attorney General Sessions' Testimony Contradicted by Report of Meetings with Russian Ambassador

The Washington Post has published a report that contradicts Attorney General Jeff Sessions' previous testimony about his interactions with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign. According to the report, Sessions spoke twice with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, including during the height of Russia's alleged cyber campaign to influence the election.

During his confirmation hearing in January, Sessions told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he had no communication with Russian officials during the campaign. However, the Post's report reveals that Sessions met with Kislyak on two occasions, including one meeting that took place during the height of Russia's alleged cyber campaign.

The report has sparked controversy and raised questions about the accuracy of Sessions' testimony. Some have argued that Sessions' statement was misleading, while others have pointed out that there is ambiguity about whether Sessions was referring to his work as a campaign surrogate or as a senator.

Sessions' spokesperson has denied any wrongdoing, stating that the senator had over 25 conversations with foreign ambassadors as a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, including the Russian ambassador. However, the Post's report suggests that Sessions' contact with Kislyak was unusual, as none of the 20 members of the committee who responded to the Post's inquiry reported meeting with the Russian ambassador.

The controversy surrounding Sessions' testimony is just the latest in a string of scandals surrounding the Trump administration's ties to Russia. Last month, former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn was forced to resign after it was revealed that he had spoken with Kislyak in December and may have suggested that Trump would lift sanctions against Russia.

Democrats have called on Sessions to recuse himself from any investigation into Trump's ties to the Justice Department and have demanded an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate the Trump-Russia scandal.

Title: Trump's Gun Control Push Faces Skepticism as Political Realities Remain Unchanged

Article:

In the aftermath of the Florida school shooting, there was a sense that something was different this time, with the activism of teenagers and the push for gun law reform gaining momentum. However, as lawmakers returned to Washington, it became clear that the political realities on the Second Amendment remained as entrenched as ever.

Despite President Donald Trump's promise to "turn our grief into action," his administration's proposals for gun control have been met with skepticism. Trump has called for steps to "harden" US schools and strengthen background checks, but his proposals have been criticized as insufficient by gun control advocates.

The White House is considering expanding background checks to gun shows and private transactions, but it is unclear whether this will be enough to satisfy gun control advocates. Trump has also stopped talking about raising the age limit for buying long guns from 18 to 21, a proposal that was met with resistance from some Republicans.

The political constraints that have frozen the gun debate remain strong, with pro-Second Amendment Republicans dominating Congress. While some Republicans, such as Sen. Pat Toomey and Joe Manchin, have expressed support for universal background checks, others, like Sen. Orrin Hatch and John Kennedy, have expressed skepticism.

Sen. Chuck Schumer, the Senate Minority Leader, has called for universal background checks on gun purchases, but it is unclear whether this will be achievable. Sen. John Cornyn, a top Republican, has suggested that universal background checks are not legislatively possible.

The White House has announced that Trump will meet with lawmakers on Wednesday to try to forge a way forward, but it remains to be seen whether any significant action will be taken.

Title: Hong Kong Government Withdraws Controversial Extradition Bill, But Protesters Demand More

The Hong Kong government has announced the full withdrawal of the extradition bill that sparked a three-month-long pro-democracy movement, ceding to one of the five demands protesters have been making. The bill, which would have allowed the Chinese government to extradite anyone present in Hong Kong, including non-residents and foreigners, to the Chinese prison system, has been widely criticized for its potential to undermine Hong Kong's autonomy and human rights.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam made the announcement in a public address, stating that the government is withdrawing the bill to "fully allay public concerns." However, she also blamed the peaceful protest movement for the violence and chaos that has engulfed the city, saying that citizens, police, and reporters have been injured, and that roads and tunnels have been blocked.

Lam also announced that she would modify the membership of the Independent Police Complaints Commission, a nod to one of the remaining four demands – an independent inquiry on police brutality against protesters. However, protesters have expressed concerns that the police would exonerate itself of human rights crimes if it conducts the investigation.

The withdrawal of the bill is seen as a significant concession by the government, but protesters have called it "too little and too late." They are demanding four other changes: freedom for political prisoners, direct election of lawmakers, an apology for calling the June 12 protest a "riot," and an independent inquiry into police brutality.

Prior to the withdrawal, Lam had refused to withdraw the bill, saying it was "dead" in July. However, protesters have pointed out that tabling a bill keeps it alive and allows lawmakers to revive it at any time. The government's decision to withdraw the bill has been met with skepticism, with some questioning whether it is a genuine concession or just a tactic to placate the public.

The withdrawal comes after a bombshell report by Reuters revealed audio of Lam saying she would like to resign as chief executive, but is not allowed. Lam has conceded that the audio is real, but claimed that her choice of words was taken out of context. Protest leaders have called Lam's withdrawal of the bill "too little and too late," and vowed to continue their struggle for freedom from China.

**Trump Tweets on North Korea: "The World is Watching"**

In a recent tweet, President Trump expressed cautious optimism about the possibility of progress in talks with North Korea, stating that the world is watching and waiting. The tweet comes after a rare two-day visit by South Korea's national security director, Chung Eui-yong, to Pyongyang, where he met with North Korean officials to discuss denuclearization and normalization between the two countries.

According to Chung, North Korea is willing to give up its nuclear weapons if military threats against it subside and its regime is guaranteed. The North has also agreed not to attempt any strategic provocations, such as nuclear and ballistic missile tests, while dialogue continues.

The visit marks a significant shift in tone from North Korea's previous threats to continue developing its nuclear and missile program. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has called for continued international pressure on North Korea, stating that its nuclear and ballistic missile programs pose a global threat.

The development comes after a flurry of cooperative steps taken during the Pyeongchang Olympics, which sparked the first talks between the two Koreas. North Korea sent a delegation of athletes, cheerleaders, and officials to the games, and Kim's sister, Kim Yo Jong, met with South Korean President Moon Jae-in during a three-day visit.

While some experts believe Kim's proposal is genuine, others remain cautious, noting that the devil is in the details. The international community will be watching closely to see how North Korea follows through on its promises and whether the United States will respond positively to the overture.

Title: Presidential Candidate Tulsi Gabbard Responds to Hillary Clinton's Suggestion She's a Russian Asset

Article:

Presidential candidate Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) has responded to a suggestion made by former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton that she is the "favorite of the Russians" in the 2020 election. Clinton made the comment during an interview with David Plouffe, host of the podcast "Campaign HQ," without specifically naming Gabbard. However, it was clear that she was referring to the Hawaii congresswoman, who has had to repeatedly deny accusations of being a Russian asset.

Gabbard took to Twitter to respond to Clinton's comments, calling her the "embodiment of corruption" and "personification of the rot that has sickened the Democratic Party." She also accused Clinton of being behind a concerted campaign to destroy her reputation since she announced her candidacy.

Gabbard has faced ongoing concerns from political observers that her campaign is being amplified by Russian bots and online trolls, and has raised eyebrows with her anti-establishment foreign policy positions, including her accusation that the U.S. engages in regime-change wars and her meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad in 2017.

According to the RealClearPolitics polling average, Gabbard is currently polling at 1.2 percent nationally, making her one of the lower-tier candidates to make this week's primary debate in Ohio.

Title: Iran Denies Responsibility for Downing of Ukrainian Passenger Plane, Citing Lack of Evidence

Iranian officials have denied reports from American and European intelligence agencies that the country shot down a civilian passenger plane shortly after attacking U.S. positions in Iraq. The Ukrainian International Airlines Flight 752 from Tehran to Kyiv was allegedly shot down by an anti-aircraft missile battery, according to U.S. officials. President Trump suggested on Thursday that the incident was the result of an error, saying "somebody could have made a mistake on the other side."

Iran's aviation department head, Ali Abedzadeh, stated at a press conference that "what is obvious for us, and what we can say with certainty, is that no missile hit the plane." Abedzadeh also invited officials from Boeing to join the investigation and share their findings.

The head of the Iranian investigative team, Hassan Rezaeifar, said Iran would not share the aircraft's black box flight recorders until the country had completed a study of them. The team may reach out to international experts if it is unable to extract the recordings, but the investigation could take over a month to fully retrieve the black box data. After that, the investigation itself could continue for up to a year.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed that Canadian intelligence believed the crash was caused by a missile strike. At least 63 Canadian citizens were on board the aircraft. "The evidence indicates that the plane was shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile," Trudeau said on Thursday.

In total, 176 people died in the crash, mostly Iranian and Canadian citizens. While Ukraine International Airlines has yet to comment on the incident, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said his country "will conduct a detailed and independent investigation" into the crash.

Title: Trump's Rise and Resilience in the Republican Primary
