The article discusses the rise and resilience of Donald Trump in the Republican primary, highlighting his ability to maintain a strong grip on the Republican primary voter despite controversies and setbacks. According to the article, Trump's handlers have kept him off news interview shows and away from major policy pronouncements, and he has run very little in the way of paid media. However, Trump's overwhelming triumph in New York and leads in all five states set to vote in the coming week suggest he will get the overwhelming share of the 267 delegates to be selected, putting him less than 100 votes shy of 1,000 delegates.

The article also notes that Trump's opponents, such as Ted Cruz, could potentially block his path to the nomination by winning key states like Pennsylvania and Indiana. However, Trump's strong performance among Republican voters, particularly white voters, has allowed him to maintain a dominant position.

The article also touches on Trump's potential general election prospects, noting that he has a 10-point problem in terms of his national poll numbers, running 10 points worse among women against Hillary Clinton. However, the article suggests that Trump could still win the general election, citing the potential impact of the FBI investigation into Clinton's State emails and Trump's ability to rally Sanders voters who share his opposition to trade deals and refusal to take super-PAC money.

Overall, the article provides an analysis of Trump's rise and resilience in the Republican primary, highlighting his ability to maintain a strong grip on the Republican primary voter and his potential prospects in the general election.

Title: Fifteen Years After 9/11: A Nation's Evolution and the Ongoing Struggle Against Terrorism

The article reflects on the 15th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, which had a profound impact on American society. The author notes that the country has changed significantly since then, with increased security measures and a heightened sense of awareness about terrorism. However, despite these efforts, terrorism continues to be a persistent threat, with numerous attacks occurring around the world.

The article raises several questions about the effectiveness of the measures taken to combat terrorism, including the role of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and the National Security Agency (NSA). It also questions whether the war on terror has been successful and whether the country has made the right decisions in its response to the attacks.

The article also touches on the impact of the 9/11 attacks on American society, noting that the country has become more divided and that some people are no longer as concerned about terrorism. It also notes that the war on terror has been ongoing for 15 years, with no signs of it ending.

The article concludes by noting that the country is stuck in a duality, trying to balance the need for security with the need for freedom. It also notes that the terrorists did not win on 9/11, but America is not the same, and the country faces a tireless enemy who continually tries to test its good nature.

The article provides a neutral and factual account of the 15th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, raising important questions about the effectiveness of the measures taken to combat terrorism and the impact of the attacks on American society.

Title: Julie Swetnick's Credibility Questioned as She Walks Back Some Claims Against Brett Kavanaugh

Article:

Julie Swetnick, a woman who made uncorroborated and lurid sexual assault allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, is facing credibility questions as she appears to partially walk back some of her more salacious claims. In a sworn statement last month, Swetnick claimed she had seen Kavanaugh "engage in abusive and physically aggressive behavior toward girls" and alleged that he and his friend Mark Judge were involved in a scheme to spike the punch at parties with drugs or alcohol to lower girls' defenses and get them disoriented so they could be "gang raped" in a side room by a "train" of boys.

However, in an interview with NBC News, Swetnick appeared to walk back some of the claims about Kavanaugh, while standing by her claims of sexually aggressive behavior. She said she was unclear about what Kavanaugh was doing, but saw him giving red solo cups to girls during parties and being around the punch containers. She also clarified that while she saw Kavanaugh and Judge at the party and other boys were gathered, she "can not specifically say that he was one of the ones who assaulted me."

Swetnick's shifting and uncorroborated claims have led to questions about her credibility. The FBI is currently conducting a background investigation into sexual assault claims made against Kavanaugh, and the agency is expected to wrap up its investigation by Friday.

Swetnick has struggled to provide corroborating witnesses, with only one of the four names she provided to NBC News backing up her story. Two of the others did not respond to requests, and one said he did not remember Swetnick and did not think he had socialized with her.

Kavanaugh has denied the allegations, and Judge has said he "categorically" denies them. Swetnick's lawyer, Michael Avenatti, has said she is willing to take a polygraph test and has done "significant due diligence" before going ahead with the allegations. However, some have questioned the motives behind the allegations, with Republican Sen. Bill Cassidy suggesting the FBI scrutinize Swetnick in a tweet.

The controversy surrounding Swetnick's allegations has also led to questions about her past, including a lawsuit she was involved in 2000 for allegedly falsifying her educational background and concocting false sexual harassment allegations. The suit was voluntarily dismissed by her former employer, Webtrends, shortly afterwards.

Title: Trump's Path to Clinching Republican Nomination Remains Unclear, But Possible

The Republican presidential primary season is approaching its final stretch, with Donald Trump still in the running to clinch the nomination before the July convention in Cleveland. While his path is narrow and perilous, Trump can still achieve this goal by winning a significant number of delegates in the remaining primaries and caucuses.

Trump's rivals, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich, can only hope to stop him, but it's a challenging task. Trump is the only candidate with a realistic chance of reaching the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination before the convention.

The next crucial step for Trump is the New York primary on Tuesday, where he needs to win a big majority of the 95 delegates at stake. If he can achieve this, he'll be closer to reaching the magic number. However, it won't be easy, as he'll have to win a significant portion of the statewide vote and congressional districts.

In the following weeks, Trump will face more challenges in the remaining primaries and caucuses. He'll need to perform well in Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, and Rhode Island, where a total of 172 delegates are up for grabs. He'll also need to win a significant number of delegates in Indiana, Nebraska, West Virginia, Oregon, and Washington State, where a total of 199 delegates are at stake.

On June 7, the final day of the primary season, Trump will need to win a big majority of California's congressional districts to clinch the nomination. If he can achieve this, he'll win a significant number of delegates and bring him closer to the 1,237 mark.

While Trump's path to clinching the nomination is still uncertain, it's not impossible. He'll need to perform well in the remaining primaries and caucuses, but it's still within his reach.

Title: NSA Denies Collecting Millions of Phone Records Across Europe, Citing Foreign Intelligence Agency Data

The National Security Agency (NSA) Director, Gen. Keith Alexander, has denied recent reports that the agency is collecting millions of phone records across Europe. In congressional testimony, Alexander stated that the reports were "completely false." The comment was part of a House Intelligence Committee hearing focused on improving information gathering and privacy protections.

The hearing took place amid an international uproar over reports that the NSA monitored the cellphone of German Chancellor Angela Merkel for a decade, part of a pattern of the agency eavesdropping on friendly countries' leaders. Officials at the hearing did not deny that such spying takes place, instead, their answers raised questions about the extent of the spying and the White House's knowledge of it.

Director of National Intelligence James Clapper responded to questions about the importance of gaining access to foreign leaders' communications, stating that knowing "leadership intentions" is crucial. When asked if America's allies conduct espionage on the US, Clapper confirmed that they do, citing the importance of understanding "leadership intentions."

The NSA's Alexander explained that the data in question, provided by Edward Snowden to European media, was actually collected by foreign intelligence agencies, often in war zones of crucial security interest to the US and its European allies. He emphasized that the data was not collected on European citizens, but rather was gathered in defense of countries and in support of military operations.

The hearing also discussed proposed reforms to the NSA's program for bulk collection of communications under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). A bipartisan group of lawmakers proposed discontinuing the program, while another group would keep it intact with strengthened privacy protections. The House Intelligence Committee's top Democrat, Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger, emphasized the importance of the program in connecting the dots of brewing terrorist activities, but also called for FISA reforms to increase transparency and privacy protections.

The NSA's Alexander concluded that the agency's operations are getting things right, citing the absence of mass casualty attacks in the US since 9/11. However, he also acknowledged the need for improvement and openness to change.

Title: Retired Neurosurgeon Ben Carson Endorses Donald Trump as Republican Presidential Nominee

Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon and former presidential candidate, has officially endorsed Donald Trump as the Republican nominee for president. Carson made the announcement alongside Trump at Mar-a-Lago, Trump's luxury club in Palm Beach, on Friday.

During a press conference, Carson stated that he has found philosophical and spiritual alignment with Trump, citing their discussions on various topics. When asked about his decision, Carson emphasized the need to empower the people and create an equal playing field, stating that this cannot be achieved through traditional politics.

Carson also mentioned that he and Trump discussed education and improving schools during their meeting earlier in the week. According to sources close to Carson, the two met in Palm Beach and reached an agreement on several issues.

In an interview with Fox News Radio, Carson hinted at his potential involvement with the Trump campaign, saying he is "leaning" towards supporting Trump. Carson also noted that there are "two Donald Trumps" - the one seen on television and the one he has gotten to know behind the scenes.

This endorsement marks a significant development in the Republican primary race, as Carson was a prominent candidate who dropped out of the race last week. The endorsement is seen as a significant boost for Trump, who has been gaining momentum in the polls.

**Ross Perot, Self-Made Billionaire and Two-Time Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89**

Ross Perot, a self-made billionaire and two-time presidential candidate, has passed away at the age of 89 after a five-month battle with leukemia. Perot, a native-born Texan, made his fortune by founding Electronic Data Systems Corp. and was known for his business acumen and patriotic spirit.

Perot's first presidential bid in 1992 saw him win 19% of the vote as a third-party candidate, making him the most successful third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt's 1912 bid. His second campaign in 1996 garnered 8% of the vote, but the Reform Party he founded began to disintegrate. Despite this, Perot's ideas on trade and deficit reduction remained a part of the political landscape, and he continued to speak out about federal spending for many years.

Born in Texarkana, Texas, on June 27, 1930, Perot's early life was marked by hard work and financial prudence, which helped his family survive the Great Depression. He went on to attend the U.S. Naval Academy and later joined International Business Machines (IBM) before founding Electronic Data Systems in 1962 with a $1,000 loan from his wife, Margot.

EDS's big break came in the mid-1960s when the federal government created Medicare and Medicaid, and the company won contracts to handle the millions of claims. The company went public in 1968, making Perot an overnight billionaire. He sold control of EDS to General Motors Corp. in 1984 and received a $700 million buyout. He later established another computer-services company, Perot Systems Corp., which was sold to Dell Inc. in 2009.

Perot's net worth was estimated to be $3.5 billion in 2011, according to Forbes magazine, making him one of the richest Americans. Despite his passing, Perot's legacy as a successful entrepreneur and presidential candidate will be remembered for years to come.

Title: Trump Threatens to Close Southern Border and Cut Aid to Central American Countries

President Donald Trump warned on Friday that if Democrats do not agree to fund his proposed border wall, he will consider closing the Southern border entirely and cutting aid to Central American countries. In a series of tweets, Trump stated that he will "be forced to close the Southern Border entirely" if the Democratic Party does not provide the necessary funding for the wall and change the current immigration laws.

Trump also threatened to pull back on trade with Mexico, citing the country's trade deficit with the United States. He claimed that the country loses "soooo much money" on trade with Mexico, with an estimated $75 billion per year, and suggested that closing the Southern Border could become a "profit-making operation."

The President also threatened to terminate aid to Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, stating that these countries are doing "nothing for the United States but taking our money." He referred to reports of a new caravan of migrants planning to leave Honduras in January.

The tweetstorm came amid the ongoing partial government shutdown, which has entered its second week. The shutdown began after Republicans and Democrats failed to agree on a funding package that would keep the government open and fund Trump's proposed border wall. Democrats have offered $1.3 billion for general border security, but Trump has refused, demanding $5 billion for the wall.

There are no signs of the impasse ending anytime soon, with both sides refusing to budge. A member of the House Republican leadership told a news outlet that a resolution may not emerge until the new year.

The President's threats have sparked concerns about the potential consequences of closing the Southern border, including economic and humanitarian impacts. A cut-off of trade relations with Mexico could also risk a new agreement that DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen announced this month, which calls for immigrants claiming asylum in the U.S. to be returned to Mexico as their cases are processed.

In response to Trump's threats, Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi's deputy chief of staff, Drew Hammill, stated that Democrats have offered Republicans three options to re-open government, all of which include funding for strong, sensible, and effective border security, but not the President's "immoral, ineffective, and expensive wall."

Title: Trump Accused of "Unprecedented Pattern of Obstruction" as He Resists Congressional Investigations

The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Oversight Committee, Representative Elijah Cummings, has accused President Donald Trump of an "unprecedented pattern of obstruction" after he ordered federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations. The president has refused to cooperate with multiple investigations, including those into his tax returns, White House security clearances, and the probe of Russian interference in U.S. politics.

Cummings warned federal employees to "think very carefully about their own legal interests" in refusing to comply with the panel's requests. The president has vowed to resist every subpoena from House Democrats investigating his administration and to fight any effort by them to impeach him.

The Justice Department has rebuffed a House committee's request for an interview with an official involved in the administration's decision to put a citizenship question on the 2020 census. The department said John Gore, a deputy assistant attorney general, would not participate in a deposition scheduled for Thursday if he could not have a Justice Department lawyer at his side.

The committee had offered to allow a lawyer to sit in a different room. Cummings said the committee would gather to hear Gore's deposition on Thursday and suggested he "should be well aware of his constitutional, legal and ethical obligations to comply with a duly authorized subpoena" from Congress.

The Department of Justice official said the committee had provided "no legitimate or constitutional basis for excluding a DOJ lawyer from assisting at the deposition." "If a DOJ lawyer may appear to protect privileged subjects, then the Attorney General will allow the deposition to go forward," the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Trump has promised to fight all the way to the Supreme Court against any effort by congressional Democrats to impeach him, even though the U.S. Constitution gives Congress complete authority over the impeachment process. The president has accused Democrats of conducting the Russia investigation for purely political purposes ahead of the 2020 election.

Democrats remain divided on whether to proceed with an impeachment of Trump after the Russia inquiry. Trump defiantly proclaimed on Twitter that the investigation "didn't lay a glove on me." If the partisan Dems ever tried to Impeach, I would first head to the U.S. Supreme Court," the Republican president said on Twitter without offering details about what legal action he envisioned.

In an opinion piece in the Washington Post, Hillary Clinton urged members of both parties to follow the facts, whether they lead to "the eventual filing of articles of impeachment, or not." "Either way, the nation's interests will be best served by putting party and political considerations aside and being deliberate, fair and fearless," Clinton wrote.

Mueller's findings, released in a redacted report last week, detailed how Trump often tried to impede the inquiry but stopped short of concluding he had committed the crime of obstruction of justice. The report said Congress could address whether the president violated the law.

Title: House Democrats Uncover Details of Secretive Effort to Sell Nuclear Technology to Saudi Arabia

A new report from the House Oversight and Reform Committee has revealed disturbing new details about a secretive effort by top Trump administration officials to sell sensitive nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia, potentially defying ethics statutes. The report, accompanied by internal White House emails, details a scheme spearheaded by former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn to sell technology for roughly 40 nuclear power plants to Saudi Arabia.

The plan was part of a broader Middle East economic development plan Flynn began working on before Trump's inauguration, while serving as an adviser to Trump's campaign and transition team. During this time, Flynn was also working as an adviser for a private company called IP3 International, a firm run by retired US military generals that bills itself as a "global enterprise to develop sustainable energy and security infrastructure." The company had a clear financial interest in exporting US nuclear energy technology to Saudi Arabia.

Once Trump was inaugurated, Flynn, along with longtime Trump associate Thomas Barrack, worked with other senior officials in the new Trump administration to make the plan a reality. The report reveals that several retired generals from IP3 met with Derek Harvey, a senior staffer on Trump's National Security Council, to discuss the nuclear plan for Saudi Arabia. The meeting led to the addition of information about IP3's plan for 40 nuclear power plants to the briefing package for President Trump's call with Saudi Arabia's King Salman.

The proposed nuclear deal would require the US to sign a "123 agreement" with Saudi Arabia, which establishes the criteria for the US to sell nuclear materials to other countries. However, according to the report, Harvey ignored the necessary steps and insisted that the decision to transfer nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia had already been made. This raises concerns that the deal could allow Saudi Arabia to pursue a nuclear weapon with US-sold equipment.

The report also highlights the personal involvement of Michael Flynn, who used to consult for IP3. Whistleblowers who spoke with House Democrats were concerned about Flynn skirting ethics rules. White House ethics officials apparently brought up the issue, with one senior political official stating that the proposal was "not a business plan, but rather a scheme for these generals to make some money."

The report is a significant development in the ongoing scrutiny of Trump's foreign policy. The House Democrats' report fills in gaps and sheds new light on how the Saudi nuclear deal went from being an idea to a serious policy pursued at the highest levels of the White House. The report's release is a warning shot, but it could be a sign of bigger things to come, as Democrats continue to oversee Trump's foreign policy and scrutinize his administration's actions.

Title: Florida Halts Publishing Real-Time Coronavirus Death Data Amid Discrepancies

Florida health officials have stopped publishing real-time coronavirus death data reported by medical examiners, citing concerns over privacy. The decision comes after The Tampa Bay Times reported that the medical examiners' death count was 10% higher than the official state total.

The Medical Examiners Commission, led by Dr. Stephen Nelson, had been publishing the data since 1992. However, state health officials intervened, instructing the commission to redact causes of deaths and descriptions of cases from the data, making it "meaningless." Nelson expressed concern that the decision would hinder transparency and the public's right to know.

The Palm Beach County medical examiner's office was also instructed to stop releasing the numbers, with Dr. Paul Petrino stating that the data was important for providing accurate information about the health crisis. The health department claimed that the decision was made to address "privacy concerns" for individuals who had passed away due to COVID-19.

The move has raised concerns among public health advocates, with Barbara Petersen of the First Amendment Foundation calling the efforts to keep public health information under wraps "shocking." The Florida Department of Health has attributed the discrepancies in the state's numbers to a lag in reporting and the exclusion of travelers and seasonal residents who died in the state.

The Florida Democratic congressional delegation has written a letter to Governor Ron DeSantis, questioning the inconsistencies between COVID-19 death tracking methods used by the Florida Department of Health and county medical examiners. The delegation has called for a "detailed explanation of the public health justification" for excluding non-residents from the state's death count.

Title: The Evolution of "Me Too" and the Blurred Lines Between Conformity and Due Process

The term "Me Too" has undergone a significant transformation since its inception. Initially, it referred to individuals who publicly supported the policies of President Franklin Roosevelt, often out of a desire to fit in with their Democratic neighbors and colleagues. Today, the phrase has taken on a different meaning, as it has become a rallying cry for those seeking to hold powerful individuals accountable for their actions.

The #MeToo movement has led to the downfall of several high-profile figures, including television hosts, movie moguls, and politicians. The latest target is Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, whose character has been assailed by allegations of sexual misconduct. The accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, has faced scrutiny for her inconsistencies and lack of concrete evidence, yet many still demand that her story be believed without question.

The #MeToo movement has also led to the ostracism of individuals who do not conform to its ideals. Comedian Norm Macdonald was disinvited from appearing on The Tonight Show after expressing his relief that the movement has slowed down. Similarly, writer Jian Gomeshi, acquitted of sexual assault charges, was removed from his position as editor of the New York Review of Books after publishing an essay on the #MeToo movement.

The #MeToo movement's emphasis on believing accusers without question has led to a disregard for due process and the presumption of innocence. The movement's zeal has also led to the silencing of those who do not conform to its ideals, including comedians and writers who are being punished for expressing their opinions. This raises concerns about the erosion of freedom of speech and the importance of due process.

The #MeToo movement has undoubtedly brought about significant changes in the way we address sexual harassment and assault. However, it is essential to strike a balance between holding perpetrators accountable and ensuring that the accused receive a fair trial. The movement's Reign of Terror has led to unforeseen harms, including the silencing of voices and the erosion of due process. As the movement continues to evolve, it is crucial that we find a way to balance accountability with fairness and respect for the rights of all individuals involved.

Title: Global Leaders Condemn Trump Administration's Plan to Impose Tariffs on Vehicle Imports

The Trump administration's decision to investigate whether tariffs are needed on imports of vehicles and automotive parts into the United States has been met with strong condemnation from China, Japan, and the European Union. The move, which would allow President Donald Trump to restrict imports and impose unlimited tariffs on national security grounds, is seen as an effort to gain a bargaining chip in stalled talks with Canada and Mexico over the North American Free Trade Agreement.

According to the Department of Commerce, Mexico is the top exporter of passenger vehicles and light trucks to the U.S., followed by Japan, Canada, Germany, and South Korea. Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, Hiroshige Seko, stated that Japan will continue to remind U.S. officials that any trade measures must conform to the rules of the World Trade Organization. Seko expressed concern that such a measure would be an "extremely far-reaching trade sanction that would put the global market into turmoil."

Germany's association of industry groups described auto tariffs as a "provocation" and "another nasty blow to our economic relations" with the United States. The EU executive stated that it would be against the rules of global trade. China's Commerce Ministry spokesman, Gao Feng, warned that abusing national security provisions would "undermine the multilateral trade system and disrupt the order of international trade."

Japanese and European automakers did not issue individual comments, but some referred to Global Automakers, an industry group of international automakers. Global Automakers' Chief Executive, John Bozzella, stated that the move would merely hurt American consumers, citing the U.S. auto industry's thriving and growing nature. He warned that the path to tariffs would lead to fewer choices and higher prices for cars and trucks in America.

Last week, Japan went to the World Trade Organization to warn of possible retaliation for tariffs on steel and aluminum, which Trump imposed in March. Japan estimates these tariffs will cost it about 50 billion yen ($450 million) a year. China is a relatively minor player in the U.S. auto import market, ranked 10th in dollar terms, but its massive car industry is eager to expand abroad. In auto parts exports to the U.S., China was ranked second last year.

A person familiar with the discussions said the president has suggested seeking new tariffs of 20 to 25 percent on automobile imports. Critics fear other countries will retaliate with trade sanctions of their own and question whether the move would ever be effective given the lengthy review required and legal challenges ahead.

Title: Capitol Hill Press Access Under Scrutiny Amid Growing Concerns Over Safety and Crowding

The increasing number of journalists on Capitol Hill has raised concerns about the safety and practicality of open press access to lawmakers. The Senate Rules Committee recently clarified that no changes have been made to the existing rules governing press coverage on the Senate side of the Capitol complex. However, the committee has been working with press galleries to ensure compliance with existing rules and guarantee a "safe environment" for everyone.

The crowded conditions on Capitol Hill have become a major concern, with some estimating that the number of reporters has doubled under the Trump administration. The crowded areas, such as the basement where the Senate subway cars arrive, can be overwhelming, with 20-30 microphones jammed into senators' faces as they exit the cars. The moving press horde then ascends a flight of stairs and proceeds another 50 feet or so until the senators can escape into the members-only elevator.

The concerns about safety are not unfounded, as senators are often elderly and could be at risk of tripping or falling. For example, Senator Orrin Hatch, 83, is often surrounded by 3-4 million reporters, making it a potential hazard.

The increased number of reporters on the Hill is largely due to the significant amount of news coming from the Hill, including the government's unified control under one party and the ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the election. The FBI and two select congressional committees are conducting investigations, and the press is eager to get answers from lawmakers.

The majority of reporters are not asking questions that lawmakers are thrilled to answer, with queries focusing on topics such as Trump's tweets, healthcare bills, and the handling of classified information. The constant barrage of questions can be overwhelming, and some lawmakers may be seeking a more controlled environment.

In contrast, White House and campaign reporters have limited access to principals, whereas on Capitol Hill, reporters can often approach lawmakers freely. If open press access on the Hill were restricted, it would likely shift more communication to flacks and impede another check on power.

If lawmakers are concerned about the size of reporter mobs and their safety, they could be more forthcoming with information and hold regular press conferences. Until then, it's essential to be mindful of the potential risks and find ways to navigate the crowded conditions safely.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Urges Republican Party to "Stop Being the Stupid Party"

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, a potential 2020 presidential contender, called on the Republican Party to "stop being the stupid party" in a keynote address at the Republican National Committee's winter meeting. Jindal emphasized the need for the party to shift its focus from Capitol Hill to the "real world beyond the Washington Beltway." He also urged conservatives to stop fighting with Democrats on their terms about the size of government in Washington and focus on connecting with voters across the nation.

Jindal's comments come as Republican leaders promise to release a report in March outlining recommendations on party rules and messaging designed to appeal to a rapidly changing American electorate. The report, dubbed the "Growth and Opportunity Project," aims to help the party expand its appeal to Hispanic, Asian, and African-American communities, which overwhelmingly supported President Barack Obama's re-election bid.

GOP strategist Sally Bradshaw, who is working on the report, said the party will "put on a different face" and "go into areas that we do not go into and see folks that we do not see." Bradshaw emphasized the need for the party to adapt to changing demographics and voter preferences.

The Republican Party has faced criticism for its struggles to win over women and minorities in the 2012 election. Mitt Romney, the party's presidential nominee, struggled to connect with these groups, and down-ticket Republican candidates alienated female voters with their stance on abortion and Todd Akin's controversial comments on rape.

GOP strategist Ari Fleischer suggested that the party could learn from Democrats on messaging, saying, "Republicans talk policy and Democrats talk people. Republicans can learn a little bit from Democrats on how to make those people connections with our policies."

Jindal's comments come a day after the House passed a bill to permit the government to borrow enough money to avoid a first-time default for at least four months, defusing a looming crisis setting up a springtime debate over taxes, spending, and the deficit.

The Louisiana governor's blunt remarks follow criticism from other high-profile Republicans, including New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who publicly blasted GOP leadership on Capitol Hill for their handling of disaster relief for victims of Superstorm Sandy. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich also emphasized the need for the party to develop a sound strategy for confronting the Obama administration and promoting better ideas.

Title: Supreme Court Rejects Alabama's Redistricting Plan, Calls it "Legally Erroneous"

The United States Supreme Court has ruled that a district court's decision upholding Alabama's redistricting plan, which some argue overloaded some districts with black Democrats, is "legally erroneous. The court's 5-4 decision sent the case back to the lower court for further review.

In a majority opinion delivered by Justice Steven Breyer, the court rejected the lower court's ruling and sent the case back to the lower court. Justice Breyer was joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, and Anthony Kennedy, with Justice Clarence Thomas writing a separate dissent.

The case revolves around Alabama's 2010 redistricting plan, which aimed to equalize district sizes after the 2010 census showed population shifts. The plan moved about one-sixth of eligible black voters from majority-white districts to majority-black districts, increasing the black majority in some districts to over 70%. The plan also made neighboring districts more white and more likely to elect Republicans.

The Supreme Court's decision sends the case back to the lower court to review claims of racial gerrymandering on a district-by-district level, rather than statewide. Justice Breyer also stated that the lower court did not apply the correct test when it found that race was not the primary motivating factor.

State officials argue that they had no choice but to concentrate black voters in some districts, making neighboring seats more white and apt to elect Republicans. The case highlights the ongoing debate over redistricting and racial gerrymandering, with Democrats arguing that the plan constitutes unconstitutional racial quotas.

Title: Republicans Divided on Immigration Reform Approach

Article: The Republican Party's post-election epiphany on immigration reform is facing a major hurdle: disagreement among its own members on the best approach. Some Republicans advocate for piecemeal reform, tackling individual issues while leaving the more contentious topics, such as a pathway to citizenship for millions of illegal immigrants, for later. Others, like Senator John McCain, prefer a comprehensive reform package that addresses the entire issue.

Representative Raul Labrador (R-Idaho) is among those who believe a comprehensive bill would be a "big mistake." He argues that it would result in a bill that nobody likes, with everyone hating one piece of it. On the other hand, Senator John Cornyn (R-Texas), the incoming Senate minority whip, notes that a piecemeal approach could build bipartisan momentum for a broader overhaul, but warns that a bill can become too big and cumbersome to pass.

The general outlines of a comprehensive package are clear, including provisions on border security, law enforcement, and reforms to the legal immigration system, as well as a solution for the millions of illegal immigrants living in the United States. However, Democrats fear that if Congress takes apart immigration reform, the pathway to citizenship for these individuals would be left behind.

Representatives Charles Gonzalez (D-Texas) and Xavier Becerra (D-California) argue that a piecemeal approach would not effectively address the issue, and that it is better to tackle the entire problem at once. "Why only half fix the problem?" Becerra asked. "Let's go ahead and fix the whole thing."

Title: The "Fiscal Cliff" is a Slope, Not a Cliff: A Gradual Approach to Budget Reform

The so-called "fiscal cliff" is not a cliff, but rather a slope, and it's not as dramatic as some make it out to be. The term "fiscal cliff" refers to the combination of tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect on January 1, 2013, if a budget deal is not reached. However, these changes are not as sudden or drastic as they seem.

In reality, the tax increases and spending cuts are likely to be phased in over a longer period, making the impact less severe. The payroll tax increase and extended unemployment benefits are already in place, and the other changes will be implemented gradually. This means that the "dramatic impact" on the economy is more of a myth than a reality.

To further mitigate the impact, congressional leaders can spread the tax increases and spending cuts over a longer period, making the "bunny slope" a more viable option. This approach involves implementing half of the 2001-2003 Bush income tax cuts for families with income over $250,000 and individuals over $200,000, with the other half expiring in 2014. Additionally, the sequestration cuts can be elongated over three years, with smaller cuts in 2013 and 2014.

The article also suggests increasing the payroll tax that funds Social Security to its normal rate over two years and letting business expense tax write-offs and other business tax provisions expire over two years. These changes would reduce the budget deficit by about $148 billion in both 2013 and 2014.

Assuming tax and spending policies remain the same after 2014, the budget deficit is expected to decline to about $652 billion in 2015, $452 billion in 2016, and $230 billion in 2017. By the end of 2017, the non-debt-service portion of the U.S. budget is expected to be balanced.

In conclusion, the so-called "fiscal cliff" is not as dire as some make it out to be. A gradual approach to budget reform, like the "bunny slope," can mitigate the impact of the tax increases and spending cuts. Investors and typical Americans should not agonize over the current budget talks, as a deal can be reached and the American people will be proud.

Title: Trump's Tariffs on Mexican Goods Could Add $87 Billion to US Revenue, but May Come at a Cost

The United States has collected approximately $19 billion in tariffs since President Trump imposed tariffs on aluminum and steel imports, as well as Chinese imports. A new proposed 25% tariff on Mexican goods could add up to $87 billion to this total. However, this move may come at a cost for American farmers, who may need to find new markets after Mexico is likely to impose retaliatory tariffs.

The tariff is intended to pressure Mexico into taking stronger steps to address immigration issues along the US-Mexico border. While the cost of the tariff would be borne by Americans, the Mexican economy is also likely to suffer from lost sales to the US. However, critics argue that tariffs are a crude tool to address complex issues, as most immigrants seeking to cross the border are fleeing problems in Central America beyond the control of the Mexican government.

Past administrations have sought cooperation from Mexico on immigration issues without disrupting economic relations between the two countries. In contrast, President Trump's decision to link tariffs to immigration issues threatens to disrupt both economies, as the manufacturing sectors in Mexico and the US are closely intertwined. According to Deutsche Bank, about two-thirds of trade between the countries is between factories owned by the same company.

Title: Sen. Amy Klobuchar Withdraws from VP Consideration, Citing Need for a Woman of Color as Running Mate

Article:

Senator Amy Klobuchar has announced her withdrawal from consideration as Joe Biden's running mate, stating that a woman of color should be chosen as the vice-presidential nominee instead. This decision comes after Klobuchar had been considered a strong contender for the position. According to reports, some political observers believe Klobuchar may have seen the writing on the wall, referencing graffiti from Black Lives Matter activists declaring "Don't pick Amy Klobuchar."

In a hypothetical worst-case scenario, if Biden were to choose Klobuchar as his running mate, it could lead to disappointing African-American voters and progressive activists who are critical of her record as a prosecutor. This could result in lower-than-expected turnout among African-American voters in key swing states, potentially leading to Trump's re-election.

However, if a Biden administration comes to pass, Klobuchar could still be offered a prestigious cabinet post, and Biden may feel he owes her a plum posting. Regardless of the outcome, it is clear that Klobuchar has put her personal ambitions aside and played good soldier twice, first in the primary and now in the running-mate selection process.

Title: Trump's Job Approval Rating Hits New Low in Latest Poll

A recent survey conducted by The Washington Post and ABC News has revealed that 60% of Americans disapprove of President Donald Trump's job performance, marking a new high for the president in polling. The poll, released on Friday, found that only 36% of Americans approve of Trump's job performance, a decrease from the 40% approval rating recorded in the previous Washington Post-ABC News poll in April.

The poll also found that most Americans would oppose Trump granting a pardon to his former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, with 66% of respondents saying they are against a pardon. Only 18% said they would support a pardon.

The survey also touched on the ongoing controversy surrounding Attorney General Jeff Sessions, with 62% of Americans siding with Sessions and 64% saying Trump should not fire him. The poll found that 63% of respondents support Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, while 29% oppose it.

The poll also asked respondents about Trump's potential interference in Mueller's investigation, with 53% saying they believe Trump tried to interfere in a way that "amounts to obstruction of justice," while 35% said he did not try to interfere.

In contrast, the poll found that Americans were more divided on Trump's handling of the economy, with 45% approving and 47% disapproving.

The poll, which included a sample of 1,003 adults, was conducted from August 26 to August 29 via landlines and cellphones, with a margin of error of plus-or-minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Seven Inflection Points That Could Tip the Election

The presidential race between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney remains extremely close, with neither candidate willing to take significant risks to alter the trajectory of the campaign. According to recent polls, the race is a 3-percentage-point affair, with Obama hovering just below 50% and Romney around 45%. Despite the lack of significant changes since the primaries, operatives on both sides believe a handful of inflection points could shape the outcome of the election.

These points include:

1. Debate performances: The upcoming debates between the two candidates could be a turning point in the campaign, with both sides viewing them as crucial in influencing voter perceptions.
2. Unemployment numbers: The next unemployment report could have a significant impact on the race, as it may affect voter confidence in the economy and the candidates' handling of it.
3. Credit downgrading: A potential credit downgrade could further erode voter confidence in the economy and Obama's leadership.
4. European crisis: A significant development in the European debt crisis could influence voter perceptions of Obama's foreign policy and leadership.
5. Vice presidential choice: The selection of a running mate could be a key factor in the campaign, with both sides viewing it as an opportunity to energize their base.
6. Health care ruling fallout: The aftermath of the Supreme Court's decision on the Affordable Care Act could continue to shape the narrative around the candidates' health care policies.
7. Mideast or other foreign policy issues: A significant development in the Middle East or other foreign policy issues could become a major campaign issue, potentially affecting voter perceptions of Obama's leadership.

While some of these points are within the control of the campaigns, others are global events that could have a significant impact on the race. Republican strategist Curt Anderson noted that there is more peril than upside for Obama in these potential inflection points, while Democratic strategist Steve Murphy believes the race will remain locked in its current state.

Title: US Economy Shrinks by 0.1% in Q4 2012, Marking First Contraction Since 2008 Recession

The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) released its advance estimate of the fourth-quarter 2012 gross domestic product (GDP), revealing a slight contraction of 0.1% in the US economy. This marks the first time the economy has shrunk since the end of the 2008 recession. The real GDP decreased at an annual rate of 0.1% from the third quarter to the fourth quarter, according to the BEA.

The downturn in real GDP was primarily driven by declines in private inventory investment, federal government spending, exports, and state and local government spending. However, this was partly offset by an increase in non-residential fixed investment, a decrease in imports, and an acceleration in personal consumption expenditures (PCE).

A significant factor contributing to the economic contraction was a 22% decline in federal military spending. Non-military federal spending increased by 6%, but did not offset the decline in military spending cuts. The Department of Defense may have attempted to make up for the impending budget cuts by increasing spending in the third quarter, only to reduce it in the fourth quarter.

The looming threat of the budget sequester, brought on by the 2011 Budget Control Act, may have led to the sharp decline in defense spending. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the defense spending cuts will result in a 0.4% drop in GDP.

Despite the negative news, personal consumption spending and investment showed growth, increasing 2.2% and 8.4%, respectively. The boost in personal spending was driven mainly by durable goods, indicating that consumers are reaching the limits of hoarding and are now replacing old items.

The BEA emphasized the uncertainty surrounding its estimates, stating that the fourth-quarter advance estimate is based on incomplete data and is subject to further revision. The "second" estimate for the fourth quarter, based on more complete data, will be released on February 28, 2013.

Title: Romney's Foreign Policy Stance Leaves Questions Unanswered

The article discusses Mitt Romney's recent speech at V.M.I., where he addressed the Palestinian issue and faulted President Obama for failing to deliver on the goal of a democratic, prosperous Palestinian state. However, the article notes that Romney's specific descriptions of what he would do on issues like drawing red lines for Iran's nuclear program and threatening to cut off military aid to difficult allies like Pakistan or Egypt sound close to Obama's approach.

The article also highlights the fact that Romney's foreign policy team is still in the process of being formed, with some notable figures from the Bush administration not yet on board. The article mentions that Romney's advisors are divided on issues like spreading American-style freedoms in the Middle East or simply managing and limiting the rise of Islamist governments.

The article also notes that Romney's speech did not provide specific details on how he would achieve his goals, leaving many questions unanswered. For example, he did not specify what resources he would devote to supporting Libya's efforts to forge a lasting government or pursuing the terrorists who attacked the US consulate in Benghazi.

Overall, the article suggests that Romney's foreign policy stance is still evolving and lacks specificity, leaving many questions unanswered.

Title: Market Analysts Weigh In on Economic Recovery Timeline

The stock market experienced a mixed day of trading on Wednesday, with bank stocks rising and tech-focused stay-at-home plays falling. As the U.S. economy begins to reopen, market analysts and economists are divided on the timeline for recovery. Four experts shared their insights on the current state of the market and the challenges ahead.

David Lebovitz, global market strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management, emphasized the importance of caution, citing the uncertainty surrounding the reopening process. "We have been surprised by the speed and magnitude at which things have moved, but when you think about building a diversified portfolio, you have the 10-year Treasury yield at 70 basis points. Equities look attractive even if they're trading at north of 20 times," Lebovitz said. However, he noted that the reopening process is complex and unpredictable, and that the economy may not recover as quickly as some expect.

Mike Mayo, managing director and head of U.S. large-cap bank research at Wells Fargo Securities, believes the Federal Reserve should allow its policies from the previous recession to guide its decisions. "We've run over 200 earnings models. We've run different scenarios: a V recovery, a U recovery, an L recovery, and it's pretty tough, we think, for the government to conclude that large banks, well-capitalized banks, well-capitalized banks that earned their dividend twice over in the first quarter, in a quarter when they built reserves, we find it very tough for the Fed to conclude that banks should cut the dividends now," Mayo said.

Jason Furman, economic policy professor at Harvard University and former chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, warned investors not to get too optimistic too soon. "I think we're going to have two phases from here. One is a partial bounce back, which will be very rapid. It'll look like we're on the upslope of a V. We've already seen that. When you look at daily data, it bottomed out around April 15. You've even seen growth in consumption spending, a decent amount of it, from April 15 to May 15. Problem is that's the low-hanging fruit of growth where you turn the lights back on, call some of the furloughed workers back. There's a lot more people that aren't coming back to their jobs, businesses that aren't going to be revived, and so once you get past that first phase, I think you're in for a long and painful slog," Furman said.

The experts' differing opinions highlight the uncertainty surrounding the economic recovery and the challenges that lie ahead. As the market continues to navigate the complexities of reopening, investors will be closely watching for signs of growth and recovery.

Title: New York Attorney General's Office Uncovers $1 Billion in Wire Transfers Linked to Sackler Family in Ongoing Opioid Crisis Case

The New York Attorney General's office has revealed that it has discovered approximately $1 billion in wire transfers between the Sackler family and their shell companies, according to court filings on Friday. The transfers occurred during the same time frame that the Sacklers were draining Purdue Pharma of its opioid proceeds. The documents were obtained as a result of subpoenas issued to financial institutions believed to have information related to the defendants in the case.

The New York Attorney General, Letitia James, stated that the Sacklers are attempting to hide their financial misconduct and that the office will continue to investigate whether the transactions were a deliberate attempt to conceal assets from litigants. James emphasized that the limited number of documents provided so far underscore the necessity for compliance with every subpoena.

Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin, is facing thousands of lawsuits linked to the opioid crisis, which has killed tens of thousands of people in the U.S. The company has reached a tentative settlement with thousands of local governments and more than 20 states to pay $3 billion upfront and then more from the sale of Mundipharma, a sister company of Purdue Pharma also owned by the Sacklers. The proposed settlement would not include an admission of guilt.

The New York Attorney General's office has expressed concerns that the proposed settlement does not account for the depth of pain and destruction caused by Purdue and the Sacklers, calling it an "insult." A spokesperson for Mortimer D.A. Sackler, a former Purdue board member, has denied the allegations, calling the investigation a "cynical attempt" to generate defamatory headlines and torpedo a mutually beneficial settlement.

Title: Obama's "Private Sector is Doing Fine" Statement Sparks Republican Backlash

Article:

President Barack Obama's recent statement that the private sector is "doing fine" has sparked a heated backlash from Republicans, who argue that the comment is out of touch with the current economic reality. During a White House news conference, Obama said that the private sector has created 4.3 million jobs over the past two years, with 800,000 jobs added this year alone. However, his statement was quickly seized upon by Republicans, who pointed to recent job numbers showing a slowdown in private sector growth.

House Speaker John Boehner and Majority Leader Eric Cantor were among the first to respond, with Boehner saying that the private sector is "not doing well" and Cantor stating that Obama's comment was "kidding." Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, also weighed in, saying that Obama's statement showed him to be "out of touch."

The criticism was not limited to politicians, as many Republicans on social media also jumped on the opportunity to criticize Obama's comment. The hashtag #doingfine was trending on Twitter, with many users sharing their own opinions on the matter.

Obama attempted to clarify his statement during a photo op with Philippine President Benigno Aquino, saying that he understands the economy is not "fine" overall, but rather that the private sector is doing well compared to the public sector. However, his attempt to unring the bell may have been too little, too late, as the controversy has already gained significant traction.

It's worth noting that while Obama's statement may have been seen as tone-deaf by some, it is true that the private sector has created jobs throughout the recovery, albeit at a slower pace in recent months. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 87,000 non-government jobs were created in April and 82,000 in May.

Title: Republican Party Divided: Anger and Alienation Simmer Amidst Nomination Race

The Republican Party is facing a deepening divide as the nomination race heats up, with some party leaders warning that the party's future is at stake. According to Senator Lindsey Graham, Republicans are in a "demographic death spiral" and must start appealing to Hispanics and young people to survive. However, many voters are resistant to this approach, seeking an unapologetic brand of conservatism that confronts the political establishment.

Conservative talk radio hosts like Rush Limbaugh and commentators like Ann Coulter have amplified these sentiments, influencing the party's agenda. Laura Ingraham, a talk-show host, believes that voters are fed up with Republican leaders who have ignored their concerns. "All the things the voters want have been shoved off to the sidelines by Republican leaders," she said.

The party's internal divisions would be difficult to heal regardless of the nominee. If an establishment candidate wins, the highly energized voters backing Donald Trump and Ted Cruz may revolt. A Suffolk University/USA Today poll found that about two-thirds of Trump supporters would vote for him as a third-party candidate, a possibility that could help the Democratic nominee. If Cruz is nominated, he will have to balance winning over party leaders with not appearing to sell out to his anti-establishment supporters. A Fox News poll found that 66% of Cruz supporters in Iowa felt "betrayed" by politicians in their party.

Party leaders would face a daunting task if they backed Trump, as they would have to campaign in parallel universes, supporting a candidate who has proposed mass deportations of illegal immigrants and a temporary ban on Muslims entering the country, while also trying to diversify their predominantly white male base.

Title: Clinton's Email Controversy: A Growing Scandal

The controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's emails during her time as U.S. Secretary of State continues to unfold. Clinton has attempted to downplay the issue, joking about her love for Snapchat's disappearing messages. However, the facts suggest a more serious situation.

Clinton deleted 30,000 government emails, claiming they were personal and on a personal server, which she claimed allowed her to destroy them. However, federal law defines emails used during the course of one's work for the federal government as the property of the federal government. She could have designated which emails were personal and asked the government to send them to her and delete them from government servers instead.

The 55,000 emails she sent to the feds were printed emails, which she claimed would enable her to carry only one mobile device for both personal and governmental emails. However, she later admitted to carrying four devices. The scandal took a more serious turn when Clinton's lawyers revealed that after she deleted the 30,000 emails, she had the server professionally wiped clean.

The inspector general of the State Department and the inspector general of the intelligence community found four classified emails among a random sample of 40. One of these emails was deemed top-secret, discussing satellite imagery of a foreign country and intercepts of foreign agents' communications. Clinton initially denied routing classified materials through her server, but later changed her explanation to "I never sent or received any email marked classified." However, emails are not "marked classified," but rather "top-secret," "secret," or "confidential."

The State Department has since located 305 of her undeleted emails that are likely in the top-secret or secret or classified categories. If Clinton is indicted for failure to secure classified information, she will likely argue that if one of the above markings was not on the email, she did not know it was top-secret. However, this argument would be difficult to sustain, as the secretary of state is presumed to know what is top-secret and what is not.

The article concludes by referencing recent cases where individuals were indicted for similar offenses, including a young sailor who took a selfie in front of a sonar screen on a nuclear submarine and emailed it to his girlfriend, and a Marine who sent an urgent warning to his superiors on his Gmail account about a dangerous Afghani spy who eventually killed three fellow Marines inside an American encampment. The article questions what will happen if the FBI recommends that Clinton be indicted and the White House stonewalls, and whether the public will accept a potential pass for Clinton.

Title: Multiple U.S. Citizens Killed in Ambush in Northern Mexico

A group of at least three women and six children, all U.S. citizens, were killed in an ambush in northern Mexico, according to officials. The victims were traveling in a convoy of SUVs when they were attacked by drug cartel gunmen. Six children were found alive, one with a bullet wound, and one child remains missing.

Mexican Security Secretary Alfonso Durazo stated that the gunmen may have mistaken the group's large SUVs for rival gangs. At least five children have been taken to Phoenix, Arizona, for treatment.

The incident has sparked an international response, with U.S. President Donald Trump tweeting that it is time for Mexico to wage war on the drug cartels. However, Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has refused this approach, stating that the worst thing that can happen is war.

This is the second failure in recent weeks for López Obrador's "hugs not bullets" anti-crime strategy. Two weeks ago, Mexican troops had to release a drug lord after his supporters mounted armed attacks in Culiacan, Sinaloa.

The victims were part of a decades-old settlement founded by members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Sonora state. Many of the church's members were born in Mexico and hold dual citizenship.

The group was attacked while traveling in a convoy of SUVs, and the relative of one of the victims stated that the cartel gunmen may have mistaken the group's vehicles for rival gangs. The relative also stated that the cartel gunmen gathered about a mile away after the ambush, armed to the teeth.

The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on members of the break-away church, which has been targeted by drug cartels in the past. In 2009, Benjamin LeBaron, an anti-crime activist and relative of the victims, was murdered in neighboring Chihuahua state.

Title: U.S. Senators Introduce Legislation to Impose Stiff Sanctions on Russia

Article:

A bipartisan group of U.S. senators introduced legislation on Thursday aimed at imposing stiff new sanctions on Russia and combating cybercrime. The bill, which includes restrictions on Russian sovereign debt transactions, energy and oil projects, and uranium imports, as well as new sanctions on Russian political figures and oligarchs, is the latest effort by lawmakers to punish Moscow over its interference in U.S. elections and activities in Syria and Ukraine.

The bill also expresses strong support for NATO and requires a two-thirds majority vote in the Senate to approve any effort to leave the alliance. Russian markets reacted quickly to the measure, with the rouble slumping towards two-week lows.

Senator Lindsey Graham, a lead sponsor of the bill, stated that the current sanctions regime has failed to deter Russia from meddling in the upcoming 2018 midterm elections. Earlier this week, Graham had announced plans for a "sanctions bill from hell" to punish Russia.

The bill is an attempt to strengthen the sanctions regime passed by Congress last summer, which some lawmakers felt was not being fully implemented by the administration. Senator Bob Menendez, a co-sponsor of the bill, stated that the administration had not fully complied with the sanctions and that the bill is the next step in tightening the screws on the Kremlin.

The bill would need to pass both the Senate and House of Representatives and be signed by President Donald Trump to become law. Aides to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell referred questions about the bill to the Senate Banking Committee, which has scheduled hearings on the matter.

Title: Russian President Putin Appears to Secure Political Future with Constitutional Referendum

Russian President Vladimir Putin appears to have secured his political future, with 78% of votes counted supporting a controversial national referendum that could see the former KGB agent stay in power until 2036. The referendum proposed over 200 constitutional amendments, one of which will reset presidential term limits, allowing Putin to run for the job again in 2024 and 2030 if he chooses.

According to official results, after 98% of ballots had been counted, Putin had easily won the right to run for two more six-year terms. The Central Election Commission reported that 78% of votes counted across the world's largest country had supported changing the constitution, with just over 21% voting against.

The Russian leader, who has been president for over 20 years, made the case for constitutional revisions invoking patriotism and making a vague promise of securing Russia's future. The Kremlin had been keen to downplay the resetting of Putin's length of office, with over 200 other issues put to the public in the polls. However, these amendments amounted to little more than fine print on the ballot papers.

The vote was irregular for a Russian election, with online voting and a nearly week-long opportunity for citizens to stop by polling stations amid the coronavirus pandemic. The most novel aspect of the election was that early results were announced by the Central Election Commission well before polls had closed in many parts of the country.

The result does not set Putin's future in stone, but it does pave the way for him to possibly hold on to power until 2036, giving him the opportunity to be Russia's longest-serving ruler since Peter the Great. However, he will have to run two more presidential campaigns, and the question then will be how many people turn out to vote.

**Parkland School Shooting: Authorities Investigate Warning Signs**

A 19-year-old former student, Nikolas Cruz, has been charged with killing 17 people at a Florida high school, leaving a trail of worrying signs that may have gone unheeded. Authorities are investigating reports of Cruz's obsession with weapons, harassing neighbors' pets, and stalking one of the girls he killed.

According to a complaint affidavit, Cruz admitted to being the gunman who entered the campus armed with an AR-15-style rifle and shot students he saw in the hallways and on the school grounds. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) received a tip last September that a YouTube commenter with the same name as Cruz made an alarming claim, "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." However, the FBI did not link the comment to Cruz at the time.

Cruz had been expelled from the school and had a reputation in his neighborhood as a socially awkward menace who would steal mail, run through yards, and hurt animals. Neighbors and classmates described him as having a "cold, cold stare" and being obsessed with guns.

The FBI conducted a database review and checks but was unable to identify the person who made the comment. The agency received a tip from a bail bondsman, Ben Bennight, who reported the comment as spam to YouTube, which took it down. Bennight said he felt the agency took the issue seriously, but was limited in how they could respond because it wasn't a direct threat.

The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are exploring Cruz's mental health history and the possibility he had autism. His defense team is gathering his mental-health history and will explore his brain development.

The incident has sparked a renewed call for action on school violence and mental health. Attorney General Jeff Sessions said, "Perhaps we haven't been effective enough in intervening immediately to deal with that." President Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Rick Scott have announced plans to redouble efforts to stop school violence, focusing more on mental health than gun control.

Title: Jobs Report Exceeds Forecasts, but Unemployment Rate Increases

The latest jobs report released on Friday exceeded expectations, showing a gain of 171,000 jobs in October. However, the unemployment rate increased to 7.9% from 7.8% in September, denying President Barack Obama a clean chance to trumpet a quickening recovery. The report has become a key topic in the final days of the presidential campaign, with both President Obama and Mitt Romney using it to buttress their economic messages.

The report shows a continued trend of job growth, with companies hiring more workers in October than in any time in the last eight months. However, the unemployment rate has remained stubbornly high, and the economy still has 9 million jobs short of what it had in 2008, when President Obama took office.

Romney's campaign has sought to portray the jobs report as a disappointment, citing the increase in the unemployment rate and the fact that the economy has not yet fully recovered. "He said he was going to lower the unemployment rate down to 5.2 percent right now, today we learned that it is actually 7.9 percent and that's 9 million jobs short of what he promised," Romney said during a campaign stop in West Allis, Wisconsin.

On the other hand, the Obama campaign has highlighted the continued trend of job growth and the fact that the economy has created nearly 5.5 million new jobs since 2008. "In 2008 we were in the middle of two wars and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression and today our businesses have created nearly five and a half million new jobs and this morning we learned that companies hired more workers in October than in any time in the last eight months," Obama said at a campaign rally in Hilliard, Ohio.

Economists are divided on the significance of the report, with some saying it is a modest benefit to Obama but does not change the overall picture of the economy. "These job numbers shouldn't play an important role in the election," said Moody's Analytics chief economist Mark Zandi. "They are not strong enough to help the president, not weak enough to help Governor Romney."

Title: Chicago Police and ICE Sign Agreement, Raising Concerns Among Immigrant Rights Activists

The City of Chicago is preparing to vote on amendments to its "sanctuary" law, which would strengthen the city's protections for undocumented immigrants. However, a recently unearthed agreement between the Chicago Police Department (CPD) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has raised concerns among immigrant rights activists.

The agreement, signed by former Supt. Eddie Johnson in April, allows ICE to designate certain CPD employees as "customs officers." These officers are authorized to enforce federal offenses, but not administrative violations of immigration law. CPD spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi defended the agreement, stating that it allows police to investigate drug trafficking, human trafficking, gangs, and financial crimes through Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), a branch of ICE.

However, immigrant rights activists are concerned that the agreement could lead to increased cooperation between CPD and ICE, which could undermine the city's sanctuary status. Rey Wences, a member of Organized Communities Against Deportations, said, "Police-ICE collaboration is police-ICE collaboration no matter how you paint it. The existence of this agreement... makes you wonder what other kinds of agreements the city has [with ICE]."

The agreement has also raised questions about the city's commitment to its Welcoming Cities ordinance, which bars CPD from assisting ICE in enforcing civil immigration operations. The ordinance was introduced by Ald. Carlos Ramirez-Rosa and Ald. Michael Rodriguez in December, with the support of Mayor Lori Lightfoot.

ICE officials did not respond to requests for comment, but CPD spokesperson Guglielmi emphasized that the agreement does not involve immigration enforcement. "Chicago, like many other major cities, has the authority to appoint officers to conduct joint state and federal investigations with Homeland Security Investigations, which is a branch of ICE," he said.

However, some critics argue that the agreement could lead to increased cooperation between CPD and ICE, which could undermine the city's sanctuary status. Freddy Martinez, a policy analyst at Open the Government, said, "We know ICE uses deceptive practices to get CPD to cooperate with them on immigration enforcement, with or without their knowledge. Significant questions remain about why [CPD] felt the need to enter into these types of agreements when there are no officers deputized to assist ICE."

The agreement has also raised concerns about the blurring of lines between ICE's Enforcement and Removal Operations and its Homeland Security Investigations branch. ICE has historically maintained that these branches operate separately, but critics argue that the agency's actions have blurred the lines between the two.

The controversy surrounding the CPD-ICE agreement highlights the ongoing debate about the role of local law enforcement in immigration enforcement. While some argue that cooperation between police and ICE is necessary to combat crime, others believe that it undermines the trust between law enforcement and the community and puts undocumented immigrants at risk of deportation.

Title: Iran's Economy Struggles Amid Hopes for Sanctions Relief

Iran's economy is facing significant challenges, with many Iranians struggling to make ends meet. Despite some marginal improvements under President Hassan Rouhani's administration, the country's economic woes persist. The government's efforts to lift sanctions and improve relations with the international community are seen as crucial to reviving the economy.

In Tehran, a young man who wished to remain anonymous shared his concerns about the country's economic situation. He noted that while President Rouhani has brought a more optimistic atmosphere, real changes have yet to materialize. The individual, who works in the petrochemical industry, expressed frustration with the high tariffs on imported goods, citing the example of a 105% tariff on cars.

Income inequality remains a significant issue in Iran, with some individuals profiting from the country's isolation. The Revolutionary Guard, a powerful economic player, is seen as a major obstacle to economic reform. A graduate student who wished to remain anonymous expressed frustration with the previous administration's lack of progress, stating that the sanctions only benefited those with connections to the government.

In poorer neighborhoods, the economic struggles are more pronounced. Residents are frustrated with the government's decision to replace direct cash payments with food baskets, which they see as inadequate. Despite the challenges, some residents remain hopeful that better times are ahead.

The lifting of sanctions and improved relations with the international community are seen as crucial to reviving the economy. However, the process is complicated, and some experts warn that the sanctions regime is not yet crumbling. The Iranian government is working to attract foreign investment, but companies are hesitant to commit due to the ongoing sanctions.

For now, Iranians are left to struggle on, recognizing that their economic future depends on factors beyond their control.

Title: White House Fires Under Secretary of State Steve Goldstein Over Contradictory Account of Tillerson's Firing

The White House has reportedly fired Under Secretary of State Steve Goldstein, according to officials, following a statement he made on Tuesday that contradicted the administration's account of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's dismissal. Goldstein's statement suggested that Tillerson did not speak with President Donald Trump before his firing and was "unaware" of the reason behind his dismissal, which differs from published accounts citing unnamed White House sources.

According to the Associated Press, Goldstein's statement also claimed that Tillerson had "every intention of staying" in his position before his firing. This account differs from the one provided by a White House official, who said that White House Chief of Staff John Kelly informed Tillerson on Friday that Trump would be firing him.

The firing of Goldstein comes amid ongoing tensions between Trump and Tillerson, who had previously clashed over reports that the secretary of state referred to Trump as a "moron." Trump announced Tillerson's dismissal on Tuesday, stating that he made the decision to oust him on his own and that Tillerson would be "much happier now."

In related news, the White House announced that Heather Nauert, previously the State Department's spokesperson, has been named as Goldstein's replacement.

Title: "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" Celebrate the Best in Satire and Parody

The year 2023 has been marked by controversy, satire, and parody, with "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" providing a platform for comedians to tackle the most pressing issues of the year. From the NSA's surveillance programs to the government shutdown, the shows have used humor to shed light on the absurdity and hypocrisy of it all. Here are some of the best segments from the two shows:

One notable segment is John Oliver's three-part series on gun control in Australia, which highlights the country's strict gun control measures and the stark contrast with the United States. Oliver's investigation is a testament to the power of satire in sparking important conversations.

Another standout segment is Jessica Williams' "Frisky Business," which exposes the hypocrisy and racism of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's stop-and-frisk program. Williams' parody is a masterclass in using humor to tackle serious issues.

The shows have also poked fun at the music industry, with Stephen Colbert and actor Alan Cumming performing a parody of LL Cool J and Brad Paisley's song "Accidental Racist." Colbert also spoofed MTV's Video Music Awards, joking that Daft Punk's surprise performance would have been ruined if they had appeared on his show.

Aasif Mandvi's segment on North Carolina GOP leader Don Yelton, who made racist comments about voter ID laws, sparked outrage and led to Yelton's resignation. The segment highlights the importance of holding public figures accountable for their words.

The shows have also tackled the annual "War on Christmas" debate, with Megyn Kelly expressing outrage over the idea of a black Santa Claus. The "Daily Show" and "Colbert Report" have also poked fun at CNN's shoddy news coverage, with a parody of the network's coverage of the government shutdown.

Jon Stewart's verbal assaults on the GOP during the government shutdown were a highlight of the year, with one notable segment calling out House Republicans as "self-righteous Orwellian zebra queefs." Colbert's parody of CNN's coverage of the shutdown, "Pointless Counter Pointless," was another standout, featuring special guests Oscar the Grouch and Big Bird debating the most pressing issues of the day.
