Almost 20% of Millennials believed the Communist Manifesto better guarantees freedom and equality for all, compared to just 2% of Baby Boomers and 5% of Gen X. Additionally, a YouGov survey found that 87% of high school students flunked a five-question test of basic knowledge about American history, and only 35% of them could correctly identify the individuals on Mount Rushmore.

The lack of understanding of history is also evident in the fact that two-thirds of American Millennials could not identify the Nazi extermination camp of Auschwitz, and 22% said they had not heard of the Holocaust or were unsure if they had heard of it. The oldest Millennials were small children when the Berlin Wall was knocked down, and they never experienced the threat of the Cuban Missile Crisis or the Cold War.

Ocasio-Cortez has said that her generation has never known true prosperity, and the idea of a college debt bailout may seem like the socialist dream come true. However, according to Kibbe, the misery AOC blames on capitalism is not reality. Those who crunch numbers can see that we are living in the most prosperous, most opportunistic, and most beautiful times in the history of the universe.

Title: Former Homeland Security Chief Warns of Ongoing Terror Threat from Islamic State

The White House's dismissal of the government's July 4 weekend terror warning as "standard operating procedure" was inaccurate, according to former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge. Ridge made the statement on Fox News Channel's "Your World with Neil Cavuto" on Monday. He emphasized that the threat from the Islamic State (ISIS or ISIL) is real and permanent.

Ridge warned that the United States may be at risk of attacks at any time unless the country takes a more aggressive stance against ISIS. He stated that the warning made by the FBI, Homeland Security, and National Counterterrorism Center may ultimately become a standard warning, indicating that the country is at risk all the time.

The warning comes amid a "confluence of events," as described by House Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul. ISIS celebrates its one-year anniversary of major territorial wins this week, and the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, currently underway, has seen ISIS calling for it to be changed from a month of peace to a month of calamities.

Former CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell also emphasized the gravity of the situation, stating that he would not be surprised if the United States is discussing an attack over the weekend. He warned that the threat is serious and that the country needs to take it seriously.

Ridge attributed the recent ISIS attacks on Friday across three continents to the group's global reach and coordination. He urged the White House, the president, and Western allies to take a more aggressive stance against ISIS to eliminate the threat.

Title: Federal Workers and Contractors Apply for Unemployment as Shutdown Drags On

As the partial government shutdown enters its 34th day, federal workers and contractors are feeling the financial pinch, with many forced to apply for unemployment benefits for the first time. Long-time federal contractor John Woodson, who typically receives a paycheck, spent his day filing an unemployment claim instead. "We should still be at work right now," Woodson said. "Politicians should handle this – don't put this on the citizens. You're hurting us. You're hurting our families."

Federal workers and contractors are now missing paychecks for the first time since the shutdown began on December 22. This has led some to consider applying for unemployment benefits, with at least 7,000 claims filed by federal government workers and contractors in Washington, D.C. and Maryland since the shutdown began. Officials expect this number to rise sharply if the shutdown continues.

Federal employee Steve, who did not want to use his full name for fear of repercussions, said he left a higher-paying job in the private sector to work for the government due to the stability it offered. However, he now feels unappreciated and unstable. "The real benefit was a job that I felt appreciated at – a job that had stability," Steve said. "And right now, I feel unappreciated and unstable."

The shutdown has affected around 800,000 employees, with an estimated 420,000 working without pay and 380,000 on furlough. Federal employee Michelle, who did not want to give her full name, said she never expected to be in this position. "I show up to work. I do a good job. I'm doing everything a responsible adult is supposed to do," she said. "All of a sudden, it's all blown up and I don't know what else to do."

The shutdown will cost at least $50 million a day in lost wages and productivity, according to the federal government. However, there are hidden costs that go beyond money, said Randy Erwin, president of the National Federation of Federal Employees. "Who in the world is going to want to work for the federal government when workers are disrespected... when people are not able to fill prescriptions, bouncing checks [and] ruining their credit?" Erwin asked.

The details surrounding who is – and is not – eligible for unemployment can get complicated. Federal employees who have been furloughed can apply for unemployment benefits, while workers who have been deemed "essential" and are working without pay are not eligible. Federal employees who do receive unemployment benefits will have to reimburse the government if Congress votes to give employees backpay, which typically happens when the government re-opens.

The U.S. Office of Personnel Management has issued guidance for furloughed workers on what to do during a shutdown – including how to write to creditors and mortgage companies. On Friday, President Trump said he would sign a bill passed by both the House and the Senate to give back pay to federal workers affected by the shutdown.

Title: US Contractor Alan Gross Released from Cuban Prison After Five Years

Article:

American contractor Alan Gross, 65, has been released from a Cuban prison after being held for five years. The release was part of a landmark humanitarian prisoner exchange announced by President Obama at the White House. The agreement was reached after more than a year of secret back-channel talks at the highest levels of both governments.

Gross, who is said to be in poor physical condition, was convicted of espionage by a Cuban court in 2011 and sentenced to 15 years for bringing telecommunication devices into Cuba while working as a subcontractor for the United States Agency for International Development. The Cuban government accused him of being part of a U.S.-led plot to overthrow the government through an "Arab Spring."

The release of Gross represents a first step towards normalizing relations with Cuba, with the U.S. and Cuba set to begin talks to restore diplomatic relations. The U.S. also plans to re-establish an embassy in Havana, as announced by President Obama.

In a statement, Obama said, "Today, the United States is taking historic steps to chart a new course in our relations with Cuba and to further engage and empower the Cuban people." He also emphasized the importance of maintaining U.S. advocacy for human rights in Cuba.

Gross was held in a small room at a military hospital 24 hours a day with two other Cuban political prisoners. He had refused medical and dental care, outside privileges, and declined visits and food from the U.S. Interest section in Havana. He had threatened to go on a hunger strike leading to death if not released by the end of the year.

In return for Gross' release, the United States has agreed to the humanitarian release of three Cuban agents convicted of espionage in a controversial trial. The agents were most recently held in North Carolina at a federal medical facility for the U.S. Bureau of Prisons.

The humanitarian release is just the beginning of a promised new relationship with Cuba. The White House is indicating the beginning of new talks on everything from travel restrictions to eventual lifting of the Cuban embargo, which has been in place since John F. Kennedy was president.

Title: Republicans' Sex-Crimes Prosecutor Says Case Against Brett Kavanaugh Would Not Hold Up in Court

Article: The sex-crimes prosecutor hired by Republicans to question Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and accuser Christine Blasey Ford at Thursday's hearing told senators that the case would not hold up in a courtroom, according to sources. Rachel Mitchell, the prosecutor, spoke at an overnight meeting with all 51 Republican senators, where she reportedly stated that she would not charge Kavanaugh and would not even seek a search warrant. This guidance could prove critical as wavering lawmakers prepare to vote on the nomination.

Mitchell's opinion could sway fence-sitting senators ahead of a critical Senate Judiciary Committee vote set for Friday afternoon. It is not necessary for Kavanaugh to secure majority approval of the committee in order to advance to the full Senate, but a favorable recommendation could bode well for his imperiled nomination.

In a significant development, Republican Sen. Jeff Flake announced Friday morning that he will support Kavanaugh, stating, "I left the hearing yesterday with as much doubt as certainty." With Flake's support, 48 Republican senators have now pledged to vote for Kavanaugh at the scheduled full Senate vote on Tuesday. The outstanding Republicans are Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Mike Enzi of Wyoming. Enzi is expected to vote in support of Kavanaugh, but has said he will not announce his position until he votes.

However, Collins, Murkowski, Flake, and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin could vote in a bloc. The source told Fox News that Collins, Murkowski, and Flake huddled with Manchin on the sidelines Thursday evening to discuss the nomination, right before the GOP lawmakers were briefed by Mitchell. They spoke for approximately 30 minutes.

"It's a tough one. She offered good testimony, and so did he," Flake said Thursday night, before announcing his support. "If you're making an allegation, you want there to be some corroboration. Where is the burden? It's like impeachment. You don't know."

Republicans, including President Trump, have stressed that none of the sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh made in the last several days have first-hand corroboration. Ford insisted during Thursday's testimony that Kavanaugh and a friend trapped her in a room during a high school gathering in 1982, and the now-court nominee tried to force himself on her before she escaped. She said she's "100 percent" sure it was him, though Kavanaugh adamantly denied it.

Asked whether more time or investigating would help, as Democrats suggested repeatedly on Thursday, Flake rejected the idea. "Where does this start, where does it end?" he asked. "More time, more ludicrous allegations. What does that do to the accused?"

Manchin, from deep-red West Virginia, is seen as a possible "yea" vote for Kavanaugh. "There have been no decisions," Manchin reportedly said outside the hearing room. "There are some concerns that people have, and we're going to try to close that loop."

Democratic Sens. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Donnelly of Indiana also have not revealed which way they might vote. Early Friday, Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., said that he would vote "no." Republicans hold a narrow 51-49 majority in the Senate, and can only afford one defection in their bid to confirm Kavanaugh, assuming they secure no Democratic votes.

Other Republican senators whose votes were expected to be up in the air, like Sens. Bob Corker, came out in support of Kavanaugh late Thursday. "While both individuals provided a compelling testimony, nothing that has been presented corroborates the allegation," Corker said in a statement, referring to Kavanaugh and Ford.

Kavanaugh vehemently denied the allegations leveled against him by Ford, calling the process a "national disgrace" and a "circus." "The Constitution gives the Senate an important role in the confirmation process," Kavanaugh said in his opening statement. "But you have replaced advise and consent with search and destroy."

Title: Facebook's Early Data Sharing Experiments Led to FTC Agreement and Internal Resistance

Facebook's agreement with regulators in 2011 was a direct result of the company's early experiments with data sharing. In late 2009, Facebook changed the privacy settings of its 400 million users, making some of their information accessible to all of the internet. The company shared this information, including users' locations and religious and political leanings, with Microsoft and other partners, which it called "instant personalization." The feature aimed to customize what people saw on sites like Bing, but it drew complaints from privacy advocates and many Facebook users that the social network had shared the information without permission.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) investigated and in 2011 cited the privacy changes as a deceptive practice. Facebook officials stopped mentioning instant personalization in public and entered into a consent agreement. As part of the decree, Facebook introduced a "comprehensive privacy program" to review new products and features. The program was initially overseen by two chief privacy officers and was assessed by PricewaterhouseCoopers every two years.

However, the privacy program faced internal resistance from the start, according to four former Facebook employees with direct knowledge of the company's efforts. Some engineers and executives considered the privacy reviews an impediment to quick innovation and growth. The core team responsible for coordinating the reviews was moved around within Facebook's organization, sending mixed signals about how seriously the company took the issue.

Critically, many of Facebook's special sharing partnerships were not subject to extensive privacy program reviews, according to two former employees. Executives believed that because the partnerships were governed by business contracts requiring them to follow Facebook data policies, they did not require the same level of scrutiny. The privacy team had limited ability to review or suggest changes to some of those data-sharing agreements, which had been negotiated by more senior officials at the company.

Facebook officials stated that members of the privacy team had been consulted on the sharing agreements, but the level of review "depended on the specific partnership and the time it was created."

Title: US Senate Confirms First Female CIA Director Amid Controversy Over Interrogation Techniques

The US Senate has confirmed Gina Haspel as the CIA's first female director, despite her involvement in the agency's post-9/11 interrogation program. The 54-45 vote followed a partisan fight among senators about the CIA's use of techniques such as waterboarding during the Bush era.

Haspel, a 33-year veteran of the CIA, oversaw a "black site" in Thailand after the 2001 attacks, where harsh interrogation techniques were used that a Senate report deemed to be torture. She was selected to run the site in 2002, and later ordered the destruction of 92 video tapes documenting the interrogation of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri and Abu Zubaydah.

Six Democrats crossed party lines to vote in favor of Haspel's confirmation, with Senator Mark Warner stating that she had pledged to never use enhanced interrogation techniques, even if the president demanded it. Two Republicans, Jeff Flake and Rand Paul, voted against her confirmation.

The confirmation of Haspel as CIA director sends a message about breaking the glass ceiling for women in the agency, according to Republican Senator Richard Burr, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. However, human rights groups have criticized Haspel's involvement in the CIA's use of torture, with some arguing that she oversaw further US torture after leaving Thailand.

It is unclear what role Haspel played in the CIA's use of torture, as her exact record has been classified by the agency. President Donald Trump has previously called for the US to resume waterboarding terrorism suspects.

Title: Yemen's Humanitarian Crisis: A Complex Issue with Multiple Actors

The ongoing conflict in Yemen has resulted in a staggering humanitarian crisis, with over 57,000 lives lost, half of the population displaced, and 2.3 million people forced to flee their homes. The conflict between the Saudi-supported government and the Iran-backed Houthi rebels has been fueled by the involvement of both countries, with Iran providing arms, training, and terrorist proxies to the Houthi rebels.

The Houthi rebels have used Iranian-supplied advanced arms to launch ballistic missiles against Saudi cities, deploy explosive unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) against Saudi civilian targets, and attack commercial ships in the Arabian Gulf. The Iranian-backed Houthi rebels have also detained thousands of Yemenis and subjected many to extreme torture.

The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and Iran-backed Lebanese Hezbollah terrorists have provided training and support to the Houthi rebels, increasing their combat effectiveness and ability to threaten Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, international shipping in the Gulf, and U.S. forces in the region. Even if Iranian weapons are cut off, the Houthi rebels' combat experience and training will persist for decades.

The U.S. has powerful interests in ending the humanitarian crisis in Yemen, stopping Iran and its Shi'a terrorist proxies, as well as Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and ISIS-Yemen, from establishing permanent footholds in the region. The U.S. must also address the Saudi-led coalition's role in the conflict, including their lack of institutional accountability and lax military culture, which have contributed to civilian deaths.

The U.S. must engage with its partners, including Saudi Arabia, to find a political solution to the conflict and ensure that the Houthi rebels are not empowered to take part in a future government, which would formalize an Iranian-Yemeni security relationship and harm U.S. national security interests. Any negotiation must prioritize the welfare of the Yemeni people and ensure that the conflict does not become a breeding ground for terrorism.

In conclusion, the humanitarian crisis in Yemen is a complex issue with multiple actors, and resolving it requires addressing the roles of both Iran and Saudi Arabia. The U.S. must engage with its partners to find a political solution and ensure that the Houthi rebels are not empowered to take part in a future government, while also addressing the Saudi-led coalition's role in the conflict and the need to remove Iran's foothold in Yemen.

Title: President Obama's State of the Union Address Focuses on Economic Fairness and Middle-Class Economics

President Obama delivered his State of the Union address on Tuesday, highlighting the need for economic fairness and the importance of middle-class economics. The address came at a time when the president has only two years left in office and faces a Congress controlled by a party that has historically ignored his pleas for cooperation. Despite the challenging circumstances, Obama chose to focus on the issue of economic inequality, emphasizing that the top earners, big banks, and Silicon Valley have done well while the middle and working classes remain stagnant.

The president proposed a plan to address this issue by redistributing wealth from the rich to those below, deploying other measures to raise wages and increase jobs. He framed the debate over inequality as a choice between an economy where only a few succeed or one that generates rising incomes and opportunities for everyone who works hard. Obama's proposal includes raising the capital gains tax to 28%, imposing ordinary income tax rates on dividends, and ending a tax code provision that shields inherited wealth. These changes would finance tax breaks for middle-income families, including credits for two-earner couples, increased child care and college tuition credits, and other programs.

The president's plan is designed to be revenue-neutral, with the tax increases paying for the new programs to avoid the ongoing debate over deficits. While the proposal may not be radical, it is a significant step towards addressing the issue of economic inequality and inserting it into the political debate. The address is likely to have implications for the 2016 presidential elections and beyond, as Hillary Rodham Clinton or other Democratic nominees will be hard-pressed to ignore the issue of economic fairness. Even Republicans may find the idea of doing something for the middle class attractive, despite their reluctance to raise taxes on top-tier earners.

Title: Emails Reveal Early Description of Benghazi Attack as It Unfolded

The United States Department of State released email alerts sent during the September 11 attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, providing the earliest description of the events as they unfolded. The emails were sent to various government and intelligence agencies, including the White House Situation Room, the office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the FBI.

The first alert, sent at 4:05 p.m. Eastern time, reported "US Diplomatic Mission in Benghazi Under Attack" and stated that approximately 20 armed people had fired shots, with explosions also heard. The alert also mentioned that Ambassador Christopher Stevens and four Chief of Mission/embassy personnel were in the compound's safe haven.

Less than an hour later, at 4:54 p.m., another alert was sent, stating that the firing in Benghazi had stopped, and a response team was on site attempting to locate the embassy personnel.

The third alert, sent at 6:07 p.m., reported that the Islamic military group Ansar al-Sharia had claimed responsibility for the Benghazi attack on Facebook and Twitter and had called for an attack on the Embassy in Tripoli.

The emails are expected to become part of the ongoing political debate over whether the administration attempted to mislead in saying the assault was an outgrowth of a protest, rather than a planned attack by terrorists.

Fourteen hours after the attack, President Obama sat down with Steve Kroft of "60 Minutes" for a previously scheduled interview and stated that he did not believe the attack was simply due to mob violence. "You're right that this is not a situation that was -- exactly the same as what happened in Egypt, and my suspicion is that there are folks involved in this who were looking to target Americans from the start," Mr. Obama said.

The White House and State Department declined to comment on the email alerts. The House Oversight Committee told [reporter] that the information in the emails will be part of their ongoing investigation into the Benghazi attack.

Title: Obama Promises to Work with Republicans to Create a Better Government

Article:

In a recent political fundraiser in Chicago, President Barack Obama emphasized the need for a bipartisan approach to create a better government for the next generation of Americans. Speaking at the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) event, Obama acknowledged that while Washington may appear broken, it can be fixed. He emphasized that the key to success lies in creating a politics that matches the decency, hard work, and determination of the American people.

The president expressed his willingness to work with all Republicans who do not view compromise as a dirty word, stating that the task facing politicians is to create a government that is befitting the next generation of Americans. He highlighted the importance of creating a system that allows the next generation to express their creativity, ingenuity, and values through politics.

During the event, Obama touched on several key issues, including gun control, education, U.S. infrastructure, and climate change. He emphasized the potential for the United States to become energy independent over the next couple of decades, which would have a significant impact on geopolitics and the environment.

The fundraiser was attended by around 150 people, who paid between $1,000 and $5,000 to hear the president speak. The event was also attended by members of the Illinois congressional delegation, Democratic power players, and longtime supporters of the president. The president also visited the home of Paul and Bettylu Saltzman, who he credited with helping him get elected.

The pair of fundraisers is the third that Obama has headlined for the DCCC this year, with three more scheduled for the remainder of the year.

Title: Democrats Prepare to Introduce Big-Government Bills in the New Year

As the new year approaches, Democrats are gearing up to introduce a slew of big-government bills that could potentially see a floor vote once they take control of the House. Proposals like "Medicare for all" and other generous-but-costly welfare programs that were previously discussed but never passed with Republicans in control could now have a chance to move forward.

According to Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman, D-N.J., there are dozens of measures that have been languishing with Republicans at the helm for years, and she expects many of them to finally come to the floor under Democratic leadership. These measures include everything from education to healthcare, and Democrats increasingly favor major government expansions.

The consideration of these bills on the House side would mark a first step in formally considering major government expansions, which could reveal just how broad their support is. However, it's unlikely that these measures would make it to President Trump's desk with the GOP's expanded majority in the Senate.

Some of the Democratic Party's agenda, likely to be spearheaded by Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi, was outlined in their "A Better Deal" campaign platform. The set of proposals claims nearly every item could be paid for by rolling back the Trump tax cuts. The most liberal bills have emerged from the Congressional Progressive Caucus.

The "Green New Deal" platform, pushed by progressives like Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, includes a tuition-free and federally funded education system, guaranteed jobs with an emphasis on "green" jobs, and more. Over 40 Democratic lawmakers back the plan, although it's unclear whether it would ever be translated into a bill, let alone come to a vote.

Other proposals include "college for all," "debt-free college," "child care for all," and a "jobs guarantee." Democratic members, while in the minority, sponsored individual bills calling for these measures during the last two years, which could now be voted on along with climate legislation, pro-labor union bills, and attempts to roll back the tax reform bill that passed in late 2017.

Rep. Watson Coleman introduced the Federal Jobs Guarantee Development Act in 2018, which would establish job-guarantee test sites in 15 high-unemployment areas across the country. The federal government would match those seeking employment with jobs in understaffed fields.

Other Democratic lawmakers have also introduced their own bills, including Rep. Bobby Scott, D-Va., who introduced the "Worker's Freedom to Negotiate Act," which bans state laws that allow employees to opt not to join a union and pay union dues. Currently, 28 states have some form of a "right-to-work" law.

The Democratic campaign plan also calls for spending $40 billion on "universal high-speed Internet." A similar bill was promoted by Rep. Cheri Bustos, D-Ill., who pushed to expand Internet into rural areas.

Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., has been a leading advocate of the Child Care for Working Families Act, which would ensure that no family under 150 percent of a state's median income pays more than 7 percent of their income for child care. The legislation would also establish a federal-state partnership to provide child care from birth through age 13.

Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif., said he anticipates his Job Opportunities for All Act, with 22 Democratic co-sponsors, will make it to the floor in the new Congress. The legislation would provide federal funding to put people to work immediately in both the public and private sector.

Rep. Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., could play a prominent role in such legislative proposals. She is a co-chairwoman of the Medicare For All Caucus, which has nearly 80 members committed to a complete government-run healthcare system. She was also elected co-chairwoman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, set to have more than 90 members after the election.

Jayapal was also the sponsor of the College for All Act in 2017, which would eliminate tuition and fees at public colleges and universities for families earning up to $125,000, and make community college free for everyone. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., introduced the Senate version. Rep. Mark Pocan, D-Wis., the other progressive caucus co-chairman, introduced a similar bill, the Debt-Free College Act, which would provide more federal funding to states to alleviate student loan debt.

Title: White House Aides Say President Obama Not Worried by Recent Rebellion

The article reports on the current state of the Democratic party's unity and President Barack Obama's leadership during the recent government shutdown and the subsequent issues with the Affordable Care Act (ACA) website. According to White House aides, President Obama is not concerned by the recent rebellion within the Democratic party, which has seen some lawmakers question his leadership and the administration's handling of the ACA rollout.

The article highlights how the president's popularity and the Democratic party's unity were boosted during the shutdown, with many lawmakers rallying behind him. However, the problems with the ACA website have since caused a shift in public perception, with many questioning the administration's ability to effectively implement the law.

The article also mentions that some Democrats, such as Senator Joe Manchin, are pushing for changes to the law, including a delay of the individual mandate penalty. White House officials are confident that the public will move past the political issues surrounding the ACA and focus on its benefits once the website is improved.

Overall, the article provides an update on the current state of the Democratic party's unity and President Obama's leadership during the ACA rollout, highlighting the challenges the administration faces in addressing public concerns and implementing the law effectively.

Title: New York Attorney General Sues Trump Foundation, Alleging Extensive and Persistent Lawbreaking

The New York Attorney General, Barbara Underwood, has filed a lawsuit against the Trump Foundation, as well as Donald Trump and his children, alleging "extensive and persistent" lawbreaking. The lawsuit seeks to dissolve the foundation and recover $2.8 million in restitution.

According to the petition, the Trump Foundation engaged in "unlawful political coordination" designed to influence the 2016 election. The lawsuit claims that the foundation and its directors, including Trump and his three eldest children, Donald Jr., Eric, and Ivanka, violated laws governing non-profit organizations.

The attorney general is also seeking to bar the president and his children from serving on the board of any New York-based charity, citing "misconduct and total lack of oversight." The case has been referred to the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Election Commission.

The lawsuit alleges that Trump used charitable assets to pay off legal obligations, promote his own businesses, and purchase personal items, including a painting of himself. The Trump Foundation has denied the charges, accusing the attorney general of holding its remaining funds "hostage for political gain."

This lawsuit is the culmination of a two-year investigation, which began under the previous New York attorney general, Eric Schneiderman. Schneiderman resigned last month after several former girlfriends accused him of physical abuse.

The Trump Foundation had previously been ordered to stop fundraising in New York in 2016 after finding it had no proper registration. Trump had vowed to shut down the foundation in December 2016 to avoid "even the appearance" of conflict of interest.

The lawsuit adds to Trump's legal challenges, which include a wide-ranging special counsel investigation into alleged ties between the Trump campaign and Russia.

**NSA Admits to Thousands of Privacy Violations, Calls Them "Mistakes"**

The National Security Agency (NSA) has acknowledged that it has broken privacy rules thousands of times since 2008, according to an internal audit. The audit, first reported by the Washington Post, found 2,776 incidents of unauthorized collection, storage, access, or distribution of legally protected communications in the preceding 12 months.

The NSA's director of compliance, John DeLong, acknowledged that "mistakes occur" but emphasized that most incidents are quickly addressed and that the agency has a "zero tolerance" for misconduct. DeLong stated that the agency detects and corrects mistakes as they occur and are identified, which stops them from being "propagated."

The audit found that most incidents involved unauthorized surveillance of Americans or foreign intelligence targets in the country. In one case, the NSA decided it did not need to report the unintended surveillance. The agency also reported that it had failed to report a "large number" of calls placed from Washington that were intercepted due to a programming error that confused the capital's 202 area code for 20, the international dialing code for Egypt.

Congressional leaders have expressed concern about the mistakes and called for more oversight. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vermont, said he will continue to demand "honest and forthright answers" from the intelligence community and will hold a hearing on the Post's revelations. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called for "rigorous oversight" by Congress on the "incidents of non-compliance."

The NSA has defended its programs, stating that its foreign intelligence collection activities are continually audited and overseen internally and externally. The agency also emphasized that it has a "persistent, dedicated effort to identify incidents or risks of incidents at the earliest possible moment, implement mitigation measures wherever possible, and drive the numbers down."

Title: GOP Rep. Lou Barletta Wins Pennsylvania Republican Senate Primary

Article:

Representative Lou Barletta has won the Pennsylvania Republican Senate primary, defeating state Representative Jim Christiana. The Associated Press called the race after 52 percent of precincts had reported their numbers, showing Barletta with 59 percent of the votes. Barletta will now face Democratic incumbent Bob Casey Jr. in the high-stakes race for U.S. Senate.

Barletta received support from President Donald Trump, who tweeted in February that Barletta was "a Great Republican" and one of his "very earliest supporters." Trump also criticized Casey, stating that he listens to "Tax Hikers Pelosi and Schumer." Trump sent out another tweet on May 16, congratulating Barletta on his victory and stating that Barletta will "very much help MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!"

Barletta will now face Casey in the November general election for U.S. Senate.

Title: Criticism of Trump's Leadership Style and Media's Role in Political Discourse

The article discusses the criticism of Republican politicians and the media's role in shaping public opinion. The author argues that the media often provides unsolicited advice to Republican leaders, which can lead to their downfall. The article also touches on the media's criticism of President Trump's leadership style and its potential impact on his re-election chances.

The author suggests that Trump's success is partly due to his indifference to the media's counsel, and advises him to continue ignoring the media's advice. The article also criticizes the media's criticism of Trump's potential decision to fire Special Counsel Robert Mueller, stating that the media's reaction would be overblown and that Trump would likely benefit from such a move.

The article also highlights the author's disagreement with former CIA Director John Brennan's comments, in which he suggested that government officials should refuse to carry out orders to fire Mueller. The author views Brennan's comments as treasonous and anti-American, and argues that he is attempting to undermine the elected head of the US government.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of the media's role in shaping public opinion and its potential impact on political leaders.

Title: US Warns Syria Against Using Chemical Weapons, Amid Reports of Increased Activity

The United States has issued a stern warning to Syria against using chemical weapons, as reports emerge of increased activity at the country's stockpiles. According to intelligence reports, the Syrian government has been moving its chemical weapons stockpiles to more secure locations, sparking concerns among American officials.

At a news conference in August, President Barack Obama stated that any evidence of the Syrian government using its chemical weapons in a threatening way or making use of them would be a "red line" that could prompt direct American intervention. "That would change my calculus," he added. "That would change my equation."

American officials have refused to comment on the specific intelligence reports, but a senior administration official warned that the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government would be a serious escalation that would demand decisive action from the international community.

The White House has also emphasized that the United States is closely monitoring developments related to Syria's stockpiles of chemical weapons and is in regular contact with international partners who share its concerns. The administration official stated, "The Assad regime must know that the world is watching, and that they will be held accountable by the United States and the international community if they use chemical weapons or fail to meet their obligations to secure them."

The reports of increased activity at the chemical weapons stockpiles have sparked concerns among some lawmakers, with Representative Mike Rogers, a Michigan Republican who heads the House Intelligence Committee, stating that the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government would be an extremely serious escalation that would demand decisive action from the rest of the world.

The United States has taken steps to prepare for the possibility of a chemical weapons attack, with the military quietly sending a task force of over 150 planners and specialists to Jordan to help the armed forces prepare for the possibility of a chemical weapons attack. Turkey has also requested two batteries of the Patriot antimissile system from NATO, citing concerns that Syrian missiles could be used to attack Turkish territory.

This is not the first time activity at the chemical weapons stockpiles has been detected. In September, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta stated that there had been "some movement" of Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles to more secure locations. However, officials are no longer willing to say that all the sites remain secure.

The increased activity has also raised concerns about the potential for opposition groups, including those linked to Hezbollah, to gain access to the chemical weapons depots. The United States and its allies have increased electronic surveillance and other monitoring activities of the sites, with a senior defense official stating that no United States troops have been put on heightened alert in response to the activity, although the Pentagon is prepared to do so if necessary.

Title: George Conway Discusses Views on Trump Administration and Marriage with Kellyanne

George Conway, the husband of Kellyanne Conway, a senior advisor to President Donald Trump, recently sat down with Yahoo News for an in-depth interview on the podcast Skullduggery. Conway, who has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration, shared his thoughts on his wife's role in the White House and his own experiences with the administration.

Conway revealed that he was considered for a position at the Justice Department as chief of the civil division, but ultimately declined due to his concerns about the administration. He described the experience as "like being in a dumpster fire" and cited the firing of FBI Director James Comey and Trump's comments about having Russia on his mind as reasons for his decision.

Despite his criticisms of the administration, Conway praised his wife's "amazing" work and acknowledged her role in helping Trump become president. He stated that she "steadied that boat" during the campaign, but acknowledged that Trump has changed the country and the Republican party under his leadership.

Conway also expressed his discomfort with being a Republican and stated that he would rather move to Australia than vote for Trump again. He compared his disagreements with his wife to any other marital disagreement, saying that if he had a nickel for every person in Washington who disagrees with their spouse, he wouldn't be on the podcast.

The interview provided insight into the personal and professional life of George Conway, as well as his views on the Trump administration and his marriage to Kellyanne Conway.

Title: Israel Expresses Concerns Over Iran's Nuclear Program and Palestinian Peace Talks

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has expressed concerns over Iran's nuclear program and the ongoing peace talks with the Palestinians. In a speech at the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, Netanyahu warned the world to learn from the past and prevent another Holocaust, drawing parallels between the Nazi genocide and Iran's suspected drive to acquire nuclear bombs. He emphasized the importance of identifying and acting against existential threats in time, citing the failure of most world leaders to recognize the danger of the Holocaust before it occurred.

Meanwhile, Secretary of State John Kerry has warned that if a two-state solution is not reached in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israel risks becoming "an apartheid state" like the old South Africa. This statement has sparked outrage among Jewish leaders in the United States and could attract unwanted attention in Israel. Senior American officials have rarely used the term "apartheid" in reference to Israel, and President Obama has previously rejected the idea that the word should apply to the Jewish State.

The Israeli government has expressed concerns over the Obama administration's handling of the peace talks, which have stalled due to ongoing tensions between Israel and the Palestinians. The Israeli government has also expressed concerns over Iran's nuclear program and its leaders' repeated references to the destruction of Israel and denial of the Holocaust.

Title: U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm Faces Criminal Charges Amid Campaign Finance Allegations

U.S. Representative Michael Grimm, a Republican, is facing criminal charges from federal prosecutors, according to his attorney, William McGinley. The charges stem from allegations of campaign finance violations, which have been ongoing since Grimm's first campaign for Congress in 2009 and 2010. A House Ethics Committee investigation was launched in November, and the panel announced it would defer its inquiry due to a separate Department of Justice investigation.

Grimm's attorney, McGinley, stated that his client has done nothing wrong and is not surprised by the charges. "After more than two years of investigation plagued by malicious leaks, violations of grand jury secrecy, and strong-arm tactics, the U.S. Attorney's Office has disclosed its intent to file criminal charges against Congressman Grimm," McGinley said in a statement. "When the dust settles, he will be vindicated."

A spokesman for the U.S. Attorney's Office in Brooklyn declined to confirm, deny, or comment on the case. The FBI's New York office, which handles investigations, also declined to comment.

Grimm has been dogged by allegations of campaign finance violations, including receiving $250,000 to $300,000 in contributions from followers of an Israeli rabbi, Yoshiyahu Yosef Pinto. Some members of Pinto's congregation subsequently said they made tens of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions, including gifts passed through straw donors. Grimm has denied knowledge of any improprieties, and the FBI has not accused him of any wrongdoing.

A Houston woman, Diana Durand, who was romantically involved with Grimm, was indicted on charges of using straw donors to make illegal campaign contributions and making false statements to the FBI. Durand's attorney, Stuart Kaplan, said she will plead not guilty to the charges.

Grimm's office did not immediately return requests for comment. A House member who has been indicted does not lose any rights or privileges under federal law or the chamber's rules, according to a report by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service.

**Title:** Sanders Spends Most on Ads, Trump Spends Best

**Article:**

The 2020 general election is shaping up to be one of the most expensive in history, with a record-breaking number of TV ads already aired. According to the Wesleyan Media Project, 480,000 ads have been broadcast so far, a 112% increase from the 2012 election. Despite the high spending, the data suggests that the best-performing candidates are not always the biggest spenders.

Bernie Sanders has spent the most on TV ads, with nearly 125,000 ads aired as of May 8, fueled largely by small donations. Hillary Clinton spent about $11 million less, with $62.6 million spent on 105,000 ads. However, when looking at spending per vote, Sanders spent about $8 per vote, while Clinton spent about $5 per vote.

On the Republican side, the spending disparities are more striking. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal's campaign spent about $17,000 per vote, dwarfing the spending of other candidates. However, when excluding Jindal's astronomical figure, the data shows that Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, and Lindsey Graham spent millions but had few votes to show for it.

The super PAC has changed the campaign fundraising game, but money does not guarantee votes. Jeb Bush and his super PAC, Right to Rise, know this firsthand. Part of the issue is that advertising is an arms race, and ads may be losing their effectiveness as Americans cut the cord and spend more time online.

One candidate stands out by not standing out: Donald Trump. As of the May 3 contests, Trump spent about $2 on TV ads per vote, less than half of what his competitors spent. Part of this is that he had less work to do, as he was already a household name. However, it's also true that Trump worked to get as much free media as he could, using his celebrity status to his advantage. By one estimate, he received $2 billion in free media coverage as of March.

Title: Pentagon Reports 11 Troops Pulled Out of Iraq for Brain Injury Treatment, 17 Return to Duty

The Pentagon has provided an update on the number of troops affected by brain injuries in Iraq. According to Hoffman, the military conducted follow-on screenings and found that 11 troops were pulled out of Iraq for brain injury treatment. Of the 34 troops diagnosed with brain injuries, 17 have returned to duty, including one service member who was transferred to Kuwait for treatment.

Eight service members have been transferred to the U.S. for treatment after initially being sent to Germany. Nine are still undergoing treatment and evaluation in Germany. Hoffman attributed the change in numbers to symptoms that "are late-developing" and "manifest over a period of time."

President Trump played down the initial reports of injuries, stating that he heard they had headaches and a couple of other things, but that it is "not very serious." Secretary of Defense Esper clarified that the Pentagon does not normally report such injuries and that most cases are outpatient, trackable, and not serious. Esper also emphasized the importance of being accurate and categorizing injuries properly, not just in Iraq, but wherever troops are engaged.

The Pentagon's commitment to transparency and accuracy is evident in their reporting of injuries around the globe.

Title: Facebook's Trending Topics: A Study in Biased Curation

Facebook's trending topics feature, designed to provide users with a snapshot of the most popular and relevant news stories, has been found to be less organic than advertised. A recent investigation by Gizmodo revealed that former Facebook curators admitted to excluding conservative news and opinion sites from the trending topics list, including The Drudge Report, Breitbart News, The Washington Examiner, and RedState. The suppressed topics included events such as the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) and discussions about Mitt Romney.

The investigation also found that curators received instructions to "inject" topics into the index to artificially produce discussion, with some topics appearing to be agenda-driven. The Black Lives Matter movement, for example, was injected into the trending topics list, despite being a topic that originated on Facebook.

Facebook's trending section appears to work like a newsroom, with editors selecting topics, sources of information, and the manner and order of presentation to readers. However, Facebook has claimed that its process involves no value judgments, stating that the topics are based on factors such as engagement, timeliness, Pages you've liked, and your location.

Facebook has denied the allegations, stating that they have found no evidence that the anonymous allegations are true and that their tools make it technically not feasible to systematically discriminate against sources of any ideological origin.

The controversy has sparked questions about what conservatives should do in light of these allegations. Some have suggested that conservatives should dump Facebook altogether, but this would be a mistake. Facebook is enormous, with nearly three in five American adults having an account. Instead, conservatives should use the platform to engage with others, make connections, and expand the reach and relevance of their agenda.

However, conservatives and all Facebook users should treat the platform with more skepticism than they once did. With the ability to access a wide range of news sources and information, consumers should exercise their own choices and call out biases when they become obvious. Informed consumer choice is not only an antidote to editorial bias but a freedom worth exercising on any and all social networks.

Title: White House Expands on IRS Details, Clarifies Communication on Investigation

The White House has provided additional information on its knowledge of the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) scrutiny of conservative political groups, clarifying the extent of its communication on the matter. Press Secretary Jay Carney revealed that White House officials, including Deputy Chief of Staff Mark Childress, consulted with the Treasury Department on the timing of releasing the findings and the actual audit.

Carney stated that the conversations involved discussing the possibility of a speech by Lois Lerner, who oversaw the IRS's work on tax-exempt groups, as well as testimony by the acting commissioner of the agency and what he would say if asked about the issue. Only two senior White House staff members, Chief of Staff Denis McDonough and White House Counsel Kathy Ruemmler, were aware of the IRS probe, with Ruemmler making the decision not to inform the President of the forthcoming inspector general report.

Carney emphasized that the White House had provided an "enormous amount of information" about its communication on the issue, but refused to disclose more details on who else knew of the report's existence before news stories emerged on May 10. When pressed for information, Carney only mentioned that Ruemmler may have had conversations about the issue, but did not provide further details.

The briefing became testy when Carney was asked if he was among the senior staff informed of the IRS investigation, with him stating he was not, like the President, learning about it from news reports. The White House has maintained its position that it did not inform the President about the inspector general's report before the news became public.

Title: Medicaid Doctors Face 42% Pay Cut in 2015: A Looming Cliff for Healthcare Access

The Affordable Care Act (ACA) temporarily boosted payment rates for primary care doctors who see Medicaid patients in 2013 and 2014 to ensure they would continue participating in the program as it expanded to cover millions more Americans. The pay raise, averaging a 73% increase, was funded through the end of 2014, setting up a looming cliff that will see a 42% pay cut for Medicaid doctors starting January 1, 2015.

The pay cut will vary significantly from state to state, depending on each state's Medicaid payment rates. Fifteen states have decided to step in and provide funding to either fully or partially continue the payment increase, with states like New Mexico and Mississippi already paying Medicaid doctors relatively well.

The concern among Medicaid advocates is that lower payment rates will translate into fewer doctors being willing to see patients, potentially affecting access to care for millions of Americans. However, some studies suggest that Medicaid patients have just as good access to primary care as those with private insurance, and thousands of doctors have continued to see Medicaid patients even before the pay bump.

The future of Obamacare and Medicaid payment rates remains uncertain, with the federal government not extending the pay cut and Congress failing to pass legislation to extend it. As the clock ticks closer to January 1, 2015, the fate of Medicaid doctors and the millions of Americans they serve hangs in the balance.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Implements Immigration Enforcement Changes, Expanding Categories of Illegal Immigrants Targeted for Deportation

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has released two memos outlining a series of immigration enforcement changes ordered by President Trump. The directives aim to toughen enforcement by expanding the categories of illegal immigrants targeted for deportation, while sparing so-called "dreamers" and those given a reprieve in 2014.

The changes prioritize criminal illegal immigrants and others for deportation, including those convicted or charged with any criminal offense, or who have abused any public welfare program. The DHS is also expanding the 287(g) program, which allows participating local officers to act as immigration agents, and starting the planning, design, and construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall.

The memos also aim to end "catch-and-release" policies, under which illegal immigrants subject to deportation are allowed to potentially abscond and fail to appear at removal hearings. The exact timelines and budgetary constraints for these objectives are unclear.

The directives come as the Trump administration faces criticism from Democratic lawmakers and immigration advocacy groups for recent ICE raids of illegal immigrants. DHS officials have stressed that they are operating under existing law and have shot down an erroneous news report claiming National Guard troops could be utilized to round up illegal immigrants.

The changes do not affect Obama-era protections for illegal immigrants who came to the U.S. as children and others given a reprieve in 2014. A DHS official said the agencies are "going back to our traditional roots" on enforcement, prioritizing criminal illegal immigrants and others for deportation.

The memos also hint at future efforts to potentially use money otherwise meant for Mexico to fund the border wall, following Trump's repeated campaign vow to make Mexico pay for it. Mexican officials have repeatedly said they will not pay for a border barrier.

Title: FEMA Terminates Contract with Contractor Over Underdelivery of Meals to Puerto Rico

A recent investigation by The New York Times has revealed that a contractor, Tiffany Brown and her company Tribute Contracting LLC, drastically underdelivered on a massive contract to provide millions of meals to Puerto Ricans affected by Hurricane Maria. The $156 million contract, awarded by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) on October 3, required Tribute to provide 30 million self-heating meals to the island. However, the company only delivered 50,000 meals, falling short of the deadline to provide the first 18.5 million meals.

FEMA terminated the contract by email on October 19, citing the company's failure to meet the deadline. A FEMA official, Carolyn Ward, described the operation as "a logistical nightmare" and instructed Brown not to ship any more meals. A FEMA spokesman stated that other suppliers provided "ample" food and water for Puerto Ricans, and that Tribute's contract did not result in any missed meals.

This is not the first time Tribute has failed to deliver on a contract. The company has been awarded dozens of contracts, but has failed to deliver on several, including four that required it to deliver food products to correctional facilities in the Federal Prison System. At the time the FEMA contract was awarded, the Government Publishing Office had a ban on awarding contracts of more than $35,000 to Tribute until January 2019 due to a mishandled project.

Brown is now fighting the FEMA contract termination and seeking a $70 million settlement. Her appeal argues that FEMA canceled her contract because the meals Tribute provided were packaged separately from their heating pouches, and claims that FEMA did not specify that the meals had to be self-heating.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is investigating the Tribute contract. Committee Democrats criticized FEMA in a letter to committee chairman Trey Gowdy, stating that FEMA should have considered Tribute's history and lack of large-scale disaster relief experience before awarding the contract. They highlighted the Tribute contract as the latest example of how FEMA was unprepared to handle the hurricane aftermath in Puerto Rico by not preparing contractors in advance.

FEMA and the Puerto Rican government reached an agreement earlier this month to continue providing food and water to affected communities, after the agency faced major backlash following a report that it would stop the distribution.

Title: US National Security Adviser Says Evidence of Russian Meddling in 2016 Election is "Incontrovertible"

Article:

The US national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, stated at the Munich Security Conference in Germany that the recent FBI indictments have proven that Russia meddled in the 2016 US presidential election. McMaster emphasized that the evidence is now "incontrovertible" that Moscow interfered in the campaign. He also expressed skepticism about the possibility of working with Russia on cybersecurity, saying that the country must demonstrate a commitment to curtailing its espionage activities.

The indictment, brought by special counsel Robert Mueller, accuses 13 Russian nationals and three Russian companies of interfering in the 2016 election. The charges detail a sophisticated plot to wage "information warfare" against the US, with the goal of sowing discord in the US political system, including the 2016 presidential election.

The indictment does not allege that any American was a knowing participant in the illegal activity or that the interference changed the outcome of the election. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein emphasized that the investigation is ongoing and that the charges do not imply any collusion between Trump associates and Russian officials.

Russia's foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, dismissed the indictment as "just blabber," stating that the US has not provided any evidence of Russian interference and that officials have said no country influenced the election results. Lavrov called for the US to provide facts before making accusations.

The 37-page indictment, signed by Mueller, details the actions of the defendants, which date back to 2014. The defendants are accused of spreading derogatory information about Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, denigrating Republican candidates Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, and ultimately supporting Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders and then-Republican candidate Donald Trump.

President Trump tweeted that the indictment did not tell the whole story, stating that the results of the 2016 election were not impacted and that the only collusion was between Russia and Crooked H, the DNC, and the Democrats.

**Romney's Economic Program Takes a Hit as Controversial Video Emerges**

A recent video surfaced, showing Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney describing a significant portion of President Barack Obama's supporters as dependent on government and unwilling to take responsibility for their own lives. The video, posted on the website of liberal magazine Mother Jones, shows Romney speaking at a private fundraiser earlier this year.

In the video, Romney stated that 47% of the population will vote for Obama regardless of his policies, and that these individuals are dependent on government support, believing they are entitled to healthcare, food, and housing. He also mentioned that these individuals pay no income tax.

Romney's comments sparked controversy, with some interpreting them as unflattering to Obama supporters and millions of people who hold jobs and pay payroll taxes but do not earn enough to pay income tax. The comments echoed ideas he has laid out elsewhere as central to his candidacy, stating that the federal government spends too much money and has unmoored the country from the principles of free enterprise and hard work.

Romney's campaign did not back away from his remarks, with the nominee saying they were not "elegantly stated" but were made in response to a question. Romney believes that Americans who pay no taxes or receive government benefits would be less likely to support his campaign, as his message of cutting taxes and shrinking the size of government would not resonate with them.

The incident is reminiscent of Obama's remarks this summer, which were interpreted by Republicans as a disparagement of entrepreneurialism. Democrats said the president meant only that government spending on infrastructure and other programs is important to business owners.

The controversy comes as Romney's campaign is facing signs that Obama is building a lead in national opinion polls and most battleground states. Romney's campaign has pledged to roll out more policy specifics and has released a set of new TV ads, marking an effort to regain his footing.

Title: Contact Tracing Efforts Raise Concerns Over Privacy and Trust

The novel coronavirus pandemic has brought about unprecedented measures to contain its spread, including the deployment of "contact tracers" to identify individuals who may have come into contact with those infected. While this tactic has shown promise in other countries, its implementation in the United States raises concerns over privacy and trust.

The National Association of County and City Health Officials estimates that at least 100,000 contact tracers will be needed to keep the virus at bay as communities reopen. New York state has set a goal of hiring 6,400 to 17,000 contact tracers, while New York City's "Test and Trace Corps" will launch with 1,000 tracers.

While Johns Hopkins University offers a free online course in contact tracing, which covers the biology of the virus and ethical considerations, including respect for privacy, the actual deployment of contact tracers is being managed by state, city, and local government agencies. This raises concerns over potential abuse of power.

In Washington state, the phased reopening plan includes an initial 1,371 contact tracers, which has raised questions about privacy rights. The state requires businesses to keep a log of customers' names, dates, and contact information, which has sparked concerns over the potential for government overreach.

In California, a contact tracing program announcement sparked concerns over the potential for forced isolation, with some individuals receiving official phone calls hanging up or refusing to cooperate. A San Francisco contact tracer noted that some people are hesitant to share information due to mistrust of the government.

Participation in contact tracing is voluntary, and officials acknowledge that some individuals may refuse to share information. Even if cooperation became mandatory, enforcement would be challenging, as individuals could potentially lie to government officials they do not trust.

The success of contact tracing efforts depends on winning public trust and cooperation. Public officials must demonstrate the effectiveness and innocence of their tactics to convince the public to participate.

Title: Federal Reserve Lowers Economic Outlook, Reduces Odds of Interest Rate Hike in June

The Federal Reserve has lowered its economic outlook, citing a harsh winter that slowed down the US economy's growth. This move has reduced the likelihood of an interest rate hike as soon as the Fed's June meeting. The central bank's statement did not provide a clear signal on when it plans to raise its benchmark interest rate for the first time since 2006, but policymakers have indicated they expect to act this year.

The Fed's statement noted that economic growth slowed during the winter months, partly due to transitory factors such as unusually cold weather. However, it expects the economy to rebound and grow at a moderate pace in the coming months. The central bank also stated that job growth moderated, household spending declined, and business investment softened, while exports declined.

The Fed's preferred measure of inflation, which excludes food and energy costs, rose 0.9% last quarter, the smallest increase since 2010. The government reported that the economy grew just 0.2% at an annual rate in the first quarter, down from 2.2% in the previous quarter.

The Fed reiterated that it will bump up its federal funds rate when it has seen further improvement in the labor market and is reasonably confident that inflation will move back to its 2% target over the medium-term. The central bank has kept its benchmark interest rate near zero since the 2008 financial crisis, but with the economic recovery now almost six years old, it has been preparing financial markets and consumers for a return to normal interest rate policy.

Many economists believe the Fed is unlikely to act until September at the earliest, allowing it to assess whether the economy is regaining the momentum it had built last year. This timetable is consistent with the Fed's median forecast in March and recent speeches by Fed policymakers, including Chair Janet Yellen.

Title: Pompeo's Scandal: A Pattern of Abuse of Power and Disregard for Procedure

The recent revelations surrounding Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's activities have brought him into the headlines, with allegations of a pattern of abuse of power, disregard for procedure, and a propensity to treat a government position as a personal fiefdom. The scandal was propelled by Pompeo's own efforts to keep it quiet, and the closer we look, the more disturbing his actions appear.

Investigations by various news organizations have uncovered a series of luxurious dinners hosted by Pompeo and his wife, Susan, at the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms, paid for by taxpayers, with guest lists comprised mostly of Republican donors and activists rather than foreign diplomats and policy experts. NBC News reported that 39% of the nearly 500 invitees were from Fox News.

The investigation also revealed that Pompeo had asked President Trump to fire the State Department's Inspector General, Steve Linick, who was investigating potential instances of fraud and abuse in the government. Linick was investigating Pompeo's use of a State Department political appointee to conduct personal errands, such as walking his dog and picking up his laundry.

The allegations have grown more disturbing, with Engel, the chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, revealing that Linick was investigating Pompeo's use of a State Department political appointee to conduct personal errands. NBC reported that Linick was investigating Pompeo's use of a State Department political appointee to conduct personal errands, including walking his dog and picking up his laundry.

The investigation has also raised questions about the purpose of the dinners, with some suggesting that they may have been used to further a political career within the Republican establishment. The guest list included Fox News personalities, conservative donors, and Republican members of Congress, among others.

The events, with their own logo embossed on State Department invitations, brought hundreds of people to the center of US diplomacy more than 20 times since Pompeo became Secretary of State. Pompeo's spokeswoman, Morgan Ortagus, described the dinners as an "opportunity to discuss the mission of the State Department and the complex foreign policy matters facing our exceptional nation." However, the guest list suggests a different purpose.

The investigation has also raised questions about the role of Susan Pompeo, the Secretary of State's wife, who received information about each guest and forwarded it to her private Gmail account. This raises concerns about the potential misuse of government resources for political purposes.

The scandal has sparked outrage and calls for accountability, with Democratic Rep. Eliot Engel decrying the "politically-motivated firing of inspectors general and the President's gutting of these critical positions." The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what further revelations will come to light.

Title: Hong Kong's Opposition Pro-Democracy Movement Makes Unprecedented Gains in District Council Elections

Hong Kong's district council elections have seen the opposition pro-democracy movement make significant gains, with 17 of the 18 councils now controlled by pro-democracy councillors. The election, which was seen as a test of support for the government after months of unrest, protests, and clashes, has resulted in a comprehensive defeat for the pro-Beijing camp.

According to local media counts, over 2.9 million people cast their votes, representing a turnout of more than 71%, compared to 47% in 2015. The election was the first in months without any clashes between protesters and police, and it saw a record 4.1 million people register to vote, more than half the population.

The election was seen as a test of support for the government after the withdrawal of the extradition bill, which sparked the crisis. However, the results showed that the pro-democracy movement has gained significant ground, with many young first-time candidates, who had aligned themselves with the protesters, unseating established politicians backing the government.

The election also saw the defeat of several pro-Beijing lawmakers, including Junius Ho, who lost his seat. Ho, a controversial politician, had openly voiced his support for the Hong Kong police force and had been involved in several high-profile incidents.

The results of the election are seen as a significant blow to the government and Beijing, as the district councillors will also sit on the 1,200-member committee that votes for the chief executive. The pro-democracy movement hopes that the overwhelming victory will force the government to take their demands more seriously.

Jimmy Sham, a political activist who has risen to prominence as the leader of the Civil Human Rights Front, won a seat after running for the first time. Sham has been attacked twice, once with hammers, and has been a vocal critic of the government.

The election was also marked by a record number of candidates running for 452 district council seats, with over 1,000 candidates vying for the positions. The results are seen as a significant victory for the pro-democracy movement, which has been calling for greater democracy and accountability in Hong Kong.

Title: Republicans Emphasize Legislative Achievements as Midterm Elections Approach

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, Republicans are working to emphasize their legislative achievements as a key selling point for their party. Despite the booming economy being expected to be a core pillar of the GOP's midterm messaging, it is unclear whether the party will get credit for the tax law, which has lagged in polls. To bolster their case, Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell are highlighting a range of legislative accomplishments, including the recent passage of a $1.5 trillion tax-cut package, increased spending for the military, and the confirmation of a conservative Supreme Court justice and 21 conservative circuit court judges.

McConnell has been on a media blitz in recent weeks to tout the Senate's work, while Ryan and his top lieutenants have made a similar pitch. They are emphasizing not only the tax cuts but also increased spending for the military, the repeal of 15 regulations, and the confirmation of conservative judges.

The GOP is also trying to paint a picture of Republicans as hard at work, with McConnell announcing that most of the August recess will be canceled so that senators can work on spending bills and Trump's nominations before a September 30 funding deadline. This move has the added benefit of keeping dozens of Democratic senators off the campaign trail in August.

It is unclear whether the GOP's messaging strategy will work, especially when accomplishments on Capitol Hill can be easily overshadowed by more dramatic developments coming out of the White House. The same week that Congress sent a trio of bills to Trump's desk, for example, the president dominated the news cycle by canceling a planned historic summit with North Korea.

Despite majorities in both chambers and control of the White House, Republicans failed to repeal and replace ObamaCare or fund Trump's signature border wall, disappointing the president and his most fervent supporters. Trump has bashed Congress over the failure on the wall, to the chagrin of Republicans, who think it shortchanges the accomplishments that have been secured.

The effort to push a more aggressive Republican agenda could please some conservatives, who have said tax reform alone is not enough to run on in the midterms. "You can't just rest on your laurels," said Rep. Mark Walker, chairman of the Republican Study Committee. "You've got to keep fulfilling your promises to the American people."

While the tax law's poll numbers have improved, GOP strategists point out that some voters may not see the benefits until next year. There are also concerns that the economic gains from the tax law could be wiped out after Trump slapped tariffs on steel and aluminum imports worldwide, including from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico.

Title: President Obama Considers 19 Steps to Address Gun Control Without Congressional Action

President Barack Obama is exploring 19 separate steps to address gun control, which he can take without congressional approval. These measures aim to tackle gun trafficking, improve research on gun control, and enhance school safety. The President is expected to unveil his proposals this week, which will likely include a mix of items that require congressional approval and those he can take on his own.

The steps under consideration include tougher measures on gun trafficking, freeing up federal agencies to conduct more research on gun control, and giving schools flexibility to use grants to improve safety. The President has vowed to take meaningful action on gun violence following the shooting deaths of 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, last month.

Vice President Joe Biden, who is leading a task force on the issue, met with Democratic lawmakers on Monday to outline some of the measures the President could consider. However, it is unclear which proposals the President will take up or present to the country this week.

One measure that may face significant opposition is a ban on military-style, so-called "assault weapons." Some lawmakers, including National Rifle Association President David Keene and U.S. Senator John McCain, have predicted that such a measure would not pass through Congress. Other potential measures include limiting high-capacity ammunition clips and requiring universal background checks for gun buyers.

President Obama acknowledged the difficulty of getting some of these items passed, stating, "Will all of them get through this Congress? I don't know. My starting point is not to worry about the politics. My starting point is to focus on what makes sense, what works."

Title: Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Faces Prospect of Indictment Over Alleged Lies to Investigators

Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, a frequent target of President Donald Trump's criticism, is facing the possibility of an indictment after his lawyers failed to persuade senior Justice Department officials to drop charges that he lied to internal investigators. Two people familiar with the matter, who were not authorized to discuss the issue publicly, said that the deputy attorney general declined an appeal from McCabe's lawyers to prevent a prosecution.

It is unclear when or if the United States Attorney's Office in Washington, which has been leading the investigation, will announce charges against McCabe. McCabe's attorneys have argued that he should not face charges for allegedly lying to investigators about whether he authorized a news media leak in the fall of 2016. McCabe has denied intentionally misleading anyone.

An indictment of McCabe would refocus public attention on the chaotic months of 2016 when the FBI was entangled in presidential politics through investigations touching both main contenders – Democrat Hillary Clinton and Trump, her Republican opponent. Prosecutors are likely to focus on whether McCabe lied to investigators on specific dates, while McCabe's attorneys are expected to argue that the prosecution is part of a political vendetta driven by the president.

McCabe's lawyers have said any false statements made to investigators were the result of a faulty memory, and that the interviews took place during a tumultuous time for the bureau as it investigated potential ties between Russia and the Trump campaign. McCabe became acting director of the FBI after Trump fired former Director James Comey in May 2017. He has said his 2018 firing – for what the Justice Department called "lack of candor" – was politically motivated.

The investigation followed an October 2016 story in The Wall Street Journal that described internal debates roiling the FBI and the Justice Department weeks before the presidential election about how aggressively the Clinton Foundation should be investigated. The article recounted a particularly tense phone call between McCabe and a senior Justice Department official about the investigation.
