The inspector general's report said McCabe told internal investigators that he had not authorized anyone at the FBI to speak with the reporter, and he did not know who did. The report said McCabe ultimately corrected that account, and confirmed that he had encouraged the conversation with the reporter to counter a narrative that he thought was false – namely, that he had been trying to stymie investigations into Clinton and the foundation.

McCabe has been a target of Trump's attacks since news emerged in the fall of 2016 that McCabe's wife had accepted campaign contributions from a political action committee associated with former Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, a Clinton ally, during an unsuccessful run for the state Senate.

Title: Trump Wins Nevada Republican Caucuses, Expands Lead in Republican Field

Article:

Donald Trump won the Nevada Republican presidential caucuses on Tuesday, securing a decisive victory with 45.9% of the vote. This marks his third consecutive win, further solidifying his position as the likely Republican presidential nominee. Trump's victory was met with a subdued reaction from his opponents, Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, who will likely continue their campaigns.

The results show Trump's broad appeal, as he won among every ideological group, education level, racial group, and gender. According to surveys, Trump carried evangelical Christians, Hispanics, and both Republicans and independents. The theme that emerged among his supporters was concern and dissatisfaction with the current state of the nation, with 94% expressing a negative view of the government and 60% describing themselves as "angry."

Trump's victory rally in Las Vegas saw him declare, "We won the evangelicals, we won with young, we won with old, we won with highly educated, we won with poorly educated. I love the poorly educated. We're the smartest people; we're the most loyal people."

The Nevada caucuses mark a significant milestone in Trump's campaign, as he has now won decisive victories in New Hampshire, South Carolina, and Nevada. The next test will come on Super Tuesday, with contests in a dozen states, including the South, where Trump's support is expected to be strong. The outcome of these contests will determine whether Trump's opponents can mount a comeback or if he will continue to expand his lead.

The article concludes by noting that Trump has already won a record number of delegates and has expanded the Republican electorate, drawing record turnouts. The next few weeks will be crucial in determining the outcome of the Republican primary, with nearly a third of delegates chosen on Super Tuesday and nearly two-thirds chosen in the following weeks.

Title: Obama's Campaign Attacks Romney as a Return to Bush Era Policies

Article:

In the upcoming presidential debate, President Barack Obama is expected to repeat his criticism that electing Mitt Romney would mean a return to the same policies that led to the financial crisis. This attack is a way of saying that Romney would represent a third term for George W. Bush, with a hands-off approach to taxes, spending, and regulation. Obama's campaign has been using this line all year, emphasizing that Romney's policies would lead to a repeat of the economic crisis.

According to a recent CNN poll, 62% of self-described moderates blame the Republicans and Bush for the country's economic troubles, while only 30% fault the Democrats and Obama. This suggests that Obama's strategy of "triangulation" - separating himself from his own party and the opposition - may not be an option, but a necessity.

Romney's campaign has not yet responded to Obama's attacks, and some analysts believe that making both parties responsible for the country's fiscal problems would help him detach himself from Bush and gain credibility with voters. Many conservatives are already critical of the spending that took place under the last administration, and the GOP base is eager to oust Obama. According to Michael Tanner of the Cato Institute, making twin villains of Bush and Obama would be a smart move, as it would blunt Obama's attacks on Romney and rally tea party supporters who are skeptical of Bush and the Republican establishment. Grover Norquist, an anti-tax crusader, agrees that the speech writes itself.

Title: Wisconsin's $100 Million Tax Incentive Package for Kimberly-Clark Raises Concerns about Crony Capitalism

Article:

Wisconsin's recent proposal to offer Kimberly-Clark a $100 million tax incentive package to keep its operations in the state has sparked concerns about crony capitalism and the role of government in the economy. The package, which would provide a 17% tax credit for existing jobs paying between $30,000 and $100,000 annually and a 15% capital-investment credit, is seen as a departure from the state's usual approach to economic development.

The proposal comes at a time when Kimberly-Clark is restructuring its global workforce, resulting in the loss of up to 5,500 jobs nationally and the closing of ten manufacturing facilities, including two in Wisconsin. The state's economic development officials argue that the incentive package will help save 600 jobs at the Neenah and Fox Crossing facilities, which support 600 jobs.

However, critics argue that the package is an example of central planning and market distortion, which can lead to inefficient use of resources and a narrative of economic development built on myths and hubris. They point out that Wisconsin's economy is already booming, with low unemployment, rising wages, and business optimism, making it unnecessary to offer such incentives.

The proposal also raises questions about the role of government in the economy. Republicans, who often argue that government shouldn't pick winners and losers, have been accused of embracing a role for government in targeting companies and industries with incentives and handouts. This approach can create a narrative that government is responsible for creating jobs, rather than allowing the market to determine the outcome.

Wisconsin's experience with FoxConn, which received a $3 billion incentive package to build a $10 billion facility, has also been criticized for its high cost per job and the potential for market distortion. The state's governor, Scott Walker, has made the deal a centerpiece of his campaign for a third term, but critics argue that it sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to a larger and more permanent government role in the economy.

The proposal has sparked a debate about the role of government in the economy and the effectiveness of tax incentives in creating jobs. While some argue that the package will help save jobs and stimulate economic growth, others believe it is an example of crony capitalism and a departure from the state's usual approach to economic development.

Title: Trump Survives Second Presidential Debate, Regains Momentum Against Clinton

The second presidential debate at Washington University in St. Louis was a crucial moment for Donald Trump, who managed to recover from the previous week's damaging tape and put Hillary Clinton on the defensive. Despite the intense scrutiny surrounding the recording of Trump boasting about his sexual assaults on women, he was able to pivot and focus on Clinton's judgment and record.

Trump effectively used the debate to remind Americans of what they dislike about Clinton, citing her destruction of emails, ignoring pleas for help from Chris Stevens, and enthusiasm for admitting Syrian refugees. He also brought up her wavering support of the TPP, leaked tapes revealing her inclination to say one thing in private and another in public, and Obamacare's failings.

Clinton, on the other hand, accused Trump of being unfit for the presidency and repeatedly called him a liar. She also blamed Trump for the Benghazi attack and criticized his handling of the economy. Trump countered by saying Clinton would go to jail if elected and accused her of being all talk and no action.

The debate saw both candidates discussing various topics, including law and order, the inner city blight, tax proposals, and foreign policy. Trump faltered when asked about the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo, while Clinton emphasized her experience in fighting terror and her commitment to children and families.

When asked about their potential Supreme Court picks, Clinton said she would look for a justice who would support Roe vs. Wade and marriage equality, while Trump said he would appoint someone like Scalia who would defend the Constitution. Trump also got a jab in by saying his pick for the Court would stand up for the second amendment, unlike Clinton's likely choice.

Overall, the debate was not a confrontation that made either candidate look noble or appealing. However, Trump was able to regain some momentum and prove he is still in the race to win.

Title: The Des Moines Register Endorses Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio in Iowa Caucuses

The Des Moines Register, Iowa's most prominent daily newspaper, has endorsed Hillary Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination and Marco Rubio for the Republican nomination, just over a week before the Iowa caucuses on February 1. The editorial board praised Clinton's "depth of knowledge and experience" and ability to work across party lines as a New York senator, while Rubio was commended for his potential to "chart a new direction" for the GOP.

The Register's endorsement of Clinton acknowledged her imperfections, citing her email controversy and changing stances on gay marriage and immigration. However, the board argued she is more qualified than her Democratic opponents, Bernie Sanders and Martin O'Malley. Rubio's campaign quickly celebrated the endorsement, while strategists and observers questioned whether the paper's approval can influence voters and whether it could even be counterproductive.

The Register has been endorsing candidates since 1988, but this cycle's blessings came amid an "upside-down political atmosphere" where once-vaunted traditions have become unwelcome reminders of insiderdom. Republican strategists and political observers predicted that a Register endorsement is no longer a coveted prize, as Trump and Cruz did not court the paper's endorsement and may even use it as a talking point to diminish its impact.

The endorsement may have more influence outside of Iowa, particularly for Rubio, who is seeking to run as an establishment-oriented alternative to Trump or Cruz. The endorsement enables him to say he is the establishment pick, which could be valuable in more moderate enclaves. The Democratic endorsement may be more influential since the paper's left-leaning editorial board tends to connect better with Democrats.

The Register's endorsement is its 10th and 11th since it first backed Paul Simon in 1988. The endorsements come in a year where mainstream media institutions are under attack, and candidates can afford to do battle with prominent outlets. Endorsements are seen as less impactful in today's 24/7 news cycle, and candidates can spin them as negative, especially on the Republican side, where the dislike of all things establishment is prevalent.

Title: Puerto Rico's Governor Calls for Cancellation of Contract with Whitefish Energy to Rebuild Power Grid

Puerto Rico's governor, Ricardo Rossello, has requested the cancellation of a contract with Whitefish Energy, a Montana-based company, to help rebuild the island's power grid. The head of the US-controlled island's power authority, Ricardo Ramos, has accepted the recommendation and intends to cancel the deal. The contract was awarded to Whitefish Energy without a public bid process, sparking concerns about the legitimacy of the agreement.

More than 70% of Puerto Rico's population was without power as of Sunday morning, over five weeks after Hurricane Maria devastated the power grid. The governor emphasized the need to prioritize the restoration of power as quickly as possible, stating, "There can be no distraction to alter the commitment to restore the power system as quickly as possible."

The Puerto Rican Electric Power Authority (PREPA) Executive Director, Ricardo Ramos, also expressed his intention to cancel the contract. The governor has instructed PREPA to coordinate with the states of Florida and New York to reinforce brigades rebuilding the grid on the island.

Concerns have been raised about the lack of a public bid process and the decision to award the contract to Whitefish Energy, which has little experience with projects of this scale. The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) distanced themselves from the deal late last week, stating that any language in the contract claiming FEMA approval was inaccurate.

FEMA also expressed significant concerns about how PREPA procured the contract and has not confirmed whether the contract prices were reasonable. The contract states that PREPA represents and warrants that FEMA reviewed and approved the deal, but FEMA denies this, stating that any such language is inaccurate.

It is unclear what will happen to any outstanding costs, and a former director of the US National Center for Disaster Fraud noted that any dispute may result in appeals, administrative hearings, and lawsuits. The US House of Representatives Natural Resources Committee is also scrutinizing the contract, and top Democrats have requested an investigation by the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general.

Title: Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer to Deliver Democratic Response to Trump's State of the Union Address

Governor Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan will deliver the Democratic response to President Donald Trump's State of the Union address on February 4. The 48-year-old former prosecutor and first female leader of the Democratic caucus in the Michigan state Senate won the governorship in the 2018 midterm elections, defeating Republican nominee Bill Schuette.

Whitmer's campaign focused on expanding healthcare and addressing "dinner-table issues," which she believes are at the center of what makes the party stronger. She has also avoided mentioning President Trump, a strategy that has helped her avoid divisive and partisan fights.

In an interview with the Associated Press, Whitmer stated that voters in her state are more concerned with "fundamentals" such as fixing deteriorating roads and offering job training for better-paying positions, rather than Trump's tweets. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer praised Whitmer's vision for the future, saying it is exactly what the country needs.

Whitmer will deliver her response to Trump's State of the Union address immediately after his speech, which is scheduled for 9 p.m. ET on February 4.

Title: The Dangers of Government Mass Surveillance: A Historical Perspective

The concept of government mass surveillance has been a contentious issue for centuries, with the United States being born out of a defiant reaction to government surveillance. In the decade preceding the signing of the Declaration of Independence, the British government imposed the Stamp Act and the Writs of Assistance Act, which allowed for the search and seizure of colonial homes without specific cause or description.

The Stamp Act required colonists to purchase stamps from a British government vendor and affix them to all documents, including financial, legal, and personal papers. The Writs of Assistance Act granted general warrants to search and seize documents, allowing British officials to invade private homes without specific cause or description. This led to widespread opposition and violence against stamp vendors, with many colonists fearing the true purpose of the tax was to remind them of the king's authority.

The repeal of the Stamp Act in 1766 did not erase the harm caused by the British government's actions. The American Revolution was fought in part to secure the right to privacy and protection from government intrusion. The Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution, ratified in 1791, prohibits general warrants and requires that only judges can issue search warrants based on probable cause of crime.

In 2001, the Patriot Act was passed, allowing federal agents to bypass the Fourth Amendment and issue their own search warrants. Since then, over 300,000 National Security Letters have been issued, allowing federal agents to seize financial records and other personal information without probable cause. Section 215 of the Patriot Act, set to expire on March 15, permits designated federal judges to issue general warrants based on the old writs of assistance standard of governmental need.

Judge Andrew P. Napolitano, a former Superior Court judge and Fox News senior judicial analyst, argues that both Section 215 and Section 505 of the Patriot Act are instruments of totalitarian government and defy the Constitution. He believes that mass surveillance produces a state that knows more about us than we do about it, and that it will slowly consume our freedoms in the name of governmental needs.

As the Patriot Act's provisions are set to expire, it is essential to re-examine the dangers of government mass surveillance and the importance of protecting individual privacy.

Title: FBI Agents Considered Arresting Mysterious Professor in Russia Probe, but He Left the Country Before Evidence Was Gathered

The FBI had identified a Maltese professor, Joseph Mifsud, as a key figure in the Russia probe, but he left the United States before agents could gather sufficient evidence to detain him, according to a court filing by special counsel Robert Mueller. The FBI located Mifsud in Washington, D.C., but did not have enough information to arrest him due to misleading statements provided by former Trump volunteer George Papadopoulos.

Papadopoulos had previously pleaded guilty to charges of lying about his interactions with Mifsud during an FBI interview in January 2017. Mifsud had met with Papadopoulos in London in the spring of 2016, while Papadopoulos was working at a think tank and claimed to be an official Trump adviser. Mifsud is a mysterious figure who teaches in his native Malta and circulates among think tanks in Europe, including Russia.

The court filing recommends a prison sentence of zero to six months for Papadopoulos, who is set to be sentenced on September 7. The special counsel noted that Papadopoulos should spend some time in prison, citing a similar case that resulted in a 30-day sentence.

The investigation revealed that Papadopoulos had lied about his interactions with Mifsud, including the timing and nature of their meetings. The lies were deemed material to the investigation and hindered the FBI's ability to effectively question Mifsud when they located him in Washington, D.C. in January 2017. Mifsud had left the United States on February 11, 2017, and has not returned since.

Papadopoulos had claimed that Mifsud had told him that the Kremlin possessed thousands of Hillary Clinton's emails, but the true nature of Mifsud's statement remains unclear. Papadopoulos had also attempted to set up a meeting between candidate Trump and the Kremlin, but the meeting never occurred. He has not been charged with any collusion or attempting to obtain Clinton's emails.

Title: Twitter Introduces Notice for Politician Tweets That Violate Rules

Twitter has announced a new policy to place a notice on tweets from politicians and government leaders that violate its rules but are deemed to be in the public interest. The notice will be displayed to users before they can view the tweet, stating that the tweet breaks Twitter's rules but has been left up due to its public interest value.

The change applies to verified government officials and political candidates with over 100,000 followers, as well as individuals being considered for government positions. The notice will be displayed before users can view the tweet, stating that the Twitter Rules about abusive behavior apply, but Twitter has determined it may be in the public interest for the tweet to remain available.

This change is part of Twitter's efforts to combat harassment and abuse on its platform. The company has previously argued against removing problematic tweets from world leaders, including President Donald Trump, citing their public interest value. The new policy aims to strike a balance between preserving the public's right to access information and protecting users from harmful content.

The notice will not be applied to tweets sent before Thursday, and Twitter's safety team will decide when to use the notice, considering factors such as the potential harm from the rule violation, whether preserving the tweet will allow people to hold politicians accountable, and other factors.

The White House did not respond to a request for comment on the new policy.

Title: President Trump Stands Firm on Border Wall Funding Amidst Government Shutdown Threat

Article:

President Trump has reiterated his commitment to securing funding for the border wall, despite the looming threat of a partial government shutdown. The President has been vocal about his stance, stating that he will not sign another bill like the previous Omnibus spending bill, which did not provide sufficient funding for the border wall. In a tweet, he emphasized the importance of border security, saying, "Border Security is National Security, and National Security is the long-term viability of our Country. A Government Shutdown is a very small price to pay for a safe and Prosperous America!"

Prior to the last budget impasse, President Trump offered a deal to congressional Democrats, proposing to accept legal status for nearly a million DACA recipients in exchange for funding the border wall. However, the Democrats rejected the offer, despite the relatively small amount of $5 billion requested for the wall, which would have accounted for less than 0.004% of the total amount allocated.

As the deadline for a deal to fund seven government agencies approaches, President Trump has the opportunity to follow through on his pledge and secure the funding he has sought since the beginning of his presidency. Senate Democrats are insisting on allocating only $1.6 billion for border security, and are threatening to punish the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) if the President does not comply.

In an effort to sway public opinion, Democrats are portraying a potential partial government shutdown as a national catastrophe. However, this is simply a tactic to manipulate the public and the press. In reality, about two-thirds of the federal government is already funded through a previous budget deal, and a partial shutdown would not affect most federal employees, including those serving in the armed forces. Even if DHS were temporarily left without funding, it would not significantly impact border security, as Border Patrol and ICE agents would still be required to report for work.

President Trump is not swayed by the Democrats' tactics and remains committed to securing the border wall, recognizing its importance for national security. As the deadline approaches, it remains to be seen whether the President will hold firm and secure the funding he has sought, or whether the Democrats will continue to resist and try to portray a partial government shutdown as a national crisis.

Title: Cuomo's "America Was Never That Great" Statement Sparks Controversy, Republicans Claim Democrats Are "Collectively Bashing America"

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo's recent statement that "America was never that great" has sparked a national controversy, with both sides of the political spectrum criticizing his remarks. Cuomo made the comment during a bill signing ceremony, saying that America has not reached its full potential and that discrimination and stereotyping against women, 51% of the population, must be addressed.

The statement was met with criticism from both left and right, with gubernatorial challenger Cynthia Nixon calling it "another example of Andrew Cuomo trying to figure out what a progressive sounds like and missing by a mile." President Trump also weighed in, calling the statement a "career-threatening" remark and predicting that Cuomo's political career is over.

Cuomo has since walked back the statement, saying that he believes America is great, but that it has yet to reach its full potential. He also called the remark "inartful."

The controversy is the latest example of Democrats calling out what they see as injustices and inequalities in America. Republicans, however, are quick to point out that such statements may not play well with the general public. The Republican National Committee (RNC) released an email blast stating that "the only thing that seems to unify prominent Democrats these days is their collective bashing of America."

Other possible 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have also made statements that have been criticized by Republicans. Senator Cory Booker (D-N.J.) said that things are "savagely wrong" in America and that there is a "normalcy of injustice." Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) said that there is something "fundamentally immoral" about America due to its economic inequality. Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) described America's criminal justice system as "racist" "front to back."

The RNC points to these statements as evidence that Democrats are out of touch with the American public. A 2016 Washington Post poll found that only 7% of those polled said that America has never been great.

Title: Grassroots Effort Aims to Convince Elizabeth Warren to Run for President

A small office park in Des Moines, Iowa, serves as the hub for a grassroots campaign to persuade Senator Elizabeth Warren to run for the Democratic presidential nomination. The campaign, known as Run Warren Run, has gained momentum, with about 20 volunteers gathering to strategize and spread the word about the Massachusetts senator's potential candidacy.

The driving force behind the effort is the belief that Warren understands and represents the middle class, with supporters emphasizing her commitment to addressing income inequality and regulating Wall Street. Volunteers are using grassroots political techniques, phone banks, and attending small Democratic meetings across the state to demonstrate support for Warren.

The campaign is being funded by MoveOn.org and Democracy for America, with a combined budget of $1.25 million. Run Warren Run has eight staff members in Iowa and additional staff in New Hampshire, promoting Warren's candidacy.

Despite Warren's repeated denials of a presidential run, supporters remain optimistic, citing the growth of the campaign and the potential for long-term benefits, even if Warren decides not to run. The campaign's goal is to show Warren that she has support across the state and a path to victory.

Volunteers, including Katie Freerksen, a veterinarian technician, and Toria Pinter, a law student on medical leave, emphasize the importance of Warren's stance on issues like student loan interest rates and her commitment to the middle class. They stress that the campaign is not anti-Clinton, but rather a pro-Warren movement.

Iowa Field Director Blair Lawton believes that even if Warren decides not to run, the campaign will still have a positive impact by investing in the progressive community and building a stronger movement across the state.

Title: US-Iran Nuclear Deal: No Written Agreement Expected by March Deadline

The United States and Iran are nearing a deadline to agree on a framework for limiting Iran's nuclear capabilities, but it appears that a written agreement may not be forthcoming. According to Western diplomats involved in the talks, Iran has been resistant to signing a formal agreement, instead preferring a general statement of understanding followed by a final accord in June.

The Obama administration has downplayed the significance of the March deadline, with White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest stating that the goal is to achieve a "political agreement" by the end of the month. This agreement would involve specific commitments from Iran about its nuclear program and facilities, as well as intrusive inspections. However, the technical implementation of these agreements would require further discussions and negotiations, which are expected to continue until June.

The Khamenei regime does not acknowledge the March deadline, and it is unclear what the implications of this lack of recognition will be. The United States and its allies, including Britain, France, Germany, Russia, and China, are seeking to establish specific limits on Iran's nuclear program by the end of March. However, it appears that these limits may not be formally agreed upon until June.

The lack of a written agreement by the March deadline may be seen as a minor detail by some, but it highlights the complexities and challenges of the negotiations between the Obama administration and the Ayatollah Khamenei regime. The outcome of these talks will have significant implications for global security and the future of Iran's nuclear program.

Title: Congressional Republicans' Agenda Stalls Amid Election Year

The Republican Party's legislative agenda has come to a standstill, with many considering it unlikely that significant reforms will be passed before the midterm elections. This decision has led to concerns that the party is solely focusing on opposing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and has no other major legislative initiatives to offer.

Conservative reporters and lawmakers have confirmed that comprehensive immigration reform, tax reform, and tweaks to the federal health-care law are unlikely to be passed this Congress. Representative Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) stated, "We don't have 218 votes in the House for the big issues, so what else are we going to do?" Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, added, "It is an acknowledgment of where they stand, where nothing can happen in divided government so we may essentially have the status quo."

While it is common for legislative activity to slow down ahead of an election, February is considered early for one party to abandon policymaking and focus solely on politics. The Senate has already passed a comprehensive immigration reform bill and the Employment Non-Discrimination Act, and if the House fails to produce similar legislation, it may appear as though they are not contributing to the legislative process.

The article suggests that the Republican Party's strategy is to focus on opposing the ACA, which may not be an effective approach. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor has committed to passing an ACA alternative this year, but this intention may not materialize. If so, the party may be left with a "full repeal" of the ACA as their official health care reform platform, which is considered a political loser.

The electoral map is also playing a role in the Republican Party's strategy. Senate Democrats are defending seats won in 2008, and the electoral map is likely creating inertia, making the GOP's strategy unfalsifiable. Even a bad strategy may yield significant gains in the Senate and retention of the House.

It is unusual for a party to put all their chips in one basket so early in the cycle, and this approach may not be effective in the long run. The article concludes that the Republican Party's strategy is focused on opposing the ACA, but it remains to be seen whether this approach will yield the desired results.

Title: Supreme Court Weighs In on Trump Administration's Contraceptive Accommodation

The Supreme Court is currently deliberating on the Trump administration's accommodation regarding the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) contraceptive mandate. The accommodation, which was put in place by the Trump administration, allows employers with religious or moral objections to opt out of providing coverage for birth control, whereas the Obama administration's workaround required employers to notify the government, which would then provide the coverage directly to employees.

The Obama administration's approach aimed to strike a balance between religious liberty and governmental interests, requiring objecting organizations to notify the government, which would then work with their health insurers to offer costless contraception directly to employees. Critics argue that this approach is insufficient, demanding full exemptions for employers who object to the mandate.

The Supreme Court's conservative majority has expressed sympathy for religious objectors seeking exemptions from generally applicable laws. However, some justices have also expressed concerns about the Trump administration's broad exemption, which may not be required by law. Justices Clarence Thomas, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh have raised questions about the administration's authority to grant such an exemption.

Gorsuch, in a 2019 opinion, proposed revising the nondelegation doctrine, a constitutional doctrine used in the 1930s to restrict Congress's power to delegate authority. While his opinion is vague, it suggests that Congress must draft laws precisely if it wants to delegate power to a federal agency. This could potentially lead to a cross-partisan coalition to strike down the broad exemption.

The court's decision will ultimately determine whether the Trump administration's accommodation strikes the right balance between religious liberty and governmental interests.

Title: Trump's Claims on NATO Defense Spending Fact-Checked

Article: President Donald Trump has repeatedly made claims about the United States and its NATO allies' defense spending, stating that the U.S. has been stiffed for unpaid bills and that some countries owe the U.S. "massive amounts of money" from years past. However, fact-checking reveals that NATO is not a club with annual membership fees, and there is no ledger to track what countries pay and owe.

According to former Obama administration National Security Council official Aaron O'Connell, NATO is not set up like a club with dues. Instead, member countries make a commitment to spend at least 2% of their GDP on defense by 2024. Currently, only nine of the 29 NATO members are expected to reach this mark this year. Germany, the biggest economic power in NATO after the U.S., devotes about 1.25% of its GDP to defense, and does not plan to reach the 2% target by 2024.

Trump has also claimed that the U.S. spends 4.2% of its GDP on defense, but this is disputed by the Pentagon, which puts the figure at 3.3%. American University NATO scholar Garret Martin notes that the U.S. has global military commitments, whereas European NATO members have more limited defense needs.

Regarding Trump's claim that the U.S. pays 70-90% of the cost of protecting Europe, former NSC staffer O'Connell disputes this, stating that the U.S. pays 22% of the common NATO budget, not 90%. NATO reported that European members have increased their spending by $35 billion, a trend that predates Trump's presidency.

NATO General Secretary Jens Stoltenberg pointed out that despite Trump's complaints about the U.S. spending too much, the U.S. has actually increased its funding for military presence in Europe by 40% since Trump became president. The Senate and House have also overwhelmingly approved resolutions backing NATO.

In conclusion, fact-checking reveals that Trump's claims about NATO defense spending are largely inaccurate, and that the U.S. and its allies have made commitments to increase defense spending, with some countries making progress towards the 2% target.

Title: Trump and Pence to Celebrate Carrier Deal as a Win for U.S. Jobs

The Trump administration is set to take a victory lap in Indianapolis on Thursday to tout what they are presenting as a successful negotiation with Carrier to keep nearly 1,000 U.S. jobs from moving to Mexico. The deal, which was announced on Wednesday, is seen as a demonstration of President-elect Donald Trump's commitment to protecting American jobs and workers.

According to Kellyanne Conway, Trump's former campaign manager and top adviser, the Carrier deal is a "great first example to the country, if not the world, that the USA is open for business." Conway characterized the negotiation as a winning deal led by Trump that could be duplicated once he takes office.

Few details were revealed about what was offered to Carrier, which is owned by United Technologies, a much larger company based in Connecticut with contracts with the U.S. government. Media reports suggested that Carrier would keep about 850 jobs in the state and was given tax incentives by Indiana's government to stay.

The White House downplayed the news, saying President Obama's policies had created more than 800,000 manufacturing jobs. However, Trump's team argued that the Carrier deal shows Trump can build a positive climate for business – behind an overhaul of the tax code and reduction of regulations – that will grow the economy at a faster pace than what has been seen during the Obama years.

Fiscally conservative groups are staying quiet about the deal for the time being, but if it turns out that Trump and Pence offered any special concessions to Carrier, they are likely to cry foul. Brent Gardner, chief government affairs officer at Americans for Prosperity, said the particulars of the agreement have not been released, but the group's position on corporate welfare has not changed.

Chart Westcott, a Texas-based investor who belongs to the Koch donor network, said he would have no trouble if Trump used his leverage to keep American jobs from being shipped overseas. However, he noted that if taxpayer dollars were spent to entice Carrier to stay, it would be a "huge moral hazard" and not necessarily a good thing for the U.S. taxpayer.

The deal has raised concerns that Trump's willingness to negotiate one-on-one with companies could lead to CEOs threatening to leave the country in exchange for a sweeter deal. However, House Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said he had no issues with Trump personally getting involved to prevent the outsourcing of jobs.

Title: Marco Rubio's Path to the White House: A Horse-Race Analogy

Marco Rubio, a young and eloquent senator from Florida, is gaining momentum in the Republican presidential primary. His campaign is reminiscent of Barack Obama's 2008 bid, with Rubio's personal story and charisma drawing voters to his cause. Despite a stumble in the recent New Hampshire debate, Rubio remains a strong contender, with a clear path to the White House.

Rubio's campaign strategy involves building momentum by finishing strong in the early primary states. He can do this by emphasizing his personal story, his commitment to bipartisanship, and his ability to communicate complex issues in a clear and concise manner. His experience as a senator and his involvement in the "Gang of Eight" demonstrate his willingness to work across party lines to find solutions.

Rubio's campaign also needs to focus on data analysis and infrastructure, as Cruz's team has invested heavily in these areas. This will help Rubio stay competitive and make informed decisions throughout the campaign.

In the coming weeks, Rubio will face stiff competition from Trump and Cruz, but he has the potential to surge ahead. His strong performance in the Iowa caucuses and his ability to connect with voters make him a formidable opponent. With the right strategy and momentum, Rubio can become the Republican nominee and a strong contender for the presidency.

Sources: The article does not provide specific sources for the information presented.

**Extension of Nuclear Talks with Iran: A New Deadline Set**

The United States and its allies have agreed to extend the deadline for a nuclear deal with Iran by seven months, hoping that this extra time will help achieve what a decade of negotiations have failed to do – limit Tehran's ability to make a nuclear weapon. The new deadline is set for March 1, with a final agreement expected to follow four months later.

The decision was made after a week of tough negotiations in Vienna, where U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and other Western foreign ministers met with Iranian officials. Kerry described the extension as the "best way forward," but critics in Congress are concerned that Iran is simply buying time.

The negotiations have been ongoing since February, with the six world powers involved seeking to agree on what Iran must do and by when. The main sticking points remain the number and type of centrifuges Iran is allowed to have, as well as the length of time constraints on its nuclear program.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has expressed optimism about the progress made, saying that "many gaps have been eliminated," but acknowledged that the sides are still "some distance" from a deal. The extension has given Iran an additional 219 days to continue its nuclear program, which remains frozen but intact.

The U.S. administration has expressed concerns that additional sanctions could push Iran away from the negotiating table, while some lawmakers are threatening to impose new sanctions if progress is not made. The extension has been met with frustration from some Iranians, who see it as a sign that the West is not serious about engaging with their country.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Rival Forms Alliance to Form New Government

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's chief rival, Benny Gantz, has announced an agreement with the leader of the small Yisrael Beiteinu party, Avigdor Lieberman, to work together to form a new government. This development comes after last week's national elections, in which Netanyahu's Likud party emerged as the largest party, but fell short of the required majority to form a new government.

Gantz, leader of the Blue and White Party, stated that he and Lieberman discussed "questions of fundamental principle" and agreed to work together to assemble a government that will end the political deadlock and avoid a fourth round of elections. However, it remains unclear whether they can reach a final agreement, much less a deal with Arab politicians.

Netanyahu's opponents, led by Gantz, control a majority of seats in parliament, but there are deep divisions between the parties involved. Lieberman's secular, ultra-nationalist party and the Arab-led Joint List are among the parties opposed to Netanyahu.

Netanyahu is facing a trial on March 17, charged with fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes in connection to a series of scandals. His lawyers have requested a delay in the start of the trial, citing the need for more time to review evidence, while prosecutors have opposed any delays.

Israel's president, Reuven Rivlin, must decide by next week who to choose as the prime minister-designate, typically choosing the candidate with the best chance of forming a governing coalition. Netanyahu has defiantly insisted he won the election and accused his opponents of trying to "steal the elections" by aligning with Arab-led parties he claims are hostile to the state.

Title: Obama Defends Drone Strikes, Acknowledges Past Civilian Casualties

Article:

President Barack Obama defended his administration's use of drone strikes and airstrikes to target terrorist leaders and training camps in Somalia, Libya, and Yemen, stating that procedures for approving such strikes have improved. Obama acknowledged that in the past, civilians were inadvertently killed in these strikes, but emphasized that operating procedures are now as rigorous as ever and are constantly being evaluated.

The remarks came after the US military announced an airstrike targeting a senior terrorist leader in Somalia, Hassan Ali Dhoore, an operational commander of al-Shabab, an al-Qaeda-linked terror group. The Pentagon stated that Dhoore was involved in planning attacks, including those that resulted in the deaths of three Americans, and was responsible for several high-profile attacks in Mogadishu.

The Pentagon is still assessing the results of the operation to determine if Dhoore was killed in the strike, but officials believe that his death would be a significant blow to the terror group's operations and ability to conduct attacks. Dhoore was also linked to the December 2014 attack on Mogadishu International Airport that killed several African Union personnel and a US citizen, as well as the March 2015 attack on the Maka al-Mukarram Hotel in Mogadishu that killed 15 people. The Pentagon stated that Dhoore was planning to attack US citizens in Mogadishu.

Last month, the Pentagon launched a strike that killed up to 150 militants at a terrorist training camp in Somalia.

Title: Journalist Brian Williams' Fabrication: A Tale of Embellishment and the Human Tendency to Juice Our Stories

Article:

NBC News anchor Brian Williams has been under fire for fabricating a story about his experiences during the 2003 invasion of Iraq. Williams claimed that his helicopter was hit and forced down by enemy fire, but later admitted that it was actually another helicopter that was hit. This incident has sparked a wider discussion about the tendency for individuals, including journalists, to embellish their stories.

Williams is not the only notable figure to have gotten caught in a web of deception. Politicians such as President Ronald Reagan, Joe Biden, and Hillary Clinton have all been accused of exaggerating or fabricating their military experiences. However, as a journalist, Williams is expected to maintain a higher standard of truth-telling.

The article highlights the human tendency to "juice" our stories, making them more exciting and dramatic. Journalists, in particular, are trained to be vigilant about the stories they tell, but even they can fall prey to the temptation to embellish. The article notes that journalists often add dramatic pauses, reactions, and details to their stories, making them more engaging for their audience.

The article also touches on the concept of "stolen valor," where individuals exaggerate or fabricate their military experiences to gain prestige or admiration. This phenomenon is not unique to politicians or journalists, as many people have been known to embellish their military records.

The article concludes by noting that even successful and high-status individuals like Brian Williams can fall victim to the allure of heroism and the desire to be seen as a hero. According to scholar W. Joseph Campbell, the allure of heroism can be irresistible, and it's a warping, cinematic effect.

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Endorses Ted Cruz, Praises Donald Trump

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has announced that he will be voting for Republican candidate Ted Cruz in the upcoming primary election. In a radio interview on WIBC, Pence praised Cruz as a "principled conservative" who has "stood up for taxpayers" in fighting spending in Washington. He also commended Cruz's "strong, unwavering stand" against abortion rights.

However, Pence also took the opportunity to praise Republican front-runner Donald Trump, stating that he "likes and respects" all three candidates, including Trump. Pence credited Trump with giving voice to people's frustrations and taking a stand for Hoosier jobs. He expressed gratitude towards Trump for his voice in the national debate and his support for Hoosier jobs.

Pence emphasized that his endorsement was not intended to sway the votes of Indiana Republicans, saying, "I respect the right of every Hoosier in making their determination. I encourage everyone to make up their own mind." He also stressed that he will work hard for whoever wins the Republican nomination in the fall.

The endorsement was closely watched, as Pence will be on the ballot this fall as a candidate for re-election. Cruz hopes that Pence's endorsement will give him a boost in the Hoosier State, where he is currently trailing Trump in recent surveys. Cruz has received endorsements from other prominent Republicans, including Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who gave him his only big-state primary victory so far in this campaign.

Pence's endorsement was less forceful than Cruz would have liked, but it remains to be seen how it will impact the outcome of the election. There are 57 delegates at stake in Indiana on Tuesday, and if Trump sweeps those delegates, his path to the nomination would become clearer.

Title: Republican Candidates Engage in Substantive Policy Discussion at Kemp Forum

The Republican presidential candidates gathered at the Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity in Columbia, South Carolina, for a rare display of policy-focused discussion, a departure from the heated rhetoric and personal attacks that have characterized the 2016 campaign. The event, moderated by Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator Tim Scott, brought together a range of candidates, including Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, Ben Carson, John Kasich, and Marco Rubio, to discuss issues such as the earned income tax credit, charter-school education, and poverty alleviation.

The candidates engaged in a collegial and substantive conversation, with many praising the event as a welcome change from the usual campaign trail. The discussion was marked by a focus on policy proposals and ideas, with candidates sharing their backgrounds and experiences in addressing these issues.

The event was a stark contrast to the recent rallies and speeches by Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, which have been marked by divisive rhetoric and personal attacks. Trump and Cruz did not attend the forum, but their absence was not the only notable aspect of the event. The candidates who did participate seemed to revel in the opportunity to engage in a more serious and policy-focused discussion.

The event was not without its interruptions, however. Young immigration protesters briefly disrupted the afternoon session with Senator Marco Rubio, targeting his stance on the country's immigration laws. However, even this interruption did not disrupt the overall tone of the event, with candidates and moderators alike maintaining a calm and respectful demeanor.

The Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity provided a rare glimpse into a presidential campaign that is often marked by bombast and personal attacks. The event showed that, even in the midst of a crowded and competitive primary, it is possible for candidates to engage in a substantive and respectful discussion of the issues.

Title: What Happens to Campaign Contributions When a Presidential Candidate Drops Out?

Article:

When a presidential candidate drops out of the race, it's natural to wonder what happens to the campaign contributions they received. According to the Federal Election Committee (FEC), any excess campaign funds are not allowed for personal use, but the rules surrounding campaign finance are complex and open to interpretation.

Excess funds can be used to cover expenses or spent on other candidates. If a campaign has outstanding debt or expenses, part of the donation might be used to pay these off, which could include paying salaries for campaign staff or moving expenses. If the campaign has no debt, the excess funds might be allocated towards the candidate's future campaigns, as seen in the case of John Hickenlooper, who will likely use his excess funds towards his Senate campaign.

There is a gray area, however, as candidates can use donations to purchase "gifts" as long as they are not given to the candidate's family. What constitutes a "gift" is unclear, leaving room for interpretation.

Candidates also have the option to use donations to support political action committees or other candidates in a race, although they may prefer to keep the funds. Alternatively, the donation could be donated to charities at the candidate's discretion.

The FEC's rules are vague, and candidates adhere to them in whatever way they see fit. This raises the question of how to ensure donations are spent wisely.

While it's impossible to know for certain how individual donations are spent, campaigns are required to file FEC reports throughout and after a presidential bid is over. These reports can be accessed on the FEC database, where you can search for a candidate's campaign name and scroll to the bottom of the page to find their expenses.

However, there are limitations to these filings, as they are generally updated quarterly, and even then, it can be difficult to interpret the information. Nevertheless, this should not deter individuals from donating to their chosen candidate. In fact, it may provide incentive to vote for a candidate who promotes campaign finance reform, ensuring that future contributions are spent wisely.

Title: Romney's Campaign Faces Growing Frustration Among Republicans

The presidential campaign of Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, is facing growing frustration among Republicans across the country. Despite being deadlocked with President Barack Obama in most national polls, Romney's campaign has yet to take a commanding lead in any of the major battleground states. This has led to concerns among Republicans that Romney is not campaigning enough in key states and that resources are not trickling into vital counties.

In Ohio, Florida, and Colorado, Republicans who support Romney's efforts are worried that he is not spending enough money and appearing frequently enough in rural areas where he needs a strong turnout to win. A bus trip by Romney next week may address some of these worries.

In Colorado, Dick Wadhams, a longtime Republican strategist and former state party chairman, said he hopes to see Romney campaign harder for swing voters in suburban Denver and is pleased the candidate is planning to visit the state on Sunday, the first time in seven weeks.

While Romney has sought to turn the issue against Obama, calling the president an advocate of redistributing wealth and emphasizing "My campaign is about the 100 percent of America," Obama has focused on Romney's "47 percent" comments. "My thinking is maybe you haven't gotten around a lot," Obama said about Romney in an appearance at a Univision forum in Coral Gables.

Romney's campaign has been focusing on Iowa as one of its more promising states, but a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist College poll showed Obama with an 8-point advantage there. In a stop near Des Moines, Ann Romney said it was time for Republicans to stop second-guessing her husband. "Stop it. This is hard. You want to try it? Get in the ring," she told Radio Iowa.

The president and his aides are aware that everything could change in an instant, particularly with three presidential debates looming, and said Democrats cannot be complacent. However, for the first time in many months, Obama's job approval rating has reached 50 percent in several recent polls. He has taken the edge away from Romney on questions of who voters believe will be a better steward of the economy, which coincides with the release of modestly positive economic signals.

Construction of new houses and home sales have reached their highest levels in more than two years, new reports show, and the Census Bureau reported that the number of young adults living at home with their parents – a vivid indicator of the personal effect of the recession on young people – is dropping.

Title: Trump Says "All Options Are on the Table" After North Korea Fires Missile Over Japan

The United States has responded to North Korea's latest missile test, which flew over Japan and landed in the Pacific Ocean, by stating that "all options are on the table" to address the situation. The White House released a written statement from President Trump, which read: "The world has received North Korea's latest message loud and clear: this regime has signaled its contempt for its neighbors, for all members of the United Nations, and for minimum standards of acceptable international behavior. Threatening and destabilizing actions only increase the North Korean regime's isolation in the region and among all nations of the world. All options are on the table."

The missile test, which was conducted on Tuesday, was a mid-range ballistic missile designed to carry a nuclear payload. It flew over the U.S. ally Japan and landed in the northern Pacific Ocean. The distance and type of missile test seemed designed to show that North Korea can back up a threat to target the U.S. territory of Guam, if it chooses to do so, while also establishing a potentially dangerous precedent that could see future missiles flying over Japan.

The White House said that President Trump spoke with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Monday about the "grave" North Korean threat. "President Trump and Prime Minister Abe committed to increasing pressure on North Korea, and doing their utmost to convince the international community to do the same," the statement said.

The Pentagon confirmed that the missile launch from North Korea did not pose a threat to North America, and the Japanese military did not attempt to intercept the missile. South Korea's air force responded to the launch by conducting a live-fire drill involving powerful bombs, with four F-15 fighters dropping eight MK-84 bombs that accurately hit targets at a military field near South Korea's eastern coast.

This latest missile test comes days after North Korea fired what was assessed as three short-range ballistic missiles into the sea and a month after its second test of an intercontinental ballistic missile, which analysts say could reach deep into the U.S. mainland when perfected.

Title: White House Refuses to Confirm Whether President Will Cooperate with National Security Leak Investigation

Article:

The White House has refused to confirm whether President Obama will cooperate with an investigation into recent high-level national security leaks from the White House. The investigation, led by two career attorneys from the Justice Department, is looking into the disclosure of highly classified information, including details about a top-secret "kill list" and a US cyberattack on Iranian infrastructure.

White House Senior Adviser David Plouffe stated that the administration will cooperate with the investigation, but declined to comment on whether the President will personally answer questions from investigators. Plouffe emphasized that it is the job of the investigative team to find out who leaked the information, which was published in a series of articles by The New York Times.

The leaks have sparked concerns about the potential risks to national security, with some lawmakers and pundits speculating that the White House may have authorized the leaks to boost the President's national security record ahead of the election. Senator Joe Lieberman, an independent from Connecticut, expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the leaks, stating that the disclosure of cyberwarfare against Iran could lead to a retaliatory strike.

Many lawmakers, including Lieberman, have called for the appointment of independent prosecutors to investigate the matter, rather than relying on investigators who report directly to Attorney General Eric Holder. The White House has rejected these calls, stating that the appointment of two US attorneys is a "smart move."

The investigation is ongoing, and it remains unclear whether the President will agree to one-on-one interviews with the investigators.

Title: Political Polarization in the United States: A Growing Concern

The article discusses the growing political polarization in the United States, citing the example of a personal experience between the author and a friend, Joe, who is a Republican. The author notes that Joe is one of only a few Republicans in their extended family, which is predominantly Democratic. The article highlights the increasing divide between the two parties, citing statistics from the Pew Research Center and National Journal.

According to the Pew Research Center's 2014 findings, the share of Americans who express consistently conservative or liberal opinions has doubled over the past two decades, with 92% of Republicans to the right of the median Democrat and 94% of Democrats to the left of the median Republican. The study also found that ideological overlap has diminished, with most people staying on the edges of the political process and the most ideological making their voices heard.

The article also mentions that highly negative views of the opposition party have doubled since 1994, with 43% of Republicans and 38% of Democrats holding such views. National Journal's Ron Brownstein notes that the divide is not going away and that it is a durable standoff between a diverse, younger, urbanized, and more secular Democratic coalition and a predominantly white, older, non-urban, and more religious Republican coalition.

The author concludes by expressing their concerns about the consequences of a Republican president and the potential for appointments to the Supreme Court, which could lead to decades of damage to the search for justice and fairness.

**Global Trade Tensions Escalate as Trump and Xi Prepare to Meet**

The trade war between the United States and China has intensified, sending shockwaves through global markets. The U.S. President Donald Trump announced that he will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month, amid a backdrop of escalating tariffs and trade tensions.

China has announced plans to impose higher tariffs on a range of U.S. goods, including frozen vegetables and liquefied natural gas, in response to Washington's decision to hike tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports. The U.S. Trade Representative's office has announced plans to hold a public hearing next month on the possibility of imposing duties of up to 25% on an additional $300 billion worth of imports from China.

The move has rattled investors, leading to a sharp selloff on equities markets and a decline in the value of the Chinese yuan. Oil futures have also slumped. The U.S. and China have been locked in a trade dispute for months, with both sides imposing tariffs on each other's goods.

Trump has said that he believes the meeting with Xi will be "fruitful" and that he has a "feeling" that the trip to Beijing two weeks ago was successful. The Chinese government has emphasized that the talks are not a "one-way street" and that both sides need to work together to reach a mutually beneficial agreement.

The trade war has had significant consequences for U.S. farmers, who are among those most affected by the tariffs. Soybean sales to China have plummeted, and U.S. soybean futures have hit their lowest level in a decade. The Trump administration has announced plans to provide about $15 billion to help farmers whose products might be targeted.

The Chinese government has said that its tariffs are a response to U.S. "unilateralism and protectionism" and that it hopes the U.S. will "get back to the right track" of bilateral trade and economic consultations. The U.S. has said that it is in no rush to finalize a deal with China and that it is willing to wait for a better agreement.

Economists and industry consultants have warned that the tariffs will ultimately be paid by U.S. businesses and households, rather than Chinese exporters. The effects of the tariffs have already been felt by U.S. producers competing with goods affected by the levies.

Title: Sen. Doug Jones Announces Support for Conviction on Both Impeachment Articles

Sen. Doug Jones (D-Ala.), considered one of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats, has announced that he will vote to convict President Trump on both articles of impeachment. Jones made the announcement on Wednesday, hours before the Senate's votes on the two House-passed articles of impeachment: abuse of power over the delayed Ukraine aid and obstructing Congress's investigations into those actions.

In a statement, Jones said he had reluctantly concluded that the evidence is sufficient to convict the President on both counts. He stated that he had struggled to understand the House's strategy on the second article, obstruction of Congress, but after careful consideration of the evidence, he believes the President deliberately and unconstitutionally obstructed Congress by refusing to cooperate with the investigation.

On the first article, abuse of power, Jones expressed deep concern over the President's actions, stating that they placed his personal interests above national interests and threatened the security of the United States, its allies in Europe, and Ukraine. He emphasized that the President's actions were more than simply inappropriate, but an abuse of power.

Jones's announcement comes after weeks of deliberation, during which he had expressed uncertainty about his vote. He had told reporters that he was "getting there" but still needed to review notes and discuss with colleagues. His decision to vote to convict on both articles may be seen as a significant blow to the President's chances of being acquitted.

Title: Fact-Checking Biden's Claim: Oversight Mechanisms Established in CARES Act

The CARES Act, passed in March 2020, aimed to provide economic relief during the COVID-19 pandemic. In a virtual rally, Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden claimed that President Trump was implementing the coronavirus relief effort with "no oversight, no IGs [inspectors general], no accountability." However, this statement is inaccurate.

The CARES Act established several oversight mechanisms to ensure transparency and accountability in the distribution of economic relief funds. The Pandemic Response Accountability Committee, created by Section 15010 of the act, is responsible for auditing the economic relief funds, preventing waste and abuse, and ensuring efficient distribution. The committee consists of inspectors general from various departments, including Defense, Education, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Justice, Labor, and Treasury, as well as the Small Business Administration and Tax Administration.

The CARES Act also established the Congressional Oversight Commission, tasked with overseeing the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve's lending practices to create transparency about how the money is being used and determine the economic impact of the loans. The commission is made up of five members, with each chamber's leaders appointing one member, and is required to submit reports to Congress every 30 days until its termination on September 20, 2025.

The special inspector general for pandemic recovery, created by Section 4018 of the act, is responsible for conducting audits and investigations of the making, purchase, management, and sale of loans, loan guarantees, and other investments made by the Secretary of the Treasury. Although the position is currently vacant, President Trump has nominated his senior associate counsel, Brian Miller, for the role.

In contrast to Biden's claim, the CARES Act does establish oversight mechanisms, including inspectors general and special inspectors general, to ensure accountability in the coronavirus economic relief effort. The act also provides for the creation of the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee and the Congressional Oversight Commission, which are responsible for auditing and investigating the use of economic relief funds and lending practices.

**White House Rejects Bipartisan Immigration Deal, Calls it a "Non-Starter"**

The White House has dismissed a bipartisan immigration deal brokered by Senators John McCain and Chris Coons, just hours before it is expected to be formally introduced in the Senate. The deal, which would grant eventual citizenship to young undocumented immigrants who have been in the country since 2013 and came to the US as children, does not address all of President Trump's stated immigration priorities, such as ending family-based immigration categories and ending the diversity visa program.

The bill would also not immediately authorize the $30 billion that Trump is seeking to build the border wall, instead greenlighting a study of border security needs. It would increase resources for the immigration courts, where cases can take years to finish.

A White House official rebuffed the effort, stating that it takes "a lot of effort" to write up a bill worse than the Graham-Durbin immigration bill, but somehow "this one is worse." Trump tweeted about the latest immigration efforts, stating that any deal on DACA that does not include "STRONG border security and the desperately needed WALL is a total waste of time."

Senator Coons defended the bill, calling it a "strong starting place" and a "fresh start" if other talks about immigration do not result in a compromise. The bill has been praised by the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and moderate Republicans.

The White House has been aware of the legislation introduced by Representatives Will Hurd and Pete Aguilar for weeks, with officials being informed while it was being drafted and with Chief of Staff John Kelly and Legislative Director Marc Short being briefed on the bill in meetings with members of Congress.

The Senate is expected to turn to a floor debate on immigration soon, and Senator Coons has been part of a group of bipartisan lawmakers that have been meeting for weeks to try to find a compromise that could pass the vote with more than the 60 votes needed to advance legislation.

**Election Forecast: Clinton and Trump Neck and Neck**

The 2016 presidential election is heating up, with Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump neck and neck in the polls. According to a recent forecast, Clinton has an 80% chance of winning the election, while Trump has a 20% chance.

The forecast is based on simulations of the election, which take into account various factors such as voter turnout, voter demographics, and historical trends. The simulations produce a distribution of possible outcomes, with the tallest bar representing the most likely outcome.

The forecast shows that Clinton is leading in several key states, including Florida, Pennsylvania, and Michigan, while Trump is leading in states such as Arizona, Georgia, and Texas. The race is considered too close to call in several other states, including North Carolina, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

The forecast also provides insight into the importance of each state in determining the outcome of the election. Florida, for example, is considered a "tipping-point" state, with a 17.6% chance of providing the decisive vote in the Electoral College. Pennsylvania and Michigan are also considered crucial, with a 12.3% and 11.7% chance of providing the decisive vote, respectively.

The forecast also provides a breakdown of the popular vote, with Clinton and Trump neck and neck, with a 50-50 split. The forecast also shows that there is a 10.5% chance that Clinton will win the popular vote but lose the Electoral College, while there is an 8.3% chance of an Electoral College deadlock.

Overall, the forecast suggests that the election is too close to call, with both candidates having a strong chance of winning.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Cases on Same-Sex Marriage, Raising Questions on Legal Recognition

The Supreme Court's decision to review two cases related to same-sex marriage has sparked a new wave of debate and anticipation in the United States. The court will examine the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and a California voter-passed measure, Proposition 8, which defines marriage as between one man and one woman. The cases have been brought by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the American Foundation for Equal Rights (AFER) on behalf of same-sex couples.

The Supreme Court's decision to take the cases has been met with cautious optimism by gay rights activists, who believe it could be a major step towards achieving marriage equality. "This is it – the Supreme Court marriage moment that the ACLU has been working towards for years," said James Esseks, litigation director of the ACLU's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender & AIDS Project. "These cases are poised not just to take down DOMA and Prop 8, but to be the next building blocks for LGBT equality more broadly."

On the other hand, traditional-values groups are heartened that the marriage issue will finally be heard, noting that gay marriages are still not recognized in more than 80 percent of the states. "Taking the case sends a strong signal that the justices are concerned with the rogue rulings that have come out of San Francisco, at both the trial court and appellate levels," said law scholar John Eastman, chairman of the National Organization for Marriage, which opposes gay marriage.

The Supreme Court's review of the cases is expected to be held in late winter or early spring, with decisions issued by summer. The high court proceedings are likely to take on new urgency given the recent activity in states such as Washington, where voters recently rejected an initiative to overturn the state's gay marriage law. Same-sex couples will also be able to marry in Maine on December 29 and in Maryland on January 1.

The federal case was brought by the ACLU and other lawyers on behalf of Edith Windsor, a New York woman who married her longtime companion, Thea Spyer, in Canada in 2007. When Ms. Spyer died a few years later, their marriage was not recognized by the federal government because of DOMA, and Ms. Windsor was forced to pay nearly $370,000 in federal estate taxes.

The Proposition 8 case asks whether the U.S. Constitution prohibits the people of California from defining marriage as the union of one man and one woman in their state. The American Foundation for Equal Rights sued to overturn Proposition 8 on behalf of two same-sex couples. "This case is about the fundamental constitutional right of all Americans to marry the person they love," said Theodore B. Olson, AFER's lead co-counsel with David Boies. The Supreme Court's decision to grant review in this case "illustrates the national significance of marriage equality, and brings us closer to the day when every American will be able to equally enjoy the fundamental freedom to marry."

Title: Republican Governors Shift Focus from Tax Cuts to Spending and Revenue Growth

The 2010 election saw Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, a self-proclaimed champion of conservative policies, make a name for himself by limiting public-employee collective bargaining. However, it appears that no one, not even Governor Walker himself, is poised to replicate his success this year. As he considers a presidential run, Walker has expressed concerns about a "right-to-work" bill gaining momentum in the Wisconsin Legislature, which would further restrict unions. Additionally, he is downplaying suggestions he made a year ago to significantly slash the income tax.

In Ohio, Governor John Kasich, also rumored to have presidential ambitions, is pushing to raise taxes on energy drilling companies to fund an income tax cut, despite opposition from a Tea Party faction in the General Assembly. Michigan Governor Rick Snyder, who overcame conservative objections to financial aid for Detroit, is proposing higher gasoline taxes to improve roads, an idea unpopular among his right-wing supporters.

The prospect of sweeping new tax cuts, a cornerstone of Republican orthodoxy, seems to have diminished. This is partly due to the fact that incumbents first elected four years ago have already enacted cuts, but Republican governors are also reacting to the cautionary example of Kansas. Governor Sam Brownback, who implemented large business and income tax cuts in 2012 and 2013, promised the revenue loss would be made up by a business boom. Instead, revenues plummeted, and the state faces a significant budget shortfall, nearly costing Brownback his re-election.

In Florida, Governor Rick Scott, who was sworn in on Tuesday, outlined an agenda that calls for spending billions more on schools, the environment, and transportation, a sharp departure from his first term, which saw $3.3 billion in education cuts and the rejection of billions in federal aid for high-speed rail. Arizona's newly elected Republican governor, Doug Ducey, promised in his inauguration speech not to raise taxes, but omitted mention of campaign pledges to cut income taxes each year. This omission surprised few, given the state's substantial and growing budget shortfall.

Several Republican governors, including Tennessee's Bill Haslam and those in Wyoming and North Carolina, have announced their support for some form of Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act, arguing it is fiscally smart to accept billions of dollars in federal aid.

Title: Hillary Clinton Says She Has Not Been Contacted by FBI in Email Server Investigation

Article: Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, stated on NBC's Meet the Press that she has not been contacted by the FBI in the ongoing investigation surrounding her use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State. When asked if agents had been in touch with her, Clinton replied, "No, no, they haven't." However, she emphasized that she is willing to answer any questions the FBI may have and has already made her emails available to the public.

Clinton acknowledged that sending emails from a private server while in office was a "mistake," but emphasized that she believed her emails were being stored on government accounts. She also pointed out that other public officials have not made their emails publicly available, and she has taken the initiative to do so.

Regarding the ongoing investigation, Clinton expressed confidence that it will be resolved by the time the Democratic National Convention takes place in July. She stated, "I'm not worried about it. Because I don't think anything inappropriate was done. And so I have to let them decide how to resolve their security inquiry."

Clinton also addressed the topic of debates with her Democratic rival, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. While she expressed confidence that a debate will take place before the New York primary on April 19, she declined to commit to a specific date. Sanders has been pushing for a debate, and Clinton's campaign is reportedly negotiating the details with his team.

Title: Police Officer-Involved Incident Caught on Video in St. Paul, Minnesota

A cellphone video has surfaced showing a disturbing incident involving a 28-year-old black man, Christopher Lollie, and two police officers in downtown St. Paul, Minnesota. The video depicts Lollie sitting in a public area, waiting to pick up his children from New Horizon Academy, when a female officer approaches him and demands to know his identity.

The officer asks Lollie to explain the problem, and he responds that he has been sitting in the area for 10 minutes and does not see why he needs to provide his name. The officer insists, and Lollie becomes increasingly frustrated, stating that he is being targeted because of his race. A second officer then arrives and attempts to touch Lollie, leading to a tense exchange.

The situation escalates, with Lollie's phone being knocked out of his hands, and he is eventually tased by the officers. The police report states that the officers, Michael Johnson and Bruce Schmidt, were called to the First National Bank Building on a report of an uncooperative male refusing to leave. The female officer's identity has not been released.

Lollie's children were not present during the incident, but their classmates and teacher witnessed the event. The teacher provided a witness statement, stating that Lollie was calm and cooperative, and the officers' actions were unprovoked. As a result, all charges against Lollie were dropped on July 31.
