Lollie chose not to post the video until the charges were dropped, citing the emotional toll the incident took on him. He expressed frustration that, despite being a law-abiding citizen, he still faces discrimination and mistreatment due to his race.

Title: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver Defends GM Daryl Morey's Right to Free Speech Amidst Controversy Over Hong Kong Tweet

NBA Commissioner Adam Silver has spoken out in defense of Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey's right to free speech, despite the controversy surrounding his tweet showing support for anti-government protesters in Hong Kong. Silver made the comments at a news conference in Tokyo before an NBA preseason game between the Rockets and the Toronto Raptors.

Silver stated that Morey, as an employee of the Rockets, has the right to freedom of expression, but acknowledged that there are consequences to exercising that right. He emphasized that the NBA is not apologizing for Morey's tweet, but rather is sympathetic to the upset caused by the controversy.

The controversy began when Morey tweeted a now-deleted image that read "Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong," in reference to the ongoing pro-democracy protests in the semiautonomous Chinese territory. The tweet sparked a backlash in China, with state broadcaster CCTV canceling plans to show a pair of preseason games between the Los Angeles Lakers and Brooklyn Nets.

The NBA has faced criticism from Chinese officials and fans, with CCTV stating that it is "strongly dissatisfied and oppose" Silver's claim to support Morey's right to freedom of expression. The broadcaster also announced it would review all its cooperation and exchanges involving the NBA.

Silver is set to meet with officials and business partners in Shanghai on Wednesday, hoping to find common ground and ease tensions. He emphasized that the NBA is not apologizing for its values, but rather is willing to face the consequences of adhering to them.

The controversy has also led to the cancellation of a ceremonial NBA Cares event in Shanghai and the suspension of the Chinese Basketball Association's relationship with the Rockets. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver is set to meet with Chinese officials and business partners in Shanghai on Wednesday, hoping to find common ground and ease tensions.

Title: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Professor Jonathan Gruber's Comments on Obamacare Spark Controversy

Article:

Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor Jonathan Gruber, known for his role in shaping the Affordable Care Act (ACA), has been at the center of a controversy after tapes surfaced of him making derogatory comments about voters. In the recordings, Gruber stated that the healthcare law was written in a way to deceive voters and that the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) was not aware of the individual mandate's true nature. He also said that the lack of transparency was a significant political advantage.

Gruber's comments have sparked a backlash from politicians and healthcare experts, with some calling for him to be removed from the defense strategy of the ACA. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi distanced herself from Gruber, stating that she did not know who he was and that his comments were a year old and had been recanted. However, Gruber has since apologized for his remarks.

The controversy has also raised questions about Gruber's role in the legal defense of the ACA. In legal briefs submitted to a federal district court in Virginia, the Obama administration cited Gruber's work in a case defending their ability to pay subsidies to enrollees regardless of whether they are part of state-run or federally run health care exchanges. However, Gruber's comments about subsidies have been used by opponents of the law to bolster their arguments.

The Supreme Court has agreed to take up the case, King v. Burwell, after the challengers lost to the administration in the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The case revolves around the question of whether the subsidies can be paid to enrollees in states that have not set up their own exchanges. Gruber's comments suggest that subsidies would only flow to states that set up their own exchanges, which would mean that consumers in most states would not be eligible for subsidies.

The controversy has also led to questions about Gruber's financial ties to the healthcare law. He has made hundreds of thousands of dollars off Obamacare, serving as a consultant to the Department of Health and Human Services and to states that used health care grant money to pay him for his services.

While some have called for Gruber to be removed from the defense strategy of the ACA, others have defended his role in shaping the healthcare law. Timothy Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee University, stated that the controversy has been overblown and that Gruber was not a legislator, did not write the bill, and did not vote on the bill.

Title: Trump Administration's Proposed Rule to Increase Health Insurance Options and Reduce Costs

The Trump administration has proposed a rule to make it easier for Americans to purchase health insurance outside of the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) exchanges. The proposal would repeal an October 2016 regulation that restricted the availability of "short-term, limited-duration" (STLD) insurance, which is exempt from ACA regulations. STLD plans, which can be purchased for around $124 per month, compared to $393 on the exchanges, would be allowed to last longer than the current three-month limit.

The proposal has been met with criticism from Congressional Democrats, who argue that the availability of affordable plans outside of the ACA's risk pool could deprive the exchanges of essential revenues from healthy enrollees, increasing premiums for those who remain. However, a study from the Urban Institute suggests that the proposal would increase the number of Americans insured by 1.7 million while reducing costs to taxpayers.

The study found that 7.4 million people on the exchanges eligible for tax credits would see no change in premiums, 4.2 million would enroll in STLD plans with lower premiums, and 4.5 million on the exchanges without tax credits would see premiums rise by an average of 18.2%. The study also estimates that the proposal would reduce the number of uninsured Americans by 1.7 million.

The Urban Institute's study also found that the net fiscal impact of STLD deregulation would be a reduction in federal spending on health care for the nonelderly by $686 million, or 0.2%. The study's findings suggest that the deregulation of STLD plans would reduce the cost of health insurance, cover more people, and slightly reduce the burden on taxpayers.

Overall, the proposed rule aims to increase health insurance options and reduce costs for Americans, while also reducing the number of uninsured individuals. The Urban Institute's study provides empirical evidence that the proposal would achieve these goals, making it a viable option for those seeking affordable health insurance.

Title: Trump Administration to Allow Lawsuits Against Foreign Companies Using Confiscated Cuban Properties

The Trump administration has announced a major policy shift, allowing lawsuits in U.S. courts against foreign companies that use properties confiscated by the Cuban government since Fidel Castro's revolution in 1959. This decision, set to be announced on Wednesday, could expose U.S., European, and Canadian companies to legal action and deal a blow to Cuba's efforts to attract more foreign investment.

The move is part of the administration's efforts to punish Cuba over its support for Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, whom the U.S. considers a "dictator." The decision is also seen as a response to the Trump administration's efforts to roll back the normalization of relations between the U.S. and Cuba, which began under former President Barack Obama.

The policy shift will allow U.S. citizens to sue foreign companies that use properties seized by the Cuban government, which could lead to billions of dollars in legal claims. The European Union has warned that it may challenge the decision with the World Trade Organization, citing concerns over the extraterritorial application of the U.S. embargo.

The decision is expected to have significant implications for companies with business interests in Cuba, including Canadian mining firm Sherritt International Corp and Spanish hotel chain Melia Hotels International SA. The U.S. official defending the decision said it will only cause a "bump" in the business world but send a message of U.S. resolve against Havana.

The Trump administration's decision is seen as a major blow to Cuba's efforts to attract foreign investment, which has been growing in recent years. The country's National Assembly has declared the Helms-Burton Act "illegitimate, unenforceable, and without legal effect," and Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel has criticized the move as a "return to the worst level" in U.S.-Cuba relations.

The decision is also seen as a response to the Trump administration's efforts to roll back the normalization of relations between the U.S. and Cuba, which began under Obama. The U.S. official dismissed the EU's warning of a possible WTO challenge, saying it would be "doomed to fail."

Title: Bipartisan Budget Agreement Draws Criticism from Fiscal Conservatives

The recent bipartisan budget agreement negotiated between House Republicans and Senate Democrats has sparked intense debate among lawmakers and outside groups. The deal, brokered by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray, aims to reduce the deficit by $23 billion over the next decade. However, fiscal conservatives are criticizing the agreement, citing concerns that it does not address long-term entitlement spending and raises taxes in the form of higher fees.

The agreement increases spending in 2014 and 2015, restoring more than $60 billion in sequester spending cuts. The new spending is offset by lowering the cost-of-living adjustment for military retirees, requiring higher pension contributions from recently hired federal employees, and raising fees on travelers collected by the Transportation Security Administration.

Some winners in the deal include the Pentagon and the defense industry, which saw much of the defense-related sequester cuts restored, as well as the energy industry, which gained expanded rights for joint drilling along the U.S.-Mexico border and in the Gulf of Mexico. Industries and interests that emerged as losers in the final deal, such as airlines and federal workers, have expressed their unhappiness.

The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the bulk of the plan's deficit reduction will come in the final three years of the deal, while the new spending will occur over the next two years. The Treasury Department reported that the U.S. government ran a $135.2 billion budget deficit through the first two months of the year, short of the $226.8 billion deficit the nation had built up by this time a year ago.

House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, defended the agreement, saying that critics opposed it even before knowing what was in it. "They're using our members and the American people to their own purposes," he said. "This is ridiculous."

However, several Republican senators, including Kentucky's Rand Paul and Oklahoma's Tom Coburn, immediately came out against the deal, and many other Republican senators are expected to oppose the accord. The agreement is expected to be voted on in the House as early as Thursday, with House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan confident he has the votes to pass the bill.

Title: Authorities Capture Suspect in New York and New Jersey Bombings

Article:

Authorities captured Ahmad Khan Rahami, a 28-year-old naturalized U.S. citizen, on Monday after a dramatic gun battle with police in Linden, New Jersey. Rahami was identified as the primary person of interest in the bombings that occurred in New York's Chelsea neighborhood and New Jersey's Seaside Park over the weekend.

The investigation began when a bar owner in Linden spotted Rahami sleeping in his doorway on Monday morning. An officer confronted Rahami, and a gun battle ensued. Rahami shot an officer, identified as Angel Padilla, in the abdomen, and another officer, Investigator Pete Hammer, suffered a bullet graze to the head. Both officers were expected to recover.

Rahami was shot in the leg and eventually brought down and captured alive. He was taken to University Hospital in Newark and underwent surgery. Rahami was charged with five counts of attempted murder of a police officer and was being held on $5.2 million bail.

The FBI launched a raid at Rahami's apartment in Elizabeth, New Jersey, on Monday morning, which is about four miles from where he was captured. The apartment is located above a fried chicken restaurant. The FBI also conducted a traffic stop in Brooklyn of a "vehicle of interest" in the bombings, but the individuals in the vehicle were no longer in custody.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio stated that authorities were not currently searching for any other suspects, and the assistant director of the FBI's field office in New York, William Sweeney Jr., said there was no indication of a cell in the area.

The bombings, which injured 29 people, occurred on Saturday night in New York's Chelsea neighborhood and on Sunday morning in New Jersey's Seaside Park. The devices used flip phones as detonators and contained shrapnel consisting of ball bearings and BBs. Authorities are still searching for two individuals who removed an unexploded bomb from a duffle bag after it had allegedly been placed on the street by Rahami.

Title: Bernie Sanders Criticizes Michael Bloomberg's Wealth, Refuses to Commit to Accepting His Campaign Funds

Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, criticized Michael Bloomberg's wealth during a CNN town hall, calling it "offensive." However, he refused to indicate whether he would accept financial help from Bloomberg to beat President Donald Trump in the general election.

Sanders stated that Bloomberg has the right to run for president, but he believes it is "obscene" that someone with a net worth of $60 billion can buy the election. He emphasized that his campaign has received contributions from millions of Americans, with an average contribution of $18.50, and that he is proud of the grassroots movement behind his campaign.

When asked if he would accept help from billionaires like Bloomberg, Sanders dodged the question three times, saying that his campaign does not have a super PAC and does not accept donations from wealthy individuals. He emphasized that he would support the Democratic nominee if he does not win the nomination, but refused to commit to accepting Bloomberg's funds.

The exchange highlights the contrast between Sanders' campaign, which relies on small donations from a large number of people, and Bloomberg's self-funded campaign, which has allowed him to spend millions of dollars on advertising and campaign infrastructure.

Title: House Republicans Unveil Plan to Wean Country Off Obamacare Subsidies Amid Supreme Court Ruling

House Republicans have outlined a plan to phase out Obamacare subsidies, anticipating a Supreme Court ruling this month that could significantly impact the Affordable Care Act. The proposal, described as a "work in progress," would continue to provide full subsidies to all beneficiaries, regardless of their location, but would allow states to opt out of the program and receive block grants to help their residents obtain insurance. These block grants and subsidies would expire in 2017, requiring the next president and Congress to replace the law entirely.

The plan, which has not been finalized, would repeal the Affordable Care Act's insurance mandates on individuals and employers, a move that is likely to be met with opposition from Obamacare supporters. The proposal would use a budget process known as "reconciliation" to pass the plan, which could be vetoed by President Obama.

Some lawmakers are hesitant to approve extending Obamacare subsidies for the rest of 2015 and 2016, fearing it would send the wrong message to voters after the GOP has spent years trying to repeal the entire law. Others believe that Congress should let states opt out of Obamacare if the subsidies go away or extend temporary aid outside of the health law's framework.

The Supreme Court is currently considering a part of the law that says subsidies can be paid to residents in states that established their own exchanges. The administration argues that this was intended to cover everyone, while opponents say it was meant to exclude the 34 states that refused to set up exchanges and instead rely on the federal HealthCare.gov program. More than 6 million Americans stand to lose subsidies if the court rules against the administration.

Senate Republicans have also been discussing their own plans, including locking in the subsidies through 2017, but have offered fewer details. The Supreme Court's ruling is expected to come as early as Thursday, and lawmakers are racing to have a plan ready in anticipation of the decision.

Title: Secretary of State Kerry Raises Concerns Over Allegations of Secret Iranian Uranium Enrichment Facility

Article: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concerns over allegations made by an Iranian dissident group, the National Coalition of Resistance of Iran (NCRI), that Iran is running a secret uranium enrichment operation at a facility near Tehran. During a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, Kerry stated that US officials were aware of the facility prior to the allegations, but it had not been revealed as a nuclear facility. He declined to provide further details, citing the ongoing negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program.

The NCRI claims the underground facility, known as "Lavizan-3," has been used for clandestine nuclear research since 2008 and is equipped with advanced centrifuges. While the allegations are not immediately verifiable, the NCRI has a history of providing accurate information about Iran's nuclear activities in the past. The group exposed the existence of Iran's Natanz uranium enrichment facility and Arak heavy-water plutonium facility in the early 2000s, which have been at the center of international scrutiny and distrust of Tehran since then.

Representative Brad Sherman, a California Democrat, noted that the NCRI has provided accurate information in the past and suggested that their claims about the secret facility should be taken seriously. The allegations, if true, could potentially derail a final nuclear deal with Iran, which is currently being negotiated by the US and other world powers.

Title: South Korea's Open Approach to Combating the Coronavirus Outbreak

The article highlights the contrast between South Korea's response to the coronavirus outbreak and China's approach, which has been criticized for its authoritarian measures. While China's Communist Party has claimed success in containing the virus, the article argues that this is based on a "gigantic leap of faith" and ignores months of denial, cover-ups, and missteps that allowed the virus to spread globally.

In contrast, South Korea's response has focused on education, transparency, and mobilizing civil society, without resorting to draconian measures like forced home detention or suppressing dissent. The country has rapidly expanded testing, with 15,000 people tested daily, and has deployed drive-through sample collection stations to minimize physical contact.

South Korea's mortality rate is 0.71%, with 7,513 confirmed cases and 54 deaths as of Tuesday. The government has also implemented a three-step detection system at Incheon International Airport to prevent the export of the virus.

The article notes that some of South Korea's measures have been controversial, such as tracking confirmed cases with GPS and providing a live map of their locations. However, this is seen as a more transparent approach than China's use of surveillance drones to monitor citizens.

The article concludes that South Korea's open approach has allowed the country to effectively combat the virus, with a steady downtick in confirmed cases and a focus on transparency and public education. In contrast, China's authoritarian measures have caused massive suffering and are not a model for other countries to follow.

Title: FBI Documents Reveal Attempted Deal Between State Department Official and FBI to Alter Classification of Hillary Clinton's Emails

Article:

The FBI has released documents revealing an attempt by a State Department official, Patrick Kennedy, to negotiate a deal with the FBI to alter the classification of Hillary Clinton's emails in exchange for favorable treatment of FBI officials in overseas postings. The documents, obtained by The Weekly Standard, show that Kennedy, a close associate of Hillary Clinton, attempted to use his influence to have at least one email classified as "geological and geophysical information and data" under the Freedom of Information Act, which would have allowed it to be archived and never seen again.

According to the FBI summaries, Kennedy approached an FBI official in the international operations division in the spring of 2015, seeking help in altering the classification of the email. The FBI official reported that Kennedy wanted to obtain a "B9" exemption, which is a rarely used exemption that refers to "geological and geophysical information and data." The FBI official told Kennedy that he would look into the email if Kennedy would authorize a pending request for additional FBI personnel in Iraq.

The documents also reveal that a senior FBI official in the records management division was approached by a colleague in international operations and was pressured to declassify an email in exchange for a quid pro quo. The official stated that the request was denied.

The FBI has explained the events by stating that the bargained-for exchange never took place and that the FBI agent with whom Kennedy was communicating has since retired. The State Department has also denied any wrongdoing, claiming that the conversations were a "normal part of the classification process."

However, critics argue that the attempt to alter the classification of the emails was a clear attempt to influence the investigation and undermine the transparency of the process. The fact that Kennedy was working to remedy Hillary Clinton's denials about the existence of classified material on her email server, and was offering to bribe FBI officials in exchange for favorable treatment, raises serious concerns about the integrity of the investigation.

The incident highlights the need for transparency and accountability in government, and the importance of protecting the integrity of investigations. It also underscores the need for the public to remain vigilant and demand answers about the actions of government officials and politicians.

Title: Conservative Voices Face Online Suppression as Social Media Platforms Crack Down on Dissent

Article:

Conservative voices are facing increasing suppression on social media platforms, with several prominent figures having their accounts suspended or banned in recent weeks. Raheem Kassam, a former editor for Breitbart and a fellow at the Claremont Institute, was temporarily banned from Facebook, only to have his account restored after an intervention by Donald Trump Jr. Kassam attributed the ban to the Left's campaign to silence conservative voices on social media.

Kassam's ban was not an isolated incident. Many conservatives have been targeted by social media platforms, including talk-show host Alex Jones and British activist Tommy Robinson. Laura Loomer, a Trump supporter, had nearly a quarter-million Twitter followers before she was banned in November for criticizing newly elected Democrat Rep. Ilhan Omar. Loomer attributed her ban to pressure from the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), which has connections to Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood.

The suppression of online free speech has become a major concern, with many seeing it as an attempt to stifle dissent and silence conservative voices. Donald Trump Jr. has been vocal about the issue, tweeting that the social media crackdown is an "accident" that only happens one way. He also expanded his critique of social media censorship into a column at Real Clear Politics, stating that anti-conservative censorship has gone from bad to worse.

The stakes are high, as the social media revolution has upended people's relationship with the overwhelmingly liberal media. The Left and establishment journalists want to return to a world where their narrative is the only one that matters, and the truth is whatever they decree it to be. The suppression of online free speech has become a dreary familiarity, with many conservatives facing suspension or punishment by Twitter, Facebook, or YouTube.

The issue is not limited to individual accounts. Social media platforms are now tinkering with their terms of service to mandate that users adhere to liberal orthodoxy in their posts. For example, it is now a banishment offense to "misgender" or "deadname" transgender people on Twitter. The stakes are high, and the social media revolution has created a new battleground for free speech.

Title: Kentucky Senate Candidates Dodge Questions, Spark Debate on Political Calculus

In the first and only debate in the Kentucky Senate race, incumbent Republican Mitch McConnell and Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes both dodged high-profile questions from the moderator. The question is: what's the political calculus behind their evasions, and will it hurt them?

Grimes, Kentucky's secretary of state, refused to answer a question about whether she voted for President Obama during an interview with The Courier-Journal's editorial board. She instead emphasized the importance of the right to a secret ballot as chief election official. However, her evasion was met with ridicule from both left and right, with NBC's Chuck Todd calling her "disqualified."

On Monday, Grimes provided more context, explaining that as secretary of state, she must stand up for the right to a secret ballot. "If I as chief election official...don't stand up for that right, who in Kentucky will?" she asked KET television moderator Bill Goodman. Grimes has previously stated that she voted for Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2008 primary. The downside of revealing her vote now is that her words can be used in a McConnell ad against her.

McConnell, on the other hand, dodged a question about climate change, saying he's not a scientist and doesn't want to delve into its causes. When asked whether he stands by his "not a scientist" position and whether he believes in discussing climate change, he brushed past the question. Instead, he emphasized his focus on fighting for coal jobs in Kentucky.

Both Grimes and McConnell's political calculus appears to be that not answering the questions is better than taking a stance that could be used against them in future ads. However, some observers argue that their evasions may not matter much, as both candidates are pro-coal and the question of climate change is not a voting issue.

Title: President Obama Arrives in Israel for Historic Visit

President Barack Obama landed in Israel this morning, marking the first time he has visited the country as president. During a welcoming ceremony at Tel Aviv airport, Obama emphasized the unbreakable bond between the United States and Israel, reaffirming America's commitment to Israel's security and speaking directly to the Israeli people and their neighbors.

Obama is currently touring Israel's Iron Dome, the country's missile defense system, which the United States has helped fund. He will later visit Jerusalem and cross into the West Bank. The New York Times reports that Obama does not arrive with grand plans to revive stalled peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, but rather seeks to make a connection with the Israeli people.

The highlight of the trip will be a speech Obama will deliver to students at the Jerusalem International Convention Center on Thursday, where he is expected to reassure Israel of the United States' commitment to its security as Israel seeks to counter threats from Iran and protect its people in the midst of the civil war in neighboring Syria.

The visit is seen as a "trust-building" effort, with both sides insisting there are no major issues between them. However, there have been questions about whether Israel is serious about resuming peace talks with the Palestinians and whether the United States will take a more active role in the process.

During a press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Obama was asked about the stalled peace talks during his first term. Obama acknowledged that progress has been slow, but emphasized that "this is not easy." Netanyahu reiterated that Israel and the United States share the same assessment on the schedule regarding Iran's nuclear program.

On Syria, Obama defended the United States' efforts to bring the conflict to a resolution, stating that "having the facts before you act is important when it comes to war and peace."

Title: Pompeo Wins Senate Foreign Relations Committee Vote After Sen. Rand Paul's Endorsement

Article:

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 11-9 in favor of Mike Pompeo's nomination to become the next Secretary of State, paving the way for his potential confirmation as early as this week. The unexpected turn of events came after Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) flipped his stance and endorsed Pompeo, citing assurances from President Donald Trump that the nominee shares his views on the war in Iraq and the U.S. presence in Afghanistan.

Sen. Paul had previously indicated he would oppose Pompeo's nomination, but changed his stance after multiple conversations with Trump and receiving assurances that Pompeo believes the war in Iraq was a mistake and wants to wind down the U.S. presence in Afghanistan. Trump praised Paul's decision, saying he "never let me down."

The final vote count was 11-9, with Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) voting "present" to allow Foreign Relations Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) to steer the nomination to the floor without waiting for Sen. Johnny Isakson (R-Ga.) to vote.

Pompeo's nomination is expected to win confirmation from the full Senate with unified GOP support and backing from a handful of vulnerable Democrats. Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Sen. Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.), and Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) have already announced their support for Pompeo. However, some Democrats remain undecided, including Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia and Sen. Doug Jones of Alabama.

Activists on the left who have pushed Democrats to oppose Pompeo, citing his past statements on Islamic leaders and climate change, praised the committee's minority for staying united in opposition.

Title: U.S. Military Bases Raise Security Level to "Force Protection Bravo" Amid Growing Terror Threats

The United States military has increased security measures at its bases, elevating the threat level to "Force Protection Bravo," a designation defined by the Pentagon as an "increased and predictable threat of terrorism." This decision comes in the aftermath of the recent shooting at a Texas cartoon contest featuring drawings of the Prophet Mohammed, which was linked to a British-born jihadist.

According to a U.S. official, the military became concerned about several recent incidents, including a tweet from a jihadist linked to the Garland attack, which mentioned the name and address of a U.S. military officer connected to the military's Syrian rebel training program. The tweet appeared to encourage an attack on the address.

The U.S. military has also been concerned about the publication of the names and addresses of about 100 military members on ISIS-connected accounts several weeks ago. FBI Director James Comey stated that there are thousands of ISIS followers online in the U.S., and the agency has a general concern that the group is focusing on the uniformed military and law enforcement.

The order to upgrade the threat level was signed by Admiral William Gortney, head of the U.S. Northern Command, which oversees all U.S. military installations in the continental U.S. The security order affects 3,200 sites, including bases, National Guard facilities, recruiting stations, and health clinics.

The increased security measures may include more checks of vehicles entering bases and more thorough identity checks of all personnel. Captain Jeff Davis, spokesman for the U.S. Northern Command, emphasized that "this is the new normal, that we are going to have increased vigilance and force protection. We seek to be unpredictable."

The order to raise the force protection level to Bravo also applies to all National Guard installations, recruiting stations, and ROTC detachments. However, practically speaking, the official acknowledged that it will be difficult for ROTC detachments to do much more than security awareness.

In addition, security was raised recently at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, in response to a perceived threat to the base security. The threat was never deemed credible, but it came after another security concern at a base in Delaware used by Vice President Joe Biden when he flies home.

Since the establishment of the U.S. Northern Command in October 2002, the threat level has reached Bravo on four occasions: February 9, 2003, amid concerns al Qaeda was planning attacks on American targets; December 21, 2003, when officials were concerned about attacks during the holiday season; May 1, 2011, in the aftermath of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden; and the 10th anniversary of the September 11 attacks.

Title: National Archives' Alteration of Women's March Photo Raises Questions About Historical Record

The National Archives' decision to alter a photograph from the 2017 Women's March on Washington has sparked concerns about the integrity of the historical record. The photograph, which originally showed a sign with the words "God Hates Trump," had the word "Trump" blurred and the words "vagina" and "pussy" removed. The Archives initially defended the changes, citing concerns about the content being "inappropriate" and the agency's non-partisan and non-political stance. However, the decision was met with widespread criticism, and the Archives ultimately removed the altered photograph and issued an apology.

The incident has raised questions about the role of the National Archives in preserving the historical record and the potential for political bias in the editing process. The Archives' director, David S. Ferriero, was appointed by President Obama, which some have seen as a factor in the agency's decision-making.

The controversy has also drawn parallels to the Soviet Union's practice of altering historical records to fit their ideology. The National Archives' actions have been criticized for being a form of historical revisionism, which can have long-term consequences for our understanding of the past.

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of preserving the historical record in its entirety, without alteration or censorship. It is crucial that institutions responsible for preserving our history take a neutral and transparent approach to ensure that the record remains accurate and intact for future generations.

Title: Edward Snowden Remains in Transit, Ecuador Considers Asylum Request

Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, remains in transit at a Moscow airport, officials confirmed, as Ecuador announced that his political asylum bid could take up to two months to approve. Ecuador's foreign minister, Ricardo Patino, stated that if Snowden goes to the Ecuadorian embassy, a decision will be made, but acknowledged that it may take as long as two months, similar to the time it took to process Julian Assange's asylum request.

Snowden is wanted by the US government after leaking top-secret information on US surveillance programs to several media outlets. The US revoked his passport, but he managed to flee Hong Kong and is currently in Russia. Ecuador has denied granting Snowden special travel documents, and some speculate that he may have already left the Moscow airport and is making his way to Ecuador's embassy.

Ecuador has come under fire for offering Snowden asylum, with some calling for the US to cut off aid to the country. Ecuador has received $144.4 million in US aid over the past five years. National security analyst Aaron Cohen stated that Ecuador's decision to grant Snowden asylum could be seen as a betrayal of the US-Ecuador relationship.

Ecuador's embassy official, Efraín Baus, stated that Snowden's application will be reviewed responsibly, as are many other asylum applications the country receives each year. Ecuador has an extradition agreement with the US, but makes exceptions for political crimes. Baus invited the US to submit its position on Snowden's asylum request in writing, stating that the legal process takes human rights obligations into consideration.

Some speculate that Ecuador is taking its time considering the asylum application to come across as seriously weighing the legal implications of Snowden's request, while others point to the windfall of media attention Ecuador garners while the decision is pending. Ecuador's President Rafael Correa has been criticized for offering asylum to both Snowden and Assange, with some seeing it as a principled stance on deepening Ecuador's sovereignty and limiting US influence in the region.

The decision to grant Snowden asylum could have immediate political and economic consequences for Ecuador, including the potential loss of preferential treatment for trading certain products. However, some argue that preferential treatment was already at risk of not being renewed. Others believe that the US has limited options to respond to Ecuador's decision, with some stating that the US doesn't have many measures to utilize other than to criticize.

Title: ABC News Anchor Admits Network Killed Jeffrey Epstein Story Due to Royal Family Pressure

Article:

A recent video has surfaced, showing ABC News anchor Amy Robach admitting that the network killed a story about billionaire Jeffrey Epstein, accused of being a pedophile, due to pressure from the British royal family. This revelation comes on the heels of allegations from journalist Ronan Farrow that NBC News killed his reporting on alleged rapist Harvey Weinstein to protect their own in-house sexual abuser, morning anchor Matt Lauer.

According to Robach, ABC executives killed the story because they were afraid of losing access to the British royal family, specifically Prince Andrew, who was implicated in the allegations. Robach stated that she had the story for three years, but it was deemed "stupid" and "no one knows who Jeffrey Epstein is." The palace allegedly threatened ABC News, and the network was afraid of losing access to the royal family, including Kate and William.

The story that ABC News killed was about Epstein's alleged sexual abuse of underage girls, which he was indicted for in 2007. Epstein's lawyers, including Ken Starr, Jay Lefkowitz, and Alan Dershowitz, negotiated a 13-month sentence with former U.S. Attorney and later Trump Labor Secretary Alex Acosta.

The Epstein case highlights the growing divide between the wealthy and powerful and the rest of society. If the elite can get away with such heinous crimes with almost no punishment, the system is broken.

ABC News has responded to the footage, stating that Robach's comments were a "private moment of frustration" and that they did not run the story because they could not obtain sufficient corroborating evidence. However, this explanation is hard to accept, given that ABC News has run uncorroborated reports about Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh.

The incident raises questions about political bias and the treatment of powerful figures. ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos is a former staffer of Bill Clinton, who was a close associate of Epstein. The timing of the story's killing, when Hillary Clinton was running for president, raises suspicions.

The incident is not an isolated one. Journalist Ronan Farrow has alleged that NBC News killed his reporting on alleged rapist Harvey Weinstein to protect their own in-house sexual abuser, morning anchor Matt Lauer. CBS News has also been implicated in the scandal, with reports indicating that they fired the whistleblower who released the Robach video.

The incident highlights the growing distrust of the news media, with a recent Gallup poll showing that 69% of Americans have lost trust in the news media over the past decade. The events of the past couple of months may have pushed that number closer to 100%.

Title: Trump Optimistic About North Korea's Denuclearization Process

President Donald Trump has expressed optimism about the denuclearization process with North Korea, stating that he believes the country will begin working towards dismantling its nuclear program "virtually immediately." This comes after the historic summit between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, where they signed a joint declaration committing to the "complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula."

In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, Trump said the process is "really moving rapidly" and that he believes Kim is committed to dismantling his country's nuclear program. He also stated that Kim has already indicated his willingness to do so and has taken steps in that direction.

The joint declaration signed by the two leaders commits the U.S. to providing "security guarantees" to North Korea, while Pyongyang agrees to work towards the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Trump also announced that the U.S. will be ending joint military exercises with South Korea, and that Kim has agreed to destroy a "major" missile testing site.

While the agreement is seen as a significant step forward, it remains unclear whether North Korea will follow through on its commitments. Trump expressed optimism, stating that Kim is committed to getting the job done and that he trusts him. However, he also emphasized that the U.S. will need to "check" on North Korea's progress to ensure that denuclearization occurs.

The summit, which was almost derailed due to tensions between the two leaders, marked a significant shift from the rhetoric of last summer, when Trump and Kim exchanged threats and insults. Trump attributed the success of the summit to the "rhetoric" used by both sides, stating that "without the rhetoric, we wouldn't have been here."

Title: Ben Carson Defends Flat Tax Plan, Says It's "Condescending" to Assume Poor Can't Pay Taxes

Ben Carson, a Republican presidential candidate, defended his flat tax plan on Sunday, stating that it is "proportional" and based on the biblical concept of tithing. According to Carson, those making $10 billion a year would pay $1 billion in taxes, while those making $100 would pay $1. "That's pretty darn fair if you ask me," Carson said.

Carson, a 63-year-old former pediatric neurosurgeon, grew up poor in Detroit and emphasized that poor people have pride and don't want to be taken care of. He argued that everyone should pay taxes, making it more difficult for politicians to raise taxes on everyone.

Host Chris Wallace countered that experts say a flat tax rate would need to be around 20% to match current revenue, which would result in a tax hike for low- and middle-income families, while the wealthy would receive a cut. Carson disagreed, stating that his numbers are closer to 10-15%, and he would eliminate loopholes and bring in more revenue through energy resources, corporate taxes, and a tax holiday. "That's $2 trillion right there," he said.

Carson also addressed his previous statements on Russia, stating that "all options" should remain open for dealing with the country. When asked if that included war, Carson replied, "All options includes all options. That doesn't mean that would be my first option." He emphasized that war with Russia is not an option in dealing with Ukraine, but he would handle Ukraine differently than President Barack Obama has.

Carson also defended two controversial statements he made in the past, comparing modern America to Nazi Germany and comparing Obamacare to slavery. He stated that Americans feel intimidated by their government and are afraid to speak their minds. "There are a lot of people in our society who are afraid to say what they really mean because they may get an IRS audit, people will call them names, their jobs may be interfered with," Carson said.

In an October 2013 speech, Carson compared Obamacare to slavery, stating that it fundamentally changes the relationship between the people and the government. "The government is supposed to respond to the will of the people, not dictate to the people what they are doing," he said.

Carson also addressed his statement last week that, as president, he would not have to enforce "judicial law." He pointed to the Supreme Court's Dred Scott decision, which disallowed slaves to sue for their freedom. Abraham Lincoln disagreed with that decision, leading to the Civil War, he said. "The way our Constitution is set up, the president or the executive branch is obligated to carry out the laws of the land. The laws of the land, according to our Constitution, are provided by the legislative branch," he said.

Title: Trump Administration Ends Payments to Health Insurers Under ObamaCare, Prompting Lawsuit from 18 States and the District of Columbia

The Trump administration announced its decision to halt payments to health insurers under ObamaCare, prompting a lawsuit from 18 states and the District of Columbia. The states, led by California, Connecticut, Delaware, and others, claim that the decision constitutes an attempt to gut the health and well-being of the country. The lawsuit, filed in federal court in California, seeks to force the Trump administration to make the next payment to insurers, scheduled for October 18.

The payments, worth around $7 billion this year, help lower out-of-pocket costs for low- and middle-income customers. The decision is seen as a significant step in the Trump administration's bid to ultimately repeal and replace ObamaCare. The move is expected to rattle already-unsteady insurance marketplaces.

The Trump administration has argued that Congress never properly approved the payments, and a federal judge has found that this is the case. The decision has been met with criticism from congressional Democrats, who vow to press for a bipartisan deal to restore the money by the end of the year.

Some Republicans, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, have expressed openness to continuing the payments, but only if accompanied by significant changes. Moderates like Senator Susan Collins have warned that halting the payments will make insurance costs unaffordable for some people.

The decision has also sparked debate among conservative leaders, with some, like Representative Mark Meadows, willing to back the payments if they are part of a transition from ObamaCare to something else with greater state flexibility. Others, like Representative Mark Walker, have said the payments should not be revived under any circumstances.

The fate of the payments remains uncertain, with the Trump administration refusing to make the next payment and congressional Democrats vowing to press for a deal. The decision is expected to have significant implications for the health insurance market and the millions of Americans who rely on the payments to access affordable healthcare.

**Government Shutdown and Debt Ceiling: Senate Leaders Explore Deal, But Details Remain Unclear**

Senate leaders have outlined a potential deal to end the two-week-old government shutdown and give the Treasury Department enough borrowing room to stave off a potential default this month. However, the specifics of the deal are still under negotiation, with disagreements remaining over the length of a stopgap funding bill, the amount of borrowing authority, and potential changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA).

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, have agreed on the basic framework, which would fund the government for several months and give President Obama room to raise the debt into next year. The House and Senate would appoint negotiators to work on a broader budget deal.

However, the exact dates of the debt and spending extensions, as well as potential add-ons like delays or restrictions on Obamacare, are still being negotiated. Even if a deal is reached, it is unclear whether it will pass the GOP-controlled House, where conservatives have expressed concerns about the lack of concessions on the ACA.

The Treasury Department is expected to run out of borrowing room on Thursday, leaving it with only cash on hand to pay bills. This could last a couple of weeks or be exhausted almost immediately, analysts said.

The White House has been insistent that the government reopen and the debt be raised without conditions, while House Republicans remain a major hurdle. Conservatives have expressed concerns about the lack of concessions on the ACA, while some Senate Republicans have proposed delaying a tax on medical devices, which has bipartisan support.

Title: The Erosion of National Unity: A Reflection on the Evolution of American Identity

The anniversary of the 9/11 attacks often brings forth a mix of memories, news recaps, and speculation. One question that arises is: what happened to the national unity that followed the attacks? The United States was united in its response to the tragedy, with flags adorning vehicles and a sense of shared purpose. However, this unity was short-lived, and the country soon became divided over the Iraq War and subsequent political developments.

In 2001, Americans came together to respond to the attacks, embracing their shared identity as Americans. This unity was built on a foundation of shared values and a sense of national purpose. However, over time, the country has become increasingly divided, with individuals identifying more strongly with their specific groups and interests.

The rise of identity politics has led to a focus on individual identities, such as progressive, populist, African-American, Ivy League, Christian, transgender, Hispanic, vegan, Jewish, and many others. This has created a sense of competition and division, rather than unity.

The article suggests that the inability to cut slack for others and accommodate different perspectives is a major feature of modern politics. This lack of willingness to compromise and understand opposing views has led to a breakdown in national unity.

The author notes that this trend is not new, as the country has always had divisions and disagreements. However, the current atmosphere is different, with a growing sense of "my way or the highway" mentality, where individuals are less willing to listen to and understand opposing views.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of finding common ground and accommodating different perspectives, rather than trying to eliminate opposing views. The author notes that this is a crucial aspect of American democracy and that the country's ability to do so is what sets it apart from other nations, such as the Russian empire.

Title: Romney's Post-Convention Poll Numbers Show Small Bounce, But No Significant Shift in Voter Intentions

The Republican National Convention has concluded, and initial polls suggest Mitt Romney has received a small boost in his image among voters, but no significant change in voter intentions. According to a Reuters/Ipsos poll, Romney's overall image has improved, with 31% of registered voters finding him "likeable" in the latest survey, up from 26% on Monday. However, the poll also showed that Romney still trails President Barack Obama in general favorability, with Obama leading 52% to 50%.

Rasmussen Reports' daily Presidential Tracking Poll also showed a six-point swing in Romney's favor, with him now leading Obama 48% to 44%. The poll also found Romney surging ahead by two points in 11 key swing states.

Gallup's data prior to the convention indicated that the GOP had slightly bolstered its image compared to 2008, while Democrats' favorability has declined by double-digits over the same period. This information is relevant for pollsters attempting to measure the composition of the 2012 electorate and predict the election's outcome.

While Romney's convention bounce may not be as significant as some had hoped, it is clear that his image has improved among voters. Republicans have a sizeable enthusiasm edge this year, and their convention helped their nominee. However, it remains to be seen whether this momentum will translate into a lasting advantage in the polls.

Title: Sanders Clarifies Stance on Pro-Life Democrats, While Buttigieg Avoids the Question

Article:

During a recent MSNBC town hall, Senator Bernie Sanders was asked by host Stephanie Ruhle if he believed there was room for pro-life Democrats in his vision of the party. Sanders responded by stating that being pro-choice is an essential part of being a Democrat, citing its importance in modern times. This stance is a departure from his 2017 endorsement of Heath Mello, an Omaha, Nebraska mayoral candidate who supported a bill requiring doctors to inform women of their right to an ultrasound before an abortion.

In contrast, Pete Buttigieg, another Democratic presidential candidate, dodged a similar question from Kristen Day, executive director of Democrats for Life, during a Fox News town hall. When asked if he would support more moderate platform language to include pro-life Democrats, Buttigieg responded with evasive answers, stating that the best approach is to agree on who should draw the line, with the woman who is faced with the decision in her own life.

The article highlights the differing approaches of Sanders and Buttigieg to the abortion debate, with Sanders being more direct in his stance and Buttigieg avoiding the question. The article does not take a stance on the morality of abortion or the validity of pro-life or pro-choice beliefs, instead focusing on the political implications of the candidates' responses.

Title: Obama Campaign Outspends Romney, But Polls Show Limited Impact

The Obama campaign has outspent Mitt Romney's campaign by a significant margin, with a reported $70.8 million spent in June compared to Romney's $38.8 million. The majority of Obama's spending went towards television advertising, with a focus on attacking Romney's ties to Bain Capital. However, despite the large spending gap, polls suggest that Obama's efforts have not had a significant impact on the election.

According to recent polls, Obama's job approval rating has dropped to 44%, with only 39% approving of his economic performance. The polls also show that voters are increasingly pessimistic about the economy, with 52% of independents believing Obama will "never improve" the economy. Additionally, Obama's favorability ratings have taken a hit, with 28% of independents viewing him unfavorably.

The Obama campaign's spending has not yielded the desired results, with many of his ads going unnoticed or being met with skepticism. The campaign's efforts to define Romney in voters' minds have not been successful, and Obama's approval ratings have not seen a significant boost.

The article also highlights the Obama campaign's struggles to generate excitement and enthusiasm, with thousands of empty seats at his May re-elect kickoff event in Columbus. The event was intended to portray Obama as still popular among young people and able to energize large crowds, but the reality was far from that.

Overall, the article suggests that Obama's campaign is struggling to make an impact and that his spending has not yielded the desired results.

Title: International Sanctions on Iran Lifted After Nuclear Deal Verification

The international community has lifted sanctions on Iran after the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed that the country has complied with a deal aimed at preventing the development of nuclear weapons. The landmark agreement, agreed upon in July, requires Iran to drastically reduce its number of centrifuges and dismantle a heavy-water reactor near the town of Arak, both of which could be used in creating nuclear weapons.

The IAEA's verification process has confirmed that Iran has taken the necessary steps to meet its obligations under the deal. The lifting of sanctions will unfreeze billions of dollars of assets and allow Iran's oil to be sold internationally. The country's oil reserves, the fourth largest in the world, will be able to resume being traded on international markets, and the country will have access to more than $100 billion in frozen assets.

The deal was hailed as a major achievement by the European Union's foreign policy chief, Federica Mogherini, who stated that it will contribute to improved regional and international peace and security. The US Secretary of State, John Kerry, also welcomed the development, saying that Iran had "undertaken significant steps" and that the deal will make the world a safer place.

However, not everyone is pleased with the deal. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has expressed concerns that Iran has not relinquished its ambition to obtain nuclear weapons and continues to act to destabilize the Middle East and spread terror throughout the world.

The lifting of sanctions comes as part of a prisoner swap between the US and Iran, which saw the release of four Iranian-American prisoners, including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who was jailed on charges of espionage. In return, the US released seven Iranians being held in the US for sanctions violations.

The IAEA has installed a device at the Natanz plant to monitor Iran's uranium enrichment activities in real-time, ensuring that uranium enrichment levels remain at or below 3.67%, as agreed upon in the deal. The organization's head, Yukiya Amano, is set to visit Tehran on Sunday for meetings with President Rouhani and other officials.

The deal, agreed upon in July 2015, limits Iran's sensitive nuclear activities for more than a decade in return for the lifting of crippling sanctions. The US is confident that the agreement will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, while Iran maintains that its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes only.

Title: Biden Criticizes "Squad" and Progressive Democrats, Suggests They Don't Represent Party's Future

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has spoken out against the "squad" and progressive Democrats, stating that they do not represent the future of the Democratic Party. In an interview with Axios, which will air on HBO this weekend, Biden expressed his concerns about the party's shift to the left and suggested that Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other progressive lawmakers are a separate entity from the Democratic Party apparatus.

Biden attributed the rise of progressive Democrats to bad judgment and claimed that the media portrays the Democratic voter base as more liberal and left-leaning than it truly is. He stated that Senator Elizabeth Warren and Senator Bernie Sanders, who are considered progressive leaders, appeal to a narrow segment of voters who are more vocal but do not represent the Democratic base as a whole.

Biden emphasized that he believes his rivals for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination are misreading the party and that Warren and Sanders are appealing to the wrong segment of primary voters. He also mentioned that he believes the party is not moving to the left and that the progressive left is a static element of the party.

This stance may play well with voters in early primary states like Iowa, South Carolina, and Nevada, where progressive ideas like Medicare for All do not seem to be resonating with voters. However, it remains to be seen how Biden's criticism of the "squad" and progressive Democrats will be received by the broader Democratic Party and its supporters.

Title: President Obama Urges House to Approve Comprehensive Immigration Reform

President Barack Obama called on House lawmakers to approve comprehensive immigration reform on Thursday, stating that the current system is "not fair" and has been "kicked down the road for too long." The president emphasized that this is the moment to "finally get the job done" and urged Republican leaders to put aside politics and work towards a bipartisan solution.

The president's remarks come as House Republican leaders have announced plans to hold an immigration debate this year, but have refused to consider the comprehensive reform plan approved by the Senate, which would grant a pathway to citizenship for an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants. The president argued that this plan would be good for the economy and the country, and that Republican leaders should disregard the politics of the issue.

"We can't just sweep the problem under the rug one more time," Obama said. "Let's not delay, and let's do it in a bipartisan fashion." The president emphasized that he is not seeking to score political points, but rather believes that comprehensive reform is the right thing to do.

House Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, responded through a spokesman, stating that the speaker agrees that the immigration system is broken and that reform is needed to boost the economy. However, he emphasized that the House will not consider massive, Obamacare-style legislation and instead will pursue a step-by-step approach that gives Americans confidence that reform is being done the right way.

Title: MIT Media Lab Director Resigns Amid Scrutiny Over Ties to Jeffrey Epstein

The director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's (MIT) Media Lab, Joi Ito, has resigned from his position, effective immediately. The decision comes after an article in The New Yorker revealed the measures taken by the media lab to conceal its relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, a financier accused of sex trafficking.

According to internal emails shared with The New York Times, the media lab received a $2 million gift from Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, which was described as being "directed by Jeffrey Epstein" in an email from October 2014. However, a development official at the media lab, Peter Cohen, wrote in a subsequent email that the gift would not be attributed to Epstein for "gift recording purposes."

A spokesperson for Bill Gates denied any business partnership or personal relationship between him and Epstein, stating that any claim of a directed grant or programmatic partnership is "completely false." Gates was introduced to Epstein as someone interested in increasing philanthropy, but Epstein's aggressive pursuit of Gates led to no such partnership.

This development is part of a broader scrutiny of high-profile individuals who have been linked to Epstein. Other notable figures, including President Trump, former President Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, and business executives Leslie Wexner and Leon Black, have faced questions about their connections to Epstein. Former Labor Secretary R. Alexander Acosta, who was involved in the 2008 plea agreement with Epstein, stepped down from his position amid criticism of the deal.

Title: COVID-19 Patients Face Increased Risk of Mental Health Issues Due to Isolation and Loneliness

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in hospitalizations, with many patients experiencing life-threatening complications. However, a lesser-known consequence of this crisis is the mental health toll it takes on patients, particularly those who are isolated from their loved ones. According to medical experts, the stress, loneliness, and fear experienced by patients during their hospitalization can increase their risk of developing mental health disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Hospitals have implemented measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including restricting visitors, which can exacerbate the sense of loneliness and isolation for patients. This can be particularly challenging for patients who are already dealing with the uncertainty and fear of their illness. Dr. Ami Rokach, a clinical psychologist, notes that loneliness can have a significant impact on both physical and mental health, comparable to the effects of smoking, obesity, and diabetes.

While some experts suggest that the increased use of communication technology may help mitigate the broader impact of the pandemic on loneliness, the situation is different for COVID-19 patients. The prolonged treatment process, often without the support of loved ones, can be "heart-wrenching" for patients, according to Dr. Martha A.Q. Curley, a professor of pediatric nursing.

The risk of PTSD is higher for COVID-19 patients, particularly those who have experienced traumatic events or feel threatened by the disease. Dr. Anthony King, a professor of psychiatry and psychology, notes that the coronavirus is a threat to life, which can increase the likelihood of PTSD. Long-term studies have shown that PTSD is more common in patients who have experienced serious illnesses, including those with COVID-19.

Experts agree that more research is needed to understand the full extent of the mental health impact of the pandemic on patients. However, some are advocating for changes to hospital policies to allow patients to have a support person with them during their treatment. Dr. Curley suggests that family facilitators can help with the careful screening, preparation, and support needed to make this possible.

In conclusion, the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of addressing the mental health needs of patients, particularly those who are isolated and alone. By acknowledging the risks of PTSD and loneliness, healthcare providers can take steps to support patients and their families, ultimately improving their overall well-being.

Title: Hillary Clinton Declared Winner of Democratic Presidential Primaries, Bernie Sanders Campaign Disputes Results

Article:

The Associated Press has announced that Hillary Clinton has secured the necessary 2,383 delegates to clinch the Democratic presidential nomination, with superdelegates putting her over the top before Tuesday's primaries even begin. Clinton urged voters to head to the polls in the six states set to vote on Tuesday, including California, stating that the party will come out of the primary "even stronger to take on Donald Trump."

However, Bernie Sanders' campaign is disputing the results, claiming that it is wrong to count the votes of superdelegates before they actually vote at the convention this summer. Sanders' spokesperson Michael Briggs stated that Clinton does not have and will not have the requisite number of pledged delegates to secure the nomination. The superdelegates will not actually vote until July 25, and Sanders plans to spend the time until then convincing them that he is the stronger candidate.

Despite being on the verge of being eliminated from the race, Sanders has had a lasting impact on the Democratic Party, pushing the party left on economic issues and attempting to change the party's platform on Israel. Sanders has already named pro-Palestinian representatives to the platform committee, including those who support the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement, which aims to delegitimize the Jewish state. Pro-Israel Democrats have expressed concerns that these changes in the party's platform would be "dead on arrival."

A recent Pew Research Center analysis shows that for the first time in a decade, the percentage of liberal Democrats sympathizing with Palestinians is greater than those aligning with Israel. This division could lead to a fight at the Democratic National Convention to determine where the party's support lies. Even if that doesn't happen, the split could be an indication that the Democrats may be moving toward more support for Palestinians and possibly less for Israel in the future.

**Australia Wildfires: Thousands Flee as Apocalyptic Conditions Unfold**

Wildfires burning across Australia's two most populous states, New South Wales and Victoria, have trapped residents of a seaside town in apocalyptic conditions, causing at least two fatalities and feared to have destroyed many properties. The fires, which started in September, have burned over 5 million hectares of land, with 12 people confirmed dead and more than 1,000 homes destroyed.

The town of Mallacoota in Victoria state was evacuated on Tuesday, with residents fleeing towards the water as winds pushed an emergency-level wildfire towards their homes. The smoke-filled sky turned the town's sky a bright red, leaving residents in a state of panic.

The Australian wildfire season, which peaks during the Southern Hemisphere summer, started early due to an unusually warm and dry winter. Record-breaking heat and windy conditions triggered devastating wildfires in New South Wales and Queensland states in September.

New South Wales state Rural Fire Services Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons described the current situation as the worst on record, with no relief in sight. "We've seen extraordinary fire behavior," he said. "What we really need is meaningful rain, and we haven't got anything in the forecast at the moment that says we're going to get drought-breaking or fire-quenching rainfall."

The wildfire crisis has reignited debate about whether Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government has taken enough action on climate change. Australia is the world's largest exporter of coal and liquefied natural gas. Morrison has acknowledged that climate change has contributed to the wildfires, but critics have accused him of not doing enough to address the issue.

The Australian military has sent air and sea reinforcements to assist in the firefighting efforts, while 70 firefighters from the United States and Canada have been requested to help. The country's Prime Minister has apologized for going on a family vacation to Hawaii during the crisis.

As the situation continues to unfold, authorities have warned of significant property losses across the region, with more than 115 communities in Victoria under emergency warnings. The city of Sydney's New Year's Eve fireworks display went ahead, despite concerns about sparking new wildfires.

Title: Biden and Ryan Face Off in Vice Presidential Debate

The highly anticipated vice presidential debate between Vice President Joe Biden and Representative Paul Ryan is set to take place tonight in Danville, Kentucky. The stakes are high, with Biden facing pressure to rebound from his boss's lackluster performance in the previous presidential debate, which gave the Republican ticket a national polling lead. Republicans believe Ryan's intellectual firepower will make Biden look foolish, while Democrats see the Wisconsin congressman as a two-faced politician who will be exposed by Biden's preparedness.

Vice presidential debates are often quickly forgotten, but this one is expected to be widely watched and set the stage for the second presidential debate on Tuesday in New York. The debate will likely focus on substantive issues, with both candidates having a strong background in their respective fields. Biden, a 36-year Senate veteran, will aim to clarify the differences between the two parties' policies, while Ryan, the House Budget Committee chairman, will emphasize the Republican ticket's plans.

Republicans hope that Biden will make a gaffe that will undo his efforts, while Democrats believe Ryan's lack of experience in a campaign debate will be exposed. Ryan will need to show he has "gravitas" and can present his positions well, while Biden will aim to use his storytelling skills to connect with voters. The debate will be a strong contrast between the two candidates' styles, with Biden's "straight-talking, tell-it-like-it-is" approach facing off against Ryan's more analytical, wonkish style.

The debate will be closely watched, with many expecting it to be a key moment in the campaign. While some predict a close race, others believe Biden's experience and preparation will give him an edge. Regardless, the debate will provide insight into the two candidates' views on key issues and their ability to present their positions effectively.

Title: Ukraine Confronts New Front as Pro-Russia Rebels Launch Powerful Offensive

Article:

Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko held an emergency security session on Wednesday as pro-Russia rebels launched a new offensive in eastern Ukraine. The new front comes amid increasing accusations and evidence of Russian military forces being directly involved in the conflict. The town of Novoazovsk, located in southern Ukraine between Russia and the annexed Crimea Peninsula, had earlier escaped the violence that has swept over parts of the country. However, only a few hours after a landmark meeting between the Russian and Ukrainian presidents late Tuesday, shelling began in the town, and pro-Russian rebels drove Ukrainian forces out of the town on Wednesday.

The new southeastern front raised fears that the separatists are seeking to create a land link between Russia and Crimea. If successful, it could give them or Russia control over the entire Sea of Azov and the gas and mineral riches that energy experts believe it contains. Ukraine has already lost roughly half its coastline, several major ports, and significant Black Sea mineral rights in March when Russia annexed Crimea.

The BBC reports that the incursion could be used as a way to divert Ukrainian troops from Luhansk and Donetsk, where they have made headway against pro-Russian separatists in recent months. Ukraine accused Russia this week of sending heavy weaponry into southern Ukraine to aid pro-Russian rebels. National security spokesman Col. Andriy Lysenko said Russian soldiers crossed as far as 30 miles beyond the border in armored personnel carriers and a truck this week.

The prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic acknowledged that there are Russian servicemen fighting alongside pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. Alexander Zakharchenko claims there are between 3,000 and 4,000 Russian volunteers fighting with the rebels. Some of these individuals are retired Russian military, Zakharchenko said in a televised statement on Russia 24, a state-run station.

Accusations of direct Russian involvement in Ukraine have prompted Western governments to implement sanctions against Russia, despite Moscow's repeated denials. Russia refers to the crisis in Ukraine as a national issue that must be resolved internally. The Obama administration this week accused Russia of moving artillery and air defenses to help pro-Russia separatists in Ukraine. "These incursions indicate a Russian-directed counteroffensive is likely underway," said Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman.

International leaders from France to Germany to NATO officials have expressed alarm. "I think there's a shift here that we may be witnessing, very recently, from largely covert, ambiguous, deniable support to what appears increasingly to be flat-out, overt and obvious [support] and with the only form of ambiguity being that the Russians... claim it is not happening," a NATO diplomat told reporters in Brussels on the condition of anonymity.

NATO officials are expected to give a briefing today on the situation in Ukraine. French President François Hollande said this week that if Russian soldiers are in Ukraine, "it would be intolerable and unacceptable." German Chancellor Angela Merkel called Russian President Vladimir Putin for clarification on the Kremlin's involvement. "The latest reports of the presence of Russian soldiers on Ukrainian territory must be explained," Merkel spokesman Steffen Seibert said of the call. "She [Merkel] emphasized Russia's major responsibility for de-escalation and watching over its own frontiers."

A report by the UN found that the death toll in eastern Ukraine over the past month grew to at least 36 people killed each day. An estimated 2,200 people have died since the conflict began in April, according to the UN.

Title: Obama's Struggles in the 2012 Presidential Election

The 2012 presidential election is heating up, with President Barack Obama facing stiff competition from his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney. Despite a dire slate of polls showing Obama's approval ratings in decline, the race remains tied, with many voters expressing dissatisfaction with both candidates.

According to a recent poll, 57% of likely voters believe America is a civilization in decline, and 53% believe the country has changed for the worse over the past few years. Obama's approval ratings on his overall job performance and handling of the economy are also underwhelming, with a 12-point deficit on the economy, the number one issue this year.

The poll also reveals that respondents are more likely to believe the federal government should leave them alone rather than lend a hand, with a 20-point margin in favor of non-intervention. When asked if Obama wants to make Americans more dependent on the government, 53% said yes, while only 44% said no.

Despite these challenges, Obama's campaign has focused on defining Romney as a big-government liberal, which may not be a winning strategy in swing-state America. However, Romney's own campaign has struggled to connect with voters, with 10% of respondents saying they are undecided or reject the major party choices.

The election is now just 74 days away, and Obama's team is trying to ring alarm bells for Democrats, who are concerned about voter intensity and turnout. Romney, on the other hand, is reintroducing himself to a skeptical electorate through his selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate and a recent op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, in which he shared his 25-year career as a corporate turnaround artist.

The next week will be crucial for Romney, as he seeks to make the most of his final phase of campaigning. If he can successfully reintroduce himself to voters and emphasize his competency, accomplishment, and steadiness, he may be able to capitalize on Obama's struggles and secure a narrow victory.

**Philippines Impounds North Korean Freight Ship Amid Escalating Tensions**

The Philippines has impounded a North Korean freighter, the Jin Teng, in Subic Bay, and plans to deport its 15-member crew. The move comes as a response to North Korea's recent nuclear test and missile launch, which have been widely condemned by the international community.

The impounded ship, operated by Ocean Maritime Management, is one of 31 vessels named in a United Nations resolution as being subject to an asset freeze. The Jin Teng arrived in Subic Bay on Thursday, carrying a cargo of palm kernels from Indonesia.

The Philippine government has also found minor safety violations on the ship, including faulty emergency light bulbs, a lack of fire hoses, corroded air vents, and inadequate accommodations for the crew.
