A team from the United Nations may inspect the Jin Teng, according to Philippine presidential spokesman Manuel Quezon III. The Philippine government will report its findings to the UN.

The impounding of the ship is part of a broader effort by the international community to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear ambitions. The UN Security Council has imposed new sanctions on North Korea, including a ban on the country's textile exports and a cap on its imports of refined petroleum products.

Despite the sanctions, North Korea has continued to engage in provocative behavior, including a recent nuclear test and missile launch. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has vowed to strengthen the country's nuclear capabilities, saying that the country needs to be prepared to use its nuclear warheads at any time.

The international community remains concerned about North Korea's nuclear ambitions, as well as its ability to develop missiles that could strike targets around East Asia and beyond. While some experts believe that North Korea's boasts about its military capabilities are largely bluster, others worry that the country may be closer to developing a nuclear weapon than previously thought.

Title: Former President Obama's Speaking Fees Spark Controversy Amidst Secrecy Surrounding Milan Climate Change Address

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has faced criticism and scrutiny over his speaking fees, with some estimates suggesting he may have earned up to $3.2 million for a recent climate change address in Milan. The exact amount, however, remains unclear, as neither Obama's team nor the hosting organization, Seeds & Chips, has disclosed the fee. The secrecy surrounding the payment has sparked wild speculation and raised questions about Obama's potential payday.

Obama's speaking fees have been a topic of discussion in recent weeks, with the former president reportedly earning $400,000 for two separate speeches. The first was at a Wall Street conference run by Cantor Fitzgerald, and the second was at an A&E Networks advertising upfront at The Pierre Hotel in New York City. While Obama's speaking fees are not uncommon for a former president, some critics have raised concerns about the potential for his tax-exempt Obama Foundation to be used as a money generator.

The Obama Foundation is intended to raise money for his presidential library, but critics have compared it to the Clinton Foundation, which took in tens of millions of dollars and sparked "pay-to-play" accusations. In an effort to avoid similar comparisons, Obama announced in January that he would not accept contributions from for-profit entities, federal lobbyists, or foreign nationals or agents while in office.

It's worth noting that Obama's speaking fees are not unique to him. Other former presidents, such as Gerald Ford, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush, have also earned significant sums for their speaking engagements. Ford earned up to $40,000 per speech after leaving office in 1977, while Clinton reportedly earned $750,000 for a single talk in Hong Kong in 2011. Bush has made between $20 million and $35 million in speaking fees since leaving office in 2009.

Despite the controversy surrounding his speaking fees, Obama's team maintains that he will continue to give the occasional speech, but will focus most of his time on writing his book and training a new generation of political leaders in America.

Title: Reid Insists on Running for Reelection in 2016, Despite Republican Opposition

Article:

Harry Reid, the 73-year-old majority leader, has announced his intention to run for reelection in 2016, despite being a target for Republicans due to his inflammatory rhetoric and hardball tactics during the government shutdown. Reid has been seeking commitments from aides to stay with him through 2016 and is ramping up his campaign organization. He has also been spending more time fundraising, with his campaign and political action committee account raising over $600,000 in the third quarter.

Reid's strategy has been to keep Democrats together, which has been a difficult task. However, removing him from his spot as majority leader has become a leading Republican campaign pitch in the run-up to the 2014 midterms. Republicans are eager to take him down, and Reid knows it.

Reid has been accused of being a polarizing figure due to his pugnacious stand during the shutdown fight. His strategy has kept Democrats together, but it has also made him a target for Republicans. He has been ridiculed for his constant derision of the Republican Party, using words like "extreme" and "anarchists" to describe conservative Republicans in the House and Senate.

Reid has also been accused of refusing to schedule votes on House GOP bills to fund popular agencies and programs one at a time, and has refused to negotiate with Republicans until they agree to pass a Senate bill to keep the government open until mid-November. This has led to Republicans wanting to "tear their hair out."

Despite the opposition, Reid remains confident about Democrats' prospects in 2014 and believes the Republicans' handling of the government shutdown has only made them weaker. He has raised over $5.5 million in the third quarter, more than he did in the same period in 2010.

Title: US Economy Adds 288,000 Jobs in April, Unemployment Rate Falls to 6.3%

The US labor market continues to recover from the financial crisis, with the economy adding 288,000 jobs in April, the strongest month for job growth in two years. The unemployment rate fell to 6.3%, down from 6.7% in March, according to the Department of Labor. While this news is a positive sign, economists caution that the labor market remains far from fully healed.

The jobs report showed that the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since September 2008, but the participation rate, which measures the percentage of Americans working or actively looking for work, declined. This could indicate that fewer young people are entering the job market for the first time, and more seniors are retiring and staying that way.

Economists note that the employment data can fluctuate from month to month, and while this month's report is above expectations, it is still consistent with recent trends. The jobs recovery has dragged on for four years, and long-term unemployment remains elevated, with 3.5 million people out of a job for six months or more.

Despite this, the recovery is now broad-based across many industries. Professional and business services added 75,000 jobs in April, and retail, restaurants, and bars, as well as blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction, are showing signs of growth. The only major sector cutting jobs is the federal government, which slashed 83,000 positions over the last 12 months.

While the jobs recovery is slow and uneven, economists estimate it could take at least another two years until the job market returns to its pre-recession health.

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Weighs in on Hillary Clinton's Potential Presidential Bid and Foreign Policy Expertise

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, a prominent Democratic Party figure, recently discussed Hillary Clinton's potential presidential bid and her qualifications on the "State of the Union" program. While not an official endorsement, Feinstein praised Clinton's leadership abilities and foreign policy expertise, stating that if she were to win the presidency, America would have a top foreign policy expert in the White House.

Feinstein's comments came in response to recent remarks by Karl Rove, a Republican strategist, questioning Clinton's cognitive abilities. Feinstein deemed Rove's comments "pathetic" and unnecessary, emphasizing that Clinton is in the prime of her political life and has the qualities of a good leader. She also highlighted Clinton's upcoming book, which is expected to provide insight into her foreign policy thinking.

Feinstein noted that having a president with a strong background in foreign policy is crucial in today's complex global landscape, citing the challenges posed by Russia's expansion and terrorism in Africa. She believes that Clinton's experience as Secretary of State would be a significant asset in the White House, allowing her to effectively address these pressing issues.

Title: Testimony Highlights Tensions and Allegations Surrounding Ukraine and Russia

The testimony of several officials and experts has shed light on the complex and often contentious issues surrounding Ukraine and Russia. The testimony, which took place in 2019, focused on the priorities of security, economy, and justice, as well as the support for Ukrainian democratic resistance to Russian aggression.

According to the testimony, the situation at the embassy and in Ukraine changed dramatically in March 2019, with former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani and a group of officials promoting a political agenda with a direct channel to the White House. This agenda allegedly overshadowed the original priorities and created tension among officials.

Some officials have questioned the notion that Russia was behind the 2016 election interference, instead pointing to Ukraine as the aggressor. However, the testimony suggests that this narrative is false and perpetuated by Russian security services.

The testimony also touched on the hold on security assistance to Ukraine and the efforts of Giuliani to promote investigations into the 2016 election. One official described Giuliani's actions as "explosive" and "incendiary," stating that he was pushing forward ideas that would likely come back to haunt the country.

The testimony also highlighted the personal experiences of some officials, including a "blowup" between a witness and Ambassador Gordon Sondland, as well as allegations of dual loyalty against Colonel Vindman. The witness described these accusations as "deeply unfair" and "unfair."

The testimony also touched on the role of Ambassador Bolton, who described Giuliani as a "hand grenade" due to his efforts to promote investigations into the 2016 election. The witness interpreted this as Bolton's warning that Giuliani's narrative would backfire.

The testimony concluded with a call to action, urging the American people to make their voices heard in the 2020 presidential election and to stand together against the alleged attempts to undermine the democratic process.

Title: YouTube Invests in TYT Academy to Promote Digital-First Local News Creation

The Young Turks (TYT), a prominent progressive digital publisher on YouTube, has received a significant investment from Google-owned YouTube to launch an online course called TYT Academy. The course focuses on creating digital-first local news and is part of YouTube's $25 million commitment to news efforts, which is part of the $300 million Google News Initiative announced in 2018.

TYT Academy features a two-track video series, with each track containing eight videos. Participants will take short quizzes along the way and must pass a final exam to earn a TYT Academy certificate. The course covers journalism tactics and responsibilities, as well as best practices for online video production across various platforms.

The goal of the class is to engage everyday people in digital media, enabling them to report on their local communities. TYT plans to expand the program after testing it with 10-15 people. While TYT takes a strong progressive stance as an outlet, Steven Oh, TYT's Chief Business Officer and the creator of TYT Academy, emphasized that the course is not intended to produce journalists who share TYT's political viewpoint.

This initiative is not unique to YouTube, as Facebook has also invested in online news courses from publishers. In December, Facebook funded an online deepfakes course for newsrooms by Reuters. The videos for TYT Academy, which have been online for about two months, appear to be nonpartisan. However, it is notable that YouTube is investing in a course from TYT, which has a progressive bent.

The investment is part of YouTube's efforts to promote high-quality news and journalism, and TYT's expertise in digital-first news production makes it a logical fit for this type of investment.

Title: Idaho Wedding Chapel Owners Face Threat of Jail Time and Fines for Refusing to Perform Same-Sex Weddings

Article:

Two Christian ministers, Donald and Evelyn Knapp, who own the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, are facing the threat of jail time and up to a $1,000 fine for refusing to perform same-sex weddings. The chapel is registered as a "religious corporation" limited to performing "one-man-one-woman marriages as defined by the Holy Bible." However, the chapel is also registered as a for-profit business, which city officials claim makes it subject to a local nondiscrimination ordinance.

The ordinance, passed last year, prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation and applies to housing, employment, and public accommodation. City Attorney Warren Wilson told The Spokesman-Review that the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel likely would be required to follow the ordinance. Wilson also stated that any wedding chapel that turns away a gay couple would be violating the law and could face a potential misdemeanor citation.

The Knapps' lawyer, Jeremy Tedesco, said that the couple is at risk of being prosecuted and is in a "constant state of fear" that they may have to go to jail, pay substantial fines, or both. The Alliance Defending Freedom, which is representing the Knapps, filed a lawsuit against the city and a temporary restraining order to stop the city from enforcing the ordinance.

The lawsuit claims that the city is on "seriously flawed legal ground" and that the Knapps' freedom to adhere to their faith as pastors is being threatened. The city's actions are seen as a threat to the First Amendment's protection of religious freedom.

This incident is not an isolated one, as the city of Houston recently issued subpoenas demanding that five Christian pastors turn over sermons dealing with homosexuality and gender identity. The trend of government officials using their power to punish those who oppose the advances of homosexual activists is a growing concern, according to Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council.

The Knapps' situation highlights the tension between religious freedom and the push for same-sex marriage. The incident raises questions about whether religious leaders should be forced to perform and celebrate marriages that conflict with their beliefs.

Title: Nancy Reagan Dies at 94: A Life of Devotion and Devotion to Her Husband and Country

Nancy Reagan, the wife of the 40th President of the United States, Ronald Reagan, has passed away at the age of 94. As a devoted partner and confidant, she played a significant role in her husband's career and presidency. The couple's love story has been a part of the presidential narrative, with Reagan biographer Craig Shirley describing them as "best friends and soul mates."

Throughout her life, Nancy Reagan was a fierce guardian of her husband's image, often at the expense of her own. During his rise from Hollywood actor to governor of California and eventually the White House, she was a trusted adviser. Her presence was a driving force behind Ronald Reagan's relentless and successful political career.

When Ronald Reagan was diagnosed with Alzheimer's in 1994, Nancy became his primary caretaker until his death in 2004. Throughout that time, she remained a guardian of his legacy.

The tributes poured in from politicians and public figures across the country, with many praising her as an example of integrity, loyalty, and dignity. Her passing serves as a reminder of the importance of her role in American history and her devotion to her husband and country.

Nancy Reagan's life was marked by her unwavering support for her husband and her dedication to her duties as First Lady. Her legacy will be remembered as a testament to the power of love, loyalty, and devotion.

Title: Democrats Promote Equal Pay for Women, Despite Data Showing Inconsistencies

Article:

The Democratic Party made a big show of promoting equal pay for women on Tuesday, declaring it National Equal Pay Day. The symbolic measure highlights how far along the yearly calendar a woman needs to work to earn as much as her male counterpart did the year before. According to President Obama, the wage gap puts women at a career-long disadvantage and harms families, communities, and the economy.

However, data shows that the White House itself has a history of paying female staffers less than men. An analysis of White House salaries in July 2015 revealed a 13% pay gap between male and female staffers. This inconsistency has sparked criticism of the administration's commitment to pay equity.

Leading presidential contender Hillary Rodham Clinton has faced similar scrutiny. While she has been an original sponsor of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, which expanded workers' rights to take pay discrimination cases to court, her own office has been criticized for paying women 72 cents for every dollar paid to men during her time in the U.S. Senate. The median annual salary for female staffers was $15,708.38 less than the median salary for men between 2002 and 2008, a gender gap of 28%.

The Democratic National Committee has taken aim at Republican presidential candidates, accusing them of downplaying the importance of pay equity or enacting policies unfavorable to female workers. The committee has also introduced the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would allow employees to share information about their pay and file lawsuits against an employer.

On the other hand, a coalition of four Republican senators has offered an amendment to the bill that would prohibit retaliation against employees for discussing salaries and provide grants to states to create industry-led partnerships to address disparities of opportunity.

Title: House Approves Syrian Refugees Bill with Near Unanimous Support

The House of Representatives has passed a bill aimed at blocking Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the country unless they undergo strict background checks. The bill, which was written by Republicans, received near unanimous support from Republicans and 47 votes from Democrats.

The bill, known as the American Security Against Foreign Enemies Act, would require the FBI, Homeland Security Department, and director of national intelligence to certify to Congress that any refugee from Syria or Iraq is "not a threat to the security of the United States" before being allowed to settle in the United States.

The bill's passage was a significant loss for the White House, which had urged lawmakers to reject the measure. The vote was also seen as a rebuke of President Barack Obama's plan to allow 10,000 Syrian refugees to enter the country this year.

The bill's supporters, including many Democrats, argued that the current vetting process is insufficient and that additional measures are needed to ensure national security. "I think a lot of us went in with open minds and really wanted to understand the administration's position on this," said Rep. Sean Patrick Maloney (D-N.Y.). "It is offensive to me that we would stigmatize refugees...but if you read the bill, what you find is that you have a pretty simple certification process sitting on top of an existing and extensive screening process that most of us believe works pretty well."

However, some Democrats opposed the bill, citing concerns that it would stigmatize refugees and undermine the country's humanitarian efforts. "The process that is currently in place is thorough and robust and long as it is fully implemented and not diluted...it will allow us to safely admit the most vulnerable refugees while protecting the American people," said Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.).

The bill now faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) has pledged that it will not make it to President Obama's desk.

Title: John Kasich's 2016 Presidential Campaign: A Flickering Flame

John Kasich's 2016 presidential campaign, while not particularly successful, drew comparisons to former Utah Governor Jon Huntsman's failed bid for the Republican nomination in 2012. Both Huntsman and Kasich shared a campaign architect, John Weaver, a GOP strategist known for his unconventional approach. While Kasich's campaign managed to secure a distant second place in the New Hampshire primary, it failed to gain momentum and ultimately ended with fewer delegates than Senator Marco Rubio, who dropped out on March 15.

Kasich's campaign focused on portraying himself as a reasonable alternative to Trump, emphasizing his conservative credentials and ability to win swing states like Ohio. His policy platform centered around advocating for a balanced-budget amendment, a promise tied to his work on balancing the national budget during his time in the U.S. House in the 1990s. However, some of his policy stances were at odds with the Republican Party, including his decision to accept Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act as governor, which he justified by citing his Christian faith.

Kasich's image as a soft, cuddly, and friendly politician was met with skepticism by many of his former colleagues, who remembered a more irritable and angry Kasich. Unfortunately, Republican primary voters in 2016 were not looking for a sane and rational nominee; they wanted a Trump.

Title: Obama Administration Faces Challenge in Meeting Obamacare Enrollment Targets

The Obama administration is facing a significant challenge in meeting its target of enrolling 21 million people in Obamacare exchange plans by next year. As of June, the Department of Health and Human Services counted 9.9 million customers who have purchased plans through the federal HealthCare.gov portal and state-run exchanges. While this puts the administration ahead of its own estimates for 2015, it is still short of the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) projection of 12 million for 2016.

Industry analysts consider the CBO's estimate to be "overly optimistic" and a "stretch," citing the need for more time for the law to attract more people to the Web-based markets. The administration is counting on winning over millions of customers who did not sign up in the first two years but may be pressured by the increasing pain of the "individual mandate" tax assessed on those who forgo health insurance.

The individual mandate, included in the Affordable Care Act of 2010, was designed to ensure enough healthy Americans signed up, spreading out the costs for higher-risk customers. The penalty for not having insurance will increase next year, from $325 or 2% of income to $695 or 2.5% of income. This increase may be a "big wild card" in determining how effective the penalties will be in nudging people to get insured.

The marketplaces are working, but higher enrollment would improve the insurance risk pool and reduce the number of Americans uninsured. Congressional Republicans are still intent on scrapping the health care law, and may use a fast-track budget procedure known as "reconciliation" to take a swing at it. Repealing the individual mandate is "definitely on the table," said Brendan Buck, a spokesman for House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Rep. Paul Ryan.

Despite struggling to meet the 2016 enrollment projection, the Obama administration is on track on other measures, including a CBO estimate that 17 million fewer people lack insurance this year because of the health care law. The administration has set its own, more modest goals for exchange enrollment, ignoring the CBO's guess of 12 million for 2015 and setting the mark at 9.1 million enrollees.

Title: Obama's Plan to Normalize Relations with Cuba Hits Roadblock on Capitol Hill

Article:

President Barack Obama's plan to normalize relations with Cuba has faced opposition from Republicans on Capitol Hill. Just hours after Obama announced a prisoner swap with the Cuban government for two Americans, Republicans began discussing ways to block any changes to the U.S.-Cuba relationship. Their ideas include denying funds to reopen an embassy in Havana, stalling the nomination of a potential ambassador, voting down a bill to open up travel more widely, and ignoring requests from the White House to lift a decades-old embargo.

When Republicans take control of the Senate next year, they will have the power to block presidential nominations and potentially stall or reverse some of Obama's plans. Several influential Republicans, including Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, have already spoken out against the move, citing concerns about national security and the potential for increased cooperation with the Cuban government.

Obama has called on Congress to pass legislation to lift the 50-year embargo against goods and travel to Cuba, which was imposed by President John F. Kennedy. However, Speaker John Boehner has stated that he will not allow any changes to Cuban-U.S. relations to be revisited in the House, citing concerns about human rights and democracy in Cuba.

Some Republicans have also questioned whether the Obama administration has the legal authority to roll back some travel restrictions and allow increased numbers of Cuban cigars to be brought into the U.S. Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen has stated that any action by Obama may be in direct violation of the Helms-Burton Act, which requires the release of political prisoners and free and fair elections before establishing a diplomatic relationship.

Democrats were mixed in their response to Obama's plans, with Senator Robert Menendez criticizing the proposals and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi hailing the "new chapter" in U.S.-Cuba relations.

Title: Obamacare's Impact on the Federal Budget: A Complex and Uncertain Picture

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of intense debate since its passage in 2010. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) initially estimated that the law would reduce deficits by more than $100 billion in the first decade and by half a percent of economic growth in the second decade. However, the CBO also noted that the law's deficit-reduction potential could be diminished by changes made to the law over time.

Since its passage, several changes have been made, and more are being proposed, which could impact the law's deficit-reduction potential. For example, there is a push to repeal the medical device tax, which is expected to raise about $30 billion over the next decade. Additionally, there are concerns that Congress may struggle to adhere to cost containment provisions in the law.

The Government Accountability Office (GAO) conducted a long-range simulation that included assumptions about the broader budget and found that deficits would increase by 0.7% of GDP over the next 75 years if key provisions are phased out or not implemented. This would be largely due to increased spending on Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program, and subsidies offered on health insurance exchanges.

The impact of Obamacare on the federal budget is complex and uncertain, with some experts predicting that it will reduce deficits and others arguing that it will increase them. The CBO and economists believe that part of the slowing growth in national health spending is attributable to the ACA, but it is unclear how much. The growth rate is expected to rise in the next few years as more people become insured under Obamacare.

The future of Obamacare remains uncertain, with many factors still to be determined. The new health insurance exchanges are expected to draw a diverse pool of enrollees and generate enough competition to provide affordable health care for most Americans. However, the law's success is also dependent on hospitals, doctors, and insurance companies making changes to slow cost growth and shift to a value-based health care system.

In conclusion, the impact of Obamacare on the federal budget is a complex and uncertain picture, with many factors still to be determined. While some experts predict that it will reduce deficits, others argue that it will increase them. The future of the law and its impact on the federal budget will depend on a variety of factors, including the success of the health insurance exchanges and the ability of hospitals, doctors, and insurance companies to slow cost growth.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Calls for Roy Moore to Step Aside Amidst Allegations of Inappropriate Behavior

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has called for Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore to step aside amid allegations of inappropriate behavior with teenage girls. Moore has been under growing pressure from Republicans to drop out of the Senate race after The Washington Post published a story detailing accounts from four women who said Moore pursued relationships with them when they were between 16 and 18 years old.

McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, said during a tax reform press conference in Louisville, "I believe the women." The Post's story detailed an account from Leigh Corfman, now 53, who said she had a sexual encounter with Moore in 1979, when she was 14 years old and he was 32.

Moore has denied the allegations, saying he does not remember anything like that and maintained that there was no inappropriate sexual behavior. However, several Republican senators have called on Moore to step aside, including Orrin Hatch and Susan Collins.

Gardner, the chair of the Senate GOP campaign arm, went further, saying that if Moore wins the special election, the Senate should vote to expel him, as he does not meet the ethical and moral requirements of the United States Senate.

Despite the growing pressure, Alabama Republicans have publicly defended Moore and warned that if he left the race, it would hand the Senate seat to Democratic candidate Doug Jones. The Alabama Republican Party Chairwoman Terry Lathan also pushed back against a write-in campaign, saying it would be a serious error for any current elected GOP official or candidate to publicly endorse another party's candidate.

Moore has used the blowback from Republican lawmakers in his fundraising appeals, saying that "establishment Republicans are colluding with the Obama-Clinton Machine."

Title: Obama's ISIS Assessment Criticized After Paris Attacks

Article:

In the aftermath of the November 2015 Paris attacks, which resulted in over 100 deaths, former US President Barack Obama stated that ISIS was "contained." However, this assessment was met with criticism from some quarters. Despite the attacks, some liberals argued that the violence was a sign of ISIS's desperation to gain attention.

Earlier in the year, Obama had described ISIS as a "junior varsity" team, and later, during the Democratic primary debate, Bernie Sanders echoed this sentiment, stating that global warming was the greatest threat to humanity and the root cause of terrorism in the Middle East. Meanwhile, Martin O'Malley expressed his intention to bring in 60,000 Syrian refugees, despite concerns about potential security risks.

The White House Deputy National Security Advisor has confirmed that the refugee resettlement program will continue as planned. The Republican Party has historically struggled to win domestic policy elections, but when it comes to foreign policy, the American people tend to prioritize a strong stance against terrorism.

Hillary Clinton, the former Secretary of State, has also faced criticism for her stance on ISIS. During the Democratic primary debate, she stated that the group cannot be contained and must be defeated, while also emphasizing that it cannot be an American fight. However, she also suggested that the United States does not have the primary responsibility to address the issue, and instead placed the burden on Syria's dictator, Bashar Assad, and other regional leaders.

The article concludes that the Republican Party has historically struggled to win domestic policy elections, but when it comes to foreign policy, the American people prioritize a strong stance against terrorism.

Title: Women in Congress Reach Milestone, But Representation Still Lags Behind

The recent midterm elections in the United States have marked a significant milestone for women in American politics, with the number of women in Congress reaching 100 for the first time in the nation's history. While this achievement is a step forward, the total female representation still lags behind, with women making up only about 18.6% of the 535 members of Congress.

According to Debbie Walsh, director of the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University, women tend to enter politics because they want to solve a problem or address a policy issue, whereas men often run for office to pursue a political career. This difference in motivation can contribute to the lower number of women in leadership positions.

The article highlights the challenges women face in entering politics, including the need to raise vast sums of money, which can be more easily accomplished by well-connected men. Additionally, women tend to enter politics later in life, leaving less time to build power and recruit other women into the field.

The article also notes that women who do run for office tend to win at similar rates to men, and once in office, they tend to function more as consensus builders, often building bipartisan support for legislation. The article cites the example of Senator Susan Collins, who led a group of women senators to find a way out of the 2003 government shutdown.

The article also highlights several "firsts" for women in the recent elections, including the election of Joni Ernst, the first female combat veteran to the Senate, and Mia Love, the first black woman elected to Congress as a Republican. These milestones are seen as a step forward in breaking the pattern of inequality in American politics.

Overall, while the election results mark a significant milestone for women in Congress, the article argues that more needs to be done to increase representation and address the systemic barriers that prevent women from entering and succeeding in politics.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Book "What Happened" Falls Flat on All Fronts

Article:

Hillary Clinton's 512-page memoir, "What Happened", recounts her experience as a presidential candidate in the 2016 election. The book focuses on her interactions with Donald Trump, including an uncomfortable debate moment where he followed her closely and made faces. Clinton chose to keep her cool, unlike some might have done, and instead opted to "keep smiling and carry on".

The author of this article argues that Clinton's book fails to offer valuable insights, instead dwelling on her own experiences and emotions. The book also brings up David Foster Wallace's "This Is Water" speech, which Clinton uses to illustrate the problem of recognizing sexism. However, the author believes that Wallace's speech is misinterpreted by Clinton, who uses it to explain away her own problems rather than acknowledging her own role in them.

Throughout the book, Clinton's focus is on her own experiences and emotions, rather than the issues that affected the election. The author notes that Clinton's problems were largely self-made, and that she blames external factors such as sexism and misogyny for her failures. The book also includes cutesy stories and occasional eruptions of disdain towards those who didn't support her campaign.

The author concludes that Clinton's book is more about her own experiences and emotions than about the issues that affected the election. The book's focus on government and politics as a solution to every problem is also criticized. Overall, the author believes that Clinton's book is awkward and self-serving, and that it fails to offer valuable insights into the 2016 election.

Title: Debate Moderators' Biases Raise Questions About Fairness

Article:

The recent vice-presidential debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine was marked by a perceived bias in favor of the Democratic candidate, with moderator Elaine Quijano asking Pence significantly more questions than Kaine. According to an analysis by NewsDiffs, Quijano peppered Pence with tough questions, reserving only one for Kaine. The debate was criticized by some as being unfair and lacking in balance.

The New York Times acknowledged the bias, stating that Quijano "helped Mr. Kaine along" and "opened one question with a recitation of Mr. Trump's statements." However, the article later deleted the quote and eliminated any reference to the moderator in the story.

Despite the perceived bias, many in the media are admitting that Pence won the debate. Team Trump posted comments from various journalists, including Michael Barbaro and Chris Cillizza, who praised Pence's performance. Even MSNBC's Chris Matthews called Pence "eloquent," "excellent," and "looked like a grown-up."

CNN's Jake Tapper noted that the media's coverage of the debate would likely focus on Kaine's allegations that Pence couldn't defend his running mate's position. However, Tapper understated the case, as the mainstream media is likely to continue its bias against the Republican ticket.

Not all media outlets were as biased, with some, like Fusion, taking a more balanced approach. However, others, like Univision, were heavily biased in favor of Kaine. The debate's running commentary was also criticized for being childish and biased, with some outlets using GIFs and memes to make light of the debate.

Overall, the debate raised questions about the fairness and impartiality of the moderators and the media's coverage of the election.

Title: The Case for Increasing the Minimum Wage: A Policy with Both Benefits and Drawbacks

The idea of increasing the minimum wage is a popular concept that has been debated extensively in recent years. Proponents argue that it is a good way to help low-wage workers, address income inequality, and reduce poverty. The policy also has the advantage of being an off-budget mechanism, meaning it does not create a new welfare program or add to the national debt.

The minimum wage increase has been a topic of interest for both liberal elites and lawmakers, as it is seen as a way to fight for the rights of low-wage workers. However, conservatives have been hesitant to support the idea, citing concerns about job losses and the potential negative impact on employment.

Recently, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released an analysis concluding that a phased-in $10.10 minimum wage would have a modest but real disemployment effect. The CBO projected that at $10.10, the minimum wage would reduce employment by between a trivial amount and 1 million jobs by the end of 2016. This finding was met with enthusiasm from conservatives, who have long opposed any increase in the minimum wage.

Despite the CBO's findings, proponents of the minimum wage increase argue that it is a necessary step to address poverty and income inequality. According to the CBO, a $10.10 minimum wage would pull about twice as many people out of poverty (900,000) as it would leave without a job, and increase wages for nearly 20 times more people (16.5 million) than that.

Critics of the minimum wage increase argue that it would lead to job losses and reduced employment opportunities. However, proponents point out that a higher minimum wage would likely mitigate some of the consequences of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), as people who earn higher wages are less likely to quit their jobs and are more likely to slide up the ACA's means-tested benefit scale.

In conclusion, while the minimum wage increase has both benefits and drawbacks, the case for it remains strong. The policy has the potential to help low-wage workers, address income inequality, and reduce poverty, and its benefits outweigh its costs.

Title: Obama Proposes Community College Initiative and Cybersecurity Measures

The President has unveiled a new proposal to invest $60 billion over a decade in a community college initiative, as well as new tax credits aimed at the middle class. The plan includes a $500 credit for families with two working spouses, a subsidy of up to $2,500 annually to pay for college, and a tripling of an existing tax break to pay for college. The President emphasized the importance of addressing child care as a national economic priority.

The President also expressed his stance on the United States' approach to Cuba, stating that the current strategy of isolation has been ineffective and that it is time to try a new approach. He recognized Alan P. Gross, an American prisoner freed in December as part of the new détente, who mouthed "thank you" in response.

In his address, the President also touched on the topic of Iran, stating that the United States has an opportunity to strike a deal with the country to prevent the development of a nuclear weapon. He expressed opposition to legislation that would impose new sanctions before negotiations have been exhausted.

The President also addressed the issue of cybersecurity, calling for legislation to bolster protections against computer-enabled assaults. He emphasized the importance of protecting American networks, trade secrets, and family privacy, stating that if the country does not act, it will leave itself and its economy vulnerable to attacks.

Title: US Ambassador Haley Reiterates Trump Administration's Position on Syrian Chemical Attack

The United States Ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, reiterated the Trump administration's stance on the recent chemical weapons attack in Syria, stating that the US was "fully justified" in launching missile strikes against a Syrian airbase in response to the attack. The strike, which killed dozens of civilians, including children, was a response to the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government.

Haley emphasized that the responsibility for the use of chemical weapons falls not only on Syrian President Bashar Assad, but also on his allies, Iran and Russia. She suggested that Russia may be complicit in the situation, either through incompetence or complicity, as they were entrusted with ensuring the removal of chemical weapons from the war-torn country.

The US Ambassador also warned that the international community has failed to act collectively to address the situation, and that states may be compelled to take unilateral action when necessary. She noted that the indiscriminate use of chemical weapons against innocent civilians is one of those times.

Russia has condemned the US missile strikes and promised to bolster Syria's anti-aircraft defenses. The situation remains tense, with the US and Russia at odds over the use of force in Syria.

Title: Major Newspapers Break with Tradition, Endorse Hillary Clinton Over Donald Trump

In a rare move, several traditionally conservative newspaper editorial boards across the United States have rejected Donald Trump and instead endorsed Hillary Clinton for president. The Cincinnati Enquirer and The Arizona Republic, which had previously backed only Republican presidential candidates, are among the notable exceptions. Since making their endorsements, both papers have faced backlash from readers, with The Enquirer reporting "angry letters and subscription cancellations in the triple digits."

The Arizona Republic's editorial board stated that they had lost subscribers and received at least one death threat since publishing their endorsement. However, the paper's director, Phil Boas, emphasized that they are confident in their decision, saying, "We know we're doing the right thing."

The Dallas Morning News and USA Today are also among the major newspapers to break with tradition and endorse Clinton. The Morning News, which had not endorsed a Democrat since World War II, urged readers to back Clinton, stating that her mistakes are "plainly in a different universe" compared to Trump's values. USA Today, which had never endorsed a presidential candidate in its 34-year history, published a scathing editorial calling Trump "unfit for the presidency."

The endorsements are seen as a significant departure from the norm, with at least a dozen major American newspapers backing Clinton and none endorsing Trump. The backlash from Trump supporters is not surprising, as the candidate has made anti-media sentiment a central part of his campaign. Analysts suggest that the endorsements may not significantly impact the presidential race, but could influence voters considering third-party options.

David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Institute, noted that newspaper editorials may encourage voters to stick with one of the major party candidates rather than casting a protest vote. The endorsements are a testament to the importance of the media in shaping public opinion and holding politicians accountable.

Title: Congressional Democrats Push for Ban on Gun Sales to Terror Suspects

Article:

Congressional Democrats are attempting to build support for a bill that would prohibit the sale of firearms to individuals listed on the government's terrorist watchlists. The proposal aims to address concerns about national security and public safety, particularly in the wake of recent terrorist attacks in Paris. However, the measure is likely to face opposition from the National Rifle Association (NRA) and Republican lawmakers, who have consistently blocked gun control measures in the past.

The bill, introduced by Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), would require the Attorney General to compile a list of known and suspected terrorists and prohibit federally licensed gun dealers from selling firearms to individuals on that list. Currently, individuals on the government's terror watchlists are not automatically disqualified from purchasing weapons, although the FBI is notified when a background check generates a match with the watchlist.

The proposal has sparked debate, with some arguing that it would help prevent terrorist attacks, while others claim it would infringe on Second Amendment rights. The NRA has expressed opposition to the bill, citing concerns about the accuracy of the government's watchlists and the potential for innocent individuals to be mistakenly added to the lists.

The bill is not the only gun-related measure being considered by Democrats. Senator Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) has introduced a separate bill that would prohibit the sale of guns to foreigners from countries that do not require visas to visit the United States.

The debate surrounding the bill comes as Republicans are trying to capitalize on public anxiety about national security following the Paris attacks. Last week, the House passed a bill that would prevent Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the United States until the administration tightens restrictions on their entry. While some Democrats supported the bill, others opposed it, citing concerns about the impact on refugees and the effectiveness of the current screening process.

The prospects for the bill are uncertain, as it would require support from at least 60 senators to pass. Democrats have struggled to pass gun control measures in the past, despite having a majority in the Senate after the 2012 Newtown massacre. The bill's fate will likely depend on the willingness of Republicans to consider new gun control measures and the ability of Democrats to build a broad coalition of support.

Title: Senator McCain Questions Benghazi Investigation on Meet the Press

Senator John McCain appeared on NBC's Meet the Press, where he expressed concerns about the ongoing investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans. During the interview, McCain emphasized that there are still many unanswered questions surrounding the incident and accused the Obama administration of a "massive cover-up."

When asked by host David Gregory what he meant by "cover-up," McCain explained that he was referring to the lack of transparency regarding the deaths of the four Americans. He provided a list of unanswered questions, including what the president did and who he spoke to on the night of the attack, and why those who were evacuated from the consulate the next day were not interviewed.

McCain also questioned the administration's initial claims that the attack was a spontaneous demonstration, and why President Obama continued to say he didn't know whether it was a terrorist attack or not for two weeks during the heat of the presidential campaign. He suggested that the administration may have been trying to avoid revealing the truth about the attack's connection to Al Qaeda.

The senator's appearance on Meet the Press sparked a lively discussion about the ongoing investigation and the need for transparency and accountability.

Title: James Comey's Book Raises Questions About Credibility as Witness Against Trump

James Comey, the former FBI director, has released a book that details his encounters with President Donald Trump, including the president's requests for loyalty and the FBI's investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election. The book, "A Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership," has sparked controversy and raised questions about Comey's credibility as a witness against Trump.

The book is seen as a 300-page witness statement, and any discrepancies between what Comey provides in the book and what he told special counsel Robert Mueller's team could lead to challenges in the investigation. Jack Sharman, a former special counsel, noted that the book will be a "pain" for Mueller to deal with.

The Republican National Committee has launched an attack on Comey's credibility, challenging his account of events and questioning his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. Former FBI assistant director Ron Hosko said the book may open the door to criticism that Comey wrote the dramatic account to enrich himself.

In an interview, Comey characterized the book project as an obligation to drive a healthy conversation about leadership and ethics. He defended the timing of the book's publication, saying it was not intended to influence the Russia inquiry or the Justice Department inspector general's examination into the FBI's handling of the Clinton email investigation.

Patrick Cotter, a former federal prosecutor, noted that while there is less risk in limiting a witness's public statement about an ongoing case, Comey's story has already been the subject of a full Senate Intelligence Committee hearing. Cotter said that unless there are glaring inconsistencies in Comey's testimony and what he told the special counsel and in his book, he does not see a problem.

The controversy surrounding Comey's book has sparked debate about the credibility of witnesses in high-profile investigations. While some have questioned Comey's motives, others see the book as an important contribution to the national conversation about leadership and ethics.

Title: Gina Haspel Confirmed as First Female Director of CIA, Despite Controversy Over Torture Program

Gina Haspel, a 33-year veteran of the Central Intelligence Agency, has been confirmed as the first female director of the CIA, despite concerns over her role in the agency's harsh interrogation program after the 9/11 attacks. The 54-45 vote split both parties, with six Democrats joining Republicans in supporting her nomination.

Haspel, 61, has spent nearly her entire career in undercover positions, working in Africa, Europe, and classified locations around the globe. She was tapped as deputy director of the CIA last year and worked under former CIA Director Mike Pompeo until President Donald Trump moved him to Secretary of State.

Haspel's opponents argued that it was not right to promote someone who supervised a covert detention site in Thailand where terror suspects were waterboarded, an interrogation technique that simulates drowning. They said the U.S. needed to slam closed what was one of the CIA's darkest chapters that tainted America's image with allies abroad.

Several senators said Haspel was not forthcoming in answering questions about her role in the torture program or the CIA's decision to destroy video-taped evidence of the sessions. They also had questions about her rejection of the now-banned techniques.

Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said in a floor speech that Haspel "offered up almost the classic Washington non-apology." He asked how the Senate could take seriously Haspel's "conversion on torture?"

Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the world was watching the confirmation vote, which he called a "referendum on torture." He said the so-called "enhanced interrogation techniques" the CIA used at black sites, including slamming detainees against walls and confining them in coffin-shaped boxes, amounted to "government-sanctioned torture."

Haspel has vowed never to restart such a program and says her "strong moral compass" would prevent her from carrying out any presidential order she found objectionable. That was enough to coax some senators into the "yes" column. However, Leahy said he still questioned her judgment and lamented that she has never publicly condemned torture as "immoral."

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., said the nomination was not just about Haspel, but the U.S. grappling with its past mistakes. "The bottom line is this: No one has ever been held accountable for the torture program and I do not believe those who were intimately involved in it deserve to lead the agency," Feinstein said before casting her vote against Haspel.

Six Democrats ultimately supported Haspel, citing her experience as essential in confronting today's threats from U.S. adversaries like Russia, North Korea, China, and Iran. Among those supporting Haspel were several up for re-election this fall in states where Trump is popular.

After the vote, human rights groups quickly issued statements denouncing the confirmation and the now-defunct program. "The Senate has now rewarded that atrocious conduct by promoting someone that reportedly administered it to lead one of the government's most powerful agencies," said Daphne Eviatar at Amnesty International USA.

Title: Job Creation Slows Down, Ruling Out June Rate Hike and Weighing on Economy

The United States saw a significant slowdown in job creation in May, with only 38,000 new positions added, far below the expected 160,000. This disappointing report has led to a sharp decline in the likelihood of a rate hike in June, with futures markets now indicating a mere 4% chance of an increase. The odds of a hike in July, however, have not been entirely ruled out, with some economists still considering it a possibility.

The weak job creation data has sent shockwaves through the financial markets, causing stocks to dip and bond yields to fall. The U.S. dollar also weakened as investors reassessed the likelihood of a rate hike. The unemployment rate ticked down to 4.7%, but this is largely attributed to a decline in the labor force rather than an increase in job growth.

Economists are now closely watching Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's upcoming speech on Monday, hoping for more insight into the Fed's thinking. While the June rate hike is now off the table, some still see a possibility of a hike in July, pending further economic data.

Title: Facebook Removes Pages Linked to Russian Inauthentic Behavior, Exposing Potential Foreign Efforts to Whip Up Political Passions

Article:

Facebook has removed 32 pages from its platform and Instagram, citing "inauthentic behavior" potentially tied to Russia. The move has sparked concerns that the social media company's efforts to combat Russian bots and trolls may have backfired, exposing potential foreign efforts to whip up political passions on both sides of the political aisle.

Among the removed pages was an event page for a counter-march to a white nationalist march in Washington, D.C. The page was organized by Black Lives Matter DC, which claims that Facebook's actions have hurt their reputation and may impact their participation in the event. The group has set up a new page for the event, which was being organized before the first page was created.

Facebook stated that the administrators of the "Resisters" page were connected to those from other legitimate pages, who worked to drum up support for the protest. However, organizers of the event claim that the page was taken over and controlled by "a lot of real people doing real work" and have not seen any evidence of a "bad actor."

The removal of the pages has also raised concerns about the difficulty social media sites have in identifying Russian actors. While the intelligence community has concluded that Russia meddled in the election through online activities, Russia's meddling has not been limited to pro-Trump activities, especially this election cycle.

The issue highlights the broader challenge social media sites face in identifying Russian actors and the potential for both sides of the political aisle to be targeted by foreign meddling. The Russian agenda of sowing discord in the U.S. is not new, and the administration has acknowledged the ongoing threat of Russian disinformation campaigns.

In February, Trump approved the vice president of Facebook ads, Rob Goldman, who stated that the majority of Russian spending on ads occurred after the 2016 election, and that swaying the election was not the main goal of those ads. However, Goldman later clarified that "the Russian campaign was certainly in favor of Trump" and said his point was that the misinformation campaign was "ongoing."

The New York Times reported that Russia used Facebook groups for a wide range of causes, including groups such as United Muslims of America, Blacktivist, and Secured Borders. The administration has made it clear that they accept the prior U.S. intelligence findings and take the threat of Russian disinformation seriously.

At a White House press briefing last Thursday, officials warned that a disinformation campaign from Moscow is ongoing and that a single attack can have widespread and cascading consequences. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen stated that "our democracy itself is in the crosshairs."

Title: Republican Representative Urges Colleagues to Join Obama on Quick Deal to Extend Tax Rates

Article: Representative Tom Cole, a Republican from Oklahoma, has called on his colleagues to vote to extend the Bush tax rates for all but the highest earners before the end of the year, and then battle over the rest later. In an interview with POLITICO, Cole emphasized that this approach would not violate the anti-tax pledge signed by many Republicans, including himself.

According to Cole, extending the tax rates for most taxpayers would provide an "early Christmas present" and strengthen the Republican position. He believes that fighting over tax rates for the top earners after everyone else is taken care of would rob the president of the argument that Republicans are holding up tax cuts for all but the top earners.

Cole, who has served as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee and held other official posts within the party, acknowledged that he is not alone in his stance. He noted that some other lawmakers are also willing to listen to his proposal and that he is likely to support his leadership when a package is put on the floor.

The representative emphasized that his approach would not raise taxes, but rather lower them for most people and do nothing for the rest, which would result in an increase. He believes that this strategy would not violate the Norquist pledge, which binds signers not to join any effort to raise income tax rates.

Cole's proposal is seen as a departure from the typical Republican stance on taxes, but he believes it would be a pragmatic approach to avoid a sharp fall off the so-called fiscal cliff.

Title: Supreme Court's Conservative Majority Relies on Textualism in Recent Decisions

The Supreme Court has been settling disputes involving workers, immigrants, prisoners, and patent owners by meticulously defining the meaning of specific words and phrases in the laws under review. This approach, known as textualism, has been a hallmark of the court's decisions this term, with conservative justices Neil Gorsuch, Clarence Thomas, and Samuel Alito leading the way.

Gorsuch, in particular, has been a champion of textualism, as he promised during his Senate confirmation in 2017. In recent decisions, he has stuck to the letter of the law, refusing to read into the National Labor Relations Act rules for handling legal disputes under the Federal Arbitration Act. In another case, he ruled that an administrative board created to review patents cannot pick and choose which parts of a patent to review.

The court's liberal justices, led by Ruth Bader Ginsburg, have dissented in these decisions, arguing that the laws are more nuanced and require consideration of context, purpose, and history. In one case, Ginsburg noted that the National Labor Relations Act guarantees workers the right to unionize, bargain collectively, and engage in other concerted activities.

The court's conservative justices have also relied on textualism in other recent decisions. In one case, Justice Alito ruled that illegal immigrants can be detained indefinitely while their cases are reviewed, rather than given intermittent bail hearings. In another case, Justice Thomas found that service advisers at car dealerships can be excluded from the Fair Labor Standards Act's wage and hour protections because their duties are akin to those of salesmen and partsmen.

Supreme Court experts say that Gorsuch's addition to the court has merely returned it to the brand of textualism popularized by the late Justice Antonin Scalia. However, others argue that Gorsuch is trying to put a fresh spin on textualism and is having some success.

The court's decisions on textualism have sparked debate about the role of judges in interpreting laws. Elizabeth Wydra, president of the liberal Constitutional Accountability Center, says that both liberals and conservatives are guilty of reading into statutes what they want them to say. The battle over textualism is far from over, and the court's decisions on issues like immigration, gay rights, politics, abortion, taxes, and technology are likely to be closely watched.

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order on Social Media and Big Technology Companies

President Trump has announced plans to sign an executive order on Thursday aimed at regulating social media and big technology companies. The move comes after a fact-check on the president's tweet about voting by mail, which was flagged by Twitter. The executive order seeks to limit the liability protections afforded to social media companies under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act.

Section 230, enacted in 1996, was intended to shield providers of interactive computer services from liability for the content posted by their users. However, President Trump's executive order aims to add regulations to this section, limiting the liability protections for companies that editorialize or censor content or speech. The president has also instructed the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to act as a check on reported political bias.

The executive order is the result of a partnership between President Trump and Attorney General Bill Barr, who has stated that the new order does not repeal Section 230, but rather aims to ensure that the law is interpreted correctly. The move has been met with criticism from both Republicans and Democrats, who argue that the law allows social media companies to avoid responsibility for ensuring truth is present online.

The executive order is expected to be challenged in court on its constitutionality.

Title: Immigration Overhaul Stalls in House, Despite Bipartisan Support in Senate

The push for an immigration overhaul in the United States has stalled in the Republican-controlled House, despite gaining bipartisan support in the Senate. The Senate passed a comprehensive bill in June, which would provide a 13-year path to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants currently in the country illegally, along with stricter border security provisions. However, House Speaker John Boehner has rejected any negotiations with the Senate over the bill.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, the No. 3 Democrat, who helped negotiate the Senate bill, expressed cautious optimism, stating that while the number of opponents has remained steady, the number of supporters has grown, and those in the middle are less opposed than before. However, this does not guarantee a successful outcome.

Republican Party leaders, backed by business groups, consider an overhaul crucial to repair their political standing with Latino and immigrant voters. Barry Jackson, former Chief of Staff to Speaker Boehner, is now consulting for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which supports an overhaul that expands high-tech visas and guest worker programs.

However, immigration is less of an issue during midterm elections, when immigrants are less likely to vote, and House members in safe districts are less concerned about moderate swing voters. The biggest threats to Republicans come from primary challenges from more conservative candidates who argue that changing the immigration status of someone in the country illegally amounts to amnesty for a lawbreaker.

Representative John Carter, a Republican from Texas and one of the "Gang of Eight" House members who attempted to forge a bipartisan overhaul, believes that an election year is not the time to push forward. "Immigration is a very, very contentious issue," he said.

Title: President Obama's Hawaiian Vacation: A Luxurious Getaway with Official Duties

President Obama has been on a 16-day holiday retreat in Hawaii, where he has been enjoying a luxurious vacation with his family. During his stay, the president has taken part in various activities, including golfing, snorkeling, and visiting a private zoo. He has also received daily presidential briefings and taken part in official duties, such as issuing a statement about ailing former first lady Barbara Bush and signing a handful of bills.

The Obamas are paying for the $56,000 cost of their rental home, while taxpayers are footing the bill for their travel on Air Force One, which costs over $180,000 per hour. Hundreds of federal workers, including White House staffers and Secret Service security detail, have joined the first family for their vacation.

According to watchdog.org, the government has rented at least seven homes in the area, costing taxpayers over $183,750, and the total bill is expected to be around $4 million. This year's Hawaiian vacation has been less eventful than in 2012, when the president flew to Washington to negotiate with congressional Republicans about preventing a "fiscal cliff," which cost taxpayers at least $7.2 million.

During his free time, the president has played golf with New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, his teenage son Max, and White House aide Marvin Nicholson at the Marine Corps base at Kaneohe Klipper Golf Course, which is rated as one of the world's best military golf courses. The president has also gone on eight gym workouts and taken two family hikes, two beach trips, and a jaunt to Hanauma Bay Nature Preserves, where they snorkeled with parrotfish and green sea turtles. The preserve was closed to the public during their visit.

The Obamas have also met with U.S. troops once, but have not found time to attend church services, even for Christmas. Reporters and photographers have been kept at a distance and have had limited access to the president during his excursions. However, they were allowed to watch the president and his family go out for shaved ice at a shopping center on New Year's Eve.

Title: White Supremacist Rally in Washington, D.C. Faces Transportation and Service Challenges

The upcoming "Unite the Right" rally in Washington, D.C. on Sunday, marking the one-year anniversary of the Charlottesville, Virginia, white supremacist violence, may face difficulties in transportation and service provision. According to reports, Uber and Lyft have informed their drivers that they have the right to refuse service to passengers who are harassed or threatened, while the Restaurant Association of Metropolitan Washington has sent a toolkit to restaurateurs, advising them of their legal rights to refuse service to white nationalists and other political fringe groups.

In preparation for the rally, Airbnb has threatened to ban users who participate in the event, stating that it will take appropriate action against those who engage in behavior that is antithetical to its community commitment. The company has confirmed that it will remove users from the platform if necessary.

Rally organizer Jason Kessler has obtained a permit for Lafayette Park across from the White House, expecting around 400 supporters to attend. The first "Unite The Right" rally in Charlottesville on August 12, 2017, resulted in violent clashes between white supremacists and counter-protesters, with one person killed when a white supremacist drove into a crowd of counter-protesters.

Several restaurant owners have expressed their intention to refuse service to those participating in the rally or plan to close their businesses altogether. Founding Farmers owner Dan Simons stated, "Our mentality is we're going to protect each other. This is our city. Our house. Our people." Ellen Kassoff Gray, owner of Equinox restaurant, said she would refuse to serve those who espouse hate, while Alan Popovsky, owner of Lincoln restaurant, plans to close his business for dinner on Sunday.

Meanwhile, Twitter has suspended numerous accounts associated with the Proud Boys, a controversial group of right-wing chauvinists, for violating Twitter's policy against "violent extremist groups."

Title: Trump Hosts "Celebration of America" Event, Disinvites Philadelphia Eagles from White House Visit

The White House hosted a "Celebration of America" event on Tuesday, featuring the United States Marine Band and the United States Army Chorus, in an effort to honor the country and its national anthem. The event was announced by President Trump, who took to Twitter to promote the event and express his disapproval of the Philadelphia Eagles' decision to not visit the White House.

Trump had initially invited the Super Bowl champions to the White House, but the team reportedly wanted to send a small group of players, which led to the event being canceled. The President took to Twitter to express his disappointment, stating that staying in the locker room during the national anthem is "as disrespectful to our country as kneeling."

The decision to disinvite the Eagles sparked backlash from Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney, who called Trump a "fragile egomaniac" and accused him of being more concerned with crowd size than hosting a successful event.

The controversy surrounding the Eagles' visit is part of a larger debate over national anthem protests in the NFL. Last month, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell announced that the league would fine teams and league personnel who do not "stand and show respect for the flag and the anthem." The new policy allows players to remain in the locker room during the anthem.

Trump has praised the new policy, but his decision to disinvite the Eagles and his swipe at those who stay in the locker room reflects ongoing tension between his White House and players protesting police violence by sitting out the national anthem. The President also took to Twitter to note past events the White House has held with other championship teams, including the Chicago Cubs, Houston Astros, Pittsburgh Penguins, New England Patriots, Alabama and Clemson National Champions, and NASCAR and Champion Martin Truex Jr.

Title: House Republicans Consider Lawsuit to Compel Release of Fast and Furious Documents

The House of Representatives is likely to file a lawsuit to compel the Justice Department to release more documents related to the Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation, according to House Speaker John Boehner. The move comes after the GOP-led House approved two resolutions on Thursday, one of which put Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress for failing to provide additional documents to congressional investigators.

The resolutions, approved by the House, opened the door for the House to call on the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia to bring the case before a grand jury. However, Deputy Attorney General James Cole told Boehner in a letter that the agency would not prosecute Holder, stating that his failure to release the documents "does not constitute a crime."

The second resolution grants the House the ability to ask a court to compel the Justice Department to hand over the documents. President Obama has already asserted executive privilege over the documents in question.

The Fast and Furious operation, which was run out of an Arizona field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, involved putting roughly 2,000 assault guns into the hands of arms dealers, with the expectation that they would resurface at crime scenes and lead agents to organizers of Mexican drug cartels. Two of the weapons were found at the scene of U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry's death in a 2010 shootout.

The controversy surrounding the operation has been ongoing for 16 months, led by GOP Rep. Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. The White House Chief of Staff, Jack Lew, has stated that the Justice Department's decision not to prosecute Holder was based on a Reagan administration memo and that the House's continued efforts are "political" and a "fishing expedition."

Title: Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper Criticizes Trump's Stance on Foreign Opposition Research

Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper recently appeared on Anderson Cooper 360 to discuss President Donald Trump's comments on accepting foreign opposition research. Clapper expressed strong disapproval of Trump's willingness to consider information from foreign countries, particularly Russia, stating that it could be disinformation and undermine the FBI's integrity.

Clapper emphasized that accepting foreign opposition research without verifying its accuracy is a concerning practice, citing the example of the Steele dossier, which was compiled by a former British spy and was not independently verified by the FBI. He noted that the FBI's acceptance of the dossier as fact without verifying its contents was a mistake and that the government has an obligation to independently verify information used to obtain FISA warrants.

Clapper also pointed out that opposition research is a common practice in political campaigns, and that Hillary Clinton's campaign had the right to conduct research on Trump. He emphasized that the government's obligation is to verify the accuracy of the information, not to accept it at face value.

Cooper described Trump's stance as a "clarion call" for information from foreign countries, particularly Russia, and Clapper warned that Russia will likely repeat its 2016 tactics in the 2020 election. Clapper expressed his concern that Trump's actions will encourage Russia to engage in similar activities, which could undermine the integrity of the election process.

Title: Planned Parenthood Affiliates Ordered to Return $80 Million in PPP Loans

The Small Business Administration (SBA) is seeking repayment of $80 million in Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans granted to 37 Planned Parenthood affiliates, citing eligibility issues. The affiliates, which are part of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PPFA), had applied for and received the loans, with the largest single loan being $7.5 million to the Planned Parenthood of Orange and San Bernardino Counties in California.

According to the SBA, affiliates of larger organizations with more than 500 employees are not eligible for PPP distributions. The PPFA has over 600 employees, making its affiliates ineligible for the program. The SBA is sending letters to each involved affiliate explaining the issue and requesting repayment.

One Planned Parenthood affiliate, the Planned Parenthood Metropolitan Washington (PPMW), received a letter stating that it will need to return the $1.328 million loan it received. PPMW had previously stated it would not accept federal funds, but the SBA's decision has forced the affiliate to reconsider.

The SBA warned that incorrect or false eligibility certifications by PPP recipients could result in criminal or civil sanctions if the SBA determines borrowers made knowingly false statements. The SBA letter explained that PPFA affiliates are clearly covered by the PPP affiliate rules, citing the organization's bylaws and policies.

Senator Marco Rubio, R-Fla., has called for an immediate investigation into the matter, stating that there is no ambiguity in the legislation that passed or public record around its passage that organizations like Planned Parenthood are not eligible for the Paycheck Protection Program. The SBA has not yet commented on the matter.

The controversy surrounding Planned Parenthood's PPP loans comes as the organization reported a record-high number of abortions and government funding for 2018-2019. While Planned Parenthood claims abortion constitutes only a small percentage of its services, the organization has faced criticism for its involvement in the program.

Title: Alabama Senate Passes Near-Total Abortion Ban, Sending Measure to Governor's Desk

The Alabama Senate has passed a bill that bans nearly all abortions in the state, sending the measure to Governor Kay Ivey's desk to be signed into law. The legislation, which passed with a 25-6 margin, would prohibit abortions in virtually all instances, including for victims of rape and incest, and would only permit the procedure if necessary to save a mother's life. Anyone performing an abortion could face punishment by 10 to 99 years in prison, but no criminal charges would be filed against a person undergoing the procedure.

The bill's proponents hope the legislation, along with similar restrictions in other states, will set up a Supreme Court battle that will see the overturning of the landmark Roe v. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. The bill's sponsor, State Rep. Terri Collins, stated that the exceptions for rape and incest were removed to ensure the law is strong enough to force a federal court battle.

Sixteen states have passed or are considering abortion bans once a fetal heartbeat is detected about six weeks into pregnancy. Alabama's law is the most restrictive in the country, with no exceptions for rape or incest. State Sen. Vivian Figures expressed concern that the law would drive women away from the state, saying, "If I were them, I would be making plans to leave Alabama. Who is going to stay in a state like this?"

The pro-abortion rights group NARAL Pro-Choice America swiftly condemned the vote, expressing concern that the current makeup of the Supreme Court puts Roe v. Wade at risk after the Senate confirmed President Trump's two nominees. The organization's president, Ilyse Hogue, stated, "Alabama just passed a law that is a total ban on abortion, criminalizing the act and punishing women and doctors. Anti-choice Republicans no longer even pretend to respect the law or the women that it protects."

Title: A Glimpse into Syria's War: A Complex Web of Loyalties and Fears
