Title: White House Exerts Executive Privilege Over 'Fast and Furious' Documents, Raising Tensions

The White House has invoked executive privilege over documents related to the "Fast and Furious" operation, a move that has escalated the controversy surrounding the Obama administration's handling of the botched gun-trafficking operation. The decision comes as the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is set to vote on whether to hold Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress for failing to turn over the documents.

The committee's Republican majority has subpoenaed the documents, which are believed to contain information about the operation's tactics and the role of the Justice Department in the scandal. The controversy surrounding "Fast and Furious" began in December 2010, when a U.S. Border Patrol agent was killed, and two guns connected to the operation were found near his body.

Attorney General Holder appeared before the committee in June, where he faced questioning from Chairman Darrell Issa and other Republican lawmakers. Republicans accused Holder of not being forthcoming about the operation's tactics and not complying with subpoenas. The committee is expected to vote on whether to hold Holder in contempt, with a possible vote expected after the committee reconvenes following a recess.

The exertion of executive privilege by the White House has raised tensions in the dispute, with Republicans accusing the administration of stonewalling and Democrats defending the decision as necessary to protect executive branch confidentiality. The committee has not yet voted on the contempt citation, with members still debating the issue along partisan lines.

Title: Republican Greg Gianforte Wins Montana Congressional Seat, Defeating Democrat Rob Quist

Article:

Republican Greg Gianforte won the special congressional election in Montana, defeating Democrat Rob Quist and Libertarian Mark Wicks. The Associated Press called the race for Gianforte more than 2.5 hours after polls closed, with Gianforte leading Quist by a margin of 50.3% to 43.9%. Wicks received 5.8% of the vote.

Gianforte's victory comes less than 24 hours after he allegedly body-slammed a reporter from the Guardian newspaper, leading to a criminal charge being filed against him. Gianforte apologized to the reporter, Ben Jacobs, saying it was a mistake and that he took an action he cannot take back.

The outcome of the election means Republicans will now hold a 239-193 majority in the House. Steve Stivers, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, described the outcome as another "hard-fought victory" and applauded Gianforte for offering an apology.

During the campaign, Gianforte embraced President Trump, who won the state by more than 20 percentage points in the November election. However, there were signs that Gianforte's victory could cause headaches for GOP lawmakers, who faced a barrage of questions over whether they condone Gianforte's behavior and whether he should be barred from joining the GOP conference.

House Speaker Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican, told reporters on Capitol Hill that Gianforte should apologize to Jacobs but said the rest lay in the hands of Montana voters. "The choice will be made by the people of Montana," Ryan said. "I do not think this is acceptable behavior, but the choice will be made by the people of Montana."

Sen. Steve Daines, Montana Republican, also said Gianforte's behavior was unacceptable and said he doesn't condone that sort of violence. Meanwhile, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, described Gianforte as a "sort of wannabe Trump" and said she hoped Montana voters would demand a "higher standard of behavior... for the sake of the children."

Voters, many of whom have a negative opinion of the news media, were not swayed enough to push Quist over the finish line. More than 200,000 absentee ballots were cast before the tussle. The party is eager to capitalize on the wave of anti-Trump sentiment among progressive activists and to score an electoral victory that they can point to as proof that Trump's star has dimmed four months into his presidency.

Democrats had hoped the backlash against the bill the House GOP passed to repeal and replace Obamacare would be enough for Quist to capture the at-large seat, which Republicans have held since 1997. However, Gianforte's victory means Republicans will continue to hold the seat.

Title: The Importance of Discussing Politics at the Thanksgiving Table

As the holiday season approaches, many Americans are reminded to avoid discussing politics at the dinner table. However, some progressive media outlets have taken it upon themselves to advise against even bringing up the topic, citing the potential for discomfort and conflict. But what about the importance of discussing the political issues that affect our families and communities?

For many American families, Thanksgiving is a time to reflect on the values that have bonded their family for generations. It is an opportunity to share stories and experiences, and to pass down traditions and cultural heritage. However, for conservative families, this holiday may be a chance to recalibrate their family members who have moved away from their conservative values and are now living in liberal strongholds.

The article highlights the importance of discussing politics at the Thanksgiving table, particularly for conservative families who may have family members who have moved away from their values. It emphasizes the need to share stories and experiences, and to explain the reasons behind one's beliefs and values. The article also encourages families to discuss the impact of politics on their daily lives, such as the economy, law enforcement, and social issues.

The article also touches on the idea that many progressive media outlets have created a "bubble" around themselves, where they only hear one side of the story and are not exposed to opposing viewpoints. It suggests that this bubble can be a result of living in coastal cities or attending liberal colleges, where rational thought and political balance are often absent.

The article concludes by encouraging conservative families to use the Thanksgiving holiday as an opportunity to share their stories and experiences, and to explain their beliefs and values to their family members. It emphasizes the importance of being open and honest, and of sharing the reasons behind one's beliefs.

Title: Trump's Presidency Brings New Storylines and Challenges for Newsrooms

The outcome of the presidential election has sent shockwaves through newsrooms, as journalists scramble to adapt to the new reality. The surprise victory of Donald Trump, a reality TV star and businessman with no political experience, has presented a unique set of challenges and opportunities for news organizations.

Major TV networks, such as MSNBC and CNN, had anticipated a ratings drop after the election, but instead, they are experiencing a surge in interest and engagement. "This changes everything," said Phil Griffin, president of MSNBC. "We left the studio at 4 a.m., and we knew there was a whole other world of storylines and changes that are going to happen."

The first 100 days of Trump's presidency are expected to be a dynamic and unpredictable ride, with politicians jockeying for key Cabinet positions and Trump's governing style and tendencies under scrutiny. "You've got a more dynamic transition in place," said Chris Isham, CBS News' Washington bureau chief. "He's not a predictable Republican, not in the way of previous administrations."

Gauging Trump's comfort level with the press is already underway, with reporters who have known him for years describing him as accessible and willing to banter. However, he has also sought political advantage in bashing the mainstream media. "Let's see how much access he grants," said Chris Ariens, editor of TVNewser. "He's not the candidate anymore. He's not going to be calling into Fox and Friends."

One of the first major interviews Trump granted after the election was to 60 Minutes, which will air Sunday. Jeff Fager, executive producer of 60 Minutes, said the show had planned on pursuing an interview with the president-elect regardless of the election outcome, but the uncertainty surrounding Trump's governing philosophy and policy specifics has heightened the urgency. "It's not about good TV. It's about how we can help people better understand," Fager said. "There's a lot to talk about. Hopefully, we'll get some details."

In an interview clip released early by CBS, Trump said he's willing to retain some key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, including prohibiting insurers from denying coverage to patients with pre-existing conditions. Coverage planning for Trump's presidency must entail deep-diving into these issues to hold him accountable for some of his outlandish proposals, Fager said.

Beyond issues, scrutinizing Trump's governing styles and tendencies – not as a career politician, but honed on the fly based on his experience as a real estate developer and TV personality – will also be a rich source of stories. "He's a businessman who's a negotiator," Fager said. "There's a lot of stories that could be generated in (covering) someone who's got a totally different perspective on how to get things done."

While no news executives may admit it publicly, the possibility of Trump's gaffes and unfiltered diatribes, frequently evident during his campaign, remains an intriguing variable, said Mark Feldstein, a broadcast journalism professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, and a former journalist at NBC. "Media critics are always attacking TV for ideological bias," he said. "But the real bias is toward conflict, controversy, and excitement because that's what increases revenue. Whether you love or hate him, he is going to bring controversy."

**Trump Softens Stance on Immigration, Courts Non-White Vote**

In a recent development, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has appeared to soften his stance on immigration, a signature issue of his campaign. Trump's comments on the topic have been notoriously difficult to pin down, with some critics accusing him of flip-flopping. However, in a recent town hall with Fox News anchor Sean Hannity, Trump stated that immigrants not in the US legally would not get citizenship, but would instead be allowed to "pay back taxes" and "work with them."

This apparent moderation on immigration comes as Trump attempts to aggressively court Hispanic and African American voters. According to a Quinnipiac University poll, Trump trails Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton by a significant margin among likely non-white voters.

In a recent speech, Trump highlighted the struggles faced by African Americans and Hispanics, stating that they have been failed by their politicians and are suffering from high rates of poverty, crime, and poor education. However, his comments have been criticized for being overly broad-brush and potentially offensive.

Trump also claimed that crime is at "levels that nobody's seen," citing inner cities as examples. However, crime statistics show a steady decline since 1991, with some demographics still experiencing high rates of criminal activity.

Additionally, Trump has been accused of misrepresenting unemployment rates among African Americans. His campaign cited a statistic claiming that 58% of young black men and women are unemployed, but this figure was based on outdated data and included individuals not actively seeking employment. The Bureau of Labor Statistics puts the unemployment rate among 16- to 19-year-old black Americans at 25.7%, adjusted seasonally.

Trump's attempts to court non-white voters have been met with skepticism, with a recent NBC/Wall Street Journal poll showing him receiving the support of only 1% of African American voters.

Title: Joe Biden's Presidential Bid: A Unity Candidate's Challenges Ahead

Article:

Joe Biden is set to announce his third presidential bid, with some polls indicating he is the front-runner or co-front-runner among Democratic candidates. He has led in 36 of 37 polls and is ahead in Iowa and California. However, his campaign faces challenges in uniting the party across ideological and demographic lines. Biden's long history of association with past Democratic Party trends, particularly those unpopular among minority and feminist constituencies, has raised doubts about his ability to bridge the gap between the Clinton-Obama era and the more progressive future.

Recent allegations of inappropriate behavior toward women have further eroded his reputation. While his standing in polls remains steady, his approval rating among Democrats is 75%, and he is the top second-choice candidate among those who prefer Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, or Bernie Sanders. However, his rivals may target him with attacks that have been confined to media elites and political Twitter so far.

Biden's ability to unite the party could be undermined by his own efforts to distinguish himself from more progressive candidates or by accommodating himself to a more self-consciously progressive electorate. His campaign may need to balance his past record with his vision for the future, which could be a difficult task.

Some argue that Biden's campaign could become an "apology tour," focusing on his growth and learning since his past stances on issues like crime and abortion. His aides have discussed a one-term pledge and a potential running mate like Stacey Abrams, which could reinforce this strategy. However, this approach might not be enough to overcome his past record and could lead to a campaign that "loses as badly as Jeb Bush did."

Ultimately, Biden's success will depend on his ability to establish himself as the most electable opponent against Donald Trump. His unique appeal to white working-class swing voters in Rust Belt states could be a key factor in his campaign. While it's early to predict the outcome, Biden's strong performance against Trump in polls suggests he may have an advantage if the election becomes a referendum on the incumbent.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Point to Volker's Testimony to Defend Trump Against Impropriety Allegations

Article:

Republican lawmakers are citing closed-door testimony from senior diplomat Kurt Volker to defend President Donald Trump against allegations of impropriety in the House impeachment inquiry. Volker, Trump's special envoy to Ukraine until two months ago, testified that there is no evidence to support the specific allegations against Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden that Trump and his allies have been pushing online and on TV for months.

According to Volker, Biden's push for Ukraine's then-prosecutor general, Viktor Shokin, to be fired was justified, as Shokin had a "notorious reputation" for not doing his job. Volker also testified that Biden's son, Hunter, was not involved in any improper actions on his father's behalf.

Volker's testimony has been released by the House Intelligence Committee, and Trump tweeted a "thank you" to Volker for his testimony. However, Volker's account explicitly undercuts the specific allegations against Biden that Trump and his allies have been pushing.

The allegations against Biden stem from his role as the Obama administration's point man on Ukraine when he was vice president in 2016. Biden had pressured Ukraine's leadership to fire Shokin, who was investigating alleged corruption in Ukraine, including corruption within the major gas company Burisma, which had added Biden's son to its board two years earlier.

Republicans have described Biden's son as someone "with no energy experience and no Ukraine experience." However, Volker testified that it is "quite possible" that Burisma executives believed they were "buying influence" through Biden's son, but Volker did not believe Biden would take any improper action on his son's behalf.

The ousted ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch, also testified that Shokin had a "notorious reputation" for not doing his job. Even Trump's congressional allies, such as Rep. Jim Jordan and Rep. Mark Meadows, conceded behind closed doors that Shokin was viewed as "a bad guy."

However, Volker acknowledged that the allegations against Biden have "never actually been investigated" and have therefore never been directly or fully debunked.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Releases Impeachment Report Against President Trump

The House Judiciary Committee has released a 658-page report detailing the impeachment case against President Trump, outlining two alleged impeachable offenses: abuse of power and obstructing Congress during its investigation. The report claims that President Trump has prioritized his personal and political interests over national security, free and fair elections, and the system of checks and balances.

The report states that President Trump's actions have led to a pattern of misconduct that, if left unchecked, will continue to harm the country. The Democrats argue that Trump's abuse of power encompasses both constitutional and criminal offenses, including bribery and multiple federal crimes. They believe that Trump has betrayed the national interest and the people of the United States, and that he should be removed from office.

In response, Republicans have pushed back against the report, criticizing the Democrats for pursuing impeachment without a solid case and relying on hearsay and assumptions. The minority report argues that the majority's claims are not supported by evidence and that some of the allegations are simply a continuation of an earlier attempt to politicize the Russia collusion investigation.

The full House is expected to vote on the articles of impeachment this week.

Title: Wisconsin Teenager Found Safe After 88-Day Kidnapping Ordeal

A 13-year-old Wisconsin girl, Jayme Closs, has been found safe and sound after being missing for 88 days. She was discovered on Thursday, fleeing on foot from a remote house, and was taken into police custody after a woman who was walking her dog stopped to call authorities. The girl was reunited with her family on Friday after speaking with investigators.

The suspect, 21-year-old Jake Thomas Patterson, was arrested and charged with kidnapping and murder. Authorities believe Patterson planned his actions and took steps to avoid detection. He was found down the road from the house where Jayme escaped and was arrested based on a description of his vehicle provided by the teenager.

Patterson had no prior criminal history in the area or in the state of Wisconsin, and authorities are still investigating the motive behind his actions. The local sheriff, Chris Fitzgerald, described the case as "unthinkable" and said investigators are still trying to determine what Jayme experienced during her captivity.

Jayme's aunt, Sue Allard, expressed her joy and relief at the news, saying "Praise the Lord, it's the news we've been waiting on for three months. I can't wait to get my arms around her."

The FBI special agent in charge of Milwaukee, Justin Tolomeo, described the case as "incredible" and praised Jayme for overcoming obstacles to stage her own escape. The suspect, Jake Patterson, is scheduled to make his first court appearance on Monday.

Title: Trump Administration Withdraws from Global Arms Treaty, Citing Sovereignty Concerns

The Trump administration announced its decision to withdraw the United States as a signatory to the Arms Trade Treaty, a global agreement aimed at regulating the international sale of conventional weapons. The treaty was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 2013 and signed by President Obama, but it has never been ratified by Congress.

President Trump made the announcement during a speech at the National Rifle Association (NRA) annual convention in Indianapolis, stating that the U.S. will "never surrender American sovereignty to anyone." The NRA, a key backer of Trump's 2016 campaign, has been a leading opponent of the treaty, arguing it could impinge on the rights of American gun owners.

The treaty has been ratified by 101 countries, including the member states of the European Union, but China and Russia are not parties to it. Some U.S. conservatives argue that the treaty could open the door to stricter gun regulations at home, while others claim it has no effect on domestic arms sales or gun rights.

Thomas Countryman, a former assistant secretary of state who was the lead U.S. negotiator for the treaty, stated that the document has no impact on Second Amendment rights of U.S. citizens. He explained that the treaty's language was negotiated to ensure the U.S. would be in compliance immediately, without having to change any laws at home.

The goal of the treaty was not to crack down on U.S. manufacturers or tighten domestic laws, but to ensure other countries were following the example in place for decades under U.S. law. The treaty does not hurt U.S. manufacturers, and it has the potential to strengthen their business by leveling the playing field among international arms dealers by ensuring they all subscribe to the same standards.

Rachel Stohl, managing director of the conventional defense program at the Stimson Center, a Washington think tank, said the decision was part of a U.S. retreat from global leadership. "Un-signing the Arms Trade Treaty will undermine international peace and security, increase irresponsible and illegal sales of conventional weapons, and harm the American economy," she said in a statement.

Ted Bromund, a senior research fellow in Anglo-American relations at the Heritage Foundation's Margaret Thatcher Center for Freedom, praised the president for withdrawing from a treaty that "has achieved nothing." He cited low levels of compliance with the treaty as evidence of its failure and said nations are free to impose their own legal controls on arms exports.

The decision to withdraw from the treaty has sparked criticism from some lawmakers, with House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.) decried the move as "a politically-motivated appeasement of the National Rifle Association."

Title: Senator Tim Scott Receives Death Threats and Racial Slurs, but Mainstream Media Ignores the Story

Article:

Senator Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the Senate, has revealed that he and his aides have received recent death threats and racial slurs on their office voicemail. According to a New York Times report, Scott shared two audio recordings with the publication, which contained profanity and racist slurs. One caller addressed Scott as "Uncle Tim" and threatened him, saying "take your one-way ticket straight to hell." Another caller discussed putting the senator "in his crosshairs."

Despite this disturbing news, the liberal broadcast networks ABC, CBS, and NBC failed to report on the story. Instead, they focused on promoting John Bolton's anti-Trump book and decrying President Trump's rallies. NBC also chose to ignore the outrage generated by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's comments, in which she accused the Republican Party of "trying to get away with murder," specifically referencing the death of George Floyd.

Pelosi made her comments on CBS News Radio, stating that the GOP was "trying to get away with murder, actually, the murder of George Floyd." However, CBS did not fact-check her statement or provide any context about the Republican Party's involvement in the killing. The network also failed to report on the outrage generated by Pelosi's comments.

In contrast, Senator Scott blamed the media for how his police reform legislation was being portrayed, stating that it was "interesting that we are on the right side of the police reform conversation, yet we're on the wrong side according to the people, based on the way that we are characterized in the national press."

Title: A Bipartisan Discussion on Immigration: Finding Common Ground Across Party Lines

In a rare display of bipartisanship, a group of individuals from different political backgrounds came together to discuss the complex issue of immigration. Rremida Shkoza, a real estate broker and Albanian-born US citizen, participated in a "Living Room Conversation" with three Republicans and a Democrat. The discussion focused on the personal experiences of each participant, with Shkoza sharing her own story of fleeing communist Albania as a refugee.

Initially, Shkoza was skeptical about engaging with Republicans, particularly given the party's stance on immigration under President Donald Trump. However, she was pleasantly surprised to find that her Republican co-host, Sue Googe, was a fellow immigrant who shared her passion for real estate and her love of food and people. The two bonded over their shared experiences living under communism and their desire for a more compassionate approach to immigration.

During the formal conversation, Shkoza emphasized the xenophobia she faced as a refugee in Italy and the importance of treating migrants and refugees with dignity and respect. Her Republican counterparts, Julia Song and Mario Benavente, shared their own experiences with immigration, highlighting the need for a more humane approach to the issue.

The group agreed that the US immigration system is flawed and needs comprehensive reform, with a focus on balancing the need to protect American citizens and values with the need to provide humane treatment for migrants and refugees. They also acknowledged the country's ongoing struggles with racism, xenophobia, and homelessness.

The discussion revealed that while there are differences in policy approaches, there is a shared commitment to democracy and freedom. Shkoza and her Republican counterparts recognized that the US is not perfect and that there is much work to be done to address these issues. They also acknowledged the need to make space for new immigrants in the country.

The conversation showed that even in the face of political differences, it is possible to find common ground and work towards a more compassionate and effective approach to immigration. As Shkoza noted, "We lack is not empathy – it's a personal connection with those across party lines."

Title: Federal Law Enforcement Uses Unmarked Vehicles to Detain Protesters in Portland, Raising Concerns

Federal law enforcement officers have been using unmarked vehicles to detain protesters in downtown Portland since at least July 14, according to personal accounts and multiple videos posted online. The tactic appears to be an escalation in federal force deployed on Portland city streets, as federal officials and President Donald Trump have said they plan to "quell" nightly protests outside the federal courthouse and Multnomah County Justice Center that have lasted for over six weeks.

Federal officers have charged at least 13 people with crimes related to the protests so far, while others have been arrested and released. One demonstrator was left hospitalized with skull fractures after being shot in the face with "less lethal" munitions on July 11. Officers from the U.S. Marshals Special Operations Group and Customs and Border Protection's BORTAC have been sent to Portland to protect federal property during the recent protests against racism and police brutality.

However, interviews conducted by OPB show that officers are also detaining people on Portland streets who are not near federal property, and it is unclear that all of the people being arrested have engaged in criminal activity. Demonstrators like O'Shea and Pettibone said they think they were targeted by federal officers for simply wearing black clothing in the area of the demonstration.

The use of unmarked vehicles and camouflage-clad officers has raised concerns about the lack of transparency and accountability in the detentions. Pettibone described being detained by federal officers, saying he was "tossed into the van" and had his beanie pulled over his face so he couldn't see, with his hands held over his head. He and O'Shea said they couldn't think of anything they might have done to end up targeted by law enforcement.

The situation has sparked concerns about the erosion of civil liberties and the potential for a "Pinochet-style" authoritarian takeover. Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf's visit to Portland has been criticized, with Mayor Ted Wheeler and other local officials saying they did not ask for help from federal law enforcement and have asked them to leave. Democratic Gov. Kate Brown called Wolf's visit "political theater from President Trump" and said he is looking for a confrontation in Oregon to win political points in other states.

The use of unmarked vehicles and camouflage-clad officers has also been compared to tactics used by authoritarian regimes, with some critics warning that this is a "dress rehearsal" for a broader crackdown on dissent. The situation highlights the need for transparency and accountability in law enforcement actions and the importance of protecting civil liberties.

Title: Romney Calls Individual Mandate in Obama's Health Care Law a "Tax"

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, stated in an interview with CBS News that the individual mandate in President Obama's health care law is a "tax". This characterization is in contrast to his campaign's previous stance, which described the mandate as a penalty rather than a tax. Romney's campaign had previously said that the mandate should be thought of as a penalty, not a tax.

In the interview, Romney said, "While I agreed with the dissent, that's taken over by the fact that the majority of the court said it's a tax, and therefore it is a tax. They have spoken. They concluded it was a tax. That's what it is, and the American people know that President Obama has broken the pledge he made, He said he wouldn't raise taxes on middle-income Americans. Not only did he raise the $500 billion that was already in the bill, it's now clear that his mandate as described by the Supreme Court is a tax."

Romney's statement is at odds with the stance of his campaign, which had previously described the mandate as a penalty. Eric Fehrnstrom, the campaign's spokesman, said on MSNBC's "The Daily Rundown" that Romney disagreed with the court's ruling and agreed with the dissent written by Justice Scalia, which stated that the mandate was not a tax.

The characterization of the mandate is a sensitive issue for the Romney campaign, as Romney had previously championed universal health care in Massachusetts when he was governor. While Romney has pledged to repeal what conservatives call Obamacare, he had previously avoided calling the mandate a tax, possibly due to his Massachusetts plan including a similar mandate.

Title: Political Unforced Errors: A Game of Power and Polarization

In the game of politics, unforced errors can be just as damaging as they are in sports. Recently, both sides of the political spectrum have committed major unforced errors, causing damage to their reputation and the political process as a whole.

Hillary Clinton's decision to use a private email server while serving as Secretary of State has been widely criticized. While it may have been seen as a way to maintain control over her emails, it raises questions about her judgment and transparency. Clinton's defenders argue that it was a common practice among government officials, but critics point out that it was unnecessary and potentially compromised national security.

On the other side of the aisle, 47 Republican Senators signed an open letter to the Iranian leadership, criticizing the Obama administration's nuclear deal. While the letter was seen as a legitimate exercise of their constitutional authority, it was widely viewed as an attempt to undermine the deal and embarrass the President. The letter's author, Senator Tom Cotton, was criticized for his tone and motives, with some seeing it as an example of blind arrogance of power.

These unforced errors are a result of the partisan nature of politics and the desire to gain power and prestige. In an age of polarization, it is not surprising that politicians would make mistakes that damage their reputation and the political process. However, it is essential to recognize that these errors have consequences and can lead to a breakdown in trust and a lack of confidence in the political system.

Ultimately, the game of politics is a game of power, and unforced errors can have significant consequences. It is crucial for politicians to recognize the importance of transparency, accountability, and responsible decision-making, and to avoid making mistakes that can damage their reputation and the political process.

Title: Attorney General Establishes Task Force to Combat Violent Anti-Government Extremists

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has established a task force aimed at combating violent anti-government extremists, according to a memo issued by Attorney General William Barr on June 26. The task force will focus on investigating and prosecuting violent acts, preventing extremist violence before it happens, and ultimately eliminating it as a threat to public safety and the rule of law.

The memo notes that some individuals who claim to profess a message of freedom and progress are actually forces of anarchy, destruction, and coercion. Barr emphasized that the task force will target those who commit violent acts, attack police officers and government officials, destroy public and private property, and threaten innocent bystanders.

The announcement comes amid ongoing protests in the wake of the police-custody death of George Floyd, who died on May 25 after a Minneapolis officer restrained him by kneeling on his neck. While most protests have been peaceful, some have descended into scenes of looting, arson, and violence.

The task force will provide training and resources to local law enforcement to arrest perpetrators of violence and work closely with the FBI to develop detailed information about violent anti-government extremist individuals, networks, and movements. The information will be shared with federal, state, and local law enforcement, especially in areas where these extremists pose a threat.

In his memo, Barr noted that extremist groups targeted by the new initiative seek to deny constitutional rights to others and resort to methods that are illegal. He emphasized that the DOJ has obtained information suggesting that some extremists intend to sow more chaos and that some may be supported by foreign entities seeking to create disorder.

The announcement coincided with President Donald Trump signing an executive order protecting American monuments, memorials, and statues from destruction.

Title: Rick Perry Suspends Presidential Campaign, Ending Bid for GOP Nomination

Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas, has suspended his campaign for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, citing his inability to gain traction in a crowded and experienced field. Perry made the announcement in a speech to the Eagle Forum in St. Louis on Friday afternoon.

Perry, who served 14 years as governor of Texas, struggled to raise money and gain momentum in the campaign. He had vowed to be more prepared and learn from his mistakes in his 2012 campaign, but ultimately failed to translate his fundraising success into votes. This time around, he faced a crowded field of current and former governors with extensive experience and fundraising abilities, and never found a niche.

Perry's decision to suspend his campaign comes less than a week before he was set to join the rest of the field for the second debate of the primary season. It is the second presidential campaign he has dropped out of, after his 2012 campaign was labeled one of the biggest failures in modern political history.

Perry's supporters, including Michael Dennehy, a strategist in New Hampshire, expressed disappointment but acknowledged the decision. "I fully support his decision," Dennehy said. "Campaigns are unpredictable, but it is a shame that a man with the most successful executive experience and the one who can best relate to middle-class America will not be on the ballot as we choose the Republican nominee."

Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union, noted that Perry struggled to rebound after being left out of the opening prime-time debate. "I knew that his demotion in Cleveland was punishing for him," Schlapp said. "It was really a body blow. He put a good face on it because he has class, but that was brutal for him."

Perry remains under indictment in Texas on corruption charges after prosecutors said he tried to use the state budget to force a local prosecutor out of office. His departure leaves just four candidates in the second-tier debate: Former Sen. Rick Santorum, former New York Gov. George Pataki, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal.

The main stage still features 11 candidates, including Businessman Donald Trump, retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, and several governors and senators.

Title: Pro-Israel Advocates Defend Stephen Bannon Against Anti-Semitism Accusations

Article:

The Zionist Organization of America (ZOA) has come to the defense of Stephen Bannon, a newly appointed chief strategist to the incoming Trump administration, against accusations of anti-Semitism and Israel-hatred. The ZOA's President, Morton Klein, released a statement expressing disappointment and frustration with the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) for character assassinating Bannon and his media company, Breitbart.

According to the ZOA, Bannon and Breitbart have a proven track record of being pro-Israel and anti-anti-Semitic. The organization points to several examples, including Bannon's involvement in fighting anti-Semitic rallies at the City University of New York (CUNY) and his company's publication of articles exposing the Palestinian Authority's defamatory claims against Israel.

The ZOA also highlights Breitbart's coverage of Iran's violations of the Iran deal, which pose an existential threat to Israel, and its reporting on the scourge of anti-Semitic anti-Israel boycotts, divestment, and sanctions (BDS).

In contrast, the ADL, led by President Jonathan Greenblatt, has accused Bannon and Breitbart of being anti-Semitic and anti-Israel. The ZOA argues that this is an Orwellian accusation, as Breitbart has consistently fought against anti-Semitism and has a history of defending Israel.

The article also questions whether Trump's pro-Israel advisors, including Newt Gingrich, Rudy Giuliani, Mike Pence, Mike Huckabee, Sheldon Adelson, and Orthodox Jews Jared Kushner, David Friedman, and Jason Greenblatt, would allow an anti-Semite or Israel-hater to work with them. It also asks why the ADL did not speak out against Hillary Clinton's advisors, who included some anti-Israel individuals, such as George Soros, a major donor to her campaign.

The ZOA is urging the ADL to withdraw its accusations against Bannon and apologize for its "inappropriate character assassination."

Title: Attorney General Sessions Directs Prosecutors to Pursue Most Serious Charges, Reversing Obama-Era Policies

Article:

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has issued a memo directing federal prosecutors to pursue the most serious charges possible against the vast majority of suspects, a move that reverses Obama-era policies aimed at easing overcrowding in federal prisons and reducing the number of people incarcerated. The new policy is expected to send more people to prison for longer terms.

The memo, sent to US attorneys on Thursday night and made public on Friday, instructs prosecutors to "charge and pursue the most serious, readily provable offense," which is likely to trigger mandatory minimum sentences. This approach is a departure from the Obama administration's "Smart on Crime" initiative, which allowed prosecutors to leave drug quantities out of charging documents to avoid triggering long sentences.

The change is a response to a perceived surge in violence in some big cities and the nation's opioid epidemic, which Sessions believes requires a return to tougher tactics. "The opioid and heroin epidemic is a contributor to the recent surge of violent crime in America," Sessions said in a speech in Charleston, West Virginia. "Drug trafficking is an inherently violent business. If you want to collect a drug debt, you can't, and don't, file a lawsuit in court. You collect it by the barrel of a gun."

The policy memo acknowledges that there may be cases where "good judgment" warrants a prosecutor to deviate from the rule, but any exceptions will require approval from top supervisors and must be documented. The memo also notes that even if prosecutors choose not to pursue the most serious charges, they must still provide judges with all the details of a case when defendants are sentenced, which could lengthen prison terms.

The change is expected to have a significant impact on the federal prison population, which has declined significantly since the Obama administration's policies were implemented. The number of federal prisoners has dropped from nearly 220,000 in 2013 to just under 190,000 today, with nearly half of those inmates incarcerated for drug crimes.

Advocates for the previous policy argue that the change will revive the worst aspects of the drug war and lead to a surge in prison populations. "It looks like we're going to fill the prisons back up after finally getting the federal prison population down," said Kevin Ring, president of Families Against Mandatory Minimums. "But the social and human costs will be much higher."

Title: Vehicle Rams NSA Headquarters in Maryland, Shots Fired, and One Fatality Reported

A vehicle attempted to ram the security gates of the National Security Agency (NSA) headquarters in Ft. Meade, Maryland, on Monday morning, leading to a confrontation with security forces. The incident resulted in shots being fired, and at least one uniformed guard was injured and taken to an ambulance.

According to reports, the vehicle, which was stolen from a hotel, collided with a police vehicle and another black vehicle with no insignia near the security gates. Debris was scattered across the intersection, and a white cloth covered something beside the black vehicle.

The NSA police force is handling the incident, with local agencies providing support. The BBC was unable to obtain an official comment from the NSA. Two people were injured during the incident, including the uniformed guard, and one fatality was reported.

CBS News reported that two women were in the vehicle attempting to ram the NSA gates, and at least one woman is dead, with the other taken to Shock Trauma for treatment. Authorities found cocaine and a weapon in the car involved in the incident. There is currently no indication of an organized terrorist attempt, with one anonymous official describing the attack as a "local criminal matter."

The gender of the individuals attacking the NSA headquarters is disputed in various reports, with NBC News claiming the two people in the car were "men disguised as women," while CNN reports the attackers were two men. The FBI will take over the investigation from the NSA's security force, and there are no links to organized terrorism.

The incident is the second recent report of trouble at NSA headquarters, following an earlier incident in which a man was arrested for firing shots at the building as part of a shooting spree that lasted several weeks.

**US Photojournalist Luke Somers Killed in Yemen During Failed Rescue Attempt**

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed on Saturday that American photojournalist Luke Somers was killed during a failed rescue attempt by US and Yemeni special forces. Somers had been held by al-Qaeda militants since his abduction in Yemen's capital of Sanaa in September 2013.

According to Hagel, there were compelling reasons to believe Somers' life was in imminent danger, and his death was described as murder at the hands of terrorists. A second hostage, South African Pierre Korkie, a teacher abducted in Yemen in May 2013 with his wife, was also killed during the failed raid.

The rescue operation involved US commandos dropping in by helicopter about a mile from the village where Somers was being held. US warplanes flew overhead for protection, but did not fire weapons. The commandos killed all the al-Qaeda-linked terrorists, with no US forces wounded.

President Obama authorized the rescue attempt due to information that Somers' life was in immediate danger, including a video released by his captors announcing he would be killed within 72 hours. The US believes the militants shot the two men during a firefight, and both were alive when American forces pulled them from a building on the group's compound and got them aboard aircraft.

Korkie is believed to have died during the flight, while American Somers died on the USS Makin Island, a Navy ship in the region. Those who knew Somers remembered him as a curious and adventurous person who wanted to understand the world.

Yemen's national security chief, Maj. Gen. Ali al-Ahmadi, said the militants had planned to kill Somers on Saturday, and an attempt was made to save him, but unfortunately, he was shot before or during the attack.

Title: Nine Members of Mormon Community Killed in Apparent Drug Cartel Attack in Northern Mexico

A violent attack on a Mormon community in northern Mexico has left nine members dead, including three women and six children. The incident occurred on Monday when a group of dual U.S.-Mexican citizens, who were part of a farming community that had settled in the area nearly a century ago, were traveling on a highway in the border state of Sonora. According to reports, one vehicle stopped due to a flat tire, and assailants attacked the stranded car, killing the driver and four children, including 6-month-old twins. The attackers then set the car on fire.

Two other cars were attacked nearby, resulting in the deaths of two women and two children. A family member described a chaotic scene where a child was gunned down while running away. At least eight survivors, including as many as seven children, are believed to have escaped, with some sustaining serious injuries. A 9-month-old was shot in the chest, and a 4-year-old was shot in the back. One 13-year-old reportedly walked 14 miles to the family's home to get help after hiding his wounded siblings in the brush.

The attack is believed to be the work of organized crime groups operating in the area, which has been plagued by violence and drug cartel activity. The Mexican government has confirmed the incident and is investigating the circumstances surrounding the attack.

Title: Billy Graham: A Legendary Evangelist Remembered and Celebrated Around the World

Billy Graham, a renowned evangelist, has been remembered and celebrated globally for his tireless efforts to spread the gospel of Christ. With a career spanning over seven decades, Graham preached the message of Jesus Christ to millions of people around the world, using every available communication technology at his disposal. His eloquence and sincerity inspired people to come to Jesus, earning him comparisons to the Apostle Paul.

Graham's life was marked by his unwavering dedication to his faith, and he continued to preach until his physical decline made it difficult. His courage and faith were an inspiration to many, as he showed how to finish well. News of his passing spread quickly, with tributes pouring in from Christians, Muslims, and Jews alike.

Graham's impact on Christianity was immense, with some estimating that he preached to more people in person than anyone in history. His crusades, broadcasts, and sermons reached millions, making him the most prominent religious celebrity of the 20th century. Even those who only saw him on TV or heard him on the radio were inspired by his message.

Those who attended his final big public events shared their impressions of the evangelist. Craig Allen, who attended his last major sermon in Baltimore in 2006, praised Graham's perseverance despite his health issues. Michael Freeland, who attended a crusade in New Orleans in 2006, felt the Holy Spirit during Graham's sermon, which gave him a sense of energy and passion. Maggie Rousseau, who drove 14 hours from Savannah, Georgia, to see Graham for the first time in New York City in 2005, felt a sense of awe and believed him.

While some have noted that Graham's impact may have diminished over time, his legacy continues to be celebrated. Robert, a Boston University religion professor, described Graham as a phenomenon of the Greatest and Boomer generations, with his message resonating with families who watched him on TV together. However, Balmer, a Dartmouth College expert on evangelical Christianity, noted that only 25% of his students raised their hands when asked who Billy Graham was, suggesting that his impact may have been limited to previous generations.

Regardless, Billy Graham's life and legacy serve as a testament to his unwavering dedication to spreading the gospel of Christ, inspiring countless people around the world to come to Jesus.

Title: US Grapples with Balancing Economic and Human Life Costs Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

The United States is facing a stark choice: continue strict social distancing and shelter-in-place measures to minimize the spread of COVID-19 and save thousands of lives, or end the lockdown and restart the economy. The decision has sparked a heated debate, with some arguing that the economic costs are too high and others believing that the human life costs are too great.

As of May 7, 2,231 Americans had died from COVID-19, bringing the total number of deaths in the United States to 75,662, and over 270,000 worldwide. The economic impact has been severe, with the Congressional Budget Office predicting a decline in the US Gross Domestic Product in the second quarter of 2020, the worst since 2008. Unemployment has skyrocketed, with 33.5 million people filing for benefits since March.

The choice between saving lives and restarting the economy is not an easy one. President Trump has emphasized the need to reopen the country, stating, "We can't keep our country closed. We have to open our country." However, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has posed a stark question: "How much is a human life worth? That is the real discussion that no one is admitting."

The federal government has largely abandoned its own standards for lifting shelter-in-place orders, and 31 states have decided to reopen, despite concerns from experts that it may lead to a second wave of infections. Texas is allowing restaurants and movie theaters to reopen at 25% capacity, while Georgia is lifting its stay-at-home order and allowing businesses to reopen.

The decision is complicated by incomplete and sometimes contradictory information about the virus and its impact on the economy. As a result, it is unclear what people will contribute to the economy even if states end official restrictions. The perception of risk has declined in recent weeks, independent of the spread of disease, according to polls.

The article raises questions about the value of human life and the trade-offs society is willing to make to save lives. Historically, governments have been willing to incur costs to save lives and improve public welfare, such as reducing air pollution to help people with asthma. However, the article suggests that there are limits to this trade-off, and that the decision to reopen the economy may not be as simple as it seems.

Title: Trump Reiterates No Amnesty for Illegal Immigrants, but Open to Working with Them

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump reiterated his stance on illegal immigration during a town hall with Sean Hannity on Wednesday, stating that there will be "no amnesty" for those who have entered the country illegally. However, he also expressed a willingness to work with them, saying that they will have to pay back taxes and meet other conditions.

Trump's remarks were the latest in a series of recent interviews where he has hinted at softening his stance on illegal immigration. During the town hall, he emphasized the difficulty of deporting individuals who have lived in the country for decades and have established families. "Now, everybody agrees we get the bad ones out," Trump said. "But when I go through and I meet thousands and thousands of people on this subject, and I've had very strong people come up to me, really great, great people come up to me, and they've said, 'Mr. Trump, I love you, but to take a person who's been here for 15 or 20 years and throw them and their family out, it's so tough, Mr. Trump.'"

Trump also touched on his stance on sanctuary cities, criticizing them for "protecting criminals" and making it difficult for police to do their jobs. "It's so hard for the police to -- if somebody is protected between the sanctuary city nonsense," Trump said. "We got to get rid of the sanctuary cities, we're protecting these people. We're protecting criminals. And the police, who are phenomenal people, they're at a point where they almost give up."

Trump is expected to unveil his new immigration policy next week during a speech in Phoenix, Arizona. The speech is scheduled to take place on August 31 at the Hyatt Regency in downtown Phoenix.

Title: Pennsylvania and Other States Hold Primaries Amid Congressional Redistricting and Senate Contests

Article:

Pennsylvania's primary elections are set to take place on Tuesday, with the state's congressional landscape being a focal point of Democrats' efforts to reclaim control of the House in November. The new congressional map, redrawn just three months ago, has led to 84 candidates running in 18 House districts, the most since 1984. Five Republican House members have quit or are not running again, creating seven vacancies, the most since 1976.

In Pennsylvania's 7th District, moderate Charlie Dent is abandoning the seat, where Hillary Clinton received more votes than Donald Trump in 2016. Six Democrats are running in this district, which reunified Democratic-leaning cities in the east and cut out some of Republican-leaning central Pennsylvania. Ten Democrats are also running in suburban Philadelphia's 5th District, where Rep. Patrick Meehan resigned last month amid allegations of sexual harassment.

In the Pennsylvania Senate primary, Rep. Lou Barletta is heavily favored to become the Republican challenger for Democratic Sen. Bob Casey, who is seeking a third term in November. Barletta was a Trump supporter before the 2016 presidential nomination was settled, and the president has backed him in recorded telephone calls.

In other states, Idaho voters will choose their Republican gubernatorial nominee, while Nebraska and Oregon are holding primaries. Nebraska's 2nd Congressional District, dominated by Omaha and its suburbs, features a Democratic primary with moderate former Rep. Brad Ashford fighting for his old seat and Kara Eastman, a children's nonprofit administrator, running to Ashford's left.

In Oregon, 10 Republicans are vying for the nomination for governor, the most in more than a century. The interest among candidates belies the uphill climb for the party in the Democratic-leaning state.

Title: US Employers Add 130,000 Jobs in August, Missing Expectations Amid Trade Uncertainty

The US labor market added 130,000 jobs in August, falling short of Wall Street's expectations. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.7%, near a 50-year low, while the labor force participation rate was little changed at 63.2%. Average hourly earnings rose 3.2% over the past year to $28.11, slightly higher than projections.

Employers added 105,000 jobs, excluding temporary workers hired for the 2020 census. Notable gains were seen in the healthcare and finance industries, which added 24,000 and 15,000 jobs, respectively. However, industries on the front line of the US-China trade war continued to report losses.

The lower-than-expected growth comes amid concerns that the current economic expansion in the US, which has reached a record length, may be slowing and potentially followed by a recession within two years. The jobs report is likely to give the Federal Reserve justification to lower short-term interest rates by a modest 25 basis points when policymakers meet in mid-September.

Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is scheduled to discuss the economic outlook in a speech later Friday in Zurich. The jobs report provides a mixed picture of the US labor market, with some industries showing growth while others continue to struggle.

Title: California Issues "Stay At Home" Order as Coronavirus Infections Rise

California Governor Gavin Newsom has issued a statewide "stay at home" order, effective immediately, in an effort to combat the growing novel coronavirus epidemic. The directive applies to the state's 40 million residents, with exceptions for essential travel and certain activities.

The order, announced late Thursday, requires people to remain in their homes, with exceptions for essential travel, such as trips to grocery stores, gas stations, farmers markets, food banks, convenience stores, takeout and delivery restaurants, banks, and laundromats. Critical infrastructure, including food and agriculture, healthcare, transportation, energy, and financial services, are also exempt.

The directive follows similar restrictions issued earlier this week for the San Francisco Bay Area. Governor Newsom emphasized the importance of taking action to protect the state's residents and the broader community, stating, "We're going to keep the grocery stores open, we're going to make sure that you're getting critical medical supplies. You can still take your kids outside, practicing common sense and social distancing. You can still walk your dog."

The order does not specify a time frame for how long it will remain in place. California is one of the hardest-hit states, with over 1,000 confirmed cases and 19 deaths attributed to COVID-19. The state's official projection estimates that up to 56% of residents could become infected, which would equate to over 22 million people.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that the total number of cases in the U.S. has surpassed 10,000, with officials believing the actual number of infections is significantly higher due to a lack of test kits. Globally, the Johns Hopkins University tally shows over 250,000 reported cases and over 10,000 deaths.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Complex Legacy on National Security

Attorney General Eric Holder's announcement that he will step down once a successor is confirmed marks the end of an era in the Obama administration's national security policy. Holder's tenure was marked by a mix of successes and controversies, leaving a complex legacy that has drawn both praise and criticism.

During his time as attorney general, Holder oversaw hundreds of terrorism-fighting successes, including the prosecution of plots to explode a bomb in Times Square and on a Detroit-bound airliner. However, he also authorized targeted drone strikes against Americans abroad, subpoenaed journalists' telephone records in leak investigations, and defended the government's bulk collection of millions of Americans' telephone records.

Professor Jonathan Hafetz of Seton Hall University Law School described Holder's legacy as "too supportive of executive power and insufficiently protective of civil liberties." While Holder was credited with overseeing a large number of terrorism prosecutions, his critics argued that he did not go far enough to distance the Justice Department from past practices.

Holder's decision to prosecute the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks and other alleged co-conspirators in a New York courtroom, rather than through the Guantanamo Bay military commission process, was met with political opposition and public safety concerns. The Obama administration eventually decided to walk away from the proposal, which was seen as a step towards closing the Guantanamo detention facility.

Despite the controversy surrounding his decision, Holder remained firm in supporting civilian courts for suspected terrorists. His Justice Department has won many convictions before American juries, and his position was vindicated by the capture, conviction, and life sentence of Osama bin Laden's son-in-law.

However, civil liberties advocates were frustrated when Holder defended the administration's legal rationale to kill American-born Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen, and refused to release the memo authorizing the strike. The ACLU cited the case as one of those where they had "profound disagreements" with Holder.

The Justice Department's crackdown on news media reporting involving national security matters also drew scrutiny, with the secret subpoenaing of Associated Press reporters and editors' phone records, and the use of a search warrant to obtain emails of a Fox News journalist in another leak investigation. Holder has since issued new guidelines for media leak investigations.

As Holder departs, his successor will face many of the same policy questions, including how to close Guantanamo and what to do with the detainees, how to handle potential foreign fighters trying to join extremist groups in Syria, and whether there is a vehicle for bringing former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden out of asylum in Russia and into a U.S. courtroom.

**U.S. Deportation Efforts for Iraqi Christians Spark Debate Over Safety**

The Trump administration's efforts to deport hundreds of Iraqi Christians have sparked a heated debate over the safety of the minority group in their homeland. While U.S. immigration officials have argued that Iraqi Christians are unlikely to be targeted in their homeland, another arm of the administration has insisted that Christians in Iraq face terror and extortion.

A senior Trump appointee at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) told a government commission that militias aligned with Iran "terrorize those families brave enough to have returned" and extort local businesses in the part of northern Iraq where many Christians live. The official, Hallam Ferguson, stated that the numbers of Christians who have returned after the defeat of the Islamic State have reached only 1 to 2% due to persecution by these militias.

In contrast, a Middle East expert, Michael Rubin, completed a sworn declaration at the request of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for use in its efforts to deport Iraqis. Rubin argued that Iraq is now a more stable country with an increasingly professional government, and Iraqi Christians are "largely immune" from politically motivated violence.

Government lawyers have submitted Rubin's statement, along with similar declarations by two other experts, to courts during immigration hearings. The assessments by Rubin and the other experts can have significant consequences, as the administration has sought to deport hundreds of Iraqis, many of them Christians, who immigrated to the U.S. years ago.

The Trump administration has emphasized the dangers faced by Christians in Iraq to support its decision to allocate hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid for them and other religious minorities in Iraq and Syria. However, lawyers for the deportees have filed declarations from human rights experts arguing that the deportees would be at risk of detention and abuse.

The debate highlights the complexities of the situation in Iraq, where religious and ethnic minorities have little faith in the government's ability to protect them against active, semiofficial armed groups. While the Iraqi government has succeeded in defeating the Islamic State and winning back control of its territory, experts warn that the country remains in a state of terminal collapse, with the continued presence of extremists and an unreliable central government making it difficult to ensure the safety of minority groups like Iraqi Christians.

Title: Virginia Election Results Show Anti-Immigrant Strategy Backfires, Driving Voters Away

The recent election in Virginia has revealed that an anti-immigrant strategy employed by Republican candidate Ed Gillespie was unsuccessful, according to polling data and election results. Despite initial predictions that the strategy would resonate with voters, majorities of voters from all racial and ethnic groups rejected the anti-immigrant rhetoric as "ugly and wrong."

A survey conducted by Latino Decisions found that Latino voters were less enthusiastic about Gillespie after being exposed to his MS-13 ads, with a 45-point margin against him. Similarly, white voters, African-American voters, and Asian-American voters also turned away from Gillespie, with larger margins.

Data analysis revealed that exposure to Gillespie's MS-13 ads drove white college-educated voters away from the Republican candidate, and those who were aware of the ads were more likely to vote for his Democratic opponent. This trend was not limited to the governor's race, as the Gillespie campaign had coattail effects, but of the wrong kind. Across all racial groups, those who were aware of Gillespie's MS-13 ads were more likely to vote for Democratic candidates for the Virginia House of Delegates.

The results suggest that positioning oneself as against hatred and bigotry, and in favor of inclusiveness and opportunity, is not only morally just but also a winning strategy. The Democratic Party can capitalize on this by speaking out strongly against bigotry and welcoming messages to Latino, African-American, and Asian-American voters, while also winning over white voters who oppose immigrant bashing.

The implications are significant, particularly for voters who will decide crucial House and Senate races in 2018. The results show that voters are aware of the anti-immigrant rhetoric and are rejecting it. Democrats have an opportunity to capitalize on this and speak out against bigotry, which could lead to victory in 2018 and beyond.

Title: Trump Calls for "Red Wave" to Pass Immigration Bill, Accuses Democrats of Obstruction

President Donald Trump tweeted on Friday that a "red wave" is needed to pass an immigration bill in Congress, as he accused Democrats of "doing nothing but obstructing." Trump's call comes after the Republican-led Congress pulled a major immigration bill from consideration late Thursday, pushing a vote into next week.

The bill, which was a compromise measure, aimed to address the decades-old problem of illegal immigration. It included a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants brought to the country as children, border security, and an end to "chain migration" and the diversity lottery visa. However, a sticking point for conservatives is that the compromise also offers a pathway to citizenship for 1.8 million young illegal immigrants, while the conservative bill only offers indefinite renewals of non-immigrant status for 700,000 recipients of the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., called the compromise "not a compromise" and "may be a compromise with the devil, but it is not a compromise with the Democrats." Trump, on the other hand, extended an invitation to Democrats to the White House to discuss immigration, saying "it takes two to tango." However, he also had scathing words for what he called the "extremist, open border" lawmakers.

Trump's tweets come after a fiery week in which rhetoric on both sides has escalated on the question of the administration's "zero tolerance" policy, which prosecutes all illegal border crossers. The policy led to an increase in the number of children being separated from their parents. Trump signed an executive order Wednesday ending the practice and allowing families to be detained together, but Democrats have since pushed for ending what they described as "indefinite detention" of families at the border.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu Clarifies Stance on Palestinian State

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been accused of flip-flopping on his stance on a Palestinian state after a recent interview with the conservative Israeli publication NRG. However, a closer examination of the interview reveals that Netanyahu's comments were misinterpreted by the Western media.

According to the interview, Netanyahu stated that building a Palestinian state "today" would be giving territory to radical Islam, citing the reality created in recent years. He also expressed concerns about the left's willingness to join international initiatives to return to the 1967 borders and divide Jerusalem. This has led to accusations that Netanyahu has disavowed his previous support for a Palestinian state.

However, a review of Netanyahu's past statements shows that he has consistently expressed support for the possibility of a Palestinian state. In a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University, Netanyahu expressed his willingness to consider a Palestinian state, stating that it was a "realistic" and "practical" solution.

The media's misinterpretation of Netanyahu's comments has been widely criticized, with many accusing Ha'aretz, a left-wing Israeli newspaper, of running with a false story. The media's failure to fact-check the story and verify the accuracy of Netanyahu's quotes has led to a widespread misunderstanding of his stance on the issue.

In conclusion, Netanyahu's comments have been misinterpreted and taken out of context, leading to a false narrative about his stance on a Palestinian state. A closer examination of his past statements and the context of the interview reveals that Netanyahu's views on the issue have not changed.

Title: Cruz Dares Trump to Sue Over Abortion Ad, Calls Threats "Frivolous"

The presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz has refused to back down from an ad questioning Donald Trump's record on abortion, despite the Trump campaign's cease-and-desist letter and threats of a lawsuit. The ad, which features footage of Trump stating he is "very pro-choice" in a 1999 interview, claims that voters "can't trust" Trump with serious decisions.

Cruz, a Harvard Law School graduate and former Texas attorney general, has defended the ad, calling the Trump campaign's threats "frivolous" and saying that a lawsuit against the ad has no chance. At a press conference in South Carolina, Cruz read from the cease-and-desist letter, calling it "one of the most remarkable letters I have ever read," and challenged Trump to go through with his threatened suit.

The Trump campaign has accused the Cruz campaign of running an ad "replete with outright lies, false, defamatory, and destructive statements" and threatened to hold Cruz liable for damages if the ad is not taken down. However, Cruz's campaign has refused to back down, saying that voters "deserve to know the truth."

The feud between the two candidates has escalated since the Trump campaign sent the cease-and-desist letter, with Trump regularly calling Cruz a liar and Cruz ridiculing Trump over his lawsuit threat. The dispute has also led to a separate feud between Cruz and Senator Marco Rubio over alleged dirty tricks leading up to the South Carolina GOP primary.

Title: Report Alleges President Trump Directed Former Lawyer Michael Cohen to Lie About Trump Tower Project in Moscow

Article: According to a recent report by BuzzFeed, President Trump allegedly instructed his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, to lie about the Trump Tower project in Moscow. Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying about the deal in his testimony and a two-page statement to the Senate and House intelligence committees. Special counsel Robert Mueller noted that Cohen's false claim that the project ended in January 2016 was an attempt to "minimize links between the Moscow Project and Individual 1" - widely understood to be Trump - "in hopes of limiting the ongoing Russia investigations."

The report claims that Cohen told the special counsel that after the election, President Trump personally instructed him to lie, claiming that negotiations ended months earlier than they actually did, in order to obscure Trump's involvement. If true, this could be the most serious threat to Trump's presidency, according to Rep. David Cicilline (D-RI), who reacted to the news on CNN.

Cicilline and Rep. Ted Lieu (D-CA) concluded that BuzzFeed has proven the president is guilty of obstruction of justice, stating that if the President directed Cohen to lie to Congress, that is obstruction of justice. They also called for the House Judiciary Committee to start holding hearings to establish a record of whether the President committed high crimes.

The congressmen demanded that they and their colleagues be given a chance to investigate the allegations, with Cicilline stating that they should wait for the reports to be confirmed before calling for an investigation. However, when asked if he had evidence to prove Trump told Cohen to lie, Cicilline admitted that he had not seen the evidence referenced in the article.

One of the authors of the BuzzFeed report, Anthony Cormier, stood by his reporting on CNN, stating that it was "100 percent" true. The report has yet to be confirmed or corroborated, and further investigation is needed to determine the accuracy of the allegations.

Title: House Speaker Boehner: Republicans Won't Agree to Debt Ceiling Increase Without Conditions to Rein in Deficit Spending

House Speaker John Boehner stated on Sunday that Republican lawmakers will not agree to a debt ceiling increase unless it includes conditions to rein in deficit spending. When asked if the Republican-led House would pass a "clean" debt ceiling increase with no conditions, Boehner replied, "I told the president, there's no way we're going to pass one." He emphasized that the country cannot simply raise the debt limit without addressing the underlying problem of deficit spending.

Boehner also reiterated that Republicans will demand concessions for any bill to reopen the government, specifically changes to President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, known as Obamacare. The Democratic-led Senate has rejected this demand. Obama has stated that it is the responsibility of Congress to raise the debt limit by an October 17 deadline, when the government will begin running short of funds to pay its bills. He has also refused to negotiate with Republicans over the issue.

On the government shutdown, Boehner said there have been "absolutely no" changes in the Republican position on the bill to fund government agencies. He stated that there are not enough votes in the House to pass a "clean" continuing resolution on the budget to reopen the government. When asked about a group of 195 House Democrats and 21 Republicans who have expressed willingness to pass a six-week "clean CR" without defunding Obamacare, Boehner replied, "There may be a back room somewhere, but there's nobody in it."

Boehner repeated the recent GOP line that his party has tried to compromise by passing several bills that would fund parts of the government while talks continue. Democrats have rejected these bills, saying they are a ploy to fund every part of government except the Affordable Care Act.

Title: US Air Campaign Against Islamic State Criticized for Limited Effectiveness

The US-led air campaign against the Islamic State (IS) and the Khorasan Group has been criticized for its limited effectiveness, with some experts pointing to a spared bombing target in Syria as an example. Photos of the aftermath of a US-led airstrike showed that the Islamic State finance center's rooftop communications array had been destroyed, but the building itself was left intact.

The limited effectiveness of the airstrikes is further diminished by the Iraqi security forces' decidedly mixed results in combat and inability to reverse most gains of the Islamic State, also known by the acronyms ISIL and ISIS. Iraqi troops also lack a key skill in a badly needed mission: finding and designating ground targets for US warplanes, making the American air campaign more difficult.

A retired CIA operative, Bart Bechtel, expressed frustration with the limited scope of the airstrikes, stating, "I was mad as hell when I saw the hit on a supposed ISIL building. The right question is: Why not the whole building?" A retired Air Force general who has remained in touch with the jet fighter community also criticized the air war, saying it is too narrow, with not enough planes, heavy ordnance, or sorties.

The US Central Command has conducted 190 airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq since August 8, less than an average of four per day. The airstrikes have focused on targets such as vehicles, fighters, and riverboats, but not command sites that the Islamic State has set up across Iraq in urban-type surroundings that are more difficult to strike.

The air war continues without American combat troops on the ground to uproot Islamic State positions. Iraqis have shown little ability to carry out such missions or to spot targets for US warplanes. The current setup relies on joint command centers radioing the positions of the enemy to Iraqis and US pilots based on video feeds from unmanned aircraft and other intelligence assets.

A retired military officer who visits Baghdad routinely and works with Iraqi defense officials expressed concerns about the mission gap, stating that ground spotters need a critical piece of equipment: a multiband radio that connects them to other combatants and to pilots overhead. Conventional forces also have no specialized units set up to spot targets.

The US air campaign is expected to continue for years, with the Pentagon stating that it could take a long time to defeat the Islamic State. The Iraqi army has shown itself unable or unwilling to stand up to the Islamic State, and the country's special operations arm, also referred to as counterterrorism units, are more proficient.

Title: Trump Considers Restricting Domestic Flights to Combat Coronavirus Spread

The Trump administration is considering ordering airlines to reduce domestic flights in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus between cities already affected by the pandemic. However, President Trump has not ruled out issuing a national stay-at-home order, stating that it is not necessary in some states where the virus has not had a significant impact.

Some governors have taken action in the travel space, with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis ordering anyone flying to Florida from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut to self-isolate for 14 days. Alaska and Hawaii have also implemented similar measures, requiring anyone arriving from other states to self-quarantine.

Trump expressed concerns about restricting domestic flights, citing the potential hardship it would impose on the airline industry. "Once you do that, you are clamping down on an industry that is desperately needed," he said. Airlines, industry officials, and health experts emphasize that flights are an essential service, providing transportation for people and cargo, and should continue during the crisis.

The federal government has underscored this position by including a provision in the $2 trillion coronavirus aid package, which requires airlines that accept a share of the $50 billion set aside for the industry to maintain a minimum level of service through at least September.

Title: Obama Administration Officials Concerned About Upcoming Publicity on Healthcare.gov
