The Obama administration is bracing for potential criticism and scrutiny as the healthcare.gov website is expected to face scrutiny over high insurance plan prices and limited choices. According to War Room notes obtained by CNN, project managers are concerned that once individuals begin selecting plans on the improved website, media attention will focus on their choices and potential issues that may arise. In some cases, there may be fewer options than desired to promote consumer choice and an ideal shopping experience. Additionally, some plans may have relatively high costs.

The concerns come as the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has faced criticism over its impact on rural areas. According to The Times, rural areas have fewer insurance companies offering plans in the new online insurance exchanges, with over 500 counties having only one insurer participating. The War Room notes also mentioned "problem plans" and a certification issue possibly due to a misspelling on the website.

The high cost of coverage under the new law has already been reported, with a Manhattan Institute analysis showing that Obamacare will increase underlying premiums by 41% on average in most states. Before the law's online healthcare markets launched on October 1, the administration estimated nearly 500,000 people would enroll in subsidized private insurance within the first month. However, a computer system issue has prevented most from doing so.

Recent reports have also shown that at least 3.5 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their private carriers due to their coverage not meeting the standards set by the Affordable Care Act. The exact number is unclear, as data from half the states is still unavailable. The administration has refused to release official Obamacare insurance plan enrollment numbers until mid-November, when a crash effort to fix computer issues may be showing results. Despite the challenges, numbers are expected to be disappointingly low.

Title: Romney Campaign Raises $4.2 Million Following Supreme Court Ruling, Obama Campaign Faces Funding Challenges

The Romney campaign has received a significant influx of funds following the Supreme Court's ruling on the Obama administration's tax policy, with a total of $4.2 million raised in the past 24 hours. This surge in donations comes as the campaign has pledged to repeal the entire bill on its first day in office if elected.

In a recent email, President Obama acknowledged the financial disparity between his campaign and Romney's, stating that he will be the first president in modern history to be outspent in his re-election campaign. The Obama campaign has raised a significant portion of its funds from small donors, with almost three-quarters of its money coming from individuals giving less than $1,000. In contrast, the Romney campaign has received more than three-quarters of its funds from individuals giving $1,000 or more.

The Obama campaign has emphasized the importance of grassroots support, with over 2.2 million Americans having contributed to the campaign. The campaign is facing a fundraising deadline this week and is urging supporters to donate $3 or more to help bridge the financial gap. Donations also enter individuals into a drawing to attend a grassroots dinner with the Obama family.

In contrast, the Romney campaign has received significant support from large donors and super PACs, with some estimates suggesting an additional $1 billion in outside spending. The campaign has not disclosed the identities of its major donors, but has emphasized its commitment to transparency and accountability.

Title: Obama's Farewell Address: A Call to Action for Civic Engagement and Unity

In his farewell speech to the nation, President Barack Obama emphasized the importance of civic engagement and unity, urging Americans to take action to address the country's pressing issues. The former president highlighted the need to address inequality, racial divisions, and the decline of fact-based consensus, warning that these threats pose a danger to democracy. He encouraged Americans to "lace up their shoes and do some organizing" and to accept the responsibility of citizenship.

Obama also touched on his post-presidency plans, which include doubling down on his commitment to Organizing for America, a group that supports his agenda, and working on redistricting congressional districts. He will also be involved in his presidential library and foundation, as well as writing a memoir.

The article notes that Obama's post-presidency promises to be more than just a return to his roots as a community organizer. With his young age and health, he is likely to be actively involved in politics, possibly even serving as an informal Democratic adviser to his successor. However, he has also implied that he will not stay silent if he perceives a threat to core American values.

In his speech, Obama framed his exhortations on civic engagement in a broad, nonpartisan way, calling for Americans to reengage in the hard work of forming a more perfect union. He encouraged those who are disappointed with their elected officials to "grab a clipboard, get some signatures, and run for office yourself."

Title: Obama's Economic Legacy: A Mixed Bag of Performance and Perception

The US economy has shown signs of growth in the second quarter, with a 4.6% increase in GDP. However, this growth is not enough to erase the perception that President Obama's economic policies have not delivered a strong recovery. The article argues that the economy's performance under Obama's presidency has been marked by slow growth, with only one quarter exceeding 4.6% growth during his entire presidency. The article also notes that the economy's growth has been below 2% in 10 of the 22 quarters during his presidency.

The article highlights that the economy's impact on people can be measured more directly than just a statistical growth rate. The unemployment rate has remained high, with a 5.9% rate in the latest month, which is the lowest rate during Obama's presidency. However, the average annual unemployment rate for his first five years in office was 6.9%, which is higher than the average rate during the previous administration.

The article also notes that the economy has received substantial assistance from the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and fiscal policy, which has held interest rates at roughly zero percent for almost the entirety of Obama's time in office. The federal debt held by the public has more than doubled during his presidency, growing 106% from 2008 to 2013.

The article concludes that Obama's problem with the economy runs deeper than just economics, citing his association with the subpar economy of the past five years and the fact that Americans are not accustomed to persistent failure. The article suggests that Obama should be counting his blessings for what little respect he has earned for his economy's dismal performance.

Title: Obama's Second Term Challenges: A Legacy in the Balance

The second term of a presidency can be a challenging time for any leader, as President Barack Obama is currently experiencing. Despite criticism that he has been too passive, Obama's advisors argue that his approach is a deliberate strategy to focus on long-term goals rather than getting bogged down in short-term political battles.

The Congressional Budget Office's recent announcement of a sharp drop in the projected deficit serves as a reminder that Obama's economic policies have had a significant impact on the country. However, the latest setbacks, including the failure to pass gun control legislation and the controversy surrounding the administration's handling of the Benghazi attack, have raised questions about Obama's ability to drive his agenda.

Obama's advisors point out that the second term of a presidency is often marked by challenges and setbacks, citing examples from previous presidents such as Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush. Despite these challenges, Obama's team remains focused on his long-term goals, including reducing the national debt and promoting economic growth.

In an interview, Obama's senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer noted that being in office for nearly four and a half years gives the president a unique perspective, allowing him to separate the signal from the noise and focus on what truly matters. When dealing with real-life problems, political ones seem smaller and less impactful.

Overall, Obama's second term is a complex and challenging time, marked by both progress and setbacks. While some may question his leadership style, Obama's advisors believe that his approach is a deliberate strategy to achieve his long-term goals, rather than getting bogged down in short-term political battles.

Title: Holder and Justice Department Under Fire Over Fast and Furious Operation

The parents of murdered border agent Brian Terry have expressed their frustration and suspicion that Attorney General Eric Holder and other Justice Department officials are "hiding something" in their response to the botched anti-gunrunning operation Fast and Furious. The operation, which aimed to track illicit guns to bigger traffickers, allowed many of the guns to "walk" into Mexico, with two of them later found at the crime scene where Terry was killed in December 2010.

A House panel voted along party lines to recommend holding Holder in contempt of Congress for not handing over a trove of documents related to Fast and Furious. President Obama has asserted executive privilege in keeping many of the documents out of public view. Holder has testified that he only found out about the operation after Terry's death and condemned the tactics. However, GOP lawmakers have suggested that top officials at the Justice Department knew more about the operation than they have said.

Terry's parents, Kent and Josephine Terry, expressed their disappointment and anger over the Obama administration's handling of the situation, stating that they are "upset that the administration may be preventing them from getting the full story about how their son died." They believe that Holder and other officials are "hiding something big" and that "something happened out there."

The controversy surrounding Fast and Furious has raised questions about the power of the presidency and the limits of executive privilege. The Department of Justice has defended its response, with Holder stating that he made an "extraordinary offer" to Issa, the committee chairman. The developments come as Holder tries to negotiate a way to avert the contempt proceedings and provide some documents in response to House Republicans' subpoena.

Title: White House Proposes 5% Across-the-Board Cut in Domestic Spending as Part of 2020 Budget

The White House has revealed that President Trump's proposed 2020 budget will include a 5% across-the-board cut in domestic spending. According to Larry Kudlow, the White House economic adviser, this cut is part of a broader effort to reduce the federal budget deficit. Kudlow stated that the budget will contain a proposed 5% reduction in domestic spending, with some domestic programs favored by lawmakers in both parties potentially facing cuts.

The proposed budget will also maintain the 3% tax cuts implemented in 2018, with Kudlow arguing that rapid growth is necessary to address budget deficits. The budget will not include any cuts to Medicare or Social Security, with Kudlow stating that these programs are "politically popular" and should be left alone.

The proposed budget will also include additional funding for the construction of a border wall, with Trump requesting at least $8.6 billion in new funding and $5 billion in additional funds for the Department of Homeland Security. Kudlow emphasized the importance of border security, citing the "crisis" of economics, crime, and humanity along the US-Mexico border.

It is worth noting that the proposed budget does not address the main factors behind the growing federal deficit, including the 2017 tax cut and increasing spending for the Pentagon and domestic agencies. The budget also does not include any plans to curb Medicare or Social Security, which are the chief drivers of the deficit.

Title: Senator Lindsey Graham Urges President Trump to Confront Russian Meddling and Offers Insights on Supreme Court Nominees

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina, has urged President Trump to directly confront Russian President Vladimir Putin about meddling in the US political process during their upcoming one-on-one meeting in Helsinki. Graham emphasized that Putin should not be allowed to deny the allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 election, stating, "When Putin denies that he was involved in our election in 2016, reject the denial -- challenge him, don't let him deny the obvious."

Graham also expressed concerns about Russian influence in Turkey, describing the country as "an ally adrift" after the re-election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan amid government purges. However, he acknowledged that Turkey is a new chapter in the region.

On the topic of North Korea, Graham attributed the country's criticism of US rhetoric as "gangster-like" to Chinese influence. He stated, "I see China's hands all over this. We're in a fight with China... If I were President Trump, I would not let China use North Korea to back me off of the trade dispute."

Regarding the Supreme Court nomination process, Graham praised the four potential nominees being considered by President Trump, describing them as "winners." He particularly highlighted Thomas Hardiman, a Third Circuit Court of Appeals judge, who has been compared to Supreme Court Associate Justice Samuel Alito. Graham believes that all four nominees are strong choices for conservatives and that Republicans should support them.

However, Graham also criticized the partisanship in the Senate, stating that even George Washington would struggle to secure Democratic votes for a conservative nominee. He warned that the nomination will be a "nightmare for red-state Democrats" who risk angering their constituents if they oppose Trump's pick.

The article concludes with a quote from Fox News political analyst Juan Williams, who emphasized the importance of the Supreme Court nomination and the potential for a conservative justice to be appointed, which could lead to a perception of the court as a rubber stamp for a conservative social agenda.

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Consider Allowing Voters to Revise Presidential Ballots After Candidates Drop Out

Article:

Colorado voters who have already submitted their ballots with votes for presidential candidates who have since dropped out of the race cannot redo their ballots this year. However, lawmakers are discussing the possibility of allowing voters to revise their choices in future presidential primaries. The issue arose due to the state's all-mail ballot system, which encourages voters to submit their ballots early. This means that some voters may have selected candidates who are no longer in the race, such as Pete Buttigieg.

Colorado Secretary of State Jena Griswold noted that voters who have not yet returned their ballots can still obtain new ballots or cross out their previous selection and choose a new candidate. However, those who have already submitted their ballots cannot receive a replacement ballot.

House Majority Leader Alec Garnett believes that voters should have the opportunity to change their minds, even if their initial choice has dropped out of the race. He suggests that lawmakers should consider a statutory change to allow voters to make their voices heard through Election Day. Garnett has not yet discussed specific solutions with lawmakers, but has heard from constituents who are frustrated by the current situation.

Senate Majority Leader Steve Fenberg also acknowledges that voters are frustrated by the inability to change their votes and believes that lawmakers can tackle this issue in future elections. While he is unsure of the exact solution, he thinks it is worth exploring.

The issue is particularly relevant in Colorado, which is one of only four states that holds all-mail ballot elections. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that some candidates who dropped out of the race, such as Buttigieg, could still receive delegates because they had significant support.

Title: Michael Cohen Admits to Hiring IT Firm to Influence Polls for Donald Trump's Presidential Campaign

Article:

Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer and fixer for Donald Trump, has confirmed that he hired an IT firm, RedFinch Solutions LLC, to influence polls in favor of Trump's presidential campaign in 2015. According to the Wall Street Journal, Cohen paid the firm $12,000 to $13,000 in cash, but failed to pay the remaining $37,000. John Gauger, the owner of RedFinch Solutions, told the newspaper that he was asked to manipulate the results of a CNBC poll and a Drudge Report ranking in 2014 and 2015, respectively, but was unsuccessful in getting Trump into the top 100.

Cohen confirmed the revelations on Twitter, stating that he acted at the direction of and for the sole benefit of Trump. He also expressed regret for his "blind loyalty" to the president. The Trump Organization did not comment on the matter, but Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of Trump's lawyers, called Cohen a "thief."

The Wall Street Journal reported that Cohen requested a $50,000 reimbursement for "tech services" from the Trump Tower Organization in 2017, which was noted in a federal charging document filed in August 2018. Cohen was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations, bank fraud, and lying to Congress. None of the charges are connected to his dealings with RedFinch.

The article also mentions that Cohen created the Twitter account "@WomenForCohen," which still exists, and performed other services for Cohen unrelated to the president.

Title: Pelosi Considers Delaying Impeachment Articles to Senate Amid Concerns Over Fairness

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has sparked a new twist in the impeachment process by hinting that she may delay transmitting the articles of impeachment to the Senate, where Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated he is coordinating trial strategy with the White House. This move gained momentum after McConnell's declaration that he has little interest in serving as an impartial overseer of the Senate trial.

Some legal scholars, including constitutional lawyer Laurence Tribe, have suggested that Democrats delay sending the articles to the Senate until McConnell agrees to run a fairer process. Tribe argued that under the current circumstances, the trial would fail to render a meaningful verdict of acquittal.

Pelosi's remarks, which were barely audible above the camera shutters, were unexpected and prompted reporters to shout over each other, generating confusion about the next steps in the impeachment process. When asked if she would send the articles to the Senate, Pelosi responded, "You're asking me, 'So are we all going to go out and play in the snow?' That has not been part of our conversations."

The House Judiciary Committee Democrats, including Chairman Jerry Nadler, emphasized that the only story that matters is the president's impeachment. "We defended the Constitution and we defended our democracy," Nadler said. "Right now, that's the story."

Some Democrats believe that delaying the transmission of the articles could give them more time to build on their evidence and potentially score additional legal victories that could unlock troves of new evidence and witness testimony that the Trump administration has withheld from Congress. Representative Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) said Pelosi has indicated she is interested in considering the idea and has received support from some colleagues.

The House has not yet named impeachment managers, and Pelosi will be empowered to pick them at her discretion and without a deadline. The House needs to name managers in order to transmit the articles to the Senate.

Title: Democrats Face Challenges in Defending Obamacare in New Hampshire Midterm Elections

In the lead-up to the November midterm elections, Democratic lawmakers in the United States are growing more confident in their ability to use the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, as a draw rather than a liability. Three races in New Hampshire illustrate the challenge, offering a test of whether Democrats can overcome voter skepticism about the 2010 healthcare law.

The law, aimed at expanding health insurance coverage to millions more Americans, has come under sustained attack from Republicans. President Barack Obama has urged Democrats campaigning in the elections not to run away from Obamacare but instead to "forcefully defend" it. The president has said that a surge in enrollment shows the system is running smoothly now, after its disastrous debut last October.

New Hampshire, which is closely divided between Democrats and Republicans, is one of about 10 states where Republicans hope to make gains in order to put the Democratic-led Senate under their control. Senators Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, Kay Hagan of North Carolina, and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana have been among the Democratic targets of anti-Obamacare ads by conservative groups such as Americans for Prosperity.

Republicans are counting on voter antipathy toward Obamacare to try to take charge of the Senate and expand their majority in the House of Representatives. However, while Obamacare may now be working better, national polls clearly show more people disapprove than approve of the law.

In New Hampshire, Shaheen and Representative Carol Shea-Porter, a fellow Democrat, were among the earliest advocates of the healthcare law. The state's other Democratic Representative, Ann Kuster, was elected after the law passed, but also backs it. Shaheen said in an interview that as Americans get to know Obamacare, they are embracing it. She said there was "a lot of misinformation" about the law. "The reality is it's beginning to work for people," she said.

However, 51% of New Hampshire adults oppose Obamacare while just 37% support it, the University of New Hampshire Survey Center reported last month in a WMUR-Granite State poll. Sixty-one percent of the state's voters think medical costs will increase under the act.

Skeptics include people like Derek Gagnon, a 33-year-old auto mechanic who says he would not even consider voting for anyone who had backed the Affordable Care Act. He has no health insurance, but he also says he has no intention of signing up for the private insurance offered through the government-run website, HealthCare.gov. "I shouldn't be forced to do something like that in a free country," said Gagnon, referring to the law's requirement, known as the "individual mandate," that almost all legal U.S. residents buy health insurance or pay a fine.

Obamacare is meant to extend subsidized health coverage to millions of uninsured Americans through new online private insurance markets and an expansion of the Medicaid program for the poor. However, conservative critics portray it as a government intrusion in a major sector of the economy that will hurt job growth and erode freedoms.

Shaheen's leading Republican opponent in the Senate race, Scott Brown, is betting that theme will resonate in New Hampshire, where the state's famous motto is "Live Free or Die." In April, Brown kicked off his candidacy with the declaration that New Hampshire could "Live Free or Log On" - a caustic reference to signing up online for Obamacare. Lately, he has been traveling the state on an "Obamacare Isn't Working" tour. Brown, a former senator from neighboring Massachusetts, says the act should be completely repealed and the issue of healthcare reform should be left to the states.

Brown has been rising in the polls against Shaheen. But she was ahead 45 to 39 percent in a recent WMUR-Granite State poll. Dean Spiliotes, a New Hampshire political analyst, said Shaheen, a former New Hampshire governor, still had political capital in the state, and he doubted the healthcare issue alone could defeat her. "People view her as not an ideologue. That has helped her with voters," said Spiliotes, a political science professor at Southern New Hampshire University. "If Obamacare rises to the level of taking out Jeanne Shaheen, there is something larger going on."

To be sure, Obamacare faces unique challenges in New Hampshire. Just one insurance company in the small state offered insurance policies through the program this year, and the insurer does not cover healthcare in 10 of the state's 26 hospitals, deficits Shaheen and Shea-Porter have been working to fix.

Spiliotes said New Hampshire Democrats are defending Obamacare "but they are kind of doing it in fits and starts. It's not a uniform, rah-rah kind of support." In one hopeful sign for Democrats, enrollment in Obamacare in the state of 1.3 million people has reached 40,000 - double the number that had been expected.

Shea-Porter, a former social worker who came to Congress in 2006 campaigning on healthcare reform, said she would never run away from Obamacare because she considers the law to be a "great joy and triumph." That said, she understands the political perils for Democrats of Obamacare. She lost her seat in Congress in 2010 elections after her vote for the law, only to be re-elected in 2012. Her 2014 race is considered a toss-up although her Republican opponent has yet to be chosen in a September primary.

Shea-Porter, who met last week with recent healthcare enrollees in Somersworth, said she is aware of the qualms some people have, including wariness of providing personal information on a government website. But she said the best way to advertise Obamacare's benefits is to publicize the stories of people who signed up and discovered that "nothing terrible happened." Patrice Glynn, 54-year-old New Hampshire resident, is already convinced. Glynn, a diabetic, lived without health insurance for nine months after she lost her job and before she signed up on HealthCare.gov. "If it was so bad, would 40,000 people be on it?" she asked.

Title: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman Resigns Amidst Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has resigned from his position, effective Tuesday, following allegations of sexual misconduct and abuse by four women. The allegations, published in The New Yorker, include claims of physical and emotional abuse, with one accuser stating that Schneiderman choked her and referred to her as his "brown slave."

Schneiderman had gained a reputation as a champion of women's rights and a vocal critic of President Trump, earning him the nickname "Schneider-Man" and a superhero persona on the TV show "Full Frontal." However, the allegations have now tarnished his reputation and led to widespread condemnation from both sides of the political aisle.

The women who came forward shared their experiences with The New Yorker, describing a pattern of behavior that included physical and emotional abuse. Michelle Manning Barish, one of the accusers, stated, "You can't be a champion of women when you're hitting them and choking them in bed, and saying to them, 'You're a f---ing whore.'"

Schneiderman denied the allegations, stating that he had engaged in consensual role-playing and sexual activity, but did not assault anyone. However, his resignation came just hours after the article was published, and fellow New York Democrat Andrew Cuomo called the allegations "damning" and called for Schneiderman to resign.

The news has sparked a wave of reactions from both sides of the political aisle, with some Republicans, including Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway and Donald Trump Jr., gloating over Schneiderman's downfall. However, others have expressed disappointment and outrage at the allegations, and the need for accountability and consequences for those who abuse their power.

The resignation of Eric Schneiderman serves as a reminder that no one is above the law, and that those in positions of power must be held accountable for their actions.

Title: Obamacare Fixes May Do More Harm Than Good, Experts Warn

Article:

The Obama administration and lawmakers have proposed various fixes to address the issues surrounding the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), but experts warn that these solutions may do more harm than good. The fixes aim to allow millions of Americans whose health insurance is being canceled to keep their plans and doctors, as originally promised by President Obama. However, this could lead to actuarial trouble, as healthier individuals would remain outside the Obamacare pool, making it difficult for the system to sustain itself.

According to an Associated Press survey, at least 4.2 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their insurers. This group tends to be healthier than the uninsured, who will be most attracted to Obamacare. If these healthier individuals are allowed to remain outside the system, it could lead to higher premiums and potentially an insurance system that cannot support itself.

State insurance commissioners argue that bringing back canceled policies would violate new state laws that prohibit "substandard" plans. California and New York are among the states that have implemented such laws. A reversal could add to the confusion and lack of confidence already surrounding Obamacare.

Experts warn that the crisis of confidence in the new health-care system could be debilitating. Larry Kocot, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution, notes that the rollout of Obamacare has "surpassed glitches" and is very difficult to address.

Despite the downsides, lawmakers are pushing for fixes to address the blowback from those unhappy with the cancellations. Obama's approval rating has sunk to 39%, and real people are facing higher premiums and deductibles. On Thursday, Obama announced an executive fix that leaves it up to insurers and states to allow people to return to their old health plans if they want to.

However, most Democrats do not like this bill, and Obama has promised to veto it, as it would allow new customers to sign on to canceled plans, potentially worsening the outlook for Obamacare's sustainability. Instead, Democrats are working on their own legislation. The outcome is uncertain, but the rollout is producing problems beyond a broken website. Fixing them is like pulling on a loose thread, and things start to unravel.

Title: Google Search Results Show Bias Toward Left-Leaning News, Report Finds

A recent report from media technology group AllSides has found that Google News and Google News search results have a strong preference for media outlets with a left-leaning perspective. The report analyzed the Google News homepage and search engine results over a two-week period from August 23 to September 5. According to the findings, the overall bias of Google News was approximately 65% toward the left, 20% toward the center, and 16% to the right.

The report also found that left-leaning news was almost always one of the top two results displayed, while news from the center of the political spectrum was less visible, usually appearing in the top five or six results. Right-leaning news, on the other hand, often required users to scroll down the page to find.

When news from the left competed with news from other viewpoints, the left won almost every time, with 91% of the time favoring the left over the right. Even when competing against the center, the left still dominated, winning 80% of the time.

The report did not suggest that Google intentionally favors left-leaning media sources, but rather that the algorithm's selection of links and ranking of results may be influenced by the political leanings of online news consumers, who tend to be younger and more left-leaning than the average American.

Google denied any allegations of political bias, stating that their goal is to provide the most relevant answers to users' queries and that search results are not used to set a political agenda. The company emphasized its commitment to truth and accuracy in all of its journalism.

Title: Indonesia Raises Minimum Marriage Age for Girls to 19, a Step Towards Ending Child Marriage

Indonesia has taken a significant step towards eradicating child marriage by raising the minimum age for girls to marry from 16 to 19. This decision was prompted by the country's Constitutional Court ruling that it was discriminatory to have a lower minimum age for girls than for boys. The move is a response to the widespread practice of child marriage in Indonesia, which has the eighth-highest number of child brides in the world, according to the United Nations.

While Indonesia's new policy is a step in the right direction, it is not the only country struggling with the issue. According to UNICEF, 14% of Indonesian women marry before reaching 18 years old, compared to 59% in Bangladesh and 76% in Niger. Nineteen of the 20 countries where child marriage is most prevalent are in Africa.

Families often marry off their daughters at a young age in an attempt to ensure their stability and security. However, this practice is often linked to rigid gender norms, conflict, and poverty. Education is a crucial factor, as a World Bank study found that girls without schooling are three times more likely to be married by 18 than those with secondary education.

Child marriage can have severe consequences, including increased risk of sexual violence, poorer health, and higher school drop-out rates. Girls who marry are also less likely to participate in the labor force, which has significant economic costs. A 2015 study estimated that child marriage cost Indonesia's economy 1.7% of GDP in 2014. The welfare benefit of ending the practice worldwide is estimated to be worth around $22 billion.

Indonesia's new policy is a significant step towards ending child marriage, but lawmakers will need to demonstrate that it is more than a token gesture towards gender equality. To achieve this, the government could focus on tackling the social and economic forces that drive child marriage. Ensuring girls complete their 12 years of compulsory schooling and reducing unintended pregnancies by improving access to contraception and sexual-health education would be a start. Giving girls more control over their bodies would also allow them to exercise more sway over their future, including who they marry.

Title: Trump Administration Deploys U.S. Marshals to Protect National Monuments Amid Ongoing Protests

The Trump administration has instructed U.S. marshals to prepare to guard national monuments across the country, following President Donald Trump's vow to crack down on those destroying federal property during the ongoing George Floyd protests. According to an email from Marshals Service Assistant Director Andrew C. Smith, the agency has been asked to provide federal law enforcement support to protect national monuments nationwide.

The email, which was sent with the subject line "Attorney General Assignment," suggests that it came from Attorney General William P. Barr. Smith noted that the task is challenging due to the breadth of possible targets for criminal activity.

As part of a "major effort" to bolster security around national monuments, the marshals are expected to begin their work before the end of the week. Unarmed National Guard troops will also be sent to monuments around Washington, D.C., to assist the U.S. Park Police in protecting the monuments in the nation's capital.

The security reinforcements come after weeks of statues being toppled nationwide. Initially, rioters targeted Confederate monuments, but tributes to the founding fathers and even abolitionists have been destroyed in recent days. President Trump warned that those found damaging federal property, such as monuments, would be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

In a tweet, Trump stated, "I have authorized the Federal Government to arrest anyone who vandalizes or destroys any monument, statue, or other such Federal property in the U.S. with up to 10 years in prison, per the Veteran's Memorial Preservation Act, or such other laws that may be pertinent." He added, "This action is taken effective immediately, but may also be used retroactively for destruction or vandalism already caused. There will be no exceptions!"

The president addressed the issue again on Wednesday night, tweeting, "Very sad to see States allowing roving gangs of wise guys, anarchists & looters, many of them having no idea what they are doing, indiscriminately ripping down our statues and monuments to the past. Some are great works of art, but all represent our History & Heritage, both the good and the bad. It is important for us to understand and remember, even in turbulent and difficult times, and learn from them. Knowledge comes from the most unusual of places!"

Title: NSA's XKeyscore Program: A Vast Database of Foreign Communications

The National Security Agency (NSA) has a program called XKeyscore, which provides access to a staggering amount of internet data. The program collects and stores a vast amount of information, with the NSA receiving over 20 terabytes of data per day. However, due to the sheer volume of data, the agency can only store content for a short period, typically three to five days, while metadata is stored for 30 days.

The XKeyscore system allows analysts to store "interesting" content in other databases, such as Pinwale, which can store material for up to five years. The program appears to be exclusively focused on foreign signals intelligence, including phone conversations, emails, and chat communications. Analysts can search for internet browsing activities using a wide range of information, including search terms entered by the user or websites viewed.

The program also enables analysts to learn the IP addresses of every person who visits a specified website. However, it is unclear whether this includes U.S. persons or only foreign nationals. Under U.S. law, the NSA is required to obtain an individualized FISA warrant only if the target of their surveillance is a "U.S. person," but XKeyscore provides the technological capability to target even U.S. persons for extensive electronic surveillance without a warrant, provided some identifying information is known to the analyst.

The NSA documents assert that by 2008, 300 terrorists had been captured using intelligence from XKeyscore. While the FISA Amendments Act of 2008 requires an individualized warrant for the targeting of U.S. persons, NSA analysts are permitted to intercept the communications of such individuals without a warrant if they are in contact with one of the NSA's foreign targets.

Greenwald suggests that this validates Snowden's statement that "I, sitting at my desk, certainly had the authorities to wiretap anyone, from you, or your accountant, to a federal judge, to even the President if I had a personal email." However, it is unclear whether XKeyscore provides the authority to wiretap a U.S. citizen. Rather, it appears to be a database search tool that provides access to tremendous volumes of foreign communications, which can then be searched by NSA analysts.

As Greenwald points out, there are known "compliance problems" with the NSA's surveillance programs, since communications by U.S. persons can end up in this database if the other end of the conversation is overseas. The NSA's minimization procedures are supposed to prevent such "inadvertent" targeting of U.S. persons, but there are plenty of exceptions to this rule.

**House Republicans Struggle to Secure Votes for Healthcare Bill**

The White House and congressional Republicans are facing difficulties in securing enough votes to pass their healthcare bill, which aims to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). According to CNN's whip count, 21 Republicans have come out against the current measure, with at least 17 lawmakers still undecided.

The bill's fate remains uncertain, with no vote scheduled and no clear indication of when one might take place. Vice President Mike Pence is set to spend Tuesday lobbying lawmakers on Capitol Hill, while President Donald Trump has expressed optimism that the bill will pass.

The Republican Party can only afford to lose 22 votes, assuming all Republicans are present and no Democrats cross the aisle. Several Republicans have publicly announced their opposition to the bill, including Reps. Billy Long, Brian Fitzpatrick, Daniel Webster, and Chris Smith.

The main sticking point is the treatment of pre-existing conditions, with some Republicans pushing for more flexibility in how states handle coverage for these conditions. The bill's supporters argue that it will provide better coverage for those with pre-existing conditions, while critics claim it will drive up costs and make it harder for people to get insurance.

The White House is under pressure to deliver a legislative win for President Trump, who has repeatedly promised to repeal and replace Obamacare. However, some Republicans are frustrated with the process and feel that the bill does not adequately address the concerns of moderates and conservatives.

The bill's fate remains uncertain, with some lawmakers still undecided and others expressing concerns about the impact of the bill on their constituents. The Republican Party's ability to pass the bill will be a key test of its ability to deliver on its campaign promises.

Title: Hundreds of Students Protest Norman High School's Response to Alleged Bullying and Sexual Assault

Hundreds of students from Norman High School in Oklahoma walked out of their school on Monday to protest the school's response to allegations of bullying and sexual assault against three female classmates who claim they were raped by the same person. The students were joined by parents and community members who showed their support outside the school.

The protest was sparked by the allegations made by the three students, who claim that school administrators failed to take adequate action after they reported the rapes and bullying. The students and their families say they were subjected to merciless bullying after the incidents, and the school's response was inadequate.

The students' story gained widespread attention after a detailed account was published on Jezebel, a popular online news site. The Norman Police Department has launched an investigation into the allegations, but no arrests or charges have been made. The police department has not released any details about the investigation, and a spokesperson for Norman High School did not comment on the matter.

In a letter to the school community, Norman Public Schools Superintendent Joe Siano encouraged parents to talk to their children about alternatives to the walkout, such as wearing stickers and ribbons provided by the school. The school is also expanding a task force to study the implementation of a targeted, research-based sexual assault curriculum for students.

The three students who made the allegations told Jezebel that they stopped attending classes and left school voluntarily after the bullying became unbearable. Friends of the students started a Facebook page, YES ALL Daughters, to show support for them. The page gained nearly 10,000 likes in just two weeks, and the students organized the protest with the help of their mothers and relatives.

The protest was peaceful, with organizers posting a list of "Protest Do's and Don'ts" on the Facebook page, including instructions to be peaceful, law-abiding citizens who do not disturb local businesses and to not respond to negativity. The Daily Oklahoman reported that hundreds of students participated in the protest, while organizers estimated that around 1,500 attended.

The students who organized the protest said they wanted to show solidarity with all victims of bullying and harassment and to demonstrate that they will not tolerate such behavior.

Title: Republican Vice-Presidential Candidate Paul Ryan Delivers Speech at Republican National Convention

Article:

Paul Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, delivered a speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa on Wednesday, receiving applause from conventioneers. Ryan's speech focused on criticizing the Obama administration's economic policies, specifically the Affordable Care Act, and defending the Republican Party's stance on Medicare reform. He also emphasized the importance of debt reduction.

Ryan's speech was praised for its delivery, with some noting that he effectively communicated his points. However, his economic growth solutions were criticized for being unclear and muddled. Instead of discussing Mitt Romney's tax rate proposals, Ryan used the term "tax fairness," a term often used by President Obama and liberal Democrats. The speech did not mention the proposed 20% across-the-board supply-side reduction in marginal tax rates or the 25% corporate tax rate reduction, which have been proposed by Romney.

Ryan's focus on debt was seen as a potential drawback, as some argue that it may not resonate with those who are unemployed or marginally employed, who are more concerned with finding a good-paying job. The article concludes that it will be up to Mitt Romney to clarify his own growth policies on Thursday night.

Title: Narendra Modi: From Humble Beginnings to India's Likely Prime Minister

Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat, is poised to become India's next prime minister after his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) secured a landslide victory in the country's recent parliamentary elections. Modi's rise to power has been remarkable, from his humble beginnings as the son of a tea vendor to his current position as a prominent leader in Indian politics.

Modi's tenure as chief minister of Gujarat has been marked by strong economic growth, with the state becoming one of India's best-performing states. He is known for his self-discipline and austerity, and has been praised by business executives for his pro-business approach. Under his leadership, Gujarat's economy has nearly tripled in size, and the state has become a hub for entrepreneurship and investment.

However, Modi's record is not without controversy. The 2002 religious riots in Gujarat, in which hundreds of Muslims were killed, have left a dark cloud over his legacy. While Modi has denied any responsibility for the violence, critics have accused him of not taking action to stop it. Subsequent investigations have exonerated him, but the incident remains a major concern for many Indians.

Modi's personal life has also been the subject of scrutiny. He has been married, but only acknowledged his wife's existence in April, despite her being widely reported to exist for years. His reputation has also been criticized as vindictive and abrasive, with some describing him as intolerant of dissent.

Despite these controversies, Modi remains a popular figure in India, and his party's victory is seen as a major milestone in Indian politics. If he becomes prime minister, he is likely to be granted a visa to travel to the United States, and has already met with European officials.

Title: Obama and Romney Adjust Campaign Schedules Amid Hurricane Sandy Threat

The presidential campaigns of Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have adjusted their schedules in response to the approaching Hurricane Sandy, which is expected to bring tropical storm-force winds to the eastern third of the United States in the coming days. The storm currently sits off the coast of Florida, with tropical storm watches and warnings in effect in the Carolinas.

According to Obama's press secretary, Jay Carney, the President's events in Northern Virginia on Monday and in Colorado Springs, Colorado, on Tuesday have been canceled. The President will continue to receive regular briefings on the storm and has directed his team to continue bringing all available resources to bear as state and local partners prepare for the storm.

Mitt Romney has canceled all his events scheduled for Virginia on Sunday and will instead campaign in Ohio on Monday morning.

The National Hurricane Center projects landfall around Delaware and New Jersey sometime late Monday or early Tuesday, with the storm expected to bring heavy rains and winds to the East Coast. Federal officials warn that inland areas could see up to 2 feet or more of snow.

Federal Emergency Management Agency Administrator Craig Fugate emphasized that the storm's reach will extend beyond coastal areas, affecting the Ohio Valley and Appalachian regions, and may cause flooding in the D.C. area's rivers. FEMA and other federal partners are sending teams and resources to support state and local preparedness efforts.

Both the Obama and Romney campaigns have downplayed the storm's potential effect on turnout in swing states and the optics of campaigning during a looming disaster. The Obama campaign has scheduled an event in Youngstown, Ohio, on Sunday afternoon, before the brunt of the storm is expected to hit the D.C. metro area. The President will also hold an event in Wisconsin on Tuesday, although additional schedule changes may be announced. Vice President Joe Biden is set to appear in Ohio on Tuesday.

Title: Trump Cancels Veterans Day Parade in Washington DC Due to High Costs

The White House has announced that US President Donald Trump has cancelled a Veterans Day military parade in Washington DC, initially planned for November 11, due to concerns over the high costs of staging the event. The estimated cost of the parade was reportedly around $90 million, more than three times the original estimate.

According to Trump's Twitter post, local politicians in Washington DC had requested a "ridiculously high" figure for the event, which led to its cancellation. The president stated that he may consider holding a similar event next year, but for now, he will attend parades in France and at Maryland's Andrews Air Force Base.

The original estimate for the parade's budget was between $10 million and $30 million, but a US official later provided a revised estimate of $92 million. The Pentagon had planned for the military to march from the White House to the Capitol, with a "heavy air component" at the end, and the focus was to be on the work of US military veterans throughout the ages, starting with the American Revolution.

The cancellation of the parade has been met with criticism from some politicians, with Washington Mayor Muriel Bowser responding on Twitter and members of the Democratic party expressing skepticism. The Pentagon has stated that the Department of Defense and the White House have agreed to explore opportunities for a similar event in 2019.

Title: House Passes GOP-Authored Bill to Repeal Unpopular Parts of Obamacare, Faces Uncertain Path in Senate

The House of Representatives passed a bill aimed at repealing certain provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, with a vote of 240-189. The bill, dubbed the Restoring Americans' Healthcare Freedom Reconciliation Act, would repeal insurance mandates on individuals and employers, eliminate taxes on medical device sales and generous health plans, and abolish the "Cadillac tax." The bill also defunds Planned Parenthood for one year.

The bill's passage was met with praise from pro-life groups, but was criticized by the conservative Heritage Foundation, which deemed the legislation "woefully short of GOP promises for a full repeal of the Affordable Care Act." The bill's path through the Senate is uncertain, as it will require a simple majority to pass and President Obama can still veto it.

Republican leaders are leveraging the budget reconciliation process to bypass a Senate filibuster, but the bill's fate remains uncertain. Some Senate Republicans, including Sens. Mike Lee, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio, have expressed concerns that the bill does not go far enough in repealing the ACA.

The bill's passage was not without controversy, with Democrats criticizing the repeated attempts to repeal the ACA and accusing Republicans of not addressing other pressing issues, such as the nation's debt limit and highway funding. The bill's supporters, however, argue that it will help reduce healthcare costs and improve the overall healthcare system.

The bill's path through the Senate will be determined by the parliamentarian's ruling on which provisions meet reconciliation's arcane rules. The bill's sponsors have already stripped out a provision that would repeal the Medicare spending board, as it was likely to be ruled out of order.

Title: Department of Homeland Security's Ammunition Purchases Under Scrutiny

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has faced scrutiny over its massive ammunition purchases, with Republican Representative Jason Chaffetz stating that the department is using roughly 1,000 rounds of ammunition more per person than the U.S. Army. Chaffetz, who chairs one of the House oversight subcommittees, revealed that the department currently has more than 260 million rounds in stock, with purchases exceeding 103 million rounds in 2012 and using 116 million that same year.

Chaffetz compared the DHS's ammunition usage to that of the U.S. Army, noting that the department's officers use an "exorbitant amount" of ammunition. He stated that the DHS is churning through between 1,300 and 1,600 rounds per officer, while the U.S. Army goes through roughly 350 rounds per soldier.

Nick Nayak, the chief procurement officer for the Department of Homeland Security, did not challenge Chaffetz's numbers but sought to counter what he described as several misconceptions about the bullet buys. Nayak clarified that the department is not buying up to 1.6 billion rounds over five years, as previously reported, but rather closer to 750 million. He also stated that the department buys roughly 100 million rounds per year and that claims of stockpiling ammo are "simply not true."

Democrats, however, likened concerns about the purchases to conspiracy theories, while Republicans raised concerns about the sheer cost of the ammunition. Representative Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, stated that the concerns are not about conspiracy theories but about good government. Representative Darrell Issa, R-Calif., expressed suspicion that rounds are being stockpiled, then either disposed of, passed to non-federal agencies, or shot indiscriminately, and if that is the case, he said, "then shame on you."

**Romney to Accuse Obama of Misunderstanding Radical Islam in Virginia Speech**

Mitt Romney is set to deliver a major foreign-policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute, where he will accuse the Obama administration of fundamentally misunderstanding the threat of radical Islam. The Republican presidential nominee will argue that President Obama's approach to foreign policy has been passive and ineffective, and that the country needs a more robust and muscular approach to counter the growing threat of terrorism.

According to excerpts, Romney will say that Obama's initial response to the attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya was to blame an Internet video mocking Islam, and only later to acknowledge the deliberate work of terrorists who use violence to impose their dark ideology on others. He will also criticize the Obama administration for not taking a stronger stance against terrorism and for not providing adequate support to allies in the region.

Romney will also outline his own vision for foreign policy, which includes using foreign aid to pressure Egypt to protect democracy, building the Syrian opposition, and restarting negotiations towards a two-state solution for Israelis and Palestinians. He will argue that the United States must take a more active role in promoting its interests and values around the world.

The Obama campaign has responded by saying that Romney has not shown he is up to the task of handling foreign policy and that his approach would be a disaster. The campaign has also questioned what specific differences Romney would make in his approach to Iran and terrorism.

The speech comes as the presidential race has become increasingly focused on foreign policy, with the economy still dominating the headlines. The debate over the past week has seen both campaigns trading blows on television and social media, with Romney's strong debate performance and the release of unemployment numbers benefiting Obama.

Title: Trump's Healthcare Betrayal: A Break from Campaign Promises

The American Health Care Act, authored by House Republicans and supported by President Donald Trump, has been met with widespread criticism for its failure to uphold Trump's campaign promises. Trump's campaign rhetoric emphasized covering everyone, avoiding Medicaid cuts, and boosting funding for opioid abuse treatment. However, the actual bill does none of these things, instead prioritizing a $600 billion tax cut for the wealthy.

Trump's campaign promises were clear and repeated, with him stating he would not cut Social Security, Medicare, or Medicaid. He also emphasized his plan would offer patients a more generous deal than the Affordable Care Act, with lower deductibles and the ability to pay for healthcare without worrying about it. However, the American Health Care Act does the opposite, cutting Medicaid spending and reducing federal subsidies for insurance, leaving millions without coverage.

The bill's effects will disproportionately affect those who voted for Trump, particularly in rural areas where healthcare costs are already higher and older Americans who will face increased premiums due to laxer regulations. The administration's strategy to downplay the consequences of the bill and claim nobody will lose coverage is seen as absurd, as the bill's passage relies on long-term spending cuts, which will inevitably lead to people being thrown off Medicaid.

The betrayal of Trump's promises is a significant departure from his campaign rhetoric, which resonated with many Americans. While some may not care about the details of healthcare policy, Trump's promises were made to appeal to a broad audience, and his failure to deliver on those promises will have significant consequences for millions of Americans.

Title: Trump's Hydroxychloroquine Admission Raises Questions and Controversy

Article:

President Donald Trump recently revealed that he has been taking hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug that most medical experts advise against using to treat or prevent COVID-19. The news sparked a flurry of questions and reactions, with some critics questioning whether Trump was taking the drug for political reasons or if he was genuinely seeking medical treatment.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a prominent critic of the president, expressed concern about Trump's decision, stating that he should not be taking a drug that has not been approved by scientists, especially given his age and weight. Her comments sparked a mix of reactions, with some people laughing at her perceived "fat-shaming" of the president, while others defended her right to express her opinion.

However, some critics pointed out that Trump has a history of making derogatory comments about people's weight, including calling women "fat" and "ugly." They argued that Pelosi's comments were not an isolated incident, but rather part of a larger pattern of behavior from the president.

The article goes on to list several examples of Trump's past comments and actions that have been criticized for being offensive and hurtful. It concludes by suggesting that Trump fans may not be as offended by Pelosi's comments as they claim, but rather are simply playing the part of being outraged to justify their own behavior.

The article presents a neutral and factual account of the situation, without taking a political stance or expressing personal opinions. It provides a balanced view of the controversy, highlighting the differing reactions and opinions on the matter.

**Senate Republicans Face Challenges in Reducing Insurance Premiums**

Senate Republicans are struggling to find a way to reduce insurance premiums, a key promise they made to repeal Obamacare. While they have a few options to consider, such as offering bigger subsidies, allowing insurers to offer skimpier coverage, or permitting insurers to charge more to those with pre-existing conditions, they are facing significant challenges in making these changes a reality.

According to Senator Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), reducing premiums can be achieved by kicking off those with pre-existing conditions or dramatically reducing benefits. However, Republicans argue that Obamacare's insurance regulations are responsible for making coverage expensive and that premiums would fall if those rules are rolled back.

Despite their efforts, analysts say that Republicans might achieve their goal for younger, healthier consumers, but at the cost of wiping out popular consumer safeguards like the ban on insurers charging more for coverage to those with pre-existing conditions. This could leave millions unable to afford the hikes associated with heart disease, rheumatoid arthritis, or cancer.

The Congressional Budget Office's report on the House repeal plan has made the task of Senate Republicans more difficult, concluding that allowing states to opt out of Obamacare's pre-existing condition requirement would destabilize markets and drive premiums upward for older, sicker people. Several Republican sources say the CBO's assessment would encourage lawmakers to preserve Obamacare's pre-existing condition policy.

Some Republicans support allowing insurers to sell more basic and cheaper policies without certain benefits, such as maternity coverage, mental health, or prescription drug benefits. However, they may not be able to make such changes under the complex rules governing the fast-track process being used to avoid a Democratic filibuster.

Ultimately, the GOP drive to reduce premiums could wind up expanding the number of uninsured Americans. The CBO also estimated that the House repeal bill would result in 23 million more uninsured Americans by 2026 than under the Affordable Care Act.

Premiums vary across the country, but have generally been on the rise. This year, benchmark Obamacare policies in 17 major cities rose an average of 9%, according to the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation. That's up from 2% in 2016.

Title: Trump Accuses Mueller's Team of Trying to Take Him Out, Slams Democratic Policies

Article:

President Donald Trump delivered a lengthy, expletive-laden speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Saturday, where he accused FBI Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team of trying to take him down and criticized Democratic policies. Trump claimed that Mueller's report, which is expected to be filed soon, is being produced by "people who weren't elected."

During his speech, Trump mocked the "collusion delusion" and accused his opponents of moving away from the narrative of Russian collusion. He also took aim at a top Clinton aide, saying that he "still hasn't gotten over getting his a-- kicked." Trump also singled out Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and former Hillary Clinton campaign Chair John Podesta, saying that the latter "still hasn't gotten over getting his a-- kicked."

Trump's remarks come just days after former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen testified to a House committee, and appeared to partially shut down some of the claims surrounding theories about the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Moscow. Trump also used his speech to promote his policies, including pulling back troops from the Middle East and the Green New Deal, which he jokingly encouraged Democrats to keep pushing.

The president's speech was filled with jokes and anecdotes, as he went off-script to josh and joke with the audience. He also used humor to promote his policies, saying that the Green New Deal should be part of the dialogue in the next election. Trump also shared an anecdote about flying into Iraq over Christmas and being told to turn off the lights on Air Force One as it landed, saying that the US spent $7 trillion and couldn't even land a plane with the lights on.

The crowd appeared to eat up everything Trump had to say, with audience members standing on chairs to get a glimpse of the president as he took the stage.

Title: Former NSA Officials Baffled by Rep. Devin Nunes' Claims of Trump Transition Team Surveillance

Article:

A group of former top National Security Agency (NSA) officials gathered in Washington, D.C. on Friday to discuss the latest developments in the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 US election. The conversation turned to Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA), the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, who made headlines this week by claiming that President Trump's transition team had been subject to surveillance by US intelligence agencies.

The former NSA officials were left scratching their heads, struggling to understand what Nunes was referring to. They found his claims vague and inconsistent, unsure what form of spying he was referring to. James A. Lewis, a senior vice president at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) and former State Department official, witnessed the discussion and described the confusion as "indicative."

The controversy began when Nunes held a surprise press conference on Wednesday, announcing that a source had revealed to him "dozens of reports" showing that unnamed US intelligence agencies had collected information about Trump or members of his transition team as part of their "normal foreign surveillance." Nunes clarified that this collection was legal and not confirmation of Trump's tweets claiming he was wiretapped by President Obama.

However, Nunes' actions have raised concerns among Democrats, who argue that his moves have put the credibility of the investigation into doubt. Critics have called for an independent commission or select committee to take over the Russia investigation. Nunes maintains that he is simply fulfilling his responsibilities as intelligence panel chief.

The dispute centers around Nunes' claims that he has seen documents showing that Trump-related names were "unmasked" in reports collected by the NSA under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. This law allows the NSA to listen in on foreign targets, and if the foreign target contacts a US citizen, the NSA can still spy on the communications. The agency must mask the name of the American, but it can be unmasked for compelling intelligence reasons.

What remains unclear is who was talking to whom, and why the names were unmasked. James Lewis of CSIS suggests that Russian targets for collection may have discussed the election and mentioned the names of some people, but it's unclear why those names were unmasked.

The controversy has raised the political temperature of the investigation, with the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA), stating that Nunes' actions have raised "profound doubt" about the panel's ability to conduct an impartial investigation. The situation has become further inflamed with Nunes canceling a public hearing featuring former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, among others, and instead holding a closed hearing with FBI Director James Comey and NSA Chief Adm. Mike Rogers.

Title: Trump's Campaign Faces Uphill Battle as Polls Show Struggling Republican Ticket

The Donald Trump campaign is attempting to pivot and shake up its strategy, bringing in Stephen Bannon, an executive from Breitbart News, to take on the top post and demoting Paul Manafort, who has since resigned. However, experts say this may not be enough to turn the tide for the Republican ticket, which is struggling in the polls.

According to recent aggregate poll numbers, Trump is consistently behind Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton, with some polls showing him trailing by as much as 5.8 percentage points. The data suggests that Trump is struggling in almost every part of the country, including traditionally Republican strongholds like Utah.

Trump's campaign has been plagued by controversy and divisive rhetoric, which has alienated voters and stirred doubts about his ability to be president. His attempts to appeal to new constituencies, such as African-American voters, have been met with skepticism, and his brand of speaking has become a major liability.

Efforts to reach out to new voters will be difficult, as Trump's campaign has consistently failed to stay on message and has instead doubled down on provocative language. Bannon's appointment may even push Trump further in this direction, given Breitbart's reputation for provocative content.

The Republican Party as a whole faces significant challenges, particularly with African-American voters, who have consistently shown little support for Trump. The party will need to work to reverse its disadvantage on key issues like voting rights, economic inequality, and police violence to win back this crucial demographic.

With the summer coming to a close, the election is now in its final stretch, and it will be extremely difficult for Trump to mount a comeback. While there have been instances of candidates surging in the polls, these are rare and often short-lived. The three presidential debates in late September offer an opportunity for Trump to change the direction of the race, but most often, there is no October surprise.

Title: Trump's Racist and Anti-American Sentiment: A Threat to the Melting Pot Principle

The recent tweets by President Donald Trump, targeting four freshman Democratic Representatives, have sparked widespread outrage and concern. The tweets, which told the representatives to "go back" to their countries of origin, have been widely condemned as racist and anti-American. This article will examine the facts and implications of Trump's statements, and how they contradict the fundamental principles of the United States.

Facts:

* Three of the four representatives Trump targeted were born in the United States, while the fourth, Ilhan Omar, was born in Somalia and became a naturalized US citizen at the age of 12.
* Trump's statement that the representatives should "go back" to their "totally broken and crime-infested places" makes little factual sense, as three of the four were born in the US.

Implications:

* Trump's statement is racist, as it targets non-white women and implies that they are not from here, their views are not welcome, and they need to leave. This definition of racism is in line with Merriam-Webster's definition: "A belief that race is the primary determinant of human traits and capacities and that racial differences produce an inherent superiority of a particular race."
* Trump's statement is also anti-American, as it goes against the fundamental principles of the United States, which has prided itself on being a melting pot of cultures and ideas. The country's diversity is seen as a strength, not a weakness.

Historical Context:

* Trump's vision of America is vastly different from the country's founding principles. During his campaign, he painted a dark picture of America, suggesting that it was a country in decline, and that he was the only one who could fix it. His slogan "Make America Great Again" implies that America was better off in the past, when white people and men held more power.

Comparison:

* In contrast, former President Barack Obama's vision of America is one of unity and inclusivity. In his 2008 speech, he emphasized the importance of solving the country's challenges together, recognizing that people may have different stories, but share common hopes.

Conclusion:

* Trump's tweets are a stark reminder of the importance of understanding and respecting the diversity of the United States. His statements are not only racist and anti-American but also a threat to the very principles that have made America great. It is essential to recognize that America is a country built on the idea of a melting pot, where people from different backgrounds come together to create a better future for all.

Title: China's Interest in West Qurna I Oil Field: A Potential Game-Changer for Iraq and the Global Energy Market

The China National Petroleum Corporation's bid for a 60% stake in the West Qurna I oil field has sparked interest in the global energy market. The stake is currently held by Exxon Mobil, which may be forced to divest due to its oil interests in Iraqi Kurdistan. Despite initial resistance, Exxon Mobil has expressed willingness to form a partnership with the Chinese company.

The development is seen as a potential game-changer for Iraq, which relies heavily on oil revenues to finance its military and social programs. The country estimates that it needs $30 billion in annual investments to reach production targets and become one of the world's premier energy powers.

For China, the investment is part of its strategy to diversify its energy sources and meet its growing energy demands. The country recently became the world's biggest oil importer, and over 50% of its oil imports come from the Middle East. China is investing heavily in oil and gas fields around the world, with $12 billion worth of investments in 2011 alone.

The increased Iraqi production, much of it pumped by Chinese workers, has also shielded the world economy from a spike in oil prices resulting from Western sanctions on Iranian oil exports. The boom in American domestic oil production in new shale fields has also reduced the country's dependence on Middle Eastern oil, making access to the Iraqi fields less vital.

Experts say that China's interest in Iraq could also help stabilize the country as it faces a growing sectarian conflict. "Our interest is the oil gets produced and Iraq makes money, so this is a big plus," said David Goldwyn, who was the State Department coordinator for international energy affairs in the first Obama administration. "Geopolitically, it develops close links between China and Iraq, although China did not get into it for the politics. Now that they are there, they have a great stake in assuring the continuity of the regime that facilitates their investment."

The partnership between Exxon Mobil and the China National Petroleum Corporation could also benefit the United States, as it would increase Iraqi oil production and reduce the country's dependence on Middle Eastern oil. "It's pretty simple," said Kevin Jianjun Tu, an expert on Chinese energy policies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "China needs more energy and needs to diversify its sources."

The revenue generated from the West Qurna I oil field could either help pave over tensions between Kurds, Shiites, and Sunnis or worsen those tensions as competing camps fight over the spoils. The Iraqi government needs the investment to reach its production targets and become a major player in the global energy market.

Title: Obama's Syria Plea Won't Rally Public Support

The article discusses the challenges President Barack Obama faces in rallying public support for his plan to take military action against Syria. The author, George C. Edwards III, argues that even great communicators, such as past presidents, have struggled to move the public to support their initiatives. Edwards cites examples from history, including President Franklin D. Roosevelt's failed efforts to convince Americans to rearm and aid their allies during World War II.

The author notes that the president faces strong competition for the public's attention, with barely a tenth of the population watching his State of the Union address in 2013. Many people who do pay attention miss the president's points, and the less people know about a topic, the more confidence they have in their pre-existing beliefs and resist factual information.

Edwards also highlights the role of partisanship, which can bias perceptions, interpretations, and responses to the president. The deep polarization of today's politics only exacerbates these tendencies, making it even more challenging for the president to rally public support.

The article concludes that, barring dramatic events in Syria, the president is unlikely to substantially increase public support for military action against the country. The author attributes this to the nature of public opinion and the president's communication environment, rather than any personal shortcomings on the part of President Obama.

Title: FISA-Gate Scandal: A Pattern of Government Misconduct and Media Silence

The FISA-Gate scandal, which involves the alleged misuse of surveillance powers by the Obama administration against the Trump campaign, has sparked a heated debate about government accountability and media bias. The scandal centers around the Department of Justice's (DOJ) request for court approval to surveil Carter Page, a Trump campaign advisor, allegedly for colluding with Russian interests. However, the warrant requests were based on an unverified dossier funded in part by the Hillary Clinton campaign, which was intended to smear Donald Trump during the 2016 election.

The scandal has led to the resignation of the FBI's deputy director, Andrew McCabe, and the reassignment of two FBI officials who worked on the Russia collusion probe. The FBI's top lawyer, James Baker, was also reassigned after allegedly leaking the Steele dossier to a sympathetic journalist.

The scandal has also raised concerns about the politicization of government agencies and the media's role in covering up government wrongdoing. Critics argue that the Obama administration weaponized the DOJ and FBI to assist the Hillary Clinton campaign, and that the media is now defending these actions rather than uncovering them.

The FISA-Gate scandal has sparked a debate about the role of government agencies in politics and the media's responsibility to hold them accountable. While some argue that the scandal is a minor issue compared to other government scandals, others believe that it is a serious breach of trust and a threat to democracy.

In conclusion, the FISA-Gate scandal highlights the importance of transparency and accountability in government and the media's role in uncovering and reporting on government wrongdoing.

Title: International Concerns Surround Potential US Strike Against Syria

The potential strike by the United States against Syria has sparked widespread concern among countries and leaders worldwide, including the Pope, due to its potential consequences. The strike could lead to more innocent victims, escalate the conflict, and spread it beyond Syria's borders, potentially destabilizing the Middle East and North Africa. It could also undermine multilateral efforts to resolve the Iranian nuclear problem and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The conflict in Syria is not a battle for democracy, but an armed conflict between the government and opposition in a multireligious country. The United States State Department has designated Al Nusra Front and the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, fighting with the opposition, as terrorist organizations. The internal conflict, fueled by foreign weapons supplied to the opposition, is one of the bloodiest in the world.
