The involvement of mercenaries from Arab countries and hundreds of militants from Western countries, including Russia, is a concern. The experience gained in Syria could potentially be brought back to other countries, as seen in the case of Libya and Mali.

Russia has advocated for peaceful dialogue and a compromise plan for Syria's future, emphasizing the importance of preserving international law and order. The use of force is only permitted under current international law in cases of self-defense or with the decision of the United Nations Security Council. Any other action would be considered an act of aggression.

While it is acknowledged that poison gas was used in Syria, there is reason to believe it was used by opposition forces to provoke intervention by their powerful foreign patrons, who would be siding with fundamentalists. Reports of militants preparing an attack against Israel cannot be ignored.

The international community is urged to use the United Nations Security Council and prioritize preserving law and order in today's complex and turbulent world.

Title: Republicans Abandon Health Care Bill, Obamacare Remains Intact

The Republican-led House of Representatives has officially abandoned their efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The decision comes after failing to secure enough support from within their own party. This move marks a significant setback for the Republican Party, which had made repealing and replacing Obamacare a central promise during the 2016 presidential election.

The news was met with celebration from Democrats, who took to social media and held press conferences to declare a "sigh of relief" for the American public. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called the outcome a "victory" for the American people.

The failure of the health care bill was attributed to both internal Republican disagreements and external pressure from liberal groups and constituents. Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-California, stated that the bill's downfall was not only due to Republican infighting but also to the liberal movement's efforts to push back against the new Republican government since President Donald Trump's inauguration.

The bill's demise has sparked concerns about the Republican Party's ability to govern effectively. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer warned that the health care disaster sets a poor precedent for Republicans in the new Congress and that they are unlikely to have much luck with the president's budget plan.

The defeat has also led to concerns about the upcoming battle over Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch. Democrats are planning to filibuster the nomination, and Republicans may attempt to change the rules to bypass the filibuster. However, this would require a change to the rules, which could be unpopular with the public.

The failure of the health care bill has also raised concerns about the 2018 midterm elections. Republicans are already fretting about the impact on their party's image and the potential for Democrats to target vulnerable Republicans in competitive districts.

In a sobering press conference, Speaker Paul Ryan acknowledged the Republican setback, stating that "doing big things is hard." The defeat has left many Republicans worried about their ability to govern effectively and the consequences for the party's image.

Title: Trump's Response to Charlottesville Violence Falls Short

Article:

President Donald Trump has faced criticism for his response to the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, where a white supremacist rally turned deadly. Trump initially condemned "violence on many sides," a statement many saw as vague and insufficient. The president's subsequent statement, attributed to an anonymous White House aide, did little to clarify his stance.

While it is true that violence has been perpetrated by both sides, including black-shirted rioters and white-shirted white supremacists, Trump's failure to specifically denounce the white supremacist movement and its ideology is a significant omission. The president's association with Steve Bannon, who has been accused of promoting white nationalist and anti-Semitic views, has also raised concerns.

The violence in Charlottesville had all the hallmarks of a terrorist attack, with a car plowing into a crowd of counter-protesters, leaving one dead and several injured. The incident was reminiscent of similar attacks in Nice, London, and other cities.

Trump's failure to condemn the white supremacist movement and its ideology has been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle. Republicans, including Senator Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, have called out the white supremacist movement for its hate speech and violence. The president's refusal to join them in denouncing the movement has been seen as tacit approval.

The article concludes that Trump's response to the violence in Charlottesville has been inadequate and that he has a responsibility to set an example by unequivocally condemning the white supremacist movement and its ideology.

Title: US Accuses China of Stealing Innovative Ideas, Raising Questions About China's Approach to Intellectual Property

The United States has officially accused China of stealing innovative ideas from American industries, a practice that has been a long-standing concern in the business world. The US government has pointed to China's systematic pilfering of intellectual property through cyber-espionage, reverse engineering, and other means, which has allegedly cost the US nearly 1 million jobs in 2009, according to the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation.

China's government has invested heavily in science parks and "hot" industries like clean energy, producing more engineers than the US and increasing its research investment as a percentage of gross domestic product since 2000. Its top scientific universities have gained global recognition. However, despite these efforts, China's approach to innovation has been criticized for prioritizing quantity over quality, with high rates of plagiarism in scientific papers and research misconduct.

The country's top-down economic planning and state-run enterprises have also been seen as stifling the emergence of innovative thinkers, unlike the US, where entrepreneurs like Steve Jobs have been able to thrive. China's long dependence on foreign technology and its drive to develop its economy quickly may be contributing factors to its tendency to take others' creative work. Additionally, the country's authoritarian political system, which suppresses the truth, may also be a factor.

In contrast, India, with less government funding for research, has been able to inspire technological innovation through its open society. The quest for truth is not new to China, with a long history of importing ideas, including communism and Western-style market capitalism. However, China now needs to look to its own people for creativity rather than taking it from elsewhere.

Title: White House Security Clearance Process Criticized for Delays and Obstruction

The security clearance process within the Trump administration has been plagued by delays and obstruction, according to a federal security clearance lawyer who represents several senior administration officials. Sean M. Bigley, a lawyer who has been battling the White House personnel security office, claims that a small group of career bureaucrats are intentionally slowing down the process to thwart the president's agenda and prevent the appointment of officials who will execute it.

The security clearance process, which is typically handled by the Office of Personnel Security (EOP Security), has been criticized for its inefficiency and lack of transparency. The office, which is staffed by fewer than a dozen career officials, has a reputation for bureaucratic red tape, but it has now adopted an adversarial stance towards the Trump administration.

Bigley claims that the completed FBI background checks are often delayed or stalled by the EOP Security office, which has resulted in a backlog of over 40 officials working with interim security clearances. This has led to concerns about the security risks posed by these officials having access to sensitive information.

The controversy surrounding the security clearance process has been highlighted by recent incidents, including the forced resignation of former White House staff secretary Rob Porter, who was accused of domestic abuse by his ex-wives. The White House initially defended Porter's character, but public outrage and a photograph of his ex-wife with a black eye forced his resignation.

White House Chief of Staff John Kelly has acknowledged that the administration mishandled the episode and has ordered an overhaul of the security clearance process. The overhaul includes reining in the number of interim clearances and requiring the FBI to hand-deliver background investigation files to the White House counsel, bypassing the EOP Security office.

The controversy has also led to the downgrade of senior adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner's top-secret clearance, although he still has clearance for access to government secrets. The exact reasons for the downgrade are unclear, but it is believed to be related to the security clearance process.

The security clearance process is a critical aspect of the administration's operations, and its inefficiencies and delays have raised concerns about the security risks posed by officials with incomplete or delayed clearances. The controversy highlights the need for a more streamlined and transparent process to ensure the security and integrity of the government.

**Trump's Body-Slamming Video Sparks Concerns and Criticism**

President Donald Trump shared a video of himself body-slamming someone with a CNN logo superimposed on his face, sparking concerns and criticism from the media and politicians. The video was posted on Twitter, where Trump often uses his account to share his thoughts and opinions.

CNN responded to the video, stating, "It's a sad day when the President of the United States encourages violence against reporters... We will keep doing our jobs. He should start doing his." The network emphasized that they will continue to report on the news, despite the president's attempts to discredit them.

Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is working on changes to the GOP health care bill, rather than repealing Obamacare first. Trump is set to return to Washington, D.C. tonight to celebrate the Fourth of July, hosting a picnic for military families at the White House and a viewing of fireworks.

The video has sparked concerns about the president's behavior and the potential impact on the media. Some have argued that Trump's tweets are impulsive outbursts, driven by short-term tactical decisions, while others see it as a way for the president to connect with his base.

The article also highlights other news stories, including the Senate health bill, which has been criticized by Republican Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, who says it makes it harder for states to treat opioid addicts. Additionally, at least 17 states are pushing back against the Trump administration's request for voter registration data as part of the new election integrity commission.

The Note is a daily feature that highlights the key political moments of the day ahead.

Title: US President's Top Lawyer Under Criminal Investigation, Justice Department Announces

The United States Justice Department has announced that Michael Cohen, the top lawyer for US President Donald Trump, is under criminal investigation. Prosecutors are focusing on Cohen's business dealings, rather than his work as a lawyer, according to a court filing.

The investigation has been ongoing for months, with Cohen's own lawyer attempting to stop prosecutors from reviewing material seized from his office. Cohen's team argues that the seized materials are covered by attorney-client privilege, but prosecutors disagree.

During a court hearing in New York, prosecutor Tom McKay accused Cohen of trying to use attorney-client privilege as a way to challenge the government's ability to review evidence. The government believes Cohen has a "low volume of potentially privileged communication" because he appears to have only one client, President Trump.

The filing also noted that while Cohen is an attorney, he has other business interests and sources of income, and is being investigated for criminal conduct that largely centers on his personal business dealings.

A new lawyer for President Trump, Joanna Hendon, has taken over the case and asked the judge to adjourn the session to allow her more time to prepare. According to a New York Times report, President Trump phoned Cohen to "check in" on him.

In a separate development, Cohen reportedly negotiated a $1.6 million settlement with a former Playboy model on behalf of a Republican fundraiser, Elliott Broidy. Broidy acknowledged a "consensual relationship" with the model, who became pregnant. Broidy said it was "unfortunate" that the personal matter was "the subject of national discussion" due to Cohen's involvement.

Cohen has previously admitted to paying $130,000 to a porn actress, Stormy Daniels, before the 2016 US presidential election. Daniels claims she had an affair with Trump, and he and his lawyers made attempts to buy her silence.

Title: The New York Times' Biggest Errors and Inaccuracies in 2016

The New York Times, considered the "paper of record," has had its fair share of mistakes and inaccuracies in the past. In 2016, the outlet made several notable errors, which have since been corrected. Here are some of the most significant blunders:

1. Claim that 17 Intelligence Agencies Agree on Russia: In June, The New York Times reported that 17 U.S. intelligence agencies agreed that Russia was responsible for meddling in the 2016 election. However, this claim was baseless and was debunked by fact-checking organizations. The paper later corrected the report, stating that only four intelligence agencies came to a consensus on Russian meddling.

2. Parody Twitter Account Mistaken for Official North Korean Government Account: The New York Times mistakenly attributed a tweet mocking American military efforts to the North Korean government, when it was actually from a parody account. The account, called the DPRK News Service, claims to be the "official news feed of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea," but is actually run by two Americans.

3. Story on Food Stamps and Soda Flubbed - Twice: The New York Times misreported data from a government study on what people buy on food stamps, stating that recipients spend nearly 10 cents of every dollar on soft drinks. However, the report actually said that recipients spend around 5.5 cents of every dollar on sweetened beverages, which includes soft drinks. The paper later updated the story without issuing a correction, and the updated version still incorrectly stated that soft drinks are not included in the "sweetened beverages" category.

4. NYT Reporter Forced to Correct Statement on Attorney General Jeff Sessions: New York Times editor Jonathan Weisman was forced to retract a tweet insinuating that Attorney General Jeff Sessions was corrupt. Weisman had stated that Sessions asked former FBI Director James Comey to call the Russia probe "a matter," but Comey had actually testified that former Attorney General Loretta Lynch made the request.

5. Correction to Editorial Attacking Sarah Palin with Debunked Conspiracy Theory: After a shooting at a GOP congressional baseball practice, The New York Times used a debunked conspiracy theory to attack former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin in an editorial. The paper baselessly linked her campaign messaging to the shooting of Democratic Representative Gabby Giffords in 2011. However, the map in question depicted Democratic districts in crosshairs, not individual Democratic lawmakers. The paper later corrected the editorial, stating that no link was established between political rhetoric and the 2011 shooting.

Title: Narrow Political Victories Can Lead to Significant Changes, So Let's Do a Better Job of Understanding One Another

Article:

The recent presidential election has once again highlighted the significance of narrow political victories and their potential to bring about substantial changes in public policies. With a margin of just 77,744 votes, Donald Trump secured the presidency, leading to a more conservative Supreme Court, the rollback of Obamacare, and numerous other policy shifts. This is not an isolated incident; similar instances of close elections have had far-reaching consequences, such as the 2008 U.S. Senate race in Minnesota, where Al Franken's narrow victory led to the passage of Obamacare.

The political system is designed to produce significant policy consequences from relatively small vote margins. This is exacerbated by increasing partisan polarization over the past few decades. The two-party system, which has been in place for over a century, incentivizes each party to aim for more than 50% of the vote. While this helps bind the country together, it also emphasizes what divides us.

In the past, neither party has always reached the 50% mark, with 15 of the 41 Democratic-Republican presidential contests since 1856 resulting in a winner receiving less than 50% of the popular vote. The 1876 election, in which Samuel Tilden lost by a single electoral vote, is a notable example.

In the aftermath of the election, many are left wondering how to move forward. One suggestion is to engage in a process called "active listening," where individuals explain to others why they support a candidate, even if they disagree. This can help foster a better understanding of the opposing side's perspective.

Another suggestion is for pundits and commentators to adopt a more nuanced approach, recognizing that good people can have different opinions and values. This might involve acknowledging that opposing views are not necessarily wrong or evil, but rather a reflection of different priorities and values.

Finally, it's essential to avoid getting bogged down in process arguments, such as the Electoral College debate. While these discussions can be interesting, they often distract from the real issues at hand.

In conclusion, the recent election serves as a reminder of the significance of narrow political victories and the importance of understanding and respecting opposing views. By adopting a more nuanced approach to politics, we can work towards a more constructive and respectful dialogue.

Title: Trump and Xi Agree on Denuclearization of Korean Peninsula, Urge Restraint

The leaders of the United States and China, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, discussed the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula during a phone conversation on Friday. According to a White House statement and Chinese state television, the two leaders agreed that a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula is a goal worth pursuing.

During the conversation, Xi also requested that the U.S. and North Korea tone down their recent rhetoric and avoid actions that could worsen tensions between the two nations. Xi emphasized the importance of maintaining restraint and avoiding actions that could exacerbate the situation on the Korean Peninsula.

The White House confirmed that Trump and Xi spoke on Friday, and the conversation focused on the recent adoption of a new United Nations Security Council resolution regarding North Korea. The leaders agreed that North Korea must stop its provocative and escalatory behavior and reiterated their commitment to the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

The conversation also touched on the importance of maintaining stability on the Korean Peninsula. Trump and Xi agreed that the recent tensions between the U.S. and North Korea are a concern and that it is essential to avoid any actions that could worsen the situation.

The phone call was the latest development in the ongoing diplomatic efforts to address the nuclear crisis on the Korean Peninsula. The U.S. has been urging China to pressure North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program, which North Korea says is nearing the capability of targeting the United States. China is North Korea's biggest economic partner and source of aid, but it has said it alone cannot compel Pyongyang to end its nuclear and missile programs.

In related news, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to do everything in his power to protect his nation's people as tensions escalate over North Korea's plans to send missiles over Japan toward Guam. Abe made the comments while visiting his father's tomb in his ancestral hometown of Nagato, in western Japan. The Japanese Defense Ministry has deployed four surface-to-air Patriot interceptors in western Japan to respond to a possible risk of fragments falling from missiles.

Title: US Economy Sees Robust Job Growth and Wage Increases in January

The United States saw a significant increase in job growth and wage rises in January, according to the latest jobs report from the Labor Department. The report revealed that employers added 200,000 jobs last month, with paychecks rising at the fastest pace in over eight years. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.1%, a 17-year low.

The report showed that nonfarm payrolls jumped by 200,000 jobs in January, following a 160,000 increase in December. Average hourly earnings rose 0.3% in January to $26.74, building on December's solid 0.4% gain. This boosted the year-on-year increase in average hourly earnings to 2.9%, the largest rise since June 2009.

Economists attribute the strong job growth to buoyant domestic and global demand, with companies struggling to find qualified workers. This is expected to drive wage growth, with some companies already reporting difficulties in finding skilled labor. The minimum wage increases in 18 states in January also contributed to the wage growth.

The report suggests that the US economy is approaching full employment, with job growth expected to slow this year. However, wage growth is expected to continue, driven by companies competing for scarce labor. The report also notes that companies like Starbucks and FedEx have said they will use some of the savings from lower taxes to boost wages for workers.

While some experts are optimistic about the economy's prospects, others are cautioning that the strong growth may not be sustainable. The Atlanta Fed's projection that 2018's Q1 economic growth will surge past five percent is a positive sign, but it is worth noting that the New York Fed's estimate for Q4 2017 was also robust, only to fall short of expectations.

Overall, the jobs report suggests that the US economy is in a strong position, with fundamentals indicating a healthy labor market. However, the exact strength of the economy remains to be seen, and experts will be closely monitoring the data to determine whether the current trends continue.

Title: CIA Director Warns of Potential ISIS Attacks, Politicians Debate Gun Control Measures

The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director John Brennan delivered a dire warning to the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday, stating that the Islamic State (ISIL) is training and attempting to deploy operatives for further attacks in the days ahead. According to Brennan, ISIL has a large number of Western fighters who could potentially serve as operatives for attacks in the West. He emphasized that the group is exploring various means for infiltration, including joining the flow of refugees into Western countries, using smuggling routes, and commercial travel.

The warning comes as lawmakers on Capitol Hill are divided on how to prevent future terrorist attacks in the United States. Democrats are pushing for stricter gun control measures, while Republicans are advocating for the president to take tougher action against ISIS and Islamic extremists.

President Barack Obama's critics have blamed his open border approach to immigration and poor foreign policy decisions for the rise of ISIS and the Orlando massacre. Senator John McCain, R-Ariz., initially stated that the president was "directly responsible" for the mass shooting due to his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Iraq in 2011, which led to the rise of ISIS. However, he later backed off from the statement.

The Senate is set to vote on new gun control legislation on Monday, with Democrats advocating for a "no fly, no buy" policy, which would ban individuals on a terror watch list from purchasing firearms. Senator Dick Durbin, D-Ill., stated, "There's no reason a suspected terrorist ought to be able to buy a firearm that can kill so many innocent people."

However, House Republicans do not plan to consider new gun legislation, with Speaker Paul Ryan stating, "Is going after the Second Amendment how you stop terrorism? No!"

Presumptive GOP nominee Donald Trump criticized the president, vowing to protect American gun rights. "To a large extent, he's blaming guns, and I'm going to save your Second Amendment, folks. I'm going to save your Second Amendment," Trump promised.

Earlier in the week, Trump suggested that if more people at the Orlando nightclub had been armed, fewer people would have died. However, President Obama dismissed this idea, stating, "The notion that the answer to this tragedy would be to assure that more people in a nightclub are similarly armed to the killer defies common sense."

As the president and vice president visited the Orlando memorial, a Christian from Illinois drove 1,200 miles to place 49 crosses at the site, each bearing the name of a victim. The individual, Greg Zanis, emphasized the importance of love and acceptance, saying, "My message today is love your brother, love your neighbor. Don't judge them... I'm just offering hope in a very hopeless situation."

Title: FBI Arrests Three Uzbek Men Accused of Planning to Join ISIS and Engage in Domestic Terrorism

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) conducted a series of terror raids in Brooklyn, New York, on Wednesday, arresting three men from Uzbekistan who were allegedly planning to join the Islamic State (ISIS) and potentially engage in domestic terrorism. The men, identified as Akhror Saidakhmetov, Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev, and Abror Habibov, were arrested at JFK Airport and in their homes.

According to a criminal complaint filed by the FBI, Saidakhmetov allegedly posted on an Uzbek-language website that he would buy a machine gun and shoot police officers and FBI agents if his plan to join ISIS was thwarted. Juraboev, 24, posted on the same website in August 2014 that he would kill President Obama if ISIS asked him to.

The plot is described as "aspirational, not operational," but the early stages of the plan were reportedly well underway. Saidakhmetov was arrested at JFK Airport attempting to board a flight to Istanbul, while Juraboev's plane ticket would have put him in Turkey a month later. The travel was funded by Habibov, who operated a domestic support network.

The men were allegedly inspired by ISIS's social media outreach program, which includes tweets and forum posts calling for "lone wolf" jihadis to launch attacks in America and Europe. The FBI charged the men with conspiracy to provide material support to ISIS, and they could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted.

The men's plans were laid out in greater detail by Saidakhmetov to a criminal informant. If he could not get into Syria, he planned to "just go buy a machine gun, AK-47, and shoot all police." He had a four-stage plan: "It is legal in America to carry a gun. We will go and purchase one handgun and then go and shoot on police officer. Boom! Then we will take his gun, bullets, and bulletproof vest. Then we will do the same with a couple of others. Then we will go to the FBI headquarters and kill the FBI people."

Juraboev allegedly left a post on an ISIS-aligned website, saying, "We too wanted to pledge our allegiance and commit ourselves while not present [in Syria]. I am in USA now but we don't have any arms. Is it possible to commit ourselves as dedicated martyrs anyway while here? What I'm saying is to shoot Obama and then get shot ourselves, will it do? That will strike fear in the heart of infidels."

The arrests are a reminder of the ongoing threat posed by ISIS and the importance of vigilance in preventing domestic terrorism.

Title: Romney's VP Pick: Condoleezza Rice a Strong Contender

Article:

The guessing game about Mitt Romney's vice presidential pick is heating up, and Condoleezza Rice is emerging as a top contender. The former Secretary of State received a warm reception at Romney's donor retreat in Utah and a standing ovation at a fundraiser for GOP women in Washington, D.C. Rice's potential selection would be a significant move for Romney, as she would be the first African-American woman on a major party's presidential ticket.

Rice's expertise in foreign policy, gained from her experience as Secretary of State, would complement Romney's lack of international experience. Her selection would also help Romney appeal to minority, female, and single women voters, who have been a key demographic for the Democratic Party.

However, Rice's selection would not come without controversy. Her refusal to ban abortion rights could spark opposition from the left, while her role in the Bush administration, particularly her involvement in the Iraq War and the weapons of mass destruction controversy, could lead to criticism from the right. Additionally, some Republicans have expressed concerns about her past and her role in the Bush administration.

On the other hand, Rice has shown political courage by standing up against anti-immigrant fervor from the GOP right wing, and her partnership with Joel Klein to draw attention to the crisis in American public education could be a significant asset for the Romney campaign. The report they co-chaired found that 75% of American young adults do not qualify to serve in the military due to inadequate education levels, and Rice's expertise in this area could help Romney address this critical issue.

Rice's selection would also align with Romney's recent focus on education reform, as he has expressed a desire to "stop the unfairness of urban children being denied access to the good schools of their choice." By putting Rice on the ticket, Romney could reform his image and give the education reform movement a boost.

Overall, Condoleezza Rice is a strong contender for Romney's vice presidential pick, bringing a unique set of skills and experiences to the table. While there are potential downsides to her selection, Rice's expertise in foreign policy, education, and her political spine make her an attractive choice for the Romney campaign.

Title: Solar Energy Poised to Disrupt US Power Markets, Study Finds

The US shale boom may be slowing, but the nation is expected to remain a leading global producer of oil and natural gas well into the future, thanks to advances in drilling technology. However, a new study by Scotland-based consultancy Wood Mackenzie suggests that solar energy is the next big breakthrough in the US energy supply.

The study, titled "Is Solar the Next Shale?", highlights the significant reductions in the costs of making solar modules, which puts the technology in a strong position to compete with other forms of electric power in many parts of the US. In fact, the economics for large-scale solar installations have already reached parity with those for gas combined-cycle and combustion plants in California and other parts of the US. By 2020, Wood Mackenzie expects parity to exist in 19 states, increasing to 38 by 2030.

According to the study, solar energy will continue to be a small part of total US electric generating capacity, accounting for 6% of the nation's generating mix in 2035, compared to just 1% currently. However, a relatively small amount of solar capacity can go a long way toward disrupting electric power markets. For example, solar power contributes the most during the day, when the sun is shining and demand for electricity is often at its peak, which is also when fossil-fuel power plants, including natural gas units, make most of their money.

The trend is set to continue, as the cost of solar continues to come down while the cost of combined-cycle gas plants, the preferred option for utilities, rises. "We certainly see an upside to solar, a significant upside. And you really don't need that much solar to hurt the economics of fossil-fuel plants," explains Prajit Ghosh, a research director with Wood Mackenzie. "Even a small amount of solar can have a pretty significant impact on the value of gas and coal plants and reliability."

The growing challenge for the electric power industry and its regulators is to integrate solar into the grid without forcing gas-fired power plants offline and disrupting the reliability of utility systems. California is already grappling with the issue, and other regions with significant solar potential, like Arizona, New Jersey, and Texas, will increasingly do so.

The study's findings suggest that the industry will not be significantly impacted if the federal investment tax credit expires on December 31, 2016, as scheduled. The subsidy provides a 30% credit for solar systems on residential and commercial properties. The Obama administration, in its recent budget proposal, calls for extending the tax break to support continued growth in solar energy, and the industry strongly supports the idea. However, Wood Mackenzie's Ghosh believes the incentive is no longer necessary, citing the significant cost savings expected in solar.

Title: CNN Tonight with Don Lemon Faces Backlash Over Segment Mocking Trump Supporters

Article: A recent episode of CNN Tonight with Don Lemon has sparked controversy after guests Wajahat Ali and Rick Wilson made derogatory comments about President Trump and his supporters. During the segment, Wilson described Trump's base as "credulous, boomer rube" and mocked their supposed lack of geographic knowledge, saying they wouldn't be able to find Ukraine on a map. Ali joined in, joking that Trump's supporters are "elitists" who know where Ukraine is.

The segment has drawn criticism from several Twitter users, with some calling it "bigotry" and "disrespect" towards Trump supporters. Others have described it as a "campaign commercial" that will be used against the Democratic Party.

The segment has also sparked debate about the tone and content of the show, with some arguing that it was an example of elitism and condescension towards those who disagree with the hosts' views. Others have defended the segment, saying it was a humorous and lighthearted commentary on the political divide.

It is worth noting that the exact quotes and context of the segment may be subject to interpretation, and some viewers may have different opinions on the matter.

Title: Trump Jr. and Other Key Figures Downplay Significance of Infamous Trump Tower Meeting

The Senate Judiciary Committee has released over 1,800 pages of transcripts from interviews with figures involved in the June 9, 2016 meeting at Trump Tower, which sparked allegations of Trump campaign coordination with Russia. Donald Trump Jr. and other key figures involved in the meeting have largely downplayed its significance, stating that Hillary Clinton was hardly discussed despite past speculation.

According to Trump Jr., he was skeptical going into the meeting, arranged by music promoter Rob Goldstone, who had promised to provide information on Clinton's supposed involvement with Russia. Trump Jr. testified that the meeting provided no meaningful information and turned out to be about Russian adoptions, which is what he said over a year later in his statement.

Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya stated that no information specific to Clinton was provided in the meeting. She lamented the "apocalyptic Hollywood scenario" that a private conversation between a lawyer and a businessman can be turned into.

Trump Jr. testified that he had no way to gauge the reliability, credibility, or accuracy of anything Goldstone promised and that he would have consulted with counsel if he had received information on Clinton. He also noted that he was not aware of who would be in the meeting and that it was not focused on Russian activities.

The meeting is under scrutiny in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. The testimony of Fusion GPS co-founder Glenn Simpson was also made public, revealing that he was not aware of the meeting beforehand and was "stunned" to later learn about it. Trump Jr. testified that he had never heard of Simpson or Fusion GPS at the time of the meeting.

The Senate Judiciary Committee released the transcripts and exhibits from interviews conducted to provide the public with the most complete picture of the events surrounding the meeting to date.

Title: FBI Director Comey's Memos Detail Conversations with President Trump

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Director James Comey's memos, detailing his conversations with President Donald Trump, have been released to the press. The documents, which span from early January to April 2017, provide insight into the interactions between the two leaders. According to the memos, Comey authored them to aid his memory of various meetings with the president.

The memos reveal that Trump expressed concerns about the judgment of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who would later plead guilty to lying to the FBI about his conversations with a Russian ambassador. In another memo, dated January 28, 2017, Comey reassured Trump that the FBI would be fair in its investigation into Russian collusion and interference in the 2016 election.

During a dinner conversation, Comey told Trump that he doesn't engage in "sneaky things" and doesn't "leak" or "weasel moves." Comey was attempting to reassure Trump that the FBI would conduct its investigation fairly. Trump reportedly replied that he needed loyalty and expected loyalty, with Comey noting that he did not respond or react to this statement.

In a phone conversation on March 30, 2017, Trump and Comey discussed the Russia investigation, with Trump urging Comey to tell the public that he was not under investigation. Comey wrote that he told Trump he would "see what we could do" and that the FBI would do its work well and as quickly as possible.

The release of these memos provides new insight into the interactions between Comey and Trump during the early days of the Trump presidency.

Title: Florida Surpasses 300,000 Confirmed COVID-19 Cases, Sees Surge in Infections

Florida has surpassed 300,000 confirmed cases of the coronavirus, according to data collected by Johns Hopkins University. The state has seen a significant surge in infections in recent weeks, placing it behind only California and New York in the number of confirmed cases reported. Health officials reported an additional 10,181 new confirmed cases on Wednesday.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis held a news conference on Wednesday, where he discussed the state's testing capacity and results. DeSantis stated that the state is conducting over 90,000 tests per day, but the results are taking too long to process. He announced that the state will be shifting business away from commercial labs that have not been able to return test results within 48 hours, as originally agreed upon when testing was expanded in early May.

Contact-tracers have also expressed concerns about the delays in testing results, which are making their jobs more difficult. Florida reported an additional 112 deaths on Wednesday, bringing the total number of deaths due to COVID-19 to over 4,500.

Florida's emergency management director, Jared Moskowitz, compared the state's response to a hurricane, but one complicated by politics. "When a Category 5 hits, nobody argues whether it was a Category 5, and in this disaster, we are arguing over everything," he said.

To address the surge in infections, DeSantis announced that additional medical personnel have been sent to Miami-Dade County, which is facing some of the highest infection rates in the state. Although the county's ICU beds are at capacity, the governor said hospitals still have plenty of other space that can be utilized for coronavirus patients. However, he emphasized that the real issue is a lack of healthcare workers.

The governor also announced that the state will be introducing lanes at testing sites specifically for those exhibiting COVID-19 symptoms. People who use those lanes will administer the swabs themselves and their test results will be expedited.

**Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Threatens to "Fight" Against Elizabeth Warren's Potential Breakup Plan**

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has expressed concerns about the potential consequences of breaking up the company, should Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, become the next US president. In an internal employee meeting in July, Zuckerberg stated that he would "go to the mat" and "fight" against any attempts to break up the company.

Warren has proposed breaking up several tech giants, including Facebook, citing concerns over their market dominance and alleged anticompetitive practices. Zuckerberg believes that breaking up the company would not solve the issues and would instead lead to more problems, such as decreased ability to detect hate speech and election interference.

In the meeting, Zuckerberg acknowledged that there are valid concerns about the company's size and influence, but argued that breaking it up would not address these issues. He also pointed out that smaller companies like Twitter face similar challenges but lack the resources to address them effectively.

Warren responded to Zuckerberg's comments on Twitter, stating that what would "really suck" is if the government does not address the issues of illegal anticompetitive practices, consumer privacy rights, and the responsibility to protect democracy.

The discussion comes as Facebook faces increased scrutiny over its handling of user data and its role in spreading misinformation. The company has faced several high-profile scandals, including the Cambridge Analytica data breach, and has reached a $5 billion settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

Zuckerberg's comments highlight the potential legal battle that could ensue if Warren's plan to break up the company becomes a reality.

Title: US Orders Departure of Non-Emergency Employees from Iraq Amid Heightened Tensions with Iran

The United States has ordered the departure of non-emergency employees from its diplomatic missions in Iraq, citing safety concerns amid heightened tensions with Iran. The move is the latest development in a series of escalatory measures taken by the Trump administration to counter what it claims is a heightened threat from Iran to US soldiers and interests in the region.

The US State Department announced that employees at the US embassy in Baghdad and its consulate in Erbil, the capital of the semi-autonomous Kurdistan region, were being pulled out immediately due to safety concerns. Visa services were suspended at the heavily-fortified US missions, with no specific threat mentioned.

The decision comes as the US and Iran engage in a war of words, with the US imposing new sanctions on Tehran and sending additional forces to the Middle East. Iran, in turn, has called the US actions "psychological warfare" and a British commander has cast doubt on US military concerns about threats to its roughly 5,000 soldiers in Iraq.

Germany and the Netherlands have also suspended their military operations in Iraq, citing increasing regional tensions. Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi has expressed optimism that the situation will "end well" despite the rhetoric.

The US State Department emphasized that ensuring the safety of US government personnel and citizens is its highest priority, and that it is taking steps to reduce the risk of harm. A senior Iranian official warned that any conflict in the region would have "unimaginable consequences."

The US has issued a travel advisory for Iraq, warning that US citizens are at high risk of violence and kidnapping, and that anti-US sectarian militias may also threaten US citizens and Western companies throughout the country.

Title: Descendants of Confederate Military Leaders Weigh In on Renaming Army Bases

The debate surrounding the renaming of six Army bases named after Confederate military leaders has sparked a complex discussion among their descendants. A recent poll found that a significant majority of the general public is ambivalent about the issue, with many believing the bases should be left alone or unsure what to do about them. However, descendants of the Confederate leaders have spoken out, with some advocating for the removal of their ancestors' names from military monuments and facilities, while others believe they should be honored.

The descendants of eight Confederate military leaders, including those of Generals Nathan Bedford Forrest, Leonidas Polk, and A.P. Hill, were tracked down by ██. Most of them have expressed a consistent view that it is time for a change, with some passionately believing their ancestors' names should be excised from all military monuments, buildings, streets, ships, planes, or paraphernalia. A minority of them, however, are fervent that their ancestors deserve to be honored.

The views of the descendants are not uniform, with some being torn about how to strike the right balance between righting historical wrongs and acknowledging their ancestors' honorable post-war accomplishments. Some, like George E. Pickett V, believe their ancestors' names should be permanently removed and either destroyed or sunk in the ocean for a fishing/diving reef, dubbed the "Graveyard of the Confederacy."

Others, like Tim Hill, are adamant that their ancestors' names should not be changed, citing their ancestors' beliefs and motivations. For example, Tim Hill, a descendant of General A.P. Hill, believes his ancestor fought for what he believed in, and that the fight was not about slavery but about "Northern aggression."

The Army bases in question are Fort Rucker in Alabama, Forts Benning and Gordon in Georgia, Fort Polk and Camp Beauregard in Louisiana, Fort Bragg in North Carolina, Fort Hood in Texas, and Forts A.P. Hill, Pickett, and Lee in Virginia. These bases were established long after the Civil War, mainly during World War I and World War II, when the military was still segregated into Black and white units. Many elected leaders from the South, including powerful members of Congress, were avowed racists and sought to recast the Civil War as not about slavery but a defense of states' rights.

The Army has only recently reconsidered the names, with Major General Malcolm Frost stating in 2015 that "every Army installation is named for a soldier who holds a place in our military history." He emphasized that the names "represent individuals, not causes or ideologies," and the decision to name bases for Confederates was "in the spirit of reconciliation, not division."

For many in the bloodline of these rebel officers, there is no doubt about what needs to be done today. Mimi Kirk, the great-great-great granddaughter of General John Brown Gordon, wants Georgia's Fort Gordon renamed so it is not honoring a leading white supremacist. Others, like Milbry Polk, 66, believe it is past time to honor only Americans whom everyone can agree are deserving, citing the importance of valuing diverse figures in American history, such as Native Americans, women, and African Americans.

Title: Attorney General Barr Warns Against Overly Restrictive State and Local Shutdown Orders

Attorney General Bill Barr has instructed federal prosecutors to monitor state and local shutdown orders for any potential infringement on constitutional rights. In a memo issued on Monday, Barr recognized that while some restrictions are necessary to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, others may go too far. He noted that the Department of Justice may have an obligation to address overreach in federal court if a state or local ordinance crosses the line from an appropriate exercise of authority to stop the spread of COVID-19 into an overbearing infringement of constitutional and statutory protections.

Barr emphasized that while the Constitution forbids discrimination against religious institutions, it also prohibits discrimination against disfavored speech and undue interference with the national economy. The Justice Department previously filed a statement of interest in a Mississippi lawsuit, siding with a church after local officials tried to stop Holy Week services broadcasting to people sitting in their cars in the parking lot.

As some states begin to loosen restrictions as the number of cases decreases, others remain vigilant. Protests have emerged in some areas of the country as shutdown orders have resulted in a skyrocketing unemployment rate. In a recent appearance on Hugh Hewitt's radio program, Barr said some state orders were "disturbingly close to house arrest." He stated that while the goal was to flatten the curve of COVID-19 cases, that goal has largely been achieved and states should now use "more targeted approaches."

Barr placed the head of the Justice Department's civil rights division and the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan in charge of coordinating the department's efforts to monitor state and local policies and take action if needed. The memo emphasized that while the department does not want to unduly interfere with the important efforts of state and local officials to protect the public, the Constitution is not suspended in times of crisis.

President Trump was asked about Barr's directive during a Monday press briefing, stating that the Attorney General wants to see people get back to work and maintain their rights, and that he does not want people to be held up when there is no reason for doing it.

Title: Trump Questions Obama's Commitment to Fighting Radical Islamic Terrorism

Article:

Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has cast doubt on President Barack Obama's commitment to fighting radical Islamic terrorism, stating that "there's something going on" and that Obama either lacks the toughness, intelligence, or has an ulterior motive. Trump made these comments during a phone interview on "Fox and Friends" and later on NBC's "Today" show.

Trump questioned Obama's handling of terrorism, stating that the president does not understand the term "radical Islamic terrorism" and does not want to acknowledge it. He also suggested that Obama may be intentionally pursuing ignorance on the topic of Islamism. Trump's comments come in the wake of a mass shooting at an Orlando, Florida, nightclub that killed 49 people and injured dozens more.

Trump's statements have been met with criticism from journalists and others, who have accused him of using dogwhistling and spreading conspiracy theories. Trump has repeatedly criticized Obama's handling of terrorism and has accused him of apologizing to Muslims after visiting a mosque to combat rhetoric against Muslim-Americans.

In his comments, Trump stated that Obama does not know about radical Islamic terrorism because he does not do much about it in terms of intelligence gathering. He also suggested that Obama thinks everyone is a "sweetheart" and does not want to use the term "radical Islamic terrorism."

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Suspends Re-election Campaign After Insider Trading Arrest

Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican and a strong supporter of President Trump, has suspended his re-election campaign following his arrest on charges of insider trading. The FBI accused Collins of selling stock in a pharmaceutical company after learning that a key drug's clinical testing had failed, resulting in a $760,000 profit for his family.

In a statement, Collins denied the charges, calling them "meritless," and vowed to clear his name. He also expressed concerns that his continued involvement in the election could become a distraction, particularly in a high-stakes election where control of Congress is at stake.

The arrest has sparked criticism from Democrats, who see it as further evidence of a culture of corruption within the GOP since President Trump took office. They believe that Collins' suspension of his campaign could make the seat more competitive, potentially putting it in play.

It is unclear whether Collins will meet the criteria for removing his name from the ballot. The news marks an about-face for Collins, who initially planned to stay on the ballot after the news first broke.

Title: Tucker Carlson Criticizes CNN Anchors for Alleged Misleading Coverage of FISA Report

The host of "Tucker Carlson Tonight," Tucker Carlson, has accused several CNN anchors and contributors of spreading misleading or false narratives about the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) report released by Justice Department Inspector General Michael E. Horowitz. According to Carlson, CNN hosts, contributors, and guests have claimed that the Steele dossier was "totally irrelevant" to the FISA warrant application, which he believes is false.

Carlson specifically targeted CNN primetime anchor Don Lemon, who stated that the report found the Russia probe's origins to be "legally sound" and "unbiased." Carlson sarcastically referred to Lemon's statement as "Facts first," implying that the anchor was not accurately representing the report's findings.

Carlson also criticized CNN anchor Chris Cuomo, who mocked President Trump for claiming he is a "victim" in the midst of the FISA firestorm. Carlson suggested that Cuomo had not actually read the IG report and was instead relying on CNN's narrative.

Additionally, Carlson called out CNN anchor Jim Sciutto, who in a 2018 tweet claimed that the FBI would "further corroborate information in the Steele dossier" before using it to justify the FISA warrant. Carlson stated that this was a lie, as the report actually showed the FBI hiding information exposing the dossier as false and pretending it had been authenticated.

Carlson also criticized NBC News intelligence correspondent Ken Dilanian, who tweeted in 2018 that Trump was "wrong about Carter Page, the dossier, and the FISA warrant." Carlson argued that Trump was correct, and Dilanian and his sources in the intel community were wrong.

Overall, Carlson accused CNN of spreading misinformation and misleading coverage of the FISA report, and called out specific anchors and contributors for their alleged inaccuracies.

Title: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich Criticizes President Obama's Immigration Policy

Article:

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich has criticized President Barack Obama's immigration policy, stating that it is not just another new government program, but a "new law" created by the executive without Constitutional authority. In an opinion piece for CNN, Gingrich argues that the president's prime-time address on Thursday was "technically a fine speech" but "very little of it was true."

Gingrich claims that Obama's proposal to prioritize the deportation of felons, criminals, and gang members over others in the United States illegally is not what the president described it to be. According to the White House, Obama has directed the Department of Homeland Security to create a deferred action program to give illegal immigrants work permits for at least three years, and establishes criteria to keep people exempt from deportation.

Gingrich notes that the policy memo from the Office of Legislative Affairs, released hours before Obama's speech, outlines a 17-point plan that includes several new programs without Congressional approval, budget appropriation, or spending authorization. Many of these programs bear only a faint resemblance to what Obama described in his speech.

The former speaker also points out that the policy memo establishes extensive new criteria for people to register and be exempt from deportation, including requirements such as biometric data, background checks, and payment of fees. Additionally, applicants must prove they have been in the country for at least five years and pay taxes.

Gingrich concludes that Obama's actions are "an order of magnitude larger" than those taken by previous presidents and lack congressional sanction. He compares the address to a "Gruber speech," referencing Obamacare co-architect Jonathan Gruber's statements on how the Obama administration relied on the "stupidity of the American voter" to enable the healthcare reform plan.

Title: US Christian Leaders Urge Trump to Recognize Jerusalem as Israel's Capital, but White House Hesitates

Article:

A group of over 60 influential US Christian leaders have sent a letter to President Donald Trump urging him to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital and move the US Embassy there. However, a White House official told Reuters that President Trump is hesitant to make the move, citing concerns that it could complicate a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

The idea of moving the US Embassy to Jerusalem has been a long-standing campaign promise of President Trump's. During his presidential campaign, he repeatedly stated that he would move the embassy to Jerusalem, the "eternal capital of the Jewish people." However, the White House has since clarified that the president is not planning to make the move at this time.

The US has maintained a consulate in Jerusalem since 1844, with the current location being a 10-minute drive away from the US Embassy in Tel Aviv. The consulate reports directly to the State Department rather than the US Embassy in Tel Aviv.

The question remains whether the US will eventually move the embassy to Jerusalem. David Parsons, media director of the International Christian Embassy Jerusalem (ICEJ), helped draft the 1995 Jerusalem Embassy Act. He believes that moving the embassy would strengthen the peace process and give Israel confidence that its ally, the US, is behind it.

Israeli leaders also hope that the US will relocate its embassy to Jerusalem. Dore Gold, president of the Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs (JCPA), stated that the connection between the Jewish people and Jerusalem goes back 2,000 years and that the movement of the embassy would be an American recognition of the special ties of Jerusalem to the Jewish people.

While some critics argue that moving the embassy would undermine the "peace process" and undermine the ability to negotiate a deal, Parsons believes that it would actually strengthen the process. The current waiver for the Jerusalem Embassy Act expires on June 1, and it remains to be seen whether the US will exercise its option to move the embassy to Jerusalem.

Title: Arizona Sheriff Challenges Obama's Immigration Order in Court

Article:

A lawsuit filed by Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his attorney, Larry Klayman, argued in a Washington, D.C. court on Monday that President Obama's immigration order, designed to spare nearly 5 million people from deportation, is unconstitutional. The hearing was the first courtroom challenge to the administration's immigration actions.

During the hearing, U.S. District Judge Beryl Howell questioned whether Arpaio has legal standing to challenge Obama's action, suggesting that Congress is better positioned to question the president's authority. A lawyer for the Obama administration called the lawsuit a "political dispute" that should be dismissed.

Arpaio and Klayman argue that the president violated the Constitution by doing an end-run around Congress and that drastic changes in immigration programs should be stopped. They claim that the administration's policy change allows more people to enter the country illegally and commit crimes, adding to the burden of law enforcement.

The Justice Department countered that Obama's program places greater emphasis on removing criminal aliens and recent border crossers, and that the theory presented by Arpaio and Klayman is "speculative and unsubstantiated." The case is separate from one filed by two-dozen states against Obama's immigration actions and another in which a federal judge declared Obama's immigration plans "unconstitutional" in an unrelated immigration case.

The lawsuit is the first to consider a direct challenge to Obama's orders, and Arpaio's attorney, Larry Klayman, voiced confidence in their case, suggesting they might take their suit to a higher court if necessary.

Title: Hundreds of Central American Migrants Reach Mexican Border City, Seeking Asylum in the US

Hundreds of Central American migrants, including LGBTQ individuals, have arrived in the Mexican border city of Tijuana, marking a significant milestone in their journey to seek asylum in the United States. The group of approximately 400 migrants broke away from the larger caravan of 5,000 people in Mexico City and traveled to Tijuana on Tuesday.

The migrants, who hail from Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, claim they are fleeing persecution, poverty, and violence in their home countries. They have been making their journey on foot, with some using buses to cover the distance. The group is expected to be joined by larger numbers in the coming days.

The smaller group of LGBTQ migrants, who reached Tijuana on Sunday, parted ways with the main caravan after experiencing discriminatory treatment from local residents and fellow travelers. Despite the challenges, the migrants remain determined to continue their journey and claim asylum in the US.

The caravan began in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, on October 13, covering a distance of approximately 4,350 kilometers (2,700 miles) to Tijuana. Many migrants have expressed concerns about the dangers of the route, including attacks by criminal gangs, and have chosen to travel in larger groups for safety reasons.

The current caravan is significantly larger than previous ones, with over 1,000 Hondurans initially departing and thousands more joining from Guatemala and Mexico. US President Donald Trump has responded to the caravan by deploying up to 9,000 troops to the border and closing down several lanes of traffic at two border crossings from Tijuana to California.

The US has a legal obligation to hear asylum claims from migrants who arrive at the border, but Trump recently signed a proclamation temporarily barring migrants who enter illegally from claiming asylum. The caravan has become a contentious issue in the US midterm elections, with Trump warning without evidence that the migrants are comprised of "gang members," "hardened criminals," and even Middle Eastern "terrorists."

Title: Trump Calls for Comedian Samantha Bee to be Fired Over Vulgar Comment About Ivanka Trump

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has called for comedian Samantha Bee to be fired after she made a vulgar comment about his daughter and White House adviser Ivanka Trump on her cable television program "Full Frontal". The comment was made during a discussion about the president's controversial immigration policies.

The controversy comes after a week of debate over language used by two television stars, with Bee's liberal-leaning audience on one side and fans of the sitcom "Roseanne" and its Trump-supporting star on the other. The debate was sparked by Roseanne Barr's racist remark in a post on Twitter, comparing a former top Obama administration official to an ape.

Trump criticized ABC and Disney CEO Bob Iger on Twitter, but did not address the content of Barr's comments. He took exception to Bee's use of a crude term for the female anatomy to describe Ivanka Trump, calling for her to be fired.

Bee and the TBS cable network, which airs the show, apologized on Thursday. Bee said she had "crossed a line" and deeply regretted her actions. Following Trump's remarks, TBS declined to comment further.

Several sponsors, including State Farm Insurance and Autotrader, have suspended their commercials. Trump's presidential candidacy was previously criticized in 2016 after a tape emerged of him boasting about being able to grab women by their genitalia because of his star status.

The controversy has highlighted the ongoing debate over language and political correctness, with some defending Bee's right to free speech and others condemning her comments as offensive. The debate has also highlighted the political divide in the United States, with some seeing it as a reflection of the country's deep-seated political divisions.

Title: Trump Shifts Focus to Democratic Lawmakers' Comments on Israel

President Donald Trump has attempted to deflect criticism over his supporters' chants of "Send her back!" at a rally in North Carolina, instead focusing on comments made by four liberal lawmakers about U.S. policy and Israel. Trump departed the White House for his New Jersey golf club, stating that the lawmakers' comments about Israel are "so bad" he won't repeat them.

The president has been critical of the quartet of freshmen Democrats, known as "The Squad," which includes Rep. Ilhan Omar, a Somali refugee who became a U.S. citizen before being elected to Congress from Minnesota. Trump has described them as the new "extreme" face of the Democratic Party and, in a tweet, told them to "go back" to their countries if they're unhappy. However, all four lawmakers are U.S. citizens, and Omar is the only one born outside the country.

Trump disavowed the chant on Thursday, but since then has focused on the liberal lawmakers' comments instead of critics who say he's fanning an ugly side of his base ahead of the 2020 election. When pressed on whether the lawmakers are using their First Amendment rights when they complain about U.S. policy, Trump stated that "we have First Amendment rights, also, we can certainly feel and say what we want."

Trump also denied taking any advice from First Lady Melania Trump or his daughter Ivanka on how to respond to the chants, calling reports to the contrary "fake news."

Title: Obamacare's Enduring Unpopularity and Ongoing Challenges

The recent Washington Post/ABC News poll and a new Kaiser Family Foundation poll have revealed continued widespread dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The polls show a majority of Americans deem President Obama's presidency a failure, with many believing the law has divided the country and negatively impacted healthcare. The survey also found a low presidential approval rating for the implementation of Obamacare, with a majority opposing the law despite the poll's question wording not mentioning the term "Obamacare" or the "Affordable Care Act."

The ongoing challenges facing the ACA include the ongoing parade of unpleasant developments, such as the recent revelation that Healthcare.gov was hacked. Additionally, individual market premiums have exploded in 2014, and are expected to grow by roughly eight percent in 2015, with many consumers facing double-digit spikes. The law was billed as a premium reducer, but individual market premiums have increased, and overall health spending continues to rise.

The upcoming open-enrollment period for Obamacare is expected to be problematic, with many consumers facing cancellations and renewal letters in October. The HealthCare.gov backroom is still not fully built, and the exact number of people enrolled in Obamacare is unknown. The open-enrollment period is scheduled to begin 11 days after the November election, and many consumers will have only four weeks to get their enrollment validated for January 1.

Large businesses expect to pay between 4 and 5 percent more for health-care benefits for their employees in 2015, with few employers planning to stop providing benefits. However, a third of employers are considering cutting or reducing subsidies for employee family members. Employees are paying more each year in out-of-pocket health care expenses, and the data suggest that the law has not achieved its promised goals.

Numerous polls have consistently found that roughly twice as many Americans say they have been personally hurt by Obamacare than helped. The Washington Post reports that higher costs and reduced benefits are on the way for many who receive health coverage through their employers. The White House knew that employer-based plans would be impacted by the ACA, and Senate Democrats voted down a Republican effort to reinforce the president's "keep your plan" promise.

In conclusion, the ongoing challenges and controversies surrounding Obamacare are far from over. The law's impact on healthcare and the economy will continue to be felt in the coming months and years.

Title: Romney Criticizes Trump's Conduct, Trump Fires Back on Twitter

Article:

Mitt Romney, set to be sworn in to the Senate on Thursday, published an op-ed in The Washington Post on Tuesday night, criticizing President Donald Trump's conduct over the past two years. In the article, Romney expressed disappointment that Trump has not risen to the occasion, citing his actions this month as evidence. Romney's criticism comes after he initially praised Trump's policy decisions and expressed interest in joining his administration.

In response, Trump fired back on Twitter, calling Romney's criticism "so fast" and questioning whether he is positioning himself as a replacement for Jeff Flake, a Republican who frequently criticized the president. Trump also encouraged Romney to focus on border security and other issues where he can be helpful.

Romney's criticism of Trump is not new, as he previously referred to Trump as a "phony" and "fraud" during the 2016 presidential campaign. Trump also responded with criticism, calling Romney a "failed presidential candidate" who "choked like a dog." After Trump's election, Romney softened his tone, praising some of Trump's policy decisions and expressing interest in joining his administration. Trump also publicly supported Romney's bid for the Senate.

The article does not provide further information on the specific actions Trump is referring to, as "this month."

Title: Trump Meets with Moderate Lawmakers to Discuss Bipartisan Tax Reform

President Donald Trump met with a group of moderate lawmakers from both parties on Wednesday to discuss bipartisan tax reform. The meeting comes as Trump is pushing for a tax overhaul, which he believes will spur economic growth and help communities affected by recent hurricanes. Trump suggested that wealthy Americans may face higher taxes under his plan, but emphasized that the focus is on helping the middle class and creating jobs.

The meeting was attended by eight Democratic and five Republican lawmakers, who are part of the self-described "Problem Solvers" caucus. Trump's willingness to work with Democrats has raised concerns among some Republicans, who oppose tax hikes. However, some Republicans, such as Rep. Mark Meadows, R-N.C., are open to considering the idea of higher taxes for the wealthy.

Trump's meeting with moderate lawmakers is part of his effort to pass a tax reform bill, which he believes will be a key achievement of his presidency. The president has argued that cutting taxes and simplifying the tax code will spur economic growth, helping recovery in communities damaged by hurricanes Harvey and Irma.

However, some experts have questioned the connection between tax reform and hurricane relief, and noted that neither the Trump administration nor Congress has a specific tax plan yet. Others have expressed skepticism about Trump's ability to leverage hurricane relief against a tax bill in Congress.

Despite these concerns, Trump remains optimistic about the prospects for a bipartisan deal. "The rich will not be gaining at all with this plan," Trump said. "We are looking for the middle class and we are looking for jobs – jobs being the economy. So we're looking at middle class and we're looking at jobs."

**Census Citizenship Question: A Legal Battle Continues, Despite Low Chances of Success**

The Trump administration's efforts to include a citizenship question on the 2020 census have sparked controversy and legal battles, with experts warning that the issue could lead to an undercount of residents in Democratic-leaning areas. Despite the Supreme Court blocking the question in June, the Department of Justice has announced plans to explore alternative explanations for its inclusion, while President Donald Trump has hinted at using an executive order to force the question onto the census.

Legal and political experts agree that the constant media coverage surrounding the issue could deter undocumented immigrants from participating in the census, potentially leading to an undercount in areas with high immigrant and Latino populations. This could benefit non-Hispanic whites, a core part of Trump's support, and help Republicans gain seats in Congress and state legislatures.

The U.S. Constitution requires the government to count all residents, regardless of their legal status, every 10 years. The information collected becomes the basis for voting maps and distributing federal funds. It is illegal for the Census Bureau to share information about individuals with law enforcement or immigration authorities.

While some argue that knowing citizenship status is important, demographers, advocacy groups, corporations, and even the Census Bureau's own staff have expressed concerns that the question threatens to undermine the survey. Researchers estimate that more than 4 million people may not participate, which could have significant consequences for the accuracy of the census.

The legal battle is ongoing, with the American Civil Liberties Union filing a motion to prevent the citizenship question from being added. Experts warn that any attempts to add the question through an executive order or alternative explanations would likely be challenged in court and could further undermine the census.

In the meantime, the controversy surrounding the issue may already be having an impact on the census, with some experts suggesting that the constant media coverage could be deterring participation and potentially leading to an undercount.

Title: U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Nikki Haley Demands Action Against Bolivian and Cuban Delegations After Disruptive Event

The United States Ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, has sent a letter to Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, expressing outrage over the behavior of the Bolivian and Cuban delegations during a recent event on the plight of political prisoners in Cuba. The event, titled "Jailed for What? The Plight of Cuba's Political Prisoners," took place in the UN's Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) chamber on Tuesday.

According to Haley, the diplomats from the two countries, including Bolivian Ambassador Sacha Llorenti, disrupted the event by banging on tables and screaming slogans, causing chaos and damaging UN property. Speakers, including former prisoners and relatives of those currently imprisoned under the communist regime, struggled to be heard over the noise.

In her letter, Haley called the behavior "outrageous" and demanded that the UN Secretary-General condemn the conduct and require the Cuban and Bolivian delegations to pay for the damage they caused. She also expressed disappointment that the UN initially suggested the US would be responsible for the damage, but later decided to bear the cost itself.

Haley emphasized that the US is the largest contributor to the UN budget, paying 22% of the budget, and therefore should not be responsible for the damage. She demanded that the Bolivian and Cuban delegations be made to bear the cost.

The Cuban Mission has responded by calling for an investigation into how the event was allowed to take place, describing it as "a political comedy staged on false arguments and with supporting actors of a dark history at the service of a foreign power." The mission also accused the US of having a "fascist, racist, and xenophobic agenda."

The UN's Spokesman, Stephane Dujarric, stated that missions must certify that public meetings are consistent with the purposes and principles of the UN and are non-commercial in nature. He also noted that it is not the role of UN security to remove disruptive delegates unless they pose a physical threat.

The event on Tuesday still went ahead, with speakers yelling over the protesters, but the US said the event was delayed after the Cuban delegation refused to allow security to conduct a sweep of the chamber.

The incident highlights the ongoing tensions between the US and some UN member states over issues such as human rights and the role of the organization.

Title: Rick Perry's Exit from the 2016 Presidential Race: A Missed Opportunity for the Republican Party

The recent withdrawal of Rick Perry from the 2016 presidential race has been met with disappointment from many who believe he was a qualified candidate. Perry, the former governor of Texas, brought a unique set of experiences and qualifications to the table, including his successful governance of the state. During his tenure, Texas experienced economic growth, upward mobility, and a more equitable recovery compared to the rest of the country.

Perry's record in Texas is a testament to the success of Republican governance, and his candidacy could have been a valuable asset to the party. However, his performance in the debates was not impressive, and his campaign struggled to gain traction. Despite this, Perry's experience and qualifications made him a more credible candidate than some of his opponents.

The Republican Party's decision to allow Perry to languish in the "kid's table" debate and the media's focus on Donald Trump's hat rather than Perry's qualifications are seen as a travesty. The party's reliance on opinion polls and the media's surrender to their authority have led to a process that favors candidates who are more likely to generate headlines than those who are qualified to lead the country.

Perry's exit from the race is a loss for the party, as his experience and qualifications could have been a valuable asset. The Republican Party would have benefited from having a candidate like Perry, who has a proven track record of successful governance and a unique perspective on the issues.

Title: Minority Children More Likely to Live in Disadvantaged Neighborhoods, Study Finds

A recent study by researchers at Brandeis University and Ohio State University has shed light on the stark disparities in neighborhood opportunities across the United States. The Child Opportunity Index, which analyzed data from diversitydatakids.org, found that approximately 40% of black children and 32% of Hispanic children live in the lowest-opportunity neighborhoods in their areas, compared to 9% of white children.

The study examined socioeconomic indicators such as housing foreclosure rates and access to basic educational and health-care facilities. The findings revealed that minority children are more likely to live in neighborhoods that lack access to early childhood education centers, parks, health-care facilities, and other vital resources.

The data showed that white children do not experience the same level of disadvantage, even in cities where they are worst off. For example, 23% of white children in Honolulu live in the lowest-opportunity neighborhoods, compared to 60.3% of black children in Albany, New York, and 57.6% of Hispanic children in Boston.

These disparities can have long-term consequences for children.
