A 2008 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that living in a disadvantaged neighborhood is equivalent to missing a year or more of school, and the negative impact persists even after the child moves out of the area.

The study's findings are supported by similar research, including a 2012 book by Harvard sociologist Robert J. Sampson, who examined incarceration rates in Chicago. Sampson found that a black neighborhood with one of the highest incarceration rates had a rate more than 40 times higher than the white neighborhood with the highest rate.

The Child Opportunity Index's data highlights the persistence of neighborhood disparities across the nation, placing minority children on a worse trajectory at the start of their lives.

Title: Philip Bilden Withdraws from Consideration for Secretary of the Navy

Philip Bilden, the nominee for Secretary of the Navy, has withdrawn from consideration for the post, citing concerns about privacy and separating himself from his business interests. Bilden's decision comes just days after the White House denied reports of his withdrawal, with Press Secretary Sean Spicer stating that he was "100% committed to the role."

Bilden, an intelligence officer in the Army Reserve from 1986 to 1996, had relocated to Hong Kong to establish an Asian presence for HarbourVest Partners, a global private equity management firm. He recently retired from the company after 25 years.

This is the second Trump nominee to withdraw from consideration for a post overseeing the military. Earlier this month, Vincent Viola, a West Point graduate and former airborne officer, withdrew from consideration to be Secretary of the Army. Viola cited his inability to successfully navigate the confirmation process and Defense Department rules concerning family businesses. The post remains unfilled.

In a statement, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said Bilden had informed him of the decision and that he would make a recommendation for a new nominee in the coming days. Bilden himself stated that he had determined he would not be able to satisfy Office of Government Ethics requirements without "undue disruption and materially adverse divestment of my family's private financial interests."

Bilden's withdrawal leaves the position of Secretary of the Navy unfilled, with the Defense Department scrambling to find a new nominee.

Title: House Republicans in Leadership Crisis After Rep. Kevin McCarthy Withdraws from Speaker Bid

Article:

House Republicans are facing a leadership crisis after Representative Kevin McCarthy announced he would not run for Speaker of the House, leaving the party without a clear successor. McCarthy's decision, made just moments before a planned closed party election, has sent the House GOP into a state of disarray. The party is now torn between two ideological poles, with no clear sense of who will serve as their next leader or what their governing agenda will be.

McCarthy's decision was reportedly due to concerns that he would not be able to secure the necessary 218 votes to become Speaker, similar to the problems faced by former Speaker John Boehner. The California representative had been dogged by controversy, including the creation of the Select Committee on Benghazi, which some Republicans saw as a political stunt.

With McCarthy out of the running, Wisconsin Representative Paul Ryan is now seen as the top contender for the speakership. Ryan has been asked to reconsider his bid by top Republicans, and has canceled his fundraising appearances for the next 48 hours. Other lawmakers, including Representatives Lynn Westmoreland, Mike Conaway, Bill Flores, John Kline, and Tom Cole, are also being floated as potential candidates.

The House Freedom Caucus, a bloc of roughly 40 Republicans, has endorsed Representative Daniel Webster as their preferred candidate. The group vowed to vote together in the closed party election, making it difficult for McCarthy to secure the necessary votes.

The leadership vacuum has left the House GOP scrambling to find a new leader, with some lawmakers suggesting that a caretaker speaker could be appointed until after the 2016 elections. The party's internal divisions and lack of a clear agenda have raised concerns about the party's ability to govern effectively.

The situation is reminiscent of a similar crisis in 1998, when Louisiana Representative Bob Livingston's resignation plunged the House into chaos. In that instance, Representative Tom Delay rallied his vote-counting operation behind Representative Dennis Hastert, who went on to become the longest-serving Republican Speaker. The current crisis is likely to continue to play out in the coming weeks, as the House GOP tries to find a new leader and develop a governing agenda.

Title: President Trump Honors Public Safety Officers and Civilians Who Responded to Recent Mass Shootings

Article:

President Donald Trump honored six public safety officers and five civilians who responded to the recent mass shootings in Dayton, Ohio, and El Paso, Texas, on Monday. The officers were recognized for their bravery and swift response in confronting the gunman in Dayton, which prevented further casualties. The civilians were honored for their selfless acts of heroism in helping others during the El Paso shooting.

The president presented the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor to Sgt. William Knight and Officers Brian Rolfes, Jeremy Campbell, Vincent Carter, Ryan Nabel, and David Denlinger, who responded to the shooting in Dayton. The officers returned fire on the gunman, Connor Betts, 24, who was wearing a mask and bullet-proof vest and carrying a semi-automatic pistol modified with an extended-capacity drum magazine. It was unclear which officer or officers fired the bullets that killed Betts.

The five civilians honored for their bravery were Robert Evans, Gilbert Serna, Marisela Luna, Angelica Silva, and Chris Grant. Grant, who was still recovering from gunshot wounds, risked his life to distract the gunman, Patrick Crusius, 21, by throwing bottles and merchandise at him, preventing him from shooting others.

The president praised the 11 individuals for their bravery and selflessness, stating, "In the darkness moments of danger and despair, God calls the bravest to action. These 11 individuals answered the call. They stared down evil. They put love of neighbor above life itself, and we are blessed by their courage. We are honored by their presence."

The twin shootings have sparked renewed national discussion on gun control, with Democrats and mayors from cities affected by mass shootings, including Dayton, pressing the Senate and White House to act on House bills calling for stricter background checks. The president has expressed support for tougher background checks in the past but has also questioned their value and praised the NRA since the latest mass shootings.

Title: Secretary of State Kerry Addresses Criticism of Iran Nuclear Deal

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry recently addressed concerns about the nuclear deal with Iran, which was announced in Geneva. One criticism is that the agreement allows Iran to enrich uranium, despite six United Nations Security Council resolutions declaring the activity illegal. Kerry sought to preempt this criticism by highlighting the significant progress Iran has made in its nuclear program since 2003.

Kerry pointed out that in 2003, Iran offered to address its nuclear program, but the offer was not taken. As a result, sanctions were imposed, and today Iran has 19,000 centrifuges, with 10,000 actively enriching uranium to low levels. Kerry suggested that this rapid growth in Iran's enrichment capability has forced the hand of negotiators, making restrictions on the program the only realistic option.

However, a review of reports by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and analyses by leading research institutions reveals that the majority of Iran's enrichment capability came online during the Obama administration. By late 2007, Iran had around 3,000 centrifuges, and it is estimated that around 25% of the current total was installed during the Bush-Cheney era. This means that around 74% of the centrifuges were installed since the Obama-Biden team took office.

Kerry's comments on the matter were made in a series of interviews before leaving Geneva. He emphasized that the deal is a step towards halting and rolling back Iran's nuclear program, and that the focus is on working towards a comprehensive agreement to bring an end to it. A spokesman for Kerry professed ignorance of the exact numbers involved, but emphasized the progress made in halting and rolling back the program.

The article does not provide a clear answer to the exact number of centrifuges installed during the Bush-Cheney era, but it does provide a review of reports and analyses that suggest the majority of the growth in Iran's enrichment capability occurred during the Obama administration.

Title: Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley Pledges Support for Iran Nuclear Deal, Bringing Total to 31 Senators in Favor

Article:

Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon has announced his support for the Iran nuclear deal, bringing the total number of senators publicly backing the agreement to 31. Merkley's statement emphasized that the deal is the "best available strategy to block Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon." The senator's endorsement brings the number of Democratic supporters to 31, with 13 remaining undecided.

The deal, reached in July between six world powers and Iran, would ease economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for curbs on its nuclear program. President Barack Obama has pledged to veto any legislation aimed at killing the pact, and Merkley's support puts him only three votes short of securing the necessary 41 votes to sustain a likely veto.

The Republican-controlled Congress has until September 17 to pass a resolution disapproving the deal, but Obama has vowed to veto any such resolution. While Republicans have been united in their opposition to the deal, only two Democratic senators, Charles Schumer and Robert Menendez, have joined them so far.

Senator Chris Coons, a Delaware Democrat, is expected to announce his decision on Tuesday, while other undecided Democrats, including Ben Cardin and Cory Booker, have yet to disclose their positions. The only uncertain Republican vote is that of Senator Susan Collins of Maine, who has not yet made a decision and is expected to do so after September 7.

In his statement, Merkley acknowledged the deal's "significant shortcomings," including the lifting of sanctions on Iran's conventional arms trade after five years and ballistic missile technology after eight years. He also expressed concerns about the lack of restrictions on how Iran can use the money it reclaims when sanctions are lifted. However, Merkley rejected a proposal to renegotiate the deal for better terms, stating that rejecting the deal would undermine a strong framework for peacefully blocking a potential Iranian bomb.

Title: Trump's Impeachment Inquiry Sparks Controversy and Questions About Party Loyalty

The recent announcement of impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump has sparked a flurry of messages and emails from the Trump campaign and allied GOP organizations, echoing concepts discussed in a 2018 article predicting the potential scenario. The messages, which have been flooding the author's inbox, assume that as a Republican, they will overlook and excuse Trump's "Ukraine-gate" behavior no matter how egregious and potentially impeachable.

The author, a longtime loyal Republican who voted for Trump, is troubled by these assumptions and feels compelled to speak out. They express concern that the messages are trying to turn impeachment into a campaign advantage and play the victim card, exploiting the circumstances to raise money. The author notes that since Pelosi's announcement, $13 million has flowed into GOP coffers.

The messages, which have been sent to the author, include phrases such as "We're 5X matching every Patriot who will stand with the President" and "Impeachment Alert: Democrats announced that they're launching another WITCHHUNT! Rush anything you can to defend President Trump." The author feels that these messages are trying to guilt-trip them into donating to the president's "Impeachment Defense Team."

The author is concerned that these messages assume that as a Republican, they will overlook and excuse Trump's behavior, no matter how egregious. They express pride in being an American who values the Constitution, separation of powers, and the well-being of the nation, and emphasize the importance of facts and evidence.

The article concludes by posing questions about whether Republican elected leaders and voters will stand with President Trump no matter what, even if the evidence proves he violated his oath of office. The author also questions whether the nation is careening towards a monumental constitutional crisis that will plunge the country into an "uncivil war."

Title: Michelle Obama Stumps for McAuliffe in Virginia Governor's Race

Article: Michelle Obama, the wife of US President Barack Obama, is continuing her role as a popular surrogate for her husband's 2012 reelection campaign, stumping for key 2013 races. On Thursday, she will raise money for Terry McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chief running for Virginia governor, at a hotel fundraiser in Fairfax County. According to McAuliffe's campaign spokesman, Josh Schwerin, Obama is "one of the most popular figures in America" and is committed to continuing her work on issues such as women's rights, military families, and children.

The Virginia governor's race is considered critical, as the state is a swing state that Democrats hope to convert for the foreseeable future. The contest between McAuliffe and GOP nominee Ken Cuccinelli is dominating the airwaves, with both candidates trying to woo female voters and build a winning coalition.

Obama's appearances are seen as a way to help her husband's cause, as she has a higher approval rating than the president. According to Gallup, Obama's approval rating has slipped below 50%, while her favorable rating stands at 65%. Democratic consultant Tracy Sefl notes that Obama "speaks with a combination of accessible language and emotion" and "audiences find her magnetic."

While some speculate that Obama's recent appearances may be an early sign of her potential candidacy, Professor Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics believes she will likely move on to other pursuits once her husband's term ends. Sabato notes that most first ladies have been content to return to private life after their White House stint.

Obama will appear at the Sheraton in Tysons Corner on Thursday to support McAuliffe, with tickets ranging from $100 to $750. The event is expected to draw several hundred supporters.

Title: Trump's Transparency: Uncovering the Obama Administration's Secrecy

The incoming Trump administration is expected to face skepticism about its legitimacy from the start. Critics will likely accuse it of governing in unprecedented and reckless ways. However, the best response to such charges is to open the books and expose the Obama administration's commandeering of power, which many Americans were unaware of.

In 2009, President Obama released secret Bush administration legal memos that explained why the president was entitled to order torture, deploy troops in American towns and cities, and ignore the Fourth Amendment's prohibition on warrantless searches. Trump should follow this precedent by revealing the secret memos underlying Obama's "targeted killing" drone assassination program. The disclosures would help give the Trump administration a reputation as a champion of transparency.

The article also suggests that Trump should release the paper trail preceding and following the US bombing of Libya in 2011. The US has armed and bankrolled Al-Qaeda-linked groups in Syria, despite federal law prohibiting providing material support to terrorist groups. Americans deserve to see the bureaucratic smoking guns on this fiasco.

Additionally, the article recommends that Trump should reveal the records on US intervention in the Syrian Civil War, which would vindicate his warnings on the campaign trail about plunging deeper into the conflict. The article also suggests that Trump should expose the records on the US bombing of Libya, which has been in chaos since the US joined the assault.

The article also highlights the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) has become largely a mirage under the Obama administration, with federal agencies slamming the door on routine requests, especially from the media. The article notes that the Department of Homeland Security has a dreadful FOIA record, with the agency permitting political appointees to stifle FOIA responses.

The article concludes that Trump's promise to end and replace the Affordable Care Act would be greatly assisted by releasing the memos behind Obama's endless "fixes" to that law. Many sweeping regulations have been rushed into law with shaky rationales or scant evidence, and Obama relied on "bureaucratic bulldozing rather than legislative transparency."

Title: Progress in Closing the Gender Pay Gap Slows Down

The National Committee on Pay Equity has designated Tuesday as Equal Pay Day, a day to highlight the disparity in pay between men and women. According to the latest census data, women working full-time year-round typically earn 78 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts. While this progress may seem steady, closer examination reveals that the gender pay gap has stalled over the past decade.

Research by the Economic Policy Institute shows that men outearn women at every rung of the income ladder. The gap is more pronounced at the higher end, where corporate norms and policies play a significant role in determining pay scales. Women are still paid significantly less than men, even among high-earning individuals.

The gender pay gap is also evident among college-educated workers. The higher the level of education, the bigger the gap. Men and women who have attended but did not graduate from college have the narrowest gap, with women making about 80% of what men made. Among those who have graduated from college, women's pay is about 78% of men's pay, and among those with advanced degrees, women make about 74% of what men make.

The data suggests that the longer the gap persists, the less it can be explained away by factors other than discrimination. The minimum wage is a significant factor influencing pay scales, particularly at the low end of the income ladder. However, even among low-wage workers, women are paid less than men.

These findings underscore the need for continued efforts to address the gender pay gap and promote equal pay for equal work.

Title: EPA's Tier 3 Sulfur Rules: A Costly Pursuit of Minimal Health Benefits

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has issued over 1,920 regulations since President Obama's 2009 inauguration, with many expected to have little to no health or environmental benefits but significant economic and unemployment costs. The latest example is the Tier 3 rule, which aims to further reduce sulfur in gasoline, allegedly improving air quality. However, experts argue that the benefits are minimal and the costs are substantial.

According to the Heritage Foundation, the 20 major EPA rule-making decisions costing $100 million or more annually could cost the United States over $36 billion per year. The Tier 3 rules alone are expected to cost $10 billion in upfront capital expenditures and $2.4 billion in annual compliance expenses, leading to a 6-9 cent increase in gasoline prices.

The American Petroleum Institute and industry experts claim that these costs will ripple throughout the economy, affecting job creation and retention, the price of goods and services, commuting costs, and family vacations. The rules will disproportionately harm poor families, who already struggle with economic burdens.

The EPA's Tier 3 standards are part of its broader anti-hydrocarbon agenda, which has led to a regulatory tsunami. The agency's approach assumes that there is no safe threshold for pollutants and that they must constantly be reduced to zero, despite the fact that competent epidemiologists know that the dose makes the poison. There is a point below which a chemical is not harmful, and some chemicals are essential to proper bodily function at low levels.

The EPA's actions are forcing the country to expend vast resources to achieve minimal or zero quantifiable health benefits. The enormous air- and water-quality improvements to date are adequate, and there is no clear evidence that further reductions are needed to safeguard human health. The agency's approach is not science-based and is instead driven by an anti-hydrocarbon agenda. Scrapping the unnecessary Tier 3 rules is a good place to start, and citizens and lawmakers must ensure that the EPA and the president get the message.

Title: Western Women Joining ISIS: A Growing Concern Amidst the Global Jihad

Article:

A recent report estimates that around 30 Muslim women from the West, mostly from Britain, have joined the Islamic State (ISIS) in the Middle East, sparking widespread shock and concern. However, this phenomenon is not new, as Muslim women have long been a potent force in Islamic jihad. Experts at the Kings College International Center for Radicalization in Britain have been monitoring the online activities of these women, who often attract other women to ISIS and support its recognition as a means to perpetuate itself.

Women join ISIS for various reasons, including a desire to help build the new Islamic State, as called for by ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, or to take on traditional roles such as marriage and childbearing. Others are drawn to the group's call for skilled workers, including doctors, nurses, and engineers. Some women also seek combat and are joining to wage war.

The British female jihadists are often young, including Zara and Salma Halane, 16-year-old twins from Manchester, Aqsa Mahmoud, a 20-year-old from Glasgow, and Khadija Dare, a 22-year-old from London who aspires to be the first ISIS female to behead an "infidel." In the United States, the recent case of 19-year-old Sharon Conley of Colorado is a chilling example of an American female newly converted to Islam and seeking jihad.

Female Islamists, including violent jihadists, have long been prominent. In 2010, Afia Siddiqui, a neuroscientist from Pakistan, was found guilty of attempted murder of U.S. personnel investigating her material support to Al Qaeda. She is now serving an 86-year sentence in federal prison.

Experts note that women have always been swept up by the romance of jihad, just like men. At their most extreme, female jihadists become suicide bombers. Developed by the female Tamil Tigers, suicide bombing was imported by Hezbollah and became the hallmark of the Second Intifada against Israel. Radical clerics issued fatwas legitimizing women as suicide bombers.

Since ISIS burst onto the global stage, we have been enthralled by its brutality – decapitations, crucifixions, the severing of a Christian child in half, the beheadings of babies, and the executions of children by hanging, shooting, and decapitation. Many of these brutalities – executions, stonings, rape, child marriage, forced marriage, and slavery – have befallen women.

If women have been considered in the public discourse, it is mostly through the lens of ISIS' misogyny – commentators worry that even that has been relegated to the margins. However, even less attention has been given to women who choose to participate in ISIS as perpetrators, rather than as victims.

Islamist ideology is intrinsically supremacist, racist, and expansionist. It is also by definition anti-Semitic and misogynistic. Regardless of what attracts them, women jihadists serve a fleeting purpose for ISIS. They are unaware that they will progressively lose their freedoms as they empower Islamism through their actions.

Western women are joining ISIS nonetheless, so Americans must recognize the deadly ideology that attracts them for what it is: lethally totalitarian, misogynistic, anti-Semitic, supremacist, and profoundly anti-democratic. Political Islamism, whether espoused by men or women, is the gravest threat to secular democracy man has known. By unveiling these invisible women for the radical Jihadists they truly are, we can begin to confront Islamist ideology for what it is: a singularly lethal assault upon our sacred ideals.

Title: Congressional Hispanic Caucus Members Removed from Meeting with ICE, Citing Unprecedented Exclusion

Article:

Two members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, Representatives Luis Gutiérrez and Norma Torres, were removed from a meeting with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) on Thursday, just two days after the agency's acting director, Thomas Homan, abruptly canceled a meeting with the CHC. The removal sparked shock and outrage among caucus members, who claimed it was unprecedented and unprecedented in their 20-plus years of experience.

According to Gutiérrez, Republicans asked them to leave the meeting, citing a lack of jurisdictional interest in immigration enforcement. The House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi, stated that ICE determined the guest list, initially excluding all members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, but eventually inviting the caucus chairwoman, Michelle Lujan Grisham.

The meeting was arranged to discuss the recent raids on immigrant communities, which have resulted in the arrest of over 680 undocumented immigrants. The raids were touted by President Donald Trump as a "crackdown on illegal criminals." However, immigrant rights groups and lawmakers have criticized the actions, citing the potential for widespread fear and trauma among affected communities.

The meeting was canceled at the last minute, with ICE citing concerns over the size of the meeting and the need for it to be bipartisan. However, caucus members argued that the explanation was "bullshit" and that administration officials regularly met with nonpartisan groups of lawmakers.

In response to the removal, Pelosi called the incident "unprecedented" and "hopeless," while Senator Kamala Harris of California took to the Senate floor to denounce the president's actions on immigration. Harris emphasized the need to protect the rights of refugees and immigrants, citing the uncertainty and pain caused by the president's actions.

Meanwhile, immigrants across the country participated in a "day without immigrants" boycott, refusing to go to work to highlight their contributions to the American workforce. The boycott was intended to protest Trump's immigration actions, which have sparked widespread fear and uncertainty among immigrant communities.

Title: Trump Arrives in England for State Visit Amidst Diplomatic Tensions

President Donald Trump arrived in England on Monday for a three-day state visit, which has been marred by controversy and diplomatic tensions. In a series of tweets, Trump criticized London Mayor Sadiq Khan, calling him a "stone-cold loser" who has done a "terrible job" as mayor. Trump also compared Khan to New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, saying they share similar qualities.

Khan had previously written an op-ed in the Observer, in which he criticized Trump as a "global threat" and blamed him for stoking the rise of the far-right movement. Trump's visit has sparked debate among British politicians, with some arguing that the country should "hold its nose" and honor the president despite his divisive behavior.

In another diplomatic kerfuffle, Trump denied calling Meghan Markle, the Duchess of Sussex, "nasty," despite an audio recording of his comments to The Sun newspaper suggesting otherwise. Trump's tweets have been met with criticism from the media and the public, with many calling for him to apologize for his comments.

The controversy surrounding Trump's visit has sparked a wider debate about the role of the British monarchy and the country's relationship with the United States. While some argue that the UK should maintain its special relationship with the US, others believe that the country should take a stand against Trump's divisive behavior and values.

The visit is expected to be a closely watched event, with many eyes on Trump's interactions with the British royal family and his potential meetings with Prime Minister Theresa May.

Title: Hawaii Legislature to Consider Marriage Equality Act in Special Session

The Hawaii Legislature will convene in a special session on Monday to consider the Marriage Equality Act, which would legalize same-sex marriage in the state. The bill would make Hawaii the 15th state to recognize same-sex marriage, joining the growing list of jurisdictions that have taken steps to extend marriage rights to same-sex couples.

The debate surrounding same-sex marriage is not new to Hawaii, as the state's Supreme Court ruled in favor of gay couples in 1993. However, a constitutional amendment adopted in 1998 took jurisdiction away from the courts and gave it to the Legislature, which subsequently banned same-sex marriages.

Proponents of the bill, including Governor Neil Abercrombie, argue that the legislation would extend the state's "Aloha spirit of equality" and boost tourism. Opponents, on the other hand, believe that the decision should be left to Hawaiian voters, not lawmakers.

In the lead-up to the special session, rallies have been held in Honolulu, with groups on both sides of the issue expressing their views. The Episcopal Diocese of Hawaii has also announced its support for the bill, making it the largest denomination to do so.

If the bill is approved, it would take effect on November 18. A public hearing on the matter will be held as part of the special session, according to the Hawaii Legislature's website.

Title: Harris Warns Trump of Potential Prosecution for Obstruction of Justice

Article:

In a recent interview, Senator Kamala Harris, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, expressed her stance on potential prosecution of President Trump. Harris stated that if she were to win the presidency, she believes the Justice Department would likely charge Trump with obstruction of justice, citing the department's policy against indicting a sitting president. Once out of office, Trump would be subject to charges, according to Harris.

Harris emphasized the importance of holding everyone accountable for their actions, citing her experience as a former California attorney general and San Francisco district attorney. She believes that the president is not above the law and should be held accountable like anyone else.

Harris is not the only high-profile Democrat to suggest that Trump should face criminal charges once out of office. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has also made similar comments, stating that she wants to see Trump "in prison." Trump responded by calling Pelosi a "nasty, vindictive, horrible person."

Other Democratic presidential candidates, including Senator Elizabeth Warren and Senator Cory Booker, have also hinted that prosecuting Trump might be appropriate. Warren stated that Trump would be "carried out in handcuffs" if he were anyone else, while Booker emphasized the importance of upholding the law and not undermining the independence of the Department of Justice.

It is worth noting that while these comments may be seen as controversial, they are not unprecedented. Trump himself has made similar comments about his political opponents, including Hillary Clinton, during his 2016 presidential campaign.

Title: National Republican Congressional Committee Creates Fake News Websites to Disguise Political Messaging

The National Republican Congressional Committee (NRCC), led by Oregon congressman Greg Walden, has created a network of fake news websites aimed at deceiving voters into believing they are reading news articles when, in fact, they are being fed Republican messaging. The websites, which target Democratic candidates and incumbents, are designed to appear like local news outlets, complete with sections listing "Most Popular" articles and "Most Viewed" videos.

The NRCC has created about two dozen of these fake news sites, each tailored to a specific congressional district. The articles themselves start with a neutral tone, often citing a Democrat's record and encouraging readers to draw their own conclusions. However, they quickly transition into partisan messaging, often using opposition research to support their claims.

The websites are designed to deceive readers, with no clear indication that they are sponsored by the NRCC until the very bottom of the page, where a "Paid for by the National Republican Congressional Committee" disclaimer can be found. Some articles are more egregious than others, with one example targeting Arizona Democrat Ron Barber.

The NRCC's "Tucson Update" article claims that Barber's office is facing questions about his hypocrisy on pay equality, citing an article from the Arizona Daily Star. However, the article is actually an excerpt from NRCC opposition research, which raises questions about the fairness and accuracy of the information presented.

This tactic, known as "talking-point laundering," represents a new level of sophistication in the NRCC's efforts to disguise their messaging as news. In the past, they would rely on the lax ethics standards of certain cable news outlets to transform their talking points into "journalism." With the creation of these fake news websites, the NRCC has cut out the middleman, making it easier to deceive voters and manipulate public opinion.

Title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos Blames Social Media for Polarization, Confirmation Bias

Amazon's founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos, recently spoke at the Wired 25 conference, where he expressed concerns about the role of social media in perpetuating polarization and confirmation bias. According to Bezos, social media companies are creating echo chambers for their users, which can lead to the amplification of identity politics and tribalism.

Bezos' comments were in response to a question about the current state of technology, and he noted that the internet can be a "confirmation bias machine." He explained that when users search for information online, they tend to find content that confirms their existing beliefs, and their newsfeeds often show them information that reinforces their viewpoints.

This phenomenon is supported by a 2017 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, which found that social media algorithms can rely on confirmation biases to surface relevant content for users. The study's co-author, Alessandro Bessi, noted that users tend to seek out information that confirms their pre-existing beliefs and that this can create "well-shaped, highly segregated, and mostly non-interacting communities" around specific topics.

Facebook and Google have faced criticism for their role in perpetuating political bias and confirmation bias. Facebook has removed hundreds of pages and accounts that were spreading misinformation and fake news, while Google's search algorithms have been accused of prioritizing certain viewpoints over others. Twitter has also faced criticism for allowing tribalistic abuse to run rampant on its platform.

Despite his concerns about the current state of technology, Bezos remains optimistic about its potential to drive progress and innovation. He believes that the benefits of technology outweigh the risks and that it is better to continue innovating and taking risks, even if some of those innovations have dual uses.

Bezos' comments highlight the ongoing debate about the role of social media in shaping our online experiences and the potential consequences of confirmation bias. While social media companies have taken steps to address these concerns, the issue remains a topic of ongoing discussion and scrutiny.

Title: Camera Tricks: How Photographers Use Lens Length to Create Misleading Crowd Scenes

As the world slowly reopens, news outlets and social media platforms are filled with images and videos of crowded beaches, parks, and public spaces. However, these visuals may be misleading, and it's not just because of the actual crowd density. A common photography technique, using a zoom or telephoto lens, can compress the foreground and background of a picture, making it appear as though people are closer together than they actually are.

This technique, used by many photographers, can create a false impression of a crowded scene. For instance, a 300mm lens "compresses the crowd and makes it look larger yet more compact, creating more vibrant, more amplified photos," according to Outdoor Photography Guide. This means that a photo of a "crowd" may actually be of people scattered around the beach or park, not as densely packed as it appears.

While this technique can be used to deliberately mislead, it's also a common way to show many people in a crowd without having them appear at different sizes and with a lot of space in between. Photographers may use this technique to capture the essence of a scene, rather than intentionally trying to deceive the viewer.

To illustrate this point, a newspaper editor explained that a photographer shot a beach reopening photo with a long lens because they wanted to accurately depict the scene, not to mislead the public. Similarly, a landscape architect, Jeff Cutler, took photos of a local beach with different lenses to demonstrate how the camera trick can change the appearance of a crowd.

This camera trick also applies to video, as seen in a tweet that appears to show a packed boardwalk in Ocean City, Maryland. However, upon closer inspection, the video shows that the people are actually quite far apart. The man in the baby carrier appears to be just over the shoulder of the woman standing still in the foreground, but by the time the clip cuts off, he's still behind her.

Misleading crowd shots are a problem as we reopen, as people are nervous and trying to avoid crowds. These photos and videos give us fodder to argue with each other on social media, driving tensions ever-higher. If infections don't rise with reopening – perhaps because people are being cautious during their outings and maintaining proper distance – someone will likely dig up these photos to claim that everything was crowded and things turned out just fine anyway.

Title: Republican Presidential Campaign Enters Combative Phase Ahead of Debate

The Republican presidential campaign is gearing up for a more aggressive phase as candidates prepare to take the stage on Wednesday night. The GOP field has seen a shake-up after weeks of stagnation, with Ben Carson overtaking Donald Trump in Iowa and Jeb Bush struggling to regain momentum. Carly Fiorina's strong debate performances have yet to translate into significant poll numbers, and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker has dropped out of the race.

Here are six things to watch in the CNBC debate:

1. Trump's shift in tone: After being challenged by Carson's rise, Trump is expected to take a more aggressive stance, potentially targeting Carson's religious affiliation. However, Carson has shown no interest in engaging in a back-and-forth, preferring to focus on his campaign message.

2. Bush's comeback attempt: Jeb Bush will be two spots removed from Trump on the debate stage, a visual representation of his struggling campaign. His advisors suggest he may try to show a more fiery and loose side to revamp his image.

3. Fiorina's momentum: Despite her strong debate performances, Fiorina's poll numbers have stagnated. Her campaign emphasizes that she is focused on winning over voters at a slow and steady pace.

4. The debt ceiling debate: The issue of raising the debt ceiling is expected to divide the Republican candidates, with some advocating for spending cuts and others supporting a two-year budget deal.

5. The also-ran candidates: Mike Huckabee, Chris Christie, John Kasich, and Rand Paul are struggling to gain traction, with poll numbers stuck around 3%. They face pressure to boost their rankings and persuade donors to keep funding their campaigns.

6. The challenge of keeping viewers engaged: With the novelty of the debates wearing off, candidates face the challenge of keeping viewers interested and engaged. The debate will be kept to just two hours, with opening and closing statements, making it harder for candidates to tackle questions and make a splash.

The stakes are high for the candidates as they face off in the CNBC debate, with the Iowa caucuses just three months away.

Title: Former Governor Mark Sanford Seeks Redemption in Congressional Race

Former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford is seeking to reclaim his seat in the US Congress, a move that comes after his infamous affair and subsequent resignation from office. Sanford is one of 16 Republican candidates vying for the open seat in the 1st Congressional District, which was vacated by Senator Tim Scott's appointment to the Senate.

Sanford's past is well-documented, having been caught lying about his whereabouts during an affair in 2009. However, he claims to have learned from his mistakes and is now seeking redemption. In an interview with CNN, Sanford stated, "At some level or another, we all hope for redemption."

Sanford's bid for redemption is not without its challenges. He faces stiff competition from other Republican candidates, including Teddy Turner, the son of CNN founder Ted Turner, who has gained significant attention and support in recent polls. Turner's family ties and deep pockets have made him a target for opponents, who are filling mailboxes with attack ads.

On the Democratic side, Elizabeth Colbert Busch, the sister of comedian Stephen Colbert, is the favorite to win the primary. She has been running a serious campaign, emphasizing her qualifications and experience.

The race is expected to be a close one, with many of the candidates vying for the attention of voters. State Senator Larry Grooms is another contender, having collected important local endorsements and boasting a strong staff.

John Avlon, a CNN political contributor, believes Sanford's honesty about his personal life has made him more relatable to voters. "There is an affection for a guy who admits he's a sinner and asks for forgiveness, especially down here," Avlon said.

Despite his past transgressions, Sanford maintains he is worthy of the public trust. "Oddly enough, I think you learn from the valleys of life rather than the peaks," Sanford said.

The winner of the Republican primary will likely face off against Elizabeth Colbert Busch in the general election. The race is expected to be a closely watched contest, with many factors at play, including name recognition and voter sentiment.

Title: Trump's Top White House Strategist Steve Bannon's Future Uncertain

Article:

Steve Bannon, the chief executive of the conservative news organization Breitbart News and a key strategist for President Donald Trump's campaign, is facing speculation that he may be losing favor with the president. This comes after a series of policy blunders, which have made Trump appear inexperienced and uninformed.

When asked about Bannon, Trump responded that he "likes" him but emphasized that Bannon was not involved in his campaign until late. Trump also claimed to be his own strategist and strategist, stating that he didn't need to change his strategy because he was facing Hillary Clinton.

This response has raised eyebrows, as it is similar to previous statements made by Trump when distancing himself from other top lieutenants who were implicated in the ongoing investigation into Russian espionage ties to his presidential bid. Whether Trump is hinting that Bannon may also be involved in these ties is unclear.

It is worth noting that Trump's statement about Bannon's involvement in his campaign is not entirely accurate. Bannon was a key figure in the Trump campaign, serving as the executive chairman of the campaign's alternative media arm, Breitbart News. He was also a key advisor to Trump during the campaign and played a significant role in shaping the president's policy agenda.

The uncertainty surrounding Bannon's future in the White House has sparked speculation that he may be on his way out. However, at this time, there is no official confirmation of his departure.

Title: Fact-Checking Claim: Bernie Sanders' Tax Proposal

The claim that 2020 presidential candidate Bernie Sanders proposed a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000 has been circulating on social media. However, a closer examination of the claim reveals it to be false.

The claim likely originated from a memo released by Sanders' Senate office ahead of the introduction of the Medicare for All Act of 2019. The memo discusses different tax proposals to finance his healthcare program, including a progressive income tax schedule with a 52% tax rate, but only applied to incomes over $10 million. Another option proposed is a 7.5% payroll tax, exempting the first $2 million in payroll to protect small businesses. A final option is a 4% income-based premium applicable to all households making more than $29,000.

During the ninth Democratic debate, Sanders' opponent, Pete Buttigieg, questioned the lack of transparency on how to pay for Sanders' healthcare plan, citing the need for a "multi-trillion-dollar hole" even after raising taxes on those making over $29,000. However, there is no instance of Sanders or anyone else mentioning a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000 during the debate.

A review of Sanders' website and public statements confirms that his plan is to finance Medicare for All through a mixture of taxes, including a wealth tax, but there is no mention of a 52% tax rate on incomes above $29,000. The current marginal tax rate for households making more than $29,000 (and below $40,124) is 12%, with the 4% premium being the only evident proposal that could raise taxes on incomes above $29,000.

In conclusion, the claim that Bernie Sanders plans to tax anyone making above $29,000 a year 52% is false.

Title: The GOP Establishment's Record of Failure: A Lesson in Abject Failure

The article discusses the Republican Party's establishment and its track record of choosing candidates that have failed to deliver. The author argues that the establishment's choices have led to a string of failures, citing examples such as Mitt Romney, John McCain, and Bob Dole, who all lost their presidential bids. The article also mentions that even when establishment candidates do win, their presidencies are often unsuccessful, citing George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush as examples.

The author notes that the GOP establishment has a history of opposing candidates who go on to become successful, such as Ted Cruz, Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Marco Rubio. The article also highlights the example of Charlie Crist, who was the establishment's choice for senator but lost to Marco Rubio and later became a registered Democrat.

The author argues that the GOP establishment's record of choosing candidates is a lesson in abject failure, citing the failed senatorial campaigns of Richard Mourdock and Todd Akin as examples. The article also notes that the establishment's choices have led to a lack of accountability and a failure to address important issues such as federal spending and the national debt.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of the grass-roots movement and the need for the Republican National Committee to listen to its voters and allow them to choose their own candidates. The author also mentions the emergence of a new organization, The Real Conservatives National Committee, which aims to challenge the GOP establishment and elect real conservative leaders.

Title: NRA Files Lawsuit Against Florida Over New Gun Control Measures

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has filed a lawsuit against the state of Florida, just hours after Governor Rick Scott signed legislation placing new restrictions on guns in response to the recent mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The gun group claims that one of the bill's provisions, raising the age to buy firearms to 21, "eviscerates" the gun rights of young adults.

The NRA's lawsuit, filed in the Northern District of Florida, argues that the new Florida law violates the Second and 14th Amendments of the US Constitution. The Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, while the 14th Amendment guarantees equal protection under the law.

The NRA's complaint argues that the bill is particularly offensive to women under the age of 21, who are "much less likely to engage in violent crime than older members of the general population who are unaffected by the ban." The organization also claims that the bill is an affront to the Second Amendment, as it "totally eviscerates the #2A rights of law-abiding adults to keep and bear arms."

The Florida bill includes new gun control measures, such as raising the age to buy firearms to 21, imposing a three-day waiting period on most firearms, banning bump stocks, and allowing police to petition in court for a risk protection order. The bill does not include an assault weapons ban.

The NRA's lawsuit names Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi and Rick Swearingen, commissioner of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, as defendants. Bondi, a Republican, said in a statement she is proud of the law, stating, "This bill is not perfect, and sadly it will not bring back the 17 lives lost in the horrific school shooting, but the safety of our children is not a political issue – it's simply the right thing to do."

Cameron Kasky, one of the survivors of the February 14 Parkland shooting, said in a tweet that the Florida bill was only the first step.

Title: U.S. Officials Struggle to Gauge Threat from American Fighters in Syria

U.S. intelligence officials are tracking at least 140 American citizens who have joined the fight in Syria and Iraq, with the number more than doubling since the beginning of the year. The problem is that officials are unsure which groups these fighters have joined, with some joining the Islamic State or al-Qaida's affiliate in Syria, Jabhat al-Nusra, which are both designated terrorist organizations. The chaos on the ground makes it difficult to distinguish between groups, and U.S. officials are taking a cautious approach, assuming the worst-case scenario.

The story of former Army Private Eric Harroun is a prime example. Harroun spent about six weeks fighting with rebel groups in Syria, initially linked to the Free Syrian Army. He documented his journey on Facebook and YouTube, posting videos that showed him in the midst of battle. However, he later joined an avowedly anti-American Islamist fighting force called the Al-Aqsa Islamic Brigades, which led to his arrest on terrorism charges.

Harroun's case highlights the complexity of the situation in Syria, where the fighting is chaotic and it is difficult to determine which groups are fighting for what reasons. U.S. officials are concerned that American citizens who join the fight may be getting caught up in a game beyond their comprehension, and that it is a bad idea for U.S. citizens to be fighting on the ground in Syria.

The U.S. attorney in Virginia, Neil MacBride, who led the Harroun prosecution, stated that there has yet to be a happy ending for U.S. citizens who have gone abroad to fight in Syria. Harroun's story did not end well, as he was arrested and later died of an overdose of prescription pills.

U.S. officials are taking a cautious approach, assuming the worst-case scenario, and arresting people before they leave for Syria. A handful of people have been arrested so far this year, nearly all of which have some connection to the Islamic State. The FBI has started arresting people before they leave for Syria, and U.S. officials are urging Americans to avoid getting involved in the conflict.

Title: Trump Criticizes Sanford, Latest Republican to Challenge Him in Primary Contest

Article:

President Donald Trump has lashed out at Mark Sanford, a former South Carolina governor, who is the latest Republican to challenge him in the party's primary contest. Trump described Sanford and two other hopefuls as "badly failed candidates" and brought up Sanford's extramarital affair with an Argentine woman in 2009. The president also recalled the scandal in June 2009 when Sanford went missing for several days, with his staff telling reporters he had gone to hike the Appalachian Trail, but later admitted he had gone to Argentina to see his mistress.

Sanford, 59, announced his decision to challenge Trump during an interview with Fox News on Sunday, stating that he believes the Republican Party has lost its way on issues such as debt and deficits. He plans to center his campaign on cutting government debt and spending.

Trump now has three official challengers for the 2020 Republican presidential nomination, with analysts not expecting them to succeed in wrestling the Republican mantle from him. No sitting president in the modern era has lost the race to be nominee for their own party, and Trump remains very popular with Republicans.

The Republican National Convention, at which the nominee will be formally chosen, will take place in late August 2020 after a series of state primary elections and party caucuses. Some state Republican parties, including in South Carolina, have decided not to hold primaries in 2020 to clear the path for Trump and save money.

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order on Law Enforcement Reform Amidst Ongoing Protests and Calls for Change

President Trump has signed an executive order titled "Safe Policing for Safe Communities" in response to the death of George Floyd and the subsequent protests and calls for reform in the law enforcement system. The order aims to promote accountability in law enforcement, equip police officers for constructive community engagement, and uphold clear and high policing standards.

According to the White House, the executive order will address issues such as use of force best practices, information sharing to track officers with repeated complaints against them, and federal incentives for police departments to deploy non-police experts on issues like mental health, homelessness, and addiction.

The president did not provide specific details about the order during a roundtable discussion, but emphasized the importance of law and order and justice. The White House tweeted that the order will "help law enforcement build trust and effectively serve the community as our first line of defense here at home."

The executive order comes as Trump faces criticism over his handling of the unrest following Floyd's death and his efforts to balance his desire to be a "LAW & ORDER!" president with his campaign's efforts to court black voters. The order is seen as an attempt to add to his record on criminal justice reform, which includes the criminal justice reform legislation he signed in 2018.

Meanwhile, Trump has threatened to send federal forces to clear out protesters from a six-block area of downtown Seattle, which has been declared "cop-free" by its occupants. The area, known as the "Capitol Hill Organized Protest" or CHOP, has been the site of ongoing protests and demonstrations.

Title: Uber Driver Arrested in Connection with Michigan Rampage that Left Six Dead and Two Wounded

A 45-year-old married father of two, Jason Dalton, has been arrested in connection with a shooting rampage that left six people dead and two others wounded in Kalamazoo, Michigan, on Saturday night. According to authorities, Dalton was working as an Uber driver at the time of the incident.

Dalton passed a background check when he was hired by Uber, and he had no criminal record, with only five traffic violations. The Michigan prosecutor, Jeff Getting, confirmed that authorities are investigating a Facebook post that indicated Dalton picked up Uber customers around the time of the shootings.

Dalton lived in a ranch-style house outside Kalamazoo with his wife of at least 15 years and two children, ages 10 and 15. His wife cooperated with police in their investigation after being contacted by authorities to ensure she was not a victim.

The shooting spree began around 6 p.m. in the parking lot of an apartment complex in Richland Township, where a woman was shot and seriously wounded. The suspect was arrested without incident early Sunday morning in downtown Kalamazoo, following a massive manhunt. Authorities found weapons in his vehicle.

The victims included four people killed outside a Cracker Barrel restaurant and a father and son killed outside a Kia dealership. A 14-year-old girl was wounded and remains in critical condition, while a woman shot outside an apartment complex is in serious condition.

Kalamazoo County Undersheriff Paul Matyas described the shootings as "our worst-case scenario," stating that authorities do not believe the shootings were targeted at specific people. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities still trying to determine a motive for the rampage.

Title: Saudi Arabia's Oil Production Capacity: A Matter of Spare Capacity and Market Balance

The White House has clarified that Saudi Arabia's leader, King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud, told President Donald Trump that the country has 2 million barrels per day of spare capacity, which it can use if needed to ensure market balance. This statement appears to row back on an earlier tweet by Trump, which suggested Saudi Arabia had agreed to boost oil production by 2 million barrels per day.

According to the White House, Trump discussed the oil market with King Salman during a call on Friday, and the Saudi leader emphasized the need to preserve oil market stability and efforts by oil-producing countries to compensate for any potential shortage. The statement did not mention any intention by Saudi Arabia to raise production by 2 million barrels per day.

A source familiar with Saudi Arabia's production plans told a news agency earlier in the week that the kingdom intends to increase output by 200,000 barrels per day this month. This would be in line with the agreement reached by OPEC and non-OPEC nations, including Russia, to boost production by 700,000 to 1 million barrels a day.

Saudi Arabia's spare capacity is reportedly 2 million barrels per day, which it can use if needed to ensure market balance. However, a consultancy expert noted that bringing this capacity online would take time and money, potentially up to one year.

Benchmark Brent crude was trading around $79 a barrel on Friday, and a poll showed prices are expected to remain strong for the rest of the year due to supply disruptions in countries like Libya and Venezuela, as well as the extra oil from OPEC failing to meet rising demand.

The Trump administration is pushing countries to cut all imports of Iranian oil from November, when the United States re-imposes sanctions against Tehran, after Trump withdrew from the 2015 nuclear deal. The US is prepared to work with countries on a case-by-case basis to help them reduce imports of Iranian oil and suggested some exemptions were possible.

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei accused the US of trying to turn Iranians against their government, while Iran's OPEC governor, Hossein Kazempour Ardebili, accused the US and Saudi Arabia of trying to push up oil prices and acting against the foundation of OPEC.

Title: Justice Department Continues Investigation into Possible Civil Rights Violations in Trayvon Martin Shooting

The Justice Department is continuing its investigation into possible civil rights violations in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, despite the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the state trial. The investigation, which began over a year ago, has not turned up any evidence of racial bias on Zimmerman's part, according to previously filed FBI documents.

Attorney General Eric Holder has confirmed that the department is still investigating, while expressing concern for the Martin family and those who are pressuring the DOJ to take action. Holder emphasized the importance of addressing the underlying attitudes, mistaken beliefs, and stereotypes that contribute to such incidents.

However, Florida defense attorney Brian Tannebaum believes that the lack of new evidence makes it unlikely that the Justice Department will pursue a federal case against Zimmerman. "There's been an acquittal. The evidence has not changed. It's not like the feds are going to go in and find more evidence," he said.

The question of racial bias is key in this case, as federal hate-crimes law is one of the few tools the department would have to pursue a case. However, it is unclear how the department could prove racial bias, as no evidence of such bias has been found.

The Justice Department has used federal civil rights law before to pursue defendants who had been acquitted at the state level, but in this case, the circumstances are different. There is no video of the shooting, and the federal hate-crimes law applies to both law enforcement and civilians.

The department has received pressure from some groups to pursue the case further, including the NAACP, which has posted a petition on the website MoveOn.org. Attorney General Holder plans to speak at the NAACP convention on Tuesday.

Title: Washington Warns of Looming Fiscal Crisis as Debt Ceiling Deadline Approaches

The Obama administration has issued a warning to House Republicans that a deal on increasing the federal debt limit may need to be reached sooner than expected, as the country approaches two looming deadlines. In a letter to House Speaker John Boehner, Treasury Secretary Jack Lew emphasized the importance of extending the nation's borrowing authority to prevent a potential default.

The debt ceiling, currently set at $16.7 trillion, is expected to run out in the middle of October, according to Lew, leaving the Treasury Department with limited "extraordinary measures" to avoid bumping up against the limit. If Congress fails to raise the cap, the country may face a default, which could have severe economic consequences.

The warning comes as Congress and the Obama administration are still working to agree on a temporary spending deal to prevent a partial government shutdown. The process is complicated by disagreements over the sequester, which started this spring, and the ongoing debate over the Affordable Care Act.

In his letter, Lew emphasized that extending borrowing authority does not increase government spending, but rather allows the Treasury to pay for expenditures Congress has previously approved. He urged Congress to take responsibility for protecting the nation's credit by extending the borrowing authority.

Boehner's office responded by stating that the debt ceiling is a reminder of the country's failure to address its debt and deficit under President Obama. The debt ceiling was last increased in 2011, when Boehner and Obama reached a deal that included roughly $900 billion in spending cuts and an increase in borrowing authority.

The debt ceiling has had a significant economic impact, causing financial markets to fluctuate and contributing to Standard & Poor's downgrade of the U.S. credit rating. Economists had predicted the federal government would no longer be able to pay its bills after Labor Day, but some had estimated the deadline to be closer to November.

The White House and a group of Republican senators have been working on proposed fiscal deals to avoid last-minute negotiations, but talks have stalled. Boehner has indicated he wants to pass a short-term spending bill to avoid a government shutdown, but has vowed to put up a "whale of a fight" over the debt limit.

Michigan Rep. Sander Levin, the top Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee, urged the GOP to increase the debt limit, stating that Republicans must "do the right thing – not the far right thing." With only nine legislative days scheduled in September, Levin emphasized the need for Republicans to move beyond brinksmanship and work towards a solution.

Title: Florida Governor's Response to Hurricane Irma Criticized by Mainstream Media

Article:

Florida Governor Rick Scott's response to Hurricane Irma has been criticized by the Mainstream Media, with The Washington Post publishing an article claiming that Scott "refused to recognize climate-change risks." The article stated that Scott's office did not respond to a request for comment, which some critics have interpreted as an attempt to avoid addressing the issue.

However, the article's headline and content have been met with skepticism by some, who argue that the Governor's office may have been too busy dealing with the aftermath of the storm to respond to media inquiries. The article's focus on Scott's supposed refusal to acknowledge climate change has been seen as an attempt to advance a political point, rather than providing a balanced and informative report.

The article quotes political critics of Scott at length, but fails to include any opposing viewpoints. The article's tone has been criticized for being overly critical and one-sided, with some accusing the Mainstream Media of using the crisis to advance a political agenda.

The article's claims about Scott's response to Hurricane Irma have been disputed by some, who argue that the Governor's office was focused on responding to the storm and providing aid to affected residents, rather than engaging in a debate about climate change. The article's focus on Scott's supposed refusal to acknowledge climate change has been seen as an attempt to distract from the Governor's efforts to respond to the storm.

It is worth noting that the article's claims about the scientific consensus on climate change are not universally accepted, and that there is ongoing debate among scientists and experts about the role of human activity in global warming. The article's failure to include opposing viewpoints and its one-sided tone have been criticized by some as an example of the Mainstream Media's tendency to advance a political agenda rather than providing balanced and informative reporting.

Title: Trump Gives Congress Six-Month Deadline to Fix US Immigration System, Ending DACA

The United States Attorney General, Jeff Sessions, announced on Tuesday that President Donald Trump has given Congress a six-month deadline to fix the country's immigration system. As part of this deadline, the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, established by the Obama administration, will come to an end after the deadline.

DACA grants work permits to undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children, allowing them to work legally and live without fear of deportation. Sessions stated that the program was an "unconstitutional exercise of authority" since only Congress has the power to create such a program.

President Trump issued a statement saying that his highest duty is to defend the American people and the Constitution, but he also recognizes that the US is a nation of laws. He expressed his willingness to work with Congress to find a legislative solution.

Before the announcement, Trump had tweeted that it was time for Congress to fix the immigration system, hinting that his administration would end DACA but delay enforcing the decision to give Congress time to act. The administration hopes that the six-month deadline will give Congress enough time to come up with a legislative fix before the government stops renewing permits for people already covered by the program.

The DACA program was established in 2012 to protect young immigrants, known as "dreamers," who did not choose to violate US immigration law since they were brought to the country by their parents or other family members. The program has protected roughly 800,000 people from deportation, allowing them to work legally and live without fear of deportation.

The president has been weighing his options on what to do about the program, with some Republican state officials threatening to sue the administration if he did not end the program. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said that Trump is in the process of finalizing a decision and wants to make sure it is done correctly.

Many people have protested the potential ending of the program, citing its economic impact. According to a survey from the Center for American Progress, 91% of DACA recipients are employed. Some members of President Trump's evangelical advisory board have also asked him to protect the "dreamers."

The White House hopes that delaying the enforcement of the decision by six months will give Congress time to act on a broader solution for immigration reform.

Title: Trump Endorses House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator John McCain in Republican Party Reconciliation

Article:

In a sudden turn of events, US presidential candidate Donald Trump has publicly endorsed House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator John McCain, just days after refusing to do so in a high-profile spat within the Republican Party. Trump's decision to endorse Ryan and McCain comes after the two had criticized his attacks on the parents of a US Muslim soldier killed in Iraq.

During a campaign stop in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Trump expressed his support for Ryan, stating, "I support and endorse our Speaker... Paul Ryan. We need unity - we have to win this election." Trump also endorsed Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire. In an earlier interview with the Washington Post, Trump had said he was "just not quite there yet" when asked about endorsing Ryan and McCain.

The endorsement marks a significant reconciliation between Trump and the Republican Party leadership, which had been strained due to Trump's criticism of Ryan and McCain. The two had criticized Trump's attacks on the parents of Humayun Khan, a US Muslim soldier killed in Iraq in 2004.

The development comes as Trump's campaign continues to gain momentum, with tens of thousands attending his rallies and over $80 million in campaign funds raised in July alone. The Republican establishment had initially been hesitant to support Trump, but his campaign's success has led to a shift in their stance.

Title: Hollywood Stars' Call for Unity Falls Under the Radar Amidst Polarized News Coverage

The 92nd Academy Awards, held on February 9, saw two prominent actors, Renee Zellweger and Joaquin Phoenix, use their acceptance speeches to promote unity and inclusivity. Despite being influential figures, their messages were largely overlooked in media coverage, which instead focused on controversy and partisanship. Zellweger and Phoenix emphasized the importance of common ground and the need to work together to address social issues.

Zellweger highlighted the power of shared heroes, stating, "When we look to our heroes, we agree, and that matters." She listed a range of inspirational figures, from Neil Armstrong to Harriet Tubman, to illustrate the idea that people can come together despite their differences. Phoenix, meanwhile, emphasized the need to use one's voice to advocate for marginalized groups, saying, "I think, whether we're talking about gender inequality or racism or queer rights or indigenous rights, we're talking about the fight against injustice."

Despite these uplifting messages, the media largely failed to cover these calls for unity, instead focusing on more sensational topics like celebrity feuds and lavish gift bags. This oversight is particularly striking given the current state of political polarization in the United States, where reminders of commonalities and shared values are desperately needed.

While some outlets did acknowledge the speeches, such as CNN and Vulture, the lack of widespread coverage is a missed opportunity to promote a positive message of unity and inclusivity. As the entertainment industry's biggest stars, Zellweger and Phoenix's words carry significant weight, and their emphasis on common ground and social justice is a message that resonates with many Americans.

Title: Deaf Individuals Face Systemic Barriers and Injustices, Highlighting the Need for Increased Accessibility and Understanding

The experiences of deaf individuals, such as Robert Kim, Daniel Kevin Harris, Pearl Pearson, and Magdiel Sanchez, serve as a stark reminder of the systemic barriers and injustices they face. These incidents, as noted by Amiel Fields-Meyer in a 2017 article for The Atlantic, are a result of officers' gaps in cultural competency and miscommunication, often leading to the use of deadly force.

Deaf individuals face numerous challenges, including limited access to mental health services, healthcare, and sign language, as well as inadequate online accessibility and limited employment opportunities. These inequalities disproportionately affect people of color, exacerbating the burden of their effects.

In an effort to raise awareness of these systemic barriers and stigmas attached to deafness, a performer accepted an invitation to sign the national anthem at the Super Bowl. Although the performance was not made accessible to all viewers, the individual hoped it would spark action and promote understanding.

One way to take action is by respecting all languages and identities, as demonstrated by parents who learned sign language to communicate with their deaf children. This can lead to better laws and a higher quality of life. The National Association of the Deaf has posted videos of the performer's entire performances on YouTube.

Title: Lawmakers Question Legality of Obama Administration's Bergdahl-Taliban Swap

The controversy surrounding the Obama administration's decision to release five high-ranking Taliban members in exchange for Army Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl's freedom continues to unfold on Capitol Hill. The swap, which was carried out without the consent of Congress, has sparked outrage among many lawmakers and Bergdahl's fellow soldiers, who view him as a deserter.

Two top lawmakers on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein and Republican Senator Saxby Chambliss, have expressed concerns that the administration broke the law by not informing Congress before the prisoner exchange. Chambliss stated that he had not had a conversation with the White House about a possible exchange for at least 18 months.

Senator Feinstein echoed these concerns, saying that the administration's actions were "totally not following the law" and that the committee is "very dismayed" about the situation. Former federal prosecutor Andy McCarthy, who put the Blind Sheik in prison for his role in the first World Trade Center bombing, has also expressed concerns about the rule of law not being followed. Judge Andrew Napolitano agrees that this situation could be grounds for impeachment.

The controversy has left the White House facing a major problem, as many had expected the Bergdahl decision to be met with "euphoria." The situation highlights the ongoing debate about the balance between national security and the rule of law, and the Obama administration's handling of the Bergdahl-Taliban swap has sparked a heated discussion on Capitol Hill.

Title: US Government Shutdown Enters Record-Breaking 22nd Day, No End in Sight

The partial shutdown of the US government has reached its 22nd day, surpassing the previous record of 21 days in 1995-96 under then-President Bill Clinton. The impasse is due to President Donald Trump's refusal to approve a budget unless it includes funds for a border wall with Mexico. About a quarter of the federal government remains shut down, leaving around 800,000 employees unpaid.

On Friday, those workers, including prison guards, airport staff, and FBI agents, missed their first salaries of the year. President Trump has calmed speculation about declaring a national emergency to bypass Congress and get the necessary funds. He described such a move as an "easy way out" but said he would prefer Congress to resolve the issue. However, if Congress fails to do so, he would consider declaring a national emergency.

Democrats have threatened to challenge such a move in court. Meanwhile, some federal workers have shared their blank paychecks on social media, with one aerospace engineer at NASA posting a $0 paycheck and another air traffic controller showing a payslip with a single cent payment.

A food bank in Washington D.C. is organizing pop-up markets for unpaid federal workers, while a classified advertising website, Craigslist, has seen an influx of listings from government employees trying to sell their possessions. Thousands of federal employees have applied for unemployment benefits amid the financial uncertainty.

The House and Senate passed a bill to ensure government workers receive retroactive pay after the shutdown ends, which President Trump is expected to sign. However, this may offer little comfort to those affected by the impasse. The president is still demanding that Democrats approve funding for a wall or steel barrier, while the Democratic leader of the House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, has said the ball is in the president's court.

The White House is considering diverting some disaster relief funds to pay for the wall, but this option is not under serious consideration, according to Republican congressman Mark Meadows.

Title: Middle East Chaos: A Complex Issue with No Simple Solutions

The Middle East has long been a region plagued by conflict and instability, with various actors and interests at play. The recent stabbings and shootings in Israel, including the murder of an American and his Israeli wife, have sparked outrage and concern. The incident has also highlighted the complex and deeply entrenched issues in the region.

The Palestinian gunmen responsible for the attack celebrated their actions on social media, while the Israeli government condemned the violence. The US government has expressed its concern and called for calm, urging all parties to refrain from actions that escalate tensions.

The situation is complex, with both sides having valid concerns and grievances. The Israeli government has accused the Palestinian Authority of not doing enough to prevent such attacks, while the Palestinian Authority has accused Israel of perpetuating occupation and oppression.

The Middle East is a region where chaos and violence have been a part of its history, and it is difficult to pinpoint a single cause or solution. The recent attack is a stark reminder of the devastating consequences of violence and the need for a peaceful resolution.

It is essential to approach this issue with a nuanced understanding of the complexities involved, rather than simplistic blame or finger-pointing. The international community must work together to promote a peaceful and lasting solution, recognizing the legitimate rights and concerns of all parties involved.

Title: Lawyer Returns to Supreme Court to Argue Against Gerrymandering 55 Years After Landmark Voting Rights Case

Emmet Jopling Bondurant II, an 82-year-old lawyer, is set to argue before the Supreme Court again, this time against partisan redistricting in North Carolina. This case bookends his legal career, which began with a landmark voting rights case in the 1960s. Bondurant was part of the team that successfully argued for equal population numbers in congressional districts, leading to the "One Person, One Vote" principle.
