In the 1960s, Bondurant was frustrated by the segregationists dominating Georgia politics and began studying how elections worked in the state and around the country. He noticed that urban populations had grown significantly, but politicians were not adjusting the districts accordingly. This led to malapportioned districts, where some districts had significantly more voters than others, giving certain groups more political power.

Bondurant compares this practice to partisan redistricting, also known as gerrymandering, today. He believes that politicians want to maintain the status quo and avoid new competition, rather than creating fair and equal districts.

In the 1960s, Bondurant worked on a case, Wesberry v. Sanders, which aimed to force states to draw new political maps with equal populations in each district. The case went to the Supreme Court, and Bondurant argued before the court at the age of 26. The court ruled in favor of Bondurant's side, requiring states with more than one House representative to have districts with the same population.

Bondurant has had a long and distinguished legal career, winning big corporate cases and taking on cases for individuals and small civil rights groups. He has been an ally to people of color and has risked his reputation to fight for their rights.

In this latest case, Bondurant is asking the court to block partisan redistricting in North Carolina, which has ensured that Republicans would dominate the congressional delegation. Despite being 82 years old, Bondurant has no plans to retire and continues to fight for democracy and fair representation.

Title: Colorado House Passes Bills to Limit Ammunition Magazines and Implement Universal Background Checks

The Colorado House has passed four gun control measures, including limits on the size of ammunition magazines and universal background checks, amidst emotional debates and strong resistance from Republicans. The bills were approved on Monday, with the Democratic-controlled House voting 34-31 in favor of the magazine restrictions and 33-32 in favor of the background checks.

The proposed legislation limits magazines to 15 rounds for firearms and eight for shotguns, with three Democrats joining all Republicans in voting against the bill. Republicans argued that the proposals restrict Second Amendment rights and will not prevent mass shootings like those in Aurora and a Connecticut elementary school.

The House also approved a bill requiring background checks on all gun purchases, including those between private sellers and firearms bought online. Other proposals would ban concealed firearms at colleges and stadiums, and another requires that gun purchasers pay for their own background checks.

While some Democrats joined Republicans in voting against the bills, the Democrats' 37-28 advantage in the House gave them enough leeway to pass the measures. The Senate still needs to consider the proposals, and Democrats will need to be more unified in their support to ensure passage.

The debate highlights a fundamental philosophical difference between many Democrats and Republicans, with Democrats pushing for stricter gun control measures and Republicans advocating for Second Amendment rights. The bills are now headed to the Senate, where they will face further consideration and debate.

Title: Biden Leads Trump Among Voters Who Don't Like Either Candidate

Article:

Presumed Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden is gaining ground among voters who do not have a favorable opinion of either him or President Trump, according to recent polls. This "least-worst" scenario is a key factor in Biden's electability argument, as he is able to attract working-class voters who may not have been enthusiastic about Hillary Clinton in 2016.

Exit polls from the 2016 election showed that nearly one-fifth of voters in key swing states like Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin did not have a favorable opinion of their options on the ballot. Trump outperformed Clinton among these voters, winning by 37 percentage points in Wisconsin, 25 points in Pennsylvania, and 21 points in Michigan. These voters contributed to Trump's slim margins of victory in those states.

A recent Monmouth University poll found that 20% of respondents do not have a high opinion of either Trump or Biden. However, Biden bested Trump among this subset of voters by a 59% to 17% margin. The same poll showed that the composition of the "dislike both" group has shifted, with 51% of voters leaning Democratic and 21% leaning Republican.

Another key difference between the two election cycles is that the pool of "favor neither" voters has shrunk, as more Republicans appear to have picked sides. A Morning Consult poll found that Biden held a 45% to 42% lead over Trump, while a recent OH Predictive Insights poll found Biden with a 50% to 43% edge in Arizona.

Overall, Biden's ability to attract voters who do not have a favorable opinion of either him or Trump is a key factor in his electability argument. While Trump has a silver lining in the poll numbers, with a slight increase in support among voters who do not like either candidate, Biden's lead among this group remains significant.

Title: Democrats Coordinate Disruptive Tactics to Stall Kavanaugh Confirmation Hearing

The confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh got off to a chaotic start, with Democratic senators employing tactics to stall the process and raise concerns about access to documents. The hearing, which began on Tuesday, saw Democratic senators repeatedly object, delay, and even attempt to adjourn the proceedings amid requests for more documents and time to review the files.

According to reports, Democratic senators coordinated their strategy over the holiday weekend, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer reportedly leading a phone call discussing protest plans. However, the party's top lawmakers ultimately decided against staging a mass walkout, fearing it would backfire and help the Republican Party.

The hearing saw younger Democrats, such as California Sen. Kamala Harris, hijack the proceedings almost immediately, urging the committee to delay the hearing amid protests by liberal activists. Harris received praise for her defiance of the chamber's norms, with some calling her a "leader" for taking a stand.

Despite the obstructionist tactics, Democrats also allowed themselves to become part of the process, grilling Kavanaugh during the hearing and hoping to mobilize opposition to his candidacy. However, the strategy may still backfire, as moderate Republicans may not be swayed by the Democratic tactics.

The hearing also saw a viral moment when Fred Guttenberg, the father of a Parkland shooting victim, approached Kavanaugh for a handshake, only for the nominee to walk away. Guttenberg said it was his decision to approach Kavanaugh, and not part of a coordinated plan.

Title: The Obama Administration's Missteps in Egypt: Who Lost the Country?

The United States government is reportedly planning to significantly reduce its aid to Egypt, a move that has sparked concerns about the future of the country's relationship with the US. The decision comes as a result of the country's tumultuous political landscape, which has seen the rise and fall of the Muslim Brotherhood and the military's subsequent takeover.

The story begins in 2009, when President Barack Obama delivered a speech at Cairo University, outlining his vision for US relations in the Middle East. In the speech, Obama emphasized the importance of democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. Many in the Arab world took him at his word, but the promises proved to be hollow.

The Western media, which had initially hailed the Arab Spring as a revolution, failed to understand the complexities of the situation. The term "Arab Spring" is often seen as a misnomer, as it implies a sudden and peaceful transition to democracy, which did not occur. In reality, the protests were hijacked by autocratic forces, including the Muslim Brotherhood.

The Obama administration's handling of the situation has been criticized for its lack of clarity and consistency. The US government failed to understand the Muslim Brotherhood, describing it as "moderate" despite its authoritarian tendencies. The election of Mohammed Morsi, the Brotherhood's leader, was seen as a victory for democracy, but in reality, he became a authoritarian ruler who suppressed opposition and led the country into economic collapse.

The Western media's failure to accurately report on the situation has contributed to the loss of Egypt as a key ally. The country's 14 million protesters, who took to the streets against the Brotherhood, were ignored, and the military's subsequent takeover was met with criticism.

The reduction in US aid to Egypt is likely to worsen relations between the two countries, rather than bring about democratic change. The Obama administration's mistakes have had far-reaching consequences, and the question remains: Who lost Egypt?

Title: US Proposes Collecting Social Media History of Visa Applicants

The US State Department has announced a proposal that would require nearly everyone seeking a visa to enter the country to provide details of their social media history. The proposal would affect around 14.7 million people annually, including those seeking both immigrant and non-immigrant visas. Applicants would need to disclose all social media identities used in the past five years, as well as five years of their telephone numbers, email addresses, and travel history. They would also be asked if they had ever been deported from a country or if any relatives had been involved in terrorist activity.

The proposal would not apply to citizens from countries that have visa-free travel status with the US, such as the UK, Canada, France, and Germany. However, citizens from non-exempt countries like India, China, and Mexico could be affected if they visit the US for work or a holiday.

The proposal aims to help identify potential extremists and is a response to the 2015 San Bernardino shootings, in which 14 people died. The authorities had missed signs of radicalization in messages on a messaging platform sent between the attackers.

The proposal is subject to approval by the Office of Management and Budget and the public will have two months to comment on it before a decision is made. Civil liberties groups have condemned the policy as an invasion of privacy that could damage free speech.

The social media platforms covered in the proposal include US-based entities such as Instagram, LinkedIn, Reddit, and YouTube, as well as overseas platforms like China's Sina Weibo and Russia's VK social network.

Title: Expert Witness Testifies that Impeachment Case Against Trump is "Woefully Inadequate" and "Dangerous"

A legal expert, Jonathan Turley, testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, expressing concerns about the integrity of the impeachment process against President Trump. Turley, a law professor at George Washington University Law School, stated that while he is not a supporter of the president, he believes the current legal case for impeachment is "woefully inadequate" and "dangerous."

Turley's testimony focused on the July 25 phone call between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which Trump pressed Zelensky for investigations that could help him politically. Turley argued that the reference to the Hunter Biden deal with Burisma should never have occurred and is worthy of criticism, but it is not a case of bribery. He stated that the issue is not whether the comments are correct, but whether they are corrupt.

Turley also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of lowering impeachment standards to fit a paucity of evidence and an abundance of anger. He emphasized the importance of rising above the "age of rage" and engaging in a civil and substantive discussion.

The hearing is part of the House impeachment inquiry into President Trump's actions, which began in September. The inquiry is centered around Trump's phone call with Zelensky, in which he pressed for investigations that could help him politically. The White House has declined to participate in the hearing, calling it "baseless and highly partisan."

The hearing will continue with a 45-minute period for Democrats, followed by 45 minutes for Republicans, and then five-minute rounds for each of the 41 members. The hearing is expected to set the stage for the next phase of the House impeachment inquiry into the president.

Title: Trump and May Discuss Potential "Phenomenal" Post-Brexit Trade Deal

Article:

During his state visit to London, US President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Theresa May discussed the potential for a "phenomenal" post-Brexit trade deal between the United States and the United Kingdom. Trump stated that the two countries could do two to three times the amount of trade they are currently conducting, emphasizing the tremendous potential in the deal.

May, who is stepping down as head of the Conservative Party this week, will remain as prime minister until her successor is chosen. The new prime minister will be responsible for achieving Brexit and any bilateral trade deal with the US.

During the joint news conference, Trump avoided any rhetoric that could embarrass May, glossing over even the most sensitive issues such as Huawei and her succession. He mentioned Boris Johnson, who has stated that the United Kingdom should leave the European Union on October 31, deal or no deal, and Jeremy Hunt, Britain's foreign minister who has warned against leaving without a deal.

When asked about the UK's decision to allow Huawei a limited role in 5G networks, Trump said he would work out any issues with the UK, emphasizing the strong intelligence relationship between the two countries. He stated that there are no limitations on their cooperation and that they will have no problem with Huawei's involvement.

The Trump administration has previously advised allies not to use Huawei's 5G technology and equipment due to concerns about Chinese espionage. Huawei denies any involvement in Chinese intelligence.

The state visit, promised by May back in January 2017, aimed to celebrate the "special relationship" between the US and the UK, boost trade links, and reaffirm security cooperation. Trump praised the UK as a "great, great country" that wants its own identity, borders, and affairs.

May praised the "precious and profound" alliance between the US and the UK, stating that friends can also be open to disagreement, such as on the Iran nuclear deal and the Paris climate agreement. The UK still supports the international agreement to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions, while Trump has withdrawn the US from the deal.

Title: The "Resistance" Media Strategy Fizzles: A Business Model in Decline

The article discusses the struggles faced by media outlets that have devoted significant resources to attacking President Trump and his supporters. The Weekly Standard, a 28-year-old neoconservative institution, is reportedly on the verge of dissolution after its founder, Bill Kristol, spent almost three years attacking the President. Similarly, other liberal-leaning media outlets, such as Vice, Vox, Mic, Buzzfeed, and Mashable, are either looking for buyers or reevaluating their strategies to become profitable. Mic has laid off most of its workers, while Vice and Vox are firing staff.

The article also highlights the decline of CNN, which has abandoned its journalistic tradition and ethics to focus on a partisan crusade against President Trump. As a result, its ratings have plummeted, falling behind the Hallmark Channel and Home and Garden Television in October.

The article concludes that the "resistance" media strategy is not only corrosive to the country but also a losing business model. Bill Kristol's descent into fringe irrelevance and the possible end of his once-illustrious magazine serve as a perfect illustration.

Title: Rep. Tulsi Gabbard Focuses on Ending Wars, Criticizes Trump's Iran Policy

Article: Representative Tulsi Gabbard, a Democratic presidential candidate, has been a vocal critic of the United States' aggressive foreign policy during the first Democratic debate. When asked about rejoining the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, Gabbard gave a clear "yes," warning about the dire consequences of war. She emphasized that war with Iran would be worse than war with Iraq and urged President Trump to "put America first" by re-entering the deal.

Gabbard's stance contrasts with those of other Democratic candidates on stage, including Senator Cory Booker, who said he would not automatically re-enter the deal, and Senator Amy Klobuchar, who favors re-entry but wants stricter terms. Klobuchar also emphasized the need for congressional authorization if a war with Iran were to occur.

Throughout the debate, Gabbard has kept the focus on the U.S.'s aggressive foreign policy. When asked about the gender pay gap, she declined to answer, instead choosing to denounce the current interventionist foreign policy. Later, when Representative Tim Ryan referenced the recent deaths of two U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan as a reason to continue the war, Gabbard was critical, saying that it is "unacceptable" and that the U.S. has lost many lives and spent a lot of money.

Gabbard's campaign has been focused on ending wars and promoting peace from the beginning. She has been willing to take a different approach than her fellow candidates, who have been more focused on domestic policy issues. While her single-minded focus on war and peace may not win her many votes, her willingness to challenge the status quo and take a different stance on key issues has been a refreshing moment in an otherwise left-leaning debate.

Title: Lame-Duck Speaker Boehner Reaches Budget Deal, But Some Republicans Express Concerns

In a last-minute move before the election of a new speaker of the House, Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, has reached a budget agreement with the White House and top congressional leaders. The 144-page resolution, submitted to the House Rules Committee, raises federal spending by $80 billion over the next two years, with $40 billion allocated to defense and $40 billion to domestic programs. The deal is partially paid for by cuts to Medicare and Social Security disability benefits. The debt ceiling will also be lifted until March 2017.

The agreement was reached in talks involving only five parties: the top two Republicans in Congress, the top two Democrats, and the White House. Some hard-line conservatives have expressed concerns about being excluded from the negotiations, with Rep. Justin Amash, R-Mich., stating that the leadership team negotiated the deal without consulting members of the Republican conference.

While Speaker Boehner hopes the deal will make his successor's job easier, some Republicans argue that the presumptive heir, Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, should have been involved in the negotiations. Rep. Bill Flores, R-Texas, believes that Ryan's lack of involvement will "insulate" him from criticism, but others may still take out their frustrations on him.

The House is expected to vote on the budget agreement as soon as Wednesday, the same day Republicans are expected to officially nominate Ryan as the next speaker.

Title: Obama and Romney Campaign in Iowa and Nevada Ahead of Election

In the final stretch of the presidential campaign, President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, are crisscrossing the country, trying to fire up their supporters and cast doubts about each other's qualifications. With just 13 days left until the election, both candidates are focusing on key swing states like Iowa and Nevada.

In Iowa, Obama held rallies in Davenport and Denver, where he repeated his recent attacks on Romney, including the notion that his opponent has "Romnesia" due to his changing positions on key issues. Obama also touted his own second-term agenda, which he claims will create jobs and stimulate the economy.

Meanwhile, Romney campaigned in Reno, Nevada, where he emphasized his economic plan and criticized Obama's record on job creation. He pointed to a man he met who had seen his income drop from $25 an hour with benefits to $9 an hour without benefits, highlighting the struggles many Americans face in the current economic climate.

The two candidates have been neck and neck in recent polls in Iowa and Nevada, with Obama holding a slight lead in Nevada and the race tied in Iowa. Obama's campaign schedule included a trip to Burbank, California, for a taping of the Tonight Show with Jay Leno and a stop in Nevada, while Romney's running mate, Rep. Paul Ryan, delivered a speech on upward mobility in Cleveland.

The Obama campaign faced a minor setback when it released a transcript of the president's interview with the Des Moines Register, which was supposed to be off-the-record. Romney's campaign, on the other hand, was dealing with fallout from a comment by Republican Senate candidate Richard Mourdock, who said that pregnancies caused by rape are "intended" by God. Romney's campaign distanced itself from the statement, but some are calling for him to take further action.

In other news, reality TV star and businessman Donald Trump offered $5 million to the charity of Obama's choice if the president releases his college transcript and U.S. passport. The White House and Obama campaign declined the offer.

Title: Trump and Clinton Engage in Friendly Roast at Al Smith Dinner, with Some Cringe-Worthy Moments

The Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner, a traditional event where presidential candidates poke fun at themselves and their opponents, took place on Thursday night. The dinner, now in its 71st year, aimed to provide a comedic relief after three contentious presidential debates. However, the evening turned into a 3-alarm fire, with some cringe-worthy moments.

Donald Trump, the Republican nominee, spoke first, and his jokes were met with silence from the crowd at times. He complained about politicians who loved him, his money, and his endorsements before he decided to run for president. Trump also made jokes about Hillary Clinton's ongoing email server saga, saying, "And even tonight, with all the heated back and forth between my opponent and me at the debate last night, we have proven that we can actually be civil with each other."

Clinton, the Democratic nominee, smiled throughout Trump's speech, but when it was her turn, she fired back with jokes about Trump's claims of a rigged election and his running mate, Mike Pence. She also mocked Trump's debate performance and his comments about women's looks.

The evening saw some awkward moments, with Trump calling Clinton "corrupt" and alluding to recent emails showing Clinton staffers disparaging conservative Catholics. Clinton, on the other hand, mocked Trump's debate performance and his running mate's defense of him.

Despite the cringe-worthy moments, the event ended on a positive note, with Trump and Clinton shaking hands on stage, a development announced to applause. The Al Smith Dinner, traditionally a respite from bitter campaign seasons, may have failed to achieve its goal this year.

Title: Republican Senators Criticize Majority Leader McConnell's Coordination with White House on Impeachment Trial

Senators Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska have expressed concerns about Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's coordination with the White House on the impeachment trial. Collins, speaking with Maine Public Radio, stated that senators on both sides of the aisle are engaging in "inappropriate" behavior by prejudging the evidence before it is presented. She specifically named McConnell and Sen. Elizabeth Warren, saying that they are not giving the appearance of impartiality.

Collins emphasized the importance of senators taking an oath to render impartial justice and not influencing the outcome of the trial. She also expressed her willingness to consider calling witnesses, but believes it would be premature to decide who should be called until the evidence is presented.

Sen. Murkowski, who earlier this month expressed her concerns about McConnell's comments on coordinating strategy with the White House, reiterated her concerns, stating that it has further complicated the process. Democrats, led by Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, have been pushing for witnesses to be called in the trial, citing a recent New York Times report detailing how Trump's order to put a hold on Ukraine aid was handled within the White House. McConnell has opposed calling witnesses in the trial.

These criticisms from Republican senators add to the growing debate over the impeachment trial, with both sides presenting their arguments and concerns.

Title: Protesters Demand Restrictions on Self-Defense Rights, but Some Opponents Will Not Comply

Article:

Across the country, students, teachers, and other Americans have been walking out of classes to call for further restrictions on protections against unreasonable search and seizure. The protesters are exercising their right to free speech and assembly, a fundamental right protected by the First Amendment. However, some individuals who value self-defense rights are not convinced that the proposed restrictions are necessary or effective.

From a philosophical perspective, the concept of individual rights is a complex and debated topic. Some argue that individuals are sovereign beings free to do as they please, as long as they do not cause harm to others. This perspective is rooted in the idea that the government's role is limited to preventing harm to others, as John Stuart Mill put it.

The protesters' demands for restrictions on self-defense rights do not necessarily mean that those who value those rights will change their behavior. Statutes are not like the law of gravity; individuals can choose whether to abide by them or actively oppose them. The laws will mostly be obeyed by those who agree with them and disobeyed by those who are committed to self-defense rights or believe that their liberty is not open to challenge.

The track record on disobeying restrictive laws is clear. Residents of Connecticut and New York have defied requirements to register their "assault weapons," while gun owners in Colorado have ignored mandates to pass all person-to-person sales through the background check system. Even in countries with stricter gun laws, such as France and Germany, millions of illegal firearms remain in circulation.

Exercising one's liberty in contradiction to restrictive laws is a fundamental aspect of human nature. People's unwillingness to submit is what made Prohibition fail and what hobbled the similar ban on marijuana. Even taxes are dependent on people's willingness to pay, as there is always the option to work and do business off the books.

The protesters' demands for restrictions on self-defense rights are a legitimate exercise of their free speech and assembly rights. However, those who value those rights will not be deterred by the proposed restrictions. The limits on what people are willing to tolerate from the powers-that-be are a fundamental aspect of political systems everywhere.

**Trump's Visit to China: A Chance for Charm and Deals**

Beijing (China) - Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to welcome US President Donald Trump to Beijing on Wednesday, marking a continuation of the "bromance" between the two leaders. The visit comes as Xi has grown more powerful since their last meeting, while Trump faces a political cloud after his former campaign manager was indicted in an investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election.

Chinese experts say Beijing has learned to manage Trump, a real-estate mogul who had never held elective office before becoming president, and whose administration has been turbulent in its first 10 months. "China has an objective view of him. We're going to make him feel comfortable," said Wang Yiwei, a professor of international relations at Renmin University.

During his visit, Trump is expected to receive a "state visit-plus" experience, which includes a trip to the Forbidden City and an inspection of Chinese troops. The protocol aims to let Trump "rejoice in grandiosity," important for keeping relations stable, said Teng Jianqun, head of American Studies at the China Institute for International Studies.

On the commercial front, the visit is expected to bring a slew of deals, but some in the US business community worry that Trump will be placated by a handful of contract wins instead of resolving long-standing complaints over discriminatory Chinese policies and market access restrictions.

The visit marks a contrast between the two presidents, with Xi's strong and confident vision for China contrasting with perceptions that Trump often seems to pick arguments. However, Trump's popularity in China remains high, with many admiring his business acumen.

Title: Obama's Final State of the Union Address Falls Flat

The State of the Union address, a tradition dating back to 1790, is a significant event in American politics. It is a chance for the President to reflect on the past year's accomplishments and outline their vision for the future. However, President Barack Obama's final address on January 12, 2016, failed to inspire or inform the nation, according to a former White House official.

The speech was described as disjointed, irrelevant, and disappointing, with the President focusing on his own legacy rather than setting an agenda for his final year in office. The official noted that the President's goals were not explained, and he failed to address pressing issues such as terrorism and the recent capture of two US Navy ships by the Iranian Navy.

The article also touched on the partisan divide, stating that the President's party has been diminished at the State and federal levels, and that his leadership has been criticized for being "leading from behind." The author expressed disappointment that the President did not address the recent terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, California, and instead focused on his own priorities, including closing the Guantanamo Bay detention center.

The article concludes that the speech will not be remembered and will historically be irrelevant, leaving the country searching for new leadership.

Title: House Republicans Seek to Limit Nationwide Injunctions, Citing Constitutional Concerns

The House Judiciary Committee has approved legislation aimed at curbing nationwide injunctions issued by federal judges, a move that has been met with criticism from some Democrats and praise from Republicans. The bill, proposed by Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.), would instruct judges to write rulings that apply only to the individuals, organizations, or entities involved in the lawsuit, rather than extending them nationwide.

The Trump administration has been a vocal critic of nationwide injunctions, citing concerns that they overstep the authority of federal judges and hinder the executive branch's ability to implement its policies. The Department of Justice has issued new guidance to government attorneys, advising them to argue vigorously against nationwide injunctions.

The issue has been a contentious one, with some arguing that nationwide injunctions are necessary to protect individual rights and others seeing them as an overreach of judicial power. The Trump administration's efforts to roll back the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) executive order have been met with resistance from the courts, with some judges issuing nationwide injunctions to block the administration's actions.

Chairman Goodlatte has argued that the Constitution gives courts the authority to decide cases for the parties before them, not to act as "super-legislators" for the entire country. He believes that the current system allows opponents of government action to seek a preliminary injunction and win in one district, only to have it apply nationwide despite being upheld elsewhere.

A bipartisan group of professors of remedies, federal courts, and administrative law has also called for limits on national injunctions, citing concerns about the imbalance of power between the branches of government. The bill is expected to be voted on by the full House of Representatives soon.

Title: US-Greenland Relations: A Complex Web of Politics and Environmental Concerns

The idea of the United States purchasing Greenland has been met with skepticism from the left, who advocate for improving existing alliances instead. However, the concept is not new, as the US has previously considered buying the island in the past. In 1946, US Secretary of State James Byrnes proposed the idea to the Danish foreign minister at a United Nations meeting, but it never came to fruition. Similarly, in the late 19th century, Secretary of State William Seward explored the possibility of purchasing Greenland from Denmark.

Greenland is believed to be rich in natural resources, including iron ore, lead, zinc, diamonds, gold, rare earth elements, uranium, and oil. However, the country's ice sheet, which covers 80% of the land, has been rapidly melting due to global warming, making it more feasible to extract these resources. This has led some to suggest that the US could benefit from acquiring the island, particularly those who prioritize economic interests over environmental concerns.

However, others argue that buying Greenland would be problematic, citing the country's indigenous population and the potential for colonialism. Greenland is home to 56,000 people, and the idea of buying their ancestral lands raises concerns about cultural sensitivity and respect for indigenous rights. Additionally, Greenland's unique system of land ownership, where private land ownership does not exist, would require significant changes to US law and policy.

The article also highlights the potential challenges of integrating Greenland into the US, including the country's nationalized healthcare system and state-owned industries. Greenland's unique system of governance and economy would require significant adjustments for the US to absorb the island as a state.

While some have raised concerns about the potential for corruption and quid pro quo deals, others argue that the evidence is circumstantial and not strong enough to support impeachment. Regardless, the idea of the US purchasing Greenland remains a complex and contentious issue, with both economic and environmental implications.

**New Claims by John Bolton Cast Shadow Over Impeachment Trial**

Former national security adviser John Bolton's claims that President Donald Trump told him he wanted to withhold aid to Ukraine until it helped with investigations into Joe Biden have raised new questions about the impeachment trial. According to Bolton's upcoming book, Trump allegedly told him that he did not want to release military aid to Ukraine until the country helped with investigations that could damage Democrats, including former Vice President Joe Biden.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's office has confirmed that they did not have advance notice of Bolton's manuscript, which has reportedly been reviewed by the Trump administration. McConnell's spokesman stated that the Senate majority leader "did not have any advance notice" that the National Security Council had a copy of Bolton's manuscript for weeks.

Trump has refuted Bolton's account, tweeting that he never told Bolton that the aid to Ukraine was tied to investigations into Democrats, including the Bidens. Bolton's lawyer, Charles J. Cooper, provided a copy of the book to the Trump administration on December 30 to review for classified information.

The controversy has sparked debate among senators, with some Republicans expressing skepticism about the need for additional witness testimony during the impeachment trial. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has expressed skepticism about the need for additional witness testimony, while some Republicans, such as Senator Mitt Romney, have called for Bolton to testify.

The impeachment trial is ongoing, with the House delivering two articles of impeachment to the Senate on January 15. The trial is expected to continue for several weeks, with the outcome uncertain.

Title: House Freedom Caucus Denounces Obamacare Replacement Bill, Introduces Alternative Plan

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative Republicans, has expressed its opposition to the Obamacare replacement bill supported by House Speaker Paul Ryan and announced the filing of an alternative plan. Senator Rand Paul, who was flanked by members of the House Freedom Caucus, including Chairman Mark Meadows and Rep. Jim Jordan, emphasized that a clean repeal of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) should not divide Republicans.

Jordan stated that to bring down costs and improve medical care, Congress must repeal Obamacare completely. He believes the first step is to vote on the 2015 bill, which was sponsored by then-Rep. Tom Price and repealed Obamacare, eliminated every single tax, and eliminated the mandate. Jordan emphasized that the plan supported by Ryan and the House Republican leadership is Obamacare in a different form.

The House Freedom Caucus is pushing for a market-centered, patient-centered, and doctor-centered plan that actually brings down the cost of insurance. Meadows noted that all Obamacare replacement bills will be subject to scoring by the Congressional Budget Office, but the only score that matters is whether it really lowers health care costs and premiums.

Senator Paul emphasized that in the House, the score that counts is 218 votes. If the GOP leadership has 218 votes, they will pass their bill and move on. If not, they will have to find the votes and talk to conservatives.

The meeting between Vice President Mike Pence and members of the House Freedom Caucus was described as direct and focused, with Pence and Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price discussing the need to adjust regulations on insurance companies to make sense.

**Polls Show Obama Leads in Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania**

A recent poll conducted by The New York Times, in collaboration with Quinnipiac and CBS News, has revealed a snapshot of the presidential race in six key states. The poll found that President Barack Obama holds a lead over his challenger, Mitt Romney, in Florida and Ohio, with a margin of 6 percentage points in both states. In Pennsylvania, Obama leads by 11 percentage points.

The poll, which surveyed likely voters in Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania, found that Obama faces significant challenges, particularly in the area of the economy. Voters in each state expressed concerns that his policies would hurt their personal financial situation, with double-digit margins in each state. However, more than half of voters in each state also believe that the administration's actions are slowly improving the economy or will do so if given more time.

The poll also found that Obama has a clear advantage on personal measures, with more voters saying he cares about the needs and problems of people like them. Romney, on the other hand, is seen as being able to do a comparable job on the economy, with more voters in Florida saying his economic policies would be better for their own financial situations.

The poll surveyed 1,177 likely voters in Florida, 1,193 likely voters in Ohio, and 1,168 likely voters in Pennsylvania from July 24 to July 30. The margin of error for each state is plus or minus three percentage points.

Title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Fomenting Unrest in Eastern Region

The Ukrainian interim government has presented evidence that Russian military and intelligence forces are behind the unrest that has destabilized the eastern part of the country since Russia's annexation of Crimea last month. According to The New York Times, photos and descriptions circulated by the Kiev government show some of the "green men" – gunmen who have seized government buildings and demanded Crimea-style referenda on becoming part of Russia – have been identified as being among Russian troops. One of the men in the photos has been identified as Igor Ivanovich Strelkov, a veteran Russian military and intelligence operative.

The Ukrainian authorities have released a wanted poster for Strelkov, accompanied by a pencil sketch of his gaunt face. The Obama administration has endorsed the claims of the Ukrainians, stating that Russia could face new economic sanctions if government buildings currently occupied by demonstrators are not vacated under the terms of an agreement reached among Russian, Ukrainian, American, and European diplomats.

Russian officials, including President Vladimir Putin, have repeatedly denied that Russian forces are involved in the unrest, which began after the February deposition of pro-Russian Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. The separatists themselves claim that their movement is entirely homegrown and in response to what they consider an illegal coup that resulted in Yanukovych's downfall.

Ukraine's State Security Service alleges that Russian operatives are coordinating pro-Russian militias, helping them identify targets, and carrying out seizures of key installations, such as police and security headquarters, government offices, and communications infrastructure. Ukrainian security officials say Russian intelligence has spent years building up a network of sleeper agents in eastern Ukraine.

One of the alleged Russian operatives is Igor Bezler, a 49-year-old Crimean native who allegedly served in the GRU until 2002, when he moved to the eastern city of Horlivka. He worked as a security guard and as head of a funeral company. Then, last week, after a pro-Russian mob took over the town's police station, a video posted on a local news organization's website showed him parading in fatigues in front of a couple dozen local police, identifying himself as a lieutenant colonel in the Russian army and telling them they had a new chief.

The Ukrainian government has accused Russia of using its intelligence services to coordinate the unrest, citing evidence of Russian military and intelligence operatives on the ground. The endgame of the separatists is unclear, with some seeking federalization within Ukraine, others wanting independence, and others dreaming of a Crimea scenario, energized by Putin's recent mention of Novorossiya (literally, New Russia), a tsarist-era imperial term for what is now southeastern Ukraine.

Title: Democrats Unanimous in Backing Impeachment Inquiry into Trump, But Policy Discussions May Take a Backseat

The Democratic presidential candidates have largely rallied behind the House Democrats' decision to launch an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, who is accused of seeking foreign help to damage Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden ahead of the 2020 election. The move is expected to overshadow the Democratic primary race and potentially energize the Democratic base.

The impeachment inquiry, which was announced by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday, centers around Trump's July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, in which he pressured Zelenskiy to investigate Biden and his son Hunter, who had worked for a company drilling for gas in Ukraine.

While the impeachment inquiry is likely to dominate the political landscape in the coming months, it may also make it challenging for Democratic presidential candidates to focus on their key policy issues, such as universal healthcare and income inequality. Kurt Meyer, Democratic party chairman for three rural Iowa counties, expects the impeachment proceedings to energize the Democratic base, but notes that it may also energize Trump's base.

Trump's re-election campaign raised a quarter of a million dollars in just 15 minutes after Pelosi's announcement, and his campaign sent repeated fundraising appeals to his supporters. Trump has portrayed himself as the victim of partisan Democratic attacks and has denied any wrongdoing.

The impeachment inquiry may also overshadow the Democratic presidential debates, which have so far focused on policy issues. Erin O'Brien, associate professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, notes that Trump has been the "elephant in the room" and that the impeachment inquiry will now take center stage.

Biden, who leads polls in the Democratic race, has said he would back impeachment if Trump fails to comply with congressional requests for information on Ukraine and other matters. Trump has raised unsubstantiated charges that Biden improperly tried to halt a Ukrainian probe of a company with ties to his son, without providing any evidence of wrongdoing by either.

The impeachment inquiry may also have implications for Biden's campaign, as some experts warn that it could backfire on Democrats if they are seen as overreaching. Kyle Kondik, a political analyst at the University of Virginia, notes that Trump has a "great ability to drag people into the mud with him," and that Biden's supporters may be affected by the negative attention.

Despite the challenges, some Democratic strategists believe that the impeachment inquiry could ultimately benefit the party by making Trump look afraid of Biden. Joel Payne, a Democratic strategist who advised Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, notes that Democrats should act swiftly to convince voters that their actions are necessary and prevent Trump from successfully arguing that he is being unfairly prosecuted.

Rebecca Cordova, an independent voter from Texas, said it would take strong evidence of wrongdoing to dissuade her from voting for Trump again. "I think the Democrats are just blowing smoke," she said. "They're just trying to start something up like they did with Russia."

Title: Rep. Justin Amash Resigns from House Freedom Caucus, Citing Desire to Avoid Distraction

Article:

Representative Justin Amash, a libertarian Republican from Michigan, has resigned from the House Freedom Caucus, a group he helped co-found in 2015. Amash made the announcement on Monday evening, citing his desire to avoid being a distraction for the group. In an interview with CNN, Amash stated, "I have the highest regard for them, and they're my close friends. I didn't want to be a further distraction for the group."

Amash has been a vocal libertarian voice during his four terms in Congress, often taking stances that diverge from his Republican colleagues. His departure from the Freedom Caucus had been anticipated, as the group formally condemned him in May after he stated that President Donald Trump had committed "impeachable conduct."

The House Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative lawmakers, was founded in 2015 by Amash and nine other freshman Republicans. The group's membership list is not publicly disclosed, with Representative Mark Meadows, R-N.C., serving as its current chairman.

Amash has been a prominent figure in Congress, known for his dedication to transparency and his willingness to take unpopular stances. He was the first Republican to call for Trump's impeachment, citing the president's alleged obstruction of justice during the investigation into former special counsel Robert Mueller's findings.

Amash has also gained attention for his dedication to voting transparency, explaining almost every vote he takes on his Facebook page. He has also been known to take pride in his voting record, having taken 4,289 consecutive votes in Congress before missing one in 2017.

There has been speculation about Amash running for president in 2020 as a libertarian or challenging Trump in the Republican primary. While Amash has not entirely ruled out the possibility, he has not made any official announcements about his political future.

Title: President Obama Calls for Closing Tax Loopholes to Fund Free Community College for All Americans

President Barack Obama addressed the graduating class at Lake Area Technical Institute in Watertown, South Dakota, on Friday, emphasizing the importance of community colleges in the 21st-century economy. The president reiterated his proposal for two years of free community college for everyone, which remains stalled on Capitol Hill. Obama emphasized that community colleges play a vital role in providing access to higher education, regardless of the institution's size or reputation.

The president highlighted the importance of investing in education, stating that "our budgets should reflect that we care about you, and that means giving everybody in America the chance you've had here." He emphasized the need to lower the cost of community college to zero, ensuring that striving Americans are not priced out of the education they need to get ahead.

Obama's proposal would aim to close tax loopholes for millionaires and billionaires, using the savings to fund free community college for all Americans. The president believes that this initiative is in "everybody's interest," providing a vital tool for individuals to improve their economic prospects and contribute to the country's growth.

The president's speech was part of his tradition of speaking at graduation ceremonies, having previously addressed commencements at Notre Dame, Northwestern University, West Point, and other institutions. By choosing to visit a small technical school in South Dakota, Obama aimed to underscore his commitment to making higher education accessible to all Americans, regardless of the institution's size or reputation.

Title: WikiLeaks Clarifies Snowden's Asylum Status, Denies Venezuela Decision

Article:

WikiLeaks, the organization that has provided logistical support to Edward Snowden since his flight from the United States, has clarified that the former National Security Agency contractor has not yet made a formal decision on asylum in Venezuela. The clarification comes after a brief but intriguing tweet from Russian lawmaker Alexei Pushkov, who suggested that Snowden had chosen his next destination.

Pushkov's initial tweet was later deleted, and WikiLeaks responded with a statement on Twitter, stating that Snowden has not made a decision on Venezuela and that any announcement would be made by the relevant authorities and confirmed by WikiLeaks. The organization emphasized that the announcement would be made "if and when the appropriate time comes."

Snowden, who revealed details of a U.S. intelligence program to monitor internet activity, arrived at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport on June 23 and has been believed to be still in the airport's transit zone. He has not been seen publicly since.

The confusion surrounding Snowden's asylum status may have stemmed from remarks by Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, who has offered asylum to the whistleblower. Maduro stated that it is a "collective humanitarian asylum" with various countries saying "Come here!" However, Venezuelan Foreign Minister Elias Jaua said that his country has not yet been in contact with Snowden.

For Snowden to leave Moscow, he would need Venezuela to issue him travel documents and find a way to get there. The only direct commercial flight from Moscow stops in Havana, Cuba, which could cause complications due to the U.S. having annulled his passport.

The White House has stated that Russia has not notified the United States about any Snowden departure, and it appears that the Tuesday flap was due to an errant tweet. The administration has reiterated its desire for Snowden to return to the United States, where he is wanted on felony charges, and has communicated this message to Russia and other nations that might be willing to receive him.

Title: California Imposes New Restrictions to Combat Surge in COVID-19 Cases

California Governor Gavin Newsom has ordered the closure of indoor non-essential businesses in 19 counties, including Los Angeles and Orange counties, in an effort to combat a surge in coronavirus cases. The restrictions, which will remain in place for at least three weeks, include bars, dine-in restaurants, indoor movie theaters, and indoor tasting rooms at wineries. Restaurants may remain open for takeout meals.

The decision comes as California reported 110 deaths and nearly 6,000 new cases on Wednesday, the most the state has recorded since April. Hospitalizations have jumped 51 percent in the past two weeks, and ICU admissions are up 47 percent over the same period.

Newsom emphasized the importance of taking precautions to prevent the spread of the virus, saying, "I deeply respect people's liberty, their desire to go back to the way things were, but I can't impress upon you more, our actions have an impact on other people." He also recommended canceling fireworks shows and closing parking lots at state beaches in Southern California and the Bay Area to limit crowds.

The new restrictions are targeted at areas with high rates of community spread and positivity, rather than being imposed statewide. Newsom said, "We're focusing and targeting local parts of the state where we're seeing an increase in community spread and we're seeing an increase in the positivity rate. Not every part of the state is impacted equally, and as a consequence, we are not targeting on a statewide level these rules and regulations, we are focusing in on areas of concern."

California's move comes as an increasing number of states have been backtracking their reopenings as coronavirus cases and hospitalizations spike just ahead of the July 4 holiday weekend. Other states, such as Arizona, Georgia, Texas, and Ohio, have also reported record numbers of cases and hospitalizations.

Title: Trump and Obama Tie as Most Admired Man in 2019 Gallup Poll

The 2019 Gallup poll has revealed that President Donald Trump and his predecessor, Barack Obama, are tied as the most admired man in America. This marks Trump's first time earning the distinction, while Obama has received the honor 12 times previously. The poll, conducted between December 2 and 15, asked Americans to name the man and woman they admire most living anywhere in the world.

The results show a clear divide along party lines, with 41% of Democrats naming Obama and 45% of Republicans choosing Trump. No other man was mentioned by more than 2% of respondents, with the top 10 men including Jimmy Carter, Elon Musk, Bill Gates, Pope Francis, Bernie Sanders, Adam Schiff, the Dalai Lama, and Warren Buffett.

Michelle Obama was named the most admired woman in America for the second year in a row. The sitting president is typically the most admired man, taking the honor in 58 of the 72 prior polls. Trump's job approval rating has seen an increase, with 45% of Americans approving of his performance, his best rating as president.

The results come despite Trump becoming the third president in history to be impeached by Congress earlier this month. The 18% of Americans naming Trump as the most admired man is up from 13% in 2018 and 14% in 2017.

In the women's category, Melania Trump was voted the second-most admired woman, followed by Oprah Winfrey, Hillary Clinton, and Greta Thunberg, who tied for third place. The remainder of the top 10 women included Queen Elizabeth II, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Senator Elizabeth Warren, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and former US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley.

Title: Tea Party Lawmakers Vow to Oust Fellow Republicans Over Debt Deal

Article:

Tea party lawmakers and conservative groups have signaled that they are not deterred by the recent debt debate and are instead planning to oust fellow Republicans who they believe did not stand firm against the government shutdown and debt deal. Mississippi state Sen. Chris McDaniel announced his intention to challenge U.S. Sen. Thad Cochran in the Republican primary next year, just a day after the GOP's senior senator voted to end the 16-day government shutdown and grant President Obama more borrowing authority.

The move was met with support from outside groups that had rallied against the debt and spending agreement. "Our country can't afford any more bad votes that stem from old friends and back-room deals," said Daniel Horowitz, deputy political director of the Madison Project. "And as witnessed from the recent budget battle against Obamacare, we can't win against Democrats if we don't grow our conservative bench in the Senate."

The debt debate has exposed deep divisions within the GOP, with Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas, Mike Lee of Utah, and their allies pushing to withhold all government spending unless Obama agreed to cancel Obamacare, while party leaders called that a losing strategy and tried to come up with alternatives. A majority of Republicans supported the deal in the Senate, but the situation was reversed in the House, where Cruz allies refused to sign off on a series of plans put forward by GOP leaders to end the stalemate.

Ahead of the vote, each side blamed the other for squandering leverage. Obama, Democratic leaders, and even many top Republicans said they hoped the tea party side had learned some political and tactical lessons, particularly in fighting a fight that now appears to have been futile from the start. However, tea party lawmakers say they could have won if all Republicans had stuck together, and the lesson they draw is that they need to oust those who surrendered.

The tea party's popularity has plummeted in recent months, with a new Pew Research Center poll finding that 49 percent of the public has an unfavorable view of the tea party, compared to 30 percent who hold a favorable view. However, the poll also found that the decline has been particularly dramatic among moderate and liberal Republicans, with just 27 percent of moderate and liberal Republicans having a favorable impression of the tea party, down from 46 percent in June.

Despite the challenges, tea party lawmakers are vowing to continue their fight, with new generation of tea-party-style candidates announcing bids to run against veteran GOP lawmakers in 2014. In South Carolina, Nancy Mace, the first female graduate of The Citadel, lampooned GOP Sen. Lindsey Graham for being the sole Republican in the state's congressional delegation to support the debt deal. In Tennessee, state Rep. Joe Carr accused Sen. Lamar Alexander of violating conservative principles by voting to raise the debt ceiling without any accompanying spending cuts. And in Louisville, Ky., Matt Bevin, a wealthy businessman, praised Sen. Ted Cruz as the new face of the conservative movement and blasted Sen. Mitch McConnell, who wrote the final debt deal with his Democratic counterpart, Majority Leader Harry Reid.

Title: U.S. Considers Offering More Help as Migrants Arrive in Europe

The Obama administration is actively considering ways to assist in the ongoing migrant crisis in Europe, which has seen thousands of Syrian refugees and other migrants arrive in Germany and other European countries. The U.S. is exploring options, including allowing more refugees into the country.

The crisis has put a strain on infrastructure in Greece, Macedonia, and Hungary, and has highlighted divisions between European Union countries. Germany's Vice Chancellor has stated that his country could accept at least 500,000 migrants annually, while calling on other European countries to do more. In contrast, Hungary's Prime Minister is urging the completion of a 13-foot fence at its border with Serbia by the end of the year.

The migrants are primarily fleeing economic instability, and many do not require asylum status to protect their lives, according to NPR's Eleanor Beardsley. Hungarian police are hindering migrants' journeys through southeast Europe towards the West, while Romania believes that migrant quotas are not the solution and that EU countries must work together in solidarity to overcome the crisis.

France and Britain have pledged to accept thousands of migrants, with France committing to 24,000 and Britain to 20,000. However, these numbers are significantly lower than Germany's recent intake of at least 20,000 migrants. Germany has allocated $6.7 billion to cope with the crisis.

The U.S. is considering a range of approaches to address the global refugee crisis, including refugee resettlement. The White House notes that the U.S. has provided over $4 billion in humanitarian assistance since the Syrian crisis began and over $1 billion this year, making it the single largest donor to the Syrian crisis.

As of 2015, more than 367,000 refugees and migrants have crossed the Mediterranean Sea to seek safety and better prospects in Europe, with over 244,000 arriving in Greece and at least 121,000 reaching Italy. The U.N. Refugee Agency reports that the number of migrants rose sharply in August to nearly 130,000.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Economic Platform: A Focus on the Middle Class and Economic Growth

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the head of global strategy at Envestnet and author of "The Leading Indicators: A Short History of the Numbers That Rule Our World", has announced her candidacy for the presidency. Her campaign is likely to focus on the struggles of the American middle class to adjust to a changing economic landscape. Clinton has been emphasizing the need for smart economic policies and sound investments to promote broad-based growth and shared prosperity.

Clinton's campaign will likely contrast her husband's administration with the current economic situation, highlighting the 23 million new jobs and 7 million people lifted out of poverty during his eight years in office. She will also stress the importance of addressing inequality of opportunity, less mobility, and the "outrage" that many women are still paid less than men for the same work.

The article notes that the current economic situation is more complex and nuanced than the early 1990s, with a lower participation rate of American workers and stagnant wages for the majority of workers. However, it also highlights the progress made during the 1990s, including the creation of 23 million new jobs and the lifting of 7 million people out of poverty.

Clinton's campaign will likely focus on the need for government to work in conjunction with individual initiatives and businesses to boost opportunities, implying that this is what happened during her husband's presidency. The article notes that the 1990s saw a boom in employment and economic growth, with sentiment about satisfaction with the economy improving greatly.

Overall, Hillary Clinton's economic platform is likely to focus on the struggles of the middle class and the need for smart economic policies to promote broad-based growth and shared prosperity.

Title: Republicans Eye Phase Two of Tax Reform, Seeking Support from Democrats

Article:

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, implemented just a few months ago, has given Republicans a chance to look ahead to phase two of tax reform. With the 2018 midterms approaching, the GOP aims to score more points with voters by lowering taxes. This strategy may force Democrats into tough votes, such as making popular individual tax cuts permanent.

According to U.S. Rep. Mark Walker (R-NC), the individual tax cuts under the current law are set to expire in 10 years, and budget rules required Republicans to make them temporary to pass the bill without Democratic support. Now, the GOP sees an opportunity to make them permanent ahead of the midterm elections. If the measure doesn't receive the necessary votes from Democrats, it puts them on record against the cuts.

Walker believes the second phase of the tax plan will consist of smaller adjustment bills, including the Universal Charitable Giving Act, which allows families and individuals to deduct donations to local churches, shelters, and communities. This bill aims to ensure that the new tax plan does not negatively affect donations to churches and non-profits.

While Walker does not expect another attempt to repeal the Johnson Amendment through tax reform, he believes it remains a priority for some lawmakers with a conservative worldview and faith. Lawmakers anticipate voting on parts of phase two as early as this month.

Title: Special Counsel Mueller Warns of Possible Subpoena for Trump in Russia Probe

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller has reportedly warned that he could order President Donald Trump to testify as part of the investigation into alleged Russian election meddling. This is the first time Mueller has raised the possibility of issuing a subpoena, according to US media reports.

The warning came during talks with Trump's lawyers in March, after they insisted that the president was under no obligation to face questions from federal investigators. Mueller's team responded by suggesting they would issue a subpoena if Trump declined, and agreed to provide his lawyers with more specific information about the questions they wished to ask.

The list of possible questions has since been published in the New York Times, covering the president's motivations in dismissing former FBI Director James Comey last May and his campaign's contacts with Russia. Trump has repeatedly denied collusion and Russia has also denied the allegations.

The possibility of a subpoena has sparked a new level of tension in the investigation, with Trump's lawyers considering whether to fight it in court or have him plead the Fifth Amendment. Some of Trump's advisors are reportedly divided on the issue, with some advocating for cooperation and others opposed.

The special counsel's investigation is ongoing, with Mueller looking into Russia's efforts to interfere in the 2016 US election, as well as whether there was any collusion between the Kremlin and Trump's election campaign, and whether the president unlawfully tried to obstruct the inquiry.

Title: Senate Republicans Unveil "Justice Act" Police Reform Legislation

Article:

Senate Republicans have introduced the "Justice Act," a police reform legislation aimed at holding officers accountable, pursuing restrictions on chokeholds, and creating new commissions to study law enforcement and race. The bill was spearheaded by Senator Tim Scott, the lone African-American GOP senator, in the wake of George Floyd's death and nationwide protests demanding racial justice.

The legislation includes several key provisions, such as an enhanced use-of-force database, requirements for law enforcement to compile use-of-force reports, and the establishment of the Breonna Taylor Notification Act to track "no-knock" warrants. The bill also encourages agencies to eliminate chokeholds or risk losing federal funds and provides funding for training to "de-escalate" situations and establish a "duty to intervene" protocol to prevent excessive force.

Senator Scott emphasized that the legislation is a bridge between law enforcement and communities of color, stating, "The answer to the question of which side do you support is 'I support America,' and if you support America, you support restoring the confidence that communities of color have in institutions of authority." He acknowledged the real fears people of color have about encountering the police, saying, "We hear you. We're listening to your concerns."

The Republican package also includes several bipartisan proposals, such as making lynching a federal hate crime and launching a study of the social status of black men and boys. The bill also extends funding streams for various federal law enforcement programs, including the COPS program.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has announced plans to bring the legislation to a vote on the Senate floor by next week, stating, "We're serious about making a law here." However, Democrats have already panned the legislation as not going far enough, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling it "inadequate" and "not action."

Title: Howard Dean Withdraws from Democratic National Committee Chair Race, Keith Ellison Remains Front-runner

Article:

Howard Dean, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee (DNC), has withdrawn from the race to lead the party, citing a lack of time to dedicate to the job. This move leaves Representative Keith Ellison as the front-runner for the position. Ellison, who would be the first Muslim to hold the role, is facing criticism that he may not be able to adequately perform the job while remaining in the House of Representatives.

Ellison has acknowledged the concerns, stating that he is still deciding whether he can take on the role while serving in Congress. He emphasized the importance of building and strengthening the DNC, but acknowledged that many Democrats are concerned about his ability to balance the two roles.

Ellison's past comments critical of US foreign policy regarding Israel have raised concerns about his ability to represent the Democratic Party's traditional support for a strong and secure Israel. The Anti-Defamation League has expressed concerns about Ellison's views on the matter, citing editorials he wrote for his college newspaper. Ellison responded with an open letter, stating his commitment to Israel's safety and security, as well as his support for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Ellison was an early favorite for the job, with endorsements from Senators Bernie Sanders and Chuck Schumer, both of whom support a more populist position for the Democratic Party. However, Dean's withdrawal has opened up the race, with two remaining opponents, Jaime Harrison and Ray Buckley, vying for the position.

Harrison and Buckley agree that the future of the DNC should focus on rebuilding the state parties after recent losses in congressional and gubernatorial elections. They also emphasize the need for a new approach, with Harrison suggesting a community-based organization and Buckley proposing a more hands-on approach to running the party.

The DNC chair will be decided in February, when over 400 members of the committee meet to vote on who will lead the party during President Trump's presidency.

Title: Trump Administration Reallocates $3.8 Billion in Weapons Programs to Support Border Wall Construction

The Trump administration has announced that it is redirecting $3.8 billion in weapons programs to support the construction of the U.S.-Mexico border wall, a move that has upset lawmakers who argue the White House is sidestepping their authority. The Pentagon has transferred $2.2 billion from its fiscal 2020 budget and $1.6 billion from the Overseas Contingency Operations war fund to the Department of Defense's counter-drug fund, which will then be applied to border wall construction.

According to the Department of Homeland Security, the funds will be used to construct additional physical barriers and roads in areas along the southern border of the United States that are being used by individuals, groups, and transnational criminal organizations as drug smuggling corridors. The agency has identified these areas as necessary to impede and deny drug smuggling activities.

This is not the first time the administration has chosen to use executive authority to shift federal funds to the wall, largely due to Democratic lawmakers' opposition to immigration enforcement funding. The announcement has already rankled lawmakers who demand that the White House seek congressional approval first.

Democratic lawmakers have criticized the move, with New York Democratic Rep. Nita Lowey and Indiana Democratic Rep. Pete Visclosky stating that the administration is "raiding defense accounts" and that Congress must take action to stop it. Even a top Republican lawmaker, Texas GOP Rep. Mac Thornberry, took a shot at the administration, stating that the re-programming is "contrary to Congress's constitutional authority" and that it requires Congress to take action.

The Trump administration has set an ambitious goal of completing 450 border wall miles by the end of 2020, tackling a campaign goal ahead of the November presidential elections. As of February 7, Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has announced that the administration has built 119 miles of new border wall in areas where dilapidated walls existed or where no walls previously existed at all.

Title: The Kavanaugh Confirmation Process: A Tale of Political Gamesmanship and Character Assassination

The confirmation process for Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has been marked by intense political gamesmanship and character assassination. The article highlights the dramatic shift in the Democratic Party's narrative, from accusing Judge Kavanaugh of being a "serial rapist" to criticizing his "temperament" and "behavior" during his Senate testimony.

The article notes that the Democrats have few tools to destroy their political opponents, relying on accusations of racism, sexism, and homophobia. They accused Judge Kavanaugh of being a rapist, with no evidence or corroboration, and demanded that people "believe all women." The article suggests that this tactic is a form of railroading, where asking questions is seen as a crime.

The article also criticizes Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein for her attacks on Judge Kavanaugh's temperament, calling his testimony "aggressive and belligerent." The article argues that Judge Kavanaugh's passionate defense of himself against false accusations is a normal response to being smeared and that his "temperament" is not in question.

The article concludes by noting that the legacy media has perpetuated the narrative of Judge Kavanaugh's "bad temperament" and that the Democrats have moved on to new accusations, such as an incident from his college days where he allegedly threw ice on someone. The article concludes that the Democrats' behavior is a malicious effort to destroy innocent people for political gain and urges readers to remember this in November and vote accordingly.

Title: Former Defense Secretary Robert Gates Warns Next President May Face International Crisis, Criticizes Trump and Clinton on Foreign Affairs

Article: Former Defense Secretary Robert Gates, who has served eight presidents over 50 years, has expressed concerns about the next president's ability to handle international crises. In an op-ed published in The Wall Street Journal, Gates warned that the next president may face an international crisis shortly after taking office.

Gates criticized both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton for their credibility problems in foreign affairs. He stated that Clinton was the senior-most advocate for using the U.S. military to bring about regime change in Libya, which led to chaos, and failed to anticipate the consequences. Gates also noted that Clinton and other Democrats criticized the Bush administration for its handling of post-Saddam Iraq.

Regarding Trump, Gates said that he has expressed support for building a wall between the U.S. and Mexico, torturing suspected terrorists, and killing their families, as well as praising Vladimir Putin's dictatorial leadership and Saddam Hussein's non-existent successes against terrorism. Gates described Trump as "beyond repair" on national security issues, stating that he is "stubbornly uninformed about the world and how to lead our country and government, and temperamentally unsuited to lead our men and women in uniform."

Gates also noted that Clinton has time to address her trustworthiness and reassure the public about her judgment before the election. He believes that her willingness to stake out positions on national security issues and speak specifically about her plans for dealing with China, Russia, North Korea, Iran, the Middle East, and international trade will affect how people vote, including himself.

Title: Pennsylvania Woman Receives $200 Fine for Violating Stay-at-Home Order While Driving Alone

Article:

A Pennsylvania woman, Anita Shaffer, received a $200 fine for violating the state's stay-at-home order while driving alone in her car. According to Shaffer, she went for a leisurely drive to get out of the house, but was pulled over by state police officers who claimed her taillight was out. The ticket issued to Shaffer stated that she violated the state's Disease Control and Prevention Act of 1955 and failed to abide by the governor and secretary of health's order to control the spread of a communicable disease.

The incident raises questions about the enforcement of stay-at-home orders and the balance between public health measures and individual freedoms. While public health officials emphasize the importance of social distancing, some argue that driving alone in a car is not a significant risk to public health. In fact, Shaffer's story is not an isolated incident, as a paddleboarder in California was arrested last week for violating the state's stay-at-home order.

The issue of aggressive enforcement of stay-at-home orders has sparked debate, with some arguing that it is necessary to prevent the spread of the disease, while others believe it can lead to unintended consequences, such as increased risk of disease transmission among law enforcement personnel and potential civil liberties violations. Elizabeth Goitein, director for liberty and national security at the Brennan Center for Justice, warns that ramped-up scrutiny of everyday life could become a new normal that tilts away from freedom.

The incident also highlights the importance of proportionality in public health measures. While stay-at-home orders are necessary to prevent the spread of the disease, they should be proportionate to the risks involved and not last longer than necessary. The police should not have the power to stop and question everyone who leaves their home in apparent contravention of a stay-at-home order. Instead, they should focus on preventing large public gatherings and actual violations of social distancing guidelines.

In this case, York County District Attorney Dave Sunday has announced his intention to withdraw the citation against Shaffer, citing the facts of the case and the fact that she was cooperative. The incident serves as a reminder that public health measures should be balanced with individual freedoms and that enforcement should be proportionate to the risks involved.

Title: Former President Obama Speaks on Gun Laws in the United States

Article:

Former President Barack Obama recently spoke at a tech conference in Brazil, where he made a statement about the lack of regulations on gun sales in the United States. The moment was captured on YouTube and later removed, but not before it was shared on social media platforms. In his speech, Obama stated that "some of you may be aware, our gun laws in the United States don't make much sense" and that "anybody can buy any weapon any time, without much, if any regulation."

Obama's comments were made in the context of discussing the Sandy Hook school shooting, in which he expressed his pain and dismay at not being able to tell parents that the laws would change to prevent the easy purchase of machine guns. However, it is worth noting that the Sandy Hook shooter was actually prevented from purchasing a weapon, as he stole it from his own mother, whom he murdered first.

Critics have pointed out that Obama's statement is inaccurate, as there are many laws and regulations governing the purchase, sale, use, and manufacture of weapons in the United States. Additionally, the country has a lower murder rate compared to some other countries, including Brazil.

It is unclear what specific regulations Obama had in mind to prevent the scenario of the Sandy Hook shooter, as he did not provide any specific examples or solutions.
