Some have suggested that a total ban and mass confiscation of weapons may be the only way to prevent such scenarios, but this is a topic of ongoing debate.

Regardless, Obama's comments have sparked a renewed discussion about gun laws in the United States, highlighting the complexities and nuances of the issue.

Title: HIV Researcher Reflects on Parallels Between Ebola and HIV Reactions

The recent Ebola outbreak in the United States has sparked a wave of fear and hysteria, reminiscent of the early days of the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Rick Elion, a long-time HIV researcher, has witnessed firsthand the devastating impact of fear-based policies and the importance of bringing humanity into the equation. In an interview, Elion shared his thoughts on the parallels between the two viruses and the lessons that seem to be lost on policymakers.

Elion, clinical-research director at the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington, D.C., has seen the devastating effects of fear and stigma on those affected by HIV. He notes that the public's reaction to Ebola is eerily similar, with a desire to isolate and quarantine those suspected of carrying the virus. This echoes the early days of HIV/AIDS, when patients were treated like untouchables and schools closed down.

Elion believes that the desire to isolate Ebola victims stems from a fundamental human fear of the unknown. "There's that same tension between our desire to help and our desire to run," he said. This tension is a familiar refrain from the HIV/AIDS era, where the fear of contagion led to widespread stigma and discrimination.

The parallels between the two viruses are striking. Both HIV and Ebola are highly infectious diseases that have sparked widespread fear and panic. Both have been met with a mix of ignorance, misinformation, and fear-based policies. Elion notes that the quarantine policies being proposed in response to Ebola are eerily similar to those tried and failed during the HIV/AIDS epidemic.

Elion emphasizes that the key to controlling both diseases is not isolation, but rather a combination of education, research, and compassion. "The longer we didn't bring humanity into the equation, the more the disease flourished," he said. "And the more we did, the more we got it under control."

As the Ebola epidemic continues to unfold, Elion's words serve as a stark reminder of the importance of learning from history and bringing humanity to the forefront of disease response.

**Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Continues, Despite Recent False Leads**

The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8 with 239 people on board, has continued despite recent false leads and empty searches. The Bluefin-21, a high-tech underwater drone, has scanned more than 90% of the underwater search area, with its 12th mission underway. The search area is vast, with authorities using a combination of planes, ships, and satellites to cover the Indian Ocean.

Recently, a metal object was found near Augusta, Australia, which was initially deemed an "object of interest" in the search. However, detailed pictures revealed it was not a lead in the search. The search area has been extensively searched, with authorities using sonar and other equipment to scan the ocean floor. Despite the efforts, no signs of the Boeing 777 jetliner have been found.

The search has been complicated by the ocean's vastness and the presence of trash, jellyfish, and fishing gear, which have been mistaken for debris. The search area is vast, with authorities using a combination of planes, ships, and satellites to cover the Indian Ocean.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has stated that the search will not be abandoned, and authorities will continue to search until all possible leads are exhausted. The search area may be expanded or changed if the underwater search comes up empty, with options including using deep-towed sonar and mapping the ocean floor.

The investigation into Flight 370's disappearance is officially Malaysian, with Australia leading the search and participating in the investigation as an accredited representative. The Malaysian Cabinet has approved the appointment of an international investigation team, with the names to be announced next week. The team will focus on evaluating and determining the cause of the accident, rather than the criminal aspects of the investigation.

Title: Obama and Boehner Reach Agreement on Deficit Framework, but Differences Remain

The White House and Speaker John Boehner have reached a deficit framework agreement, with President Obama offering a plan to raise $1 trillion over 10 years and Boehner proposing a framework that would raise $1 trillion over the same period. The details of the plan will be settled next year by Congress's tax-writing committees and the Obama administration.

The White House plan would permanently extend Bush-era tax cuts on household incomes below $400,000, with the top tax bracket increasing from 35% to 39.6%. The plan would also cut spending by $1.22 trillion over 10 years, with $800 billion in straight cuts and $122 billion in savings from adopting a new measure of inflation that slows the growth of government benefits, especially Social Security.

The plan would also include $290 billion in savings from lower interest costs on a reduced national debt. The White House is counting on $800 billion in straight cuts, with $200 billion from federal health care programs, $100 billion from military spending, and $100 billion from domestic programs under Congress's annual discretion.

To make these changes happen, the president proposed fast-track procedures to help Congressional tax writers overhaul the individual and corporate tax code and make changes to other programs. However, senior Republican aides made it clear that differences remain, with disagreements over counting lower interest payments on the national debt as savings and the impact of the new inflation calculations on certain populations.

The president is also insisting on some protections for vulnerable populations, such as wounded veterans and disabled people on Supplemental Security Income. Additionally, he is sticking by his request for additional upfront spending on infrastructure and an extension of expiring unemployment benefits.

The plan would also secure some tax and policy changes long sought by both parties, including permanently extending popular business tax breaks like the credit for corporate research and development, permanently stopping the expansion of the alternative minimum tax, and stopping a long-planned and deep cut to Medicare health providers.

To keep the country from returning to fiscal showdowns, the president wants the government's borrowing limit to rise high enough to take the issue off the table for two years, although he said Congress could periodically weigh in and try to override a presidential lifting of the debt ceiling, should it want to.

Title: Central American Leaders Meet with Obama to Address Root Causes of Youth Migration Surge

The presidents of El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala met with President Barack Obama at the White House to discuss the surge of unaccompanied youth migrants from their countries entering the United States illegally. The leaders agreed to work on a comprehensive plan to address the root causes of migration, including reducing crime and promoting social and economic opportunities in their countries.

The meeting aimed to find a solution to the humanitarian crisis, which has become a partisan flashpoint in the ongoing debate over U.S. immigration reform. The Central American presidents and Obama issued a joint statement reiterating their commitment to preventing families and children from undertaking dangerous journeys and promoting safe, legal, and orderly migration.

The meeting focused on addressing the root causes of migration, including strategies for reducing crime and promoting social and economic opportunities. The leaders emphasized the need to pursue criminal enterprises that exploit vulnerable populations and discourage the use of smuggling networks that put migrants at risk of violent crime and sexual abuse.

The Obama administration is working on a pilot program to assess asylum claims in Central American countries, which would reduce the number of illegal immigrants entering the U.S. However, Obama played down this option, stating that it would only be considered for those who meet specific criteria, such as being a refugee or fleeing persecution.

The meeting comes as the Obama administration and Congress struggle to find a consensus on how to address the surge of unaccompanied minors at the border. The administration has requested $3.7 billion in emergency funds, while Republicans and some Democrats in Congress are resisting the proposal and offering alternatives that would spend less and change immigration policy to deport kids faster.

House Republicans are expected to vote on a scaled-down border bill next week, which would provide less than $1 billion to address the crisis and modify a 2008 law to make it easier to deport children from Central America who enter the U.S. illegally. The proposal is unlikely to pass in the Senate, where Democrats are opposed to the change.

The administration is also considering sending National Guard troops to the border, following a similar move by Texas Governor Rick Perry. The number of unaccompanied minors crossing the border has slowed significantly since last month, with a team from the Pentagon and Department of Health and Human Services assessing Border Patrol efforts in the Rio Grande Valley.

Title: Rep. Al Green Becomes First to Read Articles of Impeachment Against President Trump on House Floor

Rep. Al Green (D-TX) has become the first member of Congress to officially read articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump on the House floor. The articles, which were read aloud on Wednesday, focus on Trump's tweets deemed "disparaging" towards various groups, including NFL players, Puerto Ricans, Muslims, LGBTQ individuals, and President Barack Obama. The articles do not mention Trump's firing of FBI Director James Comey or allegations of obstruction of justice.

Green's proposal is unlikely to move forward, given the Republican majority in the House and Senate, as well as the skepticism from many Democrats. In an interview, Green acknowledged that his articles of impeachment are unlikely to gain traction, but he believes it is his duty to bring attention to Trump's actions.

The articles of impeachment, which can be read in full, accuse Trump of committing "high crimes and misdemeanors" by engaging in actions that "may with peculiar propriety be denominated political." Green cites specific examples, including Trump's tweets about NFL players, his vow to ban transgender people from the military, and his comments about President Obama.

Green's proposal has received a mixed reaction, with some calling it an "imbecilic" case of "Trump Derangement Syndrome" and others viewing it as a necessary step to hold the President accountable. Despite the criticism, Green remains resolute, stating that he is willing to stand alone in his efforts to bring attention to Trump's actions.

Title: GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy Questions ABC News About Jeffrey Epstein Story

Article:

In a letter to ABC News President James Goldston, Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy has raised several questions about the network's decision to reportedly spike a story about Jeffrey Epstein, a convicted sex offender and alleged child trafficker who died in prison last year. The letter, obtained exclusively by Megyn Kelly, comes after a series of Project Veritas videos revealed that former ABC News reporter Amy Robach had been working on a story about Epstein's alleged abuse of women and minors, but it was never aired.

McCarthy's letter asks six specific questions, including whether ABC News will provide Congress with the interview Robach conducted with a victim, what the network learned about Epstein after Robach presented her story to executives, and who was involved in deciding the story was not of public interest. The letter also asks if Robach can expand on the "outside forces" she mentioned as potentially responsible for the story not running, and if authorities were alerted at any time after Robach presented her reporting to the network.

The controversy surrounding ABC News' handling of the Epstein story has sparked widespread criticism, with many questioning why the network chose not to air Robach's reporting. In a recent interview with Kelly, Robach expressed her frustration and disappointment with the network's decision, stating that she had "firsthand information" about Epstein's alleged abuse and that "ABC News chose to bury the truth."

The letter from McCarthy adds to the growing scrutiny of ABC News' handling of the Epstein story, and raises further questions about the network's decision-making process.

Title: Congress Off to Rocky Start as Veto Threats and Filibusters Dominate Early Agenda

The 114th Congress has barely begun, and already, the legislative process is facing significant hurdles. President Obama has issued veto threats on three measures, prompting Democratic leaders to vow to deliver the votes to back him up. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, stated that her troops will vote to uphold those vetoes.

Meanwhile, Senate Democrats launched their first filibuster of the year, blocking debate on the Keystone XL pipeline bill, which has bipartisan support. The filibuster came on the third day of business, making it the fastest on record, according to an analysis.

Despite having criticized Republicans for procedural tactics when they were in the minority, Senate Democrats refused to allow debate to begin without going through the necessary procedural hoops. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, expressed frustration, saying, "We'll work through this because we're determined to get bipartisan jobs legislation on the president's desk as soon as we can."

President Obama has issued veto threats on the Keystone measure, as well as two other bills: one to repeal Obamacare's 30-hour workweek definition and another to delay Dodd-Frank financial reform regulations. Senator Joe Manchin III, West Virginia Democrat and a Keystone supporter, believes enough Democrats could rally behind the project for the Senate to override an Obama veto.

However, House Minority Leader Pelosi said she will muster Democrats to uphold the veto on Keystone and the other two issues where Mr. Obama has drawn lines. She emphasized that the president's veto is key to Democrats' legislative strategy this year.

The early disagreements have already poisoned the atmosphere on Capitol Hill, with Republicans blaming Democrats for blocking action and Democrats accusing Republicans of adopting tactics they fought against when they were in the minority. The standoff has raised questions about the effectiveness of the legislative process and the ability of the two parties to work together.

Title: US Keeps Options Open, Including Military Strikes, in Response to Oil Tanker Attacks

The Trump administration has stated that it is keeping all options on the table, including military strikes, in response to the recent attacks on two oil tankers near the Strait of Hormuz. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo claimed that the attacks were carried out by Iranian troops with the intent to deny transit through the strait, which is responsible for transporting about a fifth of the world's oil daily.

The Pentagon released photographs and a grainy black-and-white video showing Islamic Revolutionary Guard troops removing an unexploded mine from the side of an oil tanker targeted in the Gulf of Oman. The US Central Command stated that American forces in the region witnessed and recorded an Iranian boat approaching the oil tanker Kokuka Courageous and removing an unexploded limpet mine from the vessel.

Pompeo stated that the US intelligence community has significant evidence to blame Tehran for the attacks, while Iran has persistently denied such claims. The US has also blamed Iran for a May attack on four oil tankers, which used limpet mines.

Not everyone is convinced by the US take on the situation. Germany's foreign minister has requested additional evidence before pointing blame on Tehran, and the Japanese owner of one of the tankers has disputed the US account, stating that the ship was hit by a flying object, not a mine.

Saudi Arabia and Britain have joined the US in pointing fingers at Iran. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman called on other countries to take a "decisive stand" against the attack, while Britain plans to send elite military forces to the region in response to the attacks.

The British Defense Ministry downplayed the significance of the move, stating that it is a "pre-planned training deployment" and is not related to the ongoing situation in the Gulf of Oman. As tensions escalate between Washington and Tehran, Pompeo maintained that the US does not seek war with Iran but will defend itself if necessary.

The Trump administration has repeated that it is considering a "full range of options" to respond to the attacks, but is "confident" that it can take a set of actions that would restore deterrence. When asked whether such action would include a military response, Pompeo responded, "Of course."

Lawmakers have warned that the administration lacks congressional approval to use military force. Pompeo insisted that the administration "always" has the authorization to defend American interests, stating that "every option that we look at will be fully lawful."

**Tensions Escalate between North Korea and South Korea, Israel Launches Airstrikes against Syria**

In recent days, tensions have increased between North Korea and South Korea, with both sides trading rocket and artillery fire. The most significant incident in five years, it resulted in no casualties. The North Korean military has been placed in a "semi-war state" by dictator Kim Jong Un.

The exchange began after two South Korean soldiers were wounded in a land mine explosion in the demilitarized zone, which the South blames on the North. In response, the South began blasting propaganda in the demilitarized zone, a practice that was previously agreed upon to be discontinued in 2004.

The US and South Korea began their annual joint military exercises on August 16, which the North denounced as training for an invasion. The North fired at the South, prompting a response from the South. The US briefly suspended and then resumed the exercises.

The North has demanded that the South stop its loudspeaker propaganda by Saturday afternoon, threatening an attack if the ultimatum is not met. The South has rejected the demand.

Meanwhile, Israel launched airstrikes against the Syrian military and allied militant groups in Syria on Thursday and Friday, in response to rocket attacks on the Golan Heights. Israel claims the rocket attack was conducted by the Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad and coordinated by Iran. Syria's government claims five civilians were killed in the second round of strikes, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says they were pro-government fighters.

Israel has linked the rocket attacks to the Iran nuclear deal, with Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon alleging the rocket strikes were a "preview of a richer and more murderous Iran" after sanctions are lifted.

Title: Homeland Security Releases Thousands of Criminal Aliens, Despite Discretion to Keep Them in Custody

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security released over 17,000 criminal aliens from custody last year, with 57% of those released being done so by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) discretion, according to new numbers obtained by House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte. This means that ICE officials chose not to detain these individuals, despite having the authority to do so, allowing them to be released into the community while their deportation cases are pending.

The numbers show that over 3,700 "Threat Level 1" criminals, deemed the top priority for deportation, were released, along with thousands of others with serious criminal convictions. ICE officials claim that these releases were made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account humanitarian factors such as deteriorated health, advanced age, and caretaking responsibilities.

However, ICE numbers reveal that nearly all of those released under electronic monitoring broke the terms of their release, with over 30,000 individuals violating the conditions of their release in 2014 alone. This includes multiple violations per individual, with an average of 10 instances per violator.

ICE officials point out that violations can include minor issues, such as lacking a strong cell signal for voice verification or being a few minutes late for phone checks. However, only 2,420 of the over 30,000 violators were deemed serious enough to warrant rearrest.

The agency's ability to detain and track violators is limited due to a lack of available beds, according to an inspector general's report. ICE officials have not requested additional beds, and the Obama administration's 2016 budget request actually sought fewer beds to hold detainees, prioritizing alternatives to detention.

The controversy surrounding ICE's treatment of those awaiting deportation proceedings has been ongoing for several years. In 2013, the agency released 36,007 convicted criminals who were awaiting the outcome of their deportation cases, with 116 homicide convictions, 15,635 drunken driving convictions, and 9,187 convictions related to "dangerous drugs."

Title: Election Coverage Suggests Trump's Campaign May Be Fading, But Experts Caution Against Writing Him Off

The media coverage of the 2016 presidential election has led many to believe that Donald Trump's campaign is on the brink of collapse, with Hillary Clinton coasting to victory. However, experts warn against writing off Trump just yet, citing the unpredictability of elections and the potential for unexpected events to shift the momentum.

Recent polls and forecasts suggest that Clinton is indeed in a strong position, with some predicting she will reach the 270 electoral votes needed to win. The media has been quick to highlight Trump's struggles, with headlines like "Trump is in a funk: Bitter, hoarse and pondering, 'If I lose...'" and "ROVE: HE'S TOAST" painting a bleak picture for his campaign.

However, experts caution against reading too much into the current polls and predictions. Many elections have seen candidates bounce back from being written off, and unexpected events can still shake up the race. The article notes that Trump has been attacked by both parties for not promising to accept the election outcome, but this could be a strategic move to avoid being seen as conceding defeat.

The article also highlights the media's focus on the horse race aspect of the election, with stories about Clinton's potential cabinet picks and Trump's struggles to stay competitive. However, it also notes that the media is not the only one writing off Trump, with some Republican leaders concluding that it's too late to salvage his campaign.

The article concludes by noting that while the media and many Americans may be eager for the election to be over, there are still two weeks to go, and anything can happen. As Yogi Berra said, "It ain't over till it's over."

**Taliban Suicide Blast Kills U.S. Soldier, Romanian Service Member, and Civilians in Kabul**

A Taliban suicide bombing in the center of Kabul, Afghanistan, killed a U.S. soldier, a Romanian service member, and at least 10 civilians near the headquarters of the international military force and the American embassy. The blast occurred on Thursday, marking the second major attack this week.

The NATO Resolute Support mission confirmed that the two service members killed were "killed in action," but declined to provide further details or release their names. The American soldier was the fourth to be killed in the past two weeks in Afghanistan.

The blast also wounded 42 people, according to Interior Ministry spokesman Nasrat Rahimi. Surveillance footage showed the bomber's vehicle turning into a checkpoint and exploding, with a passer-by trying to sprint away just seconds before the blast.

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that they targeted vehicles of "foreigners" trying to enter the heavily guarded Shashdarak area, where Afghan national security authorities have offices. The blast occurred hours after a Taliban attack against a foreign compound late Monday, which killed at least 16 people and wounded over 100, mostly local civilians.

The violence comes as the Afghan government warned that a U.S.-Taliban deal on ending America's longest war is moving at a dangerous speed. The deal, which would see the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan, has raised concerns among Afghan leaders, with presidential adviser Waheed Omer stating that the agreement is moving with "excessive speed" and warning of difficult days ahead.

The Afghan government has expressed concerns about the deal, citing the potential for a full U.S. troop withdrawal without requiring the Taliban to meet certain conditions, such as reducing violence, which could lead to "total civil war." The U.S. seeks Taliban guarantees that they will not allow Afghanistan to become a haven for extremist groups such as al-Qaida and the local affiliate of the Islamic State group.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Expected to Leave Department of Justice Within Weeks

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is expected to leave the Department of Justice (DOJ) within weeks, according to reports. Rosenstein has informed President Trump of his plans to depart, with White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders confirming the news in a recent interview. Sanders stated that Rosenstein has always intended to serve for approximately two years and is making room for the confirmation of Attorney General nominee William Barr.

Rosenstein's departure is expected to occur after the confirmation of Barr, which is scheduled to take place next week. However, sources told The Washington Post that there are no firm plans for Rosenstein's departure or a timeline. NBC News reported that Rosenstein will not leave until Special Counsel Robert Mueller submits his final report.

As Deputy Attorney General, Rosenstein has overseen the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, led by Special Counsel Mueller. Trump has frequently criticized the investigation, calling it a "witch hunt" and accusing the DOJ and FBI of bias against him. Trump previously forced the resignation of Attorney General Jeff Sessions and appointed his chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker, as acting attorney general. Whitaker has overseen the Mueller probe despite past public criticism of the investigation.

Rosenstein's departure would come after a rocky tenure as Deputy Attorney General, with speculation swirling last year that Trump would fire him after The New York Times reported that he discussed secretly taping the president and invoking the 25th Amendment to remove Trump from office.

Title: Trump Administration Officials Differ on North Korea's Commitment to Denuclearization

The Trump administration's national security adviser, John R. Bolton, stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" that most major steps towards denuclearization could be taken within a year. However, private officials within the administration claim that Bolton's view remains unchanged since joining the administration: that North Korea will never entirely give up its nuclear program.

The question remains whether North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is genuinely willing to change course or simply playing for time, as his predecessors did with past presidents. Frustrated by reports that North Korea is continuing to advance its nuclear program despite its "denuclearization" pledge, President Trump tweeted that there have been no rocket launches or nuclear testing in eight months, with only the opposition party and the "fake news" complaining.

While Trump is correct that there have been no missile or nuclear tests since November, a freeze and denuclearization are distinct concepts. North Korea retains its nuclear capabilities and can resume testing at any time. Just a year ago, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson deemed this position insufficient, as it merely perpetuated the ability to strike that Trump had previously characterized as intolerable.

The situation also highlights Trump's tendency to conflate a good meeting with a good outcome. It is reminiscent of President John F. Kennedy's meeting with Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev in 1961, which did not prevent the Cuban missile crisis from breaking out 16 months later. North Korea has already achieved a significant goal, as the heat has been turned down drastically, and the United States has unilaterally suspended military exercises with South Korea.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on California's Same-Sex Marriage Ban

The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday regarding California's Proposition 8, a measure that bans same-sex marriage, with supporters and opponents of the ban agreeing that this is a watershed moment. The court is considering whether to strike down the ban or uphold it, with possible outcomes ranging from dismissal to a broad ruling on whether same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.

Supporters of same-sex marriage, such as Nowlin Haltom, a real estate agent from Los Angeles, are hopeful that the court will make a significant statement in favor of marriage equality. Haltom, who married his partner of 15 years in New York, has been fighting for this cause for a long time and is grateful for the progress made so far. However, he acknowledges that there is still much work left to do, including addressing issues such as Social Security benefits for same-sex couples.

Opponents of same-sex marriage, like Tim Wildmon, president of the American Family Association, argue that the court is considering redefining thousands of years of human history and that there is no cultural or historical precedent for same-sex marriage. Wildmon believes that a broad Supreme Court ruling in support of same-sex marriage would fly in the face of the clear majority opinion in America, citing the fact that 31 states have passed legislation defining marriage as between a man and a woman.

The court's decision is expected by early June, and some indications suggest that it may be wary of making a broad ruling. Justice Anthony Kennedy described the plaintiffs' request as asking the court to head into "uncharted waters." Paul Linton, special counsel at The Thomas More Society, a national anti-abortion and anti-gay marriage advocacy group, believes that a broad decision could lead to some states calling for a constitutional amendment, which could lead to Congress convening a constitutional convention.

The case has sparked a range of reactions, with some calling for a broad ruling and others urging caution. Regardless of the outcome, the debate is expected to continue, with both sides vowing to continue their efforts to shape the future of marriage in the United States.

Title: Study Examines Options for Universal Healthcare Coverage in the US

A recent study by the Urban Institute has shed light on the various options for expanding access to healthcare in the United States. The report, funded by the Commonwealth Fund, examines different plans for reform, including Medicare for All, and their potential impact on the national healthcare system.

The study found that Medicare for All, which would cover everyone in the country, including undocumented immigrants, would raise national spending on healthcare by nearly $3 trillion in 2020 and $34 trillion over 10 years. This plan would require an additional $2.7 trillion in federal revenue and would decrease employer spending on healthcare by $955 billion and household spending by $887 billion.

In contrast, a "lite" Medicare-for-All plan, which would cover all legal residents in the US but not undocumented immigrants, would cost roughly $17.6 trillion over 10 years. This plan would reduce national spending on healthcare by about $209 billion in 2020 and decrease federal spending by $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

The study also explores an alternative plan that combines private and public health insurance, which would cover everyone in the US except for 6.6 million undocumented immigrants. This plan would increase federal spending by $122.1 billion if implemented next year and by $1.5 trillion over 10 years, but would decrease total national health spending by $22.6 billion in 2020.

According to Sara Collins, a vice president at the Commonwealth Fund, the report shows that universal healthcare coverage can be reached in different ways, with varying costs. The study's findings highlight the complexity of the issue and the need for policymakers to consider multiple approaches to achieve universal coverage.

Title: Record-Breaking Turnout in Republican Primaries as Democrats' Enthusiasm Fades

The recent Republican presidential primary elections in several big states have seen a massive surge in voter turnout, with over 240,000 new Democrats and independents casting their ballots. This significant shift in enthusiasm and interest is a stark contrast to the Democratic Party's performance, which has seen a decline in voter turnout.

According to exit polling analysis, nearly 10 million people have cast their ballots in the 15 primaries and caucuses so far, about 4 million more than voted in the same Republican races in 2008. Donald Trump, the Republican front-runner, attributes this growth to his campaign's efforts, stating that he has expanded the Republican Party.

The numbers are striking, with 14 of the 15 Republican contests setting records for turnout. In contrast, Democratic turnout has plummeted in every race except Colorado's caucuses, with a 30% decline compared to the 2008 elections. Republicans now account for 59% of the votes cast, compared to 62% for Democrats in 2008.

Some Democrats attribute the disparity to the size of the Republican field, which had 12 candidates in Iowa and 5 in Super Tuesday races, compared to 3 for Democrats. However, the White House disputes this claim, citing Hillary Clinton's stronger performance in states like Virginia.

The Republican Party is confident that the overall turnout in Virginia bodes well for recapturing the state in November. John Findlay, executive director of the Virginia Republican Party, noted that Republican turnout exceeded that of Democrats in almost every region of the state, including key swing counties.

While some voters expressed concerns about Donald Trump's candidacy, others, like Cori DeFrancis, 61, a consignment shop owner, backed Marco Rubio because they thought he had the best chance of beating Trump. Party leaders are worried that Trump's candidacy could drive away rank-and-file Republicans.

Trump's coalition has hit the Republican sweet spot, doing well among voters who identify as "somewhat conservative" and holding his own among very conservative and moderate voters. His performance among Hispanic voters has also been stronger than expected, with nearly identical rates of support in states with sizable Hispanic populations like Nevada and Texas.

Title: Wisconsin Democrats Sidestep Labor Debate in Governor Recall Election

The recall election in Wisconsin, sparked by the state's civil war over union rights, has seen the issue of collective bargaining take a backseat. Democratic candidate Tom Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee, has chosen not to focus on the issue, instead targeting Governor Scott Walker's tactics and ethics. Barrett's decision to distance himself from the labor movement's preferred candidate, Kathleen Falk, has allowed him to deflect charges of being beholden to organized labor.

In the May primary, Barrett defeated Falk, who had pledged to veto the state budget unless collective-bargaining rights were restored. While Barrett supports restoring collective-bargaining rights, he refused to commit to Falk's approach. This decision has allowed him to appeal to independent voters who may not be enamored with unions.

However, some critics argue that backing away from the contentious issue of collective bargaining may hurt Democrats in their final push to get voters to the polls. The Republican National Committee Chairman, Reince Priebus, has called the issue a "dead dog loser" for the left.

Instead of focusing on labor rights, Barrett has been campaigning on issues such as the John Doe criminal probe, which has led to the indictment of several former Walker aides. He has accused Walker of using deceptive political tactics and endearing himself to the tea party. The mayor's latest ads have focused on the John Doe investigation and job creation.

The recall election is set to take place on June 5, with Barrett facing off against Walker. The outcome is seen as crucial, with some predicting that a Democratic victory could have significant implications for the national political landscape.

Title: White House Response to Mass Shootings Raises Questions on Prioritizing Policy Discussions

The recent mass shootings in Las Vegas and New York City have sparked a stark contrast in the White House's response to the tragedies. While the administration's initial condolences and sympathies were extended to the victims and their families, the tone and focus shifted significantly in the days that followed.

In the aftermath of the Las Vegas shooting, which left 58 people dead and over 500 wounded, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders emphasized the need for unity and mourning, stating that "today is a day for consoling the survivors and mourning those we lost." She declined to discuss policy changes, citing the ongoing investigation and the need for all facts to be known.

In contrast, when an Uzbek immigrant drove a truck into a bike path in New York City, killing eight people, the White House's response was more swift and decisive. President Donald Trump tweeted about ISIS before offering condolences and prayers, and later announced that he had ordered the Department of Homeland Security to "step up our already Extreme Vetting Program." He also took to Twitter to criticize Senator Chuck Schumer's sponsorship of a bipartisan immigration plan in 1990, calling for a change to immigration policy.

The stark contrast in the White House's response has raised questions about the administration's priorities and willingness to engage in policy discussions. While the initial response to the Las Vegas shooting was focused on condolence and unity, the response to the New York City attack was more focused on political attacks and policy changes.

The White House's stance on policy discussions has been consistent, with Press Secretary Sanders stating that "today is more, again, a day of reflection, a day of mourning, a day of gratefulness for those that were saved." However, critics argue that the administration's reluctance to engage in policy discussions is a missed opportunity to address the root causes of these tragedies and to work towards solutions.

As the nation continues to grapple with the aftermath of these mass shootings, the White House's response will be closely watched and scrutinized.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Hesitate to Endorse Trump and Carson, Citing Electability Concerns

Republican presidential front-runners Donald Trump and Ben Carson have yet to receive any endorsements from Capitol Hill lawmakers, despite their agendas being supported by most members and popular with voters back home. The hesitation to endorse the two outsider candidates has afflicted Republican lawmakers of every stripe, from establishment stalwarts to renegade tea partyers.

When pressed about the complete lack of endorsements, most lawmakers insisted it was too early or there were too many candidates to choose from – not that Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson are too far outside the mainstream to risk associating themselves with them. However, some Republicans bluntly questioned Mr. Trump's ability to go all the way to the White House or to do the job if he somehow makes it.

Rep. Trent Franks, an Arizona Republican and member of the conservative Freedom Caucus, said, "I think Mr. Trump would be hard to elect." He pledged to support Mr. Trump if he wins the nomination, but expressed concerns about his electability. Rep. John Fleming, another Freedom Caucus member, questioned Mr. Trump's trustworthiness, stating, "He uses a lot of broad statements in the way that Barack Obama did, and these things can become fill-in-the-blanks. In other words, you hear what you want to hear, and then you get a surprise down the road."

The lawmakers generally handled Dr. Carson more gently, with Rep. Peter T. King, a New York Republican, saying, "Trump and Carson have to show they know what the job is about, not just be media stars." Doug Heye, a Washington-based Republican political consultant, attributed the lack of endorsements to electability concerns, stating, "Every historical pattern we know tells us that Trump and Carson are unlikely to win the nomination. That may end up not being the case, but it explains why members have not endorsed."

The Carson campaign said that Dr. Carson deliberately has not solicited endorsements from a single governor, senator, or congressman, stating, "Political endorsements will come in due time. They are not a priority for our campaign attention." For Mr. Trump, the dearth of endorsements contrasts with his strong push to crack down on illegal immigration and negotiate tougher trade deals with China and other trading partners – stances backed by conservative Republicans in Congress.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican, disagreed that his colleagues were afraid to endorse Mr. Trump or Mr. Carson, stating, "Most people are a little slow to endorse. We don't have many endorsements for any candidate." Other GOP contenders have managed to pick up endorsements on Capitol Hill, with former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina receiving endorsements from three House members, Mr. Huckabee receiving endorsements from two senators and four congressmen, Mr. Rubio receiving endorsements from two senators and eight House members, and Mr. Cruz receiving endorsements from seven House members.

Sen. Rand Paul was endorsed by eight congressmen and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a fellow Kentuckian whom Mr. Paul backed in a tough 2014 reelection race. Jeb Bush collected the most endorsements in Congress: three current senators and 23 current House members. Rep. Kenny Marchant, a Texas Republican, attributed the lack of endorsements for Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson to the Bush family's long-standing influence, stating, "They might endorse now but don't want to offend Bush 41 and 43."

Despite lingering policy questions and doubts about electability, Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson remain neck and neck at 24 percent and 23 percent, respectively, in a nationwide poll of likely GOP voters.

Title: Department of Homeland Security Faced with Criticism Over Lack of Transparency on Immigration Detainee Releases

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is facing criticism from state and federal authorities over the lack of transparency regarding the release of immigration detainees in an effort to save money. According to ICE, hundreds of detainees have been released across the country, but lawmakers and local officials are seeking more specific information on the number of releases, involved detention centers, and the cost savings goal.

Representative Mike McCaul, chair of the House Committee on Homeland Security, has demanded answers from ICE Director John Morton by March 6. McCaul expressed concern that the releases were undertaken without notification to the appropriate Congressional oversight committees. Pinal County Sheriff Paul Babeu also fired off a letter to DHS Secretary Janet Napolitano, demanding answers and stating that protocol and logic required notification to the top law enforcement official in the county where the releases occurred.

In contrast, El Paso Sheriff Richard Wiles and San Diego County Sheriff William Gore were informed by ICE officials ahead of the releases, but still do not know the exact number of detainees released. San Diego County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Jan Caldwell stated that the release of detained undocumented immigrants does not impact the Sheriff's Office, as they do not enforce federal immigration law.

A letter from Napolitano to Senator Barbara Mikulski, chairwoman of the Committee on Appropriations, on January 31, hinted at the current release policy, stating that ICE would not be able to sustain current detention and removal operations or maintain the 34,000 detention beds mandated by Congress. The letter also mentioned potential cutbacks in Border Patrol agents along the border, which could affect progress made in recent years.

Some lawmakers, like Representative Beto O'Rourke (D-Texas), see the decision to release low-risk detainees as a potential solution to a festering problem. O'Rourke, who sits on the House Committee on Homeland Security, believes that detention centers are a "horribly broken element of our immigration policy" and that the released individuals do not pose a threat to the United States.

Title: Obama's Legacy Hangs in the Balance as Supreme Court Weighs Health Care Law

The fate of President Barack Obama's health care reform law and his re-election bid are intertwined, with many concluding that if he loses both, it will be a blow to his presidency. According to presidential historian Robert Dallek, "he bet on his major reform, and the Supreme Court defeated it, and he lost his hold on the presidency."

As the Supreme Court deliberates, Obama and his advisors are no longer in denial about the possibility of the law being struck down, but they are still holding out hope that it will be upheld. However, some former aides are now emphasizing the aspects of the bill that are not connected to the individual mandate, such as subsidies to buy insurance. Others argue that losing the mandate could be a political boon, as it would rob Republicans of their core complaint against the law.

The article highlights Obama's willingness to make sacrifices during his presidency, including his refusal to settle for a more limited health care overhaul. He had an economic rationale for stabilizing the health system, but he also saw it as a moral issue. The article notes that Obama's declaration that he and his wife Michelle are "perfectly comfortable if we're only here one term if we feel like we really accomplished something" sounds different today, as he now feels he must win re-election to achieve his goals.

The article also mentions Obama's views on the individual mandate, with him calling the argument that it violates the Constitution "without merit whatsoever." However, there are clues that he is privately grappling with the potential loss of universal health care and how much of it he might be able to restore. If the court strikes down the mandate and Obama wins in November, he could face the choice of settling or expending more capital on health care.

The article concludes that the final result on health care will help determine whether Obama is the game-changing president he aspired to be, with some predicting that he will expend more capital on health care, while others believe he will learn to live with a sharply edited law.

Title: Senators from Both Parties Work Together to Overhaul Immigration Laws

A group of eight senators from both parties, known as the "Gang of Eight," has been meeting regularly to work on a comprehensive immigration reform bill. The senators, led by John McCain, Charles Schumer, Lindsey Graham, Marco Rubio, Dick Durbin, Jeff Flake, Michael Bennet, and Robert Menendez, have been working together to address the nation's complex immigration issues.

The senators meet in private, alternating between McCain's and Schumer's offices, and have been working diligently to find common ground. Despite their differences, they are driven by a shared goal of passing a bill that can become law.

The legislation being worked on would secure the border, provide a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country, crack down on employers, and improve legal immigration. While there are still some challenges to overcome, the senators have made progress on border security and the path to citizenship.

The group has been working towards a self-imposed deadline of releasing their legislation in March, although it may slip until after their two-week recess in April. If successful, the bill would then go to the Judiciary Committee and eventually the full Senate and House for consideration.

The senators' efforts are a departure from the typical partisan gridlock in Washington, with all members of the Gang of Eight expressing a desire to find common ground and pass a bill. Despite the challenges ahead, the senators remain optimistic that they can succeed in solving a problem that has bedeviled Washington for decades.

Title: US Secretary of State Pompeo to Meet Taliban Officials in Qatar Amid Efforts to Salvage Historic Deal

Article:

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will meet with Taliban officials in Qatar on Monday as part of efforts to salvage a historic deal signed with the armed group in February. The meeting will be the highest-level talks ever between the United States and the Taliban. According to the US State Department, Pompeo will meet with Mullah Baradar, the Taliban's chief negotiator, to press the group to continue complying with the agreement signed last month.

The deal, which was signed in Qatar, calls for the Taliban to reduce violence and engage in talks with the Afghan government. In return, the US has agreed to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan over a 14-month period. However, the deal has been stalled due to disagreements over the release of prisoners held by the Afghan government, which the Taliban has demanded.

Pompeo's visit comes as the Afghan government and the Taliban have failed to begin formal negotiations, hampered by a feud between President Ashraf Ghani and his rival, Abdullah Abdullah, over who is the rightful leader of the country. The two leaders have been at odds since a disputed presidential election in September.

The US has been pushing for the release of prisoners as a condition for the talks to begin. The Taliban has also demanded the release of its prisoners held by the Afghan government. The US Special Representative for Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, has urged both sides to act quickly on the release of prisoners, citing the urgency of the situation due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

The pandemic has also affected the planned withdrawal of US and other foreign troops from Afghanistan, with some troop movements slowed due to the outbreak. The Taliban has continued to carry out attacks despite the deal, and the Afghan government and the Taliban have not begun formal negotiations as planned.

The meeting between Pompeo and the Taliban officials is seen as a crucial step in salvaging the deal and achieving lasting peace in the war-torn country.

Title: Trump Threatens to Sue The New York Times, Attacks Columnist Maureen Dowd on Twitter

Article:

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, threatened to sue The New York Times and launched a Twitter tirade against columnist Maureen Dowd, calling her "a neurotic dope" and accusing her of making up facts. The attacks followed Dowd's interview on CNN, where she discussed her new book "The Year of Voting Dangerously".

In the interview, Dowd alleged that Trump appeared to enjoy inciting violence at his rallies, which Trump denied. He tweeted that his lawyers wanted to sue The New York Times for "irresponsible intent" and that the newspaper was "willing to say anything" to boost his rival, Hillary Clinton. Trump also attacked Dowd personally, calling her "crazy", "wacky", and "a neurotic dope", and claiming she "hardly knows" him.

Dowd had told CNN that she told Trump that inciting violence at his rallies was wrong and that reporters were getting roughed up. Trump reportedly paused and acknowledged her concerns, but then disagreed, saying the violence added "a frisson of excitement" to his rallies.

Title: Hillary Clinton Jokes About Beating Trump in 2020, but Reiterates No Plans to Run

Article:

Former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recently joked about potentially running against President Donald Trump in the 2020 election, stating that she could "beat him again" in a hypothetical rematch. The comment was made during an interview with Judy Woodruff on PBS Newshour, where Clinton referenced her popular vote win in the 2016 presidential election.

Clinton's comment was in response to Trump's suggestion that she enter the 2020 race to "steal it away from" Senator Elizabeth Warren. Trump also tweeted that Clinton must "explain all of her high crimes and misdemeanors, including how & why she deleted 33,000 Emails AFTER getting 'C' Subpoena!" Clinton responded by saying "Do your job" and not to tempt her.

During the interview, Clinton characterized Trump's tweet as "just so typical of him," stating that "nothing has been more examined and looked at than my emails." She also expressed confusion about what motivates Trump, saying that she doesn't understand what drives him beyond personal grievances and a desire for adulation.

Clinton has repeatedly stated that she has no plans to run in the 2020 election, but her latest tweet has sparked rumors and speculation about her potential candidacy.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary and Attorney General Visit Border, Criticize "Sanctuary Cities"

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and Senator Ron Johnson (R-WI) concluded a visit to the US-Mexico border on Friday, emphasizing the importance of border security and the need to stop human trafficking. The trio held a press briefing on an access road on the US side of the border, where Secretary Kelly reaffirmed the Trump administration's commitment to building a physical barrier along the southern border.

According to Secretary Kelly, the number of illegal border crossings has decreased by 64% compared to the same period last year, citing the administration's seriousness about border security and enforcing immigration laws. Attorney General Sessions praised the progress made by the Trump administration, stating that it has exceeded his expectations.

The Attorney General also warned about the danger of gang infiltration, specifically mentioning MS-13, and emphasized the importance of stopping human trafficking. He also launched a broadside against "sanctuary cities" and the "would-be'sanctuary state' of California.

The Attorney General recalled the case of Kate Steinle, who was shot and killed in San Francisco in 2015, and the alleged shooter, an illegal immigrant with seven prior felony convictions who had been deported five times. He stated that the city's sanctuary policies allowed the shooter to be released from custody, despite a federal immigration detainer request.

The Department of Justice sent letters to nine jurisdictions, including California, requesting legal justifications for their policies, which may violate federal law. The Attorney General urged New York and other jurisdictions to reconsider their policies.

The visit concluded with a press conference held between two existing border fences, where Senator Johnson emphasized the importance of supporting law enforcement and the Trump administration's commitment to enforcing the law.

When asked about the argument that enforcing immigration law would hurt local policing, Attorney General Sessions described it as an "excuse" rather than a reason, suggesting it is driven by ideology rather than evidence. He also rejected accusations of racism and defended his recent comments about a federal court ruling on President Trump's travel ban.

**California Hit by Powerful 7.1 Magnitude Earthquake, Residents Describe "Rocking Chair Gone Crazy"**

A powerful 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck Southern California on Friday night, causing widespread damage and panic in the region. The quake, centered 11 miles northeast of Ridgecrest, California, released 11 times the energy of Thursday's 6.4 magnitude quake, also centered near Ridgecrest.

Residents described the earthquake as a "rocking chair gone crazy," with bottles falling from shelves, patrons dropping to the floor, and food making a slippery getaway for frightened guests who sprinted outside. The quake swayed buildings and cracked streets and foundations, sending terrified residents into the streets.

The region has seen an average of one aftershock per minute since Friday's quake, with more than 4,700 quakes occurring since Thursday, according to the US Geological Survey (USGS). At least 3,000 quakes above a magnitude 1 have been reported, with three magnitude 5 or greater quakes striking within the first hour.

The earthquake caused gas leaks, structure fires, and water main breaks, with power and communications out in some areas. Several injuries were reported, but no fatalities have been confirmed. The Governor of California, Gavin Newsom, declared a state of emergency in Kern County and requested a presidential emergency declaration for assistance, which was approved by President Donald Trump.

The earthquake also affected Naval Air Weapons Station China Lake, a US weapons testing facility near Ridgecrest, which sustained "infrastructure damage" and authorized the evacuation of non-essential personnel and dependents. The facility is not mission capable until further notice, with security protocols remaining in effect.

The San Bernardino County Fire Department reported multiple reports of damage, including homes shifting, foundation cracks, and retaining walls down, with one minor injury reported. The LA County Fire Department reported no major damage, deaths, or serious injuries, but said some wires were down and power was out in some locations.

The earthquake was felt as far away as Mexico and Las Vegas, with the NBA Summer League game between the New Orleans Pelicans and the New York Knicks in Las Vegas postponed following reports of the quake.

Title: US Secretary of State Pompeo Urges Venezuela's Maduro to Back Down Amid Escalating Unrest

The United States Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, has called on Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro's regime to back down as the country's political crisis continues to escalate. In an interview on Fox News Sunday, Pompeo stated that every option is on the table, including military intervention, to ensure the Venezuelan people's voices are heard and democracy reigns in the country.

The statement comes as violence broke out along the country's border with Colombia, with troops loyal to Maduro blocking a U.S.-backed drive to deliver foreign aid. The troops fired tear gas, leaving several dead and hundreds wounded, targeting protesters aligned with opposition leader Juan Guaidó.

The Trump administration and several European nations have backed Guaidó, who declared himself interim president last month. The U.S. has also imposed sanctions on Maduro and his government, while several Democratic presidential candidates have called on him to refrain from violence against his own citizens, labeling him a dictator.

Pompeo emphasized that the U.S. will continue to offer humanitarian assistance to the Venezuelan people and hold Maduro accountable. He stated that there are more sanctions to be had and more humanitarian assistance that can be provided. The Secretary of State believes that the Venezuelan people will ultimately hold accountable those who have done harm to their fundamental rights.

The situation in Venezuela remains volatile, with the opposition and government forces engaged in a power struggle. The international community continues to monitor the situation closely, with the U.S. playing a key role in the crisis.

Title: US Expands Military Presence in Syria with Deployment of Additional Special Operations Forces

The United States has announced the deployment of an additional 200 Special Operations Forces to Syria, building on a "proof of concept" approach that has shown promise in combating the Islamic State (ISIS). The decision comes as a diplomatic cease-fire in the region falters, with questions remaining about the long-term goals and end state of the US military strategy.

The initial deployment of 50 special operators last fall aimed to train Kurdish and Arab Sunni forces on the ground, with the goal of gaining traction against ISIS. According to Melissa Dalton, a former intelligence analyst for the Defense Intelligence Agency, the expertise of these forces has been "critical" in driving ISIS out of key areas.

The expanded deployment is seen as a low-risk gambit, with President Obama emphasizing the need to keep the US out of another war in the Middle East. The move is also seen as a way to empower anti-ISIS forces in a proven way, without becoming embroiled in a broader conflict.

The US has previously attempted more grandiose efforts to fight ISIS, including a $500 million program to train Syrian anti-ISIS forces, which yielded only a handful of fighters on the battlefield. The new approach focuses on refining the message to potential recruits, explaining the benefits of training and US support.

The trainers have also had success in expanding the number of Syrian Arabs within the Syrian Democratic Forces, which is seen as important in building trust among anti-ISIS forces. The Kurdish forces, who have been the most reliable partners for the US, have been accused of ethnic cleansing and forcibly removing Sunni Arabs from their homes.

The deployment of additional special operations forces is seen as a step towards building a more diverse coalition against ISIS, with the ultimate goal of taking back control of their hometowns and governing together. The US has previously emphasized the need for a more inclusive approach, with Defense Secretary Ash Carter stating that the US is seeking to "empower local forces to take the fight to ISIS."

The expanded deployment is seen as a cautious and incremental approach, with the US seeking to avoid getting bogged down in a broader conflict. As Nicholas Heras, a Middle East analyst at the Center for a New American Security, notes, "incrementalism is the right approach" in this case.

Title: U.S. Senator Jeff Flake Compares Trump's Anti-Media Rhetoric to Stalin's Propaganda

Article: U.S. Senator Jeff Flake (R-AZ) recently discussed his upcoming speeches on ABC News' "This Week," where he compared President Donald Trump's animosity towards the media to totalitarian dictator Joseph Stalin's propaganda. During the interview, Flake expressed concern about the damage caused by Trump's rhetoric, particularly his use of the term "enemy of the people" to describe the press.

Flake emphasized that this phrase, popularized by Stalin, has real consequences and can be used by authoritarians around the world to justify cracking down on their opposition or stifling legitimate debate. He also noted that Trump's actions, including his planned "fake news awards," have real-world implications.

The senator's criticism of Trump is not new, as he has previously attacked Trump's agenda and supporters as angry and resentful. The tension between Flake and Trump began when Flake published his book "Conscience of a Conservative: A Rejection of Destructive Politics and a Return to Principle," which criticized Trump's policies. Trump responded by mocking Flake at a rally in Phoenix.

In his upcoming speeches, Flake aims to highlight the dangers of Trump's rhetoric and its potential consequences for democracy.

Title: The Power of Family Ties: How Close Relationships Can Spread Misinformation

In times of uncertainty, people often turn to their family members for comfort and reassurance. This desire for social connection can lead to a sharing of information, which can sometimes spread misinformation. According to sociologist Emma Spiro, this process helps alleviate anxiety by giving individuals a sense of communal understanding, making them feel like they are making decisions based on a shared understanding of what is happening. However, when the purpose of a conversation is to comfort, people become more likely to share information that appeals to them rather than information grounded in facts.

Compounding this issue is the tendency for people to believe misinformation when it comes from those with whom they have close ties. Cailin O'Connor, an associate professor of philosophy at UC Irvine, notes that people assess information based not only on its quality but also on their perceived social and cultural similarity to the person sharing it. "The closer you perceive yourself to someone...the more you trust the information they're sharing," O'Connor said.

Family group chats are also likely to include individuals who are less familiar with social media and less skilled at filtering out misinformation. For example, an 80-year-old grandmother may not be aware of the latest online trends or have the skills to verify the accuracy of information. A 2019 study found that people from older generations tend to share misinformation nearly seven times more frequently than younger family members, even when controlling for education and partisan affiliation.

Despite recognizing that their relatives are spreading misinformation, people may hesitate to speak out due to their close relationships. A 2019 study found that only 21% of people surveyed in the UK reported correcting others who shared false or inaccurate information. This number is likely to be even smaller in family group chats, as it can be uncomfortable to disagree with those close to you. "There is this psychological force of us all kind of wanting to conform a little bit and not stick out," O'Connor said. "Within families, it can be a powerful force. When someone is saying, 'Oh, I believe X,' it pushes others just to accept it rather than to say, 'Well, you're wrong about X.'"

Title: Atlanta Police Officers to Face Criminal Charges in Shooting Death of Rayshard Brooks

The Fulton County District Attorney's Office announced on Wednesday that two Atlanta Police Department officers, Garrett Rolfe and Devin Brosnan, will face criminal charges in connection with the shooting death of Rayshard Brooks on June 12. Officer Rolfe is charged with felony murder, while Officer Brosnan is charged with aggravated assault.

According to District Attorney Paul Howard, the officers' actions after shooting Brooks did not reflect fear or danger, but rather "other kinds of emotions." Howard described Brooks, 27, as calm, cordial, cooperative, and almost jovial during his interaction with the officers before the shooting. Brooks was asleep in his car in the Wendy's drive-thru when the officers initially engaged him.

The officers initially woke Brooks up and told him to park his car in the Wendy's lot. After Brooks got out of the car, the officers verbally confirmed he was not armed and patted him down. Brooks was cooperative during the process, but attempted to escape when the officers were putting him in handcuffs. The officers attempted to wrestle him to the ground, and Brooks fought them off. During the struggle, Officer Brosnan pulled out his Taser, which Brooks was able to take from him. Brooks then escaped and fled with the Taser, prompting Officer Rolfe to pull out his own stun gun and attempt to stun Brooks. Surveillance footage shows Brooks pointing the Taser at the pursuing officers, and three shots were fired, with Brooks being shot twice in the back.

Following the incident, Officer Rolfe was fired from the department, and Officer Brosnan was placed on administrative leave. Police Chief Erika Shields resigned from her position after 25 years of service with the department. The Wendy's restaurant where the shooting occurred was also set on fire during subsequent protests.

Title: Former Ambassador Yovanovitch Testifies in Impeachment Inquiry, Trump Responds with Criticism

Article:

Former Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch testified before the House Intelligence Committee on Friday, sharing her experiences and concerns about her time serving as the United States Ambassador to Ukraine. During her testimony, she expressed feeling threatened when President Donald Trump brought up her service in Ukraine during a July call with the country's President Volodymyr Zelensky. Yovanovitch described the moment as "shocking and devastating" and stated that it was a "terrible moment."

The testimony sparked a reaction from Trump, who tweeted that Yovanovitch had performed poorly during her career as a U.S. ambassador. Trump's tweet stated that "everywhere Marie Yovanovitch went turned bad" and mentioned her service in Somalia and Ukraine. He also emphasized that it is a U.S. President's absolute right to appoint ambassadors.

Fox News anchor Chris Wallace reacted to Yovanovitch's testimony during an interview with anchors Bill Hemmer and Sandra Smith, stating that the testimony was "very powerful" and that it was "intimidating" for witnesses to see the President attacking her. Wallace also noted that the testimony was not just about the past, but played out in real-time with the President's tweet.

The impeachment proceedings will continue into Friday afternoon, with major news networks such as ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, Fox News, C-SPAN, and PBS pre-empting regular programming to cover the historic event.

**Pentagon Chief Pushes Back on Using Military Construction Funds for Border Wall**

Acting Defense Secretary Patrick M. Shanahan has stated that he will make the final decision on allocating $3.6 billion in military construction funds for President Trump's border wall. Shanahan has refused to commit to giving the White House all the money it wants under the national emergency declaration, sparking concerns that key military projects at home and abroad could be cut.

Lawmakers from both parties have spoken out against the idea of raiding funds meant for military construction projects, citing concerns about the impact on troops and their families. Shanahan has assured that he will prioritize housing for troops, stating, "Will we take care of our men and women? Yes, is the answer."

The funds in question come from unobligated funds in defense budgets over the past five years, designated for specific military projects but not yet begun. The White House aims to pull $3.6 billion from this pool, with the remaining $8 billion coming from other sources.

Defense Department officials and lawmakers are resisting the idea of diverting military construction funds, with some Republicans arguing that it would hurt the readiness and training of American troops. Democrats, meanwhile, are using the issue to drive a wedge between the president and Republicans on Capitol Hill, citing specific military projects that could be shelved or cut.

The controversy has sparked concerns about the potential impact on military construction projects, including upgrades to a U.S. military hospital in Germany, dock repairs at Pearl Harbor, and flight training projects at military facilities in Texas.

Title: Democrats Debate Resolution to Condemn Anti-Semitism Amid Controversy Surrounding Rep. Ilhan Omar's Comments

The Democratic Party is grappling with a fresh controversy over allegations of anti-Semitism, sparked by comments made by freshman Congresswoman Ilhan Omar (D-MN). Omar's statement, which questioned the political influence of Israel in the United States, has been met with accusations of anti-Semitism from some members of her own party.

The controversy comes as the party is already divided over its stance on Israel. Omar's comment led to swift condemnation from some Democratic leaders, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA), who called her remarks "deeply offensive."

The House of Representatives has released a resolution aimed at addressing anti-Semitism on Capitol Hill, which was initially scheduled to be brought to the floor on Wednesday. However, the resolution has been delayed, and some Democrats are questioning whether it is necessary.

The debate surrounding Omar's comments has also drawn attention from Republican leaders. Rep. Steve Scalise (R-LA) called for Omar to be removed from the House Foreign Affairs Committee, while Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) described her comments as "unconscionable."

The controversy has also sparked a response from the Trump-Pence campaign, with national press secretary Kayleigh McEnany stating that the recurring anti-Semitic remarks by lawmakers like Omar are "sad for America." McEnany also called for House Speaker Pelosi to take action and remove Omar from the Foreign Affairs Committee.

The debate surrounding Omar's comments highlights the ongoing divisions within the Democratic Party over its stance on Israel. While some Democrats have condemned her remarks, others have defended her right to express her opinions. The controversy is likely to continue as the party navigates the complex issues surrounding anti-Semitism and its relationship with Israel.

Title: Romney's Sudden Shift on Income Inequality Sparks Skepticism

Article:

Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, has made a sudden pivot towards championing Americans struggling to make ends meet, a move that has left many progressives and veterans of President Barack Obama's winning reelection campaign scratching their heads. Romney's sudden conversion has sparked a mix of disbelief and amusement among Obama's 2012 campaign team, who see it as a desperate attempt to regain political relevance.

Romney's past comments, such as his infamous "47 percent" remark and his declaration that he likes being able to fire people, have left a lasting impression on many Americans. His 2012 campaign was marred by his perceived disconnect with the struggles of average Americans, and his inability to connect with the challenges faced by the middle class.

Romney's latest attempt to rebrand himself as an advocate for income inequality has been met with skepticism by many. Obama's 2012 campaign manager, Jim Messina, said that Romney's problem has always been his lack of believability and connection with the challenges of average Americans. "It's simply never going to be believable to go from car elevators, off-shore accounts, and his famous 47 percent comment to the populist income equality warrior," Messina said.

Romney's speech on the USS Midway in San Diego, where he argued that Obama's policies have failed to address income inequality, was met with no applause from the Republican crowd. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who made income inequality a centerpiece of his 2013 mayoral campaign, called Romney's sudden conversion "a strange way to suddenly come out of the box with it, and I find it disingenuous."

Democrats are also taking pleasure in Romney's sudden shift, seeing it as a desperate attempt to regain relevance. Obama's 2012 deputy campaign manager, Stephanie Cutter, said that a message only works if it's authentic to the messenger, and she's not sure voters will trust Romney's sudden conversion. Eric Fehrnstrom, a top adviser to Romney, did not respond to requests for comment.

Romney's sudden shift has also sparked a reaction from Hillary Clinton, who has been trying to distance herself from her husband's economic policies. She tweeted that attacking financial reform is risky and wrong, and that Congress should focus on jobs and wages for middle-class families.

While Romney's sudden conversion may be seen as a desperate attempt to regain relevance, it has sparked a much-needed conversation about income inequality, an issue that has become increasingly important to many Americans. As de Blasio said, "This is on the minds of more and more people around the country, because income inequality is basically the touchstone of what we're dealing with right now."

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry Criticizes Obama's One-Size-Fits-All Approach to State Issues

Governor Rick Perry of Texas, the second-largest state in the nation, has expressed skepticism towards President Barack Obama's approach to addressing state-level challenges, which Perry believes is too focused on one-size-fits-all solutions. In a recent appearance on "Meet the Press," Perry criticized the administration's handling of issues such as the death penalty and joblessness, stating that Texas has taken a different approach.

Regarding the death penalty, Perry expressed concerns about the recent botched execution in Oklahoma, which led to the death of inmate Clayton Lockett. Perry noted that Texas has a different approach, using only one drug for lethal injections, whereas Oklahoma used a combination. Perry stated that Texas has a system in place for dealing with capital punishment, and something went wrong in Oklahoma.

On the topic of job creation, Perry emphasized that Texas is focused on attracting employers and creating jobs above the minimum wage. According to Perry, 95% of the jobs created in Texas are above minimum wage, and the discussion around raising the minimum wage is not as relevant when there are no jobs available. Perry also referenced the idea that minimum-wage jobs are intended as entry-level positions, not meant to support a family.

When asked about his own presidential ambitions, Perry acknowledged that his 2012 campaign was unsuccessful, but believes that character is demonstrated by how well one performs after experiencing failure.

Title: Democrats Face Internal Divisions on Fiscal and Class Issues

As President Barack Obama approaches his second inauguration, the Democratic Party is poised to confront a central question about its political identity: whether it will continue to be a center-left party or return to a more populist, left-leaning approach. The debate centers on fiscal and class issues, with Democrats divided on how to appeal to a broad group of voters while staying true to their traditional commitment to those in need.

The entitlement debate and potential cuts to Social Security and Medicare benefits are seen as a flashpoint, with some Democrats, like Rahm Emanuel, advocating for compromise and others, like Elizabeth Warren, pushing for a more populist approach. The party must also reconcile its stance on economic issues, including Wall Street regulation and public employee rights.

Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar noted that the challenge lies in balancing the need to do the right thing with the need to work with a wide coalition of people, including workers and business. The party's presidential hopefuls will soon begin openly maneuvering, and Democrats must decide whether they want to be known as the party of Rahm Emanuel or the party of Elizabeth Warren.

The article highlights the shift in the party's internal dynamics, with the rise of the Obama coalition, a largely tolerant amalgam of youth, minorities, and women. While there may be tensions within the party on Capitol Hill, there is a wide and deep consensus on social issues like abortion rights, same-sex marriage, and immigration reform.
