Veteran Democratic strategist Mandy Grunwald noted that the center has moved, and Democrats must find a way forward that represents the interests of their supporters, from those making six figures in affluent areas to those struggling in middle-class communities. Representative Keith Ellison, co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, emphasized the need for the party to address income inequality and whether the government should play a role in fixing the problem.

The article concludes that the real struggle within the Democratic Party is where they stand on income inequality and whether the government needs to be part of fixing the problem.

Title: Harvard University Defends Admissions Policies Against Discrimination Allegations

Harvard University has defended its admissions policies against allegations of discrimination against Asian-American applicants in a federal court trial in Boston. The trial, which began in October, has pitted the Ivy League school against Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA), a group founded by activist Edward Blum, who opposes affirmative action policies. The SFFA's complaint against Harvard is backed by the U.S. Department of Justice, which launched an investigation into the university's admissions practices after President Donald Trump took office.

The trial has provided a rare look into Harvard's admissions process, which considers a range of factors, including academic achievement, extracurricular activities, and personal qualities. SFFA's lawyer, John Hughes, argued that data from Harvard shows a strong pattern of bias against Asian-American applicants, particularly in terms of "personal ratings," which measure abstract qualities such as leadership skills and friendliness. Hughes claimed that Asian-Americans receive worse personal ratings year after year, which he believes is evidence of racial bias.

Harvard's lawyers, however, conceded that Asian-Americans have received lower personal rating scores in recent years, but argued that this is only one of many factors considered in admissions. They pointed out that Asian-Americans, on average, score higher than other racial groups on some factors.

The trial is expected to conclude with a ruling from Judge Allison Burroughs between December and March 2019. Legal experts believe the case has the potential to reach the U.S. Supreme Court, which could give the newly-cemented conservative majority a chance to bar the use of affirmative action to help minority applicants get into college.

SFFA alleges that Harvard has gone beyond the Supreme Court's precedent by engaging in "racial balancing" and keeping Asian-American admissions at or under 20% annually in the years leading up to the lawsuit. Harvard denies the allegations, stating that its approach to promoting student body diversity is in line with Supreme Court precedent.

The outcome of the trial could have significant implications for college admissions policies across the United States.

Title: Trump Reveals He Decided to Fire Comey Without Regard to Justice Department's Recommendation

President Trump has revealed that he decided to fire FBI Director James Comey without regard to the Justice Department's recommendation, stating that it was "set up a while ago" and that he was going to fire him regardless. Trump made these comments in an interview with NBC's Lester Holt, in which he also criticized Comey as a "showboat" and "grandstander."

According to Trump, he decided to fire Comey because of the FBI's turmoil and the Russia storyline, which he believes is a "made-up story" created by Democrats to explain their loss in the 2016 election. Trump denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia, stating that there is "no collusion" and that the Russians did not affect the outcome of the election.

Trump also revealed that he had asked Comey if he was under investigation, a move that has raised ethical questions about the president's potential interference in the investigation. Trump claimed that Comey told him he was not under investigation, but Comey did not need to confirm this as he was already aware of the investigation.

The president also stated that he wants to get to the bottom of Russian meddling in the election, but qualified his statement by saying "if" Russia was involved. The intelligence community has concluded that Russia did meddle in the election, and Trump's comments have been met with skepticism by many.

The White House initially claimed that Comey's firing was based on the recommendation of Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, but Trump's comments have undermined this narrative. The FBI has also disputed the claim that morale was low at the agency, with Acting Director Andrew McCabe stating that Comey had the full confidence of the bureau.

Overall, Trump's comments have raised more questions about his motivations for firing Comey and his potential interference in the investigation.

Title: Partial Government Shutdown Enters Second Weekend, Disrupting National Parks and Services

The partial government shutdown in the United States has entered its second weekend, with no signs of a resolution in sight. The impasse has resulted in the closure of about a quarter of the federal government, including national parks, museums, and some government services. Joshua Tree National Park in California is one of the affected areas, where rangers have been sent home, leaving visitors to navigate the park without guidance.

The Friends of Joshua Tree National Park, a nonprofit organization, has stepped in to help maintain the park's facilities, including cleaning bathrooms and restocking toilet paper. However, the organization's executive director, John Lauretig, expressed concerns about the long-term impact of the shutdown on the park's unique cultural and historical sites.

The shutdown has also affected government contractors, who may not receive back pay when the government reopens. The American Federation of Government Employees estimates that around 400,000 federal employees are still working without pay, with the effects of the shutdown expected to be felt more widely as time goes on.

The shutdown has also disrupted government services, including the Environmental Protection Agency, which will halt operations on January 2, and the Smithsonian museums and National Zoo, which will close on January 2. The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and school lunch program are funded through January, but could be affected if the shutdown continues beyond that.

While some government services, such as Social Security and Medicare payments, are still being made, other programs, like Federal Housing Administration-backed mortgages and flood insurance, may be delayed or affected. The National Association of Realtors has expressed concerns about the impact on the housing market.

The White House has predicted that the shutdown will not have a lasting impact on the economy, but some experts warn that it could cause a temporary blip in the unemployment rate if hundreds of thousands of federal workers remain idle.

As the shutdown continues, volunteers at Joshua Tree National Park will continue to help maintain the park's facilities, but park rangers are still absent, leaving unique cultural and historical sites unprotected.

Title: Republicans Gather at Convention Amidst Postponement and Controversy

The Republican National Convention, postponed due to Hurricane Isaac, got underway on Tuesday with a day of closed-door talks between Romney aides and conservative activists resulting in a compromise that some activists claimed would "result in what we think is a very warm and fuzzy convention." The talks aimed to address concerns over new party rules that would give presidential nominees more control over delegate selection, which some saw as a "power grab" by the party establishment.

Despite the compromise, supporters of Representative Ron Paul of Texas expressed frustration over what they saw as efforts by Romney's aides and supporters to silence their voices in the convention hall. Paul, who declined a speaking slot, accused the Romney campaign of trying to control his message. Supporters of Representative Todd Akin, the Missouri Senate candidate who lost much of the party's support after his comments on "legitimate" rape and pregnancy, revived Tea Party-infused arguments against the "establishment" wing of the party, saying Romney and "party bosses" had abandoned him after his remarks.

The storm also posed a delicate challenge for President Obama, whose efforts to manage the response may have given him a moment to look presidential in Romney's absence, but were also fraught with the risk of appearing to take advantage of a natural disaster at a highly politicized moment.

Convention planners said they had no regrets about their decision to postpone Monday's activities, and they said any ripples of discord on Monday would be forgotten by Tuesday night, when Romney's wife, Ann, will speak, followed by the keynote speech by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

Some Republicans, like Newt Gingrich, dismissed the worry in the air among some senior Republicans, saying "nothing is going to happen that is anything more than noise" and that the party will leave the convention united and with enormous energy, enthusiasm, and eagerness to defeat Barack Obama.

However, a growing group of grass-roots conservative activists saw the extra day as an opportunity to mobilize support for their right to quash the effort by Romney's legal team to give party presidential nominees more say over the selection of convention delegates sent by the states.

Title: Democrats Prepare to Investigate Trump's Presidency if They Win Control of Congress

Article:

If the Democratic Party wins control of the U.S. House of Representatives or Senate in the upcoming November elections, they plan to investigate nearly every aspect of President Donald Trump's presidency, including his long-elusive tax returns, possible business ties with Russia, and conflicts of interest. Congressional sources say that the sequencing and scope of the inquiries have only begun to emerge in recent talks among party leaders and prospective committee chairs.

While impeachment is not on the immediate agenda, Democrats would move quickly to obtain Trump's tax returns to look for business ties to Russia and possible conflicts with the Republican president, his family businesses, and U.S. government interests. They would also examine his handling of security clearances and the revoking of clearances from perceived political enemies.

Polls suggest that Republicans are likely to lose control of the House while possibly expanding their majority in the Senate. Few congressional aides and leaders will speak openly about the Democrats' investigative agenda, but it is clear that they will aim for some bipartisan cooperation to avoid the appearance of political grandstanding ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned that the Democratic probes could be "reminiscent of the late 1990s when we thought it was a good idea politically to impeach Bill Clinton and the public got mad at us, and felt sorry for him." He added, "It could end up not working well for them, at all."

Democratic Representative Elijah Cummings, who would likely become the chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform if Democrats take the House, said, "The waste, fraud, and abuse is plain to see. We're going to act on what we see as a crisis of corruption in the Trump administration."

The article does not specify whether the investigations will be conducted by a special committee or by existing committees, but it mentions that the House Judiciary Committee, the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, and the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence would likely be involved. The committees would spend January organizing, with investigations cranking up as soon as February.

The Ways and Means Committee would use its authority to request Trump's tax returns from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, which could then be used to investigate whether Trump received anything of value from foreigners or had business ties to Russia. Senate Democrats have a list of Trump-related concerns that runs about 100 pages, according to a document seen by the news agency.

Title: Trump Campaign's Blimp Plans: Fact-Checking the Claims

The Trump campaign had planned to deploy a blimp over swing states from May to July, as reported by various outlets in early March. The blimp was intended to serve a dual purpose: campaigning and collecting voter data. According to initial reports, the campaign would encourage viewers to text the Trump campaign, providing their contact information for donation requests and election materials.

However, a recent article by America Web Media claimed that the Trump campaign would use "state-of-the-art spy gadgets" to collect data on those living below. This claim has been disputed, as the initial reporting indicated that voter information would be collected through a message on the blimp encouraging viewers to text the Trump campaign.

The Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment, and there have been no reported sightings of the blimp. The campaign has not publicly mentioned the blimp since the initial reports. With the coronavirus pandemic causing the cancellation of many events, it appears that the blimp never made it beyond the planning stage.

In conclusion, the America Web Media article is incorrect in its claim about the Trump campaign using "state-of-the-art spy gadgets" to gather data on the American people. The planned data collection was entirely voluntary, and the article's claims are outdated given the current circumstances.

Title: Democrats' "Turn Texas Blue" Efforts Face Headwinds Amid Abortion Debate

Article:

The Democratic Party's efforts to "turn Texas blue" by winning over Latino voters are facing challenges due to the recent abortion debate in Austin. While the party had hoped to galvanize new supporters with a hot-button issue, the fight over an anti-abortion bill is likely to create a month-long spectacle that may not appeal to the very voters Democrats are trying to win over.

According to polls, Latinos as a group oppose abortion more strongly than most other voting groups, with 53% of Hispanic Catholics saying abortion should be illegal in all or most cases. A poll by the Wilson Perkins Allen research firm found a 2-1 "pro-life" margin among Hispanic voters in Texas.

Democratic strategists acknowledge that abortion is not the issue they would have chosen to lead the pitch for Latino votes, but it was forced upon them when Governor Rick Perry added the anti-abortion bill to the special session. Terri Burke, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, said, "Is this the issue we would have picked to turn Texas blue? No, it was kind of thrust at us. We didn't pick it."

Some Democratic strategists suggest that the key to winning over Latinos is to avoid focusing too much on any one issue, especially abortion. Matt Angle, a longtime state strategist, recommends developing a broader pitch on a range of issues important to Latinos, such as overreach by imposing strict health and safety standards that force many health clinics to shut down.

While some polls suggest that Latinos' opposition to abortion may be softer than it appears, most Democrats don't think this will sink their hopes. James Aldrete, an Austin-based consultant, cited a poll by Lake Research Partners that found 74% of Latinos believe women have the right to make their own decisions about abortion without interference from politicians, and a similar percentage said they wouldn't judge women who decide they're not ready to be parents.

The Democratic Party has struggled to win over Latino voters in the past, with the party not having won a statewide race since 1994 and losing control of the Legislature years ago. However, most strategists believe that a broader approach to winning over Latino voters will ultimately be successful.

Title: Trump Campaign Shifts Focus to Elizabeth Warren as She Rises in Polls

The Trump reelection campaign is redirecting its attention to Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has been gaining momentum in the Democratic primary. The shift comes after Warren's disciplined style, populist-infused speeches, and perceived ability to win over suburban female voters have raised concerns among Trump's advisors.

According to Trump campaign pollster John McLaughlin, Warren's attacks on Trump's policies pose a threat to his support from working-class voters who propelled him to the presidency. McLaughlin has sounded the alarm internally, stressing that Warren's momentum in May and June in national and early caucus and primary states has raised concerns.

The Trump campaign is preparing to dig into Warren's past as a professor and pick apart her laundry list of policy proposals. They are also planning to brand her as a liberal extremist and highlight her support for government takeover of healthcare, free healthcare for illegal immigrants, radical environmental restrictions, and increased taxes.

Warren's populist economic agenda has gained praise from some Trump-friendly outlets, including Tucker Carlson, who compared her policies to those of President Trump himself. However, Trump aides are planning a barrage that extends beyond her heritage issue, which has been a focus of Trump's mockery and broadsides.

Warren's campaign has been enjoying a renaissance after a painful campaign rollout, with her recent national poll numbers showing her at 15%, only slightly behind Sanders for second place. In polls released this week of California and Nevada, Warren leapfrogged Sanders, running behind only Biden.

The Trump campaign's latest view is that Warren has a more coherent message and a more passionate liberal following than Biden, whose support they see as soft. However, not everyone agrees that going after Warren is the right move, with some Trump aides arguing that her liberal positions would make her an easier general election opponent.

Title: Obamacare Premiums Rise, But Consumers Can Avoid Increases by Shopping Around

Obamacare premiums are expected to increase for 2015, with experts estimating an average rise of 5.2% across all tier levels, according to Pricewaterhouse Coopers, a consulting group. However, this doesn't mean that consumers are guaranteed to pay more for coverage through the exchanges next year.

Insurers are adjusting their premiums based on their experience with the 2014 plans, which has given them a better understanding of the popularity of their offerings and the health status of their newly enrolled customers. This has led to an average increase of 10% for the cheapest silver tier plan, according to Avelere Health, an advisory firm.

Despite the premium increases, consumers have more options to choose from in 2015, with many more insurers offering plans. This means that consumers can browse through different options and find a plan that better suits their needs and budget.

For those currently enrolled in Obamacare plans, it's crucial to review their options before December 15 to avoid being automatically re-enrolled in their current plan, which may result in higher costs. Even if their premium doesn't increase, they may still experience sticker shock if their subsidy is recalculated based on the rising benchmark plan.

The Kaiser Family Foundation, a non-profit health policy research firm, found that the benchmark plan will rise 2% on average, which could affect subsidy levels. However, if the benchmark plan in their area carries a lower premium for 2015, their subsidy will be recalculated, and they may find that it covers a smaller share of their premium.

Experts emphasize the importance of shopping around this year, as consumers may be able to find a lower-cost option. "Shopping around is an imperative this year," said Dan Mendelson, CEO of Avelere Health. "In many cases, they'll be able to find a lower-cost option."

Title: Facebook Updates Privacy Tools to Simplify User Experience

Facebook is revamping its privacy tools in response to criticisms over its data practices and the upcoming European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) taking effect in May. The changes will not alter Facebook's privacy policies or the types of data it collects on users, but aim to make it easier for the platform's 2.2 billion users to navigate its complex and often confusing privacy and security settings.

The updates will provide users with a simpler way to access and download the data Facebook collects on them, including a new "Access Your Information" section. This feature will allow users to manage their data, including status updates, comments, and search history, and delete or download a copy. The changes will also enable users to browse through their information in detail, without having to download it.

Facebook's Chief Product Officer, Chris Cox, stated that the updates are "the first of many steps" the company is taking to address privacy concerns. The changes have been in the works for some time, but the recent revelations about Cambridge Analytica and Facebook's data collection practices have underscored their importance.

The updates are also designed to comply with the EU's GDPR, which requires companies to make it easier for consumers to give and withdraw consent for the use of their data. Facebook will also propose updates to its terms of service and privacy policy in the coming weeks, although no further details were provided.

Facebook's Chief Privacy Officer, Erin Egan, emphasized that the updates are intended to make it easier for users to understand and control their privacy settings, stating that "most of the privacy updates have been in the works for some time, but the events of the past several days underscore their importance."

Title: Disney's Ambitious Move into Video Streaming: A Strategic Shift with Long-Term Potential

Disney's decision to launch its own video streaming service, Disney+, has raised eyebrows in the industry. Despite the significant upfront costs, the company's grander strategic logic suggests that this move will pay off in the long run. With a low price point of $7 per month, Disney+ aims to attract subscribers and retain those who are missing out on its popular franchises like Star Wars and Marvel.

The shift to Disney+ is expensive, with a $3 billion purchase of BAMTech Media and an $85 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox. Additionally, the company will spend billions more on new original series and films for its service. However, this investment is expected to pay off in the long run, as Disney will gain valuable data and direct customer relationships.

Disney's low price point is a tactical move to attract subscribers in a crowded market. The company is releasing its service years after Netflix, Amazon, and HBO amassed tens of millions of subscribers worldwide. The low price will also help retain subscribers who are frustrated about missing out on Disney's popular franchises.

However, the real prize is data and direct customer relationships. For decades, Disney has thrived due to the interconnection and cross-monetization of its divisions. With Disney+, the company will gain a direct relationship with its customers, allowing it to make more informed decisions about content and merchandise production, increase the efficacy of its marketing and promotion, and sell more Disney-related products and experiences.

Disney's multi-product strategy has led some analysts to compare the service with Amazon's Prime Video, rather than Netflix. Apple is giving its original content away for free to those who buy its phones, tablets, or connected TV devices. AT&T is expected to give HBO Max away to tens of millions of its subscribers. The endgame in SVOD is not video, but entire ecosystems.

In conclusion, Disney's decision to launch its own video streaming service is a strategic move that will pay off in the long run. With its low price point, Disney+ aims to attract subscribers and retain those who are missing out on its popular franchises. The real prize is data and direct customer relationships, which will allow the company to make more informed decisions and increase its revenue.

Title: George Zimmerman Files Lawsuit Claiming Conspiracy to Frame Him in Trayvon Martin's Death

George Zimmerman, acquitted in the 2012 shooting of Trayvon Martin, has filed a lawsuit alleging a conspiracy to frame him and seeking over $100 million in damages. The lawsuit, announced by attorney Larry Klayman, claims that civil rights attorney Ben Crump helped swap out a reluctant witness, Brittany Diamond Eugene, for her half-sister, Rachel Jeantel, and prepared her to deliver a scripted testimony intended to land Zimmerman in prison for Martin's killing.

The lawsuit accuses Trayvon's parents, prosecutors, and state authorities of going along with the alleged ruse and "are alleged to either have known about or should have known about the witness fraud, obstructed justice, or lied repeatedly under oath in order to cover up their knowledge of the witness fraud." According to Zimmerman's lawsuit, Jeantel posed as Trayvon's girlfriend when it was actually Eugene who was dating Trayvon and on the phone with him during the encounter with Zimmerman.

The lawsuit alleges that Jeantel delivered bogus testimony on the stand at Zimmerman's trial and that the alleged conspirators went along with the plot despite Jeantel being two years older, 5 inches taller, and about 120 pounds heavier than Eugene. The plan was allegedly made final in a 3-minute phone call between Crump and Eugene on March 31, 2012.

Jeantel testified that Trayvon told her in a phone call that someone was following him, and that he tried to lose Zimmerman as he neared the home of his father's girlfriend. She also testified that she heard Trayvon talking to Zimmerman in the background and heard a bump from Trayvon's headset hitting something and "wet grass sounds."

Jeantel admitted on the stand to lying several times to Trayvon's family about her age and about her reasons for not attending Trayvon's funeral. The lawsuit seeks compensatory and actual damages of more than $100,000,000 and leaves open the possibility of an additional claim for punitive damages.

The lawsuit has been met with skepticism by Trayvon's family and their attorney, Ben Crump, who called it an "unfounded and reckless lawsuit" and a "shameless attempt to profit off the lives and grief of others."

Title: Colleges Should Encourage Students to Study in States and Regions Far from Their Comfort Zones

Colleges and universities have long been touted as bastions of diversity, but many institutions remain socioeconomically, geographically, and politically homogeneous. This lack of diversity can lead to a lack of understanding and empathy among students, perpetuating the country's partisan divide. To address this issue, colleges should offer programs that encourage students to study in states and regions far from their comfort zones.

The author, a college student, notes that their university is socioeconomically diverse, but still, more than half of their classmates come from the top 20% of family incomes. The author believes that this lack of exposure to different perspectives and experiences hinders their ability to understand the country's problems and its sources. To overcome this, the author suggests scaling up programs that allow students to spend time at different universities in the United States, rather than just studying abroad.

These programs, known as "study in the U.S." programs, have been successful in the past and could be repurposed to encourage students to learn about different cultures and lifestyles within the United States. The author notes that such programs would not only help students gain a broader understanding of the country but also help them develop skills necessary to thrive in a globalized world.

The author also highlights the importance of colleges setting up programs that encourage students to spend a semester at a campus very different from theirs. This would allow students to connect with people from different backgrounds and develop empathy and understanding. The author suggests that such programs could be the foundation for other campus initiatives to encourage students to have difficult conversations and interactions in safe and civil settings.

In conclusion, colleges should consider offering programs that encourage students to study in states and regions far from their comfort zones. This would not only help students gain a broader understanding of the country but also help them develop the skills necessary to become informed and empathetic citizens in a diverse society.

Title: The 2012 Election: A Campaign of Superlatives, but Not in a Good Way

The 2012 presidential election has finally come to a close, leaving behind a trail of controversy and criticism. The campaign, marked by its high cost and intense media coverage, has been described as the most expensive and garish election of the modern era. Many commentators have trashed the show, with some calling it a "dumbing down" of the political process.

The election was marked by a focus on trivial issues and personal attacks, with both President Barack Obama and his challenger, Mitt Romney, engaging in a "dumbing down" of the political discourse. The campaign was dominated by uproars over careless and inconsequential remarks, with much of the debate playing out on cable TV and Twitter.

The playing field was also limited, with the Electoral College's bias in favor of a few swing states intensifying the focus on mobilizing narrow demographic groups within those states. The leading actors, including Obama and Romney, were criticized for their diminished stature and inability to change the course of the campaign.

Three long-term trends contributed to the smallness of the election: the rise of modern political media and the 24-7 news cycle, the increasing importance of social media, and the growing polarization of the electorate. Obama himself had expressed disdain for the frivolous nature of modern political media, comparing it to professional wrestling.

In the end, the 2012 election was marked by a focus on trivial issues and personal attacks, rather than a substantive discussion of the issues. The campaign's smallness was a result of a combination of factors, including the candidates' inability to rise above the fray and the media's focus on sensationalism and clickbait headlines.

Title: Trump's Tweets Spark Debate on Russia Investigation and Obstruction of Justice

The ongoing Russia investigation has sparked a heated debate, with President Donald Trump taking to Twitter to express his frustration and frustration with the investigation. In a series of tweets, Trump denied any wrongdoing, stating that a meeting between his son and a Russian lawyer was "totally legal" and "done all the time in politics." The meeting, which took place in Trump Tower in 2016, was previously reported to be about international adoptions, but new information suggests it was actually about gathering opposition research from a Russian lawyer with Kremlin ties.

Trump's tweets have been met with criticism from Democrats, who have called his actions obstruction of justice. However, Trump's lawyer, Jay Sekulow, has defended the president's tweets, stating that "obstruction of justice by tweet is absurd." Sekulow also emphasized that the president's actions are protected under Article II of the Constitution, which grants the president executive powers over the government.

The debate has also sparked questions about whether President Trump is willing to cooperate with the investigation. His lawyers have advised against him sitting down for an interview with special counsel Robert Mueller, leaving the question of whether Mueller will subpoena the president. Sekulow has stated that if a subpoena is issued, they will "prepare to handle it in court."

Meanwhile, some Democrats are calling for the investigation to continue, with Senator Marco Rubio stating that it is in the best interest of the president and the nation for the investigation to run its course. Others, however, are discussing the possibility of impeachment, with some Democrats saying that if they win the House, they should begin the process of impeaching President Trump.

Title: Comey Reveals He Orchestrated Leak of Memo Detailing Trump's Request to Drop Investigation

FBI Director James Comey acknowledged that he orchestrated the leak of his memo detailing his conversation with President Donald Trump, in which the president allegedly asked him to drop the investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. Comey made the revelation during a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing, stating that he decided to make the conversation public through an intermediary after Trump tweeted that Comey had better hope there were no tapes of their discussions.

According to Comey, he initially did not consider the possibility that there might be corroboration for their conversation, such as a tape recording. However, after Trump's tweet, he realized that there might be evidence of their conversation and decided to release the memo to the public. He asked a close friend, a professor at Columbia University, to share the content of the memo with a reporter, hoping that it would prompt the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Russian election interference.

The memo was published online by The New York Times on May 16 and in the newspaper the next day, attributed to "two people who read the memo" without naming them. During the hearing, Comey did not identify his friend by name, but confirmed that they are a professor at Columbia University. Later, Daniel Richman, a law professor at Columbia, confirmed that he was the close friend who served as the intermediary.

Title: Supreme Court Partially Stays Injunctions on Trump's Travel Ban, Allows Enforcement of Certain Provisions

The Supreme Court of the United States has announced that it will review lower court injunctions blocking the enforcement of President Donald Trump's executive order banning travel from six Muslim-majority countries. In a per curiam opinion, the Court partially stayed the injunctions blocking enforcement of Executive Order 13,780, with the exception of those who lack any bona fide relationship with a person or entity in the United States.

The Court wrote that the lower court injunctions, even accepting the First Amendment arguments against the order as likely to succeed, went too far. The opinion stated that the injunctions reach beyond the scope of the order, as they also bar enforcement of Section 2(c) against foreign nationals abroad who have no connection to the United States at all. The Court noted that denying entry to such a foreign national does not burden any American party by reason of that party's relationship with the foreign national.

The Court also announced that it will consolidate the cases from the U.S. Courts of Appeal for the Ninth and Fourth circuits, Trump v. Hawaii and Trump v. International Refugee Assistance Project, respectively. Both cases found the executive order unenforceable as a likely violation of the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment Establishment Clause, as the lower courts held it was motivated by an attempt to disfavor Islam.

The Court had requested additional briefing from the parties in both cases earlier this month, signaling that it would hear arguments on the case despite going out of its regular term this week. Arguments are expected to be heard when the Court reconvenes in October. The government had argued that the injunctions had delayed the start date for the 90-day order, which would allow the ban to remain valid despite having been issued in March.

A dissenting opinion was written by Justice Clarence Thomas and joined by Justices Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch, which would have stayed the injunctions in their entirety, allowing the travel ban to go fully into effect immediately.

The executive order was the second issued on the matter, with the first, Executive Order 13,769, also including Iraq and immediately being the subject of challenges in the courts. The current order was tailored to address the concerns raised in these initial lawsuits but soon was itself enjoined in both the Fourth and Ninth Circuits.

Title: Republican Leaders Face Challenges in Passing Budget Amid Polarization and Disagreements

Article:

Republican leaders in the US Congress are facing significant challenges in passing their budgets, as disagreements over defense spending and entitlement cuts threaten to derail the process. The House and Senate have released their respective budget proposals, but the path to passage is uncertain.

The main sticking point is the fight over defense spending, with Republicans divided on whether to increase military spending or find alternative ways to fund the Pentagon. The House budget proposal, approved by the House Committee on the Budget, cuts $5.5 trillion from spending over 10 years, while the Senate proposal maintains sequester caps in later years.

The Senate Budget Committee passed its plan 12-10, with some Republicans expressing concerns about the lack of defense spending increases. The House and Senate will debate their budgets on the floor next week, with lawmakers searching for a way to support the proposals.

The budget fight is further complicated by the need to address the "doc-fix" issue, which has been a long-standing problem in Medicare. The sustainable growth rate formula, passed in 1997, was meant to cap doctors' payments, but has been repeatedly patched to avoid cuts. Lawmakers face an end-of-month deadline to avert a 21% cut to doctors' Medicare payments, but have been unable to agree on a permanent fix.

Congressional leaders have proposed a framework for a replacement, which would give doctors a 0.5% pay raise each year for five years while streamlining programs that evaluate their performance. However, some conservatives have questioned Speaker John Boehner's decision to work with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, which may make it difficult to pass the budget.

The spending fights will make it tough for House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to cobble a coalition able to pass a budget, and they are unlikely to get any help from Democrats, who have slammed the twin GOP proposals as "warmed-over stew."

Title: Obamacare Website to Shut Down for Maintenance, Enrollment Numbers Unavailable

The federal government's healthcare website, healthcare.gov, will shut down this weekend to address technical issues and improve its capabilities. The website has been flooded with 8.6 million visitors since its launch, according to officials, but the exact number of people who have enrolled in health insurance plans remains unclear.

The website's technical issues have made it difficult for millions of Americans to access the site, with many users reporting difficulties in creating online accounts and viewing available health plans. Insurance agents have also expressed frustration with the website's functionality, with one broker stating that they were unable to access the site despite multiple attempts.

The government's decision to shut down the website for maintenance has been criticized by some, including House Speaker John Boehner, who called the move a "major flaw" in the Affordable Care Act. "The news that the enrollment system is already going offline confirms that the launch of the president's healthcare law has been an unmitigated disaster," Boehner said in a statement.

However, Democrats argue that the high volume of visitors is a sign of strong public demand for affordable insurance plans. Enrollment numbers are expected to increase as the website improves, with the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association stating that enrollments are "picking up" despite technical issues.

The Obama administration has asked for patience from the public, with President Barack Obama stating that the website will be improved by Monday. However, tech experts have criticized the website's design and coding, saying that it is not ready for prime time. The site's instructions are also confusing, and it crashes frequently.

The shutdown of the website will allow technicians to upgrade its capabilities and address the technical issues that have plagued its launch. The exact number of people who have enrolled in health insurance plans remains unclear, as the website's functionality is still being worked on.

Title: White House Press Secretary Scolds Reporters for Lack of Curiosity in Flynn Case

The White House Press Secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, recently scolded reporters for their lack of curiosity in the criminal case surrounding former national security advisor Michael Flynn. During a press briefing, McEnany pointed to the Obama administration's actions, including the unmasking of Flynn by top officials during the transition period between November 2016 and January 2017.

McEnany listed several questions that she believes have been ignored by the media, including the leaking of Flynn's identity to the press in January 2017 and the FBI's alleged strategy to "get him to lie." She also mentioned the Democratic National Committee-funded Steele dossier and its involvement in the FISA warrants granted to surveil former Trump campaign advisor Carter Page.

When asked what specific crime was committed, McEnany reiterated that the leaking of Flynn's name to the press was the "crime" in question. She also brought up other instances of alleged wrongdoing, such as the leaking of classified information by former FBI Director Andrew McCabe and the lying under oath by former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper.

McEnany urged reporters to investigate these claims and answer the questions she has raised, stating that it is the job of journalists to do so. The press secretary's comments come as the Trump administration continues to push for accountability in the Flynn case and other matters related to the 2016 election.

Title: Trump's Criticism of Bush Administration's Handling of 9/11 Sparks Controversy at Republican Debate

Article:

In a recent Republican debate, Donald Trump made some bold and provocative claims that were largely true, sparking a strong reaction from the Republican Party establishment. Trump stated that the Bush administration was misled into invading Iraq and that the claim that Bush kept the country safe from terrorism is ridiculous because 9/11 happened on his watch. He also claimed that the Bush administration knew there were no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

The Republican Party establishment, including Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio, quickly came to the defense of the Bush administration, with Rubio even going so far as to say that the president to blame for 9/11 was not the one who was in office at the time, but rather Bill Clinton, who did not kill Osama bin Laden when he had the chance.

The exchange was met with boos from the crowd, which was packed with establishment Republicans. Trump's claims were seen as a departure from the typical Republican Party rhetoric, and the party establishment responded by piling on to diss him.

However, Trump's claims were largely true. George W. Bush was indeed in office on 9/11, and his administration received repeated warnings about al-Qaeda plots against the United States. The administration also rejected a plan to tackle al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which was a holdover from the Clinton administration.

Trump's claim that the Bush administration knew there were no WMDs in Iraq is more dubious, but it is true that the sort of WMD programs the White House said existed were not found, and the administration's public presentations of intelligence findings were highly skewed and selective.

The exchange highlights the tension between Trump's unconventional rhetoric and the traditional Republican Party establishment. While Trump's claims may have been seen as a departure from the typical Republican Party rhetoric, they were largely based in fact. The Republican Party establishment's response to Trump's claims was swift and decisive, but it also highlighted the party's tendency to defend its own even when faced with uncomfortable truths.

Title: Denuclearization: A Concept in Disarray Ahead of Kim-Moon Summit

The upcoming summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in has raised more questions than answers about the concept of denuclearization. The term has been bandied about in recent weeks, but there is little agreement on what it means, and confusion could lead to trouble in this week's summit.

South Korean officials and Chinese state media have said Kim is willing to discuss denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula, but North Korean state media has made no mention of the topic, and public statements by Kim have been vague. The US has consistently used the term "complete, verifiable, irreversible dismantlement" (CVID) to describe the dismantling of North Korea's nuclear program, while North Korea has not specified what it means by denuclearization.

Experts say that Pyongyang has long been expected to push for the withdrawal of US forces from the Korean Peninsula as part of the discussion, and it is unclear if this demand has changed despite President Moon's recent remarks. The US has not stationed nuclear weapons in South Korea since 1992, but North Korea considers the US military presence on the peninsula a nuclear threat.

The confusion over what each side is willing to give and what their basic goals are for the summits makes a positive outcome harder to see. Experts say that the hopes of some officials in Washington that Kim would willingly give up his nuclear weapons program are "utopian" and that given the ongoing "disdain" the Trump administration has shown for the Iran deal, it is hard to see a similar, incremental plan getting support in Washington.

The reality is that there is simply too much distrust and too little understanding between the two sides to come to an agreement. They will likely affirm the principle of denuclearization, but the implementation will be drawn up and never happen, according to experts.

Title: Forensic Evidence Links Tsarnaev Brothers to 2011 Unsolved Triple Murder in Waltham, Massachusetts

The Middlesex County District Attorney's Office is investigating whether Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the brothers suspected of carrying out the Boston Marathon bombings, were involved in the unsolved triple murder of Brendan Mess, Erik Weissman, and Raphael Teken in Waltham, Massachusetts, on September 11, 2011. The investigation is based on "mounting evidence" and "forensic hits" that make the brothers strong suspects, according to ABC News.

The triple homicide has gone unsolved since the murders, with the Middlesex County District Attorney's Office previously stating that the victims knew their killer or killers. Tamerlan had identified Mess as his "best friend" to the owner of the martial arts gym where they worked out, and family and friends of the victims recalled that he did not attend Mess's funeral and stopped making appearances at the gym.

The investigation gained new attention after family and friends of the victims recognized Tamerlan in pictures after the Boston bombings and recalled his unusual behavior. The restaurant where the victims ordered food, Gerry's Italian Kitchen, reported that a deliverywoman heard no answer from inside the apartment when she rang the bell around 8:45 p.m. on September 11, 2011. The restaurant also found empty fireworks with gunpowder removed in a charity bin in their parking lot nine days after the Boston bombings.

Residents of Waltham and nearby Watertown, Massachusetts, remembered Tamerlan delivering food and the brothers working as pizza deliverymen, but the restaurant denied that either brother worked for Gerry's. The Middlesex County District Attorney's Office confirmed that it is investigating the possibility that Tamerlan was involved in the triple homicide, stating, "We are definitely going to pursue any new leads."

The news comes as Tamerlan's burial in Virginia was revealed, and his brother Dzhokhar faces two terrorism-related charges in connection with the Boston bombings, which killed three people. Dzhokhar has not been charged in the murder of MIT police officer Sean Collier, who was allegedly killed by the brothers shortly before the firefight with authorities on April 18.

Title: FBI Director Comey Testifies on Hillary Clinton's Email Practices, Fueling Republican Questions

FBI Director James Comey testified before the House oversight committee on Thursday, stating that Hillary Clinton's claims about her use of a private email server were "not true." Comey's testimony sparked questions about whether Clinton committed a felony by making false statements under oath. The FBI director also said that Clinton's email practices put America's secrets at risk and her actions constituted the "definition of carelessness."

Comey defended the FBI's decision not to pursue charges against Clinton, stating that there was no evidence of intentional wrongdoing. He acknowledged that lying under oath is a felony, but said that there was no basis to conclude that Clinton lied to the FBI. However, he did say that Clinton's actions were "extremely careless" and that she had used multiple devices and thousands of work-related emails were not returned.

The hearing was marked by a tense exchange between Comey and Representative Trey Gowdy, with Comey stating that Clinton's claims about not using a private server were "not true" and that she had used multiple devices. Comey also contradicted Clinton's claims that she had turned over all work-related emails, stating that thousands of emails were not returned.

The hearing sparked criticism from both sides, with Republicans calling for an investigation into Clinton's actions and Democrats accusing the hearing of being political. The FBI director's testimony has fueled questions about whether Clinton's actions were a breach of security and whether she should be held accountable.

In a separate development, Comey denied a double standard was at play in the FBI's decision not to pursue charges against Clinton, stating that no one at the DOJ would have brought a case against "John Doe" based on the facts. He also said that if Clinton had worked at the FBI, she could be subject to disciplinary measures, including suspension or termination.

The hearing comes as Republicans continue to pressure Comey and Clinton over the FBI's decision not to pursue charges in the email case. House Speaker Paul Ryan has called for Comey to release all unclassified findings from the agency's investigation, while the Clinton campaign has hit back at Republicans, calling their actions a "stunt."

Title: Congressional Leaders Weigh In on President Obama's Surveillance Plan

Article:

Congressional leaders from both the House and Senate intelligence committees have expressed concerns and disagreements over President Obama's plan to overhaul the government's surveillance programs. The plan, announced on Friday, aims to reduce the risk of abuse by storing bulk phone data outside the government's control. However, the leaders have differing opinions on the proposal.

Rep. Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, expressed uncertainty about the plan, stating that it has created a sense of uncertainty about the country's ability to root out terrorist threats. He emphasized that a decision was needed on Friday, but instead, the administration provided uncertainty.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, praised the president's defense of the National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance programs but expressed concerns about the potential impact on the ability to disrupt terrorist plots. She noted that the program is designed to provide instantaneous information to prevent threats, and any changes could hinder its effectiveness.

The surveillance program, which collects phone numbers and conversation lengths but not the content of calls, has been under scrutiny since former NSA analyst Edward Snowden leaked documents revealing the program's scope. The controversy has sparked concerns about the balance between national security and individual privacy.

Sen. Patrick Leahy, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has proposed ending the NSA's bulk data collection program, putting him at odds with Sen. Feinstein. Leahy expressed concerns that the government has gone too far in invading Americans' privacy and suggested that legislation will be needed to address the issue. However, he also acknowledged the need for checks and balances to prevent government overreach.

The debate highlights the ongoing discussion about the balance between national security and individual privacy, with lawmakers seeking to find a solution that addresses both concerns. The administration has given itself 60 days to find a solution, and the debate is likely to continue as lawmakers weigh in on the issue.

Title: Stormy Daniels' "60 Minutes" Interview: What to Watch for

The upcoming interview between adult-film actress Stormy Daniels and CBS' "60 Minutes" has sparked widespread interest, with many questions surrounding what she may reveal about her alleged affair with President Trump. The interview has been shrouded in mystery, with even Daniels' lawyer, Michael Avenatti, acknowledging that he is unsure what will be included in the segment.

One of the main points of interest is whether Daniels will discuss the nondisclosure agreement (NDA) she signed with Trump, which allegedly bars her from speaking about the alleged affair. The agreement was confirmed in a lawsuit filed by Daniels earlier this month, which argues that it is invalid because it was not co-signed by Trump himself. Whether Daniels will discuss the details of the agreement in the "60 Minutes" interview remains to be seen.

Another point of interest is whether Daniels will provide evidence to back up her claims. Avenatti has hinted that video or photographic evidence of the alleged affair exists, and Daniels' lawsuit refers to "certain still images and/or text messages which were authored by or relate to" the president. Avenatti has also suggested that Daniels may have retained copies of the evidence, and a cryptic tweet about a compact disc inside a safe has sparked speculation.

The interview may also shed light on the alleged threats Daniels received in connection with the affair. Avenatti has said that Daniels was physically threatened, but declined to provide more details. Daniels herself has not publicly addressed the matter, leaving it unclear whether she will discuss it in the "60 Minutes" interview.

Additionally, the interview may provide insight into Daniels' motives for speaking out now. Her lawsuit claims she expressed interest in discussing the alleged affair publicly in 2016 after The Washington Post published a 2005 "Access Hollywood" tape in which Trump could be heard boasting about groping and kissing women without their permission. However, for over a year after that, Daniels was silent about the alleged affair, and it was only in recent months that the accusations resurfaced.

The interview is set to air on Sunday night, and whatever Daniels reveals may force the hand of Trump's own legal team. Trump's lawyers have already signaled their willingness to fight Daniels on her claims, and it will be interesting to see how they respond to the interview after it airs.

**Clinton's Health Under Scrutiny After Karl Rove's Comments**

Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, recently sparked controversy by suggesting that Hillary Clinton, a potential presidential candidate, may have suffered a brain injury. Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, has come to her defense, stating that she is "strong" and "in better shape than I am."

Rove's comments were made during a conference, where he discussed Clinton's 2012 incident, which sent her to the hospital after she fell and suffered a blood clot. Rove questioned the timing of Clinton's hospitalization and her subsequent use of special glasses to deal with double vision.

Clinton's team has strongly denied Rove's claims, with her spokesman, Nick Merrill, stating that she is "100%." Former President Bill Clinton also defended his wife, saying she works out regularly and is in better shape than he is.

Rove defended his comments, stating that it is legitimate to ask about a potential presidential candidate's health. He pointed out that Clinton's health was an issue during her time as Secretary of State, when she suffered a blood clot behind her right knee and fractured her right elbow.

The 2012 incident was not the first time Clinton dealt with blood clots. She told the New York Daily News in 2007 that she suffered a large blood clot behind her right knee while campaigning for Sen. Chuck Schumer in 1998.

The controversy surrounding Clinton's health is likely to continue as she considers a presidential bid. Rove believes that her health will be an issue in the 2016 race, regardless of whether she decides to run.

Title: Trump's Efforts to Repeal Obamacare Face Legal Challenges

The Trump administration is pushing to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, but its efforts are facing legal challenges in the courts. Two federal judges in Washington, D.C. have blocked parts of Trump's health care agenda, including work requirements for some low-income people on Medicaid and new small business health plans that don't provide full benefits required by the ACA.

A federal judge in Texas ruled last December that the ACA is unconstitutional and should be struck down in its entirety. The Trump administration has urged the Justice Department to support the Texas judge's position and argue that all of Obamacare must go. However, the litigation could take months to resolve, or longer, and there is no guarantee that Trump will get the outcomes he wants before the 2020 election.

The clock is ticking, and some experts believe that the Trump administration may not have enough time to resolve the mess created by the court challenges, much less get a comprehensive plan through Congress. If the ACA is struck down entirely, Congress would face an impossible task of passing a comprehensive health overhaul to replace it.

The case is now on appeal, and it's unclear how it will ultimately be decided. The Trump administration has not presented a comprehensive health care plan, and there is no consensus among Republicans in Congress. The various health care cases involve lower-court rulings for now, and the outcome is uncertain.

The Trump administration has been pushing for a more limited approach, focusing on smaller changes to the healthcare system rather than a comprehensive overhaul. However, the legal challenges are ongoing, and the outcome is far from certain.

Title: Republican Representative Introduces Legislation to Deport Illegal Aliens During National Emergencies

The Republican Representative Matt Gaetz has introduced the Protect American Nationals During Emergies by Mitigating the Immigration Crisis Act (PANDEMIC), which would require the deportation of all illegal aliens under U.S. custody during a national emergency due to a communicable disease. The legislation is a response to a bill introduced by Democratic lawmakers Cory Booker and Pramila Jayapal, which calls for the release of detainees and a halt to targeting illegal aliens who are deemed not to pose a substantial public safety risk.

Gaetz stated that the PANDEMIC Act puts Americans first by requiring the deportation of illegal aliens during a pandemic, ensuring that resources are used to benefit and protect American citizens. He pointed to the actions taken by the Mexican government, which has nearly repatriated all illegal aliens in its custody to reduce the risk of migrant detention centers becoming hotbeds for outbreaks.

The Trump administration has taken steps to scale back its immigration enforcement efforts, with ICE announcing it would focus on individuals who pose a greater public safety threat and releasing hundreds of immigrants at risk of coronavirus complications. However, the administration has also increased enforcement operations in other areas, such as closing the northern and southern borders to all "non-essential" traffic and threatening visa sanctions on countries that refuse to accept deportees from the United States.

Gaetz's legislation is the latest development in the ongoing debate over immigration policy and the response to the coronavirus pandemic.

Title: House Investigators Accuse FBI of Stonewalling in IRS Targeting Probe

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee's investigation into whether the FBI and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) targeted conservative group True the Vote for special scrutiny has hit a roadblock, with the FBI refusing to provide documents and information. Rep. Darrell E. Issa, a California Republican, and Rep. Jim Jordan, an Ohio Republican, are leading the investigation and are now threatening to use subpoenas to pry loose the information from FBI Director James B. Comey Jr.

The FBI's investigation into the IRS, which began in the days after an auditor's report revealed the tax agency had improperly targeted tea party groups for special scrutiny, has resulted in no release of information. The congressmen said the FBI even rescinded an offer for an in-person briefing with the assistant director in charge of the investigation, suggesting political meddling.

The FBI declined to comment on the congressional letter, saying the agency would respond in writing. The FBI did say its investigation into the IRS continues. The Justice Department referred inquiries about its involvement to the FBI.

The controversy surrounds the IRS's targeting of conservative groups, including True the Vote, which was seeking tax-exempt status. The internal auditor for the IRS reported in May that the agency asked inappropriately probing questions and delayed conservative groups' applications – in some cases for three years. After the revelations, the IRS promised to clean up its operations, and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. ordered the FBI to open a criminal investigation.

One of the conservative activists whose groups were targeted, Catherine Engelbrecht, said she was assailed by both the IRS and the FBI, as well as other federal agencies. She claimed that she and her husband faced an occupational safety investigation into their company, an IRS audit of their company, repeated rounds of IRS questions about True the Vote's activities, and six inquiries from the FBI about the King Street Patriots – including general inquiries and specific questions about someone who attended a group meeting.

The FBI's refusal to provide documents and information has led Rep. Issa and Rep. Jordan to accuse the agency of stonewalling and threaten to use "compulsory" means to obtain the information. The FBI's investigation into the IRS continues, but the agency has not provided any information or documents to the congressional investigators.

Title: Government Shutdown Enters Second Day as Negotiations Stall

The first day of shutdown negotiations between the White House and Congress has ended without a breakthrough, with the government remaining partially shut down. The House and Senate convened on Saturday, but no progress was made towards resolving the impasse.

The House gaveled into session, but Speaker Paul D. Ryan immediately put the chamber into recess, blocking any attempts at floor action. The Senate was in session for over three hours, but mostly empty floor time was spent. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell announced that lawmakers would be sent home for Christmas and would reconvene on Thursday, signaling that the shutdown will last at least until then.

The main sticking point in negotiations is President Trump's demand for $5 billion in border wall funding. The White House had earlier signaled that the president would sign a bill without the funding, but he reversed himself on Thursday and vowed to veto any bill that does not include the funding. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer stated that the president must give up his dream of a border wall before Democrats will agree to reopen the government.

The shutdown has affected over 25% of the government, with more than 800,000 employees in departments and agencies that have lost funding. Of those, 420,000 are deemed essential and will continue working without pay until the shutdown ends, while the remaining 380,000 will be furloughed. The Senate passed a bill to guarantee furloughed workers will still be paid for the time they were out of work, but it has not yet passed the House.

The government shutdown is expected to continue until at least Thursday, with the real effects not being felt by most government workers until Wednesday.

Title: Conservative Columnist Bret Stephens Deactivates Twitter Account After Being Called a "Bedbug" by George Washington University Professor

Conservative New York Times columnist Bret Stephens announced on Tuesday that he deactivated his Twitter account, citing the platform's negative impact on humanity. The decision comes after he was called a "bedbug" by George Washington University professor David Karpf in a tweet. Stephens had previously complained about the professor's comment in an email, inviting him to visit his home and use the term in person.

In the email, Stephens expressed his surprise at the level of vitriol people are willing to direct at others on Twitter, saying that Karpf had set a new standard. He also extended an invitation to the professor to visit his home, meet his family, and use the term "bedbug" to his face. Stephens promised to be courteous regardless of Karpf's response.

Karpf shared the email on Twitter, which quickly went viral. The tweet received over 8,000 retweets and 52,000 likes. Stephens later clarified that the invitation to visit his home was a "standing invitation" and that Karpf could bring his spouse.

The incident highlights the ongoing debate about the impact of social media on human interaction and the level of discourse. While Stephens has deactivated his Twitter account, the exchange between him and Karpf has sparked a wider conversation about the consequences of online interactions.

Title: Obama's Budget Gamble: A Test of Credibility and Governance

The sequester, a spending cut mechanism that President Obama once guaranteed would never happen, has gone into effect, bringing with it a new level of uncertainty and challenge for the administration. The president's credibility is now on the line as he and his administration predicted the impact of the cuts, which are expected to be felt across the country. The stakes are high, as the president's vision for governance is being put to the test.

The sequester, which has been in place since March 1, has brought about $85 billion in cuts to federal spending, affecting various government programs and services. The president's strategy relies on the public rising up and rejecting cuts to government services, which would pressure Republicans to reconsider their stance on spending. However, if the public does not respond as expected, the president may be forced to accept deeper spending cuts and potentially even more significant changes to the budget.

The president's position is awkward, as he wants to mitigate the real-world impact of the budget cuts while also exerting political pressure on Republicans to reconsider their stance on spending. The White House economic adviser, Gene Sperling, believes that as the pain of the cuts spreads to communities affected by military spending, mental health services, and border security, more Republican colleagues will be persuaded to consider bipartisan compromise on revenue-raising tax reform and entitlement reform.

Republicans, on the other hand, have their own concerns about the sequester, with some expressing alarm about its impact on Defense spending and others viewing it as a step towards fiscal sanity. However, they are united in their opposition to tax increases, which could limit the scope of potential compromises.

The president's Friday news conference highlighted the complexity of the situation, as he acknowledged the limitations of his powers to address the current state of affairs in Washington. With no easy answers, the president and his critics can only wait and see how the situation unfolds.

Title: Miss Michigan 2019 Kathy Zhu Stripped of Title Over Alleged Discrimination Against Conservative Views

Kathy Zhu, the winner of the 2019 Miss Michigan pageant, has been stripped of her title by Miss World America (MWA) due to social media posts deemed offensive, insensitive, and inappropriate. According to Zhu, the organization accused her of being racist, Islamophobic, and insensitive, citing specific tweets and her refusal to participate in a hijab-wearing event at her college campus in 2018.

Zhu's tweets in question included a statement about refusing to wear an Islamic headscarf after a Muslim woman tried to put one on her head during World Hijab Day at her college campus. She argued that the hijab is used to oppress women in certain Muslim countries, saying it's not just a fashion accessory but a symbol of oppression. MWA took issue with this statement, deeming it offensive and insensitive.

Another tweet that sparked controversy was Zhu's statement about black-on-black gun violence, saying that the majority of black deaths are caused by other blacks. She defended this tweet, stating that it was meant to encourage the black community to address their own problems rather than blaming others.

Zhu received a letter from MWA stating that her social media posts violated the organization's rules and conditions regarding good character. The letter accused her of being racist, Islamophobic, and insensitive, and stripped her of her title, stating that she was no longer recognized as a participant in any MWA events.

Zhu has spoken out about the situation, saying that she is glad the story has been brought to the public eye and that it highlights the issue of discrimination against people with different opinions. She believes that there should be diversity of thought and mindset, not just skin color, and that pageant organizations should not discriminate against individuals based on their beliefs.

The controversy has sparked a wider discussion about free speech, political correctness, and the role of pageant organizations in promoting diversity and inclusivity.

Title: Climate Change Debate: A Complex Issue with Uncertainties

The recent devastating typhoon in the Philippines has sparked a heated discussion about the role of climate change in extreme weather events. While emotions run high, a closer examination of the data and scientific understanding reveals a more nuanced picture.

Representatives of the Philippines at the UN have called for immediate action to address climate change, citing the urgency of the situation. However, Bjorn Lomborg, a prominent climate expert, has argued that the cost of implementing such measures would be catastrophic, potentially ruining economies and yielding only marginal results.

The current data suggests that carbon emissions in the US have dropped to 1994 levels, and global warming has paused for the past decade. Some scientists predict this pause could continue for another 20 years. In this context, it is challenging to pinpoint a single event, like Typhoon Haiyan, as solely caused by climate change.

Furthermore, looking at the global weather patterns, hurricanes and tornadoes are currently at record low levels. Summer 2013 has seen no hurricanes form, and tornado activity is also at an all-time low. Meteorologists attribute this to luck, shifts in the jet stream, African winds, and dust.

This raises the question of whether local weather patterns, including those in the Philippines, are more influenced by natural factors than by CO2 emissions. Since the science is not yet settled on this issue, it is essential to continue studying the complex interactions between climate and weather.

In conclusion, the relationship between climate change and extreme weather events remains a topic of ongoing research and debate. While emotions run high, a closer examination of the data and scientific understanding suggests that the issue is more complex and multifaceted than a simple cause-and-effect scenario.

Title: House Republicans Introduce Legislation to Make Permanent Tax Cuts, Boost Economy

House Republicans have introduced legislation to make permanent the tax cuts introduced last year, aiming to remind voters of the surging economy and the Republicans' role in getting it there. The three bills, dubbed Tax Reform 2.0, would make permanent the tax breaks for individuals, prevent them from facing a tax increase in eight years, and boost incentives for retirement savings and lenient tax treatment for startups and small businesses.

The legislation is expected to be voted on in the House by the end of September, allowing Republicans to crow about last year's tax cuts and force Democrats to explain their opposition amid a surging economy. However, the bills are unlikely to survive a Democratic filibuster in the Senate, as they are not protected by a budget.

The latest package is expected to add at least $650 billion to the deficit over the next decade, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning think tank. The center said that most of the savings would benefit wealthier Americans.

The tax reform is the biggest legislative accomplishment of a Congress controlled by Republicans since President Trump took office. Republicans are counting on the tax cuts to persuade voters to keep them in charge. Americans are increasingly pleased with the economy's performance, with a Quinnipiac University poll finding that 70% of respondents said the U.S. economy is "excellent" or "good," matching the poll's record high.

The latest round of numbers includes 4.2% quarterly growth in the gross domestic product, a continued low unemployment rate, and a significant boost in average wages. However, President Trump's approval rating stood at just 38% in the Quinnipiac poll, dragged down by what voters saw as personal failings of lack of honesty and leadership.

The White House has credited President Trump with a broader set of data, including small-business optimism, business confidence, real sales, real private nonresidential fixed investment, and core capital goods orders and shipments, which have surged since Mr. Trump took office. However, critics argue that the economy's growth is largely a continuation of the trend that began during the Obama administration.

The crux of the effort is making permanent changes for individuals, including lower income tax rates, a higher standard deduction, and a bigger child tax credit. The legislation aims to fix the problem Republicans created when they used a gimmick to fit into the $1.5 trillion budget space allotted for the 2017 tax cuts, making corporate tax cuts permanent but imposing a sunset on individual tax cuts, leaving Americans poised to face massive hikes in 2026.

Title: Trump's Management Style in the White House: A Mixed Bag

The Trump administration has been marked by a unique management style, one that has been shaped by the president's business background and experience on reality TV. President Trump has brought a small, loyal team of staffers to the White House, but this approach has led to mixed results. The recent resignation of National Security Adviser Michael Flynn and the withdrawal of Labor Department nominee Andrew Puzder from the confirmation process are just a few examples of the challenges the administration has faced.

Trump's business experience has not prepared him for the complexities of running a vast federal bureaucracy. He has bristled at the idea that presidential orders can be blocked by a federal judge and has upended longstanding foreign policy doctrine with ease. This lack of experience and understanding of the inner workings of government has led to mistakes and missteps.

Trump's management style has been described as "seat of the pants" by journalist David Cay Johnston, author of "The Making of Donald Trump." He has been known to make decisions quickly, often without fully considering the consequences. This approach has led to friction and palace intrigue within the White House, but some argue that it can also lead to wiser decisions.

However, Trump's lack of experience and understanding of government has also led to mistakes and missteps. His administration has struggled to coordinate its efforts and has faced criticism for its handling of key issues, such as the travel ban.

The question remains whether Trump can learn from his mistakes and adapt to the challenges of running the government. As he once said on The Apprentice, "A really good leader will step up, take responsibility, and really just find the right solution." Only time will tell if Trump can learn this lesson and become a more effective leader.

Title: US Abstains from UN Vote Condemning Israeli Settlements, Risking Lasting Peace in the Region

The United States abstained from a United Nations Security Council vote on Friday, allowing a resolution condemning Israel's settlement expansion in the West Bank to pass. The decision has sparked a sharp reaction from Israeli leaders and US Republicans, who view it as a snub to the country's key Middle East ally.

Secretary of State John Kerry defended the Obama administration's decision, stating that it aimed to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution between Israelis and Palestinians. Kerry emphasized that the US does not agree with every aspect of the resolution but believes it "rightly condemns violence" and calls on both sides to take constructive steps to reverse current trends and advance the prospects for a two-state solution.

The resolution, put forward by four nations, calls on Israel to "immediately and completely cease all settlement activity in occupied territories, including East Jerusalem." It also reiterates the longstanding UN position that all settlements on land Israel conquered in 1967 are illegal under international law.

Israel believes it has the right to expand settlements in the disputed territories as populations within them expand. Palestinians, however, do not believe the settlements should exist at all, and world condemnation of expansion is seen as a possible first step in that direction.

The US abstention has been met with criticism from Israeli leaders and US Republicans, who view it as a betrayal of the country's historic ally. Israel's Ambassador Danny Danon called the decision "a snub to the country's greatest ally" and expressed confidence that the new US administration and incoming UN Secretary General will usher in a new era in the UN's relationship with Israel.

House Speaker Paul Ryan blasted the administration for appearing to undermine America's historic Middle East ally, calling the decision "absolutely shameful." Former GOP presidential candidate and Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee called the move "a big mistake."
