The resolution was adopted with 14 votes in favor, with the US abstaining. It is the first resolution the Security Council has adopted on Israel and the Palestinians in nearly eight years. The US has used its veto power in the past to shield Israel from condemnatory resolutions, but the Obama administration has long made clear its opposition to Israeli settlement-building in occupied territory.

Title: House Minority Leader Pelosi Calls for Debate on Military Authorization to Combat Islamic Militants

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, has called on Speaker John Boehner to initiate a debate in Congress over granting President Barack Obama a new authorization to use military force to defeat Islamic militants. Pelosi made the statement during a breakfast with Bloomberg News reporters and editors in New York.

The current authorization for military action, passed in a rare bipartisan vote this month, is set to expire in December. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, has expressed willingness to call Congress back into session to vote on authorizing broader military action, but it is up to Obama to make the request.

Pelosi emphasized that Congress should not wait for the president to ask for authorization, stating, "Since when do we sit around waiting, using the excuse he didn't ask? No, if you want to have an authorization that has any constraints on the president, you don't wait for him to write it."

The debate over the authorization will likely open a divide in both parties and both chambers of Congress. Democrats, led by Pelosi, strongly oppose using U.S. ground troops to fight Islamic State, while Republicans, particularly in the House, want a more robust response, including possible ground forces.

Boehner expressed his concerns about the threat posed by Islamic State, stating, "These are barbarians." He also noted that the U.S. may have "no choice" but to put American troops on the ground if other nations fail to do so.

Pelosi also expressed concern about the upcoming debate over raising the nation's borrowing limit, set to expire as early as March. She emphasized the importance of meeting the nation's borrowing obligations, stating, "We shouldn't even be having this discussion."

Although this election year is unlikely to yield many new seats for Democrats, Pelosi predicted that her party will win a majority in Congress in 2016.

Title: Half of Obamacare Users Unhappy with Prices and Technology, Survey Finds

A recent survey conducted by Bankrate.com has revealed that over half of households that used the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) exchange last year are unlikely to use it again during the upcoming sign-up period. The survey, sponsored by Bankrate.com, found that 51% of respondents do not want to use HealthCare.gov or their state-run insurance marketplaces again.

The main concerns among those surveyed were the high prices for health plans, with 40% citing this as their reason for not wanting to use the exchange. Additionally, 25% of respondents felt that too many people remained uninsured after the health care law went into effect, while 21% mentioned technological problems that hindered the federal Obamacare website and some state-run exchanges during the first enrollment period.

Despite the negative sentiments, the survey also found that over half of respondents had a positive experience during the previous enrollment period, while 43% reported a bad experience. The Obama administration is hoping that the second round of enrollment, which will take place from November 15 to February 15, will continue to chip away at the nation's uninsured rate.

To meet congressional scorekeepers' target of 13 million enrollees in 2015, the administration will need to encourage roughly 7 million existing enrollees to re-up in their plans and nearly 6 million more first-time enrollees. Those who can afford coverage but fail to get it are subject to a tax penalty unless they qualify for an exemption.

The survey also highlighted the importance of the off-exchange market, where Americans who do not qualify for income-based subsidies can purchase insurance. However, experts suggest that there may not be significant differences between on-exchange and off-exchange policies.

In related news, 18 states have filed a legal brief to protect Obamacare subsidies for those who do qualify, opposing high-profile lawsuits that claim the subsidies should only flow to states that set up their own exchanges. The full D.C. Circuit is considering the case, with the Supreme Court expected to decide whether to take up the case in the coming days.

Title: Obama and Xi to Meet in Informal Summit, Skeptics Question Impact

Article:

The upcoming summit between President Obama and China's new President Xi Jinping has raised questions among skeptics about the potential impact of the meeting. The summit, to be held at the Sunnylands estate in Rancho Mirage, California, will focus on building a personal relationship between the two leaders, with discussions covering topics such as military and corporate cybersecurity, North Korea, territorial disputes in the South China Sea, and US-China trade.

Some experts, like Dean Cheng, a research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, are doubtful that the summit will yield significant results. Cheng believes that the tone and personal rapport between leaders do not matter in defending national interests. He expects little substance to come out of the meeting, with the possibility of some pleasantries and photo opportunities.

However, others see the informal summit as an opportunity for the two leaders to get to know each other and build a personal relationship that can lay the groundwork for US-China relations in the years ahead. Christopher Johnson, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, believes that the relaxed atmosphere will allow the two leaders to focus on developing personal rapport and exchanging views on the many strategic challenges facing the bilateral relationship.

Chinese officials have cautioned that no one should expect "deliverables" or specific agreements on the issues discussed during the summit. However, they are open to the less structured format, which may be a sign that China is willing to adapt to a new type of great power relationship with the US.

US officials see Xi's desire to refashion US-China relations as recognition of the potential pitfalls the two countries face as they assert themselves on the world economic and security stages. They believe that both sides want to avoid a big-power rivalry and are working to establish patterns of interaction to deal with the greatest sources of instability and competition.

The summit will also focus on cybersecurity, with Obama placing emphasis on the issue after a recent Pentagon-commissioned report revealed that Chinese hackers had accessed designs for dozens of key US weapons systems. The two leaders will also discuss North Korea, with the US seeking to probe China's willingness to challenge Pyongyang over its security provocations and funding schemes related to its nuclear program.

The ability of the US and China to have encouraging discussions on reining in North Korea, despite their disagreements on cybersecurity issues, suggests that the relationship is evolving into something more open and developed. This could be a sign that the two powers are ready for the "open and serious discussions" Obama and Xi will have during the summit.

**Supreme Court to Hear Abortion Case in Busy Election Year**

The Supreme Court has agreed to take up a Louisiana law that could leave the state with just one clinic, adding to its busy election-year docket. The justices will examine a Louisiana law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, which is virtually identical to a Texas law struck down in 2016.

The court's new term begins on Monday, but arguments in the Louisiana case won't take place until the winter. A decision is likely to come by the end of June, four months before the presidential election.

The Supreme Court temporarily blocked the Louisiana law from taking effect in February, with Chief Justice John Roberts joining the court's four liberal justices to put it on hold. Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, who were part of the four conservatives who would have allowed the law to take effect, are expected to play a key role in the case.

The Louisiana case and a separate appeal over an Indiana ultrasound requirement for women seeking an abortion were the most significant of hundreds of pending appeals the justices considered when they met in private on Tuesday. Both cases involve the standard first laid out by the court in 1992 that while states can regulate abortion, they can't do things that place an "undue burden" on a woman's right to an abortion.

Louisiana abortion providers and a district judge who initially heard the case said one or maybe two of the state's three abortion clinics would have to close under the new law. However, the appeals court in New Orleans rejected those claims, doubting that any clinics would have to close and saying the doctors had not tried hard enough to establish relationships with local hospitals.

The Supreme Court's decision is likely to have significant implications for abortion rights in the United States, with the justices' ruling potentially shifting the balance of power in the ongoing debate over reproductive rights.

**Primary Elections: A Look Ahead to Tuesday's Contests**

This Tuesday, voters in six states will head to the polls for primary elections, making it one of the most important primary election days of the year. Among the races to watch is a Tea Party challenge to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell in Kentucky. NPR's political editor, Charlie Mahtesian, provides a preview of what to expect.

In Kentucky, Senator McConnell is facing a challenge from Matt Bevin, a businessman and political newcomer. McConnell, the face of the Republican establishment, has raised $20 million and has a comfortable lead in the polls. However, Bevin's campaign has made some rookie mistakes, which could hurt his chances against an experienced politician like McConnell.

Other Senate races to follow include those in Georgia and Oregon. In Georgia, a crowded Republican field is vying for the nomination, while in Oregon, two candidates, Jason Conger and Monica Wehby, are vying for the Republican nomination. Wehby, a pediatric neurosurgeon, has gained attention from some conservatives who believe she could be a strong candidate in a blue state like Oregon.

In the House elections, polls suggest voters are in a cranky mood, but so far, no incumbent has lost in the primaries. While the environment is uncertain, it's still early in the election season, and more primaries will take place by the end of June.

In Idaho, an election is gaining attention belatedly, and maybe for all the wrong reasons. The state's governor's debate featured two longshot, fringe candidates who discussed Armageddon, political correctness, and discrimination against motorcycle clubs, overshadowing the top candidates' competitive race.

Title: Supreme Court to Consider Challenge to Campaign Contribution Limits

The Supreme Court is set to hear a case challenging the aggregate limits on campaign contributions, with the plaintiff, Mr. McCutcheon, and the Republican National Committee (R.N.C.) arguing that these limits violate the First Amendment by restricting their ability to express political opinions. However, this argument is unconvincing, as Mr. McCutcheon is already free to spend as much money as he wants on his own independent campaign-related speech.

The R.N.C. claims that they are only challenging aggregate limits, not individual limits, but this distinction is meaningless in practice. If the court were to strike down aggregate limits, a contributor could give money to every federal candidate and political action committee (PAC) up to the maximum amount, with no limit on the number of PACs that could be created. This would blow a hole in the longstanding scheme of campaign contribution limits.

In fact, a lower federal court has already recognized that there is no limit on the number of PACs that could be created, which would allow a contributor to give up to the maximum amount to each PAC, resulting in a total of $50 million. This would undermine the entire system of campaign finance regulations.

Justice Antonin Scalia has described this argument as a wolf in sheep's clothing, and the only reason the Supreme Court would consider it is if they want to see the destruction of all limits on an individual's donations to a political candidate. The court's decision will be closely watched, as it could have significant implications for the future of campaign finance regulations.

Title: Hillary Clinton Steps Down as Secretary of State, Leaving Legacy of Empowerment and Humanitarian Efforts

As Hillary Rodham Clinton steps down from her position as Secretary of State, many are speculating about her potential future political ambitions, including a possible presidential run. While her tenure as Secretary of State has been marked by significant accomplishments, it is her commitment to empowering women and girls that may be her most lasting legacy.

During her time as Secretary of State, Clinton expanded the scope of foreign policy to include the impact on regular people, making it a priority to focus on the empowerment of women and girls. She created the Office of Global Women's Issues, which worked to highlight the plight of women around the world and hold governments accountable for the systematic oppression of girls and women.

Clinton also included the United States in the Trafficking in Person report, a report that reviews the state of global efforts to eliminate human trafficking, which primarily affects women and girls. She also created the Office of Global Partnerships, which aimed to empower women, children, the poor, and the helpless.

As Secretary of State, Clinton demonstrated her ability to navigate the complexities of international diplomacy, managing egos, protocols, and Congress while maintaining a strong relationship with the President of the United States. Her focus on empowering women and girls has been a game-changer, making her a role model for future generations.

Clinton's legacy is not limited to her diplomatic accomplishments, but also extends to her humanitarian efforts. She has been a champion of education and inclusion in politics for women and girls, and her work has had a profound impact on the lives of millions around the world.

As she steps down from her position, Clinton's future plans remain uncertain, but her legacy as a champion of empowerment and humanitarian efforts is already cemented.

Title: Supreme Court to Reconsider Voting Rights Act's Constitutionality

The US Supreme Court is set to address a landmark case that questions whether Congress misinterpreted racial reforms in the South by reauthorizing the Voting Rights Act (VRA) in 2006. The case, brought by Shelby County, Alabama, and backed by several Southern states, argues that federal oversight of polling stations and election rules in the former Confederacy is too broad and, in some cases, discriminatory.

The case centers around Section 5 of the VRA, which requires certain jurisdictions to obtain pre-clearance from the US Department of Justice before making changes to their voting laws. Critics argue that this provision is outdated and no longer necessary, citing the progress made in voting rights since the law was enacted in 1965.

The case has sparked debate about the need for federal oversight in the South, where voting discrimination was prevalent in the past. While some argue that the VRA is still necessary to protect minority voting rights, others believe that the playing field is now even and that Southern jurisdictions should be trusted to ensure equal access to the polls.

The Supreme Court has hinted that it may be willing to reconsider the VRA's constitutionality, with some justices expressing concerns about the law's scope and effectiveness. The court's decision could have significant implications for voting rights in the United States, with some experts predicting that a ruling against the VRA could lead to further restrictions on voting rights.

The case is a reminder of the ongoing struggle for voting rights in the United States, with both sides of the political spectrum citing statistics and studies to support their arguments. The Supreme Court's decision is expected to be closely watched and could have far-reaching consequences for the future of democracy in the United States.

Title: Ahmedabad Slum Dwellers Receive Eviction Notices Ahead of Trump's Visit

Ahmedabad, India - The city of Ahmedabad is preparing to host US President Donald Trump on February 24, and in the lead-up to the visit, slum dwellers in the city have received eviction notices from municipal authorities. The slum is located near the Motera Stadium, where Trump is expected to attend an event dubbed "Kem Chho Trump" (How are you, Trump) alongside Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

Tejabhai Meda, a 36-year-old laborer who earns Rs 300 (approximately $4.2) a day, expressed shock and uncertainty about the eviction notices. "I have been living here for the past 22 years," he said. "I don't know what to do. On one side, the government is saying it is helping poor people in constructing new homes, but here we are being evicted from a piece of land."

The authorities in Gujarat state have also faced criticism for erecting a 400-meter-long, two-meter-high wall to prevent Trump from seeing a slum district along the route he will take. A senior government official claimed the wall was built for security reasons, not to conceal the slum district, which houses an estimated 800 families. However, the contractor building the wall stated that the government "did not want the slum to be seen" when Trump passes by the area.

The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has denied the allegations, stating that the news report is "incorrect and misleading" and that there are no plans for any forceful evictions in the near future. An AMC official claimed that the slum dwellers were "encroaching on government land" and that they have been asked to clear the site before.

However, Mina Jadhav, general secretary of Majdur Adhikar Manch, a trade union working for unorganized workers in Gujarat, linked the eviction to Trump's visit to Ahmedabad. "The BJP government doesn't want the world to see that poverty exists in Gujarat. They want Trump and others to see only the big buildings, roads, and that everyone here has toilets and homes," she said.

The event, dubbed "Kem Chho Trump," is expected to draw hundreds of thousands of participants, with over 100,000 registrations received so far, according to AMC Commissioner Vijay Nehra. The event provides Trump with the opportunity to woo hundreds of thousands of Indian-American voters ahead of the US presidential election in November.

Title: Connecticut's Gun Seizure Law: A Measure to Prevent Tragedies

The Connecticut gun seizure law, enacted in 1999, has been credited with potentially preventing numerous crimes and tragedies since its implementation. The law allows police to seize firearms from individuals deemed to be a risk to themselves or others, even if no law has been broken. This measure was inspired by the 1998 shooting at the Connecticut State Lottery headquarters, where Matthew Beck killed four people before taking his own life.

Mike Lawlor, the state's criminal justice adviser at the time, was instrumental in developing the law. He recognized that there was a need for a procedure to intervene and diffuse potentially volatile situations. The law allows for a warrant to seize guns, which can be kept for a year, and also includes a mental health evaluation.

The law has been used in over 2,000 cases since its inception, with the majority of complaints coming from spouses. Attorney Rachel Baird, who has represented about a dozen individuals who had their firearms seized under the law, believes that it strikes a good balance between second amendment rights and community protection. However, she notes that police and judges may err on the side of caution, and that it is often difficult to determine who is at risk.

Criminologist James Alan Fox from Northeastern University emphasizes that gun laws are not a guarantee against gun violence and that it is essential to connect with people who are isolated. He suggests that authorities should be on the lookout for individuals who are suffering and may be at risk of harming themselves or others.

The law has been credited with potentially preventing crimes and tragedies, including mass shootings. Bernard Krzynowek, whose guns were seized under the law, had his firearms taken away after his sister reported concerns about his behavior. Krzynowek had a large collection of guns, including a semi-automatic weapon and pistols, which he used for sport, hunting, and protection.

While the law is not a guarantee against all tragedies, it has been a valuable tool in preventing potential dangers. As Lawlor notes, it may have prevented a mass shooting or other serious crime. The law serves as a reminder of the importance of balancing individual rights with community safety and the need for authorities to take proactive measures to prevent tragedies.

Title: Bipartisan Support Grows for FASTER Act, a Bill Aimed at Improving Food Allergy Research and Treatment

The FASTER Act, a bipartisan bill aimed at addressing the growing food allergy epidemic, has gained significant support on Capitol Hill. Introduced by Rep. Doris Matsui (D-Calif.) in April, the bill has seen a 115% increase in congressional support, with 44 lawmakers signing on as co-sponsors. The Problem Solvers Caucus, a group of 24 Democrats and 24 Republican lawmakers, has also fully endorsed the legislation.

The FASTER Act aims to improve the lives of the 32 million Americans living with food allergies, a group that makes up roughly 10% of the U.S. population. The bill would enable major research and data collection initiatives, paving the way for new therapies and treatments, and potentially a cure.

A recent FARE-supported study suggests that medical claims for food-allergy induced anaphylaxis have increased nearly 400% nationwide since 2009. The FASTER Act would combat this trend by addressing the lack of research and data collection in the field.

The bill also takes on the critical issue of sesame as an allergen, through more stringent requirements on labeling and disclosure. According to a recent JAMA Network Open study, more than 1.5 million Americans are allergic to sesame, a figure five times higher than the previous estimate. The FASTER Act would address this dangerous problem and others, making daily life safer and simpler for those with sesame allergies.

FARE, the leading food allergy advocacy organization, supports the FASTER Act because it puts into action their mission to improve the quality of life and health of individuals with food allergies. While the growing support for this legislation is a step in the right direction, the work is not done. The organization encourages Americans to visit their website to learn more about the food allergy epidemic and to write a letter to their representative to co-sponsor the FASTER Act.

Title: The Dangers of Twitter: A Call to Log Off

The recent media debacle surrounding the supposed "smirking MAGA teenager" and the Native American elder has highlighted the perils of Twitter's influence on the media and society. The Washington Post's initial report, which was quickly spread through Twitter, was later found to be one-sided and inaccurate. This incident serves as a stark reminder of the platform's potential to amplify misinformation and fuel mob mentality.

The article's author argues that Twitter is a "disastrous scourge" that is destroying our civilization from within. They suggest that responsible members of the media should declare a Twitter strike, citing the platform's ability to spread rumors and misinformation. The author also notes that Twitter is designed to amplify the worst in us, encouraging mob action, viral groupthink, and outrage in exchange for hits of dopamine.

The article acknowledges that Twitter's addictive nature makes it difficult for many to resist its influence. However, it emphasizes that the platform's impact on the media and society is undeniable. The author suggests that Twitter is a "media-filled monster truck" that is designed to veer out of control, taking clueless journalists over the edge of a cliff.

The article concludes by highlighting the challenges of fighting against Twitter's influence, citing the platform's widespread adoption and the difficulty of changing minds through online discourse. The author notes that even those who are aware of Twitter's flaws often feel compelled to stay on the platform to stay relevant or to engage in intellectual battles.

Title: Michelle Obama's Journey: From Defying Expectations to Preserving Legacy

Article:

Michelle Obama, the wife of the 44th President of the United States, has been a vocal advocate for various social and political issues throughout her husband's two terms in office. As a former first lady, she has been known for her ability to speak frankly about difficult topics, often defying expectations and challenging societal norms. According to colleagues and friends, Mrs. Obama's goal is to look at her life afresh after leaving the White House, with some speculating that she may write a memoir and give speeches.

During her time at the University of Chicago, Mrs. Obama pointed out the institution's isolation from the surrounding black South Side, stating, "I grew up not far from here and the university never once reached out to me." Her ability to discuss sensitive topics, such as medical trials on poor black Chicagoans, was seen as one of her strengths.

In interviews, Mrs. Obama has been known to challenge traditional gender roles, saying, "What I notice about men, all men, is that their order is me, my family, God is in there somewhere, but me is first, and that's not healthy. And for women, me is fourth, and that's not healthy." She has also spoken about the importance of communication and empathy, urging people to reach out to those they may have wronged or neglected.

As the Obamas prepared to leave the White House, some of their aides suggested that Mrs. Obama may not yet know exactly how she wants to sound as a former first lady, but she has been focused on tying up her eight years in the White House as smoothly as possible. Her goal, friends and aides say, is to look at her life afresh.

Some of those same aides argue that Mrs. Obama will be most effective if she sticks to the calibrated tone she has employed during her husband's two terms. They point to Laura Bush's restrained approach as an example, noting that Mrs. Obama has always admired her. Leaving the spotlight could be a relief for Mrs. Obama, as it was for Mrs. Bush, who wrote in her 2010 memoir, "After nearly eight years of hypervigilance, of watching for the next danger or tragedy that might be coming, I could at last exhale; I could simply be."

The article concludes by suggesting that the best way for Mrs. Obama to preserve her popularity and authority may be to hold back, avoiding controversy and potential backlash. Despite being a public figure, she has been the target of revolting attacks, and speaking out more could provoke worse. As first lady, she used subtle hints, invitations, art, and clothing to convey her viewpoint, and her mere presence spoke volumes about her beliefs.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Blocks Same-Sex Marriage Ruling in Idaho, Allows Nevada to Move Forward

The Supreme Court's latest development in the ongoing same-sex marriage debate has brought a brief halt to the momentum towards legalizing same-sex marriage in the United States. On Wednesday, Justice Anthony Kennedy issued a stay on a federal appeals court ruling that would have voided same-sex marriage bans in Nevada and Idaho. However, hours later, Kennedy narrowed the stay to only apply to the Idaho cases, allowing same-sex marriages to proceed in Nevada.

The stay was issued in response to an emergency application from Idaho officials, who sought to block the 9th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals' ruling. Kennedy's order did not provide a rationale for the stay, but instructed those challenging the gay-marriage bans to file a response by Thursday afternoon.

The development is significant, as it temporarily halts the progress towards same-sex marriage legalization in Idaho, bringing the number of states recognizing same-sex marriage to 31. The 9th Circuit's ruling would have brought the number of states recognizing same-sex marriage to 32, with three other states in the circuit – Arizona, Alaska, and Montana – also potentially recognizing same-sex marriage.

The Supreme Court's decision to stay the ruling in Idaho, but not in Nevada, is likely to be a temporary reprieve, as Kennedy is expected to refer the application to the other justices. This could provide another indication of the court's willingness to engage with the same-sex marriage issue. The court had previously dismissed petitions challenging same-sex marriage bans in Virginia, suggesting a lack of interest in revisiting the question.

The stay is a setback for same-sex marriage advocates, who had been celebrating the progress made in recent years. However, the development is also a reminder that the legal landscape is constantly evolving, and the fight for same-sex marriage rights is far from over.

Title: Christine Blasey Ford Agrees to Testify Before Senate Judiciary Committee

Article:

Christine Blasey Ford, the woman who has accused Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault, has agreed to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee, according to her attorneys. The news comes after a deadline set by Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, for Ford to decide whether she would testify before the panel next week.

Ford's lawyers stated in an email that while she has agreed to provide "first-hand knowledge of Kavanaugh's sexual misconduct," they are disappointed with the "leaks and bullying that have tainted the process." The email also indicated that Michael R. Bromwich, a former inspector general of the Justice Department, has joined Ford's team of lawyers.

The timing and terms of the hearing are still unclear, as negotiations continue between Ford's attorneys and the Senate Judiciary Committee. In a letter, Ford's lawyers expressed hope that an agreement on details can be reached.

Ford alleges that Kavanaugh groped her and tried to forcibly remove her clothes during a house party in Bethesda, Md., in the early 1980s. Kavanaugh has denied the allegation and said he is willing to testify publicly to defend his integrity and clear his name.

The White House has stated that Kavanaugh is "ready, willing, and eager to testify as soon as possible." The Senate Judiciary Committee has tentatively agreed to work towards a Thursday hearing with Kavanaugh and Ford, but talks continue on a final agreement.

The developments come as Garrett Ventry, a communications aide on the Senate Judiciary Committee, resigned amid allegations of sexual harassment from his previous job. Ventry denied any past misconduct allegations and said he resigned to avoid being a distraction as Republicans work to confirm Kavanaugh.

Title: Ukrainian President Zelensky Denies Blackmail in Phone Call with Trump, Impeachment Inquiry Continues

Article:

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has denied any allegations of blackmail in a phone call with US President Donald Trump, which is at the center of a possible attempt to remove Trump from office. Zelensky stated that the call was simply a conversation to arrange a meeting and that there were no conditions from the American side. The call, which took place on July 25, prompted a whistleblower complaint and a Democratic impeachment inquiry.

The call transcript, released by the White House, shows Trump asking Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden, a Democratic presidential candidate. The investigation concerns Hunter Biden's involvement with a Ukrainian gas firm, Burisma, which was scrutinized by a former prosecutor general. Ukrainian officials have stated that there is no evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens.

The whistleblower who filed the complaint described the call as "crazy" and "frightening," with a White House official who listened to the conversation being "visibly shaken" by what transpired. The whistleblower's identity remains a secret, although US media have reported that the individual is a CIA officer.

The impeachment inquiry is ongoing, with a poll by Fox News showing that 51% of voters are in favor of impeaching Trump and removing him from office. Trump has denied any wrongdoing and has taken to Twitter to criticize the poll's results. The president is set to host a rally in Minneapolis, Minnesota, on Thursday, which is expected to be met with protests.

The whistleblower's identity has been shrouded in mystery, with lawyers representing the individual stating that they have never worked for or advised a political candidate or party. The whistleblower's prior working relationship with a current 2020 Democratic contender has been reported, although the details of this relationship remain unclear.

Title: Small Business Optimism Index Falls to 91.2 in July, Still in Recession Territory

The National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Small Business Optimism Index has taken another dip, falling 0.2 points to 91.2 in July. This marks the index's lowest point since the recession in July 2009, when it reached 86.5. The highest level the index has reached during the recession was in February 2012, at 94.5.

The index, compiled from the responses of 1,803 randomly sampled NFIB members, fell less than expected, according to the NFIB. The survey found that more business owners believe business conditions will worsen over the next six months, and real sales volumes will be lower in the next three months. Only 5% of business owners believe it is a good time to expand their business, a historically low number.

The report also found that 54% of business owners reported making capital outlays, up 2% over the past six months. Of those, 38% spent on new equipment, 19% purchased vehicles, and 14% improved or expanded facilities. Those planning to make outlays over the next six months held steady at 21%.

Poor sales was named the top problem for 20% of business owners surveyed. The net percent of small businesses reporting higher nominal sales over the past three months, seasonally adjusted, fell four points to -9%. This was after losing seven points in June's index.

The reported net change in job creation was -0.04%, but was better than June's rate of -0.11%. Before June and July, job creation was rising from December to May and were all either zero or positive. Seasonally adjusted, 10% of businesses added an average of 3.0 workers per firm, while 11% reduced employment by 2.3 workers per firm. The remaining 79% made no net change in employment.

NFIB chief economist William Dunkelberg stated that Congress has recessed without a plan to resolve the country's debt and spending cycle, and the White House has presented "fuzzy math" on the impact of planned tax increases. He noted that the denominator in the White House's calculation is wrong, and that more like 15% of small businesses can expect higher taxes in January.

Title: Freshman Congresswoman Ilhan Omar Faces Bipartisan Criticism Over Comments on Israel

Article:

Freshman Congresswoman Ilhan Omar (D-MN) has faced bipartisan criticism for her comments at a town hall event with fellow pro-Palestinian advocate Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI). Omar stated that she wanted to discuss the political influence in the country that says it is okay for people to push for allegiance to a foreign country, specifically referencing Israel. This is the second incident of derogatory speech towards the Jewish state and its supporters this month.

In an attempt to defend her comments, Omar said that many people assume that every comment she makes about Israel is anti-Semitic. She went on to state that the criticism prevents a "broader debate" about Israel's treatment of Palestinians. Omar asked, "Why is it okay for me to talk about the influence of the National Rifle Association, or fossil fuel industries or Big Pharma, and not talk about a powerful lobbying group that is influencing policy?"

Rep. Eliot Engel (D-NY), chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, condemned Omar's comments, stating that they were "unacceptable and deeply offensive" and that they "leveled the charge by invoking a vile anti-Semitic slur." Engel also called for Omar to retract her comments and apologize.

Rep. Nita Lowey (D-NY), chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee, also condemned Omar's comments on Twitter, stating that lawmakers must be able to debate without prejudice or bigotry. Lowey urged Omar to retract her statement and engage in further dialogue with the Jewish community.

Omar responded to her critics on Twitter, stating that her democracy is built on debate and that she should not be expected to have allegiance or pledge support to a foreign country in order to serve her country in Congress or serve on a committee. She also criticized her Democratic counterparts, stating that her Americanness is questioned by the President and the GOP on a daily basis, yet her colleagues remain silent.

Omar also defended her comments on Israel, stating that being opposed to Netanyahu and the occupation is not the same as being anti-Semitic. She expressed gratitude to Jewish allies who have spoken out against her comments.

This is not the first time Omar has faced criticism for her comments about Israel. Her previous comments about US lawmakers supporting Israel because of "the Benjamins" from pro-Israel groups such as AIPAC also received a great deal of criticism from top Democratic leaders.

Title: NBC's Matt Lauer Fired Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations, Multiple Victims Come Forward

NBC's Matt Lauer has been fired from his position as anchor of the "Today" show after allegations of sexual misconduct surfaced. According to a report by Page Six, Lauer allegedly sexually assaulted an employee during the 2014 Sochi Olympics. The employee, who has not been named, filed a complaint with NBC's human resources department, which led to Lauer's swift termination.

Multiple sources, including CNN's Brian Stelter and Variety's Ramin Setoodeh, have reported that The New York Times and Variety Magazine had been investigating Lauer's behavior for weeks and months prior to the employee's complaint. Stelter stated that NBC was aware of the investigations.

Ramin Setoodeh, a writer for Variety, claimed to know of "multiple victims" and shared a tweet from November 2017 stating that he and another reporter had been reporting on the story for two months. Yashar Ali, a journalist, also shared his own experiences, stating that multiple women had come forward privately about Lauer's behavior, but were too afraid to do so publicly due to his power in the media industry.

Ali described Lauer's manipulation of women as "evil, frightening stuff," and stated that he had cultivated relationships with reporters outside of NBC to silence them. He also noted that Lauer had a reputation for being "one of the worst" in terms of his behavior.

The allegations against Lauer are the latest in a string of high-profile cases of sexual misconduct in the media industry, following the departure of Harvey Weinstein and others.

Title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Most of Arizona's Controversial Immigration Law, Upholds Key Provision

The Supreme Court has struck down most of Arizona's controversial immigration law, but upheld a key provision that requires police officers to check the immigration status of those they suspect may be in the country illegally. The provision, which allows police to check the immigration status of individuals during routine stops, will now be sent back to a lower court for review and could still be subject to challenge.

The court's decision was unanimous in allowing the immigration checks to proceed, but divided on the rest of the law. The justices struck down three other provisions, including making it a crime for immigrants to seek employment without work permits and to not carry their immigration papers, as well as allowing police to arrest anyone they suspect of committing a deportable offense. Without the latter provision, the requirement to conduct routine immigration checks has little enforcement power behind it.

The decision has thrown into question how other states that had followed Arizona's lead on immigration enforcement will proceed. The Obama administration has signaled a tough road ahead for those states by suspending a key enforcement program that allowed local officials to partner with federal agents in carrying out immigration law.

The court's decision was met with a range of reactions from officials in Washington and Arizona. Some Democrats expressed concern about the remaining provision, while others declared outright victory. Republicans described the decision as disappointing, while keeping pressure on the Obama administration to fix the country's immigration system. Arizona Governor Jan Brewer hailed the decision as a "victory for the rule of law" and indicated that the state would move to carry out the remaining law, even without the three other provisions.

The federal government had claimed the law encroached on its authority to enforce immigration law. Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote the opinion on behalf of the majority, joined by Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Stephen Breyer, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Sonia Sotomayor. The decision is a significant blow to Arizona's efforts to crack down on illegal immigration, but the state's governor has vowed to continue implementing the remaining provision.

Title: Ben Shapiro Delivers Speech at UC Berkeley, No Riots or Fires Erupt

Ben Shapiro, editor-in-chief of the Daily Wire and a conservative commentator, delivered his speech on campus thuggery at the University of California, Berkeley, without any major incidents or violence. The event, which took place on September 14, 2017, saw nine people arrested for various offenses, including spitting at a police officer, having banned items, and assault. The city of Berkeley spent $600,000 on security measures, including deploying hundreds of police officers to ensure a peaceful event.

Shapiro, who had to pay for his own security, noted that the event did not cause chaos, despite some students being "triggered." He thanked the Berkeley administration for allowing him to speak and the police for providing security. The event began at 10 p.m. EST and lasted until the early hours of the morning.

In his speech, Shapiro highlighted five key points, including the idea that when police are allowed to do their jobs, groups like Antifa are powerless. He also touched on the concept of microaggressions, stating that many students are infected by the mentality, and that some on the left are willing to label anyone a white supremacist. Additionally, he emphasized that conservatism needs to be heard on campus and that the administration should ensure that events are better handled to allow for opposing views to be heard.

The event did not go without controversy, as some students were upset by Shapiro's presence and message. One freshman student reportedly sought counseling after the event. However, the police's decision to ban masks and enforce the law helped prevent any major incidents or violence.

Title: Sen. Elizabeth Warren Leads Democratic Primary Field in Wisconsin, According to New Poll

Article:

A recent poll conducted by Change Research on behalf of Crooked Media has found Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) leading the Democratic primary field in Wisconsin, with 29% of likely Democratic primary voters supporting her. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and former Vice President Joe Biden (D) trailed behind Warren, with 24% and 20% support, respectively. South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg (D) received 9% support, while Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) registered 5%.

The poll, which surveyed 1,966 likely voters in Wisconsin between August 9 and 11, found that 45% of respondents said they would probably or definitely vote for President Trump in the 2020 general election, while 46% said the same for the eventual Democratic nominee. The margin of error for the full sample is 2.2 points.

Wisconsin's primary is scheduled for April 7, 2020, and the state has received increased focus this election cycle due to President Trump's narrow win over Hillary Clinton in the state's last general election.

Title: US Unemployment Rate Drops Unexpectedly to 13.3% in May, Job Growth Surpasses Expectations

The US unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 13.3% in May, a significant drop from the record high of 14.7% in April. According to the Labor Department's report, employers added a staggering 2.5 million jobs in May, the largest increase on record. This marks a faster-than-expected recovery from the coronavirus lockdown, which had shed a combined 22.1 million jobs in April and March.

The report also showed that the leisure and hospitality sector, which was severely impacted by the pandemic, accounted for almost half of the increase, with over 1.2 million employees returning to their jobs. Construction, education, and retail also saw significant job gains, with 464,000, 424,000, and 368,000 jobs added, respectively.

The number of unemployed Americans who reported being temporarily laid off decreased by 2.7 million in May, representing the majority of the jobs that returned. However, the number of permanent job losses continued to increase, rising by 295,000 to 2.3 million.

Despite the positive job growth, the unemployment rate remains at its highest level since the Great Depression, with an estimated 21 million Americans currently out of work. Economists surveyed by Refinitiv had expected the report to show a 19.8% unemployment rate and an 8 million job loss, making this month's report a significant surprise.

Stocks reacted positively to the news, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average pointing to an open nearly 600 higher. Analysts are cautiously optimistic about the economy's recovery, with some noting that the labor market still faces significant challenges and will likely take time to return to pre-crisis levels.

Title: Rand Paul's Nevada Edge Dulls in Crowded Republican Field

Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator, was once considered a strong contender in Nevada, a state thought to be uniquely suited to his "libertarianish" message. However, things have not gone according to plan for Paul, and his rivals have geared up to compete by hiring top-notch state talent and making regular stops. At a recent gathering of 1,500 conservatives in Nevada, it was Ted Cruz who stole the show, while Paul was absent, scheduled for a medical mission to Haiti.

The event, hosted by state Attorney General Adam Laxalt, was heavy with the state's political class, and there were few signs that Paul was missed. One reason is that there are still lingering tensions over bitter disputes between supporters of Paul's father, former GOP Rep. Ron Paul, and the state Republican establishment. However, there's also a simpler explanation, one that has little to do with Paul or his father: the GOP field is so big this time around that those animated by anti-establishment and anti-Washington fervor have plenty of viable options to choose from.

Mary Burgoon, a board member of the Nevada Federation of Republican Women, said, "I don't know anybody who's going to vote for him. There are a few diehards, but that's it. Why him, when we've got so many others anyway?" The feeling was prevalent among attendees of the Basque Fry, which drew four presidential candidates to a ranch an hour south of Reno and hundreds of miles north of the state's population center of Las Vegas.

Several other presidential campaigns have already brought on staff, lined up key endorsements, and started to build out field operations. Walker signaled his intentions by going to Las Vegas the day after he announced his presidential bid in Wisconsin, while Cruz has picked up the same consultants who helped deliver Laxalt's tight 2014 win. Jeb Bush, who spoke at a town hall rally in North Las Vegas on Wednesday, can point to endorsements from GOP Sen. Dean Heller, Rep. Mark Amodei, and former Lt. Gov. Brian Krolicki. He's also hired Ryan Erwin, considered one of the state's top GOP operatives.

Sen. Marco Rubio enlisted Lt. Gov. Mark Hutchison to serve as his state director in May. Hutchison, a member of the Church of the Latter Day Saints, has helped Rubio make a serious play for the Mormon voting bloc in a state with a relatively high Mormon population.

The Paul campaign is still coming together, said Richard Bunce, an activist who coordinated Rep. Ron Paul's Nevada operation in previous cycles. "He pulls in standing-room-only crowds in Nevada, so he's a headliner person," Bunce said. "He isn't going to be a part of the machine, which is what the event was, and so that was not his crowd."

However, the mere fact that Paul's effort is still taking shape in a state that was expected to be a stronghold is itself revealing – and his rivals have taken notice.

Title: Christians Fleeing Islamic World in Record Numbers, Persecution and Extremism on the Rise

Article:

A mass exodus of Christians is currently underway across the Islamic world, with millions displaced from one end of the region to the other. The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom has reported that the flight of Christians is unprecedented and increasing year by year, with the possibility that Christians may disappear altogether from Iraq, Afghanistan, and Egypt in our lifetime.

Reports from the Islamic world confirm this conclusion. In Iraq, the Christian population has dwindled from over one million in 2003 to fewer than 400,000 today, the result of an anti-Christian campaign that began with the U.S. occupation of Iraq. The 2010 Baghdad church attack, which saw nearly 60 Christian worshippers slaughtered, is just one example of the decade-long pattern of persecution.

In Syria, entire regions and towns where Christians lived for centuries before Islam came into being have been emptied, with Christians targeted for kidnapping, plundering, and beheadings. In October 2012, the last Christian in the city of Homs, which had a Christian population of 80,000 before jihadis arrived, was murdered.

In Egypt, some 100,000 Christian Copts have fled their homeland since the "Arab Spring," with the Sinai's small Christian community attacked and evicted by Al Qaeda-linked Muslims in September 2012. In Mali, after an Islamic coup in 2012, as many as 200,000 Christians fled, with reports of house-to-house searches for Christians, churches and other Christian property looted or destroyed, and people tortured into revealing Christian relatives.

Even in European countries with Muslim majorities, such as Bosnia and Ethiopia, Christians are fleeing in large numbers. In Bosnia, only 440,000 Catholics remain, half the pre-war figure, with problems cited including a lack of building permits for Christian churches and a rise in radicalism. In Ethiopia, thousands of Christians were forced to flee after a Christian was accused of desecrating a Koran, with Muslim extremists setting fire to roughly 50 churches and dozens of Christian homes.

In Libya, Islamic rebels forced several Christian religious orders to flee, while in the Ivory Coast, Islamic rebels massacred hundreds and displaced tens of thousands of Christians. The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom has documented these and other cases of Christian persecution in its report, "Crucified Again: Exposing Islam's New War on Christians."

These reports paint a disturbing picture of Christian persecution and extremism on the rise across the Islamic world, with Christians fleeing in record numbers.

Title: Former Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner's Allegations Bring Focus to Obama Administration Lies

Article:

Former Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner has sparked controversy with his recent memoir, which revealed a 2009 prep session with senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer, where Geithner was asked to suggest that Social Security was operating in the black, despite the government's own data showing a significant deficit. Geithner declined the request, stating that he believed the government's math was inaccurate and that he couldn't deceive the public.

This incident has brought to light the Obama administration's history of alleged deception, including claims about ObamaCare, NSA spying, Benghazi, and the president's own statements about transparency and the rule of law. While government officials can legally lie, the consequences are often limited to being voted out of office.

The article highlights Geithner's views on government intervention in the economy, stating that he believes aggressive government intervention leads to a stronger financial system, whereas those who support the free market argue that it is the only moral system of financial exchanges, as every exchange is voluntary. The article also touches on the 2008 recession, which was caused by the bursting of the housing bubble, induced by the government's artificially low interest rates and the actions of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

The article presents a neutral and factual account of Geithner's allegations and the Obama administration's history of alleged deception, without taking a stance or expressing personal opinions.

Title: Former Attorney General Weighs In on Hillary Clinton's Email Server: A Comparison to Petraeus' Case Falls Flat

Article:

Former Attorney General Michael Mukasey recently drew a comparison between Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State and former CIA Director David Petraeus' federal conviction for the unauthorized removal and retention of classified information. However, Anne M. Tompkins, a former U.S. attorney for the Western District of North Carolina, disputes this comparison, citing key differences between the two cases.

Tompkins, who oversaw the prosecution of Petraeus, notes that the key element distinguishing Petraeus' case from Clinton's is that Petraeus knowingly engaged in unlawful conduct. Petraeus, as commander of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan, recorded handwritten notes in personal journals containing top-secret and sensitive national defense information, including identities of covert officers, war strategy, and diplomatic discussions. He failed to mark the journals as "top secret" and store them in a secured facility, instead allowing his biographer to take possession of the journals.

In contrast, Clinton's email retention practices are not being investigated for knowingly sending or receiving classified materials improperly. The State Department has confirmed that none of the information on Clinton's server was classified at the time it was sent or received, and the Justice Department has stated that its inquiry is not a criminal one and that Clinton is not the subject of the inquiry.

Tompkins emphasizes that Petraeus' conduct was done "knowingly," meaning he was aware that the information in his journals was classified and stored them improperly. In contrast, Clinton's decision to use a private server has been criticized, but there is no evidence of criminal conduct.

While reasonable minds may differ on the wisdom of using a private server for official business, Tompkins concludes that the comparison between Clinton's email server and Petraeus' case falls flat due to the significant differences between the two situations.

Title: Major Issues Remain Unaddressed After Election, Regardless of Winner

The upcoming election on Tuesday may not bring the resolution many are hoping for. In fact, the United States faces at least three major issues that will persist regardless of who takes office in January. These issues include the country's economic growth, foreign policy, and the erosion of trust in government and politics.

The U.S. has been experiencing an economic expansion for seven years, but the average rate of growth since 2009 has been around 2 percent, making it the weakest recovery since 1949. Economic growth is crucial for improving wealth and standards of living, as well as addressing issues like trade, immigration, and welfare. However, neither Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump has presented a plan to stimulate economic growth.

Clinton's proposed policies, such as increasing taxes and spending, are unlikely to boost the economy, while Trump's plan to add $5 trillion to the national debt could further dampen growth. If the economy does not improve, it is unlikely that other issues will be resolved.

In terms of foreign policy, neither candidate has articulated a plan to stabilize the U.S. economy, reduce international terrorism, or bring order to hotspots in the Middle East, Eastern Europe, or Asia. The world is a complex and challenging place, and it is unclear how either candidate would address these issues.

Trust in major American institutions, including the media, religious organizations, labor, and business, is at or near historic lows. This skepticism is particularly evident among millennials, who are the largest and most skeptical generation. The Iraq War was sold on bad information and prosecuted poorly, and the government's handling of healthcare reform and surveillance have further eroded trust.

Neither Clinton nor Trump has addressed the massive and ongoing evacuation of trust and confidence in government and politics. Instead, they may exacerbate the problem by nominating candidates who are distrusted by majorities of Americans. Until the major parties start governing in the light of day and nominating candidates who are trusted by the majority, it is unlikely that significant change will occur.

Title: California's Homelessness Problem Continues to Grow, Outpacing National Trend

Article:

The latest data from the federal government shows that the homeless population in the United States is growing again, with a 15,000-person increase to approximately 568,000 people, a 2.7% increase. However, California is responsible for the majority of this growth, with a staggering 21,000-person increase to over 150,000 people, a 16.4% increase. This surge in homelessness in California is enough to overwhelm declines in 29 other states, including Washington, Hawaii, and Massachusetts.

California's homelessness problem is particularly concerning, with the state having the worst housing shortage on the U.S. mainland. Despite this, the state's Legislature and local governments have shown resistance to addressing the issue. The state's population growth has slowed to a trickle, with Marin, Sonoma, Napa, and Santa Cruz counties among those that lost population.

According to HUD Secretary Ben Carson, "homelessness in California is at a crisis level and needs to be addressed by local and state leaders with crisis-like urgency." While the Trump administration has threatened a crackdown on the state's homeless population, California officials have been skeptical of their advice.

The relationship between housing scarcity and homelessness has been extensively studied, and experts agree that a comprehensive approach is needed to address the issue. The California Legislature has not passed a significant measure to expedite residential development since 2017, and the San Francisco Board of Supervisors has repeatedly shelved the most significant measure in play, SB50.

The article concludes that the state's rampant homelessness calls for reform on the order of the right-to-shelter policy backed by the leaders of Governor Gavin Newsom's task force on the issue, although Newsom himself has not yet supported this approach. Anything less will enable more demagoguery and suffering.

Title: Americans Donate Stimulus Checks to Those in Need Amid Pandemic

As the United States grapples with the economic fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic, many Americans are receiving stimulus checks from the government. While some are using the money to cover basic expenses, others are choosing to donate a portion or all of their checks to those in need.

Brooke Young, a 39-year-old librarian in Salt Lake City, donated $200 of her $1,200 stimulus check to a mutual aid group, a group helping laid-off restaurant workers, the Salt Lake City Tribune, and the local alternative weekly newspaper. Young, who is financially secure, felt it was the least she could do given the struggles many others are facing.

Toi Cudworth, a 55-year-old credit union employee in Texas, donated $950 to the San Antonio Food Bank after seeing reports of long lines of people waiting for food. She also bought groceries for a neighbor who recently lost his job and will give some money to an elderly couple.

In Sacramento, California, Laine Himmelmann, a 32-year-old fundraiser for Habitat for Humanity, donated $100 to the organization and plans to give another $250 when she receives her stimulus payment. Himmelmann believes her donation will be put to "efficient and good use" in helping low-income families access affordable housing.

Some nonprofits and grassroots groups are actively soliciting stimulus check donations. Cosecha, a national group helping undocumented immigrants, received over $40,000 in pledged donations from stimulus checks. Nail salon workers in New York, teachers in Philadelphia, and small businesses in Seattle are also encouraging people to donate their stimulus checks.

In Maine, Wendy Blackwell-Moore, a consultant and married mother of two, teamed up with a state legislator and a pastor to create the Pledge My Stimulus online campaign, which has signed up 66 people who have promised to donate to various causes across the country.

While some people are choosing to keep their stimulus checks, others are donating theirs to those in need. Adam Markowitz, a Florida tax preparer, has received over 20 inquiries from clients about the stimulus money, with some wanting to know if they can refuse the payment.

Title: Missouri Reopens Amidst Uncertainty and Concerns Over COVID-19

Missouri's Republican Governor, Mike Parson, has lifted restrictions on businesses and social gatherings, despite the state recording its largest increase in coronavirus cases. However, many residents and business owners remain skeptical about the decision, citing concerns over a potential resurgence of the virus.

In the town of Liberty, only a few businesses reopened, with many residents choosing to remain cautious. Tara Brendle, owner of Brendle's barber shop, decided to reopen with precautions, including sanitizing equipment and requiring customers to wait outside before entering. She expressed concerns about the potential impact on her customers, particularly her parents and children.

Some residents, like Lyle Hoover, welcomed the reopening, but others, like Brendle, are worried about the potential consequences. "I'm not as worried about myself as I am about other people like my parents and kids," she said.

Governor Parson's decision to lift restrictions is part of his "Show Me Strong" recovery plan, which relies heavily on testing and access to protective equipment. However, many residents are skeptical about the plan's effectiveness, citing limited resources and a lack of organization.

The governor's decision to tour an electrical contractor and a hunting and fishing store without wearing a face mask, as recommended by federal health officials, has also raised concerns. "I chose not to wear one," he said. "I don't think it's the government's role to mandate who wears one."

The decision has also sparked pushback from mayors of Missouri's two largest cities, St. Louis and Kansas City, which have kept restrictions in place. Kansas City's mayor, Quinton Lucas, plans to limit seating to 10% capacity or 10 people, including employees, when restaurants reopen.

Hammerhand Coffee, a cafe in Liberty, decided not to reopen its doors to customers, citing county guidelines that allow only six people, including staff, to be present. The cafe's owner, Lucas Bell, expressed uncertainty about the decision to reopen, saying, "I don't know if the governor knows what he's talking about."

The uncertainty is reflected around Liberty's main square, where most businesses remained closed. The florists, boutiques, and jewelers were all still shut, and Hueys on the Square restaurant was open with some tables marked "no seating" to keep patrons six feet apart.

Title: Turkish Authorities Close to Identifying Gunman Responsible for Istanbul Nightclub Attack

The Turkish Deputy Prime Minister, Numan Kurtulmus, has announced that authorities have obtained the fingerprints and a general description of the gunman responsible for the New Year's mass shooting at an Istanbul nightclub. Investigators are reportedly close to identifying the suspect.

The attack, which occurred on January 1st, left 39 people dead, including 27 foreigners, and 69 others wounded. The gunman, who arrived at the popular nightclub by taxi, unleashed his mayhem of terror within seven minutes, spraying bullets and causing chaos. The brutal assault resulted in the deaths of 39 people, including 27 foreigners, and injured 69 others.

The State Department confirmed that American Jake Raak, from Delaware, was the only U.S. citizen wounded in the attack. Raak, who was shot in the hip, said he survived by playing dead and remaining silent and still after being shot. He told NBC News that he was shot when he was already on the ground and the gunman was shooting people he had already shot.

The attack occurred when around 600 people were celebrating the New Year inside the venue. The gunman, reportedly shouting "Allahu Akbar," began firing at will, causing panic and chaos. A security camera captured the scene, showing bullets grazing the bar's railing and a man in red trying to escape, but being trapped as the killer approaches and fires a single shot from his AK-47.

Eyewitness Komron Saidaliev described the scene as "terrible," saying people were falling down due to the shooting. ISIS, which claimed responsibility for the attack, described it as a "heroic soldier of the caliphate" who targeted the nightclub, a symbol of "secular decadence," in revenge for God's religion and in response to the orders of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

Turkey, a NATO ally, has witnessed 18 major terror attacks on its soil since 2015, with the January 1st attack being the 19th.

Title: Trump Administration's "Domestic Gag Rule" on Abortion Services Faces Legal Challenges

The Trump administration's final rule, known as the "domestic gag rule," bars clinics that provide or refer patients for abortions from receiving federal family planning funds. The rule, which was first proposed last year, was met with swift legal challenges from state officials and reproductive rights groups. On July 3, the US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit issued a preliminary injunction blocking the rule from taking effect while legal challenges continue.

The rule, which is also known as the "domestic gag rule," prohibits Planned Parenthood and any other provider that performs abortions or offers abortion referrals from receiving funding under Title X, which provides birth control and other family planning services for low-income patients. Anti-abortion groups have long backed such a rule, arguing that organizations that provide abortion should not receive federal support.

However, Planned Parenthood and other groups argue that the rule will leave low-income patients without access to healthcare they need. According to Planned Parenthood, it sees about 41% of patients who get family planning services under Title X. The rule would require providers that receive Title X funds to be both physically and financially separate from any entity that provides or refers for abortions.

The rule has been met with legal challenges from Planned Parenthood, the American Medical Association, the National Family Planning & Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA), the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), and several states. The challengers argue that the rule is illegal, as it violates laws requiring that pregnant patients receiving care through Title X get unbiased counseling about all of their options, which include abortion.

The move to restrict Title X funds is one of several actions by the Trump administration that critics say will limit access to contraception and abortion. The rule is also seen as part of a broader strategy by the administration to restrict reproductive rights and challenge the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision Roe v. Wade.

The rule's opponents argue that it will leave many low-income patients without access to contraceptive care and that it is illegal. The rule's supporters, on the other hand, argue that it will prevent taxpayer dollars from being used to support abortion services.

The legal battle over the rule is ongoing, with the Ninth Circuit's preliminary injunction blocking the rule from taking effect while legal challenges continue. The outcome of the case will have significant implications for low-income patients and the reproductive healthcare system in the United States.

Title: Former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Calls for Elimination of Filibuster in the US Senate

Former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has called for the elimination of the legislative filibuster in the US Senate, stating that it has become an "unworkable legislative graveyard." In a piece published in The New York Times, Reid argued that the filibuster has been used excessively by Republicans over the past decade, stifling progress on important issues such as climate change, immigration, and gun control.

Reid, a Nevada Democrat, urged the Senate to abandon the filibuster in all its forms and called on Democratic presidential candidates to do the same. He believes that a simple majority vote should be sufficient for legislation, rather than the current 60-vote threshold required. Reid noted that his own party had previously used a rules change in 2013 to end the filibuster for many presidential nominees, and that Republicans had done the same for Supreme Court nominees in 2017.

Some Democratic activists share Reid's view, arguing that supporting the filibuster would hinder progress on key issues like healthcare and climate change. While some 2020 presidential contenders have called for the filibuster's abolition, others, such as former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, have been more hesitant.

Reid's call to eliminate the filibuster is the latest development in the ongoing debate over the role of the legislative filibuster in the US Senate. The issue is likely to remain a topic of discussion as the 2020 presidential election approaches.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Tight Deadline to Qualify for October Debate

The Democratic National Committee has announced that today is the last day for presidential candidates to qualify for the October 15 debate. While it appears unlikely that there will be any last-minute drama, the stage is set to feature a record 12 candidates, the most participants ever in a single presidential primary debate.

As of October 1, 12 candidates have qualified for the October debate, with Rep. Tulsi Gabbard being the 12th and likely the last candidate to make the cut. Marianne Williamson, the next candidate in line, still needs three more qualifying polls to join the stage.

The qualifying criteria for the October debate require candidates to reach 2% support in at least four national or early-state polls from qualifying polling organizations and collect contributions from at least 130,000 unique donors, including at least 400 donors in at least 20 states.

For the November debate, the qualifying criteria become even stricter, requiring candidates to reach 3% support in at least four national or early-state polls or 5% support in at least two early-state polls from qualifying polling organizations, as well as contributions from at least 165,000 unique donors, including at least 600 donors in at least 20 states.

The article highlights the challenges faced by middle-tier candidates, who need to rack up more qualifying polls to make the stage. Some candidates, such as Andrew Yang and Tom Steyer, are close to qualifying, while others, like Amy Klobuchar and Beto O'Rourke, still need more polls. The article also notes that some candidates, like Gabbard and Julián Castro, have cleared the donor threshold but still need qualifying polls.

The article concludes by noting that qualifying won't be easy for middle-tier candidates, but some still have a chance to make the stage. It also speculates that some candidates may drop out of the race if they fail to qualify for the November debate.

Title: Campaign Finance Ruling's Impact on Political Spending

The 2010 Supreme Court decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission (FEC) has been widely criticized by Democrats as a significant factor in the surge of money in politics. However, its effects have been less profound than often portrayed. The ruling loosened the conditions under which corporations and unions can back candidates, but organizations like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce could previously use undisclosed donations to influence elections under the guise of "issue advocacy."

The Citizens United decision was cited in a separate 2010 Supreme Court ruling, SpeechNow.org v. FEC, which allowed individuals to pool unlimited donations in political committees operating independently of candidates. Wealthy individuals like Sheldon Adelson have been able to spend unlimited sums on their own campaign advocacy since the 1976 Buckley v. Valeo ruling.

While some argue that Citizens United is an effective rhetorical tool for opponents of the decision, others believe it played a significant role in the creation of super PACs. Representative Chris Van Hollen, a Maryland Democrat, claims the 2010 decision "changed the psychology" of campaign finance, producing an "anything-goes atmosphere."

However, the largest sums have been raised through the regulated system, which drives the campaign schedules of candidates like President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney. Obama's 2008 campaign raised $745 million, while his opponent John McCain's campaign was limited to $84 million under the public financing system.

The public financing system had already eroded due to taxpayer reluctance and the increasing ability of candidates to raise large sums through the internet and other means. The system "didn't have to be pushed very hard" to collapse, said Robert Bauer, Obama's campaign lawyer.

Some effects of the Supreme Court's recent rulings may become apparent later. The combination of Citizens United and SpeechNow cases allowed corporations and individuals to donate to super PACs. Disclosures indicate that privately held corporations have taken advantage of this, but publicly traded companies have not. Jan Baran, a Republican campaign finance lawyer, noted that executives of Fortune 500 companies are cautious about funding super PACs, but this may change by November.

In addition to blaming Citizens United, some critics blame President Obama for not pushing for a change to the system. However, others argue that the system is flawed and will continue to produce widespread corruption unless addressed.

Title: US Government Transfers $400 Million to Iran, Raising Concerns Over Hostage Risks

The US government has transferred $400 million to Iran, as part of a $1.7 billion settlement to resolve a failed 1979 arms deal. The cash, consisting of euros, Swiss francs, and other currencies, was flown to Iran in January, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. The transfer has sparked concerns among Republican lawmakers that it may have put more Americans at risk of being taken hostage.

The settlement was reached by the Obama administration to resolve a dispute over the failed arms deal, which dates back to just before the Iranian Revolution. The four detained Americans released by Iran, including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, Amir Hekmati, a former US Marine, Christian pastor Saeed Abedini, and Nosratollah Khosravi-Roodsari, had been held captive for years.

State Department spokesman John Kirby denied any suggestion that the cash transfer was tied to the release of the Americans, stating that it was an entirely separate track and "utterly false" to imply a connection. Kirby explained that the funds were part of a long-standing claim at the US-Iran Claims Tribunal at The Hague and that it made no sense to continue dragging out the claim.

However, The Wall Street Journal reported that Iranian negotiators on the prisoner exchange said they wanted the cash to show they had gained something tangible. The Journal also noted that President Obama did not disclose the $400 million cash payment when he announced the resolution of the arms deal dispute.

Republican lawmakers, including Senator Mark Kirk and House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Ed Royce, have expressed concerns that the cash transfer has put more Americans at risk of being taken hostage. Royce stated that "paying ransom to kidnappers puts Americans even more at risk" and that the White House's policy of appeasement has led Iran to illegally seize more American hostages.

Since the cash was airlifted, Iran's Revolutionary Guard has arrested two more Iranian-Americans, and Tehran has detained dual-nationals from France, Canada, and the UK in recent months. The State Department has not disclosed how the $1.7 billion was paid, except to say it was not paid in dollars.

Title: Federal Judge Allows Lawsuit Against Trump Over Emoluments Clause to Proceed

A federal judge in Maryland has ruled that a lawsuit alleging President Donald Trump is violating the emoluments clause of the U.S. Constitution by benefiting from profits made at the Trump International Hotel in Washington D.C. can move forward. The lawsuit was brought by the attorneys general of Washington D.C. and Maryland in June 2017.

The attorneys general argue that Trump is violating the emoluments clause, which bars elected officials from receiving benefits from foreign governments without Congress' approval. The lawsuit alleges that businesses in D.C. and Maryland are hurt because organizations are choosing the Trump hotel over other area hotels to curry favor with the president. For example, Saudi Arabia spent thousands of dollars at the Trump International Hotel between October 2016 and March 2017, according to the complaint.

In February, the Trump Organization announced it had donated foreign earnings from its hotels to the Treasury Department, but the Maryland judge said in his ruling that those calculations have not been verified or provided to the court. A similar lawsuit against Trump brought by a liberal watchdog group was dismissed by a federal judge in New York last year for lack of standing.
