The judge in Maryland has decided that the states do have standing in this case.

Judge Peter Messitte ruled that the plaintiffs have sufficiently alleged that the President is violating the Foreign and Domestic Emoluments Clauses of the Constitution by reason of his involvement with and receipt of benefits from the Trump International Hotel and its appurtenances in Washington, D.C., as well as the operations of the Trump Organization with respect to the same. Trump was summoned in the Maryland case last week, and his lawyers now have three weeks to respond.

Title: Clinton Maintains Fundraising Lead Over Trump in Final Pre-Election Reports

Article:

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign and joint accounts with Democrats had $153 million in the bank as of last week, according to new fundraising reports. This is more than double the $68 million held by Donald Trump's campaign and partnership committees. Clinton's continued fundraising advantage ensures she can maintain her sprawling political operation at full strength in the final days of the race.

Clinton's campaign has hauled in $513 million over the course of the primary and general elections, roughly double what Trump's campaign has raised. In the first 19 days of October, Clinton's campaign reaped $53 million, while Trump's brought in about $30 million. Trump, a New York businessman who claims to be worth $10 billion, typically makes a personal contribution of about $2 million each month, but had not done so yet in October. The latest contribution reports show he had given only about $33,000.

Outside groups backing Clinton are better funded than those supporting Trump, according to the reports. Priorities USA, a super PAC supporting Clinton, raised $18 million in 19 days, with some of its biggest donors including Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz and Susan Mandel, the wife of a hedge fund founder, who each contributed $2.5 million this month. Priorities USA plans to spend $21 million on TV ads this week and next, according to Kantar Media's political ad tracker.

Rebuilding America Now, one of several pro-Trump groups, raised only about $215,000 through the early part of this month. As of last week, the super PAC had about $1.2 million in cash on hand. Another pro-Trump group, Great America PAC, raised $2 million and had about as much left to spend.

Title: Thousands of Migrants Head to US-Mexico Border, Trump Threatens to Close Southern Border

A large group of mostly Honduran refugees, estimated to be in the thousands, has crossed into Guatemala, with the intention of reaching the US-Mexico border. The migrants, who are mostly families with small children, are seeking asylum in the United States. Mexico has increased security along its southern border and has stated that only migrants with valid paperwork, including a passport, will be allowed to enter the country.

The Mexican government has announced that it will ask the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for support as it prepares to receive possibly thousands of refugee requests in the coming days. The Mexican government has also warned that migrants caught crossing illegally will be detained and deported.

US President Donald Trump has responded to the situation by threatening to close the entire US-Mexico border to prevent the migrants from entering. "I will call up the U.S. Military and CLOSE OUR SOUTHERN BORDER!" he tweeted. This is not the first time Trump has taken a hardline stance on immigration, as he previously threatened to cut foreign aid to Honduras and send the military to the border when an earlier caravan of Central Americans made their way through Mexico.

It is unclear how Trump would block the current group of immigrants from crossing at a legal port of entry. Longstanding federal and international laws allow immigrants to present themselves at a border crossing and seek protection as refugees. They are referred for a "credible fear" of persecution or torture screening to an asylum officer, who decides if they should be deported or continue the asylum process.

The Department of Homeland Security is compiling year-end figures for apprehensions at the southern border, which are expected to show "record numbers of families arriving illegally in the United States this year." While thousands of immigrant families are being arrested at the border every week, the numbers are still far below the peak in 2000, when 1.6 million unauthorized immigrants were arrested. The current surge is primarily made up of families seeking amnesty, which allows them to remain in the US for months or years while their case grinds through the backlogged immigration courts.

Title: The Worst Campaigns of 2014: Braley, Cantor, and Davis Struggle to Make an Impact

The 2014 election season has seen its fair share of ups and downs, with some campaigns struggling to gain traction and others faltering under the weight of controversy. Three notable examples of campaigns that have failed to impress are those of Democratic congressman Bruce Braley, Republican Eric Cantor, and Democratic state senator Wendy Davis.

Bruce Braley, a Democratic congressman and Iowa Senate hopeful, has made a series of high-profile gaffes that have damaged his campaign. In a radio interview, he complained about the impact of the government shutdown on the House gym, saying "There's hardly anybody working down there. There's no towel service, we're doing our own laundry down there." He also described Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley as "a farmer from Iowa who never went to law school, never practiced law," a remark that was widely criticized. Additionally, Braley was caught on video appearing to say he's a farmer, despite having no evidence to support this claim.

Eric Cantor, a Republican congressman, ran a lackadaisical and messy campaign against Dave Brat, a college professor, in Virginia's 7th congressional district. Cantor ignored key conservative groups and spent little time campaigning in the district, ultimately losing the primary election. His biggest mistake may have been running a series of hard-hitting TV ads attacking Brat by name, which provided critical name ID with voters who had never heard of him.

Wendy Davis, a Democratic state senator, was hailed as a potential game-changer in Texas politics after her June 2013 filibuster against a restrictive anti-abortion measure in the Texas Legislature. However, her campaign for Texas governor has been marred by inconsistencies in her life story and a weaker-than-expected showing against an obscure and underfunded primary opponent. She has struggled to demonstrate that she is focused on more than just abortion rights, and a recent New York Times poll showed her trailing Republican state Attorney General Greg Abbott by double digits.

These three campaigns serve as cautionary tales for politicians and their teams, highlighting the importance of careful messaging, effective communication, and a strong understanding of the issues and concerns of voters.

Title: Biden's Union Support in Philadelphia Faces Scrutiny Amid Fossil Fuel Industry Concerns

Philadelphia, Pennsylvania - Democrat Joe Biden's presidential campaign has been criticized by some union leaders and workers in Philadelphia, a city that is home to his campaign headquarters and a key battleground state in the 2020 election. The concerns stem from Biden's support for phasing out the fossil fuel industry, which has led to questions about his loyalty to union workers who rely on the industry for jobs.

The Philadelphia Energy Solutions refinery, the largest and oldest on the U.S. East Coast, closed its doors in August, idling over 1,000 employees, including 650 union workers. The refinery's closure has left many workers without jobs and without severance pay or extended health benefits. Top executives collected $4.5 million in retention bonuses just weeks before the company filed for bankruptcy in July.

Some union leaders and workers have questioned Biden's commitment to the working class, citing his silence on the refinery's closure and his support for phasing out the fossil fuel industry. Ryan O'Callaghan, the former union head of a now-shuttered Philadelphia refinery, said, "I think Biden has taken our votes for granted. Our plant closed and we didn't hear from him."

Biden's campaign has not directly responded to the criticism, but has noted his history of supporting labor and his clean energy plan, which calls for replacing oil industry jobs with well-paying, green-energy jobs. The campaign has also highlighted Biden's support for the United Association of Firefighters, one of the nation's largest unions, and his opposition to Republican-led efforts to limit union participation.

The United Food and Commercial Workers 1776 Keystone State, with some 35,000 members in Pennsylvania, has endorsed Biden, citing his long history of supporting labor. However, other unions are unlikely to rush to endorse a candidate, with some expressing concerns about Biden's stance on the fossil fuel industry.

The criticism from workers in Biden's own backyard underscores his challenges in balancing his support for labor with his push for environmental policies. Terry Madonna, a political scientist at Franklin & Marshall University, said Biden needs to walk a finer line than some of his progressive rivals who can offer a full-throated endorsement on a range of policies without fear of angering moderates. "Right now, he's trapped between his historical support for the unions on issues of energy and the left wing of his party on environmental issues who are pushing for a Green New Deal, and he's needs them both," Madonna said.

Title: Westerners Joining ISIS: A Smaller Threat Than Expected

The article discusses the phenomenon of Westerners joining the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq and Syria, with around 100 Americans and over 1,000 Europeans having done so. While this may seem alarming, experts suggest that the risk of these individuals returning to their home countries to plot attacks is lower than expected.

According to Thomas Hegghammer, director of the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, only about 1 in 9 Western jihadis who fought in a foreign war have come home to plot attacks. This estimate comes from a low-end estimate of the total number of foreign fighters, and the actual ratio of those returning to attempt an attack in the West is likely between 1 in 20 and 1 in 100.

To date, there have been about 4-6 plots involving 5-10 people in the West, out of 2,000-3,000 volunteers, making the blowback rate one in several hundred. This is a vanishingly small number.

Experts attribute the low return rate to ISIS's focus on preserving the caliphate rather than plotting attacks on the West. Additionally, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq are not yet over, and when they do conclude, Western volunteers may become more likely to return home and stir up trouble.

However, even when that happens, the risk is still relatively low. Will McCants, director of the Project on US Relations with the Islamic World at the Brookings Institution, notes that it's much easier to identify ISIS volunteers on their way home than on their way to Syria or Iraq. Once they've gone in, US intelligence is likely to find them.

The Atlantic Ocean is also a significant barrier, as airports have robust systems for detecting returning fighters, making it difficult for ISIS veterans to return to the United States without being detected. Europe is at greater risk, but even there, the risk is not huge.

Experts agree that it's hard to stay off the grid, and any terrorists trying to plan a major attack will likely need to communicate with family and friends or other militants, making it easier for intelligence agencies to intercept their communications. The 9/11 attacks, which took years to plan and execute, are a rare exception, and experts are not too concerned about the threat posed by ISIS.

Title: Obama Visits Colorado to Push for Federal Gun Control Measures

Article:

President Barack Obama visited Colorado on Wednesday to promote federal gun control measures, specifically highlighting the state's recent passage of bills requiring background checks for all gun purchases and limiting the size of ammunition magazines. The president is seeking to build momentum for similar measures nationwide, but his efforts face strong opposition from the gun lobby.

Colorado's recent experience serves as both an inspiration and a cautionary tale for Obama. The state's lawmakers responded to the Aurora movie theater shooting, which killed 12 and wounded nearly 60, by passing new gun control laws. However, the state's gun owners, such as Dudley Brown, head of Rocky Mountain Gun Owners, are strongly opposed to these measures, citing concerns about government overreach and infringement on their Second Amendment rights.

State Representative Rhonda Fields, who represents the Aurora neighborhood where the shooting occurred, has become an advocate for gun control after her own son was shot and killed in a separate incident. She believes that the recent laws are necessary for public safety and is willing to face political backlash for her stance.

Obama has warned that even with strong public support for universal background checks and other gun control measures, there is powerful opposition from the gun lobby. This opposition has already had an impact in Washington, where universal background checks face an uphill battle. Despite this, Fields remains committed to her cause, saying she has "no regrets" about the decision to support the new laws.

The visit to Colorado is part of Obama's effort to build momentum for federal gun control measures, which he believes are necessary to save lives. However, the strong opposition from gun owners and the gun lobby will likely continue to be a significant challenge for the president and Congress.

**US Navy Destroyer and Oil Tanker Collide Near Singapore, Multiple Sailors Missing and Injured**

A collision between the US Navy's guided missile destroyer USS John S. McCain and an oil tanker, Alnic MC, occurred on Monday morning, resulting in multiple sailors missing and injured. The incident occurred east of the Strait of Singapore, as the USS John S. McCain was preparing to make a routine port stop in Singapore.

According to the US Navy, four of the injured sailors have non-life-threatening injuries and were medically evacuated to a Singapore hospital. The fifth person did not require further medical attention. The USS John S. McCain sustained damage to its port side, while the Alnic MC sustained damage to a tank near the front of the ship.

Search and rescue operations are currently underway, with US military helicopters, the Singaporean and Malaysian navies, and coast guards involved. The Malaysian Navy has sent a message to fishing vessels along the Johor and Pahang coasts to keep a lookout for missing sailors.

The USS John S. McCain has arrived at Singapore's Changi naval base, where it will undergo repairs. The Alnic MC is heading to the Raffles Reserved Anchorage in Singapore. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore has reported no oil pollution and traffic in the Singapore Strait remains unaffected.

This incident is the second collision involving a US Navy ship in recent months, following a similar incident in June that resulted in the loss of seven US sailors. The USS John S. McCain is part of the US Navy's 7th Fleet, which has been involved in several other collisions in the past year.

Title: House Republicans Work on New Obamacare Repeal Compromise Amid Pressure to Deliver Win for President Trump

Article:

House Republicans are working on a new Obamacare repeal compromise, aiming to bridge the divide between hard-line conservatives and centrists who tanked the first attempt. The proposal, led by Rep. Thomas MacArthur, a New Jersey Republican, would shift the burden of deciding what services insurers must cover to the states. It would also allow insurers to charge healthy customers less, as long as states set up risk pools to subsidize sicker people priced out of the market.

The plan would preserve the most popular part of the 2010 Affordable Care Act, requiring insurers to cover people with pre-existing medical conditions. However, it would allow states to waive the requirement for essential health benefits, which includes services such as mental health and maternity care. Insurers would not be allowed to discriminate based on gender or age, but older people could still be charged up to five times more than young people.

The proposal is unclear whether it can win over enough holdouts to pass, as Republicans' first attempt last month ended in a failure. A Republican aide stated that lawmakers do not have legislative text of the proposal, making it difficult to determine its feasibility.

President Trump expressed optimism about the progress, saying that House Republicans could revive their plan and hold a vote either next week or shortly thereafter. "The plan gets better and better and better, and it's gotten really good," Trump said at a joint press conference with Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni.

House Republicans are under immense pressure from the White House to deliver an Obamacare repeal, a campaign vow that has not been fulfilled as Trump nears 100 days on the job. Failing a second time would be a significant blow to the party as it tries to prove it can wield all the levers of political power successfully.

Health care analysts are skeptical about the proposal, citing concerns that it could make coverage unaffordable for many older consumers and segregate high-cost consumers in coverage that would likely be inadequate unless the high-risk pools were very generously funded. "Maybe this is enough to convince the Freedom Caucus people that states can do what they want to do, but I don't see this as being very popular," said Timothy Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee University in Virginia.

The published plan does not provide much detail on the state waiver process, although it suggests waivers would be easy to obtain. The HHS secretary is supposed to approve the plan within 90 days of determining it is complete, although states "must attest that the purpose of their requested waiver is to reduce premium costs, increase the number of persons with health care coverage or advance another benefit to the public interest in the state, including the guarantee of coverage for persons with pre-existing medical conditions."

Title: Statewide Recounts in Key 2016 Battlegrounds Show Little Change in Trump's Victory

The recounts in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, and Michigan, initiated by the Green Party's Jill Stein, are proceeding, but the results are unlikely to alter the outcome of the 2016 presidential election. In Wisconsin, Trump has even gained votes compared to Hillary Clinton, while in Michigan and Pennsylvania, the recounts are facing legal and procedural hurdles.

In Wisconsin, the recount has been ongoing since last Thursday, with little change in the unofficial results. Trump won the state by 22,000 votes over Clinton, and the recount has only widened his margin by 146 votes. The Wisconsin Election Commission has finished recounting votes in 23 of the state's 72 counties, with Trump gaining 105 votes and Clinton dropping 41 votes.

In Michigan, the recount is on hold pending a federal court's decision, while in Pennsylvania, a federal lawsuit has been filed to stop the recount. The state's largest county, Wayne, is facing issues with ballot discrepancies, but experts say it will not affect the overall outcome.

The recounts are unlikely to change the outcome of the election, as the margins are too small and the recounts are not finding any significant discrepancies. "In any election, the actual change in the margin of votes is very, very low," said Drew Spencer Penrose, legal director at FairVote. "For people hoping for a change in results, I wouldn't hold my breath."

The recounts are expected to continue in Wisconsin and Michigan, with the results unlikely to alter the outcome of the election.

Title: California's Quality of Life in Free Fall: A Warning for the Nation

The recent Democratic Party convention in California saw a stark display of intolerance towards candidates who deviated from the progressive agenda. Former Governor John Hickenlooper and Representative John Delaney faced loud boos for expressing skepticism towards socialism and Medicare for all. However, amidst the fervor for liberal policies, a more pressing issue was overlooked: the state's deteriorating quality of life.

California's once-beautiful cities are now plagued by squalid tent cities and human waste on the streets. The state's population has shrunk by 2.5% since 2007, with a net loss of 1 million residents. A poll found that 53% of Californians are considering leaving the state, with 63% of millennials among them. The exodus is attributed to high taxes, out-of-control housing costs, and a rising crime rate.

The state's liberal policies, such as high taxes and environmental regulations, have driven families with children and those without a college degree out of the state. California is ranked as the second-most expensive state in the country, behind only Hawaii, and 48th in cost of doing business. Thousands of firms are leaving the state due to its unfriendly business environment.

The state's energy costs are also expected to increase due to its commitment to generating half of its electricity from renewables by 2030. This may lead to rolling blackouts and high energy costs for residents. The consequences of these policies are already being felt, with real people suffering from high prices for housing and energy, as well as diminished personal freedoms.

The warning signs are clear: California's liberal policies are driving people and businesses away. As the nation considers the Democratic Party's agenda, it would do well to take note of the Golden State's struggles and consider the potential consequences of similar policies.

Title: U.S. Senate Confirms Controversial Director for Justice Department's Criminal Division

The U.S. Senate has confirmed Brian Benczkowski as the new director of the Department of Justice's Criminal Division, with a 51-48 vote. Republican senators were joined by Democratic Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia in confirming the nomination. Benczkowski's confirmation comes despite criticism from Democrats, who raised concerns about his close ties to Alfa Bank, a Russian bank linked to President Vladimir Putin.

As a private attorney at Kirkland & Ellis, Benczkowski represented Alfa Bank in a legal matter in 2017, which led to an FBI investigation. The FBI ultimately concluded that there was no wrongdoing or misconduct by the bank, according to a 2017 article in The New York Times. Benczkowski has stated that he will recuse himself from any matters involving Alfa Bank during his first two years in the Justice Department.

Democrats have expressed concerns that Benczkowski's connection to Alfa Bank could undermine the investigation into Russian election interference by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. As head of the Justice Department's criminal division, Benczkowski will have a role in overseeing Mueller's probe and the criminal investigation into Michael Cohen, President Trump's former personal lawyer.

In May, Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee demanded that President Trump withdraw the nomination of Benczkowski, citing his continued representation of Alfa Bank during his consideration for the position. "He continued representing Alfa Bank in April and May 2017 even while he was under consideration to head the Criminal Division," they wrote in a letter. "At a time when we need the Department of Justice's Criminal Division to help uncover, prevent, and deter Russian interference in our democracy, Mr. Benczkowski's choices so far have not inspired confidence that he is the right person to lead that fight."

Attorney General Jeff Sessions praised Benczkowski's confirmation, calling him an "outstanding lawyer" with a "diverse" public service and criminal law background. "This will be the sixth senior position Brian has held at the Department, and we are fortunate to have someone with his breadth of experience and strong leadership skills willing to serve again," Sessions said.

Title: Commission on Presidential Debates' Criteria and the Control of Government

The Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) has released its 2020 debate schedule, accompanied by a recent court opinion, sparking questions about who controls our government. The CPD, operating under Federal Election Commission (FEC) regulations, sets standards for presidential debates, which have been criticized for limiting ballot access and political speech for third-party candidates.

The CPD's mission is voter education, but critics argue that it is actually a tool for the two major parties to maintain their dominance. The organization has the power to set standards that prevent third-party candidates from participating in debates, as long as it does not directly endorse or support a candidate. The CPD's board members, including those with ties to political parties, can also take positions that contradict the organization's "objective" standards.

The controversy surrounding the CPD began in 1987, when the League of Women Voters withdrew its support after discovering that the two major parties had control over questioners, audience composition, and press access. The League's president, Nancy Neuman, described these actions as "campaign-trail charades devoid of substance...that would perpetrate a fraud on the American voter."

Since the CPD's inception, only one third-party candidate, Ross Perot, has been invited to debate, and that was in 1992, at the request of the other participants. The CPD's criteria, which require participants to secure at least 15% support in selected polls, are rarely achieved by third-party candidates and are higher than the requirements for state ballot qualification or public financing.

The FEC and federal courts have dismissed complaints alleging regulatory non-compliance and violations of First Amendment rights and anti-trust laws, leaving the two major parties in control of the debates. An appeals court noted that the process is a "celebration of democracy (and national nightmare) that is a presidential election."

The CPD's activities are part of a long-standing effort by the two major parties to limit ballot access and political speech for third-party candidates. The Constitution and the Ballot Box notes that it was not until the 1912 elections that the two major parties and state legislatures began making access to the ballot more difficult for third-party candidates.

The results of their efforts are staggering, with the two major parties controlling 99.92% of all elected U.S. offices. Despite this, Gallup finds that 61% of Americans believe a third-party is needed. The two major parties rig the system, and it is clear who they represent.

**Domain Registrar Suspends Syrian Electronic Army's Account After Cyberattacks**

The Syrian Electronic Army, a hacker group, had its website taken offline by an internet body, reportedly in response to the group's claims of disrupting several major news websites, including the New York Times. The hackers claimed responsibility for redirecting internet traffic from the Times' and other websites, stating that domain name registrar Name.com had suspended their account due to a breach of contact.

The cyberattacks occurred on Tuesday, causing the Times' website to go offline for several hours. The newspaper stated that the disruption was the result of an external attack on its domain name registrar, Melbourne IT, and that it was working to fully restore service.

The hackers also vandalized the domain registration for Twitter.com, changing the contact email to "sea@.sy", an allusion to the Syrian Electronic Army's website. Twitter confirmed that it was investigating the incident.

The cyberattacks come at a time when the Obama administration is considering military action against Syria, where the administration blames the government for a deadly chemical attack on civilians. The Syrian Electronic Army has taken credit for previous attacks on media targets that it sees as sympathetic to Syria's rebels.

According to Melbourne IT's CEO, Theo Hnarakis, the security breach occurred at a major U.S.-based global reseller, where hackers launched a "spear phishing attack" to steal the log-in details of the New York Times and Twitter domains. The hackers then used the stolen credentials to access the domains and redirect traffic.

The hackers also attempted to hack into Twitter.com, but failed due to Melbourne IT's optional secondary security feature. The Times did not have this feature enabled, making it more vulnerable to the attack.

The incident highlights the importance of cybersecurity measures for media organizations and the need for vigilance against cyberattacks. As Michael Fey, a chief technology officer at McAfee, noted, "Regardless of technology or tactics deployed, we should expect to see more of these attacks."

Title: Kasich Threatens to Leave Presidential Race if He Fails to Win Ohio Primary

Republican presidential candidate John Kasich stated on Saturday that he will consider leaving the race if he does not win the primary in his home state of Ohio next month. In an interview in Nashville, Kasich said, "I will beat Donald Trump in Ohio, and that will be the beginning of a new day." He also commented, "Some of the other candidates, if they can't win their home state, they got to get out, OK? If I don't win my home state, I'll get out."

Kasich's statement was seen as a shot at rival Marco Rubio, who is trailing Trump in his home state of Florida by as much as 16 points in recent polls. The Buckeye State holds its primary on March 15.

Title: China's Trade Surplus with US Widens to Record in August

China's trade surplus with the United States widened to a record $31.05 billion in August, according to customs data released on Saturday. This development may put pressure on President Donald Trump to escalate the trade dispute between the two countries. The surplus has risen nearly 15% over the first eight months of the year, adding to tensions in the trade relationship between the world's two largest economies.

China's export growth in August moderated slightly to 9.8%, the weakest rate since March, but still above recent trends. The number missed analysts' forecasts that shipments from the world's largest exporter would rise 10.1%. Even with U.S. tariffs targeting $50 billion of Chinese exports in effect for their first full month in August, China's exports to the United States still accelerated, growing 13.2% from a year earlier.

China's imports from the United States grew only 2.7% in August, a slowdown from 11.1% in July. The world's largest trading nation got off to a strong start this year, but its economic outlook is being clouded by the rapidly escalating U.S. trade dispute and cooling domestic demand.

The U.S. has long criticized China's huge trade surplus with the United States and has demanded Beijing reduce it. Disagreements between the two major economic powers run deeper than just the trade balance and tensions remain over limits on U.S. firms' access to Chinese markets, intellectual property protection, technology transfers, and investment.

China's official export data has been surprisingly resilient so far, with growth exceeding analysts' expectations for five months in a row. However, anecdotal evidence of mounting trade damage on both sides of the Pacific is on the rise. Official and private manufacturing surveys for China show global demand for Chinese goods is clearly on the wane, with export orders shrinking for months in a row.

Policymakers have shifted their focus in recent months to improving credit conditions and shoring up business confidence. Beijing is ramping up spending on infrastructure projects to spur domestic demand and the central bank is tamping down borrowing costs and leaning on commercial banks to continue lending to struggling firms hit by trade troubles. However, such steps will take time to arrest the economy's slide, and analysts expect the government to unveil more stimulus measures if business conditions continue to deteriorate.

Title: Trump to Emphasize "America First" Policy at United Nations

Article:

United States President Donald Trump is set to address the United Nations General Assembly next week, where he will reiterate his "America First" policy and prioritize U.S. sovereignty over multilateralism. This stance has raised concerns among some world leaders and diplomats, who worry about the future of international cooperation and the erosion of trust in global institutions.

Since Trump's debut at the UN a year ago, the U.S. has withdrawn from several international agreements, including the Iran nuclear deal, the U.N. Human Rights Council, and the Paris climate agreement. The country has also cut funding for the U.N. agency that helps Palestinian refugees and sparked a trade war with China.

U.S. Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley has previewed Trump's address, stating that the U.S. will prioritize its own interests and sovereignty over multilateralism. She cited the Paris climate agreement and global talks on a migration pact as examples of agreements that the U.S. does not want to be involved in.

The Trump administration has also taken a hawkish stance on several issues, including Iran and North Korea. Trump is set to chair a UN Security Council meeting on nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction, which will allow him to address the latest developments in his efforts to get North Korea to denuclearize.

Some diplomats have expressed concern about the impact of Trump's approach on the future of multilateralism, with one senior diplomat describing the administration's approach as "if you want things to change, you've got to cause trouble." However, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has avoided personalizing the issue, stating that the erosion of trust in international organizations is a broader concern.

The UN General Assembly is expected to be a busy week, with Trump set to meet privately with the leaders of several countries, including South Korea, Egypt, France, Israel, Japan, and Britain. French President Emmanuel Macron is also scheduled to address the UN, emphasizing the importance of collective action and multilateralism.

Title: Romney's Health Care Plan: A Return to the Status Quo Ante?

Article:

Mitt Romney, a presidential candidate who has promised to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), recently hinted that his plan is to bring back the pre-ACA health care system. At a rally in Mt. Vernon, Ohio, he stated that the ACA was unnecessary for people with chronic conditions, claiming that the US had health care before Obamacare and still has it today. He also mentioned that those who are poor can receive Medicaid, a government support program for those who cannot afford insurance.

However, Romney's statement oversimplifies the situation. Prior to the ACA, millions of Americans did not have health insurance, and many still do not. According to the US Census Bureau, approximately 49 million Americans lacked health insurance last year. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that repealing the ACA would deny coverage to about 30 million Americans who would receive coverage if the reforms remained in place.

Romney's proposal to cap federal spending at 20% of GDP and boost defense spending to 4% of GDP would result in significant cuts to Medicaid, according to the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities. This would lead to an estimated 14-19 million more people joining the ranks of the uninsured.

In a meeting with the editorial board of an Ohio newspaper, The Dispatch, Romney again downplayed the importance of having insurance, stating that people without insurance can still receive emergency care. However, this is not entirely accurate. Families USA, a health care advocacy group, reported that 26,100 people between the ages of 25 and 64 died prematurely due to lack of health coverage in 2010.

Romney's plan seems to focus on providing emergency care, rather than ensuring that everyone has access to healthcare. This approach would likely shift costs from the patient to the general healthcare market, which could have significant consequences for those who are unable to afford insurance.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Sets Spending Limit at $2.6 Trillion, Defining Himself as a Libertarian-Conservative

Sen. Rand Paul, a Kentucky Republican and potential 2024 presidential candidate, outlined his stance on federal spending during a policy speech at the Ronald Reagan Library in Simi Valley, California. Paul emphasized that he is not against all government spending, but rather advocates for spending only what comes in, up to a maximum of $2.6 trillion dollars.

In his speech, Paul aimed to redefine his image as a libertarian-conservative, distancing himself from the perception that he is against all government. He highlighted his environmental efforts, stating that he spends his free time outdoors, engaging in activities such as biking, hiking, kayaking, composting, and planting trees. Paul emphasized that Republicans care about the environment, but also prioritize jobs and economic growth.

Paul also addressed the Republican Party's biggest challenge: being defined negatively by American cultural tastes and standards. He emphasized the need for Republicans to change perceptions and appeal to voters in traditionally Democratic states.

In his speech, Paul did not shy away from his philosophical heritage and worldview, identifying himself as a libertarian-conservative who believes in balancing common sense regulations with economic growth and jobs.

Title: Trade Deal Debate Heats Up as Global Warming Concerns Emerge

The debate over President Obama's quest for a free trade deal has taken a new turn, with opponents on both the right and left using the hot-button issue of global warming to sink the deal. Conservatives argue that the president will use trade negotiating powers to write a binding climate deal into any agreement, while liberal opponents claim the deal does not give the president enough power to work on trade.

The debate has led to a confusing dichotomy, with opponents on both sides of the political spectrum expressing distrust of the president. The issue will return to the Senate floor on Tuesday for a major filibuster showdown on whether to grant the president fast-track negotiating powers, or Trade Promotion Authority. The president needs these powers to conclude negotiations on a 12-nation Pacific Rim trade deal.

A coalition of Republicans and Democrats will try to rally support to pass the trade deal, saying it is critical to the U.S. positioning in the world economy. However, opponents are concerned that the deal will allow the president to impose global warming controls on the U.S. by negotiating stricter greenhouse gas emissions into a binding international agreement.

U.S. Trade Representative Michael B.G. Froman has insisted that the administration is not trying to deceive Congress, ruling out areas where Republicans fear circumvention. The administration has also added restrictions to the president's powers, including a specific prohibition on negotiating global warming or immigration deals as part of trade agreements.

Democratic trade opponents, however, say their fear is that the president will obey these restrictions and miss out on a good chance to force the U.S. to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. Hollywood has also weighed in, with actor Mark Ruffalo calling the restriction on global warming negotiations "insidious."

The trade package has been on weak legislative ground for weeks, surviving an early vote in the Senate but seeming to have gone down to defeat in the House. The Senate will vote on Tuesday on heading off a filibuster of the fast-track powers bill, and then likely vote on the worker assistance legislation, which has been coupled with a popular set of trade preferences for African countries and Haiti.

Title: Obama Reflects on Affordable Care Act's Progress, Calls for Medicaid Expansion

The 44th President of the United States, Barack Obama, recently shared his thoughts on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, in an ABC News interview. In the conversation, Obama gave the law an "8" out of 10, acknowledging its progress in reducing the uninsured rate. According to Obama, 16 million people or more have gained health insurance coverage since the law's passage in 2010.

The former president also highlighted the law's cost savings, stating that its price tag has been cheaper than projected. However, he expressed disappointment that many states have not expanded the Medicaid program for low-income individuals. The Affordable Care Act requires states to extend Medicaid to those earning up to 138% of the federal poverty level, with the federal government covering 100% of the program's cost from 2014 to 2016 and 90% thereafter. However, the Supreme Court made Medicaid expansion optional, and only 28 states and the District of Columbia have opted to expand their programs.

Obama criticized the decision of some states not to expand Medicaid, calling it "stubbornness based on ideology" rather than "wise public health policy." He emphasized that expanding Medicaid would not only improve public health but also save states money in the long term.

The Affordable Care Act remains a contentious issue, with the Republican-majority Congress seeking to repeal it using a budget tool called "reconciliation." The Supreme Court is also set to rule by June on whether the administration is unlawfully providing exchange subsidies to at least 34 states that rely on the federal HealthCare.gov portal. If the subsidies are deemed unlawful, the law would be less attractive in those states, potentially giving Republicans an opportunity to push their own health reforms.

While Obama is open to making changes to the law, he has expressed opposition to Republican-led bills that would scrap its mandates or hobble its effectiveness.

Title: U.S. Military Raid on Islamic State Leader Yields Valuable Intelligence and Death of Top Spokesman

The U.S. military raid that resulted in the death of Islamic State founder Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi also yielded a trove of valuable intelligence on the militant group and its top leaders, according to defense officials. The intelligence, which includes data-storage devices and files, is expected to aid in future operations against the group.

The raid, which took place on Saturday, was carried out by U.S. Army Rangers and Delta Force teams, with U.S. warplanes providing supporting firepower. The operation resulted in the death of al-Baghdadi, who was buried at sea, similar to the treatment of al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden after his death in 2011.

Defense officials have not provided details on the 11 children and two adults taken from the al-Baghdadi compound, nor have they confirmed the number of people believed killed in the operation or whether any civilian casualties may have resulted.

The raid was part of a larger effort to disrupt and dismantle the Islamic State's leadership, with a second operation resulting in the death of the group's top spokesman, Abu al-Hassan al-Muhajir, described as the group's "kind of No. 2." The spokesman's death was announced by the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, which worked with U.S. troops to fight the Islamic State before President Trump ordered a U.S. withdrawal.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Mark Milley briefed reporters at the Pentagon on Monday, saying officials are working to declassify images of the raid and may soon release them to the public. However, many questions remain unanswered, including the fate of the 11 children and two adults taken from the compound, as well as the number of people believed killed in the operation.

The U.S. military dog that assisted troops in the raid, a Belgian Malinois, was injured and is still recovering. The dog's name has not been released due to operational security concerns.

**Iowa Democrats Scramble to Make Final Choices Ahead of Caucuses**

As the Iowa caucuses approach, Democratic presidential candidates are making a last-ditch effort to win over voters and secure a spot in the crowded field. On the eve of the contest, candidates like Bernie Sanders, Pete Buttigieg, and Joe Biden rallied supporters in Iowa, emphasizing their unique strengths and qualifications.

Sanders emphasized his campaign's energy and excitement, while Buttigieg highlighted his newcomer status and ability to bring fresh perspectives to the White House. Biden, meanwhile, emphasized his decades of Washington experience and warned against "on-the-job training."

The Iowa caucuses are expected to be unpredictable, with four candidates locked in a tight race for victory. Polls show Biden, Sanders, Warren, and Buttigieg in a close race, while others like Amy Klobuchar and Andrew Yang are also competing aggressively.

New caucus rules have added to the uncertainty, with campaigns working to set expectations before the contest. The Iowa Democratic Party will release three sets of results: who voters align with at the start of the night, who they pick after voters supporting nonviable candidates get to make a second choice, and the number of state delegate equivalents each candidate gets.

The Biden campaign is trying to lower Iowa expectations, cautioning against reading too much into Monday's results. The campaign is focused on sustaining enthusiasm and money coming out of Iowa to make it to more diverse states where they hope to draw strong support from black voters.

As voters make their final decisions, many are still undecided, with 45% of likely Democratic caucus-goers naming a first choice but saying they are open to supporting another candidate. Talking to Iowa Democrats can be dizzying, with many quickly running through what they like and what worries them about the candidates in rapid fire.

The Iowa caucuses will declare a winner based on the number of state delegates each candidate wins. The Associated Press will report all three results.

Title: Ferguson Mayor Defends Comments on Racial Tensions, Says City Has No Divide

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles has reiterated his stance on racial tensions in the city, stating that he believes there is no racial divide among the city's residents. In an interview with MSNBC's Tamron Hall, Knowles maintained his position, saying that the perspective of all residents in Ferguson is that there is no racial divide.

Knowles' comments come after the fatal shooting of unarmed African-American 18-year-old Michael Brown, which sparked widespread protests and clashes between protesters and police officers. The mayor attributed the violent incidents to a small minority of the black community, stating that the demonstrations affected only a half-mile strip of street in the city. He emphasized that the majority of African-Americans in Ferguson are going about their daily lives, visiting businesses, and participating in neighborhood watch meetings.

Knowles acknowledged criticism about the Ferguson Police Department's demographics, noting that more than 90% of the force is white, despite the city's population being 63% black. He also recognized that blacks are arrested nearly twice as much as whites, and stated that he is considering proposals to increase black applicant rates. However, he still maintained that Ferguson is a "model" for Missouri.

The mayor's comments have sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that the city's demographics and policing practices suggest otherwise. According to official statistics, 86% of all stops and 92% of all searches in 2013 were of black people.

Title: House Democrats Plan to Pass Individual Spending Bills to Pressure Republicans and White House Amid Government Shutdown

House Democrats have announced plans to start passing individual spending bills this week, starting with a bill that funds the Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The move is an attempt to pressure congressional Republicans and the White House to end the ongoing partial government shutdown.

According to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the first individual bill on the agenda is the spending bill that covers the Treasury Department and IRS. Pelosi stated that this action is necessary to ensure that American families receive their tax refunds on schedule and that the certainty of their tax returns should not be held hostage to the president's demands.

The White House has already rejected the House-passed legislation, citing concerns over border security. However, passing the bills one-by-one will allow Democrats to highlight the potential real-world effects of the partial shutdown, which has now stretched beyond two weeks.

House Democrats plan to act on three other individual bills covering funding for the departments of agriculture, interior, and transportation, among other programs. This strategy is similar to the one employed by House Republicans during the 2013 government shutdown, when they rolled out smaller, piecemeal bills to re-open shuttered national parks and other programs.

In 2013, then-Sen. Harry Reid, the majority leader, refused to take up individual bills, stating that lawmakers should not pick and choose individual departments and that the entire government should be re-opened. When asked why Democrats wouldn't take up a bill to fund the National Institutes of Health, Reid replied that he had 1,100 people at Nellis Air Force base who were sitting at home, implying that there were more pressing issues to address.

The current government shutdown has resulted in real-world consequences, including delayed tax refunds, suspended food stamps, and uncertainty for homebuyers seeking mortgages. House Democrats are urging Congress to act to prevent these consequences from continuing.

Title: Trump Says Gun Age Limit Issue "Moving Rapidly" in Courts, No Immediate Action Planned

Article:

President Donald Trump stated on Monday that the issue of raising the minimum age for buying certain guns is "moving rapidly" in the courts, but he will not take immediate action himself. In a tweet, Trump said he is "watching court cases and rulings before acting" on the "18 to 21 Age Limits" proposal. He also emphasized that states are making decisions on this issue, rather than the federal government.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) filed a federal lawsuit on Friday against gun control legislation signed by Florida Governor Rick Scott, which raises the age to buy guns in the state from 18 to 21. Licensed firearm dealers under federal law cannot sell handguns to people under 21 and cannot sell long guns to people under 18. Trump has suggested supporting raising the age for long guns to 21.

The White House announced a series of recommendations on Sunday night aimed at preventing school shootings, but did not include a proposal to raise the minimum age to buy long guns. The recommendations included a full audit and review of the FBI tip line after warnings about a student who killed 17 people at a Florida high school last month were not acted upon.

The administration reaffirmed Trump's support for congressional measures, including the Fix NICS bill, which helps local officials improve efforts to enter data into the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, and the STOP School Violence Act, which aims to improve school security and provide funding for such efforts.

Trump also reiterated his opposition to schools being designated gun-free zones, stating that "if schools are mandated to be gun-free zones, violence and danger are given an open invitation to enter." He emphasized that almost all school shootings occur in gun-free zones and that cowards will only target areas with no deterrent.

Title: US Vice President Assures Baltic States of Support Amid Russian Aggression

The United States Vice President, Mike Pence, has reaffirmed Washington's commitment to the collective defense doctrine of NATO, emphasizing the importance of a strong and united alliance in the face of potential Russian aggression. During a meeting with the presidents of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, Pence emphasized that an attack on one NATO member is an attack on all, reiterating the US's Article 5 pledge of mutual defense.

The comments come ahead of large-scale military exercises by Russia and its ally Belarus, which have raised concerns among NATO members. The US army's top general in Europe has warned that the Zapad war games could be a "Trojan horse" resulting in military equipment being left in Belarus. Russia's actions have been criticized for seeking to redraw international borders by force, undermine democracies of sovereign nations, and divide the free nations of Europe.

In response, NATO's air-policing missions will be doubled during the Russian-led Zapad exercise, according to Lithuania's President Dalia Grybauskaite. Pence is also scheduled to visit Montenegro, NATO's newest member, and Georgia, an aspiring member that fought a brief war with Russia in 2008.

Pence's comments were intended to reassure the Baltic states, which have been concerned about Russian aggression following the annexation of Crimea from Ukraine in 2014. The US Vice President's visit comes amid ongoing tensions between Russia and the West, with NATO's doctrine of collective defense serving as a key pillar of the alliance's security.

Title: Clint Eastwood's Unconventional Convention Speech Steals the Show

Clint Eastwood's surprise appearance at the Republican National Convention on Thursday night became a major talking point, overshadowing much of the usual post-convention analysis. The actor's rambling and off-color appearance sparked a blame game among Mitt Romney's top advisers, who described the speech as "strange," "weird," and "theater of the absurd."

The speech was a reminder of how fleeting a successful political moment can be and how carefully staged events can be upset by an unpredictable turn. It also suggested a slip-up inside the button-down, corporate-style headquarters of the Romney campaign in Boston.

Romney advisers trusted Eastwood, 82, so much that they did not conduct rehearsals or insist on a script or guidelines for the style or format of his remarks. For Eastwood, the convention speech was a bit part in a career that has had its political moments. He served as mayor of Carmel-by-the-Sea in California for one two-year term and was briefly considered as George Bush's running mate in 1988.

During the weeks after Romney extended the invitation, Eastwood's role in the convention lineup was kept secret. On the public schedule, his slot was listed as "to be announced." As the last night of the convention approached, planners tried to keep a lid on the story, hoping his appearance would be the good kind of surprise, not the bad kind.

Instead of reading off a teleprompter, Eastwood pretended to have a sarcasm-filled conversation with President Obama, seated by his side. He said, "What do you mean, shut up?" and "What do you want me to tell Mr. Romney?" The audience was left bewildered.

The speech threw off the schedule for Romney, who was backstage during Eastwood's remarks. Some party faithful were not impressed, grumbling that Eastwood was a waste of a prime-time slot that might have been better used to feature other speakers or the biographical video of Romney's life.

Eastwood's manager, Leonard Hirshan, said the actor was traveling and would not be available for interviews. Hirshan said he had heard a chorus of response since the speech, divided evenly between those supportive and those critical. Eastwood's next film, "Trouble with the Curve," is set for release on September 21.

Title: Congress Debates Coronavirus Relief Bill, Representative Thomas Massie Criticized for Potential Delay

The United States Congress is currently debating the third phase of its coronavirus relief effort, a $2 trillion bill aimed at providing targeted relief to individuals and businesses affected by the pandemic. The bill passed the Senate on Thursday with a vote of 96-0, a significant accomplishment after several days of contentious debate.

The disagreement centered around House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's liberal wish list, which included new environmental measures and millions of dollars in funding for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington D.C. The bill was initially intended to focus on providing relief to those in financial distress due to the coronavirus outbreak.

Representative Thomas Massie, a Republican from Kentucky, has been criticized for threatening to demand a recorded vote on the bill, which could potentially delay its passage. This move has drawn criticism from his colleagues, including Representative Ruben Gallego, who had to take a red-eye flight to return to Washington to vote on the bill.

Other lawmakers, such as Representative Dean Phillips, have also expressed frustration with Massie's actions, stating that the American people, small businesses, and healthcare workers need relief now. Representative Gil Cisneros added that taking a red-eye flight to return to Washington, "The American people, small businesses, and our healthcare workers need relief now."

The bill is currently being debated in the House, with a vote expected soon.

Title: Trump Shifts Tone in Final Republican Debate Before Crucial Primaries

In the final Republican debate before the potentially decisive round of primaries, Donald Trump toned down his usual bombastic style, opting for a more presidential posture. The billionaire businessman and current GOP frontrunner avoided insults and crude remarks, instead focusing on policy issues, albeit in generalities. Trump's performance was a departure from his previous debate, where he hawked steaks, water, and wine, and was met with a sigh of relief from Republican officials.

The debate, held in Miami, saw all four remaining candidates, including Trump, Ohio Governor John Kasich, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, and Texas Senator Ted Cruz, deliver a more subdued and dignified performance. Trump's opponents, Rubio and Kasich, also played it safe, with Rubio referencing his experiences meeting missionaries in Muslim Bangladesh and highlighting the importance of friendly Muslims in protecting them. Kasich emphasized the need for the US to work with Arab Muslim countries to defeat ISIS.

Trump's performance was marked by his continued emphasis on his anti-Islam rhetoric, stating that "I mean a lot of them" when asked about his previous comment that "I think Islam hates us." He also dodged questions on his proposed 45% tariff on Chinese goods, which economists have warned could lead to a global recession.

Despite Trump's lack of policy specifics, his supporters seem unfazed, and endorsements are now flowing to the top two contenders, with former candidate Carly Fiorina and Senator Mike Lee (R-UT) backing Senator Cruz, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson endorsing Trump. The debate's outcome may not have changed the trajectory of the Republican nomination, but it did provide a glimpse into Trump's presidential style, which prioritizes style over substance.

Title: Congress Faces Deadline to Address $85 Billion in Spending Cuts

As the deadline approaches for $85 billion in spending cuts to take effect, Congress is scrambling to find a solution. The cuts, which were triggered by the Budget Control Act of 2011, will reduce government spending by 5% across the board, affecting various government programs and services.

The White House and congressional leaders met briefly on Wednesday, but no significant progress was made on a deal to avoid or replace the cuts. The meeting was seen as a symbolic gesture, with some Republicans expressing skepticism about the president's willingness to work with Congress.

Under a Republican proposal, President Obama would be required to submit a list of alternative cuts to Congress by March 15. The plan would also limit defense cuts to $42.7 billion. Democrats, however, are pushing for a plan that would replace the cuts with more tax revenue collected from millionaires and eliminate agriculture subsidies.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell blamed each other's party for the current impasse, with Reid calling the situation a "self-inflicted wound." The two leaders are at odds over how to address the cuts, with Reid pushing for a plan that would replace the cuts with new revenue and McConnell advocating for a plan that would give the president more flexibility in deciding where to make cuts.

The White House has been on the defensive after House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte released a statement indicating that the administration has ordered the release of an unspecified number of undocumented immigrants in detention due to the looming cuts. The administration has since clarified that the released individuals are those with minor offenses or convictions and are still in removal proceedings.

The situation has sparked controversy, with some Republicans criticizing the administration's decision to release criminal immigrants onto the streets. The administration has maintained that the decision was made by career ICE employees without any White House input.

As the deadline approaches, Congress is expected to vote on a plan to replace the cuts or mitigate their impact. However, with both sides dug in and unwilling to budge, it remains unclear whether a solution will be found before the cuts take effect.

Title: House Speaker John A. Boehner Rules Out Senate Immigration Bill, House to Pursue Own Legislation

The House Speaker, John A. Boehner, has announced that the House will not pass the Senate's immigration bill, instead opting to work on its own legislation. In a joint statement with his top Republican lieutenants, Boehner emphasized that the House will "work its will and produce its own legislation" on the issue. The statement also highlighted the differences between the House and Senate approaches, with the House focusing on border security and the Senate's bill extending legal status to illegal immigrants.

The decision comes as a bipartisan group of lawmakers, known as the "Gang of Eight," is working to craft a broad immigration deal that would include legal status for illegal immigrants and a rewrite of the legal immigration system. The group announced that they had reached the outlines of a deal last week, but hit some snags and are now back on track.

The House's decision to pursue its own legislation is seen as a move to stake out a House GOP position and to tamp down some of the momentum behind the Senate bill. The bill, which emerged from the Senate Judiciary Committee, rewrites the legal immigration system and extends legal status to illegal immigrants with the promise of an eventual pathway to citizenship.

Democrats, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, have emphasized that citizenship rights are a non-negotiable part of any deal. However, Republicans are still struggling with the idea of extending legal status to illegal immigrants.

The House's decision to pursue its own legislation is seen as a way to ensure that the House has a say in the process and to avoid being seen as simply accepting the Senate's bill. The House Republican statement emphasized that "enacting policy as consequential and complex as immigration reform demands that both chambers of Congress engage in a robust debate and amendment process."

The debate over immigration reform is ongoing, with the Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, signaling that he will put the bill on the Senate floor next month. The House's decision to pursue its own legislation adds another layer of complexity to the process, but it remains to be seen whether the House and Senate can come together to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill.

Title: Republicans Concerned Mark Sanford's Baggage Could Cost Him the Election

Article:

Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina, won the Republican primary election on Tuesday, but national Republicans are not celebrating. Many privately concede that Sanford's baggage could hand a safe Republican seat to Democrat Elizabeth Colbert Busch, the sister of late-night comedian Stephen Colbert. Sanford's campaign is largely focused on seeking forgiveness for his past transgressions, which could make it difficult for him to take the fight to Colbert Busch.

Sanford's liabilities could force outside groups to spend valuable resources to salvage the district, which Mitt Romney won by 18 points. National Republicans are prepared to do whatever it takes to ensure Sanford's victory, including dumping cash into the race. However, Sanford's campaign will have a hard time overwhelming Colbert Busch in the competition for dollars, as her brother is actively raising funds for her campaign.

Operatives from both parties agree that the race is Sanford's to lose. The district is solid Republican territory, and Sanford is a gifted retail politician who is widely known. While Colbert Busch's campaign has wasted no time calling Sanford untrustworthy and anti-woman, Sanford framed the general election as a clash of ideologies between a small-government conservative and a pro-union liberal.

Polling already shows Sanford in a neck-and-neck battle, and the warning signs for Sanford cannot be ignored. Not a single member of the South Carolina congressional delegation has endorsed Sanford, indicating his weak standing among his would-be Washington colleagues. Two House Republicans backed one of Sanford's GOP primary rivals, and GOP leaders are grappling with how to get the delegation on board now that he has defeated former Charleston County Councilman Curtis Bostic in the runoff.

Particular attention will be paid to popular Sen. Tim Scott, whose appointment to the Senate triggered the race for his House seat. Scott has stayed out of the race, but national Republicans will want him to endorse Sanford. In 2009, Scott, then a state representative, signed a letter calling on Sanford to resign, citing his poor decision-making and questionable leadership.

Title: Virginia Republican Party Nominates Controversial Candidate for Lieutenant Governor

The Republican Party of Virginia has nominated E.W. Jackson, an African-American pastor and attorney, as their candidate for lieutenant governor. Jackson has gained attention for his provocative comments on social media, including comparing Planned Parenthood to the Ku Klux Klan and criticizing African-Americans for their "slavish devotion" to the Democratic Party.

In a self-produced video posted on YouTube last year, Jackson stated that the Democratic Party has created an "unholy alliance" with Planned Parenthood, which has led to the deaths of millions of unborn black babies. He also accused the party and its black civil rights allies of being partners in a "genocide."

The Democratic Party has already begun highlighting these remarks and others in emails to reporters, seeking to tie Jackson to the rest of the Republican ticket in Virginia, particularly gubernatorial nominee Ken Cuccinelli. Cuccinelli, the current state Attorney General, will face Democrat Terry McAuliffe, the former Democratic National Committee chairman, in the November election.

The McAuliffe campaign has criticized Cuccinelli and Jackson's "extremely divisive rhetoric," saying it reflects their social agenda and would impose it on Virginia. The campaign also noted that the state is looking for leaders who focus on jobs, not social issues.

Jackson, a former Marine and Harvard Law School graduate, is the founder of a nondenominational church and has been known for his controversial statements. He has questioned President Barack Obama's faith and has been leading efforts to recruit black Democrats to the GOP since last year, when he ran for Senate in Virginia.

As lieutenant governor, Jackson would hold the tie-breaking vote in the state Senate, which is currently evenly divided. Republicans currently hold the lieutenant governorship and control of the 40-seat body. However, with Jackson as the GOP nominee, Democrats are now a safe bet to pick up the lieutenant governor's office and control of the Senate.

The Democratic Party will decide their nominee in a June 11 primary. The Republican Party chose to nominate their candidates at a convention instead of a primary, giving a relatively small group of conservative activists control over the nomination process.

Title: Gun Control Debate Takes a Backseat After Congressional Baseball Shooting

The recent shooting at a congressional baseball practice in Virginia has brought a sense of unease and frustration among lawmakers and advocates for stricter gun control measures. In the past, mass shootings have often led to renewed debates on Capitol Hill about gun control, but this time, the tone was different. Instead of a push for stricter regulations, many lawmakers seemed to prioritize bipartisanship and calming the political rhetoric.

Senator Chris Murphy, a vocal advocate for stricter gun laws, expressed concern that the country is becoming desensitized to gun violence and mass shootings. "Are we so jaundiced to gun violence and mass shootings that it only takes us 24 hours to revert back to business as usual?" he wrote on his Facebook page.

Former Congresswoman Carolyn McCarthy, who has been a persistent advocate for stricter gun control measures during her nine terms in office, expressed dismay at the lack of progress on the issue. "It is a shame that nothing is done between these horrible shootings," she said. McCarthy's husband was fatally shot in 1993 during a shooting rampage on a Long Island Rail Road commuter train.

While some Republicans, such as Representative Roger Williams, suggested that more people on the scene could have shot back at the assailant, Representative Tom Garrett introduced a bill in March that would make it easier for people to carry a gun and "allow the most law-abiding among us to defend themselves."

Despite the lack of progress on gun control measures, McCarthy expressed hope that the recent shooting would lead to a renewed focus on the issue. "Towards the end of my career, I thought, 'Could we stop praying for everybody who gets shot or injured and just do something about it?' That is how frustrated you get and I know most victims feel the same way," she said.

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Suspends Re-election Bid Amid Insider Trading Charges

Rep. Chris Collins, a Republican representative from New York's 27th Congressional District, has suspended his re-election bid, citing concerns that Democrats would elect a candidate who supports impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump. Collins, who has held the seat since 2012, is facing insider trading charges and allegations of lying to federal agents.

According to the U.S. Attorney's Office for New York's Southern District, Collins is accused of tipping off family and friends about negative clinical trial results for an Australian biotech company, Innate Immunotherapeutics, in which he served on the board. The information allegedly led to the sale of 1.78 million Innate shares, resulting in losses of $768,600 for those involved.

Collins has pleaded not guilty to the charges and has vowed to clear his name. He will continue to serve out the remainder of his term, stating that he will "fill out the remaining few months" to support Trump's agenda.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi has called for Collins to resign, stating that "no person is above the law, not the President or his first supporter in Congress." The Securities and Exchange Commission has also filed a complaint against Collins, his son Cameron, and Stephen Zarsky, the father of Cameron's fiancée, alleging wire fraud, conspiracy to commit securities fraud, and seven counts of securities fraud.

The Monroe County GOP is evaluating potential replacement candidates to run in the district, with county leaders considering "several highly qualified individuals." Under New York state law, Collins cannot be removed from the ballot, but he could be nominated for a different office, such as a town clerk position, to comply with the law.

The case is set for a status hearing on October 11, with bail for each defendant set at $500,000.

Title: Republican Senate Chances Decline as Democrats Surge in Key States

The Republican Party's chances of taking control of the Senate have decreased significantly, according to Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight.com. Silver, a former New York Times statistician, estimates that Republican odds now stand at 55%, a drop from 64% just two weeks ago. The shift is attributed to changes in Senate races in Colorado and North Carolina, which have given the Democratic Party an advantage.

Silver's detailed statistical model indicates that Democrats now have a stronger possibility of winning due to their gains in these highly competitive "purple states." These states, which also include Iowa, Michigan, and New Hampshire, are currently held by Democrats. The exception is New Hampshire, where Republicans have maintained their edge.

Recent polls have shown a surge for North Carolina Sen. Kay Hagan and Colorado Sen. Mark Udall, which has contributed to the Democratic Party's momentum. However, Silver notes that this surge has occurred despite a deterioration in the Democratic Party's position on the generic congressional ballot, which is often seen as a key indicator of the nation's mood.

Silver attributes the Democratic surge in purple states to the influence of money in these races, citing massive financial advantages for the Democrats in North Carolina and Colorado, as well as higher outside spending by Democratic-leaning super PACs. As a result, the GOP's path to a Senate majority is less robust than before.

Title: Clinton Foundation to Stop Accepting Foreign and Corporate Donations if Hillary Clinton is Elected

The Clinton Foundation has announced that it will no longer accept foreign and corporate donations if Hillary Clinton is elected as the next President of the United States. This decision comes after reports of potential hacking and breaches of security at the foundation. The move is seen as a tacit admission of wrongdoing and raises questions about the foundation's past practices.

The Clinton Foundation has been under scrutiny for its acceptance of foreign and corporate donations, which some have argued create conflicts of interest and undermine the integrity of the political process. The foundation has received millions of dollars in donations from foreign governments, corporations, and individuals with business interests before the State Department.

The decision to stop accepting foreign and corporate donations is seen as a step in the right direction, but many questions remain unanswered. The foundation has still not disclosed the names of 1,100 foreign donors, and some have raised concerns about the potential for influence peddling and pay-to-play schemes.

The article highlights several instances where Hillary Clinton's actions as Secretary of State and her husband's activities have raised concerns about conflicts of interest and potential corruption. These include the approval of the transfer of 20% of all U.S. uranium to Russia, the granting of a rare "gold exploitation permit" to a company with ties to her brother, and the receipt of $2.35 million in donations from the head of a Russian government-owned uranium company.

The article also notes that the Clinton Foundation has not answered many questions about its activities and the potential for influence peddling and corruption. The article concludes by suggesting that the mainstream media should investigate these issues further and demand answers from Hillary Clinton and her campaign.

Title: Philippines Bans Two U.S. Lawmakers, Threatens Visa Restrictions Over Detention of Government Critic

The Philippines has banned two U.S. lawmakers, Senators Richard Durbin and Patrick Leahy, from visiting the country and is considering introducing tighter entry restrictions for U.S. citizens if Washington enforces sanctions over the detention of a top government critic, according to President Rodrigo Duterte's spokesman, Salvador Panelo. The move comes after the U.S. Congress approved a 2020 budget containing a provision introduced by the senators against anyone involved in the incarceration of Senator Leila de Lima.

The Philippines grants visa-free entry for up to 30 days to Americans, with 792,000 U.S. citizens visiting the country in the first nine months of 2019, accounting for nearly 13% of foreign arrivals. However, if the U.S. enforces sanctions against Philippine officials involved in de Lima's detention, the Philippines will impose visa requirements on U.S. nationals, Panelo said.

Senator Leahy's spokesman, David Carle, called the charges against de Lima "politically motivated" and stated that the detention is about the right of Filipino citizens to freely express their opinions, including those critical of government policies. Panelo countered that de Lima is not wrongfully imprisoned but detained pending trial for crimes.

The case against de Lima, a former justice minister, has sparked international concern, with human rights groups considering her a prisoner of conscience. She has called for an international investigation into President Duterte's war on drugs, which has resulted in thousands of deaths. The U.S. embassy in Manila and the State Department did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The Philippines' decision to ban the two U.S. lawmakers and consider visa restrictions is seen as a response to the U.S. Congress's move to impose sanctions on Philippine officials involved in de Lima's detention. The Philippines has a complex relationship with the U.S., with President Duterte publicly expressing disdain for the U.S. and its perceived hypocrisy and interference, while acknowledging the country's historical ties and defense alliance.

Title: Romney's Post-Debate Performance: 6 Keys to a Romney Revival

Article:

Mitt Romney's strong debate performance in Denver has sparked renewed interest in his presidential campaign, but for him to capitalize on this momentum, he must demonstrate that his performance was not a fluke. To achieve this, Romney needs to accomplish several key tasks in the coming days. Here are six potential factors that could contribute to a Romney revival:

Firstly, Romney must show that his Denver performance was not an anomaly. He needs to prove that he is a sharper, more coherent candidate than his critics have portrayed him to be. This means addressing the weaknesses he exposed in President Barack Obama's record and tone, which were highlighted during the debate.

Secondly, Romney must continue to demonstrate that he is a credible alternative to Obama. He needs to show that he can point to a clear direction for the country, rather than simply being a reactive opponent.

Thirdly, Romney's debate prep must continue to be taken seriously. He has been road-testing a more emotive and connected side of himself at rallies, which could benefit him in the town hall-style debate format at Hofstra University.
