Fourthly, Romney's campaign must capitalize on the momentum from his debate performance. He needs to continue to show voters that he is a strong leader who can bring about change.

Fifthly, Romney's opponents must be kept at bay. He needs to avoid making mistakes that would allow Obama to regain the upper hand.

Lastly, Romney's campaign must be prepared to adapt to any changes in the political landscape. He needs to be able to pivot quickly to respond to new developments and maintain his momentum.

While a clear Obama victory is unlikely, a clear Obama loss would significantly increase the odds of a Romney presidency. Romney's campaign must capitalize on his strong debate performance and continue to demonstrate that he is a strong leader who can bring about change.

Title: Trump Unveils Plan to Cut US Immigration by Half, Prioritize English-Speaking and Educated Immigrants

Article:

President Donald Trump announced a new immigration plan on Wednesday, which aims to reduce the total number of immigrants admitted to the United States by half over a decade and prioritize those who can speak English or are well-educated. The proposed legislation, known as the Reforming American Immigration for Strong Employment (RAISE) Act, would also cap the number of refugees admitted to the US at 50,000 per year and eliminate the diversity visa lottery.

According to estimates provided by the office of Senator Tom Cotton, one of the bill's sponsors, the RAISE Act would reduce the number of immigrants admitted to the US by 41% in its first year and by 50% over a 10-year period.

Trump described the bill as "legislation that would represent the most significant reform to our immigration system in a half century" and hailed it as a fulfillment of his campaign promise to create a "merit-based immigration system that protects American workers and taxpayers."

The plan has received support from some Republicans, including Senators Tom Cotton and David Perdue, who introduced the bill in February. However, it has also faced criticism from both sides of the aisle. Democrats have expressed concerns that the plan would harm the US economy and reduce the number of skilled workers, while some Republicans have argued that it would disproportionately affect certain industries and states.

The proposal has also sparked controversy over its potential impact on the racial composition of immigrants to the US. White House aide Stephen Miller clashed with CNN anchor Jim Acosta over the issue, with Miller accusing Acosta of having a "cosmopolitan bias" and Acosta saying that the bill would violate the spirit of the poem inscribed on the Statue of Liberty.

It remains to be seen whether the RAISE Act will pass Congress in its current form. While Trump has expressed support for the bill, it is unlikely to garner enough support from both parties to become law.

Title: Obama's Approval Rating Remains Steady Amidst Controversies

According to a recent CNN/ORC International survey, President Barack Obama's approval rating has remained steady, with 53% of Americans approving of his job performance and 45% disapproving. The poll, conducted between May 17-18, found that the president's approval rating has not dropped, but remains above 50%, which may be seen as good news for Democrats.

The survey also found that congressional Republicans are not overplaying their hand in their reaction to the three controversies that have consumed the nation's capital over the past week and a half. The controversies include the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) targeting of tea party and other conservative groups, the September attack in Benghazi, Libya, and the Justice Department's secret collection of phone records from the Associated Press.

The poll found that more than seven in 10 Americans believe the IRS's actions were unacceptable, while 55% say the president's statements about the scandal are completely or mostly true. Additionally, 59% believe the U.S. government could have prevented the Benghazi attack, and 54% say congressional Republicans are not overreacting in their handling of the matter.

The survey also found that Americans are taking all three controversies seriously, with 55% saying the IRS and Benghazi matters are very important to the nation, and 53% saying the same about the AP case. However, only 43% say they have a great deal or some confidence in the people who run the federal government.

The CNN poll surveyed 923 adults nationwide by telephone and has a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

Title: Republican Debate Sets New Low as Candidates Turn on Each Other

The final debate before Super Tuesday saw a dramatic shift in the tone and intensity of the Republican candidates, with Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz finally engaging in a fierce attack on Donald Trump's record, character, and policy platform. The debate, marked by vicious insults and shouting, set a new low for the Republican Party, which had been desperate for a moment like this to occur.

For the first time in 10 debates and six months, Rubio and Cruz ignored each other and focused on Trump, criticizing his policy platform, which Rubio described as "Everyone's dumb, he's going to make America great again. Win, win, win." Rubio had several breakout moments, armed with a series of comebacks and quick to respond to Trump's almost-clichéd insults. At one point, he even turned the tables on Trump, referencing his own much-maligned gaffe during the New Hampshire debates.

Cruz supporter Glenn Beck praised Rubio's performance, saying it was his best yet, giving new life to Rubio's campaign and potentially reviving hopes that Trump would not run away with the Republican nomination. However, Trump continued to leverage the same talking points against his opponents, amping up the vitriol. Rubio was now a "sweaty-faced choke artist" instead of just an inexperienced young man who kept "repeating" himself; Cruz was no longer just a "liar" who screwed over Carson in Iowa, but a "basket case" and a "crazy zealot." Cruz responded in turn, asking Trump to "get back on [his] meds."

Despite the more spirited performance from Rubio and Cruz, it remains unclear whether the chaos of the debate will be enough to catapult either candidate into the front-runner position, with nearly half of the delegates needed to win the nomination still up for grabs.

Title: White House Expresses Optimism Despite Speculation on Health Care Bill Passage

The White House expressed optimism on Friday that the Republican-backed health care bill will pass the House, despite speculation that it may not have the necessary support. White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer said President Trump is looking forward to the House passing the bill and confirmed that House Speaker Paul Ryan is meeting with Trump to discuss the way forward.

According to GOP lawmakers and congressional aides, House Republican leaders are short of the votes needed for the bill to pass. Trump tweeted that voting against the White House-backed bill is tantamount to voting for Planned Parenthood, and urged supporters to call their representatives to back the bill.

In an effort to win over conservatives, House leaders proposed a fresh amendment repealing Obama's requirement that insurers cover 10 specified services, including maternity and mental health care. Conservatives have demanded the removal of these conditions, arguing they drive up premiums.

The president met with members of the Freedom Caucus on Thursday to try and win them over, but the vote was postponed after administration officials fell short. Trump issued an ultimatum, saying he wants the House to vote on the legislation to begin dismantling ObamaCare and if it fails, he is "done with health care" and ready to move on to tax reform.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy believes the vote will wrap up by 4:30 or 5 p.m. ET. If the bill passes, it will be a monumental achievement for Speaker Ryan and Trump. However, if the bill stumbles, recriminations will abound.

The House Rules Committee is expected to prepare the health care bill starting at 7 a.m. ET on Friday. When asked about the timing of the vote, McCarthy said the House should be "done in the afternoon" but said Democrats could delay things.

The article does not provide information on the exact number of votes needed for the bill to pass or the exact number of votes expected to be cast.

**Trump Welcomes Home Detainees from North Korea**

President Donald Trump welcomed home three Americans who were formerly imprisoned by North Korea on Thursday, greeting them at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland. The three men, Kim Dong Chul, Kim Sang-duk (also known as Tony Kim), and Kim Hak-song, were released from North Korea and arrived at the base at 2:42 a.m. They were accompanied by Vice President Mike Pence and their wives, as well as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who had secured their release during a trip to North Korea.

Trump thanked North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for releasing the prisoners, saying it was a "big thing" and "very important" to him. He also joked that the event "probably broke the all-time record for television ratings for 3 o'clock in the morning."

The three men were taken to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland, for further evaluation and medical treatment. North Korea had accused them of anti-state activities.

Pompeo, who flew the prisoners out of North Korea on his plane, said they were in good health considering what they had been through and were able to board the plane without assistance. The release is seen as a further sign of thawing relations between the U.S. and North Korea, following Kim's pledge to suspend missile tests and close a nuclear test site. However, it also comes amid renewed uncertainty around the summit between Trump and Kim, which was previously announced but has been put on hold.

Title: US Secretary of State Warns of "Serious Mistrust" Between US and Russia Over Election Interference

The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, has expressed concerns about the deteriorating relationship between the US and Russia, citing Moscow's alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election. Tillerson met with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on the sidelines of the ASEAN meeting in the Philippines, where he emphasized the need to address the "serious mistrust" between the two nations.

According to Tillerson, Russia's actions have damaged the relationship, but he believes it is not "useful to just cut everything off over one single issue." The US will respond to Russia's expulsion of 755 staff from the US embassy in Moscow by September 1, he said.

US intelligence agencies believe that the Kremlin attempted to help Donald Trump win the election, while Moscow denies any involvement. The US Congress passed sanctions against Russia last month, which President Trump opposed, sparking a tit-for-tat response from Russia.

Tillerson's comments come after President Trump signed into law a bill imposing sanctions on Russia for election meddling and military actions in Crimea and Ukraine. The law also prevents Trump from lifting sanctions or returning Russian diplomatic compounds in the US, which were seized by the Obama administration in retaliation for alleged Russian meddling.

The US Secretary of State also indicated that the two countries may be able to work together to address violence in Eastern Ukraine. However, the comments by Tillerson do not suggest a significant shift in the US stance on Russia, as the country continues to face criticism for its alleged interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Border Patrol Releases Migrant Families Amid Overcrowding, Amidst Debate Over Obama's Immigration Policies

Article:

The U.S. Border Patrol has been releasing migrant families, including Edilberto Lanza Mejia, a 26-year-old from Honduras, and his family, after they crossed the border from Mexico. The family had been held in a cell for five days, waiting for processing, but with an influx of 80 to 90 people daily, the system is overwhelmed. As a result, the Border Patrol is releasing families with a promise to report to immigration officials weeks later.

According to the Christian Science Monitor, the number of unaccompanied minors crossing the border illegally has been steady for over a decade, with an average of 7,000 to 8,000 cases per year from 2002 to 2011. However, in 2012, the number jumped to 13,625, and this year, the federal government is estimating 80,000 cases.

The Obama administration attributes the surge to recent violence in Central American countries. However, critics argue that the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, introduced in 2012, has contributed to the increase. The program allowed some undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as minors to defer deportation for two years. Last week, the administration announced guidelines for a further two-year deferral.

The article highlights the arbitrary nature of the DACA program, with its two-year time limit and age cutoff of 30. Critics argue that this makes no logical, moral, or practical sense. The article also notes that Central Americans have figured out that if President Obama won't deport DACA-eligible immigrants, he won't deport new arrivals either.

A recently detained undocumented immigrant from Guatemala told the Christian Science Monitor that women and children are allowed to stay, and if they appeal their case, they can receive support to study. Texas Governor Rick Perry has asked Obama to change his immigration policies, particularly the practice of releasing illegal immigrants into the U.S. with only a promise to appear in court.

Title: Manafort's Presence at Washington Meetings Contradicts Mercury's Previous Claims

A recent disclosure has revealed that Paul Manafort, former campaign chairman for President Donald Trump, met with at least one U.S. government official connected to the Russia-aligned political party he was representing in 2012 and 2013. The meetings, which had not been previously disclosed, were part of a lobbying effort on behalf of a Brussels-based think tank that supported Ukraine's Party of Regions, headed by former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, a Manafort client.

According to the disclosures filed with the Justice Department, Manafort met with Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), former Arizona Republican Congressman Jim Kolbe of the International Republican Institute, Paula Dobriansky of the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, and Nadia Diuk of the National Endowment for Democracy. The lobbying effort was paid for by the European Centre for a Modern Ukraine, which paid Mercury, a lobbying firm, more than $1.2 million for work between May 2012 and May 2014.

Manafort's presence at the Washington meetings conflicts with Mercury's previous claims that it did not coordinate with Manafort. Mercury partner Michael McKeon stated that Manafort referred his Brussels think tank client to the firm, and that Manafort's involvement was limited to a few meetings. However, the recent disclosures suggest that Manafort's involvement was more extensive than previously claimed.

The Foreign Agents Registration Act requires lobbying firms to report their interactions and expenses with foreign governments and political parties. Mercury originally reported its lobbying for the think tank to Congress under the Lobbying Disclosure Act, but did not itemize each interaction and expense. However, Mercury later retroactively filed with the Justice Department, stating that it relied on assurances from the think tank that it was not funded or controlled by a foreign political party.

While violating the disclosure law is criminal, the office that enforces it usually settles for bringing lobbyists into compliance instead of bringing charges.

Title: Illinois Abortion Bills Spark Controversy, Thousands Protest in Springfield

Thousands of protesters gathered in the Illinois state capitol in Springfield on Wednesday to express their opposition to two new abortion bills introduced by Illinois Democrats. The bills, which aim to increase access and provision for abortion, have sparked widespread outcry from pro-life groups and residents across the state.

One bill would allow abortions up until the moment of birth for any reason, while the other would eliminate the requirement for minors to notify their parents before obtaining an abortion. Illinois Right to Life Action's Mary Kate Knorr stated that the proposed legislation disregards the health and safety of women and has sparked outrage from residents across the state.

The bills have been introduced as part of Governor J.B. Pritzker's plan to make Illinois the most progressive state in the nation for access to reproductive health care. Pro-life groups fear that this will lead to an increase in abortions, particularly among low-income women who may be more likely to take advantage of subsidized abortion services.

According to the Chicago Tribune, 5,528 women traveled to Illinois from other states to have abortions last year, a significant increase from the 4,543 women who traveled to the state in 2016. The total number of statewide abortions also saw a similar increase from 2016 to 2017.

The repeal of the Parent Notification of Abortion Act of 1995 could lead to an even greater increase in abortions, as it would allow minors to make decisions about their reproductive health without parental consent. The bill's sponsor, State Sen. Elgie Sims, Jr. (D-Chicago), argued that the goal of the bill is to increase "authentic family conversations," but opponents argue that it would lead to hasty and uninformed decisions.

The bill passed out of a state Senate committee on Tuesday, with a vote of 8-4, with all four objections coming from Republican opponents. The other bill, the Reproductive Health Act, would establish abortion as a fundamental right and require private insurance companies to cover abortion services.

Pro-life groups have expressed concerns about the bills, with Illinois Right to Life Action stating that they would allow unregulated abortion up until the moment of birth for any reason and strip away parental rights. The organization also noted that at least four abortion facilities have shut down since 2011 due to failed state inspections.

The bills have been introduced in both chambers of the Illinois General Assembly, but are stalled in the House. The controversy surrounding the bills is likely to continue as the debate over reproductive rights and access to abortion services remains a contentious issue in the state.

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Approach: A Shift from Idealism to Realism

Article:

President Donald Trump's recent international trip has sparked a mix of reactions, with some praising his straightforward approach to foreign policy and others criticizing his perceived lack of diplomacy. As the 45th president of the United States, Trump has taken a different tack than his predecessor, Barack Obama, who focused on promoting democracy and human rights globally.

Trump's approach is often described as "realist" or "pragmatist," emphasizing the importance of national interests and the need for a strong military to protect the country. In contrast, Obama's approach was more idealistic, focusing on promoting democracy and human rights worldwide.

Trump's critics argue that his approach is too focused on personal interests and lacks a broader vision for the world. They point to his decision to withdraw from the Paris climate accord and his criticism of international organizations like the United Nations. However, Trump's supporters argue that his approach is more effective in achieving American goals and protecting the country's interests.

In the Middle East, Trump's approach is seen as a departure from the previous administration's focus on promoting democracy and human rights. Trump has taken a more pragmatic approach, emphasizing the need for alliances and partnerships with countries that share American interests. This approach is seen as a departure from the previous administration's focus on promoting democracy and human rights.

Trump's critics argue that his approach is too focused on personal interests and lacks a broader vision for the world. They point to his decision to withdraw from the Paris climate accord and his criticism of international organizations like the United Nations. However, Trump's supporters argue that his approach is more effective in achieving American goals and protecting the country's interests.

In conclusion, Trump's foreign policy approach is a departure from the previous administration's focus on promoting democracy and human rights. His approach is more pragmatic and focused on protecting American interests. While his critics argue that his approach is too focused on personal interests and lacks a broader vision for the world, his supporters argue that his approach is more effective in achieving American goals and protecting the country's interests.

Title: YouTube's Health Information Disparities: A Concern for Public Health

The Health Information National Trends Survey reports that 75% of Americans turn to the internet for health information, with YouTube being one of the most popular platforms. While YouTube has emerged as a significant source of health information, concerns have been raised about the potential for video recommendations to exacerbate preexisting disparities in health. A significant fraction of the U.S. population, estimated to be around 12%, has limited health literacy, making it difficult for them to understand basic health information.

Studies have shown that social media platforms like YouTube can widen health literacy disparities by steering users toward questionable content. A study by a professor of information systems found that the most popular and engaging videos on YouTube are less likely to have medically valid information. This is because algorithms underlying recommendations on social media platforms are biased toward engagement and popularity.

The study also found that users with greater health literacy are more likely to discover usable medical advice from reputable health care providers, while those with limited health literacy are steered toward fake cures or misleading medical advice. This can be especially harmful for minority groups, who are disproportionately affected by limited health literacy.

Correcting algorithmic biases and providing better information to users of technology platforms is crucial to promoting equity. For instance, a pioneering study by the Gender Shades project examined disparities in facial recognition software and concluded that companies can make progress in reducing these disparities once issues are pointed out.

Google receives over a billion health questions every day, and those with low health literacy are at risk of encountering medically unsubstantiated information. The World Economic Forum has dubbed health-related misinformation an "infodemic." Digital platforms where anyone can engage also make them vulnerable to misinformation, accentuating disparities in health literacy.

To make health information on YouTube more equitable, those who design recommendation algorithms must incorporate feedback from clinicians and patients as well as end-users. Social media and search companies have partnered with health organizations like the Mayo Clinic to provide validated information and reduce the spread of misinformation.

Title: Senate Republicans Block Tax Cut Bill Over Dispute on Amendments

Article:

Senate Republicans blocked a $84 billion tax cut bill on Thursday, citing concerns over their inability to offer amendments, including one targeting an Obamacare medical device tax. The legislation, which aimed to revive a raft of expired tax breaks, failed to clear a procedural hurdle, with a vote of 53-40 falling short of the 60 votes needed to advance the measure.

The dispute comes just days after a similar impasse scuttled an energy efficiency bill and a vote on the Keystone Pipeline, raising concerns about six more months of gridlock and partisan bickering before the November election. Lawmakers are unsure what will happen next with the so-called tax extenders, which would renew a hodgepodge of temporary provisions benefiting teachers, commuters, banks, and others.

Some Republicans expressed hope that the delay would be brief, while others acknowledged that the move could kill the legislation until after this year's midterm elections. Senator Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) emphasized the importance of standing up for the GOP's right to introduce amendments. "Don't we care a little more about freedom and the right to bring up your amendments and the right to be a participant in the process?" he said.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) criticized Republicans for their decision, stating, "Republicans can't take 'yes' for an answer – they just voted against the second bipartisan bill in less than a week. That's what just happened: the Republicans voted against tax cuts. So maybe the Republicans will hear from their friends down on K Street and around the country and maybe they will learn this is pretty important to everybody."

Senator Mark Kirk of Illinois was the only Republican to side with Democrats. Lawmakers will take the weekend and the first couple of days of next week to see if an amendment deal can be worked out, with aides in both parties indicating that the GOP will continue to push for a vote to block the medical device tax.

Title: Congress Avoids Government Shutdown, But Funding Fight Looms in December

Congress has temporarily dodged a government shutdown, but the threat of a funding showdown is far from over. The immediate crisis was averted with Speaker John Boehner's surprise resignation announcement, which removed any doubt about a clean spending bill being passed this week. However, the real challenge lies ahead, as lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year.

Democrats are demanding an increase in domestic spending caps, while hawkish Republicans want to boost defense programs. Fiscal conservatives are opposed to any additional spending. The outcome of this funding fight is uncertain, with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stating that there is no agreement beyond a short-term funding bill this week.

The Senate will make the first move to steer Congress away from a shutdown, with a key procedural vote on Monday evening on a bill that would fund the government through December 11 and not strip money from Planned Parenthood. Senate Democratic and GOP leadership aides said there would be no issue clinching the 60 votes needed to advance the short-term spending bill.

The House will follow suit and send the bill to President Barack Obama for his signature, just in time to avert the second federal government shutdown since 2013. However, the real battle is expected to begin in December, when lawmakers must agree on a new funding bill for the new fiscal year.

In the meantime, House Republicans are diverting their energy into investigating Planned Parenthood, alleging that the organization profited from the sale of fetal tissue. The House GOP has announced the establishment of a select committee to probe the allegations, which has drawn condemnation from Democrats. The House will also vote on measures restricting abortion and drafting a reconciliation measure to defund Planned Parenthood.

Reconciliation is an appealing procedural weapon for the GOP-controlled Capitol, but it is unclear whether the Senate will follow suit and use the procedural tool to strip funding from Planned Parenthood. Some House conservatives are not pleased with the leadership's strategy, but they are resigned to the fact that a spending bill without Planned Parenthood restrictions is inevitable.

Democrats are likely to provide the lion's share of votes to keep the government open beyond Wednesday, while Republicans oppose the stopgap measure for reasons beyond money for Planned Parenthood. The real challenge lies ahead, as lawmakers must navigate the complex funding fight and agree on a new spending bill for the new fiscal year.

Title: UN Reports One Million Children Fleeing Violence in Syria, Urges International Community to Act

The United Nations has released a grim statistic, revealing that over one million children have fled violence in Syria since the conflict began in 2011. The majority of these children, three-quarters of whom are under the age of 11, have been forced to leave their homes and families behind. The UN's children's agency, UNICEF, has called on the international community to take immediate action to address the crisis.

The UN is also pushing for an immediate investigation into an alleged chemical weapons attack near Damascus, which has left over a thousand people dead. The Syrian government has denied the allegations, calling them "illogical and fabricated." However, unverified footage shows civilians, including children, suffering from horrific symptoms, and chemical weapons experts have confirmed that the injuries are consistent with nerve agents.

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has renewed calls for UN inspectors to be allowed to investigate the claims immediately, stating that there is no good reason for any party to decline this opportunity to get to the truth. The UN is acting quickly to address the allegations, with its top disarmament representative, Angela Kane, set to fly to Syria to investigate the claims.

The Syrian conflict has become the worst refugee crisis since the genocide in Rwanda in 1994, with over 100,000 people killed and over 2 million displaced within the country. Children are among the most vulnerable, with 1 million forced to flee and 2 million displaced. The UN has warned that the "youth of Syria are losing their homes, their family members, and their futures."

Education is a top concern for Syrian refugee families, with 48% of the refugee population being children who are unable to attend official schooling in their host countries. The longer children stay out of school, the less likely they are to eventually return, according to a report from Save the Children. In Jordan, over 60% of school-age children are not attending classes, despite the availability of free schooling.

The UN has urged the international community to respond to the problem, which it says belongs to everybody. "We must all share the shame," said UNICEF's Anthony Lake. "Because while we work to alleviate the suffering of those affected by this crisis, the global community has failed in its responsibility to this child. We should stop and ask ourselves how, in all conscience, we can continue to fail the children of Syria."

However, some experts have noted the limits on countries responding to Syrian children who have been forced to leave their homes.

Title: Kurdish Forces Secure Mileage of Highway 47, Cut Off ISIS Supply Route

Kurdish forces, backed by American support, have made significant gains in their fight against the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq. The Peshmerga, an ethnic Kurdish militia, have acquired a small number of armored American Humvees, abandoned by the Iraqi Army during their retreat from ISIS's rapid offensive last year. However, they have had less success with a captured American armored personnel carrier, which broke down and had to be towed.

Despite the challenges, the Peshmerga have reason to celebrate. Reaching the base of Mount Sinjar, they held a brief celebration, blasting Kurdish music and dancing. After a quick meal of bread and canned fish, they continued their march.

As they approached Highway 47, the sound of American military jets, including A-10 attack planes and B-1 heavy bombers, and explosions grew louder. Roughly two dozen United States Special Forces members are serving as advisers to Peshmerga forces, with half stationed at the main headquarters at the foot of Mount Sinjar and the other dozen spread along the mountain ridge to advise Kurdish airstrike spotters.

The Zeravani Force, led by General Waisi, has secured a broader swath of the highway west of Sinjar, while other forces working in parallel have secured different stretches. By midday, Kurdish officials reported controlling about 22 miles of Highway 47, effectively cutting off one of the main supply routes for ISIS between Syria and the vital jihadist-held city of Mosul in Iraq.

Title: Former Republican Lawmakers Urge Congressional Republicans to Block Trump's Emergency Declaration

A group of 24 former Republican lawmakers has released an open letter urging Congressional Republicans to block President Trump's national emergency declaration. The letter, published by Politico, calls on Congress to support a joint resolution ending the national emergency declared by Trump earlier this month.

The former lawmakers, who served between 1967 and 2013, argue that the expansion of executive authority would eventually be wielded against Republicans by a Democratic administration. They point out that the precedent set by Trump's declaration could be used by future presidents to impose policies that Republicans may oppose.

The letter questions what would happen when a president from a different party uses the same powers to impose policies that Republicans are opposed to. The signatories ask, "What powers are ceded to a president whose policies you support may also be used by presidents whose policies you abhor?"

The House is set to vote this week on a resolution to end the national emergency, which has received the support of only one Republican, Representative Justin Amash of Michigan.

Title: Trump's Unconventional Approach to Governance: A New Era of Presidential Power?

Article:

In a departure from traditional presidential norms, Donald Trump has become the most dominant figure in American life, despite being the most unpopular first-year president in modern history. Trump's unconventional approach to governance has raised questions about the limits of presidential power and the potential consequences of his actions.

According to presidential historian Michael Beschloss, Trump is "defining the presidency very differently" by operating within the boundaries of what is strictly legal, but pushing those boundaries if possible. This departure from traditional norms has been noted by those who have served in previous administrations. William M. Daley, who served as a cabinet secretary under Bill Clinton and White House chief of staff under Barack Obama, stated that Trump is "totally outside the box."

Trump's approach to governance has been marked by a willingness to expand the power of the presidency, similar to his predecessors. However, he has also been more aggressive in asserting his authority, lashing out at judges, lawmakers, investigators, and journalists who anger him. His sense of government is not based on coalition building or a balancing act between equal branches, but rather on his own perception of what is necessary, with the system expected to fall in line.

Trump has publicly asserted his right to order the Justice Department to open or close investigations into himself or his foes, citing the Constitution's grant of wide latitude over the executive branch. While some lawyers argue he has a point, critics have warned that thwarting the special counsel's Russia investigation could lead to impeachment proceedings.

The talk of "absolute" power and Trump's affinity for foreign strongmen have fueled fears of authoritarianism. While Trump has not yet followed through on his threats, his bark has become a power unto itself, leaving the question of whether he will continue to assert his authority in the next stage of his tenure or whether his attacks will prove self-defeating.

Title: A Veteran's Reflection on Memorial Day: Honoring the Fallen and Supporting Their Families

As the United States observes Memorial Day, a veteran reflects on their time serving during the Vietnam era and the sacrifices made by those who have given their lives fighting for the country. The veteran, who was drafted in 1971, was initially ordered to go to Vietnam but was instead sent to Camp Casey in South Korea, where they served in the 2nd Infantry Division's Army Medical Corps.

The veteran notes that their experience in Korea was vastly different from their training in a sterile hospital, where they were accustomed to using proper medical tools. In Korea, they had to adapt to a war zone environment, where even basic medical procedures were a challenge. They recall the lives of the three doctors they worked with, as well as the two soldiers they saved from extreme heat exhaustion.

As the veteran reflects on Memorial Day, they acknowledge the sacrifices made by those who have given their lives serving the country. They emphasize that today is not just about those who serve or have served, but about those who have made the ultimate sacrifice. They highlight the importance of honoring the fallen and their families, who have made endless sacrifices on behalf of the nation.

The veteran also discusses the Forever GI Bill, which they authored, and the Fry Scholarship Improvement Act of 2019, which extends educational benefits to surviving spouses and children of deceased National Guard and Reserve members. They encourage everyone to find a way to honor those who have lost their lives in service, whether through prayer, visiting a VA cemetery, advocating for veterans' issues, or volunteering with a Veterans Service Organization.

In conclusion, the veteran expresses their gratitude for those who have borne the battle on behalf of the nation and those who continue to do so today. They pray for every life lost fighting for freedom and acknowledge the sacrifices made by those who have given their lives in service.

Title: US Lawmakers Reach Deal in Principle on 2018 Farm Bill

The United States lawmakers have reached an agreement in principle on the 2018 Farm Bill, capping months of partisan debate over the legislation to fund $867 billion in food and agriculture programs. The deal was announced by the chairmen and ranking members of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees.

The agreement covers programs such as crop subsidies and support to access export markets, which are essential for American farmers, a key constituency of U.S. President Donald Trump. The funding is crucial as farmers suffer from Trump's trade wars with key commercial partners such as China, which has been absent from the market after the imposition of tariffs.

The latest bill, passed in 2014, expired on September 30 after talks over its replacement broke down. The main standoff had focused on forestry provisions following the deadly wildfires in California. The agreement is yet to be integrated into the text of the legislation and lawmakers will have to decide whether it will be voted on as a standalone bill or within a bigger package. Once voted on, the bill goes to the president for final signature.

The lawmakers have until the end of the year to finalize the process.

Title: U.S. Defense Secretary Visits Baghdad, Seeks Turkey's Role in Battle Against Islamic State

Article:

U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter arrived in Baghdad on an unannounced visit to discuss the role of Turkey in the battle against the Islamic State (IS) in Mosul. However, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declined the offer, stating that Iraqi, Kurdish, and local forces can handle the battle themselves.

Iraqi forces, backed by Kurdish peshmerga soldiers, American advisers, and ethnic minority paramilitary units, launched a large-scale offensive on Monday to recapture Mosul, which was overrun by IS militants in 2014. The U.S. goal is to resolve disputes between partners in the coalition to fight the common enemy, according to Carter.

The visit comes after a U.S. service member was killed outside Mosul, the fourth death since the U.S. began military operations in the region in August 2014. Meanwhile, an apparent counter-attack by suspected IS fighters resulted in the deaths of 80 people, mostly Kurdish security forces, and the wounding of 170 others in Kirkuk.

In a separate incident, hundreds of people were treated for breathing problems caused by a burning sulfur plant set ablaze in Mishraq, south of Mosul. The hospital ran out of hydrocortisone and oxygen supplies for the patients, mostly children and the elderly.

The United Nations Human Rights Office received reports that hundreds of families were forced out of villages and herded towards Mosul, potentially to be used as human shields by the terror group. The office is investigating reports of at least 40 civilians being shot dead in one of the villages outside Mosul.

The U.S. Defense Secretary's visit aims to resolve disputes between partners in the coalition to fight the common enemy, with Carter stating, "I am confident that we can plan a constructive role there."

Title: White House Pushes to Ease Restrictions on Guantanamo Detainees Amid Resistance from Lawmakers

The White House is seeking to ease restrictions on transferring Guantanamo Bay detainees, despite warnings from lawmakers about the potential dangers of doing so. The administration aims to use a Senate defense policy bill to advance its long-stalled goal of shipping detainees out of the Cuba-based prison camp and eventually shutting it down.

According to official estimates, nearly 28% of former detainees have been suspected of returning to the battlefield. However, administration officials argue that the bill would allow them to move out prisoners who have long been cleared for transfer overseas but are still held due to a complicated Pentagon certification process.

The bill would ease restrictions and lift a ban on bringing suspected terrorist prisoners from Guantanamo to the United States for detention, trial, or emergency medical treatment. However, lawmakers resistant to moving too quickly on Guantanamo have long warned about recidivism among former detainees.

Senator Kelly Ayotte, R-NH, and Senator Saxby Chambliss, R-Ga., are working on amendments to preserve the current high bar for transfers. Even if the Senate passes the White House-backed legislation, the House earlier this year approved a measure that further restricts transfers, including an outright ban on sending detainees to Yemen.

Yemen is a particular challenge since more than half of the 164 detainees are from there, and it is home to the world's most active Al Qaeda branch. The Obama administration imposed a ban on Yemeni transfers from Guantanamo after a Nigerian man attempted to blow up a U.S.-bound flight on Christmas 2009 with explosives hidden in his underwear on instructions from Al Qaeda operatives in Yemen.

The White House effort faces dogged resistance, with opponents pointing out that some former detainees have joined terrorist efforts after being released from the remote U.S. naval prison in Cuba. Senator John McCain, R-Ariz., agreed that the administration does not need more flexibility, stating, "All they have to do is assure us that they won't re-enter the fight, as numerous ones have, in leadership positions. We can't do that."

Chris Anders, senior legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, acknowledges the issue is always a tough vote for lawmakers but argues that there is a growing recognition that Guantanamo cannot stay open forever and harms national security. "What's different this year compared to past years is that the president is ready and willing to use whatever authority Congress gives him to start closing Guantanamo, and particularly to start sending home the majority of detainees who were long ago cleared to be sent back home," Anders said.

The administration's goal is to close the prison, with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel stating that annual spending on Guantanamo was $454 million – or about $2.7 million per detainee. The administration has not said much publicly about Guantanamo in the six months since the speech, but officials say President Obama presses Hagel and Secretary of State John Kerry on the matter every week.

Title: Obama's Remarks on Ferguson Spark Mixed Reactions

Article:

President Barack Obama addressed the situation in Ferguson, Missouri, following the killing of Michael Brown, expressing sympathy for the community's outrage while emphasizing the need to maintain public safety. The remarks were met with mixed reactions from the media and the public, with some criticizing Obama for being too subdued and others praising his measured approach.

Obama's comments were described as "guarded, reserved, and deeply clinical" by Politico, with some critics arguing that he did not delve deeply enough into the pain of the racial divide and underlying tensions. Fox News commentator Charles Krauthammer criticized Obama for not explicitly condemning the violence and chaos in Ferguson, stating that the president should instead focus on the moral imperative to condemn such actions.

However, others noted that Obama's approach was a deliberate attempt to avoid inflaming the situation and to maintain a sense of calm. The president emphasized the importance of distinguishing between lawful dissent and violence, stating that while the vast majority of protesters were peaceful, a small minority were engaging in destructive behavior.

Obama also acknowledged the historical mistrust between law enforcement and communities of color, stating that young black men are often seen as objects of fear and that there is a need to address the root causes of crime. However, he also emphasized the importance of holding individuals accountable for their actions, regardless of their background or circumstances.

The president's remarks were seen as a deliberate attempt to strike a balance between empathy and responsibility, avoiding the pitfalls of both emotionalism and inaction. While some critics may have felt that Obama did not go far enough in addressing the underlying issues, his measured approach was seen as a necessary step towards finding a way forward in a complex and sensitive situation.

Title: Trump's "War on Christmas" Sparks Concerns Over Religious Freedom

Article:

The article discusses the controversy surrounding Donald Trump's pledge to "Make America Say Merry Christmas Again" and the potential implications for religious freedom. The author, a Hindu married to a Jew, notes that they celebrate Christmas with their friends, but worries that Trump's efforts to promote a more traditional, Christian-centric holiday season could lead to the erosion of religious freedom and the exclusion of minority religions.

The article highlights Trump's criticism of businesses that do not use the phrase "Merry Christmas" in their holiday greetings, such as Starbucks, and his threat to evict the coffee shop from his hotel. The author notes that Trump's approach is reminiscent of Bill O'Reilly's views on the "War on Christmas," which the author describes as a "hysterical" and "misguided" crusade.

The article also touches on the issue of the separation of church and state, noting that while some may argue that Christmas displays in public spaces are a violation of the separation of church and state, others believe that the real issue is the majority's attempt to impose its beliefs on minority religions.

The author concludes that Trump's pledge to "Make America Say Merry Christmas Again" is a misguided and ham-handed approach that could lead to the erosion of religious freedom and the exclusion of minority religions. The article ends with a call to "pray to God to knock some sense into Trump's head and call off his misguided and ham-handed crusade."

Title: Trump's War on the Media: A Threat to Democracy

Article:

Donald Trump's presidential campaign was marked by his criticism of the media, singling out individual journalists and challenging the foundations of freedom of the press. As president-elect, Trump's war on the media continues, with him berating television executives for what he considers "outrageous" and "dishonest" coverage. According to a source, he told CNN chief Jeff Zucker that "everyone at the network is a liar and you should be ashamed."

Instead of holding a press conference, Trump released a YouTube video updating the public on the White House transition, which he claimed had proceeded "very smoothly, efficiently, and effectively." This move has sparked concerns about the difficulty journalists will face in providing the public with a clear view of presidential decision-making.

Presidential animosity towards the press is not new, with many presidents seeking to reduce the number of press conferences and increasing communication through other means. The emergence of social media has allowed Trump to take this trend to the next level. While distasteful and dysfunctional, the Republic will not fall simply because journalists have to watch YouTube like the rest of us to learn what Trump has been up to.

However, the deeper danger is that Trump's war will undermine the media's ability to play the role of watchdog and critic, envisioned by the Founders and embodied in the First Amendment. By avoiding engagement with journalists and stifling media critics through public shaming and other strong-arm tactics, Trump will weaken the press's ability to hold those in power accountable.

A Pew survey found that only 22% of Americans gave the press an A or B for its campaign coverage, with 59% giving it a D or F. A Gallup poll found that only 32% of the public trusts the press to report news "fully, accurately, and fairly," the lowest figure since 1976. The timing of Trump's war on the media is not an accident, as the media have become an arena of conflict in the partisan battles of an increasingly polarized political system.

The trend is most pronounced among younger Americans, who tend to be more liberal than their parents. In 2016, just 26% of those under 50 trusted the news media, compared to 38% of those 50 or older. The advent of social media has not helped, with only 34% of American adults trusting the information they get from social media sources.

It is unclear how Trump will deal with the media, but it is less clear how the media will respond to Trump. The past 30 years have not provided much cause for optimism, as the news industry has been pummeled by the fragmentation of the news audience and the emergence of the Internet. News organizations have shown little stomach for increasing hard news budgets or supporting investigative journalism.

Instead, a good deal of what passes for American journalism today is simply information recycled straight from government sources. There are exceptions, of course, as well as newer, non-traditional sources of news and opinion that provide alternative narratives to the mainstream media accounts. Most encouraging, perhaps, are the emerging signs that Trump's election may lead to a reinvigorated sense of duty on the part of journalists, news organizations, and NGOs. Whether these initial responses add up to an effective counterpoint to Trump's bully pulpit remains to be seen.

Title: Most Americans View Political Correctness as a Problem, Survey Finds

A recent survey conducted by More in Common, an international research initiative, has found that political correctness (PC) is deeply unpopular among most Americans. According to the survey, 80% of respondents view PC excess as a problem. The researchers asked questions about race, immigration, sexism, free speech, and other hot-button issues, and categorized respondents into seven groups: progressive activists, traditional liberals, passive liberals, the apathetic, moderates, traditional conservatives, and devoted conservatives. The two conservative categories accounted for 25% of the total, while progressive activists made up only 8%.

The survey found that everyone else, dubbed the "exhausted majority," holds views that are not significantly different from one another, even across racial and gender lines. According to The Atlantic's Yascha Mounk, "Most members of the 'exhausted majority,' and then some, dislike political correctness." The survey also found that 74% of people aged 24-29 and 79% of those under 24 are uncomfortable with PC.

The survey's findings suggest that youth is not a reliable proxy for support of political correctness, and that education level and income are better indicators. The most highly educated Americans are more likely to view hate speech as a big problem, but not political correctness.

The survey's results have implications for political campaigns, as they suggest that downplaying the concerns of the anti-PC supermajority could be a bad strategy for any would-be Trump challenger. Progressive activists may have cultural cachet, but there are not many of them, and a publication or politician that misrepresents the views of the majority may see its influence wane and readership decline.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Criticizes President Obama's Handling of Islamic State

Article: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has sharply criticized President Obama's handling of the Islamic State (ISIS) terrorist group. In an opinion piece for Fox News, Jindal accused the President of being "incapable of being commander-in-chief of the United States of America."

Jindal's criticism centers on the President's refusal to acknowledge the threat of "radical Islamic terrorism" and his administration's reluctance to use the term "Islamic State" when referring to the terrorist group. Jindal argues that this reluctance is a sign of the President's inability to confront the problem and ultimately defeat the terrorists.

Jindal also took aim at recent comments made by Marie Harf, a State Department spokeswoman, who suggested that a lack of job opportunities could be driving individuals to join terrorist groups. Jindal called this statement "madness" and argued that killing the enemy is the way to win a war.

Furthermore, Jindal criticized President Obama's request for an authorization for the use of military force, which includes a prohibition on "enduring offensive ground combat operations." Jindal believes this prohibition is a political strategy designed to appease the left and limit the military's ability to effectively combat terrorism.

Jindal concluded his piece by calling on the President to have the "fortitude to tell the American people the truth about radical Islam and put his political base aside so we can defeat these terrorists."

Title: White House Refuses to Search for Emails on Private Taxpayer Information Sharing with Obama's Aides

The White House has declined to investigate emails that could shed light on the sharing of private taxpayer information with President Obama's top aides, stating that the IRS will address the issue "eventually." The tax agency has previously claimed it lacks the capability to search for the emails, but the White House's chief counsel, W. Neil Eggleston, assured Congress that the IRS would try again once it completes its investigation into the tea party-targeting scandal.

In a letter to House Committee on Ways and Means Chairman Paul Ryan, Eggleston wrote that the IRS would address the issue after completing its document productions already in progress. However, IRS Commissioner John Koskinen's letter last year did not mention such a plan, stating that the agency was logistically incapable of performing the search due to the sheer volume of emails involved.

The White House's refusal to investigate the emails comes despite its previous efforts to search for emails in the past, such as the case of former division chief Lois G. Lerner, a key figure in the tea party targeting scandal. The IRS has been under fire for years over several scandals, including its targeting of tea party groups and the illegal release of private taxpayer information.

The IRS's inspector general investigated the issue of private taxpayer information sharing with the White House, but refused to release documents and is currently facing a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit over the matter. Both the House and Senate are now investigating IRS and White House communications.

The White House did not assert any privileges in refusing Ryan's request, instead stating that the IRS would work on it, and the IRS did not respond to a request for comment on whether it had rethought its stance in light of the White House's promise.

Title: Inmates Clash with Guards at Guantanamo Bay Over Individual Cell Housing

A disturbance occurred at the Guantanamo Bay detention center in Cuba on Saturday, following the decision by military authorities to transition prisoners from communal housing to individual cells. The move was reportedly made to improve surveillance and monitoring of the detainees, with some prisoners resisting the change and using improvised weapons, such as batons, broomsticks, and plastic water bottles.

According to the U.S. Southern Command, the decision was made after detainees covered windows and surveillance cameras, limiting guards' ability to monitor them at all times. The forced transfer was also used as an opportunity to evaluate the health of the prisoners, with dozens of them on a hunger strike.

The incident occurred in an area of the detention center that had evolved into a "medium-security" section since the first inmates were brought there over 10 years ago. The Miami Herald reported that during a recent visit, guards had lost control over the inmates, who were systematically disobeying communal camp rules and covering surveillance cameras with cereal boxes.

The hunger strike, which has been ongoing for several months, was prompted by inmates' anger over guards' searching their Qurans and other practices that began after a change in command at the base last summer. The Pentagon has estimated that 43 prisoners are currently on a hunger strike, while some news outlets and defense attorneys have reported the number to be over 60.

In a recent development, the Pentagon named 11 inmates who were being force-fed to prevent them from starving themselves to death. The incident highlights the ongoing challenges faced by the Guantanamo Bay detention center, which has been the subject of controversy and criticism over the years.

Title: Former GOP Presidential Candidate Jon Huntsman and Others Opt Out of 2012 National Convention

Former Republican presidential candidate Jon Huntsman has joined a growing list of high-profile Republicans who have announced they will not attend the 2012 Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida. Huntsman cited his desire for the party to focus on a "bigger, bolder, more confident future for the United States" and emphasized the need for inclusiveness and problem-solving.

Huntsman, a former Utah governor and ambassador to China, stated that he will not attend any future Republican conventions until the party addresses the "trust deficit" and prioritizes the country's future. This decision comes after Huntsman was reportedly dis-invited from a GOP fundraiser following his suggestion that a third party should enter the presidential race.

Other notable Republicans who have opted out of the convention include former Virginia Senator and Governor George Allen, who is too busy with his Senate race against Democrat Tim Kaine. Three other GOP Senate candidates, Heather Wilson in New Mexico, Rep. Denny Rehberg in Montana, and Linda McMahon in Connecticut, have also declined to attend the convention to focus on their respective races.

Huntsman won two delegates for his third-place finish in New Hampshire and has since endorsed Mitt Romney. In his announcement, Huntsman emphasized his campaign theme of "Country First" and encouraged a return to the party's past, citing the examples of Lincoln and Reagan, who prioritized the country's interests over politics.

**Ocean Warming and Acidification Threaten Shark Survival**

A recent study published in Scientific Reports suggests that sharks may be facing a significant threat to their survival due to ocean warming and acidification. As carbon dioxide levels in the oceans increase, the acidity of the water is rising, which could compromise the ability of sharks to swim, hunt, and feed. According to the study's senior author, Lutz Auerswald, a fisheries biologist at Stellenbosch University in South Africa, this could lead to the displacement of sharks as apex predators, disrupting entire ocean food webs.

The study focused on puff adder shy sharks, a small, bottom-dwelling species of cat shark that is easily handled and not endangered. The researchers found that the sharks' scales, which are made of a calcium phosphate material called dentin, were significantly affected by the increased acidity of the water. After two months, an electron-microscope analysis revealed that the concentrations of calcium and phosphate in the sharks' denticles were significantly reduced, with about 25% of the experimental group's scales damaged compared to only 9% in the control group.

The study's findings suggest that the impacts of ocean acidification on sharks would likely vary between species. While puff adder shy sharks are sedentary predators that ambush their prey, larger species that swim in open water, such as great white sharks, rely heavily on their scales for hydrodynamics and could be significantly affected by corrosion. Scales also play a crucial role in protecting females from male biting during courtship and help some shark species defend against other predators.

The study's results highlight the need for further research into the effects of ocean acidification on sharks and other marine species. As Auerswald notes, "One lesson is that you have to test species by species." The study's findings underscore the importance of continued monitoring and research into the impacts of climate change on marine ecosystems and the species that inhabit them.

Title: Stand Your Ground Laws: A Balanced Look at the Evidence

The "stand your ground" law, enacted in Florida in 2005, has been a topic of much debate and controversy. Critics argue that it allows for a Wild West-style gun violence, while proponents claim it is a necessary self-defense measure. However, a closer examination of the evidence reveals a more nuanced picture.

Twenty-four states have adopted some variation of a stand-your-ground law, with few reporting an increase in murders and manslaughters. Florida, which was the first state to adopt such a law, saw a slight uptick in murders and manslaughters after its passage, but the rate has since returned to the pre-law levels. Similarly, other states that have adopted similar laws, such as New Mexico, Louisiana, and Delaware, have not seen a significant increase in violent crime.

Research from Georgia State University economics researchers and Texas A&M University researchers has found that stand-your-ground laws are associated with a significant increase in homicides among whites, particularly white males. However, this increase is not universal, with some states experiencing a decline in violent crime rates after adopting such laws.

A chart from McClatchy's interactive tool shows the rates of homicide in states with stand-your-ground laws, while another chart compares the murder and manslaughter rates in Washington D.C. to those in other states. Washington D.C. has some of the strictest gun control regulations in the US, yet it still experiences a high rate of murders and manslaughters. This raises the question of whether policymakers should focus more on addressing the root causes of violence in the nation's capital rather than targeting stand-your-ground laws in other states.

Title: Trump Visits Puerto Rico to Assess Hurricane Recovery Efforts, Praises Progress

Article:

President Donald Trump traveled to Puerto Rico on Tuesday to assess the recovery efforts following the devastating Category 4 hurricane that hit the island on September 20. During his visit, Trump praised the progress made so far, stating that the federal government has done a "great job" and that the island is "starting to come back." He also acknowledged the challenges faced by the island, saying that the roads are cleared, and communications are starting to come back, but noted that truck drivers are needed to start transporting goods.

The Category 4 storm caused widespread destruction, knocking out power, communications, and transportation systems, leaving nearly 95% of electricity customers without power and many areas without access to basic necessities like food and fresh water. Trump's visit comes after he responded to San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz's criticism of the federal response, saying that the government is doing a "great job" and that the media is undermining the recovery efforts with negative reports.

However, the Trump administration's efforts were criticized by Oxfam, an international organization that fights poverty, which stated that the US government's response has been "slow and inadequate." The organization's president, Abby Maxman, said that essential services like clean water, food, fuel, electricity, and healthcare are in short supply, and that the administration is providing excuses instead of a "cohesive and compassionate response."

**Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon Found Dead Amid Sexual Harassment Allegations**

Seoul Mayor Park Won-soon, a longtime civic activist and human rights lawyer, was found dead in wooded hills in northern Seoul on Friday, more than seven hours after he was reported missing by his daughter. The 64-year-old mayor's body was discovered at around midnight, with no signs of foul play and no cause of death confirmed by police.

The apparent suicide came after a former secretary filed a complaint on Wednesday alleging that Park had sexually harassed her. Police confirmed the complaint but did not elaborate on the nature of the allegations.

In a note left on his desk, Park apologized to everyone and thanked those who had supported him throughout his life. He also requested that his body be cremated and his ashes scattered over his parents' grave.

Park's family urged people to avoid spreading "groundless statements" and warned that they would take legal action against anyone who defamed him. A representative for the family said it was time to let him go and asked that people respect his memory.

Park was reported missing by his daughter on Thursday evening, and a massive search operation was launched by police, involving over 600 officers, drones, and tracking dogs. His body was found by rescue dogs, and his bag, cellphone, and business cards were recovered.

As mayor, Park was known for his activism and criticism of social and economic inequalities, as well as his support for the #MeToo movement. He was also a fierce opponent of former conservative President Park Geun-hye and had praised women for their courage during the #MeToo movement.

Reactions to his death were mixed on social media, with some expressing condolences and others criticizing him for allegedly exploiting his power to harass a subordinate and then taking his own life to "avoid the fallout."

Title: Trump Administration Considers Rolling Back Obama-Era Definition of Sex

The Trump administration is considering rolling back the Obama administration's expansion of Title IX, a federal civil-rights statute banning sex discrimination in federally funded education programs. The controversy surrounds the definition of the word "sex," specifically whether it should be defined as a person's biological traits or their chosen gender identity.

In 2014, the Obama administration expanded the definition of Title IX to include gender identity and expression, stating that the statute's sex discrimination prohibition extends to claims of discrimination based on gender identity or failure to conform to stereotypical notions of masculinity or femininity. This expansion was done without an act of Congress or a regulatory rulemaking process.

The Trump administration has rolled back some of these directives, but has not formally responded to the previous administration's expansion of the scope of the statute. According to a recent New York Times report, the administration may issue formal guidance establishing a biological definition of sex, specifically defining sex as a person's status as male or female based on immutable biological traits identifiable by or before birth.

This definition is consistent with the original intent of Title IX, which was passed in 1972 to prohibit discrimination based on sex. Many jurisdictions across the country have since amended their nondiscrimination laws to explicitly protect gender identity.

The proposed change has sparked a heated debate, with some arguing that it would erase the identities of transgender individuals and deny their humanity. However, others argue that the change would simply conform the law to its original intent and reject an argument about identity.

The debate highlights the complexities of the issue and the need for a nuanced understanding of the intersection of biology, gender identity, and human rights. While the Trump administration's proposed change may be seen as a step back for some, it is essential to recognize that every individual, regardless of their gender identity, is protected by the Bill of Rights and other constitutional rights.

Title: Democrats and Republicans Clash Over Supreme Court Expansion

The debate over the number of Supreme Court justices has gained momentum, with Democrats pushing for expansion and Republicans fighting to maintain the current nine-seat structure. The discussion comes after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blocked President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, and President Trump went on to appoint more conservative justices, shifting the Court's ideological balance.

Some Democratic presidential candidates, such as Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Pete Buttigieg, have expressed support for expanding the Court, citing the need to counterbalance the current conservative majority. Former Attorney General Eric Holder has also weighed in, suggesting that the legitimacy of the Court is a concern and that expanding the Court could be an option if a Democratic president and Congress are willing to make it happen.

However, Republicans are strongly opposed to any changes to the Court's structure. Representative Mark Green (R-TN) plans to introduce a constitutional amendment to limit the number of Supreme Court justices to nine, arguing that schemes to "pack" the Court are dangerous to the Founders' vision of an independent judiciary. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has also announced his support for a constitutional amendment to maintain the current number of justices, citing concerns about the destabilization of essential institutions.

The debate has gained urgency in recent days, with the Supreme Court issuing a ruling that overturned a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals decision, granting the Department of Homeland Security authority to detain illegal immigrants after a court hearing. The ruling has sparked concerns among progressives, who see it as another example of the Court's conservative leanings.

Title: Clinton Launches Voter Registration Drive to Mobilize Sympathetic Voters Amidst Immigration Concerns

Article:

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign has launched a national voter registration program, "Mi Sueño, Tu Voto" (My Dream, Your Vote), aimed at signing up sympathetic voters and warning them that Donald Trump's immigration plans could result in the deportation of young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children. The program, announced on the four-year anniversary of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, will focus on mobilizing Latino and other households to go to the polls for the Democratic nominee.

The program is part of an aggressive effort by Clinton's campaign to woo the record 27.3 million Latinos eligible to vote in 2020. According to polling, Trump is doing worse with Latino voters than any GOP presidential candidate since 1996. The campaign will focus on battleground states including Colorado, Nevada, North Carolina, and Florida, where Latinos and other immigrants make up an important part of the voting base.

Clinton's campaign believes that harnessing the power of young immigrants, known as Dreamers, can help mobilize Latino voters who can vote. The program will remind voters that a Trump presidency would end the DACA program, which is already at risk after a June Supreme Court decision effectively killed Obama's efforts to give legal status to some of the 11 million immigrants living in the U.S. illegally.

The program will also serve to remind voters of Trump's hateful and dangerous agenda, highlighting his pledge to eliminate DACA and deport millions of Dreamers and immigrant families. Clinton has made revamping the country's immigration system a key plank of her presidential campaign, promising to restore and expand Obama's programs, close private sector detention centers, and take a hard look at deportation policies.

The program is part of an effort to mobilize Latino voters, who are a crucial part of the Democratic base. Clinton has called on Latino voters to help stop Trump's efforts to "fan the flames of racial division." The campaign will hold events across the country this week, including in Florida, Nevada, and North Carolina, to unveil the program.

Title: Microsoft Reports Cyber Attack by Iranian-Linked Group Against US Presidential Campaign and Government Officials

Microsoft has announced that a hacking group linked to the Iranian government, known as Phosphorus or APT 35, carried out a cyber attack against a US presidential campaign, as well as current and former American government officials. The attack, which occurred between August and September, resulted in over 2,700 attempts to identify Microsoft consumers' email accounts, with 241 accounts being attacked.

According to Microsoft, the group made more than 2,700 attempts to identify email accounts and attacked 241 of them. Four accounts were compromised, but none of them were associated with the US presidential campaign or current and former US government officials. The company has notified the affected customers and worked with them to secure their accounts.

Microsoft has been tracking Phosphorus since 2013 and received a court order to take control of 99 websites the group used to carry out attacks. The company notes that while the attacks were not technically sophisticated, the group invested significant time and resources in gathering information.

To help secure consumer accounts, Microsoft recommends enabling two-step verification and periodically checking login history. The company's Digital Crimes Unit has taken legal and technical steps to combat Phosphorus attacks.

Title: US Congress Agrees on Sanctions Against Russia, Limiting Trump's Ability to Lift Them

The leaders of both parties in the US Congress have reached an agreement on legislation that would impose new sanctions on Russia for its alleged election meddling and annexation of Crimea. The bill would also limit President Donald Trump's ability to lift any sanctions against Russia, a move that could fuel suspicion that he is too supportive of the Kremlin.

The bipartisan agreement indicates a determination in Congress to maintain a firm line against Russia, regardless of Trump's views. The bill has already passed the Senate and is expected to be voted on by the House of Representatives on Tuesday. It would allow new sanctions against Russia for its 2014 annexation of Crimea and its alleged meddling in the US election.

The legislation would also cover the possibility of further sanctions against Iran and North Korea. The US already has a raft of sanctions in place against Russian individuals and companies over Crimea. In December, following claims of election hacking, then-President Barack Obama expelled 35 diplomats and closed two Russian compounds in the US.

The Kremlin has demanded the return of the seized compounds and has threatened "specific measures" in retaliation. However, the new US bill would make it difficult for Trump to alter sanctions or return diplomatic properties without the approval of Congress.

During his presidential campaign, Trump hinted he would consider recognizing Crimea as part of Russia and suggested lifting sanctions. The bill's passage would make it harder for him to do so.

In another development, Russia's ambassador to the US, Sergei Kislyak, has returned home after ending his nine-year tenure. Kislyak has been linked to several of Trump's associates and has been named by US media as a key figure in the investigation into alleged election interference. His successor has not yet been named.

US authorities continue to investigate possible collusion between the Trump team and Russia, which Trump has repeatedly denied. In a new twist, reports emerged that Trump is considering presidential pardons for family members, aides, and even himself. Presidents have the power to pardon people before guilt is established or even before the person is charged with a crime.

Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat who sits on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, described the reports as disturbing, adding, "Pardoning any individuals who may have been involved would be crossing a fundamental line."

Title: Former Trump Fixer Michael Cohen Says He Knew Payments Were Wrong, Blames Trump for Campaign-Finance Violations

Michael Cohen, the former personal lawyer and fixer of former US President Donald Trump, has made explosive claims about his time working for Trump. In an interview with ABC News' George Stephanopoulos, Cohen stated that Trump instructed him to pay off Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal, and that he knew the payments were wrong. Cohen also claimed that Trump was concerned about how the payments would affect the election.

According to Cohen, Trump directed him to make the payments and become involved in the matters. He stated, "He knows the truth. I know the truth. Others know the truth. And here is the truth: people of the United States of America, people of the world, don't believe what he is saying. The man doesn't tell the truth. And it's sad that I should take responsibility for his dirty deeds."

Cohen's assertions have raised concerns about Trump's legal liability and the possibility of impeachment. In November, Cohen pleaded guilty to tax fraud and campaign-finance violations and began cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Cohen's claims have also led Trump's legal team to shift their defense, with Trump himself denying any wrongdoing and claiming that the payments were "peanut stuff" that was "very legal & very cool."

Title: Vice President Mike Pence Visits Mayo Clinic Without Wearing Mask, Despite Facility's Mask Policy

Vice President Mike Pence visited the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, on April 28, 2020, without wearing a mask, despite the facility's policy requiring all patients, visitors, and staff to wear a face covering or mask to slow the spread of Covid-19. The Mayo Clinic had informed Pence of its policy before his tour, but it is unclear why he chose not to wear a mask.

Pence, who leads President Donald Trump's coronavirus task force, suggested that he did not need to wear a mask because he is tested regularly for the virus and does not have it.
