Additionally, she has acknowledged her vote for the Iraq War as a "mistake" and now supports granting driver's licenses to illegal immigrants.

Clinton's opponents, such as Senator Bernie Sanders, have criticized her for what they see as a lack of consistency and authenticity. Sanders, who is also running for the Democratic nomination, has emphasized his consistent opposition to trade deals and his willingness to stand up to corporate interests.

Clinton's shifts in stance have been met with criticism from some who see her as trying to adapt to changing public opinion. However, her campaign has emphasized that her new positions reflect her growth and learning from past experiences.

In the 2008 campaign, Clinton was a supporter of the Iraq War and opposed same-sex marriage. She also supported the Second Amendment and opposed states issuing driver's licenses to illegal immigrants. In contrast, her 2020 campaign has seen her evolve on these issues, reflecting a more liberal platform.

Clinton's evolution on these issues has been met with criticism from some who see her as trying to adapt to changing public opinion. However, her campaign has emphasized that her new positions reflect her growth and learning from past experiences.

Title: Democrats and Progressives Must Learn to Work Together for Effective Policy-Making

Article:

In a recent column, E.J. Dionne, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and Washington Post columnist, highlights the need for Democrats and progressives to work together to address the country's pressing issues. Dionne notes that the Republican Party has become increasingly radicalized, opposing almost any government action to solve problems, and that the substantive part of many policy debates now takes place within the Democratic Party.

Dionne argues that progressives and moderate Democrats agree on more than they disagree, and that both sides would be more effective if they were open to learning from each other, rather than engaging in "unseemly moralism" and political superiority complexes. He acknowledges that progressives have a valid point that moderate Democrats have often allowed conservatives to dictate the terms of the political conversation, and that they have focused too much on designing technocratic policies rather than creating popular programs.

On the other hand, moderate Democrats are correct that every great progressive victory in American history has required compromise and persuading allies who disagree with them on other issues. Dionne suggests that both sides need to recognize that the other is not the enemy and that they can accomplish more by working together.

In the short term, the dilemma is that the party can only nominate one person, but before that choice is made, Dionne recommends that both sides take a step back and reflect on the strengths of the other side. For progressives, this means recognizing that moderate congressional candidates performed better in swing districts in 2018 and celebrating the progressivism of candidates like Pete Buttigieg's agenda.

Title: Former President George H.W. Bush's Funeral and Memorial Services Announced

The funeral and memorial services for former President George H.W. Bush, who passed away at the age of 94, have been detailed in a schedule released by the White House. The ceremonies will take place in Houston, Washington, D.C., and College Station, Texas, and will involve members of both the House and Senate, as well as the President and other dignitaries.

According to the schedule, Bush will lie in state at the U.S. Capitol on Monday, with an arrival ceremony at 4:45 p.m. ET. He will remain in the rotunda until Wednesday morning. A funeral service will be held at the National Cathedral in Washington on Wednesday at 11 a.m. ET, followed by a lying-in-repose ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston from 7:45 p.m. ET on Wednesday to 7 a.m. ET on Thursday.

A second memorial service will be held at the church on Thursday at 11 a.m. ET. Afterward, a motorcade will transport Bush's body to the Union Pacific Railroad Westfield Auto Facility, from where a funeral train will take him to Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, where he will be laid to rest. Bush will be buried next to his wife, Barbara Bush, who passed away in April, and their daughter, Robin Bush, who died in 1953 at the age of 3.

The Bush family has requested that donations be made to the Bush School of Government and Public Service at Texas A&M University in lieu of flowers, with the goal of perpetuating the former president's legacy of public service with integrity. More information about the funeral arrangements can be found on a tribute website for the former president.

Title: Wages Remain Flat Despite Economic Recovery, Autoworkers' Pay Falls

The US economy has officially recovered from the Great Recession, with General Motors and Chrysler saved through federal intervention. However, wages have barely budged since 2008, with the average hourly wage increasing by just 42 cents over the past four years to $23.41, according to Labor Department figures. This stagnation is particularly pronounced in the auto industry, where wages have fallen for those on the production line.

According to the latest government figures, autoworkers made an average of $21.65 an hour in April, which is $1.52 less after adjusting for inflation than they earned in 2008. This difference adds up over time, with workers losing more than $3,000 over the course of a year.

Economists attribute the lack of wage growth to the high unemployment rate of 8.2%, which allows companies to hire workers at lower wages. Many economists project that it will take years for wages to rise significantly, as the unemployment rate would need to return to its "natural" rate of around 5-6% for wages to increase.

The low salaries also reinforce a fragile economy, as consumers are unable to spend or invest in ways that drive economic growth. As a result, economists are forecasting modest growth of around 2.2% this year.

The issue has not gone unnoticed, with Mitt Romney's campaign highlighting the statistic in response to President Barack Obama's statement that the "private sector is doing fine." The Romney campaign argued that families whose household income has dropped by $4,300 are not "doing fine."

The situation is a concern for many economists, with Sherry Cooper, chief economist and executive vice president at the BMO Financial Group, stating that it is "unprecedented how modest the wage gains have been over this recovery... It's painful for consumers and detrimental for labor."

Title: Cruz's Conservative Base Shows Signs of Fragmentation in South Carolina Primary

The South Carolina primary results have dealt a blow to Ted Cruz's claim to be the sole conservative candidate capable of uniting the base. Despite spending months trying to lock down the evangelical vote, Cruz finished third behind Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, with Trump taking 33% of the evangelical vote and Cruz taking 27%. Rubio received 22% of the evangelical vote.

The results suggest that Cruz's message of being the only strong conservative candidate may not be resonating with all conservative and evangelical voters. Penny Nance, head of Concerned Women for America, stated that the results throw into question Cruz's status as the front-runner. Timothy Head, executive director of the Faith and Freedom Coalition, noted that the evangelical vote doesn't solely vote on historically socially conservative issues, and that it's still unclear which candidate will coalesce around.

Cruz still maintains strong support from movement conservative leaders, including Tony Perkins and James Dobson, who are backing him because they believe he can go the distance. However, the South Carolina results show that Cruz's message may not be translating with conservative and evangelical primary voters.

As the race heads into March 1 and the South, Cruz's campaign is bracing for a long race over a splintered electorate unwilling to coalesce around one conservative standard-bearer. Rubio and Trump also have paths in states similar to South Carolina, and Trump comes in with a head of steam. The Cruz campaign has set expectations high for March 1, but their backers are now bracing for a long and challenging race.

Title: World Health Organization Warns Young People to Avoid Socializing and Communicating with Vulnerable Groups Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

The World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a warning to young people, emphasizing the importance of avoiding socializing and communicating with older, more vulnerable individuals to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 respiratory illness. According to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the choices made by young people can be the difference between life and death for someone else.

The warning comes as the global death toll from COVID-19 surpasses 11,000, with over 4,000 deaths reported in Italy alone. The country has seen a significant increase in cases, with 627 deaths reported on Friday, making it the deadliest day since the outbreak began.

Many countries and regions have taken new measures to combat the spread of the virus, including the UK, US, Spain, Germany, and Indonesia. The UK has announced the closure of cafes, pubs, and restaurants, while the US has closed its borders with Mexico and Canada to most traffic. Spain has warned that army patrols will detain people without good reason, and Germany's second most populous state, Bavaria, has imposed a lockdown. Indonesia has declared a state of emergency in the capital city of Jakarta, shutting down bars, cinemas, and other businesses.

Tedros emphasized that while older people are most affected by the virus, young people are not immune and can still be infected. He urged young people to take precautions and avoid putting others at risk. "You are not invincible, this virus could put you in hospital for weeks or even kill you. Even if you don't get sick, the choices you make about where you go could be the difference between life and death for someone else," he said.

The WHO is now recommending "physical distance" instead of "social distancing" to help prevent transmission of the virus. Dr. Maria Kerkhove, a WHO epidemiologist, emphasized the importance of staying connected through the internet and social media to maintain mental health during the pandemic.

Title: Obamacare-Related Policy Cancellations and Job Losses Expected to Continue

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has led to millions of Americans receiving policy cancellation notices since its implementation in 2013. By the end of that year, over 5 million people had lost their insurance due to the new law making their plans illegal. Healthcare experts estimate that nearly 80-100 million private and employer-provided policies will eventually be cancelled as a result of Obamacare.

According to Stan Veuger of the American Enterprise Institute, at least half of the people on employer plans will start losing their plans by 2014. There are approximately 157 million employer health care policy holders. Avik Roy of the Manhattan Institute added that the administration estimated that approximately 78 million Americans with employer-sponsored insurance would lose their existing coverage due to the Affordable Care Act.

A recent analysis by the American Enterprise Institute showed that the administration anticipates half to two-thirds of small businesses would have policies canceled or be compelled to send workers onto the ObamaCare exchanges. The analysis predicted up to 100 million small and large business policies could be canceled next year.

The Congressional Budget Office has released new numbers showing that Obamacare will not only kill health plans but also millions of jobs. The administration has not admitted that promising the American people they could keep their health plans under Obamacare was one of its biggest mistakes. Half of voters believe the president knowingly lied about people being able to keep their plans.

It is essential to note that the exact number of policy cancellations and job losses is still uncertain, as some information is unavailable. However, the available data suggests that the impact of Obamacare on health insurance and employment will continue to be significant in the coming years.

Title: GOP Congressmen Introduce Resolution Calling for Special Counsel Robert Mueller to Resign from Russia Probe

A group of three Republican congressmen, led by Rep. Matt Gaetz, have introduced a resolution calling for Special Counsel Robert Mueller to resign from the Russia collusion probe. The resolution cites Mueller's ties to the FBI and its role in controversies involving Russia. The congressmen, including Gaetz, Rep. Andy Biggs, and Rep. Louie Gohmert, argue that Mueller's impartiality is compromised due to his supervision of a bribery probe involving a subsidiary of Russia's Rosatom and the approval of a deal allowing Russia to buy a Canadian mining company, Uranium One, which controlled a significant portion of American uranium reserves.

Gaetz stated that evidence has emerged that the FBI withheld information from Congress and the American people about Russian corruption of American uranium companies. He pointed to a confidential U.S. witness, who worked in the Russian nuclear industry, revealing that Russia had deeply compromised an American uranium trucking firm through bribery and financial kickbacks. The witness was required to sign a non-disclosure agreement, which was only lifted by the Justice Department last week, allowing him to provide information to Congress.

The congressmen are seeking answers about how the deal was approved despite the evidence gathered in the bribery probe, which was supervised by Mueller when he was FBI director. They are also questioning the FBI's handling of the case, including the gag order placed on the confidential witness.

The resolution comes as Mueller's team announced the first charges in their investigation into Russian meddling and potential collusion with Trump campaign officials in the 2016 presidential election. Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his associate Rick Gates were indicted on 12 counts, while former Trump foreign policy campaign volunteer George Papadopoulos entered a guilty plea.

The proposed resolution is not the only recent development in the Russia probe. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley has called for an independent special counsel to investigate the Obama-era Uranium One deal. Two pieces of legislation in the Senate, with bipartisan sponsorship, would ensure a judicial check on the executive branch's ability to remove a special counsel.

Title: Senator Lindsey Graham Presses Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein on Potential Recusal from Mueller Investigation

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham, a top Republican from South Carolina, has written a letter to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, questioning whether he should recuse himself from the Robert Mueller investigation due to his own connections to the case. The letter, obtained by Fox News, asks whether Rosenstein considers himself a "potential witness" in the Mueller probe in connection with the firing of FBI Director James Comey.

Graham's letter cites reports that Mueller's investigation is looking into whether President Trump obstructed justice by firing Comey, and the fact that Trump relied on a Rosenstein-authored memo to justify the firing. The memo, written by ousted FBI official Andrew McCabe, details a meeting where Rosenstein claimed Trump asked him to reference Russia in his recommendation to fire Comey. Trump has denied this, stating that he fired Comey due to his handling of the Hillary Clinton email probe.

A source with knowledge of the investigation told Fox News that Trump wanted Rosenstein to mention that Comey told him he was not under investigation in the Russia case. Trump has cited the Russia probe in explaining his decision to fire Comey, which could fuel the obstruction of justice component of Mueller's probe.

The new pressure on Rosenstein comes as Trump continues to criticize Attorney General Jeff Sessions for his decision to recuse himself from the Russia probe, which handed the reins to Rosenstein. Trump has expressed disappointment with Sessions' decision and has said he wishes he had picked another nominee for attorney general.

Title: Kentucky's Efforts to Reform Criminal Justice System Offer Lessons for Washington

Article:

Kentucky's efforts to reform its criminal justice system have garnered attention for their innovative approach to rehabilitation and reintegration. As a state, Kentucky has traditionally had a high incarceration rate, with a significant portion of its population behind bars. However, the state's governor, Matt Bevin, has taken steps to address this issue by introducing reforms aimed at reducing recidivism and promoting second chances.

The state's new expungement law, passed in the latest legislative session, allows certain non-violent offenders who have served their sentence and completed a crime-free period to have their records expunged. This move is seen as a step towards giving individuals a fresh start and reducing the stigma associated with incarceration.

Kentucky's efforts are not limited to legislation alone. The state has also established a 23-member Criminal Justice Policy Assessment Council, comprising a diverse range of stakeholders, including prosecutors, public defenders, faith-based and business leaders, state lawmakers, and local leaders. The council is conducting a thorough review of the state's criminal justice system and recommending reforms to make it more effective and less costly.

The task force's recommendations will be presented as legislation before the 2017 session of the Kentucky General Assembly. The goal is to identify real solutions to address the burgeoning cost of Kentucky's $500 million correctional system and its myriad shortcomings.

Kentucky's approach is not unique, as other states, such as Georgia and Oklahoma, have also seen success with smart justice reforms. The state's governor, Matt Bevin, has joined forces with his counterparts in these states to promote a new style of justice that seeks to rehabilitate offenders, not simply remove them from society.

The success of Kentucky's reforms has sparked interest in other states, with the hope that Congress will follow suit and pass similar reforms at the federal level. The message is clear: it's time for a new approach to criminal justice, one that prioritizes rehabilitation and reintegration over punishment and incarceration.

Title: Medicare and Healthcare Programs Receive Changes in Fiscal Cliff Deal

The recently passed bill that averted the fiscal cliff had significant implications for Medicare and healthcare programs. In addition to preventing income tax increases and delaying across-the-board spending cuts, the bill included provisions that tweaked Medicare and brought changes to other healthcare programs.

One notable change was the delay of a 27% cut in Medicare payments to doctors, which was seen as a major concern by the American College of Physicians. The organization's president, David Bronson, stated that such a cut would devastate access to healthcare for seniors. While the delay is a welcome relief, doctors are still hopeful that a more permanent solution will be found to address the flawed payment formula, which has been delayed since 2002.

Hospitals, on the other hand, are unhappy about the "doc fix" being paid for by cutting $15 billion in Medicare and Medicaid payments over the next 10 years. In the short term, doctors are concerned about the potential impact of the sequester, which could lead to cuts in graduate medical education programs.

Another healthcare program that was eliminated as part of the fiscal cliff deal was the CLASS Act, a program aimed at providing publicly administered, long-term care insurance. The program was originally part of the 2010 health law, but was put on hold in 2011 due to controversy. While some saw it as a necessary program, others viewed it as a new and potentially unlimited government program. The program was eventually replaced with a bipartisan commission tasked with finding ways to help Americans pay for long-term care.

The fate of Medicare and healthcare programs remains uncertain, with the 113th Congress likely to face more budget battles in the coming months. The lack of a Medicare entitlement fix on the table means that the start of the new Congress is likely to be rocky.

Title: Buildings Collapse in Mexico City's Condesa Neighborhood, Rescue Efforts Underway

A devastating earthquake struck the fashionable Condesa neighborhood in Mexico City, causing widespread destruction and chaos. The eight-story apartment building on Laredo Street collapsed, leaving a massive heap of concrete and rubble in its wake. At least 100 people are working together to clear the debris, piece by piece, using a human chain to pass heavy objects along.

The scene is one of devastation, with the sound of shouts and orders filling the air as rescue efforts continue. Officials estimate that around 10 people may be trapped inside the structure, and a backhoe is being used to dig into the remains. Helicopters are also overhead, providing support to the rescue efforts.

Witnesses described the terrifying scene as the building collapsed, with people trying to escape before it fell. "It fell straight down," said Moises Escobar, a 25-year-old recent college graduate. "There was a lot of smoke and dust."

Despite the chaos, a sense of community and solidarity has emerged, with neighbors and passersby joining together to help with the rescue efforts. A man was seen racing down Amsterdam Street, searching for tools to aid in the rescue, and a hacksaw was eventually obtained to help cut through wood and metal. "I work near here, but we have to help," he said. "It's our country."

The disaster has brought the community together, with many people putting aside their daily routines to help those affected. The rescue efforts are ongoing, and the full extent of the damage and casualties is still being assessed.

Title: States Offer Limited Protections to Grocery Workers Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

As the coronavirus continues to spread, grocery workers have been at the forefront of the pandemic, working tirelessly to ensure the public has access to essential goods. In response, some states have taken steps to provide protections to these essential workers, but the measures are limited and varied.

Last month, Minnesota and Vermont classified grocery clerks as emergency workers, qualifying them for free child care. Since then, over a dozen states have followed suit, offering free, subsidized, or income-dependent child care to grocery workers. This brings the total number of states providing this benefit to 20.

Despite these efforts, many grocery workers are still at risk of infection and are calling for more protections. At least 41 grocery workers have died from the coronavirus, according to the Washington Post. The United Food and Commercial Workers union, along with major supermarket chains Kroger and Albertsons, have been advocating for federal and state officials to designate grocery workers as first responders, giving them priority access to masks and gloves. They are also pushing for mandatory guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to require sanitation, social distancing, and personal protective equipment in grocery stores.

David Madland, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, believes that designating grocery workers as first responders is a step in the right direction but still falls short. "Essential workers need more than just masks and gloves," he said. "They need a broad set of protections to enable them to safely go to work." Madland supports the Essential Workers Bill of Rights, proposed by Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.), which would mandate protective equipment, sick leave, child care, health care, and a pay raise for essential employees like grocery workers.

In the absence of federal protections, workers' protections are set by the companies they work for and state and local governments. While some states have issued guidance for grocery stores to limit the number of customers and enforce social distancing in lines, only a handful have taken action to provide grocery workers with personal protective equipment. Massachusetts has made free, priority coronavirus testing available to grocery workers, while California expanded paid sick time to food sector workers and granted grocery workers the right to wash their hands every 30 minutes. Nevada and Maryland have also granted grocery workers the right to wash their hands every 30 minutes.

Title: Pro-Life Organization Live Action Accuses YouTube and Pinterest of Discrimination Against Anti-Abortion Content

Article:

Live Action, a prominent pro-life organization, has sent cease and desist letters to YouTube and Pinterest, alleging discrimination against its anti-abortion content on both platforms. The organization claims that YouTube has failed to publish its video ads, breached its contract, and caused financial losses. Additionally, Pinterest banned Live Action from its platform in June, citing its content as "pornographic." Live Action's lawyers argue that the decision was a "kneejerk reaction" and a "poorly thought-out pretext for speech suppression."

YouTube has acknowledged the concerns raised by Live Action and is investigating the matter. Pinterest has not responded to the organization's letter. The letters sent by Live Action's lawyers state that litigation is likely to ensue if the issues are not addressed.

Live Action's founder and president, Lila Rose, expressed disappointment and frustration with the actions taken by YouTube and Pinterest. "It is truly sad and disheartening that in a society built on the principles of freedom of speech and assembly, companies like YouTube and Pinterest, who clearly benefit from these first principles of American culture, are engaging in not-so-subtle tactics to suppress speech with which they disagree," Rose said.

Live Action's attorney, Harmeet Dhillon of the Dhillon Law Group, emphasized that YouTube and Pinterest are "clearly in violation of the law" and must remedy the situation. The evidence in both cases, according to Dhillon, includes suppression of speech, breach of contract, censorship, and banning of Live Action based on false claims.

This is not the first time Live Action has accused a social media platform of discrimination. Last week, the organization accused Facebook of labeling its claim that "abortion is never medically necessary" as "false" and "inaccurate." The implications of these actions, according to Rose, extend beyond the pro-life movement to free speech in America.

Title: Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearings: Five Constitutional Questions to Address

The Senate Judiciary Committee will hold confirmation hearings this week on the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to serve as an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court. As a respected federal judge, Kavanaugh has many admirers in conservative legal circles. However, there are still several unanswered questions regarding his jurisprudence. Here are five matters that the Senate Judiciary Committee should address during the hearings.

Firstly, the use of recreational marijuana is legal in multiple states, but it remains banned at the federal level. The Supreme Court has upheld the federal ban as a lawful exercise of Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce. However, this raises questions about the scope of Congress's authority to regulate local activities that do not cross state lines. Should the federal government have the power to ban an activity that is legal under state law, even if it does not affect interstate commerce?

Secondly, the Trump administration has taken the stance that certain executive orders, including those related to national security, are beyond the reach of judicial review. This raises questions about the extent to which the federal courts should defer to the executive branch when it claims to be acting in the name of national security. Should the courts give the executive branch a "free pass" when it comes to national security decisions, or should they exercise their judicial review powers to ensure that these decisions align with the Constitution?

Thirdly, the Constitution lists certain individual rights, such as the right to free speech and the right to bear arms, but it also refers to rights that are not explicitly listed. The Supreme Court has recognized and protected unenumerated rights, including the right to privacy and the right to gay marriage. However, some argue that the Court should not recognize unenumerated rights, as they are not explicitly mentioned in the Constitution. Should the Court continue to recognize and protect unenumerated rights, or should it limit its role to only enforcing explicitly listed rights?

Fourthly, in his dissent in Seven-Sky v. Holder, Kavanaugh argued that the federal courts should have abstained from ruling on the constitutional merits of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act because it was a legislative effort that deserved respect. He wrote that courts should be "cautious" about prematurely rejecting the government's Commerce Clause argument in defense of Obamacare. What are the criteria for determining when the judiciary should "afford great respect" to lawmakers and avoid "upending" their legislative efforts?

Lastly, in 2015, Kavanaugh wrote that the National Security Agency's bulk metadata collection program was "entirely consistent with the Fourth Amendment." However, this raises questions about whether the Fourth Amendment suffers a violation when the federal government engages in the wholesale warrantless collection of every American's telephone record metadata. Should the Fourth Amendment protect individuals from government surveillance, or does it only apply in specific circumstances?

The American people deserve to hear Brett Kavanaugh's thoughts on these crucial constitutional issues. The members of the Senate Judiciary Committee should ask him about them during his SCOTUS confirmation hearings this week.

Title: House Pro-Choice Caucus to Support Bipartisan Medicare Deal Despite Abortion Funding Ban

The House's pro-choice caucus has announced its intention to support a bipartisan deal to overhaul Medicare payments, despite the inclusion of a ban on using federal funds for abortion. The compromise, struck by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Speaker John A. Boehner, aims to repeal the Sustainable Growth Rate (SGR) formula, which has been overridden by Congress annually.

The SGR formula, which determines Medicare payments to healthcare providers, is set to expire on April 1, prompting concerns about a 21% cut in reimbursements for doctors. Top Democrats and Republicans have expressed support for scrapping the formula permanently.

The abortion debate centers on a ban on funding for community health centers, which has already stalled a Senate bill aimed at combating human trafficking. The ban is part of the Hyde Amendment, a temporary rider that expires annually. Pro-choice leaders, including Reps. Diana DeGette and Louise Slaughter, have expressed their distaste for the ban, but will support the bipartisan deal.

In a statement, the pro-choice caucus chairs emphasized that the language included in the compromise does not further restrict women's access to abortion and will expire along with funding, similar to the current Hyde Amendment. They encouraged other members of the pro-choice caucus to support the deal.

The compromise has been met with mixed reactions, with some lawmakers expressing concerns about the abortion funding ban. Rep. Michael Burgess, a Texas Republican and lead author of the SGR-repeal bill, said that while there may be reasons to oppose the deal, there are also many reasons to support it.

Title: Trump Children's Hypocrisy on Hunter Biden's Business Ties Raises Questions

The Trump children, Eric and Donald Trump Jr., have been accused of hypocrisy for attacking Hunter Biden's business ties, despite their own family's questionable dealings. The Trumps have been trying to spin Hunter Biden's involvement with the Ukrainian natural gas company Burisma into a scandal, claiming he leveraged his family name to secure a $50,000-a-month gig. However, the Trump children themselves have been responsible for the Trump Organization, which has business interests in over 30 countries and has generated $9.5 billion in revenue.

The Trumps have also accused Hunter Biden of cashing in on his family name in China, but the Trump Organization has received a $500 billion infusion from a state-owned Chinese construction company for a project in Indonesia. Ivanka Trump has also received trademarks from China, including some for voting machines, and her husband, Jared Kushner, received a massive cash infusion from Qatar.

The Trump children's hypocrisy is staggering, as they attack Hunter Biden for alleged profiteering from corruption, while their own family has been accused of corruption by more than 20 women. The Trumps have also been accused of violating their father's pledge to do no new foreign deals while in office.

The Trump children's actions are a clear example of the double standard they are trying to apply to Hunter Biden's business dealings. The Trumps are trying to turn corruption into a central issue in the 2020 election, but their own family's actions are a stark reminder of the hypocrisy and shamelessness they are guilty of.

Title: Trump's Tax-Cut Plan: A Bid to Boost Economic Growth and Prosperity

The Trump administration has launched a renewed push for tax cuts, with President Trump emphasizing the potential for faster economic growth and increased take-home pay. The plan aims to slash large and small business tax rates, double the standard deduction for middle-income individuals, simplify the tax code, and repeal the death tax and alternative minimum tax. While Democrats have criticized the plan as a handout to the wealthy, Trump has appealed to bipartisanship, citing the success of similar tax cuts under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan.

The Trump plan would reduce corporate tax rates from 35% to 20%, providing a 23% incentive reward for businesses. This, according to supply-side economist Art Laffer, would reduce tax avoidance and sheltering, and boost productivity. The plan also includes 100% expensing write-offs for new investment and the repatriation of trillions of dollars in U.S. company funds currently held overseas.

On the individual side, the plan doubles the standard deduction, which would benefit young millennials and those without mortgages or homes. The plan also reduces income-tax rates from seven to three brackets and cuts income-tax rates in general, providing additional supply-side incentives.

The Republican party is under pressure to pass the tax-cut bill, with the Trump administration urging lawmakers to "play hardball" and overcome procedural hurdles. The plan is expected to be polished and fine-tuned to pass the Senate with 51 votes.

Title: Rand Paul's National Security Speech: A Mixed Bag of Ideas

Rand Paul, a senator known for his isolationist and conspiracy-laden views, has attempted to reinvent himself with a new platform of "conservative realism." On Friday, he delivered a national security stump speech in New York, unveiling his vision for a more engaged America on the world stage. While some aspects of the speech were welcome, others raised concerns.

Paul's speech included some positive elements, such as his acknowledgment that the United States cannot disengage from the world. This is a departure from his previous stance as a proponent of libertarianism, which emphasizes American detachment from international affairs. However, the speech was also marked by significant omissions, including no mention of Israel, the border, or immigration.

The senator did express admiration for the US military's efforts in the weeks following the 9/11 attacks, when a small group of Special Operators and local forces successfully defeated the Taliban and routed Al Qaeda. He also criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Libyan intervention, stating that it lacked a clear strategy and Congressional consent.

However, Paul's speech was also criticized for its lack of clarity and coherence. In a week marked by terrorist attacks in Canada and New York, one would expect a strong and forthright response to the threat posed by jihadism. Instead, Paul framed the issue as a "dignity problem" in the Middle East, where millions of men and women are treated as chattel by their governments.

This argument has been criticized for its lack of substance and its failure to acknowledge the responsibility of terrorist groups and their governments. Paul's statement that "the world does not have an Islam problem, the world has a dignity problem" has been seen as a misguided attempt to shift the blame away from the perpetrators of terrorism.

The article concludes that Paul's speech was neither a genuine about-turn nor a coherent plan for national security. Instead, it was a confused and disingenuous attempt to rebrand himself as a champion of national security.

Title: Politico Corrects Story Claiming Trump Owes Millions to Bank of China

Politico recently updated an article claiming that President Donald Trump currently owes millions of dollars to the Bank of China, stating that the loan is due soon. However, the publication was forced to correct its story after it was determined that Trump does not currently owe the Bank of China millions of dollars.

The original article was updated to include a statement from the Bank of China and additional reporting. The updated article now admits that the Bank of China sold its debt on the building weeks after the 2012 loan, and Vornado Realty Trust owns 70% of the building.

According to Peter Reisman, managing director and chief communications officer of Bank of China U.S.A., the loan was securitized and sold into the commercial mortgage-backed securities market within 22 days of its issuance on November 7, 2012. The Bank of China has not had any ownership interest in the loan since late November 2012.

The article still attempts to connect Trump's response to the novel coronavirus, stating that the Trump campaign has increased its focus on portraying Biden as weak on China amid rising voter disapproval of China, the source of the pandemic.

Politico stood by the report, stating that it was based on multiple publicly available documents, including a 2017 filing with the city of New York that remains current through 2022. The loan and the Bank of China's participation in the financing of the property at 1290 Avenue of the Americas are part of the public record.

The publication included an on-the-record statement from the Bank of China's NY-based PR representative, which stated that the Bank had sold the debt shortly after the 2012 deal. The updated article and headline reflected this new reporting, and the changes were prominently flagged atop the article.

Title: Essential Service Workers Continue to Operate Amid Dallas County Shelter-in-Place Order

As Dallas County residents are under a shelter-in-place order, essential service workers like plumbers, HVAC technicians, and electricians are still going about their jobs, relying on customers to keep them safe. These workers are taking precautions to minimize the risk of spreading COVID-19, and are asking customers to notify them if anyone in the household is feeling ill or showing symptoms.

Benjamin Franklin Plumbing, a company with nearly 150 employees, is continuing to provide services, but is asking customers to inform them if anyone in the home is quarantined. The company is also providing employees with inoculations to protect themselves from unhealthy environments. Baker Brothers, another company, is giving employees permission to refuse service if they feel customers are not forthcoming about potential illness or if they are uncomfortable with a job.

To minimize the risk of transmission, employees are following guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, maintaining six feet of distance from customers, wearing protective gear, and disinfecting equipment between jobs. Berkeys Air Conditioning, Plumbing & Electrical is also taking precautions, including performing touchless payment transactions and sending invoices to customers.

The shelter-in-place order has also put an unusual strain on home plumbing systems, with an uptick in service calls for clogged plumbing, likely due to residents flushing non-toilet paper products. Benjamin Franklin plumbers are even leaving complimentary toilet paper at homes they service to help alleviate the issue.

Title: Treasury Department Denies Claims of Delay in Stimulus Checks Due to President Trump's Name

The Treasury Department has denied claims that the addition of President Donald Trump's name to stimulus checks will cause a delay in their delivery. The claims were made by The Washington Post, which reported that the process of adding Trump's name to the checks could slow their delivery by a few days.

However, Treasury Department officials have confirmed that the checks will be issued on schedule, with the first batch expected to be sent out early next week. A Treasury Department spokeswoman stated that the plan was always to issue the checks next week, and that the addition of Trump's name will not cause any delay.

Multiple Treasury Department officials confirmed to an anonymous source that the claims of a delay are inaccurate. One official confirmed that Trump's name will appear on the paper checks, and there will be no delay to make that happen.

The Treasury Department's denial of the delay has been met with criticism from some on the left, who have used the story to attack President Trump. However, the claims of a delay have been debunked, and the Treasury Department has confirmed that the checks will be issued on schedule.

It is worth noting that most Americans will receive their stimulus checks directly deposited into their bank accounts, as the IRS has their direct deposit information on file. However, some Americans will receive paper checks, which will be mailed to them. The Treasury Department has confirmed that these checks will be issued ahead of schedule, despite the addition of Trump's name.

Title: White House and Republicans at Odds Over Fiscal Cliff Plan

The White House and Republican leaders are at an impasse over a plan to avoid the fiscal cliff, with both sides expressing frustration and skepticism about the other's proposals. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner presented a plan to GOP leaders yesterday, which was described as "absurd" by a top Republican aide. The plan would raise taxes on the wealthy and reduce spending, but Republicans argue it is "completely unrealistic" and "a break with reality."

A 30-minute phone call between Speaker John Boehner and President Obama on Wednesday night was described as "unproductive" and "blunt," with the president reiterating his stance that tax rates must increase for the wealthy. The White House has emphasized that the president is willing to make tough compromises, but Republicans are pushing back against the proposal.

Boehner's office has outlined six reasons why the White House's plan won't fly, including that it would raise taxes by twice as much as the president's original proposal, and that it would not include sufficient spending cuts. The White House, on the other hand, argues that the plan is a balanced approach that asks the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share.

With just 33 days until the end of the year, President Obama is taking his case to the American people, visiting a toy manufacturing facility in Pennsylvania today to highlight the impact of the fiscal cliff on middle-class consumers. The White House says the president will continue to make the case for action, emphasizing that the current plan would raise taxes on 98% of Americans if no deal is reached.

Title: Federal Authorities Investigate Orlando Nightclub Massacre, Wife's Possible Involvement, and Mateen's Radicalization

Federal authorities are working to determine whether Omar Mateen acted alone in the Orlando nightclub massacre that killed 49 people and wounded 53 others. The investigation is focused on whether Mateen had any accomplices or if anyone knew of his deadly plans. A grand jury has been convened to investigate Mateen's wife, Noor Salman, who could face charges as an accessory.

FBI agents have interviewed Salman, who is reportedly cooperating with the investigation. However, formal charges could ensure she provides all the information she knows. The FBI has refused to comment on the investigation outside of official media briefings.

The investigation is also exploring Mateen's radicalization and potential ties to radical Muslims in the U.S. and abroad. Mateen's wife, Noor Salman, grew up in Rodeo, California, and the FBI visited her childhood home on Tuesday. Salman has been referred to as Mateen's wife, but the only proof of their marriage is a 2013 mortgage document and family members who said the two were married and had a 3-year-old son.

The FBI is also investigating Mateen's two trips to Saudi Arabia in 2011 and 2012, which could be a sign of his growing religious devotion. However, experts are skeptical that a working-class Muslim-American would make the pilgrimage twice in two years, and it's possible that the trips could have been used for terror training.

The FBI has seized a computer, camera, and other equipment from Mateen's condominium in Fort Pierce, Florida. It's unclear whether Mateen received direction or inspiration from the Islamic State (ISIS), but Fox News reported that Mateen was acquainted with another radicalized terrorist who left Florida for Syria and blew himself up in 2014.

The investigation is also probing Mateen's ties to Dwayne Robertson, a former New York gang leader who resurfaced in Orlando as an imam and is suspected of radicalizing Americans and sending them abroad to kill. Robertson denies inciting violent jihad.

As the investigation continues, more information is emerging about Mateen's background, including reports that he had been seen at the Pulse nightclub many times and had contacted someone using a dating app popular with the gay community. His first wife reportedly believes Mateen was a closeted gay man.

Title: Obama Responds to Racial Comments, Reflecting His Unique Position as the Nation's First Black President

Article:

President Obama recently responded to racial comments allegedly made by Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers basketball team, during a press conference in Malaysia. The comments, which were reported by TMZ, were said to be made by Sterling to his girlfriend, instructing her not to bring black people to his team's games. Obama's response was straightforward, stating that the comments "speak for themselves" and that "ignorant folks want to advertise their ignorance."

As the nation's first black president, Obama's responses to racial incidents have been closely watched and scrutinized. His comments on the Sterling controversy are just the latest in a long line of instances where he has addressed racial issues, including the Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Trayvon Martin cases. Obama's responses to these incidents have been met with both praise and criticism, with some seeing him as a leader who is tackling a crucial issue, while others view him as walking a tightrope between addressing the issue and avoiding alienating certain groups.

Obama's responses to racial incidents are often seen as a reflection of his unique position as the nation's first black president. He has been criticized for not being bold enough in his responses, with some arguing that he should be more vocal in his condemnation of racism. However, others see his approach as a careful balancing act, as he seeks to address the issue without alienating certain groups.

In this latest instance, Obama's response was seen as a straightforward condemnation of the comments, with no attempt to sugarcoat or downplay their significance. He also sought to put the incident in a larger context, noting that while the United States has made progress in addressing racial issues, there is still much work to be done.

The article also highlights the differing opinions on Obama's approach to addressing racial issues. Some see him as a leader who is tackling a crucial issue, while others view him as walking a tightrope between addressing the issue and avoiding alienating certain groups.

Title: Supreme Court's New Term to Address Abortion, Guns, and Gay Rights Amid Political Controversies

The upcoming Supreme Court term is expected to tackle several contentious issues that have sparked intense political debates in the United States. The court will consider cases related to abortion, guns, gay rights, the separation of church and state, immigration, and presidential power, among others. These cases have the potential to significantly impact American society and politics.

The court's conservative majority, led by Chief Justice John Roberts, is likely to rule in favor of reversing Roe v. Wade, expanding gun rights, and religious rights. However, the justices may also be divided on issues such as the power of Congress to obtain information from the executive branch and the structure of the presidential election system.

The court will hear a case challenging a Louisiana law that restricts access to abortion clinics, which is similar to a Texas law struck down in 2016. Tom Goldstein, publisher of SCOTUSblog, expects the conservative majority to eventually reverse Roe v. Wade or hollow it out, but the timing is uncertain.

The court will also consider a case testing the constitutionality of gun regulations, which could have significant implications for gun control advocates. The justices will also hear cases involving the separation of church and state, including challenges to provisions in state constitutions that bar direct or indirect aid to religious schools.

Another hot-button issue on the docket is the case of an employer firing an employee because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. A victory for the LGBTQ community would be significant, as discrimination against gay and trans individuals remains rampant.

The court will also address immigration cases, including the Trump administration's attempt to roll back the Obama-era program protecting "Dreamers" from deportation. Multiple cases are headed to the Supreme Court, with the president's aggressive assertions of immunity from investigations likely to be a major focus.

Finally, the court will consider a case testing the constitutionality of "faithless elector" laws, which impose penalties on Electoral College delegates or provide for the removal of electors who refuse to vote for the presidential candidate of their designated party. The outcome of this case could have significant implications for the 2020 presidential election.

The Supreme Court's new term is expected to be a significant one, with the justices tackling some of the most contentious issues in American society. While the court's conservative majority is likely to rule in favor of reversing Roe v. Wade and expanding gun rights, the justices may be divided on other issues, making the outcome uncertain.

Title: Coca-Cola Eyes Cannabis-Infused Drinks as Market Grows

Coca-Cola, the iconic beverage company, is considering entering the growing market for cannabis-infused drinks. In a statement, the company said it is "closely watching" the growth of CBD, a non-psychoactive component in marijuana, as an ingredient in functional wellness beverages. While no decisions have been made at this time, Coca-Cola's interest in the market has been reported by Bloomberg, which stated that the company is in talks with Aurora Cannabis, a Canadian cannabis company.

Aurora Cannabis has also expressed interest in cannabis drinks, with a spokesperson stating that the company believes the cannabis industry has "incredible potential." The company's interest in cannabis drinks is not surprising, given the growing demand for CBD products. CBD, which does not produce a high for the user, has been used for medical purposes, including easing inflammation, pain, and nausea.

Coca-Cola's potential entry into the cannabis market is not the only major company exploring the space. Constellation Brands, the maker of Corona beer, Svedka vodka, and Casa Noble tequila, has announced a $4 billion investment in Canopy Growth, a Canadian cannabis company. Several Canadian cannabis companies, including Cronos and MedMen Enterprises, now trade on US stock exchanges, and some American companies have taken stakes.

While cannabis and CBD are still illegal in the United States under federal law, a number of states have legalized marijuana. However, it is unlikely that Coca-Cola would offer a product infused with CBD in the United States until the federal law changes, according to Kris Krane, president of 4Front, a firm that advises companies on the legalities of marijuana. Krane believes that Coca-Cola would develop the product first for sale in Canada, readying it for the United States once it is legal.

Coca-Cola's potential entry into the cannabis market could be a significant development, given the company's global reach and brand recognition. According to Bonnie Herzog, an analyst with Wells Fargo, cannabis-infused drinks could become a $50 billion annual market in the United States, nearly half the size of the $117 billion market for US beer sales.

Title: Minneapolis Descends into Chaos as Protests Over George Floyd's Death Intensify

Article:

Minneapolis, Minnesota, has been gripped by chaos and violence as protests over the death of George Floyd, a black man who died in police custody, continue to escalate. The city's third precinct police station was evacuated and set ablaze by rioters, with police and firefighters reportedly being given orders to stand down.

The protests, which began on the second night following Floyd's death, have been marked by looting, vandalism, and clashes between protesters and law enforcement. Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has stated that he decided to evacuate the police precinct to prioritize public safety.

The incident has sparked a heated debate on social media, with President Donald Trump weighing in on the situation. Trump tweeted that he would not "stand back and watch" the city descend into chaos and threatened to send in the National Guard to restore order. He also criticized Mayor Frey for his handling of the situation.

The President's tweet was flagged by Twitter for "glorifying violence," with the platform stating that it may be in the public interest for the tweet to remain accessible. The move has sparked concerns about Twitter's handling of free speech and its role as a platform for public discourse.

The incident has also raised questions about the role of law enforcement and the response to the protests. The Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are investigating the circumstances surrounding Floyd's death, which has been deemed a top priority.

As the situation continues to unfold, it remains unclear what the future holds for Minneapolis and the country as a whole.

Title: Border Patrol Union Leader Criticizes National Guard Deployment to Mexican Border

The National Border Patrol Council, led by President Brandon Judd, has expressed disappointment with the current deployment of National Guard troops to the Mexican border. Judd, who initially supported the deployment, now believes it has been a "colossal waste of resources." According to Judd, the troops are not being utilized as effectively as they were during similar deployments under the Obama and Bush administrations.

Judd stated that the troops are stationed far from the border and are required to be stationed alongside agents, creating more work and not freeing up agents for patrols. This is in contrast to previous deployments, where troops were allowed to perform tasks such as lookout and observation posts, grading roads, and mending fences, which allowed agents to focus on their primary duties.

A Pentagon official disagreed with Judd's characterization, stating that the National Guard's usage has not changed significantly under the Trump administration compared to previous administrations. The official noted that the National Guard's role is perceived differently, but their tasks remain the same.

Acting Border Patrol Chief Carla Provost countered Judd's claims, stating that the National Guard presence does free up some agents. Typically, pairs of agents operate aerostat blimps to monitor the border remotely, and now troops can replace one person on those teams, freeing up agents to be on the front line.

Homeland Security spokeswoman Katie Waldman noted that the operation is not yet at full capacity and that more troops are on the way after a third request for assistance was recently approved. President Donald Trump's plan called for 2,000 to 4,000 National Guard troops from nearby states to support Border Patrol operations.

Title: Thai Cave Rescue: Four Boys Rescued, Eight Remain Trapped

The rescue of four young soccer players trapped in a Thai cave has brought relief to the world, but the ordeal is far from over. Eight boys, aged 11-16, and their 25-year-old coach remain trapped in the treacherous labyrinth, more than 2 miles into the Earth. The rescue effort, which began on Sunday, was put on hold for 10-20 hours to allow the dive teams to rest and restock the cave complex with oxygen and equipment.

The rescue operation was a complex and challenging task, with the boys being extracted one by one, accompanied by two divers each. The first boy emerged at 5:40 p.m. local time on Sunday, and the other three followed over the next two hours. The boys were placed in ambulances and given medical assessments before being taken to Chiang Rai Prachanukroh hospital.

The rescue effort was aided by international teams, with more than half of the 90 rescue workers coming from around the world. The Thai navy SEALs, who were involved in the rescue, wrote on Facebook, "We can have good dreams tonight."

The boys and their coach had hiked into the cave complex after a soccer practice on June 23, but heavy rains flooded some of the narrow tunnels, blocking their exit. Water levels inside the cave dropped by about a foot on Saturday, allowing rescuers to walk deeper into the cave, all the way to the "third chamber," about a mile from where the boys are.

An Australian doctor with cave diving experience examined the boys on Sunday and declared them fit for the operation. The rescue operation is expected to last through Monday, with Narongsak Osottanakorn, the governor of Chiang Rai province, saying that there is no time limit and that progress will depend on weather and conditions inside the cave.

Title: Media Bias: A Complex and Nuanced Issue

The debate about media bias is a contentious one, with both the left and right accusing each other of being more biased. In an effort to shed light on this issue, a recent podcast episode, "How Biased Is Your Media?", explores the topic of media bias and its implications. The episode features a range of media practitioners and academic scholars who have delved into the complexities of media bias.

One of the key challenges in measuring media bias is that it is expressed in words, making it difficult to quantify and analyze. To tackle this issue, researchers have employed various methods, including analyzing the language used in media outlets and comparing it to the language used by politicians and think tanks.

A 2004 paper by Tim Groseclose and Jeff Milyo, which became the basis for Groseclose's book "Left Turn: How Liberal Media Bias Distorts the American Mind", estimated the bias of media outlets based on the research they cite in their stories. The study found that most media outlets have a liberal bias, with the Wall Street Journal being the most liberal of all, even surpassing the New York Times. Fox News, on the other hand, was found to be one of the few outlets with a right-of-center bias.

A ranking of 20 major media outlets on Groseclose and Milyo's slant scale, with 100 representing the most liberal and zero the most conservative, provides a snapshot of the media landscape:

* ABC Good Morning America: 56.1
* ABC World News Tonight: 61.0
* CBS Early Show: 66.6
* CBS Evening News: 73.7
* CNN NewsNight with Aaron Brown: 56.0
* Drudge Report: 60.4
* Fox News Special Report with Brit Hume: 39.7
* Los Angeles Times: 70.0
* NBC Nightly News: 61.6
* NBC Today Show: 64.0
* New York Times: 73.7
* Newshour with Jim Lehrer: 55.8
* Newsweek: 66.3
* NPR Morning Edition: 66.3
* Time Magazine: 65.4
* U.S. News and World Report: 65.8
* USA Today: 63.4
* Wall Street Journal: 85.1
* Washington Post: 66.6
* Washington Times: 35.4

Additionally, a chart of Congressmembers' "Political Quotients", based on their voting records, provides further insight into the political leanings of various media outlets.

The University of Chicago economists Matthew Gentzkow and Jesse Shapiro have also conducted research on media bias, using text as data to analyze common Democratic and Republican phrases in Congress. Their 2010 study found that newspapers tend to lean left, and that this bias is driven by the language used in their reporting.

The debate about media bias is complex and nuanced, and this podcast episode aims to provide a balanced and informative exploration of the topic.

Title: Senate Confirms Tom Price as Secretary of Health and Human Services

The United States Senate confirmed Representative Tom Price (R-Ga.) as the new Secretary of Health and Human Services in a 52-47 vote on Friday. No Democratic senator supported Price's nomination. Despite Democratic opposition, Republicans have the majority in the Senate, allowing them to confirm the nomination.

Price's confirmation was met with strong opposition from Democrats, who argued that his positions on healthcare and Medicare are out of line with President Trump's campaign promises. Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) called Price's confirmation the "first assault in the war on seniors." Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) described Price as the "exact opposite" of what Trump campaigned on, citing Price's support for privatizing Medicare.

Price, a former chairman of the House Budget Committee, has previously expressed support for overhauling Medicare and reducing its costs through a voucher program. Democrats are likely to use Price's confirmation and his stance on Medicare to target Senators Dean Heller (R-Nev.) and Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), who are up for reelection in 2018.

Price faced criticism for his stock trading activities as a member of Congress, with reports suggesting he invested in health-related companies shortly before introducing or supporting legislation that benefited them. He denied any wrongdoing, stating that he made the investments through a broker. Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) called for Price to be disqualified for "basic ethics."

Despite the controversy, Republicans believe confirming Price is key to syncing up with the White House on the plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) hopes confirming Price will speed up the process, while Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) praised Price as the "right man" to lead the department, citing his understanding of healthcare policy as a practicing physician.

Title: Washington Gridlock: Obama and Boehner Fail to Reach Agreement on Sequester

Article:

The White House and Congress are at an impasse as the sequester, a series of automatic spending cuts, is set to take effect on Friday. President Barack Obama and House Speaker John Boehner have not spoken since Thursday, and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Boehner have not met since January 21. Despite the looming deadline, there is no sense of urgency to resolve the issue.

The sequester, which was designed to be a non-partisan solution to reduce the national debt, will cut $85 billion from the federal budget. Obama has called for closing tax loopholes to offset the cuts, while Boehner has proposed reducing spending and reforming the tax code. The Senate is expected to vote on a bill to increase taxes on high-income earners, but it is unlikely to pass the House.

The House is set to leave town on Friday, just as the cuts take effect, and neither side is willing to budge. Republicans are divided on the issue, with some supporting the sequester as a necessary step to reduce spending, while others see it as a threat to national security and economic growth.

Boehner has called for a comprehensive tax reform bill, which he believes will help create jobs and stimulate the economy. However, the bill is unlikely to pass the Senate, and the House is not willing to pass a separate bill to offset the sequester's effects.

The standoff highlights the deep divisions between the two parties, with neither side willing to compromise. The sequester's impact will be felt across the country, with cuts to defense, education, and other essential services. As the deadline approaches, it remains unclear whether a solution will be found to mitigate the effects of the sequester.

Title: Former Police Officer Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison for Shooting Unarmed Man in the Back

A federal judge in Charleston, South Carolina, sentenced former police officer Michael Slager to 20 years in prison on Thursday for shooting an unarmed black man, Walter Scott, in the back during a 2015 traffic stop. The decision came after Slager pleaded guilty to violating Scott's civil rights by using excessive force.

Slager, 36, was a patrolman in North Charleston when he pulled over Scott, a 50-year-old father of four, for a broken brake light on April 4, 2015. He claimed he opened fire because he felt threatened after Scott tried to take his stun gun during a struggle. However, a bystander's cellphone video of the shooting drew national attention to the case, renewing concerns about police treatment of minorities.

The footage was a centerpiece of the four-day sentence hearing, with both prosecutors and defense lawyers arguing it bolstered their cases. U.S. District Judge David Norton sided with the government, finding that Slager had committed second-degree murder and obstructed justice by lying to investigators about Scott trying to grab his Taser.

The judge rejected the defense argument that Slager was provoked or acted in the heat of passion. Scott's relatives and their lawyers called the punishment a historic moment for justice and urged law enforcement to rethink the use of deadly force.

Title: Romney's Response to Embassy Attacks Sparks Debate on Foreign Policy

The recent attacks on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya have added a foreign-policy crisis to the mix of issues dominating the 2012 election. Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's response to the attacks has drawn criticism from both the left and right, with some Republicans seeing an opportunity to paint President Obama as the heir to Jimmy Carter's perceived weakness on foreign policy.

Romney's statement condemning the attacks and criticizing the Obama administration's response has been met with criticism from Democrats, who argue that the Republican candidate is "shooting first and aiming later." President Obama himself took aim at Romney, saying that as president, one cannot act impulsively.

However, some Republicans have defended Romney's handling of the situation, arguing that his condemnation of the attacks was correct and timely. Analysts point to the difference between Obama's and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's statements, with Obama's statement appearing to equivocate on the issue.

The attacks on American diplomatic posts have added a new dimension to the election, with some Republicans drawing parallels to the Iranian hostage crisis that plagued Jimmy Carter's presidency. However, Democrats have rejected these comparisons, arguing that Obama's foreign policy record is strong and that the attacks are an isolated incident.

The debate highlights the importance of foreign policy in the 2012 election, with both sides vying for public opinion on the issue. As the campaign season continues, it remains to be seen how the public will respond to the latest developments and whether Romney's response to the attacks will have a lasting impact on the election.

Title: John Kerry's Surprising Success as Secretary of State

John Kerry, the United States Secretary of State, has defied expectations and achieved significant success in his first year in office. Despite inheriting a challenging international landscape and a reputation as a "dreamer" or "Don Quixote," Kerry has demonstrated creativity, tenacity, and the courage to stand up to leaders overseas and within the administration.

Kerry has built on the work of his predecessor, Hillary Clinton, to restore diplomacy as a central part of U.S. foreign policy. He has shown a willingness to take risks and has won widespread praise for his efforts. A senior Middle East diplomat described him as a "national treasure" for the United States, while another leader from the region praised his Israel-Palestine peace process as the "most remarkable effort I have seen in my lifetime."

Kerry's success is not limited to his diplomatic efforts. He has also been instrumental in shaping U.S. international priorities, moving away from a war footing in Iraq and Afghanistan and towards a more balanced approach that incorporates diplomacy and development. His tireless travel schedule, mastery of the facts, and force of personality have all contributed to his success.

However, Kerry's work is far from over. The success of his efforts will be determined by the outcome of the deals he has helped create, particularly in Iran, Syria, Israel-Palestine, and Iraq. The next year will be crucial in determining his legacy and that of the President he serves.

Title: Trump's Response to Coronavirus Raises Concerns Amid Growing Pandemic Risk

The Trump administration's handling of the coronavirus outbreak has sparked concerns about its preparedness and ability to respond effectively to the growing pandemic risk. While the virus is still under control within the United States, experts warn that a worsening of the situation could lead to a loss of public confidence in the administration.

At a recent press conference, President Trump emphasized the importance of treating the coronavirus like the flu, downplaying the likelihood of a widespread outbreak in the United States. However, public health officials, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), have warned that such an outbreak is likely. The same day, a new case of the virus was confirmed, which may have been transmitted locally, a key indicator of a potential pandemic.

The decision to put Vice President Mike Pence in charge of the administration's response to the virus was made just yesterday, with some officials expressing surprise and concern about the move. Pence is heavily involved in Trump's re-election campaign, which has raised questions about the potential for political considerations to influence the administration's response.

Sources close to the decision-making process indicate that Trump is concerned about the impact of the virus on the stock market, which may have influenced his upbeat statements about the situation. The president has also reportedly warned Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar to avoid criticizing China's response to the virus, saying "they have enough problems without you going out and saying they're not doing enough."

The administration's response to the coronavirus has been criticized for being slow and disjointed, with some experts warning that a lack of transparency and coordination could exacerbate the situation. As the pandemic risk continues to grow, the public will be watching closely to see how the administration responds and whether it can effectively mitigate the spread of the virus.

Title: NSA Intelligence Gathering Programs Revealed: Government Defends Surveillance Efforts Amidst Criticism

The National Security Agency (NSA) has been collecting phone records and data from major Internet companies, including Google and Facebook, as part of two secret intelligence-gathering programs. The programs, revealed by the Guardian and Washington Post, have sparked widespread criticism from civil liberties groups and concerns about privacy.

The first program, revealed by the Guardian, involves the collection of phone records from millions of Americans, while the second program, detailed by the Washington Post, allows the NSA to tap into major Internet companies to gather audio, video, and other data. A former senior NSA official confirmed that the program, code-named PRISM, began in 2007 and is used to identify suspicious individuals and track their online activities.

The government has defended the programs, with Director of National Intelligence James Clapper stating that the leaks are "reprehensible" and could harm national security. Clapper emphasized that the programs are subject to strict court-imposed restrictions and are used to prevent terrorist attacks.

The NSA has also pushed back against criticism, stating that the programs are subject to oversight by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, the Executive Branch, and Congress. The agency claims that the programs only target non-U.S. persons outside the United States and that the data collected is subject to strict procedures to ensure privacy and civil liberties are protected.

Several major Internet companies, including Google, Facebook, and Microsoft, have issued statements saying they only comply with legal requests for data and do not provide the government with direct access to their servers. The companies emphasize that they review all requests carefully and only provide information required by law.

The controversy has sparked a heated debate about the balance between national security and individual privacy. While some argue that the programs are necessary to prevent terrorist attacks, others believe that the government has overstepped its bounds and is infringing on citizens' rights.

Title: US Finds Itself Out of Sync with UN on Over Two-Thirds of Votes, Report Shows

The United States and the United Nations General Assembly were in alignment on only 31% of votes in 2018, according to a recent State Department report. This marks a decline from the final year of the Obama administration, when the two entities were in sync 41% of the time. The report highlights the growing disconnect between the US and the UN, with the US voting against 70% of assembly resolutions requiring a vote, more than any other UN member state.

The report also examined voting practices by the 15 members of the UN Security Council and 193 members of the General Assembly, comparing countries' voting records with the US. The analysis found that the US is diplomatically isolated on development and Israel-related resolutions, with the US and the UN General Assembly in alignment just 31% of the time.

The report identified the 10 countries most out of sync with the US, including Burundi, Syria, North Korea, Turkmenistan, Venezuela, Nicaragua, Niger, Cuba, and Iran. Afghanistan and Pakistan, which receive significant US aid, voted with the US only 19% and 15% of the time, respectively.

On the other hand, the US enjoys support from some allies, including Israel, Micronesia, Canada, Australia, Marshall Islands, Great Britain, Hungary, France, Poland, and the Czech Republic.

The report also noted that the US pays for more than a fifth of the UN budget, more than the next three highest donor nations combined. The US has pulled out of several UN institutions, including the Human Rights Council and UNESCO, and has withdrawn funding from the UN Palestinian refugee agency.

New UN Ambassador Kelly Craft has vowed to promote "strong American leadership" and has slammed anti-Israel bias at the UN, stating that it is "inexcusable" and that the US will "oppose all such efforts." Israel's Ambassador Danny Danon has also spoken out against anti-Israel bias, citing instances of progress and successes in recent years.

The report's findings are likely to be addressed by President Trump during his upcoming address to the General Assembly, where he is expected to discuss issues of value for money at the UN and the US's relationship with the organization.

Title: UK Police Criticize Leaks in Manchester Bombing Investigation, Intelligence Sharing Resumes

The National Police Chiefs' Council in the UK has condemned the unauthorized disclosure of potential evidence in the Manchester bombing investigation, calling it a breach of trust that undermines the investigation and the confidence of victims, witnesses, and their families. The disclosure has caused distress for families already suffering from their loss, according to Manchester's top police official, Chief Constable Ian Hopkins.

The criticism comes as the Manchester police had initially stopped sharing details of the investigation with American counterparts, but intelligence sharing has since resumed after new assurances from US President Donald Trump. Mark Rowley, an assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard and an officer on the Police Chiefs' Council, stated that the organization is now working closely with international partners, including those in the "Five Eyes" intelligence alliance, which includes the US, UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

The article also highlights the importance of responsible reporting on sensitive topics, such as terrorism, and the challenges faced by journalists in covering these stories. The author notes that the media has a responsibility to inform the public about the impact of terrorism on individuals, communities, and nations, while also acknowledging the risks faced by reporters in covering these stories.

In a separate development, the article discusses President Trump's views on leaks, which have varied depending on whether they benefit or harm him. During his presidential campaign, Trump praised WikiLeaks for releasing Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton campaign emails. However, since taking office, he has been frustrated by leaks from his own White House, which have led to the firing of his national security adviser, Michael Flynn, and the appointment of a special counsel to investigate his associates' ties with Russia.

Title: Missouri Governor Poised to Sign Restrictive Abortion Law, Part of Broader Effort to Challenge Roe v. Wade

Missouri's Republican Governor Mike Parson is expected to sign a bill into law as early as this week, banning most abortions in the state after the eighth week of pregnancy. This move is part of a wave of restrictions aimed at challenging the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision, which established a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy.
