The bill, approved by the Republican-controlled state legislature last week, would enact one of the most restrictive abortion bans in the United States, with no exceptions for cases of rape or incest. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has threatened to sue to block the law from taking effect.

Missouri is one of eight states where Republican-controlled legislatures have passed new restrictions on abortion this year. The most restrictive of these bills was signed into law in Alabama, banning abortion at all times and in almost all cases, with exceptions only for when the mother's life is in danger. The ACLU has already announced plans to sue to block Alabama's law from taking effect.

Other states that have passed new restrictions on abortion this year include Kentucky, Georgia, Utah, Mississippi, and Arkansas. Conservative lawmakers have been emboldened in their efforts to roll back Roe v. Wade by two judicial appointments by President Donald Trump, which have given conservatives a 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court.

The court has taken no action on appeals seeking to revive two abortion restrictions enacted in Indiana in 2016. The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments in the coming months on a Mississippi law banning abortion once a fetal heartbeat has been detected, and a federal appeals court has blocked a similar law in Kentucky from taking effect.

Abortion remains one of the most bitterly contested social issues in the United States, with opponents citing religious beliefs that fetuses deserve rights similar to those of infants, and abortion rights advocates arguing that the bans deprive women of equal rights and put those who seek to end a pregnancy at risk of seeking riskier, illegal methods.

Title: NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg Discusses Burden-Sharing and Defense Spending with Fox Business Network

NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg recently appeared on Fox Business Network's "Mornings with Maria" with host Maria Bartiromo, discussing the alliance's efforts to increase defense spending among its member countries. Stoltenberg emphasized the importance of fair burden-sharing within the NATO alliance, citing the rise of terrorism and the need for member countries to contribute more to the alliance.

According to Stoltenberg, President Trump's message about the need for European allies and Canada to spend more on defense has had an impact, with many countries increasing their defense spending. The NATO Secretary General stated that more allies now meet the 2% of GDP target, and the majority have plans in place to reach this goal by 2024.

The article also references a 2018 speech by President Trump, in which he expressed frustration about the disparity in financial contributions among NATO members. Trump emphasized that the alliance's commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defense is not being met by all member countries, and called for an increase to 4%.

A NATO press release from November 2019 shows that several countries have increased their defense spending to meet the 2% threshold since 2014. Countries such as Estonia, Romania, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland, and Bulgaria have already reached or exceeded the goal, while others like Turkey, France, and Norway are closing in. The United States still provides the most defense spending, with 3.42% of GDP.

Stoltenberg also highlighted the importance of increased defense spending, stating that it will allow NATO to invest in new capabilities, including advanced fighter aircraft, attack helicopters, missile defense, and surveillance drones. This increased spending will benefit both Europe and the United States, according to the NATO Secretary General.

Title: Virginia Delegate Introduces Bill Requiring AR-15 Owners to Obtain License

Article:

Delegate Mark Levine (D) has introduced a bill, HB 961, in the Virginia state legislature that would require owners of AR-15s and other "assault firearms" to obtain a license from the state. The bill defines an "assault firearm" as a semi-automatic center-fire rifle that expels single or multiple projectiles by action of an explosion of a combustible material with a fixed magazine capacity in excess of 10 rounds. Additionally, certain cosmetic traits, such as a folding or telescoping stock, a pistol grip that protrudes conspicuously beneath the action of the rifle, or a threaded barrel capable of accepting a silencer, would also classify a gun as an "assault firearm."

Under the proposed legislation, current owners of AR-15s and other "assault firearms" would have a grace period to acquire a license from the state. According to the bill's summary, individuals who legally own an assault firearm on July 1, 2020, may retain possession of the firearm after January 1, 2021, if they obtain a permit from the Department of State Police to possess the firearm in accordance with procedures established in the bill.

Title: The Gun Control Debate: A Fizzling Effort

The article discusses the decline in public support for stricter gun control laws in the United States, despite President Barack Obama's efforts to pass new legislation. After the Newtown, Conn. massacre, Obama pledged to "use whatever power this office holds" to pass new gun control laws. He held rallies, used children as props, and urged Congress to "join me in finishing the job" to pass stricter gun laws. However, recent polls suggest that public support for stricter gun laws has decreased, with support dropping from 57% to 47% according to CBS News, and from 52% to 43% according to CNN.

The article notes that the assault weapons ban and limit on magazine size have been rejected by Democrats in the Senate, and that the debate has shifted to increasing the reach of background checks. The article also criticizes President Obama for being "hopelessly detached as a legislative mechanic and ineffectual as a shaper of public opinion," suggesting that he did not consult with Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid or consider his experience with the National Rifle Association before making his pledge.

The article concludes by noting that 90% of Americans support universal background checks, and that even the NRA wants states to keep more complete records of who is forbidden from purchasing guns.

Title: GOP Debate: Fiorina Dominates, Paul and Rubio Stand Out, and Carson Fumbles

The second Republican presidential debate has concluded, featuring 11 candidates, including Carly Fiorina, who was promoted to the main stage after a change in CNN's eligibility criteria. The three-hour discussion covered a range of topics, including immigration, vaccinations, and foreign policy.

Fiorina made a strong impression, dominating the first third of the debate and showcasing her knowledge and qualifications on foreign policy. She also demonstrated her debating skills by seamlessly linking Iran and pro-life issues in a single response. When asked to respond to Donald Trump's "look at that face" comment, Fiorina took the high road, tactfully stating that "women all over this country heard very clearly what Mr. Trump said."

Other notable performances came from Senator Rand Paul (KY), who called out Governor Jeb Bush (FL) for his past marijuana use and reluctance to support medical or recreational marijuana legalization. Bush admitted to smoking marijuana, and an argument ensued over legalization.

Senator Marco Rubio (FL) had a solid performance, discussing the need for sensible immigration reform and a merit-based system. He highlighted the need to fix the legal immigration system, which "no longer works."

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie was more lively and focused than in the first debate, defending President Bush's invasion of Afghanistan and citing his family's personal experience on September 11, 2001, and his work as a prosecutor.

The most surprising moment came when Dr. Ben Carson and Donald Trump were asked to address Trump's claim that vaccines cause autism. Carson refused to condemn Trump's comments, instead opting for a lame joke. As a doctor, Carson could have easily dismissed Trump's claims, but instead chose not to engage.

Governors Jeb Bush and Scott Walker did not have any memorable lines, but their exchange defending George W. Bush's policies was a highlight.

Title: Emmy Awards See Lowest Ratings in History as Trump Bashing Dominates the Show

The 69th annual Emmy Awards, hosted by Stephen Colbert, have seen a significant decline in viewership, with an 8.2 overnight rating among metered market households, a 2.4% drop from the 2016 edition. This marks the lowest-rated Emmy telecast in history, with six of the 56 markets in Florida still reporting due to Hurricane Irma's impact. Despite the low ratings, Media Research Center vice president Dan Gainor believes the Emmys will continue to incorporate politics, as Hollywood seeks to "force politics into every single aspect of our lives."

The event saw Trump being attacked from Colbert's opening monologue to the end of the three-hour program. Alec Baldwin won an award for portraying Trump on "Saturday Night Live," using his speech to mock the president for not winning an Emmy during his time hosting "The Apprentice." Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer even made an appearance to poke fun at his tenure, sparking controversy among viewers.

Academy Awards prognosticator Steve Pond called the event "the most political Emmys show ever," stating that voters chose winners based on politics, opting for programs with a political agenda such as "The Handmaid's Tale" and "Atlanta" over less-polarizing shows like "Stranger Things." Media Research Center vice president Dan Gainor believes the Emmys celebrate shows that "almost no one either watches or cares about," with the only show honored that most people recognize being "Saturday Night Live."

The Emmys went head-to-head against NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which likely didn't help viewership. The awards have now hit new ratings lows for three straight years. Some viewers may want to enjoy the awards show as an escape from politics, or perhaps they simply don't agree with everything the Hollywood elite has to say.

Title: Senate Blocks Background Check Bill Despite Overwhelming Public Support

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook shootings, a bill to expand background checks on gun sales gained significant public support, with 9 out of 10 Americans backing the idea. However, the legislation failed to pass the Senate, with 54 senators supporting it but requiring 60 votes to overcome a filibuster. President Obama noted the disconnect between public opinion and legislative action, asking "The American people are trying to figure out how something with 90 percent support can't happen."

Several factors contribute to this disconnect. Firstly, senators represent specific geographical constituencies, which may diverge from national opinion. Gun control proposals often score well in national surveys but trigger strong resistance in the South and Mountain West, regions with relatively small populations but outsized influence in the Senate. Secondly, issue polls typically include non-voters, but politicians focus on actual voters, whose sentiments may differ. Thirdly, politicians prioritize the opinions of passionate minorities over indifferent majorities, as seen in the gun control debate.

The Newtown shootings were expected to increase support for gun control, but the timing worked against it. The tragedy occurred during Congress's focus on the fiscal cliff, followed by a relatively light work schedule. As a result, passions have cooled, and the issue has lost momentum. Additionally, presidents have limited ability to drive public opinion and mass political action, as seen in the past.

The article concludes that the system of government, designed by James Madison, is meant to prevent an automatic translation of public opinion into public policy, ensuring deliberation and minority rights. While political progressives are disappointed in the system, it has also allowed them to block conservative ideas popular with the general public. To succeed, advocates of stricter gun control measures must match the National Rifle Association's zeal, persistence, and organization.

Title: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg Drops Out of Democratic Presidential Race, Endorses Joe Biden

Billionaire media mogul Michael Bloomberg announced on Wednesday that he is dropping out of the Democratic presidential race, citing a lack of momentum and a desire to unite behind a single candidate to defeat President Trump. Bloomberg, who entered the race late and spent over $500 million on advertising, won only one contest, American Samoa, and secured four nominating delegates.

Bloomberg's decision to drop out comes after a disappointing performance on Super Tuesday, where he failed to win any of the major contests. He threw his support and fortune behind former Vice President Joe Biden, citing Biden's ability to defeat Trump. Bloomberg acknowledged that his presence on the ballot may have blunted Biden's surge, but believes that Biden has the best shot at defeating Trump.

Bloomberg's exit leaves only two major candidates remaining in the race: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii. Former candidates Pete Buttigieg and Amy Klobuchar have already endorsed Biden.

In a statement, Bloomberg praised Biden's commitment to issues such as gun safety, healthcare, climate change, and good jobs, and expressed his confidence in Biden's ability to defeat Trump. "I've known Joe for a very long time. I know his decency, his honesty, and his commitment to the issues that are so important to our country," Bloomberg said.

President Trump responded to Bloomberg's decision on Twitter, saying that Bloomberg "didn't have what it takes" and that he will now "pour money into Sleepy Joe's campaign, hoping to save face. It won't work!" Trump also predicted that Bloomberg will "fire" his campaign manager, Tim O'Brien, and other staff members who got him into the race.

Title: Justice Department Issues New Guidance on Enrolling Undocumented Immigrant Children in Public Schools

The United States Department of Justice has issued new guidance to public school districts, emphasizing their obligation to enroll children of undocumented immigrants without discrimination. Attorney General Eric Holder and Education Secretary Arne Duncan jointly released the updated guidance, which aims to ensure that schools meet their constitutional obligations to provide equal access to education.

The guidance is based on a 1982 Supreme Court decision, Plyler v. Doe, which established that children of undocumented immigrants have a right to a public education. The new guidelines update earlier guidance issued in 2011 and provide more flexibility for schools in accepting documents from parents, such as utility bills or leases, to prove a child's age and residence.

Some school districts have been challenged in the past, with some states and school boards attempting to deny education benefits to undocumented immigrants. However, courts have consistently ruled in favor of the children's right to education. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has reported that some schools still inquire into immigration status as part of the enrollment process, which can create barriers for undocumented children.

The Education Department's Office for Civil Rights has received 17 complaints related to enrollment policies since 2011, with complaints coming from multiple states. The Justice Department has also evaluated the enrollment policies of over 200 school districts in Georgia and helped resolve issues.

Attorney General Holder emphasized that public school districts have an obligation to enroll students regardless of immigration status and without discrimination. The guidance aims to ensure that schools do not create barriers for undocumented children and families, who are entitled to equal access to public education. The ACLU's Legislative Counsel, Joanne Lin, noted that school districts must adhere to the guidance and meet their constitutional obligations to ensure that no child is locked out of the schoolhouse door.

Title: Syria's "Red Line" Tested Again as Reports of Chemical Weapons Use Emerge

The Syrian government's use of chemical weapons has once again raised concerns, with reports emerging of a deadly attack near Damascus that could be the deadliest deployment of chemical weapons yet. The White House is urging the Syrian regime to allow a 20-member team of United Nations chemical weapons inspectors to examine the new sites, but the Syrian government has denied any involvement.

The reports of the attack, which killed potentially hundreds, come almost a year after President Obama's "red line" warning to the Syrian regime. The White House is still trying to confirm the reports independently, but the allegations pose a test for the embattled President Bashar Assad, who has denied any involvement.

The United Nations Security Council held an emergency session to call for a "thorough, impartial, and prompt investigation" of the charges against Syria. Russia and China approved the move, but blocked a proposal by the United States and its allies to issue a stronger statement on the incident.

The reports of the attack emerged almost a year to the day after President Obama issued his "red line" warning, saying he would ensure that Damascus would suffer "enormous consequences" if chemical weapons were used or even if they were being readied for deployment. The White House has not yet taken any concrete action in response to the latest allegations.

The Pentagon has expressed concerns about getting involved in the conflict, with General Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, writing a letter to a congressman saying that the Pentagon is opposed to even limited action in Syria because it is not certain it would be aiding those who support American interests.

Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are calling for some sort of intervention to stop the civil war, which has raged since 2011 and has killed more than 100,000 people, according to UN estimates. The Russian Foreign Ministry has suggested that the attack may have been a "provocation" by the rebels, according to a report by RT, a network that broadcasts Russian views.

The investigation is now in the hands of the UN team that arrived in Syria on Sunday, which will have to renegotiate with the Syrian government to gain access to the sites of the latest attack.

**Hospital Housekeepers and Maintenance Workers Overwhelmed by COVID-19 Pandemic**

Hospital housekeepers and maintenance workers are on the front lines of the battle against the novel coronavirus, working tirelessly to keep hospitals running smoothly. However, they are often overlooked and underprepared, lacking the medical training to know when and how to protect themselves from the virus.

According to Katina McDavis, a 43-year-old housekeeper at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, guidance from employers has been spotty, and she often has to rely on her own judgment to wear a surgical mask when cleaning. Two of her colleagues have tested positive for COVID-19, and she is concerned about her own risk.

Hospitals have protocols in place to keep housekeepers safe, but often drop the ball on communicating them, said Anne Igoe, vice president of the Service Employees International Union. For example, rooms with COVID-19 patients have been mistakenly labeled otherwise, leading housekeepers to enter with insufficient personal protective equipment (PPE).

A non-scientific poll by the Service Employees International Union showed that 75% of respondents, mostly housekeepers and nurse's assistants in Chicago and Indiana, have been told either they don't need PPE or must ask a nurse for it. However, maintenance workers and housekeepers say they often get conflicting messages when they ask what precautions are needed.

Some hospital janitors are refusing to take on certain tasks due to fear of contracting COVID-19. At Brookdale University Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, New York, a janitor handed patient Sylvia LeRoy a mop and asked her to clean her own room, according to LeRoy's sister, Shirley Licin.

To cope with the increased patient loads and demands, a number of hospitals are seeking to hire more housekeepers. Retaining those they hire is another matter. Angel Medrano, a recruiter of hospital housekeeping staff in the San Francisco Bay Area, said a hospital he works with tripled the number of housekeeping staff it required in March. Most of the people his firm has hired are African Americans or Hispanics who have lost their jobs cleaning hotels and offices.

However, around 20 people quit within the first couple of days on the job, mostly over concerns over PPE. The lack of N95 masks is a major concern, said the NYU Langone mechanic, who is so worried about getting infected that he is living apart from his wife and three-year-old son until the pandemic ends.

The pandemic has taken a toll on the mental health of many hospital workers, including Kimberly Hughes, a housekeeper at a Montana hospital, who has the chronic inflammatory lung disease COPD, leaving her at higher risk of complications from COVID-19. She is fearful of contracting the virus and feels that housekeepers are not being prioritized.

The pandemic has also affected the personal lives of hospital workers, including the NYU Langone mechanic, who is worried about how he will take care of his son if he gets sick. His son recently woke up to a nightmare that his mother was taken away in an ambulance.

Title: Trump Voters' Disconnect from Logic: A Complex Phenomenon

Article:

Former President Barack Obama's recent commencement speech at Rutgers University touched on the topic of anti-intellectualism in today's political debate, without explicitly mentioning Donald Trump or Trumpism. Obama emphasized the importance of facts, evidence, reason, and understanding of science in policy-making, criticizing a strain of anti-intellectualism that has become prevalent in the political discourse. He warned against ignorance or lack of knowledge being mistaken for challenging political correctness, and expressed concern about leaders who reject facts and experts.

The speech sparked questions about why Trump voters might be drawn to a candidate who has been criticized for his lack of intellectual rigor. According to an article by Patrik Jonsson of The Monitor, Trump supporters might be seeking a leader who embodies a sense of American exceptionalism and makes them feel that the country can regain its former glory. For them, Trump's unconventional approach and "telling it like it is" style might be more appealing than traditional political discourse.

Political scientists Eric Oliver and Wendy Rahn have identified a strong predictor of Trump voters as a disbelief in traditional sources of authority. This phenomenon is inherent in political populism, which emphasizes the power of the people over experts and institutions. Trump voters are more likely to distrust experts and mainstream sources of information, placing them on a different spectrum than Clinton supporters.

In the end, Trump voters may see themselves as the rational ones in the national political discussion, rather than Obama's Democrats. The complex phenomenon of Trump's appeal remains a topic of ongoing debate and analysis, with no easy answers or explanations.

Title: Ross Perot, Independent Presidential Candidate and Businessman, Dies at 89

Ross Perot, a billionaire businessman, philanthropist, and independent presidential candidate, has passed away at the age of 89, according to his family representative, James Fuller. Perot died after a five-month battle with leukemia.

Perot, who ran for president in 1992 and 1996, was known for his unconventional approach to politics and his commitment to supporting the military and veterans. He was a true American patriot and a man of rare vision, principle, and deep compassion, according to Fuller.

Perot's business career began in sales at IBM, where he excelled. He then founded his first company, Electronic Data Systems, with just $1,000 in savings in 1962. Over two decades later, he launched Perot Systems, which was acquired by Dell in 2009 for $3.9 billion.

As a presidential candidate, Perot ran on a platform of fiscal responsibility and protectionism, winning nearly 19% of the vote in the 1992 election, the biggest slice of the electorate for a third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt's Bull Moose Party in the 1912 election.

Perot was known for his quirks and lack of experience in establishment politics. He famously said, "I don't have any experience in running up a $4 trillion debt. I don't have any experience in gridlock government, where nobody takes responsibility for anything and everybody blames everybody else." He also famously referred to the shifting of U.S. jobs to Mexico as a "giant sucking sound."

Perot participated in all three presidential debates in the 1992 election and took a nontraditional campaign route by booking lengthy time slots on network television to lay out his political views. He was "certainly the most influential political force in the late 20th century from outside the regular party system," said Allan Lichtman, a distinguished professor of history at American University.

Perot was also a veteran and followed his service with a lifetime commitment to supporting U.S. veterans, especially during the Vietnam War. He was honored in 2009 by then-Veterans Affairs Secretary James Peake for his advocacy efforts.

Perot is survived by his wife, Margot, his five children, and 16 grandchildren.

Title: Democrats' Advantage Over Republicans Narrows Ahead of Midterm Elections

A recent CBS poll has revealed that the Democratic Party's advantage over the Republican Party has narrowed to just four points, according to a survey conducted shortly after the peak of the family separation crisis at the Southern border. The poll, which sampled 2,063 adults between June 21-22, 2018, and has a margin of error of 2.6 percent, shows that 36.4% of respondents want to see Republicans maintain control of Congress in 2018, while 40% prefer to see Democrats come out ahead on Election Day.

The poll also found that nearly 73% of Americans oppose the separation of families seeking illegal entry across the border as a form of deterrence. However, the results suggest that voters are compartmentalizing the issue, with many placing blame on the parents for bringing their children into the U.S. illegally. According to the poll, about half of voters believe parents are mostly to blame, rising to roughly eight in 10 among Republicans.

The poll also highlights the impact of gun control on the midterm elections. The Washington Post noted in a poll in April that the gap between support for the two parties in House races has narrowed considerably since the gun control debate became a raging issue after the Florida school shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in February. The poll found that nearly 40% of registered voters believe it is extremely important that political candidates share their views on gun control, with neither Democrats nor Republicans holding an advantage in support among the 42% of likely voters who want congressional candidates to share their views on the issue.

The poll also suggests that voters in Texas, Florida, and Arizona, all important states for Democrats in the midterms, believe Hispanic illegal and legal immigrants have had a negative effect on their lives. Nearly four in 10 say immigrants from Mexico and South America have made life worse, compared to a lower 33% among voters across the country. Republicans are particularly likely to say immigrants have negatively impacted their state.

Overall, the poll provides insight into the complex and nuanced views of American voters ahead of the midterm elections, highlighting the importance of issues such as family separation, gun control, and immigration in shaping voter opinions.

Title: Obama Faces Historic Challenge in Re-Election Bid

As the Democratic National Convention gets underway in Charlotte, North Carolina, President Barack Obama faces a historic challenge in his bid for re-election. No incumbent has ever been re-elected with unemployment rates as high as they are now, standing at 8.3%. The economic data makes it difficult for Obama to make the case that Americans are better off than they were four years ago.

Despite this, Obama has several key advantages in the race. Incumbency is a significant advantage, especially in a close and competitive race. Additionally, Obama has more room for error, as he only needs to win a few key states to secure the necessary 270 Electoral College votes. In contrast, his Republican opponent, Mitt Romney, needs to win several key states, including Florida and Ohio, and at least two of the three states of Virginia, North Carolina, and Wisconsin.

Demographically, Obama has a built-in edge in several key states, particularly among Latino voters, who have been a crucial demographic for the Democratic Party. New Mexico, which was once a swing state, is no longer considered a competitive battleground, and Nevada is a competitive toss-up despite its high unemployment rate and housing crisis.

The economy is the driving force behind the different 2012 map and mood. The unemployment rate in February 2009, Obama's first full month in office, was 8.3%, and it has remained at that level. The Romney campaign argues that this is proof that Obama's economic policies have failed, while the Obama team notes that unemployment hit 10% in October 2009 and argues that his policies are slowly helping to pull the economy out of a deep recession.

The Obama campaign's priority is to make the case that his approach is the better, fairer path to sustained recovery, targeting independents and conservative Democrats in battleground states. The president's convention speech will focus on this message, as well as re-energizing his 2008 base.

The convention will also feature appearances by key Democratic leaders, including Vice President Joe Biden, who will speak on the importance of the middle class. Additionally, the convention will look to the future, with ambitious next-generation prospects, such as Governors Martin O'Malley of Maryland and Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, and perhaps even a Cuomo, New York's governor, Andrew.

However, the convention will also serve as a reminder of the painful truth for the Democratic Party: President Obama is their undisputed leader, but the Obama presidency has been a time of deep Democratic decline, with losses in the Senate, House of Representatives, and governorships.

Title: Sarah Palin Sues The New York Times for Defamation Over Editorial Implying She Incited Giffords Shooting

Article:

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican politician, has filed a lawsuit against The New York Times, alleging defamation over an editorial published in June 2017 that implied she was responsible for inciting the 2011 shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabrielle Giffords. The editorial claimed there was a "clear" link between the shooting and a map Palin had created that placed crosshairs over districts that Republicans needed to flip in the 2012 election.

According to the lawsuit, Palin is seeking at least $75,000 in damages, claiming the editorial "exceeded the bounds of legality, decency, and civility" by publishing false and defamatory information. The lawsuit states that the paper knew the assertion was false but published it anyway, and that the paper's subsequent corrections and apologies were insufficient.

The editorial in question was published on June 14, 2017, and claimed that Palin's map, which featured crosshairs over certain congressional districts, was a "sickening pattern" of political incitement that led to the shooting. However, the lawsuit argues that there is no evidence to support this claim, and that the paper knew it was false.

The New York Times has since updated the editorial to include a correction stating that no link was established between political incitement and the 2011 shooting. The paper also made half-hearted Twitter apologies, but Palin's lawsuit claims these were insufficient.

The controversy surrounding the editorial has sparked debate and criticism from both sides, with some arguing that the paper's editorial was unfair and others saying that Palin's actions were irresponsible. The lawsuit is ongoing, and a court date has not been set.

Title: President Trump Announces "Second Step Act" to Focus on Successful Reentry and Reduce Unemployment for Americans with Past Criminal Records

President Trump held a celebratory event at the White House on Monday to commemorate the passage of the First Step Act, a bipartisan criminal justice reform bill approved in December. The president announced the introduction of the "Second Step Act," although he provided few details about its contents and timeline. The First Step Act aims to give prisoners who exhibit good behavior shorter sentences, particularly for nonviolent drug offenses, and reduce recidivism rates.

The president highlighted the bipartisan nature of the bill and its benefits, stating that over 16,000 inmates have enrolled in drug treatment programs since its signing. He also welcomed individuals who had been released earlier due to the First Step Act, including one individual who emphasized the need for a second step.

The First Step Act has garnered praise from both the left and the right for its goals. However, some critics have noted that the president's proposed budget requests only a fraction of the funding required to fully implement the legislation. The bill calls for $75 million in funding over five years, but the president's proposed budget provides only $14 million.

The First Step Act was propelled by Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner, along with nonprofit and other outside groups, despite opposition from some hard-right conservatives like Senator Tom Cotton. The event took place during a broader Prison Reform Summit, which aims to address issues related to criminal justice and reentry.

Title: The New York Times' Attempt to Whitewash Benghazi Falls Flat

The New York Times has published a 7,000-word article attempting to resurrect the Benghazi fairy tale, a story that has been widely discredited as a cover-up for Hillary Clinton's role in the 2012 Benghazi attacks. The article, written by David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief, is a meager attempt to provide new insights into the events surrounding the attacks, but ultimately falls flat.

The article focuses on the vase in the living room of the mother of one of the suspects, a detail that is hardly significant or newsworthy. The article also repeats the debunked claim that the attacks were not perpetrated by Islamic terrorists, but rather were a reaction to a YouTube video mocking the Prophet Muhammad. This narrative has been widely discredited, and even the White House was unable to find anyone to corroborate this claim.

The article's timing and length have sparked curiosity in Washington, with many wondering why it was published in the dead of news week. The story was quickly relegated to the back pages, replaced by more sensational and attention-grabbing headlines. The Drudge Report, a popular news aggregator, treated the story as a top story on Sunday morning, but it was quickly forgotten by Monday.

The article's publication has not impressed Congress, with Rep. Adam Schiff, a Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, complimenting the article for providing "valuable insights" but noting that it was "heavily reliant" on sources with a vested interest in the story.

The Benghazi attacks remain a stain on the Obama administration's legacy, and Hillary Clinton's involvement in the cover-up will continue to haunt her. The article's failure to provide new insights or shed light on the events surrounding the attacks only serves to reinforce the perception that the story is a political smokescreen designed to protect the Clintons' reputation.

Title: Over $600,000 Raised for Families of Men Who Defended Muslim Teenager on Train

A fundraising campaign has raised more than $600,000 (approximately £468,000) for the families of the three men who intervened to defend a Muslim teenager and her friend on a train in Portland, Oregon, on Friday. Taliesin Myrddin Namkai-Meche, 23, and Ricky John Best, 53, were killed, and Micah David-Cole Fletcher, 35, was severely injured after a man launched a verbal tirade against the teens, one of whom was wearing a hijab.

The 35-year-old suspect, who allegedly said "all Muslims should die" during the attack, is due to appear in court on Tuesday, charged with two counts of aggravated murder, attempted murder, intimidation, and being a felon in possession of a restricted weapon. The FBI is still investigating whether the suspect will face charges for hate crime.

Micah David-Cole Fletcher, who sustained a knife wound to his neck, is recovering in hospital. His mother said the injury was "a millimetre" from his jugular vein. He posted a picture from his hospital bed, alongside a poem, which included the line "I spat in the eye of hate and lived."

The three men have been hailed as "heroes" in their local community, with Destinee Mangum, the 16-year-old Muslim teenager who was traveling with her friend, expressing her gratitude. "I just want to say thank you to the people who put their life on the line for me, because they didn't even know me and they lost their lives because of me and my friend and the way we look," she said.

A vigil was held in memory of Namkai-Meche and Best, with close to 1,000 people attending. Tributes have also been paid by the city's mayor, Oregon Governor Kate Brown, and former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, who described their deaths as "heartbreaking."

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Pence Expected to Dominate, Kaine's Performance in Question

The upcoming vice presidential debate between Indiana Governor Mike Pence and Virginia Senator Tim Kaine is expected to be a one-sided affair, with Pence's impressive resume and strong performance on the campaign trail likely to overshadow Kaine's lackluster efforts. While Kaine has struggled to draw attention and has been criticized for his defense of Hillary Clinton's handling of classified information, Pence has been a net positive for the Trump campaign, reassuring voters that Trump will appoint competent leaders and be replaced by a capable individual if necessary.

The debate is expected to follow a similar pattern to previous vice presidential debates, with Kaine focusing on attacking Trump and reinforcing Clinton's talking points, while Pence will aim to appear presidential and reassure voters. The outcome of the debate is unlikely to change the trajectory of the election, but it could affect the momentum of the campaigns.

In the past, vice presidential debates have had a significant impact on the election. In 2008, Alaska Governor Sarah Palin's strong performance against Senator Joe Biden helped revitalize the McCain-Palin ticket, while in 2012, Vice President Joe Biden's strong showing against Representative Paul Ryan helped turn the election around for President Barack Obama.

The debate is also likely to bring attention to Hillary Clinton's health issues, which have been a topic of concern throughout the campaign. Trump has repeatedly questioned Clinton's judgment and fitness for office, and the debate could provide an opportunity for Pence to reinforce these concerns.

Overall, the vice presidential debate is expected to be a one-sided affair, with Pence's strong performance and impressive resume likely to dominate the discussion.

Title: Google News Study Finds Left-Leaning Bias in Search Results

A recent study conducted by AllSides, a media technology group, has analyzed the Google News homepage and found that its results are skewed towards left-leaning news sources. The study, which spanned two weeks, examined 123 individual measurements and found that 65% of the news links provided were from liberal sources, while only 16% were from conservative sources. This 4-to-1 ratio suggests a significant bias towards left-leaning news.

The study also found that left-wing news tended to be positioned at the top of the results, with right-wing news often appearing below the fold, 12 positions down. AllSides concluded that the numbers are "so significantly strong and consistent in favor of news media sources from the left that the overall conclusion of a leftward bias is well justified."

The study analyzed various news outlets, including ABC, Buzzfeed, CBS, CNN, NBC, NPR, Politico, Time, The Washington Post, The New York Times, The New Yorker, and Huffington Post, which were heavily favored. On the other hand, sites like Breitbart, The Blaze, The Daily Caller, Fox News, and the National Review were often below the fold. Even some news outlets considered to be in the center, such as NPR, Bloomberg, Al Jazeera, and BBC, were not immune to the bias.

The study found that 91% of the 123 measurements indicated a preference for news media with a left bias over sources with a right bias. Furthermore, 80% of the measurements preferred left-wing news over news from a center source.

AllSides CEO John Gable stated that the technology used in Google News "overly puts a spotlight on the most popular perspective, or the perspective that most fits you, and that cuts out other perspectives. It reduces an individual's ability to decide for themselves or know the whole story."

Google responded to the study, stating that the search engine is not used to set a political agenda and denied any bias towards a political ideology.

Title: Sanders to Emphasize Clinton's Superiority to Trump in Monday Address

Article:

The Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia is underway, with Senator Bernie Sanders set to deliver an address on Monday night. The Vermont senator will appear alongside First Lady Michelle Obama, as the party seeks to showcase unity and contrast with the Republican infighting in Cleveland. The convention got off to a rocky start, with Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz announcing her resignation on Sunday, following revelations of bias against Sanders during the primary contest with Hillary Clinton.

Despite the tension between the campaigns during the primary fight, Sanders has since swung behind Clinton, claiming he has moved the party's nominee to the left in a series of policy negotiations. According to Sanders' spokesman, Michael Briggs, the senator will emphasize that Clinton is "far superior" to Donald Trump on major issues such as economics, healthcare, education, and the environment.

In his speech, Sanders will also highlight the progressive platform, which includes agreements he reached with Clinton to expand healthcare access and make public colleges tuition-free for students from families with annual incomes up to $125,000. He will also criticize Trump for siding with the Koch brothers and echoing fossil fuel industry claims that climate change is a hoax, despite the scientific consensus on the issue.

Some Sanders supporters were in an angry mood over the DNC email revelations, and there was an ambivalent atmosphere at some events on Sunday evening. However, the Sanders campaign appeared satisfied with the outcome of a rules committee meeting on Saturday, which proposed a commission to reduce the number of superdelegates in primary contests.

Sanders will use his speech to flag ways in which supporters can continue pushing their agenda outside the mainstream. He will emphasize the need to continue the fight for economic, social, racial, and environmental justice, and will urge supporters to continue the "revolution" to transform America.

Title: FDA and CDC Delays in COVID-19 Testing Hampered Early Detection and Response

The United States is home to some of the world's most innovative biotech companies and university research laboratories, which should have given the country an advantage in detecting and monitoring emerging cases of COVID-19. However, according to a recent article by The New York Times, officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) hindered private and academic development of diagnostic tests, potentially delaying the early detection and response to the epidemic.

In January, Dr. Helen Chu, a Seattle infectious disease expert, had collected a large number of nasal swabs from local residents experiencing symptoms as part of a research project on flu. She proposed testing those samples for coronavirus infections, but the CDC told her that her lab could not test the samples unless her test was approved by the FDA. The FDA refused to approve Chu's test, citing that her lab was not certified as a clinical laboratory under regulations established by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, a process that could take months.

Meanwhile, the CDC required that public health officials could only use the diagnostic test designed by the agency, which was released on February 5. However, this test was found to be flawed. The CDC's insistence on a top-down centralized testing regime slowed down the process of disease detection as the infection rate was accelerating.

Frustrated, Chu and her colleagues began testing on February 25 without government approval. They almost immediately detected a coronavirus infection in a local teenager with no recent travel history. Chu warned local public health officials of her lab's finding, and the teenager's school was closed as a precaution. The diagnosis strongly suggested that the disease had been circulating throughout the western part of Washington for weeks. We now know that this is likely true.

The FDA and CDC did not commend Chu for her proactive approach. Instead, Washington state epidemiologist Scott Lindquist recalled, "What they said on that phone call very clearly was cease and desist to Helen Chu. Stop testing." On February 29, the FDA finally agreed to allow biotech companies and academic labs to develop and deploy new tests for the coronavirus that causes COVID-19.

The Seattle Flu Study illustrates how existing regulations and red tape, sometimes designed to protect privacy and health, have impeded the rapid rollout of testing nationally, while other countries have ramped up much earlier and faster. Faced with a public health emergency on a scale potentially not seen in a century, the United States has not responded nimbly. As a result, the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S. will likely be worse than it should have been due to red tape.

Title: Trump Administration Links DACA to Border Surge, Argues for Program's Invalidity

The Trump administration has filed new court documents, expanding on its justification for invalidating the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. In the memo, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen stated that the program's existence has sent a "wrong message" to would-be migrants, encouraging them to attempt to cross the border. Nielsen argued that the government must cancel DACA to fix this perceived issue.

The memo cites the surge of children and families on the border as evidence that the program has not been effective in deterring illegal immigration. Nielsen wrote that the government must project a clear and consistent message that it will enforce immigration laws against all categories of aliens, including those who are eligible for DACA.

The Trump administration's stance is in contrast to the views of California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, who has successfully argued that DACA recipients have built up a legal interest in the program and that it cannot be stripped away without the government going through the full process of notice and comment.

The memo also argues that DACA was always intended to be a temporary program, and that the Obama administration never intended for it to be a permanent solution. Nielsen stated that while Dreamers who apply for DACA are "sympathetic" figures, it is not enough reason for the administration to usurp powers that belong to Congress.

The Trump administration's stance on DACA has been met with criticism from judges and legal experts, who argue that the program has been beneficial for the economy and has allowed many young people to live and work in the United States without fear of deportation. The fate of the program remains uncertain, with several federal judges having ruled against the Trump administration's attempts to phase it out.

Title: Cuomo's Presidential Ambitions: A Rollercoaster Ride of Support and Skepticism

Governor Mario Cuomo's political career was marked by a series of ups and downs, with his popularity ratings fluctuating over the years. Despite his initial success, his popularity began to decline, leading state legislators to challenge him. Cuomo attributed this erosion of support to the way the media covered his response to presidential run rumors.

In 1990, Cuomo won a third term as governor, defeating his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, a financial consultant and economics adviser to presidents. However, his victory was not as convincing as his previous win against Mario O'Rourke four years prior. When he delivered his ninth State of the State address, Cuomo hinted at diminished ambitions for his next term, stating, "This is a wonderful year for raw truth. We don't have any money."

Despite his earlier denials, Cuomo flirted with the idea of running for president again in October 1991, saying he was "looking at" a potential candidacy. Many of his supporters grew skeptical of his intentions, viewing it as a ploy to revitalize his flagging political image. Ultimately, Cuomo announced in December 1991 that he would not be a presidential candidate.

In a later interview, Cuomo expressed frustration that no one took him at his word, stating that he would have run for president if Republicans had agreed to pass a budget. Cuomo's presidential ambitions were marked by a rollercoaster ride of support and skepticism, with his true intentions remaining unclear until the end.

Title: Experts Warn of Devastating Economic Consequences of COVID-19 Restrictions

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to widespread restrictions on travel, local movement, business activity, and work, with President Donald Trump expressing concerns that these measures could prove worse than the disease itself. Economists predict that the official response to the pandemic could lead to a downturn as bad as or worse than the Great Recession of 2008-09, which cost Americans an estimated $22 trillion.

Government agencies typically consider not only the number of deaths prevented but also the cost of doing so. A rough calculation based on the "value of a statistical life" suggests that the cost of COVID-19 deaths in the worst-case scenario would be around $13.6 trillion. However, if economic projections are correct, the cost of aggressive control measures will be substantially higher.

The true case fatality rate for COVID-19 is likely to be much lower than the rates suggested by official numbers, which include only confirmed cases. Assistant Secretary for Health Brett Giroir estimates that the overall mortality rate for COVID-19 is between 0.1% and 1%, while epidemiologist John Ioannidis calculates that reasonable estimates for the case fatality ratio in the general U.S. population vary from 0.05% to 1%.

The CDC's projection implies a COVID-19 CFR of 0.8%, near the high end of those ranges. However, this scenario implausibly assumes that voluntary measures to curtail the spread of COVID-19 have no impact on transmission. There is a great deal of uncertainty about these projections, and public officials may be erring on the side of caution. However, this approach ignores the potentially devastating impact of disrupting economic transactions, shutting down businesses, and depriving millions of people of their livelihoods.

Experts warn that if the CFR for COVID-19 is much lower than many people fear, "locking down the world with potentially tremendous social and financial consequences may be totally irrational." David Katz, founding director of the Yale-Griffin Prevention Research Center, favors a more carefully targeted approach that focuses on protecting the people who face the greatest risk, saying he is "deeply concerned that the social, economic, and public health consequences of this near-total meltdown of normal life...will be long-lasting and calamitous, possibly graver than the direct toll of the virus itself."

In settling on an appropriate response to COVID-19, there are no easy answers. However, wise policy starts by recognizing the trade-offs that politicians have been inclined to ignore.

Title: US Congress Close to Reaching Deal on $2 Trillion Coronavirus Economic Stimulus Package

The US Congress is reportedly close to reaching a deal on a $2 trillion coronavirus economic stimulus package, raising hopes that lawmakers can soon act to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi expressed optimism about the progress made in negotiations, with McConnell stating that the two sides are "on the five-yard line" and Pelosi saying that they are "very close."

The agreement would provide financial aid for Americans out of work due to the virus and help for struggling industries such as airlines. The package would also include oversight provisions for a $500 billion fund to aid hard-hit businesses, resolving a key sticking point.

The news sent Wall Street jumping, with the market reacting positively to the signs of progress in Washington. The coronavirus pandemic has had a devastating impact on the US economy, with over 550 deaths and over 43,800 cases reported in the country. The virus has also shuttered thousands of businesses, thrown millions out of work, and led state governors to order about 100 million people to stay at home.

The deal would be the third and largest stimulus package passed to address the crisis, following two previous packages worth $1.2 trillion and $800 billion. The package would need to be approved by both the Republican-majority Senate and Democratic-majority House, and signed by President Donald Trump.

While details of the emerging bipartisan bill are not yet available, it is expected to provide financial aid for Americans out of work due to the virus and help for struggling industries. The package would also include oversight provisions for a $500 billion fund to aid hard-hit businesses, resolving a key sticking point.

The coronavirus pandemic has had a significant impact on the US economy, with many Americans struggling to make ends meet. The stimulus package would provide much-needed relief to those affected and help the country recover from the economic downturn.

Title: House Republicans to Vote on Special Committee to Investigate Benghazi Attacks

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner announced the creation of a special committee to investigate the 2012 Benghazi attacks, which left a U.S. ambassador and three other Americans dead. The decision comes after a weeklong trip to the Middle East, during which Boehner experienced back pain and was forced to seek medical attention. The move is seen as a significant escalation in the standoff between Congress and the White House, with Boehner citing the lack of cooperation from the Obama administration as the reason for the special committee.

The decision marks a shift in Boehner's priorities, as he had previously focused on negotiating a budget-balancing fiscal deal with President Barack Obama. However, the release of emails obtained by Judicial Watch, a government watchdog group, under the Freedom of Information Act, has put pressure on the House to take action. The emails, which House panels had been unable to obtain despite issuing a subpoena, have raised concerns about the White House's cooperation with Congress.

The House will vote on a resolution to create the committee on Thursday, with Rep. Trey Gowdy, a South Carolina conservative, expected to serve as its chairman. The move has been met with mixed reactions, with some Republicans seeing it as a necessary step to hold the Obama administration accountable, while others view it as a political stunt.

Title: Trump Derangement Syndrome: A Real Phenomenon or a Political Smokescreen?

Article:

The article by David Limbaugh, a writer, author, and attorney, discusses the concept of Trump Derangement Syndrome (TDS), a term coined to describe the intense dislike and frustration many people feel towards President Trump. Limbaugh argues that TDS is a real phenomenon, citing an article by Paul Waldman of The American Prospect, which claims that Trump's presidency has led to a "contamination of our emotional lives" and a sense of dread, despair, and disillusionment.

Limbaugh counters Waldman's claims by pointing out that Democrats have been aggressively pursuing Trump since his candidacy, wasting taxpayer money and time on a "bogus case" of collusion with Russia. He also notes that the Democratic Party has not apologized for their actions and has instead moved on to new investigations, including the impeachment inquiry.

Limbaugh also disputes Waldman's assertion that Trump has made Americans feel dread and despair, arguing that Trump's policies have stimulated robust economic growth and invigorated patriotic instincts. He also criticizes Waldman's characterization of Trump's supporters as racist and cruel, stating that leftists are the ones who have been vicious and hateful towards Trump and his supporters.

The article concludes by stating that Trump has done nothing to harm the country, but has instead stood up for America and its values, and that his supporters are grateful for his efforts.

Title: Oregon Senate Republicans Absent from Session, Refusing to Vote on Cap-and-Trade Legislation

Oregon Senate Republicans have left the state, refusing to participate in the legislative session until June 30, in an effort to block the passage of a cap-and-trade bill. The bill, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 80% below 1990 levels by 2050, has been met with opposition from Republicans, who argue it would strangle economic growth and kill jobs.

According to Senate Republican Whip Dennis Linthicum, all 11 Senate Republicans have left Oregon, making them beyond the jurisdiction of state police. Their whereabouts remain unknown. Linthicum stated that the Republicans will "run out the clock" on the legislative session, citing the state budget being fine and funded until the end of June.

Democrats have accused the Republicans of playing hooky, posting a "wanted" sign with the names and photos of the Republican legislators, calling them "fugitives from justice (and their jobs)!" Oregon Senate President Peter Courtney has threatened to fine the Republicans $500 per day for each day they are absent and a quorum cannot be reached.

The cap-and-trade bill, known as H.B. 2020, would make Oregon the second state, after California, to implement such a program. The program would set a limit on greenhouse gas emissions and auction off pollution allowances to industries. Republicans argue that it would cost the average family of four at least $600 per year.

Senate Republicans have been vocal in their opposition to the bill, with Senator Herman Baertschiger stating that he would be willing to return to the session if the Democrats agreed to let the public decide by referring the bill to the ballot. However, Governor Kate Brown has refused this proposal.

The debate has sparked protests, with hundreds of people, including loggers and truckers, turning out to protest in Salem. The Oregon Democratic Party has accused the Republicans of hurting Oregonians across the state by refusing to show up for a vote.

Title: Jared Kushner Loses Top-Level Security Clearance, Will Use Lower-Level Access Instead

Article:

Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of President Donald Trump and a senior adviser to the White House, has lost his top-level security clearance, according to reports on Tuesday. Instead, he will begin using a lower-level clearance, known as a secret clearance, which restricts the amount of classified information he can access.

Kushner had held a top-secret clearance with access to Special Compartmented Information (TS/SCI), but will now be limited to a secret clearance, which is a lower level of clearance. The news comes ahead of a deadline by which the White House was asked to submit information about its clearance protocols to the House Oversight Committee.

The change in Kushner's clearance level was first reported by Politico. The reports come as questions continue to surround Kushner's role in the White House and his ability to access sensitive information. The Washington Post reported that foreign officials have discussed among themselves how they might be able to manipulate Kushner by taking advantage of his finances, business dealings, or his lack of experience in foreign policy and government.

Kushner will continue to work in his unpaid role as a senior adviser to Trump, despite the change in his clearance level. The decision was made by White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, who has been at odds with Kushner over access to the president and the nature of their jobs.

Kelly said in a statement that he would not comment on any one person's security clearance, but expressed confidence in Kushner's ability to continue performing his duties. "As I told Jared days ago, I have full confidence in his ability to continue performing his duties in his foreign policy portfolio, including overseeing our Israeli-Palestinian peace effort and serving as an integral part of our relationship with Mexico," Kelly said.

Kushner's attorney, Abbe Lowell, said that there is a backlog in the process for securing a permanent clearance, and that Kushner has done more than what is expected of him in this process. Lowell also noted that dozens of people at Kushner's level are experiencing delays in their clearance reviews, and that the current backlogs are being addressed.

Senator Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., criticized the decision, saying that Kushner's access to sensitive information should have been eliminated long ago. "Downgrading Jared Kushner's security clearance gives new meaning to the term 'overdue,'" Blumenthal said. "Kushner's access to highly sensitive, classified information should have been not just downgraded, but eliminated long ago."

The change in Kushner's clearance level comes as the White House continues to grapple with issues surrounding security and transparency. The resignation of former White House staff secretary Rob Porter had revealed that a number of people on staff had never received full, permanent clearances, meaning they were accessing national security and other secret information even after questions had been raised during background checks about their ability to qualify to do so.

Title: Arkansas Senate Votes to Override Veto of Abortion Restrictions

The Arkansas Senate has voted to override Governor Mike Beebe's veto of a bill that bans most abortions starting in the 20th week of pregnancy, as well as a separate measure that would outlaw the procedures in most cases beginning in the 12th week. The Republican-led Senate voted 19-14 along party lines to override the veto, with a simple majority required in each chamber.

The 20-week ban is based on the disputed claim that fetuses can feel pain by that point, while the 12-week bill is based on the argument that a fetus should be protected from abortion once its heartbeat can be detected during an abdominal ultrasound. The American Civil Liberties Union of Arkansas has already stated that it will challenge either bill if they become law, and opponents of the legislation are expected to seek an injunction barring enforcement of the new restrictions pending the outcome of the expected legal challenge.

Governor Beebe has expressed concerns over the constitutionality of the bills, stating that the 20-week ban contradicts the U.S. Supreme Court's 1976 Roe v. Wade decision, which legalized abortion until a fetus can viably survive outside of the womb, typically at 22-24 weeks. He has not indicated whether he will sign or veto the 12-week bill.

The near ban of abortions starting in the 20th week of pregnancy is similar to laws enacted in seven other states, while the 12-week bill is based on the argument that a fetus should be protected from abortion once its heartbeat can be detected during an abdominal ultrasound. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists has stated that it knows of no legitimate scientific information supporting the idea that a fetus experiences pain.

Title: Trump Continues to Criticize Ongoing Investigations, Claims Investigation Has Run Its Course

Article:

President Donald Trump has repeatedly expressed frustration with the ongoing investigations into his administration's alleged ties to Russia. According to sources, Trump has told associates and allies that the investigation has gone on for too long and that no evidence has been found to support the claims of collusion. He has also taken to social media to express his discontent, stating that the investigation is a "witch hunt" and that others are out to get him.

Trump's frustration with the investigation has been evident in his daily conversations with associates and allies, with some reporting that he has devoted much of his attention to the idea that the investigation has run its course. He has also been critical of the investigation's progress, stating that it has gone on for too long and that no evidence has been found to support the claims of collusion.

Trump's surrogates have also been pushing the idea that the investigation is biased and that special counsel Robert Mueller is not impartial. They have pointed out that Mueller hired people who contributed to Hillary Clinton, which they claim is a sign of bias. Trump's team has also been trying to discredit the investigation by claiming that it is a sham and that the FBI is biased.

It is worth noting that Trump's criticism of the investigation is not new, as he has been expressing his frustration with it for months. However, his recent comments and tweets suggest that he is becoming increasingly frustrated with the investigation and is trying to discredit it.

Title: House Majority Leader Eric Cantor Loses Primary Election to Professor Dave Brat in Virginia's 7th Congressional District

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, a Republican representative from Virginia's 7th Congressional District, has lost his primary election to Professor Dave Brat. The upset election was considered one of the biggest in recent history, according to elections expert Dave Wasserman. Cantor's campaign was expected to win comfortably, but Brat's anti-establishment message resonated with voters in the solidly Republican district.

Cantor outspent Brat by a significant margin, with a reported $993,000 to Brat's $76,000 in the last seven weeks leading up to the election. Despite this, Brat's campaign focused on issues such as the debt ceiling, government shutdown, and immigration reform, which proved to be effective in swaying voters.

The election outcome has significant implications for the Republican Party's stance on immigration reform, with some analysts suggesting that it may be difficult to pass any legislation in the near future. The election also highlights the growing discontent among some Republican voters with the party's leadership and the perceived lack of action on key issues.

The election was seen as a major upset, with many political experts and pundits left stunned by the outcome. The district is considered a safe Republican seat, and it is unclear at this time whether a Democratic candidate will emerge to challenge Brat in the general election.

Title: Train Accident in Western India Kills at Least 16 Migrant Workers

A freight train in Maharashtra, India, struck a group of migrant workers who were sleeping on the tracks, killing at least 16 people and injuring two others. The incident occurred on Friday, with the workers reportedly having walked all night and fallen asleep on the tracks. The railways ministry has ordered an inquiry into the incident, and the driver of the train attempted to stop but was unable to do so.

The migrant workers were returning to their villages in the neighboring state of Madhya Pradesh after losing their jobs in recent weeks due to the lockdown imposed to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. The lockdown has led to a significant disruption in public transportation, leaving many workers with no choice but to walk long distances to reach their destinations.

The opposition and activists have criticized the government for not providing adequate support to migrant workers, pointing out that planes have been arranged to bring back Indians from overseas while leaving migrant workers stranded in big cities with little food or cash. Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed his "anguish at the loss of lives" and assured that all possible assistance is being provided.

The Indian railway network is one of the largest in the world, carrying about 23 million passengers daily. Accidents are common, with most blamed on poor maintenance and human error. A 2012 government report described the loss of 15,000 passengers to rail accidents every year in India as a "massacre."

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Admits Affordable Care Act May Increase Health Insurance Premiums

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius has acknowledged that the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as ObamaCare, may increase health insurance premiums for some individuals. This admission comes as insurers prepare to release rates for plans that will take effect on January 1, 2014, when key provisions of the health law kick in.

According to Sebelius, some people purchasing new insurance policies this fall may see premiums rise due to requirements in the health-care law. The secretary noted that the law requires plans to provide better benefits and treat all customers equally, regardless of their medical claims. However, she emphasized that subsidies will be available for many lower-income Americans to help them with the cost of coverage.

The secretary's remarks are among the first direct statements from federal officials that people with "skimpy" health plans may face higher premiums for plans that are more generous. Sebelius stated that the law requires plans to provide better benefits and treat all customers equally, regardless of their medical claims.

The article also highlights a survey of over 600 doctors, which found that most physicians have a pessimistic outlook on the future of medicine, citing eroding autonomy and falling income. The survey found that six in 10 physicians believe many of their colleagues will retire earlier than planned in the next one to three years, and 55 percent believe others will scale back hours due to the changing nature of medicine.

The article also touches on the impact of the medical device tax in ObamaCare, which has led to layoffs and reduced investment in research and development at biomedical or medical device engineering firms.

Title: Canada Rejoins US and Mexico in Revamped North American Free Trade Deal

The United States, Canada, and Mexico have reached a revised agreement to replace the 24-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), just before a midnight deadline imposed by the US. The new deal, called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), aims to strengthen the middle class, create good jobs, and new opportunities for the nearly half-billion people who live in North America.

The agreement, reached on Sunday, gives US farmers greater access to the Canadian dairy market, while keeping a NAFTA dispute-resolution process and offering Canada protection if the US imposes tariffs on cars, trucks, and auto parts. The deal also maintains the current rules for goods and services trade between the three countries.

The US Trade Representative, Robert Lighthizer, and Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister, Chrystia Freeland, hailed the agreement as a "great deal" that will benefit the region. US President Donald Trump also praised the deal, saying it "solves the many deficiencies and mistakes in NAFTA" and will bring the three countries together in competition with the rest of the world.

The agreement was reached after weeks of high-pressure negotiations, with the US and Canada having previously been at odds over issues such as dairy market access and dispute-resolution mechanisms. The deal was officially notified to Congress on August 31, starting a 90-day clock for outgoing Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto to sign the pact before he leaves office on December 1.

Some lawmakers have expressed relief that Canada has been reinstated in the regional trading bloc, with Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch saying, "I am pleased that the Trump administration was able to strike a deal to modernize NAFTA with both Mexico and Canada."

Title: North Dakota Republicans Select Delegates for National Convention, Cruz Claims Majority

The North Dakota Republican Party has selected 25 national delegates to represent the state at the national convention in Cleveland. While the delegates are not bound to any particular candidate, Senator Ted Cruz claimed a majority of the delegates, with 18 of the 25 preferred delegates on his list. However, the delegates' loyalty remains uncertain, as they are free to make their own decisions at the national convention.

The delegates met on Sunday evening and selected State Party Chairman Kelly Armstrong as their chair, as well as Republican National Committeeman Curly Haugland and RNC Committeewoman Sandy Boehler to serve on the powerful convention rules committee. Party leaders, including Governor Jack Dalrymple, First Lady Betsy Dalrymple, Attorney General Wayne Stenehjem, and top party donors, also secured slots.

Some delegates who supported Cruz were adamant in their support, with Rick Becker, who ran for the Republican nomination for governor, stating he did not want to hold out for potential benefits or perks. "I'm just not interested in that," Becker said.

The Cruz campaign sought to portray the results as an unequivocal win, with Senator Cruz stating, "I'm thrilled to have the vote of confidence of Republican voters in North Dakota who delivered such a resounding victory today." However, the Ohio governor's campaign claimed a victory of sorts, with top strategist John Weaver tweeting that Cruz's "strong-arm tactics" failed in North Dakota.

The delegate selection process was marked by intense lobbying efforts from the Trump, Cruz, and Kasich campaigns. Former candidate Ben Carson rallied the state delegates for Trump, while Senator Cruz addressed the gathering on Saturday. The campaigns worked to identify supporters and set expectations, but the delegates' decisions will not be known until the national convention in Cleveland.

Title: Pentagon Cuts to Hit Military Personnel and Veterans Hard

The $85 billion in sequester cuts that went into effect at the beginning of the month will have a significant impact on military personnel and veterans. The cuts will affect programs that provide tuition assistance and support for homeless veterans, among others.

The Pentagon had warned that the sequester cuts would be catastrophic, and now it appears that the Defense Department is not the only federal agency with programs for servicemen and women that are vulnerable. The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) will cut funding for a program that helps homeless and formerly homeless veterans, which will affect around 100,000 Americans. The program provides state grants to help veterans get housing.

Active-duty military personnel will also feel the impact of the sequester. The Army has announced that it will no longer accept applications for its Tuition Assistance program, which provides up to $4,500 annually for soldiers to take courses towards high school and college diplomas. The Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard have also suspended their programs.

Pete Hegseth, CEO of Concerned Veterans for America, believes that Washington needs to examine its spending and cut waste, but notes that officials have gone after "low-hanging fruit" like military tuition assistance because special interest groups have protected big-ticket items like weapons systems.

Congress allowed the drastic, across-the-board cuts in 2011 after failing to reach a deal on a more measured approach to fixing Washington's fiscal problems. The cuts will equal roughly $1.2 trillion over 10 years.

The Department of Veterans Affairs is spared from the cuts, but cuts elsewhere in the federal budget will still affect veterans. The Labor Department's VETS job-training program will cut tens of thousands of veterans from receiving assistance, and a joint effort between HUD and the VA to provide housing vouchers for veterans may be affected due to HUD's concerns about local-level housing agencies not accepting the vouchers due to federal cuts.

The sequester cuts have sparked controversy, with some Americans complaining about the federal government's spending amid cuts to veterans and others, including $250 million in aid to Egypt and an essentially untouchable $400 billion program to build F-35 fighter jets before testing is complete.

Title: The Globalist's Trifecta: A Plan to Shape the World

The article discusses the concept of the "globalist's trifecta," which refers to the idea of building a borderless world based on the free flow of goods, people, and capital. The author, Jonette Christian, argues that this plan was sold to Congress by economists, academics, and business lobbies as a way to "make the economy grow." However, the author claims that the benefits of this plan have only gone to the 1% of the population, while the middle class has shrunk and wages for working Americans have stagnated.

The article also highlights the impact of immigration on Maine, stating that the state's population has grown by 81 million people, mostly due to immigration and the children of immigrants. The author argues that this growth has not brought economic benefits to the state, as wages for working Americans have not increased and good jobs have disappeared.

The article also criticizes the Partnership for the New American Economy, a coalition of billionaires, corporate CEOs, and politicians who advocate for increased immigration. The author claims that the partnership's data and studies are biased and lack transparency, and that they are trying to shape public opinion and influence politicians to support their agenda.

The article concludes by stating that Maine faces a demographic transition and that the state needs to think about its own needs and priorities. The author argues that employers should be required to offer livable wages to attract workers, rather than relying on foreign workers to fill the gap.

Title: Obama Leads Romney in Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin, but Advantage Shrinking
